Date: 7 January 2002

PG Six P.G. Six - Parlor Tricks And Porch Favorites

Label: Perhaps Transparent Records

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: midheaven mailorder

Cost: $12

great british-styled folk weirdness



Date: 7 January 2002

Tower Recordings - Furniture Music for Evening Shuttles

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: midheaven mailorder

Cost: $7

I like Tower Recordings but never found them to be the be-all, end-all; it's funny how they were like this mothership for later projects like P.G. Six, MV & EE, etc. but the actual records are really uneven. My view is coloured by my later perception of having seen MV in his stardom rise (at least rising to the king of a useless underground) and feeling like his hazy psych-wannabe style was rather disingenuous. But listening today, on a rainy and miserable day for me, this atmosphere really hits the spot. The songwriting has never been amazing in Tower Recordings, with P.G. Six the only conventionally talented songwriter and Valentine's compositions actually pretty terrible -- but this is more about the weird folky jams, built on abstractions and mood. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 7 January 2002

Refrigerator - How You Continue Dreaming

Label: Communion

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: midheaven mailorder

Cost: $7

I've always liked Refrigerator as a by-product of the whole Shrimper scene, but only in 2007 did I briefly become obsessed with them. This early album has some absolute masterpieces on it, still having the noisy edge before they hit the Glitter Jazz period. Even the throwaway material has something very beautiful about it. This is a band that is a secret. [13 Sept 2007]


Date: 7 January 2002

Black Dice / Erase Errata - Split

Label: Troubleman Unlimited

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: midheaven mailorder

Cost: $3.5

the erase errata LP was out of stock so this will have to suffice


Date: 18 January 2002

Source: Eric's car

Cost: $2

Date: 28 January 2002

Moondog - 

Label: 

Format: CD-R

Source: Daniel 

Cost: $0

Moondog RULES!


Date: 1 February 2002

Sunroof! - Bliss

Label: VHF Records

Format: 2xCD

Source: VHF

Cost: $12



Date: 1 February 2002

Simon Wickham-Smith - Extreme Bukake

Label: VHF

Format: CD

Source: VHF

Cost: $0

This is a less-than-thrilling Simon Wickham-Smith record, that once you get past the perverse title, offers little in the way of extreme or bukake. Simon's interest in devotional music is really clear from the get-go, as the first track is built around Hindu chanting over which a distorted drone slowly resolves itself. The second track is a tribute to the monk who self-immolated himself to protest the Vietnam war. It begins with a distorted sequenced beat and brings in more chanting in layers, which is quite moving. The last two tracks are one 38 minute piece, the first part of which continues the minimalist drone of the first two tracks, and the last incorporating more active, rustling recordings, also processed with distortion. This is an unusually dirty and aggressive record for SW-S, despite the vocal drones, because of how much harsh static saturates it. I guess that's what the title comes from. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 1 February 2002

V/A - Freak On!

Label: VHF

Format: CD-R Album

Source: VHF

Cost: $8

This CDr compilation puts together three of the leading artists from the UK's 'ecstatic drone' scene, which at the time of purchase I looked to with wide eyes, though in a few years I had met all these people and even played with some of them. Sunroof! is the opening and closing cut here, with two classic tracks, recorded in that typically raw style with clattering high pitched shaking, etc over the ringing sounds; some punchy guitar on 'Pink Horse Sweat', though it's a bit buried. Richard Youngs's track is the most minimal, being a quiet and pastoral series of ringing tones, from his more contemplative side. The live Vibracathedral track was recorded in Glasgow and by the end of it's 23 minutes it turns into full-on sturm und drang, with pounding floortoms and distorted electric guitars ringing out (Julian Bradley, I'd guess). The tribal monotony is epic, and poorly recorded of course, making the final Sunroof! track a beautiful comedown, 21 minutes of magical shimmer. [30 July 2012]


Date: 1 February 2002

Vibracathedral Orchestra - Dabbling With Gravity And Who You Are

Label: VHF Records

Format: CD

Source: VHF

Cost: $0



Date: 1 February 2002

Vibracathedral Orchestra - Hot Booty: Live 1999

Label: VHF Records

Format: CDr

Source: VHF

Cost: $8

A live CD-R of the classic lineup of Vibracathedral (Julian, Neil, Bridget, Adam and Mick) recorded at the peak of their greatness, I guess.  This is as to be expected - a long harmonius drone with various bells, more percussive elements, and other abstractions.  Not much Mick Flower guitar-shredding, but still good (or at least equivalent to everything else they released around this time).  Listening to this makes me somewhat nostalgic for the time in my life when I was involved in this scene (remotely from Glasgow, sure, but nonetheless I had a scene) even though I continually realise how much happier I've been since diversifying my activities.  I wonder how Bridget and Neil are doing these days? I pulled this out for something random to have on while coding and it did the job.  [2 November 2011]



Date: 8 February 2002

Label: Quarterstick Records

Format: CD

Source: Daron

Cost: $0

a classic. I already have this on vinyl.

Cost: $0

Date: 11 February 2002

Microwaves (((Microwaves))) - System 2

Date: 16 February 2002

Jefferson Airplane - Crown Of Creation

Label: RCA Victor

Format: Vinyl LP Album Stereo

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $5

Date: 16 February 2002

Michael Nesmith & The First National Band - Magnetic South

Label: RCA

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $5

Jerry was happy that I bought this. [2002] I've always been mildly interested in Mike Nesmith's solo country-rock records but now that I've had my country-rock renaissance of 2012, this really hits me. This is credited to Nesmith + the First National Band and it really has a great "band" feel. They play with poise, and the sound (on pre-Dynaflex RCA vinyl, thank God) is crisp, built around stunning slide guitar work by Red Rhodes. Opening cut 'Calico Girlfriend' suggests we're going to be in the same West Coast wardrobe as the Burrito Bros, but it's actually a bit more genre-rooted. Nesmith's songwriting is enamored by the classics, as his liner notes state, and he's not afraid to yodel (on 'Mama Nantucket') or open up a more sensitive side ('Joanne'). There's still some residue of the Monkees goofyness on the little interlude that closes side 1 and invites the listener to flip the record, but for the most part this is truly heartfelt. The cover of 'Beyond the Blue Horizon' that closes things is stunning, a master cap to what's a really solid record. One time I was in a bar in Boston and I saw a chubby bald dude in his 40s wearing a t-shirt with this record on it. I started talking to him, just because it seemed so random, and he got incredibly excited to talk about Mike Nesmith with me and asked me if I belonged to the fan club and I was in over my head. It's a lovely shade of blue, though, and I would totally wear this as a t-shirt. [29 December 2012]


Date: 19 February 2002

Shins - Oh, Inverted World

Label: Sub Pop Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ebay

Cost: $10.99

I'm glad I finally have this! It rules. [2002] Ah, this takes me back. A record which grew on me slowly a decade ago and I still pull out now and then. Never cared for their later stuff which always felt a bit overdone; this is one of those personal indie rock classics. Nothing special, sure, but some great songs. 'New Slang' used to be my jam though it's now associated forever with a McDonald's commercial; the more upbeat songs are the easy associations but the more subtle songs like 'Your Algebra' and 'Caring is Creepy' are the most impressive now. I remember the second album had a bunch of songs that sounded like carbon copies of the hits from this one - there was a second-rate 'New Slang', a second-rate 'Know Your Onion!', etc. This is a pretty short LP overall but it leaves me fulfilled. [26 December 2012]


Date: 23 February 2002

Areski and Brigitte Fontaine - L'Incendie

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $13

nice french folk stuff


Date: 23 February 2002

Henry Flynt - Graduation And Other New Country And Blues Music

Label: Ampersand

Format: CD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $14



Date: 23 February 2002

Joseph Jarman - As If Were the Seasons

Label: Delmark

Format: CD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $10

An early Joseph Jarman record on Delmark is music to my ears. The first half, 'As If It Were the Seasons'/'Song to Make the Sun Come Up' has the same open, playful approach to wide-eyed abstraction that is found in that Marion Brown LP I love so much. There's a lot of plinking and planking, bells, odd strings, and Sherri Scott's voice floating over everything. There's a warmth here, a summer day being celebrated, and Jarman's players have a great deal of freedom but they're locked in with a common mindset. And then it explodes on 'Song for Christopher', a tribute to the deceased pianist from Jarman's band. It's no doubt a sad tune, but it's constantly pushing ahead, restlessly, perhaps projecting grief through curiosity. It works itself into a frenzy before finally crashing to nothing and letting Scott's wail build a new construction over gongs, errant harp plucks and scraping songs. It cyclically links to the first half of the record, a nice touch by Jarman and a nice ending too. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 23 February 2002

Pierre Bastien - Mecanoid

Label: Rephlex

Format: CD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

really fucking cool!


Date: 23 February 2002

Sun City Girls - Carnival Folklore Resurrection Vol. 9/10: High Asia / Lo-Pacific

Label: Abduction

Format: 2xCD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

Another entry in the (once seemingly endless) Carnival Folklore Resurrection series, this is a double CD that, as the title indicates, deliberately apes Asian styles -- not unfamiliar territory for the Girls. There's a lot of fucking around on disc 1, High Asia - silly voices, inept stabs at non-Western instruments, and general madness. There's a strange indie-rock genre excursion in 'Old Glory's Fade' that sounds almost like an instrumental Silkworm track, and some spazzy insanity. Nothing is mindblowing but even the halfassed SCG has some charm, if you're a fan (I am). Disc two is a treat, though -- 40 minutes of Asian field recordings, mixed together from various sources, and primarily non-musical. You could call this sloppy ethnographic work, or a beautiful piece of music on its own, as it's punctuated throughout with shortwave radio recordings from Burma, making this an often-discordant pastiche. I forgot how great this was. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 23 February 2002

Gato Barbieri - In Search Of The Mystery

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $13

hot, but not too skronky


Date: 23 February 2002

Tuxedomoon - Half Mute

Label: International Deejay Gigolo Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $10

Tuxedomoon's first full-length is probably their strongest album, as it's positioned between their dark, edgy postpunk cool and the more synthetic 80s new wave direction to come. This was reissued by some hipster DJ label and it's easy to see why, as this sound definitely had descendants attaining popularity in the 00s. While some tracks sound remarkably dated ('59 to 1'), others eerie and exploratory ('Loneliness'). 'What Use?' is probably the hit here but the smaller tracks really resonate well. The violins and slight folk/ethnic tendencies are one of the more underrated aspects of Tuxedomoon and they're really evident here. [28 December 2012]


Date: 23 February 2002

V/A - Ethiopiques v. 10

Label: Buda Musique

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $0

basically free cause I got the hookup from caulen


Date: 27 February 2002

The Modey Lemon

Label: 

Format: CD

Source: Phil

Cost: $0

I think I left this in New England.


Date: 1 March 2002

Birdsongs Of The Mesozoic - Birdsongs Of The Mesozoic EP

Label: Ace Of Hearts Records

Format: Vinyl LP 12" EP

Source: Myopic Books, Providence

Cost: $3.5

Birdsongs of the Mesozoic are a band that I got into because I was way into Mission of Burma when I was 18, but also fancied myself a brainy, cerebral fan of classical-aspiring music. So when I found out that Swope and Miller did this on the side, my eyes lit up. I played piano and I liked smart instrumental indie rock stuff like Rachel's, and thus Birdsongs were like bread from heaven. There's a lot to like about them - the compositions are smart and dramatic, with some improvised guitar textures (see 'Drift', which has some freakout guitar by Swope) and a feeling that anyone could do this - it's not rocket science but it's aspirational and fits in nicely alongside other early 80s smartguy stuff like Rhys Chatham, Branca, etc. Roger Miller's piano playing has the same sweeping quality as the guy from Rip Rig and Panic/The Pop Group, but with a more mellow edge - maybe like the Pop Group crossed with the soundtrack to The Conversation. [16 July 2012]


Date: 1 March 2002

Pearls Before Swine - One Nation Underground

Label: ESP Disk

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Myopic Books, Providence

Cost: $3.5

I know it was over a decade ago when I bought this, but I really didn't need it - I already owned a reissue on 180g vinyl, I think issued by Base, and I only grabbed this because it was ESP original that only cost $3.50. One Nation Underground actually sounds pretty good on a beat-to-shit ESP original. I think Rapp was seen as a bit of a Dylan ripoff back in '67, and when you listen to 'Playmate' it's pretty hilarious, how overtly he's going for that vocal style. There's a lot more desperation here than Dylan ever did though, and Rapp is an accomplished songwriter on his own, so this deserves it's classic status. Lyrics on the back are only for three songs but one of them is 'Drop Out!', exclamation point incredibly important because it's an imperative, get it? I used to joke that "the 60s are the future to me", but in reality, I'm still aesthetically stuck somewhere between 1967 and 1981. I'm a man out of place here in Estonia, and my enjoyment of records like this makes me feel even more so. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 1 March 2002

Wire - Crazy Abouy Love

Label: Rough Trade

Format: 12" Vinyl EP

Source: Myopic Books, Providence

Cost: $5

I consider this among the original slate of Wire releases though it wasn't released until 1983 because it was recorded in '79/80 and finds the band at their most experimental. 'Crazy About Love' is a long moody piece with dual vocals by Newman and Gilbert, constructing almost a narrative that I can't quite follow and with strange repeated chants like "Where one is unable to take us ...". It feels almost like a studio construction in the dub style, perhaps with the drums being a loop or series of loops. It's long, and worth of it's own release as it wouldn't quite belong on 154. Saxophones, synthesisers, and various unidentifiable sounds pop up frequently and it's pretty impressive. The flip has two tracks, 'Second Length (Our Swimmer)' which is a sci-fi futurist version of 'Our Swimmer', which picks up the mood a great bit from 'Crazy About Love'; and 'Catapult 30' which is amazing proto-industrial scraping. I have to declare this to be "essential" (whatever that means) cause it furthers the brilliant path they blazed in such a short time; it's easy to forget how even more insane it gets with the post-154 releases, such as Document and Eyewitness. The cover of this was re-used for the Turns and Strokes record which is confusing since I file them side-by-side; side two is included on T&S but 'Crazy About Love' for some reason is not, making this necessary to own as well. [23 July 2012]


Date: 2 March 2002

Robert Ashley - Automatic Writing

Label: Lovely Music, Ltd.

Format: CD

Source: Other Music, Boston

Cost: $13.99

I bought this on CD and then later found the LP, but this is one worth having in two formats. Because for once I'll admit I'm glad to not have to flip the record here - Automatic Writing is a work best listened to in one sitting, the bizarre Tourettes-driven bit of weirdness that it is. My interest in Ashley is based primarily on this and 'In Sara, Mencken...' and the aesthetic approach here is so insanely bizarre that I don't know what to make of it. From the cover art, suggesting a cool evening palm tree vibe to the way you hear a neighbour's stereo through the 'wall' of this recording, it's unlike anything I've ever heard. I love it. There's bonus tracks here on this CD but they're fairly irrelevant. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 2 March 2002

Moondog

Label: Prestige

Format: CD

Source: Other Music, Boston

Cost: $7.99

The first Moondog release is a statement of purpose in 14 short tracks, detailing his unique musical vision. The Moondog rhythm is present throughout, and most tracks begin and end with it unaccompanied, making this an episodic work. The instrumention is generally light - very street-musiciany, with occasional vocals (the 45 perfect seconds of 'Trees Against the Sky' being a highlight). I love when the strings come in, making 'Surf Session' a favourite (which is also the longest track, and the one that most resembles Mr. Hardin's later release on Columbia under the same title as this). The closing track, 'Street Scene', is recorded there and mixes in street ambience, which is pretty great stuff for 1956. [4 Aug 2012]


Date: 2 March 2002

V/A - American Primitive Vol. I: Raw Pre-War Gospel (1926-36)

Label: Revenant

Format: CD Compilation

Source: Other Music, Boston

Cost: $13.99

I've always liked gospel music, despite being a strict non-believer myself. There's something I love about people singing with conviction, about anything really, even if it's bullshit. This pre-war gospel collection ticks all the right buttons - it's the definitive document of what Greil Marcus called the "old, weird America" after the Harry Smith collection, and admittedly, the tone of this is so fire and brimstone/apocalyptic that it actually gives the Smith set a run for its money. The 26 tracks here are all from ancient recordings, all between 1926 and 1936 but most being in the late '20s. Some of this is bouncy and fun, with group singing, like Blind Roosevelt Graves and his brother's 'I'll Be Rested', though another track by him, 'Woke Up This Morning With my Mind on Jesus' is fucking sinister. There's songs against drinking moonshine, death, and prayer, like it should be; it's all accentuated by recording artefacts as to be expected with this material: hiss, static, and dropouts. Some sound better than others, but I'm listening to this to feel ghosts of some lost Americana, so when the guitars and banjos sound less than triumphant, it contributes to that aesthetic I so completely fetishise. This is amazing and I should get volume 2. [1 Aug 2012]


Date: 2 March 2002

Globe Unity Orchestra - Globe Unity 67 & 70

Label: Atavistic

Format: CD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $12.99

Of all the Unheard Music Series releases (oh, how I miss being excited for these), this is a pretty essential one. Yeah, it's a giant ball of noise for large segments, but despite the staggering density there are some really fantastic parts. The first track in particular, which has three (!) drummers, gets into some real amazing back and forth shimmies. And there's some great tuba playing. This is a total 'who's who' of European improv greats from this time, and Schlippenbach leads it all (and is credited as "composer", though that is ridiculous). The recording is as good as possible with this many musicians all going apeshit, and I wish I had as many European free records from this time as I do American ones. [28 December 2012]


Date: 2 March 2002

Shepp, Archie - Blasé/Live at the Pan-African Festival 2xCD

Label: Charly

Format: 2xCD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $19.99



Date: 2 March 2002

Richard Youngs - May

Label: Jagjaguwar

Format: CD Album

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $11.99

I forgot about this one amongst the plethora of Richard Youngs releases, but this is a beautiful, stark record of nothing but voice and acoustic guitar. His fingerpicking style is tense, lending the songs a severity lacking in much acoustic singer-songwriter music. Of course, being Richard Youngs, there's a pastoral, inventive style to these, even if it's minimalist in form. I haven't heard these songs in so long - years and years - that they seemed totally new to me. And even though there's no surprises, there's a quality and presence that makes this one of his better solo albums, for sure. [22 August 2012]


Date: 2 March 2002

Simon Wickham-Smith / Richard Youngs - Ceaucescu

Label: Forced Exposure

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $8.99

This very early R!!!S!!! release is built around an epic title track and some songs, all drenched in thick drones, reverberating against themseles until the echo becomes almost infinite. The songs are great, but so wet in mix terms that the songs lose clarity, and the lyrics become buried, and what might become a classic is a bit hard to interface with. The opening cut, 'I Live in a Big City' is pretty much a classic anyway, and the others are warped and processed into something fairly industrial. 'Just Imagine' has an infectious rhythm and 'At Home' is schizophrenic despite its monotony. The majority of side 2 is dedicated to the title track, a mishmash of high and low experimentalism. But first we get the double vocal-led 'Two by Two' and 'A Song for the Spanish Anarchists', both of which are strange and wonderful. 'Ceacescu' is a mixture of moaning layered voice, an endless electronic vibration, and ecstatic cheap keyboards dancing around the mix. These guys have made so much music together over the years, but what amazes me is how much continually stands out as exemplary, and this is another great record. [13 August 2012]


Date: 2 March 2002

Messiean, Olivier - Quartet for the End of Time

Label: Angel

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $5.99

This much-heralded composition comes no doubt from it's circumstances of origin, which are amazing; but it's also a beautiful and sad elegy that ocupies the mid-century modernist soundworld almost perfectly. The harmonies and dissonances are balanced throughout and there are moments that are so stark and dour (such as the 'Abîme des oiseaux' movement, which is just bare clarinet mostly) that they are almost unequaled in their misery. 'Danse de la fureur' opens side two with some fanfare but there's a dark undercurrent to this. Whenever the piano ascends triumphantly, the cello and clarinet cut in with a reminder of the cycle of time, ever progressing, always winding towards darkness. In the end of time, Messiaen actually imagines a whole world of timbre through the spare choices; it's dazzling and unparalleled in 20th century music. [10 July 2012]


Date: 4 March 2002

Xiu Xiu - Knife Play

Label: Absolutely Kosher Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Absolutely Kosher

Cost: $10

So many of these old 2002 records I look at and think "Wow, has it been ten years already?" but with Knife Play it actually feels like it has been longer. Over the years I've come to really, really love this album, which I still find somewhat confounding despite it's familiarity. The electro-pulse tunes are kind of hit and miss, but Jamie Stewart excels when it comes to being delicate and fragile. Which is why, of post-Knife Play releases, nothing's ever quite done it for me apart from the more slow, acoustic tracks - 'Sad Pony Guerilla Girl' on their second album is probably the best thing they ever did. But here, the blueprint is set - absolutely warped teenage goth melodrama musique concrete noise-rock pop indie soul, and that's not even all of it. There's moments I still find spellbinding here, like the sloppy drum freakout at the end of 'Hives Hives', or the entirety of 'Dr. Troll' (the potential of which has never really been matched by anything I heard, save the abovementioned 'Sad Pony'). I wasn't ready for this in 2002 and maybe the world wasn't; it's odd that Xiu Xiu just ended up being a cult band, kind of, at least as far as I can tell (I've never really known any major fans, as it seems most people pick and choose from their discography like I do). This LP is still in pretty good shape, surprisingly, since it's packaged in a piece of newsprint. [5 Aug 2012]


Date: 4 March 2002

Mountain Goats - All Hail West Texas

Label: Emperor Jones

Format: CD

Source: Absolutely Kosher

Cost: $12

I'm a huge Mountain Goats fan, but my fandom only extends through Full Force Galesburg (a perfect, beautiful record that still brings me to my knees 15 years later). Everything after that is just all right, but it felt like a turning point - The Coroner's Gambit seemed a bit less intimate, and this one furthered my feelings. But actually, All Hail West Texas is a great accomplishment that's very much in the same vein as those early records I love so much. I guess I felt a bit of distance from Darnielle the narrator vs Darnielle himself -- those early songs, all the hundreds of 'Going to'/'Song for' format songs, all seemed like the ravings of a madman, and 100% true. I realise now that they were every bit as much characters as anything else, and that really, the record he did later about being abused is the most genuine Darnielle. At the same time, I think I want to believe in the 90's Darnielle as he presented himself, which is why I still find records like Sweden and Zopilote Machine not just great, but essential to my own adolescent development. At the time this came out, I thought it was okay, not amazing, but there are actually some incredible tunes here, and the whole record is done on the boombox, which is actually eulogised in the liner notes. I mean, this is at least as good as Nothing for Juice. 'Fault Lines' is among the greatest of the classic Darnielle narratives about love failing, and given what was going on with my life when this came out, it still really resonates. 'The Mess Inside' as well - this obsessive focus is something I feel is lacking from his recent work, and maybe that's another reason I don't listen as often. But yeah, this is actually pretty great. So I think I might need to extend my unequivocal fandom to 'all pre-4AD Mountain Goats' instead of stopping at Galesburg -- especially when I think about those great one-sided 12"s which came out after this.


Date: 4 March 2002

Extra Glenns - Martial Arts Weekend

Label: Absolutely Kosher

Format: CD Album

Source: Absolutely Kosher

Cost: $12

The Extra Glenns were a supergroup to me in the late 90s, though listening now that seems funny, because they're nothing more than Mountain Goats songs with Franklin Bruno playing some extra instrumentation overtop and doing backing vocals. But that's a good formula, and the early tricklings of Extra Glenns material, specifically 'I Hear the Planets' from the Shrimper Fantasy Band 7" and the great, great, great 'Infidelity' 7", suggested a sum greater than the parts. Now that it's been over a decade since Martial Arts Weekend came out (during which time not another peep has been heard from the Extra Glenns), I can say that this was a real disappointment. The songs are good enough - about on par as the All Hail West Texas-era material, with a few standouts ('Ultra Violet', 'Somebody Else's Parking Lot in Sebastopol') but nothing nearly as great as that almost-infallible run that Darnielle had between Beautiful Rat Sunset and Full Force Galesburg. There's a wonderful piano-based cover of Leonard Cohen's 'Memories' which is awesome, and maybe my overall favourite track, but otherwise the novelty of this (Darnielle + good production + other instruments) soon became the norm for the Mountain Goats over the next decade, which makes this seem less special in retrospect. While I still love the guy and pay attention to what he releases, nothing's really resonated with me since Galesburg, which of course came out when I was 17 -- so I am realising that the problem is really with me. Why not just release this as a Mountain Goats album? There's a bunch of 'Going to' songs (which were abandoned by the Mountain Goats around this time) and 'Malevolent Seascape Y', a sequel I guess to the masterpiece on the Extra Glenns 7", but the input of Bruno is largely wasted here. Or maybe it just shows whose ego is bigger. [25 July 2012]



Date: 6 March 2002

Crucial Unit/Municipal Waste - split LP

Label: 

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ian

Cost: $0

trading a microwaves CD for this


Date: 16 March 2002

V/A - Music of Peru 7: The Lima Highlands

Label: 

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $8



Date: 16 March 2002

Temple of Bon Matin - Cabin in the Sky

Label: Bulb

Format: LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $9

sounds pretty good. [2001] I saw Temple of Bon Matin at a crazy show in Lexington in 2003 or so, and if I only I had known what a privilege it had been, I might have appreciated it more. Actually I loved that show, but this record took me years to listen to again, as I often overlook it due to the lack of a spine. The crazy soup that is the Bon Matin is fully presented here, from the opening traditional "Muleskinner" which segues into the beautiful, distant "Shenadoah"; soon followed by the noisy, dirgy bashabout "Caledonia" (not a Cro-Magnon cover, or maybe it is). Ed Hardy's drumming is often the center though it's neither technically impressive nor even that rhythmically consistent. But he's th Svengali behind this collective and despite the variety, this is unmistakable with a consistent vision. The genres hop around - from outsider Americana to swinging free jazz ('Coloring Book' honestly sounds a bit like Cecil Taylor) to screaming helljams, but somehow it all works. On side two this melts together a bit into something uniquely wacked, with wet electric guitar solos akin to John McLaughlin, as well as Hasil Adkins-styled caterwauls. It's a really underrated record, much much better than I remember it -- it might be cool to see what they've been up to since. [28 December 2012]


Date: 16 March 2002

Kali Fasteau & Donald Garrett - Memoirs of a Dream

Label: Flying Note

Format: 2xCD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $12

This is the Sea Ensemble, one of ESP-Disk's most forgotten releases but one that I really cherish. Recorded in the mid 70's, the husband-and-wife team of Kali Fasteau and Don Garrett explore a variety of free melodies on all sorts of instruments. Disc 1 is a half-hour concert recorded in Holland and disc 2 is an hour recorded in Turkey. There's such a beautiful, organic language between these two that it sounds like one person and like many people at the same time. The reeds, strings, and numerous ethnic instruments are rotated constantly, and the live setting adds a lovely echo to things. The Turkish session was recorded badly so had noise reduction added which gives it a very strange, slightly malevolent vibe. Garrett speaks a bit at the beginning and the whole session, despite being light and airy, feels much more otherworldly. There's moments of piano playing that are wonderful and actually quite rooted in 'jazz', but for the most part it's more the free, flowing genre of human expression that Don Cherry's later work belongs to. The weird recording on the second disc makes some wow-and-flutter effects which give it a much more tripped out feel - some of the vocal glissandos on track 6, disc 2, are like an Henri Chopin recording, though with a spiritual, trance edge. This is such a mammoth blast of music to immerse oneself in, but it's genteel and provocative at the same time. [30 December 2012]


Date: 16 March 2002

V/A - Secret Museum Of Mankind Vol.1 Ethnic Music Classics: 1925-48

Label: Yazoo

Format: CD Compilation

Source: Paul's

Cost: $14



Date: 20 March 2002

Lennie Tristano & Buddy Defranco - Capitol Jazz Classics Vol. 14 Crosscurrents

Label: Capitol

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: eBay

Cost: $11.2

I bought this back when I was reading a lot about the history of free jazz, as two tracks by Tristano, 'Digression' and 'Intuition' are allegedly the first ever recordings of collectively improvised jazz. There's some debate amongst the historians - generally Ornette Coleman gets the flag, or Cecil Taylor - and since Tristano is white, there's a whole other dynamic here. Anyway, neither track is particularly impressive - it's fits in well with these two sides of 'cool' jazz, just a bit more loose. DeFranco's side is somewhat brassier as the band is bigger, but it works well with Tristano - it's a split LP that was chosen well. But ultimately these tracks are little more than a historical curiosity for me. [7 November 2012]


Date: 20 March 2002

Circle - Paris - Concert

Label: ECM Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: eBay

Cost: $8.5

The Circle 2xLP is a classic, and a lynchpin in the argument for "early ECM". These four musicans cover a lot of different ground over the four sides of this. Beginning with a Wayne Shorter composition, which is relatively feelgood, side two quickly delves into some bird-like call and response between Braxton and Chick Corea. Braxton's angular playing, choosing tonal sides that are somewhat at odds with the relatively smooth timbre, makes a really interesting counterpoint to Corea's piano playing. Holland and Altschul are solid as ever, Holland's solos are stunning and his compositions, the side-long 'Toy Room' gets quite explosive and free at points, and the 'Song for the Newborn' is the highlight of the whole record. Compared to the ARC record I have, this is night and day, and Braxton is only part of the reason. [31 October 2012]


Date: 23 March 2002

Yo La Tengo - And Then Nothing Turned Itself Inside-Out

Label: Matador

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: The Attic

Cost: $14.99

Great white music! This Yo La Tengo record was a thrill when it came out because it was so relaxed and sophisticated - only 'Cherry Chapstick' is fast and rocking, while the rest focuses on the mellow atmospheric sounds on songs like 'The Crying of Lot G' and 'Our Way to Fall'. There's energy buried deep inside, manifested through slow organ drones, tremelo, and other effects. When there is a more upbeat tune - 'Let's Save Tony Orlando's House', 'You Can Have It All' - there's a real resistance to make the walls-of-sound that created previous classics like 'Deeper into Movies' and 'Blue Line Swinger'. Maybe this is just the sound of people getting older, but I'm getting older too, and I loved this when I was 20 as well as now. And these aren't exactly ballads - just songs of twilight and contemplation. This is a wonderful double vinyl package, with side four dedicated in its entirety to 'Night Falls on Hoboken', a gentle folk-indie jam that closes out what is sadly the last truly great Yo La Tengo record. Their subsequent releases have all been great - it's hard to say anything truly bad about YLT - but the run from Painful to this one is just about perfect, so night falling is an appropriate metaphor. [26 July 2012]


Date: 23 March 2002

Blue Öyster Cult - Tyranny And Mutation

Label: Columbia

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: The Attic

Cost: $6

The BÖC's second album is a rocking affair; I have a soft spot for these first couple and this one is a confident step forward from the first one. The more psychedelic tinges are absent, replaced by a bar-rock edge. The 3D Worldrunner-style artwork is among the best album artwork of the era, and it adds an element of creepyness and mild occultism, evidenced in songs like 'Mistress of the Salmon Salt'. 'Wings Wetted Down' rules but '7 Screaming Diz-Busters' is the most aggro track from the whole first three albums, practically Black Sabbath in it's fire. Great all around. [11 December 2012]


Date: 23 March 2002

Paul Bley - Open, To Love

Label: ECM Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: eBay

Cost: $7.99

I love listening to solo piano records on vinyl.  This is one of my favourites in the genre, if not the definite favourite.  Bley is SUCH a downer - of the pieces, some are composed and some are improvised, and with lots of balance and hesistation in all the right places.  His piano has a weird, midrangey tone and on some songs it actually sounds like it's run through a flange effect.  There's a strong European tilt to his toneclouds, but in an Ingmar Bergman way more than a Micha Mengelberg one. This is wooly, melancholic, and almost disturbing in points.  [6 Aug 2011]


Date: 23 March 2002

Bob Mould - Workbook

Label: Virgin Records America, Inc.

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

I'm not that sure about Workbook. I remember listening to the two Mould solo records that came between Hüsker Dü and Sugar when I was younger, because I think i checked them out of the library. Black Sheets of Rain is a hard-edge noisy guitar record, and Workbook is the more 'sensitive' record, with lots of acoustic guitars strummed over big 80's drum production. It reminds me a ton of Warehouse: Songs and Stories, but without (I never thought I'd say it) the pleasure of Grant Hart's songs. 'Brasilia Crossed with Trenton' is a the most interesting lyric here, even if it's intoned over fairly drab accompaniment. 'See a Little Light' is probably the catchiest but overall this record sounds a lot like Toad the Wet Sprocket. [18 December 2012]


Date: 23 March 2002

Marion Brown - Afternoon Of A Georgia Faun

Label: ECM Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: eBay

Cost: $9.99

incredible! Thanks to Rob D for turning me on to this.


Date: 23 March 2002

Blue Öyster Cult - Secret Treaties

Label: Columbia

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: The Attic

Cost: $5

This is one I play quite often; if not quite as good as Tyranny and Mutation, I certainly play it more. There's such a great balance here - awesome riffs, rockstar posturing, fantastic songwriting - and just enough spooky mystery to build a legend. Too many excellent songs to point out specifically. 'Dominance and Submission', after all, is such a great and ridiculous song; but everything here is commendable - 'Subhuman', 'Career of Evil', and especially 'Flaming Telepaths'. I recently spun the Dictator's Go Girl Crazy which was produced by Sandy Pearlman too, around the same time, and I can hear a real similarity, especially with 'Cagey Cretins'. [27 July 2012]


Date: 23 March 2002

Blue Öyster Cult - Blue Öyster Cult

Label: CBS

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: The Attic

Cost: $6

The first BOC record has some great tunes on it - 'Cities on Flame with Rock and Roll', 'I'm on the Lamb But I Ain't No Sheep', 'Workshop of the Telescopes' - but they aren't quite there yet. The second and third albums transcend this, I'd say, as this relies a bit more on attitude than songwriting and performance. There's not a bad track, but it feels a bit like a novelty band, or a concept, at certain points. But I'm nitpicking - it's a great record, one that I view as the starting point of a brilliant trilogy. [24 August 2012]


Date: 23 March 2002

Richard & Linda Thompson - Shoot Out The Lights

Label: Hannibal Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

For what is (I think) their last record together, Richard and Linda put the nail in the coffin of their marriage, in the process making a great, dark record. Breaking up in public ain't easy, and the cover image should say a lot, with a desperate, despondent Richard staring ahead in a dark room, Linda only a photographic presence above him. The record actually feels more unified than that, with some hard-edged guitar work on the title track, the likes of which we haven't heard since 'Calvary Cross'. Linda's voice is beautiful as ever, with 'Walking on a Wire' being my pick of the album - a slow, delicate ballad built around uncertainty. The dramatics of 'Did She Jump or Was She Pushed?' are probably the most over-the-top moment but it works, for this is a record about sinking into the darkness, and all the false comfort that comes with it. [20 December 2012]


Date: 23 March 2002

V/A - African Songs and Rhythms for Children

Label: Folkways

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: eBay

Cost: $4.5

A lovely old Folkways release, this begins with a spoken introduction and then gives itself over to numerous recordings of singing, chanting, and the barest of instrumentation. Usually accompanied by just one drum, or just a wooden block or clicking sound, the voices here are deep and confident. It's split evenly between male and female vocals and it was recorded I think in New York, though it uses "real" Africans. It's primarily recordings from the Ewe and Ghanian traditions. Incidentally, this is the first record on my shelf as I file compilations first by title and this is alphabetically the first thing I have. [25 November 2012]


Date: 23 March 2002

V/A - The Jazz Loft Sessions

Label: Douglass Records

Format: CD Album

Source: eBay

Cost: $5



Date: 23 March 2002

Pylon - Chomp

Label: DB

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: The Attic

Cost: $10

I finally got this, but it's not nearly as good as Gyrate.


Date: 3 April 2002

Art Bears - Hopes And Fears

Label: Random Radar Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: eBay

Cost: $9.98

The first Art Bears album is perfect, but then isn't everything they did just about infallible? This is built around dark, moving songs with unbelievably beautiful lyrics, sung in Dagmar Krause's distinctive voice and with Frith and Cutler fucking about with songforms. There's some very strange chordal movements, with violins and keyboards and guitars and drums building something that sounds somehow ancient, yet furturistic. 'The Dance' is a good example of this - like something out of The Seventh Seal, with a dance that is medieval yet 20th century as you can imagine. 'In Two Minds' is utterly anthemic, the longest and most memorable song on the record, which thunders down in that Henry Cow way, but with a lighter elegance. Art Bears were a gamechanger for me - they illustrated the balance between political/social conviction and aesthetic innovation, something that I still struggle with all the time in everything I do. [18 August 2012]


Date: 6 April 2002

Jackie O Motherfucker - Liberation

Label: Road Cone

Format: CD

Source: Adam Strohm

Cost: $0



Date: 9 April 2002

Arthur Doyle - Sings and Plays from the Songbook

Label: Audible HIss

Format: CD Album

Source: eBay

Cost: $3.99

this is an insane record. Thank god I got it so cheap.


Date: 10 April 2002

Burning Star Core - AOS 2002 CD-R

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CD-R

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0



Date: 10 April 2002

Burning Star Core - A Brighter Summer Day

Label: Thin Wrist

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0

Spencer's first LP feels like so long ago, which I guess it was. At the time it was such a big deal for one of my friends to have a vinyl release, though I'm sure none of us had any idea how many more would follow this. I used to always see 'A Brighter Summer Day' as a perfect, thunderous summation of Spencer's organic one-man sound explosion. The rich violin and circular, rolling percussion is a great statement, at times recalling Tony Conrad or Angus MacLise's work in the late 60s. 'Baybe It Wasn't Meant To Me' on the B-side is an entirely different beast - a very rough collage that juxtaposes dense, swirling sound fragments with computer-processed synth, with very clean edits instead of fades. At the time I remember feeling that this was a somewhat lesser cut, but today's ears find a logic that eluded the younger me. [18 September 2012]


Date: 10 April 2002

Albert Ayler Trio - Spiritual Unity

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl LP Album Reissue Mono

Source: eBay

Cost: $8.5

utterly astounding. Glad to have this on 180g.


Date: 10 April 2002

Iovae - Quatervois

Label: DroneDisco

Format: CDr

Source: C.Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0



Date: 11 April 2002

Frank Wright Trio

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: eBay

Cost: $9.98

The lone Frank Wright Trio begins with a sprawling band improvisation that looks in every direction except the center. It feels lazy and unfocused - as free as anything else from the time, but substituting cunning for fire. The band keeps sidestepping each other, and the occasional flareup from Wright's sax bell keep it demanding the listener's attention. 'The Moon', 14 minutes across the second half, amps up the energy to the proper ESP level. Henry Grimes is miscredited on drums but actually I guess is the bass, and his weird sense of motion is as brilliant as on the Ayler albums, if Wright's sax isn't quite as thundering. It's overall a nice piece and the record is enjoyable, a bit of a different flavour, but nothing spectacular. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 19 April 2002

Pele - Realize It

Label: Crouton

Format: CD EP

Source: Crouton (promo)

Cost: $0

Pele are an interesting case, as they emerged from the 90s guitar-indie scene, with emo leanings, that produced the Promise Ring and a whole now-forgotten scene of bands I never liked. They were always a bit brainer and to be honest, I never really listened to them apart from a live concert in Pittsburgh on their last tour where they stayed at my house. I was already interested in drummer Jon Mueller and guitarist Chris Rosenau's other work, released on their Crouton label. I've since lost touch with that too, which is a shame, because they made a series of great, invigorating recordings of experimental music that I was way into ten years ago. This is possibly the last Pele release - a song called 'Realize It' which is instrumental guitar post-rock, crisp and bright like Directions in Music or something like that. The second track is a long workout, not the same theme but from probably the same recording session. It's very pleasant and has several movements, and it's a nice little EP swansong and oddly the only thing I really know by them. [30 December 2012]


Date: 19 April 2002

Telecognac - Memory

Label: Crouton

Format: CD Album Limited Edition

Source: Crouton (wholesale)

Cost: $8

I am only going to list distro CDs that I buy myself from my own distro.


Date: 19 April 2002

Jarboe / Telecognac - Over

Label: Crouton

Format: CD EP Limited Edition

Source: Crouton (promo)

Cost: $0

Over is built around a song called 'Under' by Jarboe, processed and manipulated by Telecognac, a group consisting of Chris Rosenau and Jon Mueller that I really liked about twelve years ago. Telecognac released one incredible CD called Memory and those guys also played in Pele and Collections of Colonies of Bees - for a short time I was really actively following the Crouton label, and they crashed at my place in Pittsburgh on the last Pele tour though I barely remember anything about them now. This CD continues their excellent approach to cut-up yet organic experimentalism, using piano, guitars, and drums through a very digital treatment  (there's a part on track 1 that just sounds like Jarboe's voice being skipped around on a CD, which is actually mesmerising). These guys really found a niche that pushed open areas of pure sound candy beauty, with elements of nostalgia and warm, earthy repetitions. The third track is haphazard, sounding like it's never quite getting going, and the low point though still well-constructed. Jarboe was surely a willing participant though she is only a distant presence; I wish this was longer, actually. [1 October 2012]


Date: 19 April 2002

Aranos / Jon Mueller / Chris Rosenau - Bleeding In Behind Pastel Screens

Label: Crouton

Format: CD

Source: Crouton (wholesale)

Cost: $8



Date: 20 April 2002

Crucial Unit - Moshzilla

Label: De La Mente

Format: 7" EP

Source: Mike Bolam

Cost: $0

mike gave this to me so I didn't have to buy it. On red vinyl!!


Date: 22 April 2002

Brian Lavelle & Richard Youngs - Radios 2

Label: Freek Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Dave's music mine

Cost: $6.41

it was in the "jazz" section.


Date: 23 April 2002

Mountain Goats - Protein Source of the Future ...Now!

Label: 3 Beads of Sweat

Format: CD

Source: 3 Beads of Sweat

Cost: $10

The first of Ajax/3BOS's compilations of early, essential Mountain Goats 7"s, compilation tracks, and cassettes is pretty indispensible to me. I have a bunch of these tracks anyway, which is why they feel so familiar to me - I can't listen to 'Night of the Mules' without beginning to tap along and sing the words I've listened to for so many years. The first 3 proper cassettes have been left off these - Taboo VII , which Darnielle opposed the release of for years (and for pretty good reason), and then the amazing Hound Chronicles and Hot Garden Stomp, which thankfully I own anyway on Shrimper originals -- so these compilations essentially completed my Mountain Goats collection in terms of physical media in one fell swoop, with the one exception of Nothing for Juice which I'll pick up eventually. It's hard for me to write anything critical about these songs - there's tons of them (and two more discs after this) and they generally revolve around the same obsessions and are musically uninventive. But this was a religion for me, founded through this material which I hunted down like a rabid fanboy, aged 16, convinced that this secret world of bedroom troubadours would light my path to salvation. Many favourites here I have played and replayed over the years - 'Love Cuts the Strings', 'Alphabetizing', 'Duke Ellington' -- and then there are gems such as 'The Window Song' and the entire Yam, The King of Crops cassette which I had never previously heard. [13 August 2012]



Date: 23 April 2002

Mountain Goats - Bitter Melon Farm

Label: 3 Beads of Sweat

Format: CD

Source: 3 Beads of Sweat

Cost: $10

Mountain Goats early works compilation volume 2 proceeds through the same unimpeachable territory as the first one, though I think this volume most deals with material I'm not familiar with - only three 7" singles from this CD appear in my record accumulation and two of those are compilations (though 'Song for an Old Friend' from The Wheel Method is incredible). The Transmissions to Horace cassette is probably the earliest material on here, which I had never heard before, and it's a brilliant work, beginning with 'Going to Cleveland'' and getting into 'Going to Monaco's' rant about standing on the sand six inches away ... these songs are easy to parody, but they came from a place so genuine and fruitful that I will always love them. 'No, I Can't' appears in two different forms as does the cover of Ace of Base's 'The Sign'. [22 August 2012]


Date: 23 April 2002

Mountain Goats - Ghana

Label: 3 Beads of Sweat

Format: CD Album

Source: 3 Beads of Sweat

Cost: $10



Date: 26 April 2002

Microphones - "The Glow" Pt. 2

Label: K

Format: 2xVinyl Album LP

Source: Cenotaph distro

Cost: $7.5

I forgot about this album. I also forget that Phil Elvrum exists. Every few years I think about him and about how much I enjoyed this, and then I forget that I even own it. I've heard various Mount Eerie releases over the years and also thought they were fantastic. Why am I not a massive fan? I'm going to explore what I've been missing - there's a decade of surely brilliant music he's made that I haven't paid any attention to and that's not for any reason except that my mind gets cluttered. This record is such a masterpiece - it's long but satisfying. It packs in a zillion ideas but keeps an approachable honesty that really recalls the same influences I had, especially at the time. It's all done so artfully, with a beautiful recording style, addictive hooks, and a somber, delicate tone through everything. Listening now for the first time in years I'm remembering a bunch of songs that I used to know intimately - it's a familiar, inspiring old friend. [23 August 2012]


Date: 30 April 2002

Vibracathedral String Band/Drum Troupe - split 7"

Label: Freedom From

Format: 7"

Source: Adam Strohm

Cost: $0

he didn't want this so he gave it to me. It's good!


Date: 4 May 2002

Art Ensemble Of Chicago - Certain Blacks

Label: Inner City Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: eBay

Cost: $8.47

okay.


Date: 4 May 2002

Alan Price - "O Lucky Man!" OST

Label: Warner Bros.

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

so bizarre that this was just sitting right after I watched the mick travis trilogy.


Date: 4 May 2002

Rotary Connection  - Peace

Label: Green Line Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album Reissue

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $3

I didn't realize this was a christmas album. Beat to hell. 


Date: 4 May 2002

Ian Dury And The Blockheads - Do It Yourself

Label: Stiff Records

Format: LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $3

The followup to New Boots and Panties is a really tight, almost disco-influenced pub-rock album. The band is crisp, a slave to the rhythm, and adorned with saxophone solos and waka-chika guitars. Over all of this, Dury's bizarre cockney voice wails away, appearing as an amusing affront to the music. Ironic to call it Do It Yourself when it's heavily produced, or maybe this was a tongue-in-cheek reference to Desperate Bicycles and all that stuff going on at the same time? The songs are pretty good, though when Dury tries to get more emotional ('Don't Ask Me' being a good example) it falls a bit flat. Overall it's a step back from New Boots and Panties, an album I thought I owned but I apparently lost along the way, but there are a few songs I really like - the less dancebeat ones, such as 'This Is What We Find' and 'Sink My Boats'. [30 July 2012]


Date: 4 May 2002

Rolling Stones - 12X5

Label: London Records

Format: Vinyl LP Reissue

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

not too hot, actually.


Date: 4 May 2002

Byron Allen Trio

Label: ESP

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $6

ESP vinyl at Jerry's!


Date: 6 May 2002

Volcano The Bear - Guess The Birds

Label: Beta-lactam Ring Records

Format: Vinyl 10"

Source: Cenotaph distro

Cost: $6

Side A is a very ethereal, echoey drone with hand percussion and wordless vocals rising and falling. It's a cult-like trance, a far cry from the more overtly surreal sounds on other VtB stuff of this time, and much more showing their influences of the Third Ear Band and artists like that. The B-side begins in the same vein, though a bit more active (but just as straight-ahead in terms of rhythm). Acoustic strings are plucked and bowed, and when the second track, 'All the Paint I can Breathe' comes in, we're suddenly cast into a nightmarish 50's sci-fi freak zone. It's one of the more compelling tracks in the VtB canon and the highlight of the record for sure. The closing track is actually called 'Volcano the Bear' and it's like a summation of all the previous tracks. [9 November 2012]


Date: 12 May 2002

Orrin DeForest / Jazzfinger - Untitled

Label: Traqueto

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Traqeuto distro

Cost: $6

a trade for a microwaves disc.


Date: 13 May 2002

Arco Flute Foundation - Everything After The Bomb Is Sci-Fi

Label: Cenotaph Audio

Format: CD

Source: Cenotaph

Cost: $0

It's really growing on me. In fact, I think it's fantastic.


Date: 15 May 2002

Confusional Quartet

Label: Elica

Format: CD Album

Source: Aquarius Records

Cost: $15.98

I ordered this semi-randomly because the description sounded intriguing and it's become a familiar presence over the years. Confusional Quartet were an Italian progressive rock band that bled into new-wave territory - their output was from 1980-81 and thus reflected the more aggressive elements of punk, yet still with an extremely musical angle. This certainly descends from fast and furious riffs like you'd hear on an Area record, but with production techniques that are closer to American punk. Though instrumental, 'Bologna Rock' could be a Mission of Burma tune, or even something by the Embarassment. But there's also a mad, edgy intensity throughout that leads me to think of them as being influenced by Futurism. Which is probably just a quick and easy assumption because they are Italians. The synthesisers are key here, often the lead instrument, over scraggly guitars. It's not as confusing as their name would indicate but it's definitely good. [18 September 2012]


Date: 15 May 2002

Neil Campbell / Richard Youngs - How The Garden Is

Label: HP Cycle Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album Limited Edition

Source: Aquarius Records

Cost: $12.98

a bit disappointing. I have too many richard youngs records.


Date: 15 May 2002

La Societe Des Timides a la Parade Des Oiseaux - 86-90 CD

Label: Beta-Lactam

Format: CD

Source: Cenotaph distro

Cost: $7



Date: 15 May 2002

V/A - Rembetika: Songs of the Greek Underground 1925-1947

Label: Trikont

Format: 2xCD

Source: Aquarius Records

Cost: $19.98

This set collects rembetika music, a genre of Greek folk music that chronicles drug addiction, homelessness, disease, suicide, and other such topics. I've always loved the contrast between the cheerfulness of the bouzoukis and the dour nature of the lyrics here, though without a grasp of the language I'm certainly missing out on the best part. Though I don't actually understand them, being in Greek, and the liner notes are mostly in German, there are excerpts of lyrics in the back in English and brief summaries of the topics covered. Some of which translate just great: 'Mama, I've got TB / I've got a lot of TB....' I don't love rembetika music because of a fetish for transgressive content specifically; it's really that I enjoy the overall aesthetic of these tunes, which sound dirty, raw, and sun-drenched. Plus, I like Greek music in general, but often find it over-recorded or too formal - which this is most certainly not. The instrumentals are fantastic and have that rembetika style. Some of the fingerpicking is dazzlingly rapid, but sounds lazy and tossed off, a vibe I get from Rick Bishop's playing sometimes. Here's it's often fast and slow at the same time. With two stuffed discs, this is a lot to taken in, and I usually only listen to one at a time - without any grasp on the language I admit they start to blend together. But it's a great set overall; Trikont is a pretty great label for things like this. [1 Aug 2012]


Date: 15 May 2002

V/A - Music! The Berlin Phonogramm Archiv 1900-2000

Label: Wergo

Format: 4xCD box

Source: Aquarius Records

Cost: $55



Date: 18 May 2002

V/A - Japanese Shakuhaci cassette

Label: 

Format: Cassette

Source: yard sale

Cost: $0.05



Date: 20 May 2002

Girl Talk - Secret Diary

Label: Illegal Art

Format: CD

Source: fakejazz

Cost: $0



Date: 20 May 2002

Nagisa Nite Nagisa Ni Te - Feel

Label: Jagjaguwar

Format: CD Album Reissue

Source: fakejazz

Cost: $0

Never got into this band. Sold.


Date: 20 May 2002

Andrew Hill - Judgment!

Label: Blue Note

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: ebay

Cost: $10

Another tight, crisp Andrew Hill record that unfortunately does not have Dolphy on it or any brass, actually. Elvin Jones does his thing, providing a warm, supportive bed of rhythm especially on cuts like 'Flea Flop' and the title track (spelled incorrectly, oddly) - and occasionally fires off some confident, reverberating solos. Again, I'm taken by Hill's compositional ability even if this record is easy to tune into muzak mentaly from all the piano and vibe interplay. I'm not a big vibes fan, as instruments, but this is really solid and avoids cliches through the dark, moody cadences and excellent musicianship. [11 December 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Genesis - Selling England By The Pound

Label: Charisma

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Genesis are a band that I kinda like, but not a lot, and I've always been happy just having this one record by them. The theatrics of Peter Gabriel have always pushed them quite closer to the ELP side of prog, which is sometimes great (the triumphant, screeching electric guitars can be nice) and sometimes bland. This has really overdone stuff like 'The Battle of Epping Forest' and 'Dancing With the Moonlit Knight', which is good, especially when it gets all ethereal and delicate; it's the jams that are sometimes less inspiring, especially after listening to an Area record yesterday. But maybe I'm being too hard on Genesis, and letting the horrible 80s pop stuff colour my appreciation - I used to like this record a lot. And actually, the Phil sung 'More Fool Me' is a perfect little pop song. [8 Aug 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Agitation Free - Malesch

Label: Vertigo

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

You gotta love Malesch, which is built around slow, creeping jams. It's recorded in a middle-range fidelity, which makes the excursions into subcontinental folk forms feel authentically wispy.  Side one sets the mood, and the murkiness really carries a dark, malevolent mood. The second side opens with the most interesting clash of rhythms and melodies before moving into a more loose, epic guitar workout with garbled, backwards vocals. It's a long record but right when it's about to overstay its welcome, it crashes to a conclusion. [16 December 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Kip Hanrahan - Coup De Tete

Label: American Clavé

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

I really like Kip Hanrahan's early work, even though it's sometimes awkward and overly coffeeshop-tasting. But I like coffee, and awkward. This seems to be the work of a very articulate artist who primarily works with voice and percussion, but much closer to spoken word than singing. The tracks are a who's who of genius musicians, with Chico Freeman, Arto Lindsay, Anton Fier, Byard Lancaster, Carla Bley, George Cartwright, Teo Macero, Bill Laswell, Michael Mantler, Cecil McBee and Billy Bang, to name some. It's often a jazz-rock hybrid, but heavily congo-based, giving everything a Latin pulse. The interplay between the musicians is the reason to listen, not to discount Hanrahan's own vocalising; one feels almost like he has 'coordinated' these musicians, rather than properly composing an album. His voice is soft and he's actually quiet most of the time, so the players can breathe. It never sounds like a drum circle - if anything, cuts like 'This Night Comes Out of Both Of Us' could be later Raincoats or Slits material, especially with Lisa Herman's subdued, breathy vocals. The lyrics push through boundaries of intimacy at time ('I want you to break me' jumps out) though they are easy to tune out; I suspect they should paid attention to, however. [13 August 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Julius A Hemphill - 'Coon Bid'ness

Label: Freedom

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Hemphill stakes out a real voice here on this, his second record after Dogon A.D. His band, with Hamiet Bluiett and Barry Altschul, starts off slow, as 'Reflections' and 'Lyric' unfold as carefully-composed meditations. But then 'Skin 1' kicks in, around a funky congo part with Abdul Wadud's cello keeping a motorik riff over which the horns can fuck around with each other. 'The Hard Blues' on side two is very much that - a slow, mournful blues progression that develops over about 20 minutes. The cello sounds like a guitar here and it stays back, with Philip Wilson just tapping out a bare beat and letting Hemphill and Bluiett and Baikada Carroll (on trumpet) go at it. By the end it's a giant, psychedelic mess that never lets go of the blues progression, and it's a powerful sound. [3 October 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Matching Mole - Little Red Record

Label: CBS

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

The second Matching Mole record is heavily rooted in Marxist imagery and also built around all non-Wyatt compositions. If you like "hot" electric piano, there's plenty to enjoy here -- though it doesn't sound miles away from a Soft Machine stuck permanently between their second and third albums. The musicianship is enjoyable and it avoids the sameyness of most jazz-rock. Wyatt's vocalisin' is pretty abstract, especially on a jam like 'Nan's True Hole', which gets thick and burning. I'm starting to get a little sick of prog, and so this is maybe not the best time to listen to the first side. But then on the second half, 'Gloria Gloom' starts things off as a delicious bit of dark ambience, then fading into a recording of a conversation - it's like the Pizza A Go-Go record! (But not really). But it is the highlight of what's otherwise a good record, if inferior to the self-titled. [25 August 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

John and Beverly Martyn - Stormbringer!

Label: Island

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Sold.


Date: 22 May 2002

Mekons

Label: Red Rhino

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

I never really knew what to make of this second Mekons album which was sort of their 'last' album before the breakup and rebirth. It's sometimes called Devils, Rats and Piggies which is a nicer name and it's a very transitional, experimental album that isn't like anything else they ever did except their other transitional, experimental albums (Me comes to mind). What strikes me about it now after a good listen is how contemporary it sounds - 'Snow', the first cut, could totally be some hipsters making music in Berlin today. There's a much more mellow approach, making this a true art-rock record and leaving the scraggle of Quality of Mercy behind. 'Corporal Chalkie' is one of my favourite Mekons songs, but I didn't love it until I heard the Sally Timms-crooned version on Punk Rock, which has retroactively made me love the original. This feels like it could be rediscovered by others, not just me. [18 August 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Mekons - The Quality of Mercy Is Not Strenen

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

The Mekons first album is such a ragged listen. It's well-recorded and very much a solid selection of songs, but this bears so little resemblance to the Mekons as they became even just a few years later. A few of these songs were re-recorded for Punk Rock and the melodic beauty is not so apparent in these original versions, like 'What'. The songwriting team is quite a bit different than later - no Langford is present, as least not as a songwriter, and there's a different vocalist who I think was named Kevin and didn't rejoin for the Fear and Whiskey era. The vocals have the working-class punk rock tonality that is very 1980; 'Lonely and Wet' and 'Join Us In the Countryside' are nearly epic, except they are not. There is a melodic sophistication at play on songs like 'After 6' and 'Watch the Film' which is executed all wrong, but it's kinda great. 'Dan Dare' ends the whole thing in an appropriate exuberant mess. [1 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Michael Mantler - Movies

Label: Watt

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

The title of this is appropriate for parts, which take Mantler and Bley's forward-thinking jazz (I hate to use the word fusion but with Larry Coryell and Tony Williams, this does actually "rock") and implements a Morricone-influenced soundtrack vibe. The music is tightly composed, though Steve Swallow, Mantler, and Bley definitely get to stretch out at places. I prefer this to later Mantler stuff, which takes on too much of a sheen. No one could ever accuse Movies of being sloppy, but there's still a strong sense of fun here - like the more rock parts of Escalator Over the Hill. Anything from the late 70's with Larry Coryell is worth hearing, and this is no exception. [27 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Robert Wyatt - The End Of An Ear

Label: CBS

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Robert Wyatt's only pre-disability solo album is a fun, fast romp. It starts and finishes with 'Las Vegas Tango', full of skittery piano, lively start-stop drums, and wacky layered vocals everywhere.  The middle tracks are all dedicated to different people. 'To Mark Everywhere' has brass from Mark Charig and Elton Dean, backwards tracked studio tricks, and then it gets progressively more weird. The improv bits are wild - 'To Nick Everyone' sputters out like a melted overlay of several simultaneous British jazz records. Side two begins with a mellow dedication to Caravan, with piano chords that hint at the progressions to come on Rock Bottom and subsequent work. Overall I'm generally impressed that this record is a wildly innovative experiment that uses color, mood, and studio trickery to create it's madness instead of relying on technical ability. The overall effect is quite lively and surreal, and it's a record I should listen to more often because there's a lot to be inspired by within. [14 August 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Carla Bley/Paul Haines - Escalator Over the Hill

Label: JCOA

Format: 3xLP box

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

this may be the most ridiculous record ever made.


Date: 22 May 2002

Carla Bley Band - European Tour 1977

Label: Watt

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Carla Bley's big band is a joyous thing, and while this live recording isn't as great as Tropical Appetites (oh, how I need to get a copy of that!) it's a fun, Apollonian experience in American jazz. The band is a mis of American and British artists, with both piano by Terry Adams and organ by Bley. Bley's own playing has the tendency towards fusiony vamps, but, hey, it's 1977 after all. The tuba of Bob Stewart reaches low, low, low and Michael Mantler's whole 'space trumpet' sound is in full effect. The second side ends with a big medley jam around 'The Star-Spangled Banner' and it's presented quite enthusiastically, not at all tongue-in-cheek, though maybe I'm misreading it. [5 Aug 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Glenn Branca - Lesson No. 1

Label: 99 Records

Format: Vinyl 12" 45 RPM EP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

An early Glenn Branca release, this featured layers of shiny guitars over a pounding rock drumset, with subtle harmonic movement, anchored by a bass guitar line that could have been culled from a Ramones song. Like I feel about most of Branca's work, this makes me think 'So what?' - trying to merge minimalist composition with punk rock is a noble idea, except that punk rock is already a minimal form of rock. Since I like that early 80s post-punk sound - this could be Mission of Burma (or more accurately, Birdsongs of the Mesozoic) - this is an enjoyable romp. But is it earth-shattering? Not in the slightest. [3 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Fire Engines - Aufgeladen Und Bereit Fur Action Und Spass

Label: Fast Product America

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

This compilation puts together just about everything the Fire Engines recorded, at least as far as I know. It contains almost the entirety of the Lubricate Your Living Room release, and has a bunch of instrumentals. The Fire Engines are pretty well-regarded among Scottish post-punkers and I personally prefer their rougher cacophony to bands like Josef K or Orange Juice. Through the sharp edges and the funky dance-orientated rhythm section, there's a confidence that I like; nothing twee or hesitating here. There's a lot of instrumental here which are pretty enjoyable - not as herky-jerky as Stickmen, not as experimental as the Pop Group, but a fun relic of music being made in my former home in the year I was born. [1 December 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Hamiet Bluiett - Birthright: A Solo Blues Concert

Label: India Navigation

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Another solo saxophone record, but this one's on baritone and I like Hamiet Bluiett's style. This plays up the drama, with tracks dedicated to his son and an alternation between wheezing note flurries and warbly, vibrato-laden deep tones. Sometimes he hits these frequencies where everything seems to crack, though maybe it's just something to do with the ways the mics are placed. In any case, lots of reverb here. [26 December 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Steeleye Span - Please To See The King

Label: Mooncrest

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

The third Steeleye Span record is often considered their best, and I like it because there's a somewhat more 'hard' guitar sound. 'The Blacksmith', which opens it up, has a crunchy cadence which gives a minor-key shine to Prior's haunting voice. Martin Carthy is exemplary here when singing, though the fiddle playing is relegated to the accompaniment role except on the instrumentals and jig bits. This feels like a really tight, cohesive band, and the arrangements have enough of a rock basis that it doesn't feel as rooted in the traditional; more like the familiar. I have a disproportional amount of British folk/rock on my shelves in relation to how often I actually want to listen to it, but this is one to keep going back to. [30 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Pop Group - Y

Label: Warner-Pioneer Corporation

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

I have mixed feelings after all these years about the Pop Group. Certainly there is something really truly great about this record - a genre-defying mishmash of free-jazz, punk, and dance with an experimental edge, all wrapped up in angry, Ex-like political rants. But while 12 years ago this band was blowing my mind, these days I feel less moved by it. I love the really fucked up, open pieces like 'Strange Sea' but the polemic shouting songs don't do as much for me these days. I guess asking for the Pop Group to write empathetic songs that I can relate to is silly, so maybe it's just Mark Stewart who I tire of. The piano playing and really all of the jazzy bits are great - this was a real true fusion not found by many others of their era. The record is generally dark and atmospheric, even on songs like 'We Are Time' I'm reminded of early Cure (!). [27 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Henry Cow - The Henry Cow Legend

Label: Red Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Henry Cow's first release is where it all started, and I often forget how lively and 'fruity' it sounds. The band is really playful and the somber, political stuff hasn't taken shape yet The horns give everything a fusion vibe and it's only on the introduction to 'Teenbeat' that they start to really get wild and open with the sound. Frith's guitar chords at the beginning of side two are among the most traditional, yet charming he's ever sounded, and he sonds like Eddie Van Halen one track later on the 'Teenbeat' reprise. The little bits of singing here are lovely and just the right amount - it's a shame they never really did anymore besides what Krause added. [27 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Henry Cow - Concerts

Label: Caroline

Format: 2xVinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Maybe the best overall Henry Cow recording, even though it's live - because the recording quality is fantastic and the highly improvisational nature of this band really shines in a live setting. Side 1 is a tour de force, dominated by Dagmar's voice and built around a thundering 'Beautiful as the Moon' to open and close it. Side two brings in Robert Wyatt, and the band gets into a faithful, awesome rendition of 'Little Red Riding Hood Hit the Road', which starts with Frith chugging along on a dirty sounding electric guitar - it's practically the opening chords to 'Smells Like Teen Spirit'. This is followed by an epic version of 'Ruins', ending with crashing fanfare and an appropriate comedown. The second LP is really where the free-rock chops shine, built around collective improvisations in Oslo and Udine. This runs the gamut from in-sync prog rock cadences to completely wild improvisations. The free playing, especially when the reeds are guitar are going, is of course much closer to the British school of brainy, restrained explorations than any sort of free-prog stuff - namely, it's not much like Area's contrapuntal explosions. But there's nothing too showoffty, and a general dark vibe saturates it all. Music like this is continually inspiring to me for the way in which it brings politics into the fold without compromising musical innovation. A classic. [4 Aug 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Mother Mallard's Portable Masterpiece Co. - Like a Duck to Water

Label: Earthquack

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

This is on a label called Earthquack! Earthquack! What an amazing name, and it ties into the "duck" imagery in the title of the album and the band itself. This is an all-synthesizer group, apparently a showcase of sorts for Robert Moog, but they really know how to make music as a band. As you'd expect there are long, slow passages here of pure electronic moods. A bit of vocals and some electric piano, but mostly this is the land of patch cables. It's tinged with darkness but they manage to extract something truly naturalistic out of sound sources so completely synthesised. Harmony, rather than dissonance, is the main goal here, but there are moments where the different frequencies start to clash and it created a nice unsettling buzz. It would be cool to check out what else they'd done over the years as I believe they've got an extensive discography. [28 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Johannes Ockeghem/Josquinm Desprez - Missa pro defunctis/Deploration

Label: Archiv Produktion

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

The term 'early music' is a funny one - it suggests music meant to be listened to in the morning, which this very much is. I really love this work by Ockeghem; it's built around nine male vocalists, with the odd medieval instrumentation often buried underneath. What I find so impressive about this music is how "modern" and contemporary it actually is. The melodies are like this long, unceasing tapestry that keeps getting unrolled. It's a construction that feels more akin to 1960's minimalism than any of the Western classical canon - an eternal music, always rolling towards a devotional core. There's also a piece by Desprez which is a lamentation on the death of Ockeghem and sounds pretty similar - with maybe a bit more of deeper hue. The male voices really run the range of sounds - there are tenors here who sound absolutely feminine. I'd be curious to see how this music is notated. [29 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Shirley & Dolly Collins - Anthems In Eden

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

This is the famous, epic Shirley and Dolly Collins record, or at least the one where their genius is most evident. The counterpoint of Shirley's voice against Dolly's instrumental movement is what I like, more than any sense of traditional-revival Britishisms. The organs and medieval flavours are what Dolly's famous for but when it's strings being bowed, I just love it. Call me traditional about my traditionals, though I guess these are medieval string instruments in many cases. The case for Dolly Collins as a psychedelic warrior can be made depending on your definition of psychedelia - certainly this is a rich, colourful musical palette, so that's enough for me. I'm not British and around 2007 started to develop a bit of distate for this music, but when I listen to songs like 'Lowlands' now I can't help but be moved by their weight and power. [17 December 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

This Heat - Health And Efficiency

Label: Piano

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46
