This Heat has been maybe my single biggest influence in making music (though I'm not sure how obvious that is by what I've recorded/released). This final statement is concise and perfect. It pushes the two extremes of the band to different sides - the construction of 'Health and Efficiency' versus the free exploroation of the studio in 'Graphic Varispeed'. I've listened a thousand times but I'm glad to actually own it. [13 Sept 2007]


Date: 22 May 2002

25 Rifles - Third World War

Label: none

Format: 12" Vinyl EP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

When I came across this curiosity I grabbed it on a whim. The band name recalled the line 'We've got 25 rifles just to keep the population down' from Neil Young's 'Revolution Blues' so I thought that was a good sign. Lo and behold, this 4 song EP actually features a cover of that song! But not a good one, except for the guitar solo. 25 Rifles are a band that perfectly mixes early Jam with Elvis Costello's earliest sound. That's not a bad sound - 'Little Girl' in particular is a fun, sprightly pop song and the production is crisp, the performance on point. They're actually a pretty good band and this was their only ever shot at anything, so they get relegated to history's bin. [25 September 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Can - Soundtracks

Label: Liberty

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Soundtracks is not considered one of the best albums, as it's truly a transition (between Malcolm Mooney and Damo Suzuki). However, the long version of 'Mother Sky' is incredible, and the other tracks are still pretty good. [13 Sept 2007]


Date: 22 May 2002

Can - Soon Over Babaluma

Label: United Artists Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

This was the first Can album I ever heard, strangely, just because I borrowed the CD from a friend back in my freshman year of college. Even though this lacks the crazy vocals of Suzuki or Mooney, it's still a great record. Can becomes a bit more focused here without the frontman distraction, working on their rhythmic side with Jaki Leibzeit coming to the forefront here. The singing is unobtrusive if indistinct, but it's good; 'Come Sta, La Luna' is a wild herky-jerky ride, and 'Splash' rides things out on an epic jam. But no matter how enjoyable Soon Over Babaluma is, it's always going to be the one really good Can album that you forget about and never recognise any of the songs from. [29 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Zao - Kawana

Label: RCA Victor

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Here's some French prog, which, while well-played, is mostly uninspired jazz-rock. The end of side one has a great string section bit, and the end of side two is a 9 minute jam called "Free Folk" that begins with a blast of vocoded vocals before getting into the hot basslines and other such action. The violins, played by Didier Lockwood, are definitely the highlight but I'm not sure if this is one worth keeping. [3 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Wire - 154

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

So many little parts of this record burrow into the part of my brain where infectious hooks bury themselves.  'An evening of fun in a metropolis of your dream' being one of them.  Which makes me think about how lyrics attain such a grandeur and how they get re-used all the time in art projects -- I could totally see myself organising some night called 'An evening of fun in a metropolist of your dream', which could be some seminar on urbanism or something -- and taken totally out of context.  Not that I can actually tell what 'On Returning' is about.  There's a lot of sci-fi allusions there, and weird anthropomorphic imagery; it's like something out of 'La Jetéé'.  Anyway.  Wire was really never more perfect than here.  What utter modernists.  What utter genuises.  [21 June 2011]


Date: 22 May 2002

Don Cherry - Eternal Now

Label: Sonet

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Cherry is joined here by some Swedish dudes for an excursion into the outer sounds of his mind, only tangentially related to 'jazz'. There's a lot of soft wind here - flutes, other woody things, and a general Art Ensemble-like focus on small sounds and little instruments. The centre of the album is a bit more active - the 'Bass Figure for Balatune' is built around repetitive pianos, pounding like a 60's minimalist composition; 'Moving Pictures for the Ear' takes on the more active, tribal drumming that is found on records like Orient and Blue Lake, with the requisite vocalising. This feels like an important step before the creation of the mighty Brown Rice. [1 December 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Bert Jansch - Moonshine

Label: Reprise Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Yet another Bert Jansch record, and a solid one at that. Moonshine is from '73 and wel produced, with Pentangle friends, Ralph McTell, Dave Mattacks,  and some harp. Both sides close with great, epic songs - 'Night Time Blues', which has some magical fiddle stylings, and the whole LP ends on the rocking 'Oh my Father', where the electric guitar that makes periodic appearances on this record starts to really rage. The traditional songs are done in the usual Jansch style, with the only pure solo track being 'Twa Corbies', a beauty as well. [19 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Nico - Desertshore

Label: Reprise

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

What's the most stark and extreme Nico record? It's probably Desertshore but it's not like any of them are exactly 'fun'. This isn't one I spin often but when I do I keep going back to the haunting vocal hymn 'My Only Child', which is about the pinnacle of Ms. Nico expressing a dynamic gamut of emotions with just her voice. This is in many ways an insight into what a Cale/Nico-led VU would have been like; maybe cross 'Janitor of Lunacy' with 'Sister Ray' and you get the greatest thing ever imagined that never actually happened. The cover makes me think of Arrabal films and that's probably quite deliberate; the child vocals on 'Le Petit Chevalier' as well recall the Viva la Muerte song. I don't know if it's the Nico record I pull out the most, but maybe listening more scarcely is a sign of a deeper appreciation. [18 December 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Ohio Players - Gold

Label: Mercury

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

This is a greatest hits of Ohio Players songs and the only thing I own by them, and pretty much my only record of the genre. This funk-disco hybrid is great and there's a lot of cracking, sharp edges and smooth sexyness too. This is certainly not my area of expertise and I wonder why I even own this, as rarely as I listen to it. 'Love Rollercoaster' is pretty great and if I'm only going to have one Ohio Players record, I suppose this is the one. I remember when Chris Strunk and Tim Williams were going to start a band called the Pennsylvania Players that would just cover Ohio Players songs - would have been odd, as they are two drummers, and pretty white at that. [24 September 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Wire - Pink Flag

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

For some reason I felt like listening to Wire tonight.  It's about the millionth time I've spun this triumvirate and since I was working, it sorta faded into a very familiar background.  Of course, '12XU' and 'Mr. Suit ' burrow into my consciousness and force me to tap on the desk while I'm working.  I realise I never commented on these when I got the vinyl, so it's a bit weird to write a review when there's nothing else I can say. [21 June 2011]


Date: 22 May 2002

Chico Freeman - Chico

Label: India Navigation

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Chico Freeman's second LP begins with a long exploratory track called 'MOMENTS', starting with just Chico and Cecil McBee, who's a really underrated bassist, I think. They take their time stretching out, and there's a really up-front, close studio tone that is soft, inviting, and meandering in a good way. I guess Chico (Von Freeman's son) is a minor AACM player; Muhal Richard Abrams and Steve McCall are here too, but only on side 2 -- so this is a pretty solid, familiar lineup. Some great bits when McBee is bowing and Freeman is really laying on the low register and it's totally lockstep. Side two, 'Merger' maintains a light, airy feel as the full band is playing, and there's a second percussionist so it's super Latin feeling at points, or a bit like that one Crimson record with the second percussionist. There's standard moments of solos - Abrams lets one rip right at the beginning which I like because of how faraway it sounds - and a really cohesive feel. As good as 'Merger' is, it's nothing on the first side - the McBee/Freeman duet - because that really stakes out a unique voice. [13 July 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Colin Newman - A-Z

Label: Beggars Banquet

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Where has this been all my life? Ross told me he actually preferred it to Wire's output, which was shocking to me until I heard it - this is the fourth Wire album. This is the step Colin Newman was ready to make, as it was becoming increasingly clear what his role was in the band. I'm not discounting Bruce Gilbert, but watching the live video that McDowell found, it's pretty obvious to me that his role was being gradually reduced. This is like 154 part 2 (155?) but a bit more focused, and with some really catchy parts. Art-rock at it's finest. [2 January 2004]


Date: 22 May 2002

Andrew Hill - Point Of Departure

Label: Blue Note

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

I really like Andrew Hill's records for Blue Note because he's a great composer and assembled a hell of a band too. This has Dolphy on it, and he's really tricky at times, playing around with the tenor player and generally avoiding the complete focus. Hill's own playing is not flashy; it's solid, and subtle, and when it seems that he's really more concerned with holding together the centre instead of trying to take charge, you then realise he's gone on some dazzling run that you barely noticed.. With Dolphy, you can do that - the saxes and trumpet at times weave beautiful ballads ('Dedication'), and there's the post-bop momentum through most other tracks. 'Flight 19' has them at their most furtive, with the rhythm section able to stop on a dime and change direction. There's so much colour in this music that it's remarkable really, while still adhering to conventional styles.  A young Tony Williams is on drums too, making this a historically underrated band at a critical point in several careers. [23 July 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Wire - Chairs Missing

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Reviewing this feels almost ridiculous given how many times I've listened to this, but I saw it was without a review so I threw it on and tried to hear something new. Repeated listens don't make me love this less; this time I enjoyed the beautifully chosen guitar chords on the 'Gold scissors cut...' line, and the slow throb of 'Mercy'. A cornerstone of music, absolutely. [15 July 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Don Ellis - Haiku

Label: MPS Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Don Ellis's work is beautiful and Appollonian, building small orchestra pieces around his trumpet. He's like a white Miles Davis in that way - though not as adventurous or distinct, but in the Sketches of Spain sort of way. This record is built around the idea of Japanese haikus and the sketches are often saccharine, often melodramatic, but always pleasing. Every time I think about tossing this record out I give it a listen and find something comforting in it, even though this is a long way from the edge of the French Connection soundtrack. The band, despite it's size and studio construction, can actually swing - cuts like 'Parting' make a nice contrast to the more soundtracky numbers, reminding us that Ellis is (or at least once was) rooted in 'jazz'. The cover is wonderfully psychedelic too. [26 July 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Henry Cow - Western Culture

Label: Interzone

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

I love Henry Cow's last record, which is a lot different while not reinventing the wheel. John Greaves is gone and the two sides are given over to compositions by Tim Hodgkinson and Lindsay Cooper, so it's almost like Frith and Cutler can just concentrate on playing, rather than leading. Of course, there's brilliant improvisatory moments by both of them, though this feels like the most tightly composed of any of their records. The Hodgkinson side actually reminds me of industrial music at times, and industry is certainly the image they were trying to conjure here. It returns to anthemic progressive rock licks for the ending 'On a Raft' which switches around instrumentation between the members but is stellar. Cooper's side has searing licks and is quite a distance from her solo album, which has much more of a songy, Brechtian influence. It ends on an uplifting, brisk jam which suggests these guys had so much more to offer the world, but sadly, this was it. [13 Aug 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Robert Wyatt - Rock Bottom

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

I just wrote a review of the last Camper Van Beethoven album, where I concluded with "this album is essential to John W. Fail." I don't want to get into the habit of writing that, but what else could I possibly say about Rock Bottom? This album is a cornerstone and a continual inspiration to me. It perfectly balances being weird, warm, personal, sad, and adventurous. And I have been listening to it constantly since Caleb first dubbed it for me in spring 1998. [2 January 2004]


Date: 22 May 2002

Hamiett Bluiett - Endangered Species

Label: India Navigation

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Another great early India Navigation side, this is the Hamiet Blueiett record I have that finds him rocking out with a band. The rhythm section of Philip Wilson and Junie Booth is really open, subtly playing around the Bluiett's baritone sax. On the flipside he gets out the flute and it really takes it time to rev up, not so concerned with getting anywhere which is nice. Olu Dara's is a fairly unheralded trumpet player who gives this a nice, bold exuberance, particularly when placed against Bluiett's odd bari-tones. [15 July 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Robert Wyatt - Ruth Is Stranger Than Richard

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: €4.46

Tara pointed out that it was just Rober Wyatt's birthday so I gave this a spin to get me pumped for Super Bowl Sunday, though it'd admittedly an odd choice.  I've always loved this album because its so eclectic - lively and somber at the same time, and with some really great arrangements.  My old faves have always been "Team Sprit" and "Song for Che", but today I really loved the Offenbach piece, specifically how playfully Wyatt's "imitation electric piano" is.  He tinkles on the keys in a way that injects a really silly spirit into the chord cadences, and it makes Offenbach much more playful than one would expect.  This is also one of my favorite album covers of all-time - it perfectly captures the mood of the record with a really unique, surrealistic style. I think this record is often overlooked since it came out around the same time as Rock Bottom and it's isn't as introspective or personal, but it's still one of Wyatt's best records and it's a template for fruitful art-prog-rock ideas.   It foreshadows the 80s period where he performed a lot of covers but still has some originals; it really feels like a turning point between Soft Machine/End of an Ear and the unique style of his subsequent material. [1 Feb 2009]



Date: 22 May 2002

Tom Waits - Closing Time

Label: Asylum Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Tom Waits's first album is a pretty good record of 70's American songwriting, but it's NOTHING like you expect from Tom Waits. I mean, even among his pre-Swordfishtrombones output, like Nighthawks, there's a wrecked depression to it all. But this sounds more like Jimmy Webb - folk-tinged romanticism (some of it quite touching, like 'I Hope That I Don't Fall in Love With You') and some country-rock stompers ('Rosie'). It's a pretty good debut, I guess, though it doesn't even hint at what's to come. I can't see myself listening to this much unless I were to really dedicate myself to exploring some of the songs, but time will prevent that, and I enjoy listening to Rain Dogs and Frank's Wild Years so much lately that this isn't likely to get much of my Waits attention. [11 July 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Archie Shepp - Live In San Francisco

Label: Impulse!

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Great-sounding live session featuring Roswell Rudd and Don Garrett on bass (along with Lewis Worrell).  The record is mostly cover versions apart from a Rudd original and one Shepp composition.  Side 1's centerpiece is a languid, bouncy be-bop number where Rudd bends his trombone like crazy to complement Shepp's sax.  "Sylvia" is really a Shepp solo piano piece that develops slowly but romantically with minimal accompaniment by Beaver Harris; it's followed by a recited poem.  Side two opens with "Where June Bugs Go", the Shepp original, which is tightly composed swinging bop where he harmonises with Rudd.  It's followed by the Ellington classic "In a Sentimental Mood" which opens with a fast Archie Shepp solo; "sentimental" generally describes this record, which shows that Shepp is not all fire and brimstone.  [25 Jan 2009]



Date: 22 May 2002

Richard Thompson - Live (More Or Less)

Label: Island

Format: Vinyl 2xLP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

There's more than one reason to own this record. The biggest is to have I Want To See the Bright Lights Tonight, an album I would definitely rank in the 'all-time classics' category. I don't have the standalone LP so this release thankfully includes it as the first disc. There's not much to say that hasn't already been said about Bright Lights; it's a sophisticated blend of misery and company, a landmark album that (due to the doomed marriage of Richard and Linda) works on several subtextual levels. The live portion is the second LP (whether it's more or less would require me counting the minutes and seconds, which I don't care to do) and featured a series of songs on side C and two long jams on side D. It's these final cuts that really make it - 'Night Comes In' and 'Calvary Cross', both recorded very clearly and with the sort of extended jams/solos you'd imagine would justify their running them. Thompson's less polished live vocals add something to this - 'Oh this night, like no other' sounds a bit strained, the way it should be. 'Calvary Cross' on Bright Lights is almost unbearably heavy for a non-hard rock band; the hesitations on the thundering rhythm breaks are absolutely beautiful. The live version is a bit lighter actually, with the accordion really bleeding through, bu the solos are longer and Thompson really takes his time to develop a theme. It's such a beautiful, strong and painful song that it might even be my favourite one on Bright Lights because of how this live version presents it. [30 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Chick Corea , Dave Holland , Barry Altschul - A.R.C.

Label: ECM Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

In comparison to the better-known Circle album, this is nothing special - the presence that Braxton adds to this trio makes that an absolute classic. But comparisons aside, A.R.C. is built around Corea's beautiful piano playing, which is sprightly without being saccharine; liquid without being formless. Altschul and Holland are a great pair, and I've probably written somewhere else here about how underrated I think Dave Holland is. The title track is the craziest - the piano sounds like it's exploding, opening up while at the same time falling in on itself. This Dadaist intrusion is definitely the high point of the first side, but the second side get really wild. 'Games' does this nutty volume changing doppler effect thing, and by the end, I'm thinking that I should really investigate some of Dave Holland's solo work. Liner notes are an all-caps screed about Scientology, really! [23 August 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

A Certain Ratio - To Each...

Label: Factory

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

A Certain Ratio are a band I always forget about when I think about this era, but their sound is probably the most 'contemporary' of anybody. There was a huge revival of this stuff that has probably already faded but I think it left its mark. Listening to songs like 'Back to the Start', it's pretty compelling, even on a rainy afternoon like today - the driving basslines, the club-style dance rhythms, and that dour moan overtop. Actually, it's perfect for an autumn rain in Estonia, amongst the medieval architecture and hopelessness. [19 September 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Band Apart - Jaguar EP

Label: Crammed DIscs

Format: 12"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

I bought this pretty much randomly, and it's become one of those idiosyncratic records that I love that no one else has ever heard of. I play 'Jaguar' probably every time I DJ (which is not often); it resembles a scarier, maudlin Pylon with this most incredibly repeating swelling pulse. As simple as it is - another new wave/post-punk experiment to be forgotten - the feel of this is something that's been tremendously influential on me and I've tried to emulate in my own work (unsuccessfully, and I can't even point any any explicit examples, but trust me, the intent is there all the time). The other three songs aren't bad - actually, they range from good to great; overall, I'd say Band Apart are an incredibly underrated band. Until now it had never even occured to me that there might be more Band Apart out there beyond these four songs; the Internet tells me they had a full-length called Marseille. Time to hunt it down, though to be honest, I'm happy enough with 'Jaguar'. [1 Aug 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Barre Phillips - For All It Is

Label: Japo Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

This is a great concept - Barre Phillips invited three other bassists to make a record of improvisations and compositions, with only Stu Martin's drumming to join them. The channels are split so Barre is hard left, Barry Guy soft left, Martin in the middle, Palle Danielsson soft right, and J.F. Jenny-Clarke hard right. The result is an experiment that is incredibly rewarding. The opening cut sets the pace with a really rolling, active jam, accessible and fun too - but still messy and chaotic and all the bass strings flop all over each other and it's a pleasure to sort it all out. As the record progresses we get some beautiful bowed harmonies, some purely sketch-like improv, and a feeling of cohesion that is remarkable, given the unusual instrumentation. I've always though Phillips a bit underrated, though to be honest, I don't really single out his playing here despite the hard panning - it's his vision and compositional approach that I like so much. [19 December 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Bert Jansch - Jack Orion

Label: Vanguard

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

This is a great, great Jansch record, maybe the best. And such a flattering cover! Renbourn plays second guitar on a few tracks but this is mostly Jansch doing traditionals, including a great '900 Miles' and the stunning title track, which has some fanastic pre-Pentangle interplay with Renbourn. The instrumental opener has some banjo, enough to leave me wanting more, but the guitar playing is sharp and nihilistic at points - an agressive take on familiar tunes. 'Jack Orion' is epic, really - a great example of how these old Vanguard records keep on giving so many years later. [17 December 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

National Health - Of Queues and Cures

Label: Charly

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

This second National Health album lacks 'Tenemos Roads', which admittedly is the only thing I like by this band. The six jazz-rock tunes on here are pretty okay I guess, but apart from John Greaves's 'Squarer for Maud' which has some crunching keyboards and Peter Blegvad muttering about something, it's in-one-ear-out-the-other prog rock competence. Greaves sings on 'Binoculars' which is probably my favourite track, quite charming in it's casual lyrics. But overall I'm not into this much. [17 August 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Olivier Messiaen - Et Exspecto Resurrectionem Mortuorum / Couleurs De La Cité Céleste

Label: CBS

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46



Date: 22 May 2002

Ornette Coleman - Dancing In Your Head

Label: Horizon Records & Tapes

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

This is a pretty stomping, excellent late 70's Ornette Coleman record that gets really into the fusion-rock side. But the rock that Coleman embraces is punchy, jerky Beefheartian skronk. Most of the record is built around an endless circular sax lick, around which a busy lineup, including Ronald Shannon Jackson, rocks the fucking jams. It's so endless that it splits over two sides, during which everyone gets their chance to solo. The other track features the Master Musicians of Jajouka and it's also great - a departure from the fusion, sure, but no less free and active. [24 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Pierre Bensusan - 2

Label: Rounder

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Pierre Bensusan's second album is one of those random gems that I picked up when feeling adventurous, and really loved. These are French folk songs, mostly acoustic guitar and bagpipes, though with some additional reeds at times. This highland/provincial France hybrid sound is great, and his voice and guitar playing are exemplary. While fairly clean and formal sounding, there's a real sophistication to the melodies - no dirty slacker vibe, nothing really even that Bohemian-sounding. It's just good guitar playing and great song construction. I've always meant to pick up other releases by him if I ever came across any, but I haven't. [3 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Roxy Music

Label: Atco

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Though so much of the Roxy Music reputation rests on this first album, I actually forget about it quite a lot. A shame too, cause there's some scorchingly innovative pieces here. I weirdly like the mellow, tuneful side of Brian Ferry more than the fucked-up Eno-driven stuff, but this has a great balance ('Bitters End' closes it and it's like a doo-wop track gone mad). This is a cheap, thin repressing on Atco that sticks 'Virginia Plain' on there (which I don't think is on the original) but that's Ok cause it's a great song. [17 October 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Sam Rivers - Sizzle

Label: 

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

OK, a bit on the "hot" side. Sold.


Date: 22 May 2002

Tom Waits - Small Change

Label: Asylum Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

We join Waits, here, a few years after Closing Time but not quite at Swordfishtrombones yet. His voice has developed the gravely mania that he's known for, though it's not yet left the piano-driven jazz balladry. It's a nice midpoint, though; songs like ''Inivitation to the Blues' are successful, where the scat-croon 'Step Right Up' perhaps a bit less so. 'The Piano Has Been Drinking' is on here, a song that's he's never quite shaken off and seems to sum up this era of Waits in a nutshell, though it gets too bogged down in its repetition and easy humour for me. It's such an affect, but the songwriting has always delivered for me, especially on the later records like Rain Dogs which I don't actually have. I rarely, rarely am in the mood for this but when that time comes I know there's a boozy, smoky room conjured by this LP. [20 December 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

Sameti

Label: Brain

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

A forgotten Krautrock record that I tossed soon after getting in a "I have too much stuff" purge. Probably should have kept it.


Date: 22 May 2002

Ustad Ali Akbar Khan - Master Musician Of India

Label: Connoisseur Society

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

I don't know whether to alphabetise this under Ustad, Ali, Akbar or Khan; I've always had it under U which is probably very wrong.  This is an LP with two Hindi ragas on it - 'Chandranadan' and 'Gauri Manjari'. Khan plays the sarod and is accompanied by tabla and tampura, so it's a classic raga sound.  I don't know anything about Indian classical music so it's hard for me to really review this.  The liner notes display the melodic themes for both ragas but the melodies don't set the mood so much as the way the three musicians interact.  There are long static parts where the tabla is insanely consistent and Khan is just picking a few notes every few seconds, leaving tons of heavy table-delineated space.  Both of them accelerate to the end, becoming a real jam, which is an effect both dramatic and mesmerising.  [28 May 2011]


Date: 22 May 2002

V/A - Japon 3: Gagaku

Label: Ocora

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

A beautiful find, this record collects some Gagaku music, written around the year 900 but performed in 1979. Gagaku is pretty much the heaviest thing ever - slow, barely moving, yet gradually opening sounds built around reeds and spare percussion. This collection opens with 'Etenraku' which is supposedly the pinnacle of the form; there are some dance pieces after this which aren't any less intense. Though this is the slowest music imaginable, it's still incredibly fluid; a paradox between heavy and light that is somehow both, and has to be heard because I can't describe it with words. [25 November 2012]


Date: 22 May 2002

V/A - Java - Palais Royal de Yogyakarta Musique de Concert

Label: Ocora

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.46

Royal Javanese gamelan music has its charms; perhaps it's not as smooth as the Balinese styles, but there's a heaviness  that really sticks with me after I listen. The first side of this is split into two pieces, and the second is a vocal one, where a male soloist sounds like he is eviscerating his soul. There is the most minimal musical accompaniment behind him at first, just a spare gong or drum, which really adds to the power. When the full ensemble comes in, it's a total life. Side two is a longer, courtly piece that is also lovely, and recorded in that distant yet genuine Ocora way. [29 November 2012]


Date: 2 June 2002

V/A - Planet Squeezebox

Label: Ellipsis Arts

Format: 3xCD

Source: Copacetic Comics

Cost: $11.98

a three-cd set of accordion music? How could I pass this up?


Date: 2 June 2002

V/A - Pyrophones: Experimental Musical Instruments

Label: Ellipsis Arts

Format: CD

Source: Copacetic Comics

Cost: $9.98

so cheap! I


Date: 9 June 2002

Henry Flynt - New American Ethnic Music Volume 2: Spindizzy

Label: Recorded

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $0

I cashed in on consignment.


Date: 9 June 2002

Luther Thomas and Human Arts Ensemble - Banana

Label: Atavistic

Format: CD

Source: John Corbett

Cost: $12

Freewheelin', ripping jazz from St. Louis that's recorded somewhat loosely, so you hear a lot of space and at times Mr. Thomas sounds like he's wandering down the hall with his horn. I don't really know any of these musicians but that's why it's on the Unheard Music Series, right? In college, these Unheard Music CDs were like manna from heaven - I remember getting excited about the release of each one. I'm not sure what happened to the series. Wish they were on vinyl. Anyway - Thomas makes a good case for himself as an overlooked genius; there's some really bluesy, gutbucket stuff, and when the two saxes interact it's occasionally genius. There's a swinging feel though - this is St. Louis, so the blues are felt - and there's the presence of "small instruments" by Abdullah Yakub which actually gives this a great tension between Art Ensemble-sorta stuff and more hard-bop/early free  feelings. The title track is a solo alto solo by Thomas and the last track is an alternate version, the requisite CD bonus track. [18 September 2012]


Date: 9 June 2002

Consonant

Label: Fenway Recordings

Format: CD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $8

this is my favorite rock record of the year, so far. [2002] This was a pretty big favorite back in 2002 and I pulled it out today to hear how it has aged.  It still sounds good, maybe great even - and is a pretty good model for how to age gracefully (meaning songwriter Clint Conley, not the record itself).  A lot of people seemed to think that Chris Brokaw was the secret ingredient here, which is possible as this blows away any post-reformation Mission of Burma that I've heard.  It's interesting how about half of the lyrics were cowritten with a poet , and half are from Conley's own voice; there's a weird masculine/feminine duality going on, though the bitterness in tracks like 'Call It L---' is pretty harsh.  It sounds much more like R.E.M./80s college rock than I remembered, and some of the tracks have the potential to be classics ('That Boston Life').  I never could get into the second album yet I still have a promo CD that I've carried around with me and never listened to more than twice - maybe it's time again. [9 Feb 2009]



Date: 13 June 2002

Archie Shepp - Yasmina, A Black Woman

Label: BYG Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ebay

Cost: $11

original on Affinity.


Date: 27 June 2002

Crucial Unit/Rambo - split

Label: Ed Walters

Format: 7"

Source: Ian and Bolam

Cost: $3



Date: 27 June 2002

Crucial Unit - Everything Went Strunk

Label: Six Weeks

Format: CD

Source: Bolam

Cost: $0



Date: 15 July 2002

Animal Collective - HollinndAgain

Label: St. Ives

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Cenotaph distro

Cost: $7.5

Bought from my own distro which existed at this time. I think I had a few copies left which I sold on eBay for much larger sums, though they probably still pale in comparison to what it would fetch now. Side 1 is from a WFMU session and it takes a slow, slow build into 'Forest Gospel', the memorable bit of this side. It's no great observation to point out that a live album has a more raw sound than studio ones; caught just before the release of Indian, this is an Animal Collective who stay close to their guitar pedals, which the stark radio-station production indicates. The songs here haven't achieved the sublime elegance melodically that they hit around Sung Tongs; instead, it's more hyperactive, with whooping and screaming. Side two beings with crashing, thunderous drums and the structures are there, though most fo the surface feels collectively improvised, a sea of voices in exasperation. Nothing here ever ended up on Indian in a polished form as far as I can remember, though I should listen to that again. This was released on a Secretly Canadian offshoot label called St. Ives that turned unsold LP covers inside out and did limited runs; it's subsequently been reissued in the wake of Animal Collective's success, which even a few years after the face seems difficult for me to place into context. I knew these guys at the time and remember them telling me this was coming out; now it's a totally forgotten part of their discography. [23 July 2012]


Date: 15 July 2002

Mekons - Slightly South Of The Border EP

Label: Sin Record Company

Format: Vinyl 10" 45 RPM EP

Source: Caleb

Cost: $0

birthday gift. Three months late.


Date: 25 July 2002

Hamza El Din - Eclipse CD

Label: Rykodisc

Format: CD Album

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0

Eclipse was recorded in the late 1970s by Hamza El Din, a Nubian musician who developed a unique style of oud playing by studying in Egypt (the oud is not commonly featured in Sudanese music). These five tracks are built around rolling, moody oud arpeggios and El Din's gentle yet raspy voice. The centerpiece is 'Your Love is Ever Young', a cover of an Um Kalthoum song, which extends over 18 minutes. El Din's songs expand so slowly that it's difficult to notice the movement from one section to another - a seemingly repetitive chordal patterns will shift into an entirely different one, as if the transitions are fluid and unseen. When they shift into major key harmonies, such as the end of 'The Visitors', these glimpses of Western intervals lend a familiarity to the proceedings. This is recorded in a warm, intimate room with fairly minimal production which is perfect for letting the overtones ring out. [24 July 2012]


Date: 25 July 2002

Jali Musa Jawara - Yasimika

Label: Hannibal

Format: CD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0

This is considered one of the finest kora records ever, and I can hear why. It's built around two guitars, kora and balafon, and it's absolutely transcendent and beautiful. The four songs on here are all lengthy, but not too long, and are built around repetitive runs, all in a melodic key, that go on and on and allow lots of movement and lift. Jawara's vocals are free and extemporaneous, but backed up by a female vocal chorus. The kora is the main instrument, but it's really the balafon that rips off some beautiful runs and really sings. It was a decade ago that Rennie, a guy I barely knew from Pittsburgh, sent me a massive package of promo stuff from Rykodisc because he was working there as a lawyer. I would have never heard this if it wasn't for him throwing it into the package, probably randomly, and I'm incredibly thankful because I've listened to it lots over the past 10 years. [29 July 2012]


Date: 25 July 2002

V/A - Voices Of The Rainforest

Label: Rykodisc

Format: CD Album

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0

Ethnomusicologist Stephen Feld made these recordings in 1990, in the mountains of Papua New Guinea, which are split somewhat between music of the people and the natural sounds. It's an incredible recording - the tracks of just birds, animals, and the trees themselves are mesmerising, and the vocal chants of the Kaluli people are of course fascinating too. I like how this is presented - in basic, raw academic ways and even when listening to men cutting down trees, it sounds like a window into another world. [30 December 2012]


Date: 25 July 2002

V/A - The Youruba/Dahomean Collection

Label: Rykodisc

Format: CD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0



Date: 25 July 2002

Fairport Convention - Heyday - The BBC Sessions 1968-1969

Label: Island Records

Format: CD Album Compilation

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0

Replaced with new edition that has bonus tracks.


Date: 25 July 2002

Choying Drolma and Steve Tibbetts - Cho

Label: Hannibal

Format: CD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0



Date: 25 July 2002

V/A - The Music of Upper and Lower Egypt

Label: Rykodisc

Format: CD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0

I don't know why they didn't just call this The Music of Egypt, or maybe there's a central Egypt as well that isn't represented here. This is an old Mickey Hart recording from the late 70s of Egyptian music, which bears no resemblance to Westernised pop that likely occupies Egypt today, and it was recorded while the dead were on tour in '78. The first few tracks are built around looping percussion with lots of chanting - conveying the joyousness I usually find with African music, minus the heavy Islam stuff. But that kicks in with track 5, built around a thick drone on the mizmar, with jammy drums coming in and out at points. The longest track is the last one, 'Manami', which is built around tar, tambura and darabukka. The vocalist sings from a place balanced somewhere between casual and devoted, which is probably a good representation of Egypt, as least as I perceive it having never been there. [17 September 2012]


Date: 25 July 2002

Mad Capsule Markets - OSC-DIS (Oscillator In Distortion)

Label: Palm Pictures

Format: CDDVD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0

Was given this for free; didn't really like it, don't know what happened to it.


Date: 25 July 2002

V/A - Bluegrass Jamboree

Label: Hannibal

Format: CD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0



Date: 25 July 2002

Frank Zappa/Mothers of Invention - Freak Out/Absolutely Free/We're Only In It for the Money

Label: Rykodisc

Format: 3xCD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0



Date: 25 July 2002

Fairport Convetion - House Full: Live in LA, 1970

Label: Rykodisc

Format: CD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0



Date: 25 July 2002

V/A - Music for the Gods - The Fahnestock South Sea Expedition: Indonesia

Label: Rykodisc

Format: CD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0

These are legendary gamelan recordings made in 1941 by the Fahnestock brothers, which were exhibited in their time but never commercially released until this disc, which is part of the Library of Congress's endangered music project. The majority of this was recorded in Bali but some in Madura, and it's textbook examples of classic Balinese gamelan pieces, with the Kecak (monkey chant) thrown in as well, cause no Indonesia field recordings disc is complete without it. Given the age of the recordings they sound great and have the perfect atmosphere for field recordings -- the drum-based pieces specifically sound like true audiotourism, and there's a jaw's harp track that is insane. [17 August 2012]


Date: 25 July 2002

V/A - The Bali Sessions

Label: Rykodisc

Format: 3xCD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0

This is well over 3 hours of Balinese gamelan music, making this a hell of an afternoon. It's hard to talk about this critically as it's not something I feel any way to offer an artistic opinion. Disc 1 contains ten shorter tracks, showing off various Balinese approaches, with vocals, drumming and ringing tones. Disc two is built around a 54 minute version of the Ramayana monkey chant, which is almost clichéd except it's such a powerful, awesome thing to listen to. The third disc is built around three 20+ minute pieces, which get really insanely repetitive (in a good, deep way), particularly when the gamelan is just clanging along in the same pattern and the vocalists or flute are just going apeshit. There's lots of drama here, and that gamelan thing I love where the music hangs for a second happens throughout. These discs are likely all the Balinese gamelan I'd ever need, though I have a great LP too. [25 July 2012]


Date: 25 July 2002

V/A - Utom: Summoning the Spirit: Music in the T'Boli Heartland

Label: Rykodisc

Format: CD

Source: Rykodisc (via Rennie)

Cost: $0



Date: 27 July 2002

R.E.M. - Out Of Time

Label: Warner Bros.

Format: LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

cover slightly damaged. My first R.E.M. album, originally purchased on cassette in seventh grade or so on the strength of "Losing my Religion" and the novelty of "Shiny Happy People". The former still holds up damn well, even though it's achieved Muzak status; the other real gems are "Country Feedback", "Me In Honey," and "Half A World Away". It's a strange evolution towards WYEP-music for R.E.M., I think, but their followup sure delivered. [3 January 2004]


Date: 27 July 2002

Pylon - Cool / Dub

Label: DB Recs

Format: Vinyl 7" Single

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $2

'Cool' is on side 1, and 'Dub' is on side 2. Together, these are probably the two best Pylon songs, but since I've played them both a zillion times I tend to skip over them when listening to Pylon. What else can I say? I have these in so many other versions. [5 August 2012]


Date: 27 July 2002

John Renbourn - The Lady And The Unicorn

Label: Reprise Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

Never got that into it, sold it.


Date: 30 July 2002

Vas Deferens Organization w/Brad Laner - Transcontinental Conspiracy

Label: Niklas

Format: CD Album

Source: Eric from VDO

Cost: $0



Date: 30 July 2002

Vas Deferens Organization - Drug Bubbles

Label: Tekito

Format: CD Mini-Album

Source: Eric from VDO

Cost: $0



Date: 30 July 2002

Electric Company And Vas Deferens Organization - More Pelvis Wick For The Baloney Boners

Label: Tekito

Format: CD

Source: Eric from VDO

Cost: $0



Date: 30 July 2002

Sound - Drunk On Confusion

Label: Beautamous Loaf International

Format: CD

Source: Eric from VDO

Cost: $0

This is a side project of Eric from the Vas Deferens Organisation that I traded him for years ago, and listening to it for the first time in years (maybe ever?) I'm amused, enjoying quite a lot of this disc which is about as full-on 'crazy' as psychedelic music can be.  It loses just a tad bit though, by being so full-on.  There's a few actual beautiful moments but they're immediately juxtaposed against something else crazy; it sounds like a record of someone trying to be insane but without actually having anything to express artistically (which is my general criticism of VDO).  I hope this doesn't sound too harsh because there are some really great great parts here - it just doesn't rise to the level of something like Earth Trupet's Roman or the best Nurse With Wound work. [7 Jan 2009]


Date: 30 July 2002

Vas Deferens Organization - Queas And Art

Label: Eerie Materials

Format: CD Compilation

Source: Eric from VDO

Cost: $0

a trade


Date: 1 August 2002

Richard Youngs - Advent

Label: Jagjaguwar

Format: CD Album

Source: Anomalous

Cost: $10.99

Actually this is the Table of the Elements edition. Advent is a beauty though - a real work of genius which I also have on vinyl. It builds up through it's three versions, slowly, so by the time track 3 comes in it's a total explosion. But it's actually the slightly distant second version that I really love, where the oboe creaks in over the piano loop. It's like fog lifting on a Scottish hillside, and it's truly beautiful through it's twisted, strange squeaking. The electric guitars in the third part are a raging storm though, and utterly magnificent. [20 December 2012]


Date: 1 August 2002

Agog - Dust Is Their Food And Clay Their Meat

Label: Anomalous Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Anomalous

Cost: $9.99

Interesting post-NWW-list dark muckery. Can't remember much about this - I must have sold it, or else I just somehow lost it cause I don't have it on the shelf today and haven't seen it for years. [17 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Area - Arbeit Macht Frei (Il Lavoro Rende Liberi)

Label: Cramps

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Area's first record begins with some Italian speech before 'Luglio, agosto, settembre (nero)' kicks in, which is one of the most familiar riffs in the Area canon. This is a hell of an impressive debut and an exemplary progressive rock record, though it doesn't have the fully-integrated progressiveness that their later material gets into. The quieter, more open bits are great but they feel really distanced from the "rock" parts which in turn feel very separate from the "jazz" parts. But this is a simple criticism - there's a swing throughout this, as they didn't abandon the pulse yet and they seem to be lockstep in a vision. [18 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Fairport Convention - The History Of

Label: Island

Format: 2xLP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This is a greatest hits record, really, with a beautiful family tree and booklet. There's a lot of overlap here - about half of What We Did on Our Holidays, Unhalfbricking and Liege and Lief are represented, though since i don't have Unhalfbricking on vinyl I guess that's nice. Nothing from the Judy Dyble era, and no outtakes or rarities unless you count the 'Now Be Thankful' single. It's a pretty good collection I guess, and probably all the Angel Delight/Babbacombe Lee material I'd ever want. I never pull this out but it's probably good for playing 'A Sailor's Life' on vinyl, and the lovely aforementioned family tree artwork. [8 October 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Creative Construction Company - Volume 2

Label: Muse

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Some titans of the AACM assemble here for a concert that was released over two LPs, of which I only have the second. Leroy Jenkins has such a presence; his violins are everywhere but his crude harmonica playing is particularly notable. Muhal Richard Abrams dances all over the keyboard and the Richard Davis/Steve McCall rhythm section knows when to take control, as they do on side two. This is completely free and exploratory, and Braxton is here along with Leo Smith but they are sometimes just a presence. There's no real point where everyone goes apeshit; instead, they let things get very quiet, and when Davis starts bowing it's mesmerising. Braxton and Jenkins interact in a way that sometimes feels like a playful battle; like they are teasing each other, jabbing away until one capitulates. But neither do; it's as sophisticated as it is free. [24 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Anthony Braxton / Derek Bailey - Duo 2

Label: Emanem

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I don't have a lot of Derek Bailey records so I really value this one, which pairs him with Anthony Braxton for a long concert that was originally released as a double LP. This is only the second half but it explores so much territory that it's completely satisfying. The recording quality is fantastic - the microphones are really upclose and there's a perfect balance, so when Bailey is doing more delicate acoustic guitar things, Braxton's sax doesn't drown him out. Actually, Braxton plays quite a lot of flute here, which has a softer tone more suited against the sharp pluckyness of Bailey (who, honesty, sounds like he has about six hands here). A true meeting of the minds, perhaps, and thankfully it was well-documented. [29 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Area - Are(A)zione

Label: Cramps Records

Format: Vinyl Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Area's live album is recorded in front of adoring fans; when they kick into the riff on 'Luglio, Agosto, Septembre' the crowd goes mad and the performance is basically like the album version only with different solos and a more raw, spontaneous feel. This is the least essential Area record I own but I couldn't pass it up at this price; it completes this era of their Cramps recordings and it's fun now and then, though I so rarely get the urge to listen to it. The long title track that starts the second side is the high point (well, apart from the amplified sounds of Stratos chewing and eating between songs on side 1), which builds slowly around a cathartic electric piano vamp and gets into a wide open jam. Good times, but I mostly stick with the studio albums as I like them more the more fucked up they get. [26 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Fairport Convention - What We Did On Our Holidays

Label: A&M

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This is a weird US pressing that actually is self-titled, but is really the second Fairport record (and first with Sandy Denny) -- but the sound is good enough so I can't complain. I don't think Fairport hit their stride til album #3, but you can hear them trying things out. 'Mr. Lacey' takes on an edgey blues-beat, and on a few tracks they sound like the Byrds. 'Fotheringay' and 'Meet on the Ledge' are the standout hits, but there's also a great version of 'She Moves Through the Fair'. Of all the covers of 'I'll Keep it WIth Mine' this isn't the best (I'll take Rainy Day's) but it's certainly passable, and this stuff is pretty much classic status now anyway. [25 September 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Elton Dean's Ninesense - Happy Daze

Label: Ogun

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I have lots of love for the opening track of this Elton Dean excursion, a nine-piece band showcasing some of the finest of the London avant-jazz scene circa 1977. 'Nicrotto' is a restrained, glowing ball of exuberant sound. The brass sounds brassy, the piano relentlessly makes a cloud of soft tones, and the whole piece keeps billowing out like cloud. It reminds me a lot of the opening cut on the Scatter CD I released and the only real mar against Happy Daze is that the rest of the record doesn't hold a candle to it. Dean himself is not as obvious a presence as the twin trumpet/cornet attack of Marc Chatig and Harry Beckett; they have a beautiful interplay even though I'm not sure who is who. There's some great stuff on here though, and overall I appreciate anything with the Moholo/Miller rhythm section, and Keith Tippett is also a nice presence. [28 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Dave Burrell - La Vie De Bohême

Label: BYG Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Dave Burrell takes on Puccini here, in a swinging band with Grachan Moncur III, Beb Guerin, and Claude Delcloo. The free jazz-meets-opera sound works surprisingly well, as Puccini's piano melodies provide a series of quotes which they build around. Because of this structure, Burrell and Moncur are locked into the melodies primarily and it's the rhythm section that actually can fuck around a bit. Moncur plays a lot of flute here, which is quite improvisatory when Burrell is laying down the tune. Everyone gets their solos; Delcloo's is wide and sprawling, Burrell's tends to stay bluesy and melodic, and Moncur is just having fun. It's a true hybrid of a Western classical tradition with an American jazz one, and it's strikingly successful. [26 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Don Cherry - Brown Rice

Label: Horizon

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This whole album is so brilliant and singular that I hate to talk about just one track, but 'Malkauns' is such an incredible sound experience that it stands alone. I'm almost in danger of overplaying it; the tension and release between Haden's opening bass solo and the explosion of wet, echoing cornet is unlike anything else I've ever heard in music. It's pure sound porn. The whole album is great really - the title track is a new vision of music that's never really been explored, and the second half has some great crossover moments too, plus awesome vocal growing. It's awesome to own this. [2 Aug 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Dando Shaft - An Evening With ...

Label: Decca

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Is Dando Shaft a great forgotten folk-rock band with psychedelic and jazz overtones? Or are they just another substandard Pentangle ripoff, lacking strong personalities and obscure for a reason? I think the truth is somewhere in-between. I've always enjoyed the Dando Shaft records I have quite a lot. The mandolin playing is spry, and the way the quick staccato notes are used to create painterly walls of sound is actually quite beautiful, a unique aspect of this band that doesn't really have any contemporaries. Though there's some weak lyrics - 'Cat Song' is a bit painful to get through, the sharp instrumentalism and gentle, naturalistic lyrics make this a very pleasant listen. [17 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Daevid Allen - Bananamoon

Label: Charly

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Sometimes Bananamoon is just over my limit for goofyness, but there's enough hard-psych edges to make this a winner. 'All I Want Is Out of Here' and 'I Am A Bowl' are real gems, the former being a malevolent whirlwind of fear. The long jammy 'Stoned Frankenstein' suite on side 2 has some real moments, as would anything when you put a bunch of talented prog musicians together and get them baked out of their minds in 1970. Maybe a mid-afternoon listen was the wrong time for this; I didn't really lose my mind or anything, but I do very much enjoy this album usually. [2 Aug 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Lol Coxhill, Pierre Courbois, Jasper Van't Hof - Toverbal Sweet

Label: Mushroom

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Coming right after Ear of Beholder, this is a different beast entirely, though it contains elements of free, lively improvisation that are on Ear. This is Coxhill in his natural environment, leading a group of improvisers, in this case mostly Dutch musicians. It's a lot of fun though, with Van't Hof's piano carrying things with fairly straight 4/4 melodies. There's some chunky fusion parts, and the drumming varies between jazz and more abstract/rock/Beefheartian bits. Coxhill sounds true throughout, with his horn clearing a path of everything in its wake. There's a few super short interludes, more like experiments (1/3 of a second long) which emphasise the electicism. The whole session is recorded in a dusty, groggy room and everything sounds a bit underwater, which is a unique choice for 1972 but makes it sounds wooly, warm, and contemporary. [19 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Lol Coxhill - Ear of Beholder

Label: Ampex

Format: 2xLP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Ear of Beholder is a curious album, and one that I feel really helped me in trying to figure out the relationships between improvisation, the artistic personality/ego, product, and presentation. This is a big claim to make about what might just seem like a goofy 2xLP of solo sax improvisations, piano-driven vocal pieces, and field recordings, but I couldn't think of a more accurate presentation of a person's ideas, personality and spirit than this. I've been struggling to bridge this in my own work, which I feel is mostly rooted in open-form exchanges, networks, and inter/trans-disciplinary collaborations. But then what does it mean when I make a record like The 15,000 Day Boat Trip? Or when I sit on stage and play the israj for 20 minutes? How do I bridge my own interests which are musical (which are far more than free improvisation, tape collage, whatever - but almost always geared towards media and the lovely horrible world of consumer-based music objects) with this desire to communicate across cultural lines? I don't think that Coxhill was necessarily motivated by this same urge, 40 years ago when Ear of Beholder was recorded, but I can clearly see that he is far more eclectic than the typical London free-improv dude, and wanted to release a grand statement to reflect that. Some may find this unfocused, or even silly at points, but I almost feel like I understand this man on a personal level because of this record. That he manages to weave some political/social content into a genre that is otherwise abstract and without real-life implications is all the more magnificent, and probably was a big influence on Cutler, Frith and the others doing this later in the decade. The playing, by the way, is great - there's all sorts of things on here, and every track is a delight.  - the man's technique was something special, and there's a few tracks recorded on a dictaphone in public places that have a rusty, creaky edge to them that makes them so much more enjoyable than what might have been recorded more 'cleanly' in a studio. And the honesty is just overwhelming - the spoken introduction, the simple drawings as artwork, and especially the humble "thank you" written on the back cover drawing -- it's as close as anything I've ever seen that can actually be a friendly, welcoming document of experimental jazz explorations. The other Coxhill records I have are also great but this is the one I truly cherish. [30 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Lol Coxhill - The Joy Of Paranoia

Label: Ogun

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This is split between a quartet with some British musicians, and some duets with Veryan Weston or Michael Garrick. Lol does his soprano thing well here, in a really improvised jam on side A with the quintet - it gets rowdy near the end, with Ken Shaw's electric guitar kicking up some dust. Then on the flip it's the sax/piano duets, which are organised around 4 movements with Weston and 2 with Garrick. In the middle is a short solo piece, the title track, an exuberant bit of magic that's the most memorable cut here. But Coxhill is such a treasure, he brings something crafty even with these other obscure musicians who don't distinguish themselves much. [3 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Kevin Ayers - John Cale - Brian Eno - Nico - June 1, 1974

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

The story behind this record, or at least behind why John Cale sounds so deranged and desperate on 'Heartbreak Hotel', is because he discovered just before the concert began that Kevin Ayers banged his wife. I'm not sure if that's true, but I love this version of 'Heartbreak Hotel' because of said vocal delivery - plus, the twisted female background singers, and the biting guitar. There's a whole lot more of Ayers than anything else - all of side 2 is really dedicated to his songs, but 's ok cause I like Ayers. Eno's contributions are 'Driving Me Backwards' and 'Baby's On Fire', the former being a great leadoff track - and his synths under Nico's 'The End' are awesome too. This feel like a bit of a cash grab for Island because as interesting as all of these artist were on June 1, 1974, this is no way essential. Also, Robert Wyatt has never contributed less to anything he's ever contributed to. [28 July 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Henry Cow - Unrest

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

The second Henry Cow record and I've always liked this one, maybe the most - it maintains a bleak edge, as the greyed-out sock indicates. But despite the minor key, there's a cohesive band pushing ahead with that distinctly British progressive rock sound, and I can't help but find it triumphant. 'Ruins' is one of the best, most epic Henry Cow songs. Lindsay Cooper's reeds add colour throughout, lending this a somewhat medieval British music feel at times, which ties together the history and content of the songwriting. Frith's compositions are moody, but sit well against the band's collective pieces. 'Linguaphonie' brings vocals into the mix, over a churning bassoon lick and exploratory Frith/Cutler stuff - a stunning track, which is playful and raucous while adhering to the dark mood. A bit more singing closes out the LP, I think it's John Greaves, and it's sort of elegiac. Rock in opposition, yes. [27 July 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Amon Düül II - Phallus Dei

Label: Sunset Records (UK)

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Phallus Dei has mad guitar solos, fast drum breaks, and a huge, epic acid-rock sound. It drives forward like a juggernaut, and the jam on side B, 'Phallus Dei', is a compendium of Krautrock ideas. By the end it's simmered down to a violin-driven drone jam, which reminds me of the Pärson Sound, and it's a wonderful comedown. I haven't listened to this in awhile as I've been playing the Yeti reissue mostly when wanting some Amon Düül II, but this is satisfying as well. [9 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Air - Air Lore

Label: Arista Novus

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

The weakest Air record I have, or maybe I'm just bored by it. This is a blatant stab at commercial success, being all covers of standards. I'm not against Jelly Roll Morton or Scott Joplin - and I'm all for history playing a role in contemporary music. It's just that what I like about Air is the interplay between these musicians and Threadgill's gestalt compositional style. There's a few nice solos here, but I can't help but see this as a move away from innovative composition and towards crowd-pleasing retro-fetishism. There's a Jelly Roll Morton tune on another one I have and that might be as much Air 'Lore' as I'll ever need. [17 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Area - Maledetti

Label: Cramps

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Area's wildest ride is probably my favourite release of them, which I used to own on CD but was able to upgrade to this lovely Cramps original. There's a lot of madness here, particualrly on side two, including classical music samples, primitive instrument bashing and accomplished sax solos by Steve Lacy. Stratros belts it out on side 1, but there's also parts where he's sputtering and babbling, like he's having a nervous breakdown.This all comes crashing to a halt on 'Caos', an aptly named track that is the last song on the last Area record I own (though Event 76 came out later, it was recorded earlier); it feels like a fitting conclusion. I know there are some later releases I should check out but I probably never will. [30 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

V/A - Greasy Truckers Live At Dingwalls Dance Hall

Label: Gama Records Limited

Format: 2xVinyl Album LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I bought this not for the sexy women drawn on the cover but becase it's got Henry Cow and Gong, as well as Camel and the Global Village Trucking Co., a one-off band. The Camel side is actually pretty hot - a grooving 'Radar Love' kinda vibe with some new volume-knob guitar swells and a kinetic beat underneath. The Cow side is the best by far - it opens with unrestrained free improvisation before crashing into something more composed. The one-off band is pretty insufferable soul rock, but then Gong makes up for it on the D-side.It's a deep, jammy excursion, a call to arms for the psychedelic beast that was Planet Gong. There are some pretty, delicate guitar parts (kundali guitar and glissando guitar as credited, though you can never really understand what the hell Gong people are talking about). [29 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Kevin Ayers - Yes We Have No Mañanas (So Get Your Mañanas Today)

Label: ABC Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This later Ayers record is a lot of things, but 'good' was not one of them. Sold during a subsequent purge.


Date: 2 August 2002

Kevin Ayers - Whatevershebringswesing

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This is a relatively low-key Ayers album but one I really dig; I like the more mellow, less goofy approach and I wouldn't put this on par with Shooting At the Moon but I definitely prefer it to Joy of a Toy. There's still some bouncy, rambunctious Ayersisms ('Stranger in Blue Suede Shoes') and the beautiful title track.  Bits of 'Joy of a Toy' are faded in and out of the strange, contemplative 'Champagne Cowboy Blues' as well. Lots of references to being high here, and the artwork suggests a more mature and dark flavour, though can Ayers really truly grow up? [28 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

V/A - Hoisting The Black Flag

Label: United Dairies

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition Compilation

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This is a great compilation of early United Dairies artists, which means it's a mix of strange sounds, mostly British in origin. The music is all experimental, but formed; song-based in some cases (Lemon Kittens, Truth Club) and also using tape loops and samples. The Nurse With Wound track is great, built around voices talking about aspiring; David Cross (who I think is the same one from King Crimson, not the standup comedian) has probably my favourite cut on the record, a multi-tracked mess of sharp cutting sound sources. Paul Hamilton and Joseph Duarte's 'Dance Music' is playful, like a Fred Frith improvisation mixed with echoey musique concrete - it's a beautiful track, occupying some space between early "industrial" music and free jazz.  The Whitehouse tracks are the low point for me, not because I dislike Whitehouse but because such harsh, abrasive sounds jar with the eclectic nature of the rest of the record. [25 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Jacques Coursil Unit - Way Head

Label: BYG/Actuel

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Slow moving, unfolding jazz odyssey from some lesser known figures in the late 60's avant/free scene. The interplay is somewhat low key, dark in tone, and built around tension. The side-long Bill Dixon composition puts Coursil's trumpet at the forefront, complemented nicely by Beb Guerin's arco bass. Guerin also has a bass solo at the end of side one that is pretty nice. [8 Feb 2005]


Date: 2 August 2002

Don Cherry - "Mu" First Part

Label: Affinity

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

The Mu records are a beautiful bit of musical consciousness - a true communication between Cherry and Ed Blackwell. It's not about virtuoso freakouts here, though both are exemplary at their craft. This is about Cherry taking a major step forward in his transition from Blue Note recording artist/Ornette Coleman sideman to the the magical troubadour of indescribable earthpulse that he became. Mu is built around trumpet, piano and flutes, and it's a psychedelic experience that connects the human heart to the ground beneath. It's seeming formlessness echoes the motivations of the human mind. Jazz is a starting point - certainly there are some responsive back and forth moments, with Blackwell delicately responding to Cherry's whims, which are not out of place on any of the late 60's skronk classics. But this is a step forward - the dawning of a new age. [28 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Don Cherry - Complete Communion

Label: Blue Note

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

The title of Complete Communion suggests a drone-like trance, something Buddhist or deeply spiritual perhaps -- or maybe it's just a communion of improvising musicians. This is part of Cherry's Blue Note trilogy, an important turning point before his more out explorations on Mu, Blue Lake, etc. It's built around open form post-bop jazz, with breaks for solos and melodic frameworks, but has not yet abandoned form completely. The band is shit-hot -- Gato Barbieri and Cherry come together for dual cornet/sax bursts that are really supportive of each other, yet extend the melodic explorations. Henry Grimes is the bassist and I've always considered him one of my favourites; with Ed Blackwell, it's a playful, spry combination. Side one is 'Complete Communion', broken into four movements, around a repeating theme with a slightly Spanish inflection ('Rememberance' at the end opens it up like a circus) which is possibly Barbieri's influence. Side two is 'Elephantasy', a bit more goodtimey, but with some beautiful Cherry trumpeting, especially at the end. [7 Aug 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Amon Düül II - Dance Of The Lemmings

Label: United Artists Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I often say this is my favourite Amon Düül II record. It's more prog-based than the previous two, as the mesmerising opening cut, 'Syntelman's March of the Roaring Seventies' really blends together incredible rock riffage with good songwriting - and looks ahead to Wolf City. This is pressed in that old style where sides 1 and 4 are on the same platter, so I always forget and listen to the end in the middle, which is OK because the ending track, 'Toxicological Whispering' is too riff-rocking awesome to want to wait until the end. Some of this reminds me of the more guitar-based bits on The Faust Tapes but the Yeti-style is quite prevelant too - it's infectious without being poppy, and the singing is really tasteful and genuinely weird and scary. The entire side 3 is the epic jam to counterbalance the rock, and it's perfect. A landmark, for sure - but I like all four of the AD2 records I have so this is just a high water mark among a very high ocean anyway. [22 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Art Ensemble Of Chicago, The Art Ensemble Of Chicago - Phase One

Label: America Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I have a lot of Art Ensemble records and I tend to forget about this one. Side one is a long Joseph Jarman piece that after the requisite quiet explorations, explodes into a rolling frolick, with some great Lester Bowie saturation. The B-side is a group composition, a tribute to Albert Ayler though it doesn't sound like Ayler at all. This is a staggering exploration - meaning it sounds like it's staggering around, never quite landing. There's an upcast exuberance for sure but it doesn't explode when you want it to. Vibes and reverberating bells give this an almost new-agey flavour at points. It's strangely feelgood and bluesy by the end, but only for a tease. [18 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Bert Jansch & John Renbourn - Bert And John

Label: Transatlantic

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

There's no shortage of places to hear Bert Jansch and John Renbourn together, but I think this is one of their earlier pairings. It's stripped down, purely guitars, with only a bit of singing by Jansch (one song on each side) and mostly originals, the exceptions being covers of Mingus's 'Goodbye Pork-pie Hat' and an Anne Brings tune. The playing feels a bit stiff, but not from a lack of comfort - almost like a deliberate tension, which renders the Mingus song curiously inelastic. Given Pentangle's love of jazz, and Mingus in particular, it's not a surprise, though I wished the drummer from Pentangle was there to make it more snappy. Side one's 'Soho' is a great tune that sounds like something from Jansch's solo work, and the record feels like an important step in the developmentt of their partnership, if not completely essential. [25 July 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Area - Crac!

Label: Cramps Records

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This Area record is maybe a definitive one, as in it "sounds like Area". There isn't any crazy Steve Lacy-style free improv, and it's much more rooted in progressive rock tropes than the later stuff like Maledetti. The fast runs of notes are very much in the vein of rock music, even on tracks that get a bit more exploratory. Lots of jamming, yeah, and Stratos's voice is typically astounding. There's a proper political folk/rock song in the middle of it all,which centers things a bit from the incessant riffing. Only the last track gets truly weird, but it feels like a tossed off spazzfest. Crac! is overall solid, though I like Area's more free styles the most, which are least apparent here. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Area - Event '76

Label: Cramps

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

An Area record in name only, I guess, this is really Demetrio Stratos, Paul Litton, Steve Lacy, Paolo Tofani and Patrizio Fariselli jamming like it's the end of the world. There is no resemblance to the explosive arena-prog on their regular Cramps releases. Even Maledetti, their most experimental and dadaist release, sounds tame compared to this. This is akin to the Futura records sound of the time, with moments that recall Jac Berrocal's explorations - all through a spooky, reverb-laden room which enhances Lacy's inhuman sax runs and Stratos's disembodied weirdness. Totally amazing, but not really what I want when listening to Area; maybe it's something better. [29 October 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Air - Open Air Suit

Label: Arista Novus

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Threadgill's compositions are always brainy but enjoyable. Open Air Suit is built around a theme of card games, suggesting a game approach to improvisation. It must be quite conceptual - the cover has a Mandrill bending over to show its coloured ass, which is the title of the first track. It's built around McCall's drumming, very solid, and the record opens with a very flat rhythm over which Threadgill sniffs out some tune-constructing. He switches to flute on the b-side for the sneaky sounding 'Card Cutten', where Threadgill and Hopkins seem to be engaged in a tug of war. It never gets aggressive; like most Chicago-school dudes, there's a focus that lends all of their music an impressive vitality. [23 August 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Air - 80 Degrees Below '82

Label: Antilles

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Some good parts on this Air record - a few in that Threadgill style of slow, lumbering compositions that open up with lots of space. But also some safe, inside traditional work - it opens with a Jelly Roll Morton piece. Air's aptly named cause there's a lot of it in these songs, which are smart and probing, but never heavy. [7 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Captain Beefheart - The Spotlight Kid

Label: Reprise Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Beefheart's two post-Decals records take a turn towards accessibility, at least in my mind, and I have listened to them the least of any of his output. However, The Spotlight Kid has some fantastic tunes, and there's enough mania (and leftover marimba from Decals) to stand up straight. The major difference is that while Trout Mask and Decals sound like music from another world, on this album (and Clear Spot) it sounds like music made by really strange humans. 'Glider' is a near-epic to close with and 'White Jam' is constructed in a really incredible way -- this is one that I should really find more time for. [25 September 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Quiet Sun - Mainstream

Label: Polydor (UK)

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I used to regard this as the high point of this style of 70's British prog rock.  The band is tight, first-rate musicians and the compositions are very much of the genre yet possessing something extra - an admirable quality of experimentation within the confines of crunch guitar riffs and neoclassical noodling.  Of course I'm biased cause I love Chaz Hayward and he's bashing away and singing on the wonderful last song 'Rongwrong', a proto-Heat track not just because of his piercing vocals but also Bill MacCormick's long bass solo over Dave Jarrett's resounding electric piano chords - it's exploratory and surreal and beautiful.  Listening for the first time in a few years, I find this slightly more generic than I remembered, though it's still a fantastic album, and far more than the forgettable Roxy Music side-project it was probably dismissed as during its time.  There's some Crimsony parts, other jams that sound like Hatfield and the North - actually I'm not usually fond of the electric piano but there are some lovely shimmering moments at the end of side 1.  But still, it all comes back to 'Rongwrong' - the playful singsong quality is actually great, shades of  'Moon in June' as Hayward talks about how to 'levitate my soul in six easy lessons' and 'stay home and listen to Schoenberg in the bath'.  Ah, pre-punk 70's - things never sounded more precise than here.  [6 Feb 2009]



Date: 2 August 2002

Muhal Richard Abrams - Lifea Blinec

Label: Arista Novus

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

A full band featuring Joseph Jarman and Douglas Ewart, this is my favorite of the Muhal Richard Abrams records that I have.  There's some rocking full-band blowouts and some crazed bits when it opens up.  Amina Claudine Myers contributes some singing - not enough, really - and the spirit of AACM from their peak is heard in the title track and "Ja Do Thu".  The duo pieces that end the record are a bit of a downer but they sound wonderful, as the piano interplays with little percussive bits like magic.  The fuller sounding parts of this record remind me a bit of Henry Threadgill which isn't surprising since they were colleagues.  [16 April 2009]



Date: 2 August 2002

Nico - The End...

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87
