Nothing quite says 'pick me up' like a spin of Nico's The End! My copy is a bit warped on the outer section - but this is warped music anyway. The arrangements are so heavy here - bagpipes, vacant electronic drones, and austere piano - yet it's still warm and inviting, as least to my ears. The second side is where she blasts through the title track, the Doors cover which is an extremely unsettling listening experience. But the real highlight for me is the closer, the strange, patriotic song for Germany, sung in full Teutonic ardour over thick, overlapping organ. It's like Charlemagne Palestine gone Nazi, and therefore laden with the history/baggage of postwar German identity. I can't understand the lyrics, nor do I really want to, so maybe I'm reading into this a lot, but knowing about the explosion of unrest among mid-70s German youth, I can't help but make the association and feel a curious power. [20 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Muhal Richard Abrams - Sightsong

Label: Black Saint

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This album bills Malachi Favors as second fiddle, but really is his place to shine.  The eight pieces are piano/bass duets that are mostly pretty relaxed, with some nice harmonic interplay and somewhat dreamy, arpeggiated piano runs to infuse some atmosphere.  Favor's bass is tuned strangely (or perhaps he is experimenting with different intonation) and these strange intervals make for the most compelling listening (particularly on his earthy, crunchy bass solo at the beginning of side 2).  Abrams is a somewhat underrated pianist, though this record is too accessible to be thrilling and too casual to contain any spiritual highs.  I think I like it best when they mess around in minor territory. [15 Apr 2009]



Date: 2 August 2002

Air - Montreux Suisse

Label: Arista Novus

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

A good live Air record from a Swiss festival. You can feel the open space here, especialy on the B-side. McCall and Hopkins open that up with a long, rhytmic piece that's a solo for both at times, but very restrained, focusing on the pulse. Threadgill sounds great, at always; his smooth yet piercing tone dominates the first side and even when he hangs back, his presence is felt. But that's why Air was a great group - the three had a perfect balance, a dynamic that keeps the others in check and proves to be interesting even on that record I have of jazz standards. This is actually my favourite Air record, of the ones I have, because it is the most free and exploratory. [2 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Anthony Braxton - Composition No. 95 For Two Pianos

Label: Arista

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This is one of the more odd Braxton releases I own, placing Ursula Oppens and Fred Rzewski in a duet. The photo on the back shows them both wearing monk-like robes, which makes me perceive this entire recording as a weird contemporary classical renaissance faire thing. There's also zither and melodica here, making the title mostly inaccurate. The two pianos have a strong interplay and I actually really enjoy this record, which has jazz-like runs and blues impressions yet stays in orbit around a centre. The slower parts feel very improvisatory, and it's hard to think they aren't at least somewhat - composing this type of fluidity would be impossible. But then they stop on a dime and go into some crazy counterpoint. I'm not sure which is which, in terms of musician, but there's a unity here that suggests a deeper musical relationship between these two than just being interpreters of a Braxton score. [19 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Anthony Braxton - New York, Fall 1974

Label: Arista

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I have so many Braxton records but that's because each of them has something rewarding. This is a bright, boomy mid-70's band with some solid musicians performing these unpronounceable compositions. Dave Holland, who I am always a fan of, as well as Jerome Cooper, Kenny Wheeler, and some (for the time, emerging) NYC guys on the B-side - Hemphill, Bluiett, and Oliver Lake. But the most distinctive track is the jam between Braxton and MEV's Richard Teitelbaum, a meeting of clarinet and synth which is furtive and daring, a real diversion into outer space. [19 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Kevin Ayers And The Whole World - Shooting At The Moon

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I love this album. I used to own it on CD but loaned it to someone a decade ago. This original Harvest pressing is somewhat battered (and my frequent listens haven't helped), plus the side 1 label is on both sides (but the previous owner, maybe Ross, wrote "side one" in ink). Ayers had a shit-hot band here that featured Lol Coxhill and Mike Oldfield, and this gives it the right balance between prog-rock and outer limits explorations. The songs are also balanced between some of his most tuneful pop jams ("May I", "The Oyster and the Flying Fish") and some absolutely fucked up monster jams. The title track closes it out and it's just stunning; though this pressing lacks the dynamics the CD used to (there, I said it for once) I'm still glad to have it. [29 September 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Anthony Braxton - Five Pieces 1975

Label: Arista

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This Braxton release from his Arista area is quite boucy, and begins with a cover version of a Maceo Herb Brown song -- not something to expect from Braxton, but he keeps the post-bop approach throughout, even when the band comes in. The closing track (unfortunately impossible to render even in UTF-8, like most of his titles) is a stomper - energetic (which I don't often think of Braxton as being), yet still brainy, and with a great group interplay dynamic. [13 July 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Anthony Braxton - Creative Orchestra Music 1976

Label: Arista

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Braxton's really got the orchestra cooking here - this explodes with a really sweet, soulful tune where various soloists take lead for just a line or two before the group crashes in, all over a swinging beat that seems to stave off the nervous, almost apocalyptic feeling caused by this much energy. This lively, big-band feel keeps up across side 1 - the last track (of course a pictorial title I can't write) isn't a million miles off a John Phillip Sousa jam. The second side begins with a left-field, classically somber Braxton exploration - slow, opening, and with plucking, exploratory piano and tentative, droning brass. The rest of the LP plays out in a similar vibe - slow, sneaky, and careful, but nonetheless expressive, as the increased use of space lets the vibrato really ring out. It's a good portrayal of Braxton at this point, having a little something for every mood. [1 October 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

V/A - Subterranean Modern

Label: Ralph Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

[Chrome, MX-80 Sound, The Residents, Tuxedomoon].each { get a quarter of a LP to do what they want, providing they cover 'I Left My Heart in San Francisco', appropriate since Ralph is an SF label. } Chrome and MX-80 Sound make up the more rockin' side 1, though both sorta blow off their cover. Opening cut 'Anti-Face' by Chrome is the highlight, and the MX-80 tracks feel so convetional against these other weirdos. The Residents do the best 'Heart' version, and then some totally retarded stuff ('Dumbo the Clown (Who Loved Christmas)' is amazingly idiotic, plus has Fred Frith on guitar) before Tuxedomoon take over with a great conceptual cover of 'San Francisco', the moody 'Everything You Want' and then the ethereal instrumental 'Waterfront Seat'. Great Gary Panter cover art too! [16 July 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Michael Mantler - The Hapless Child (And Other Inscrutable Stories)

Label: Watt

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This is a somewhat forgotten record of Michael Mantler writing music to Edward Gorey lyrics, with a great delivery by Robert Wyatt. The songs are in that progressive rock/jazz hybrid, though since there aren't any brass instruments here, it comes off as much more rock. The band is made from the usual Watt crew, with a rhythm section of  Steve Swallow and Jack deJohnette, and then Terje Rypdal doing searing guitar lines throughout while Carla Bley plays intense, driving piano throughout. I don't think Mantler himself actually plays at all here - at least not trumpet - and he's not credited as a musician - so I guess this is a compositional project. The record is lots of fun thanks to Wyatt's presence, which puts everything in that familiar tone, plus his whimsicality suits the dark fun of Gorey's lyrics. There's only six songs so this is more like a mini-LP, but it's a great time thanks to the band getting pretty loose. Henry Cow is actually probably the closest comparison musically, except there's not as much exploration. [8 Aug 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Anthony Braxton - 3 Compositions Of New Jazz

Label: Delmark Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I always treated this like gold, thinking it was an original pressing, but the always trusty discogs.com suggests it's actually a 1972 repress. That's no reason not to love it -- this is a fantastic debut, a masterpiece of improvised music (though I know, I know, it's 'composed') that ranks against the best late 60's AACM sides, maybe the very best. Little instruments, piano, horns, and eveything you'd expect is there -- there's a range of dynamics that was probably unlike anything anyone outside of Chicago was doing. If I have one complaint it's that this doesn't feel particularly 'Braxton' - like he hadn't yet found his compositional voice, and the distinctly cerebral edge that defines his vision. Don't tell anyone, but I'm not complaining. [25 September 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Muhal Richard Abrams - Live at Montreaux, 1978

Label: Arista Novus

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

The best kind of live solo piano records are the ones where you can really hear the night - the audience, the room, and the air are if not audible at least a presence on the record.  I don't know how many live solo piano records I've actually heard; I guess I'm just basing this on some Cecil Taylor ones.  Poor Richard Abrams has probably always lived a bit in Taylor's shadow (as all free pianists probably do) though his style is probably a lot closer to McCoy Tyner during the classic Coltrane work.  These three "songs" (as they are titled) reveal three different sides of Abrams.  The first, 'D Song', is made up primarily of single notes runs played rapidly.  'String Song' is a total departure - it's Abrams playing the inside of the piano, banging on some percussion and ringing a few gongs.  It's a nice change of pace but it feels a little bit unfocused.  'Voice Song', the 20 minute track that is the entire side 2, is a more general piano workout.  There are busy fast moments and delicate bits, as well as some rumbling softer parts, and while it certainly demonstrates his talents as a piano improviser I'm sometimes left a bit cold in knowing what it actually expresses.  If music is a spiritual force for Abrams (as the liner notes indicate) then that's fine enough, but listening to a live experience 30 years later I can't say that I completely connect with it.  [16 April 2009]



Date: 2 August 2002

Red Krayola Red Crayola - Parable Of Arable Land

Label: Charly Records Ltd.

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Ah, the Familiar Ugly! My first encounter with early Red Crayola was a bootleg CD of the first two albums, which had a terrible, washed out sound quality and a somewhat fucked up track listing. This LP sounds the way it should - those free form freak-outs scream out of the vinyl and I swear you can hear all 50 weirdos plucking about with their glass bottles and cardboard boxes. I tend to forget about this one in favour of God Bless... but there's some great, fucked up songs here - 'Transparent Radiation', and the genius 'Former Reflections Enduring Doubt' to name but two. Mayo is just beginning to figure himself out, but his voice has all the honesty you could ever want, and despite the freak-outs and the reverb and all the other things people did in 1967, they sound like the gang of outsider nutjobs they were (instead of another jammy drug band). The freak-outs are integrated pretty well, and this actually pre-dates the Nihilist Spasm Band's first record, which is remarkable because there's a real affinity of sound. 'Parable of Arable Land', the song, is a great piece of minimalist work that accidentally presages decades of out-sound fuckery for years to come. This doesn't quite usurp Easter Everywhere as the best International Artists/Texas psych record, but it's surely a contender (along with Bubblepuppy!).  [16 July 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Can - Tago Mago

Label: United Artists Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Can's masterpiece, arguably, but it's a good argument. The most exploratory tracks ('Peking O', 'Aumgn') are, simply put, some of the most incendiary and challenging experimental music ever put to tape. It's balanced with some more song and riff-based tunes, like the immortal 'Halleluwah'. As long and sprawling as this is, it's basically perfection. My copy isn't the classic cover but a weird British pressing in a matchbox-style sleeve, lovely in its own right, but due to rip eventually. After forty years it's still holding up but I get nervous every time I play this, which is often. [3 October 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Christopher Hobbs / John Adams / Gavin Bryars - Ensemble Pieces

Label: Editions EG

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I file this under 'H' for Hobbs because he's the constant over both sides, though it's hard to figure out what to do when Eno is releasing records this disjointed. 'Aran' begins is, which is Hobbs and Bryars together on reed organ and some toy instruments, with lots of overdubs. It reminds me of Moondog or Lou Harrison, but with a more somber, contemplative edge due to the constant presence of the organ. John Adams has a piece for a larger ensemble, split into three movements. 'John Philip Sousa' is a slowly accelerating bit of repetition that fails to achieve the playfulness that the Residents managed with their Sousa tribute. 'Christian Zeal and Activity' is a beautiful piece of orchestra minimalism that becomes overtaken by a recording from religious talk radio; shades of GYBE!'s 'BBF3' or Sun City Girls' 'Napoleon and Josephine', but years before either. 'Sentimentals' is a pretty melodic piece based around Duke Ellington's 'Sophisticated Lady'. On the B-side we get more Hobbs/Bryars organ minimalism, and then a very experimental Bryars piece called '1,2,1-2-3-4' which again I must compare to the Residents, or that Legion of RockStars YouTube band. The liner notes explain how various musicians (including Derek Bailey, Cornelius Cardew, and Andy MacKay) play along while wearing isolating headphones. The effect is druggy, disorientating, and somewhat chilling, and I rather like it. [29 July 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Hugh Hopper - Hopper Tunity Box

Label: Compendium Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Late 70's Hugh Hopper lacks the outness of 1984 but has a really heavy organ part in the middle of side 1 that sounds like Castlevania with a fuzz bass behind it. It's a studio affair, with Hopper and a rotating cast of sidemen that includes Elton Dean, Dave Stewart and Nigel Morris. The usual British prog stuff is here, but side two features a cover of Ornette Coleman's 'Lovely Woman' that goes for delicacy and tenderness, a wise move. Some of the slower thick bass guitar licks remind me of all those Pittsburgh-style bands that would just riff over a drummer, only slowed down here and with all the aggression removed. The final cut is Hopper solo, a moody meandering melody that is probably the most charming track on here. [24 September 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Kevin Ayers - Joy Of A Toy

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Kevin Ayers' first album is generally regarded as his best but I find it lacks the musical freakout madness of Shooting at the Moon, and the songwriting, while stellar, lacks the melancholy magic of Whatevershebringswesing. But I'm nitpicking - this is a much-deserved psychedelic classic, based around Ayers' genial personality, which just soaks these songs with a good-time feel. Even the minor key intensities in tunes like 'Lady Rachael' end up resolving in a singsong chorus; the darker psych tinges of tracks like 'Stop This Train' are offset by a songwriting style based somewhat in English music hall traditions -- and a fairytale vibe. Soft Machine is the backing band on 'Song for Insane Times' but the song is anything but insane - it's more like Tony Clifton-style lounge cabaret commentary. Ayers plays most of the instruments here but on the next album he forms The Whole World, and that's where things really take off. [18 August 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Richard Thompson - Henry The Human Fly

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Thompson's first solo album is a stunner; it sort of beats out any single Fairport album I've heard as a whole, for there's not a dud song on here. The more orchestrated English-sounding stuff is good, but when he stays true to writing rock/folk songs with a simple backing band, it's even better. The guitar solos are relatively restrained cause this is an album for his songwriting to shine, and his vocals are strong as well. There's still a bit of joyousness here, even on songs like 'The Angels Took My Racehorse Away', especially compared to the misery that would follow on his work with Linda Thompson, still Linda Peters on this album. Nice playing by Barry Dransfield on fiddle, Sandy Denny on piano (!) and a horn section that underplays, which is what's perfect for this feel. [25 September 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Maddy Prior and June Tabor - Silly Sisters

Label: Chrysalis

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

These two sound amazing together and this record is built around showcasing exactly that. It's a mix of a-capella and instrument-backed songs, with the usual gang of Brit-folk luminaries (Martin Carthy, Nic Jones, Danny Thompson). The arrangements are sometimes casual (June's 'Geordie', which just has Carthy strumming behind, is splendid) and sometimes more ornate ('Doffin' Mistress' gets quite Defender of the Crown in places). The solo duets - 'Burning of Auchidoon', 'My Husband's Got No Courage in Him', 'Four Loom Weaver' - are spellbinding. The production is crisp but not overdone, letting the voices ring out. While 'silly' is not quite accurate, there's a lightness throughout, carried by their enthusiasm for the material. [18 December 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Magma - Attahk

Label: Arabella

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I don't know what to say about Attahk - in some ways, it reminds me of an Area record, with the over the top operatic vocals in a language I can't understand, except it's an invented language instead of Italian. But the jazzy cadences are there, and the impressive drumming, guitar playing and song structures - and my distance from both of those records are equal, except maybe I like Area a bit more because it feels more political and adventurous. 'Maahnt' has a somewhat 'Third Uncle' vibe, with an edge bassline and the vocals being yelped, felt but not really heard. No disrepect to Magma, who I am a casual fan of, but Attahk feels more adult contemporary at points than I'd like it to, such as the last part of side 1 which has these female vocals in a pseudo-opratic style around a sensitive piano melody, and the Zeuhl thing is something I've never totally bought into, so I can only assess it one Earthly tones. As much as I love that Magma exists, I don't click with them on a 100% level and I think I like the other two records better. [21 August 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Floh de Cologne - Lucky Streik

Label: 

Format: 2xLP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

Theatrical, Zappa-influenced German prog that bears little resemblance to the Krautrock canon. Sold.


Date: 2 August 2002

Richard & Linda Thompson - First Light

Label: Chrysalis

Format: Vinyl

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This is a later R&L record, and not as dark and depressing as I like - neither the world-sucks misery of I Want to See the Bright Lights Tonight nor the relationship-is-over misery of Shoot Out the Lights is here, but as the third of their albums with the word 'light' in the name, it's ok. The sound is much more akin to the soft-rock sounds of Fleetwood Mac than the Fairport style, though Richard gets feudal on 'The Choice Wife'. The Linda-sung songs are lovely but I prefer Richard's voice, on songs like 'House of Cards'. The production and arrangements are so somber, even when the songs are upbeat, that there's no guitar shredding; I want another song as heavy as 'Calvary Cross' anywhere in his discography, but I don't think it exists. [18 August 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

V/A - Ohrenschmaus - Neue Pop-Musik Aus Deutschland

Label: Ohr

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

A very, very cool double LP compilation, Ohrenschmaus is practically a who's who of great Krautrock from the time. It begins with Amon Düül's 'Paramechanical World', an intense, yearning b-side from a single I never heard before. There's also tracks from Limbus, Annexus Quam, Witthüser & Westrupp, Embryo, Floh de Cologne, Tangerine Dream and Guru Guru, and the long format allows these artists to spread out a bit, which is exactly what you want from this type of music. This is presented as new "pop music" but the screeching reeds and strings of Limbus, or the dense drone of Tangerine Dream show that this is anything but popular. Witthüser & Westrupp share the last side with Floh de Cologne, and it adds a songy, operatic vibe to things. Their tracks don't do a whole lot for me, as a non-German speaker, but the trumpet playing is nice over the folky strum. [22 August 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

V/A - A Random Sampler

Label: Random Radar Records

Format: Vinyl LP Compilation

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This compilation has a lot of interesting experimental work from people like Lol Coxhill and Fred Frith. My favourites are probably Logproof, a very precise band that somehow manages to sound broken, and Steve Feigenbaum, who has a lovely solo guitar piece as well as a band track as well. The Frith pieces are casual, simple electric guitar jams, but pretty nice. Illegal Aliens (whoever they are) have one of the more interesting rock tracks, with a Ralph-style edge. Discogs shows this was their only ever release/appearance so I don't know what became of them. But Random Radar was fairly short-lived itself. [25 August 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

V/A - New Music For Electronic And Recorded Media

Label: 1750 Arch Records

Format: Vinyl LP Compilation

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

This is an awesome release of mid-70s electronic composition by all-female composers. Though the liner notes draw attention to this, the rest of the packaging doesn't make a big deal out of it, though Pauline Oliveros included a photo of an old man with a moustache for hers. Her track, by the way, is nuts - built around a sample of an opera recording, with wild synthesizer screams over it. Megan Roberts has the most tribal-sounding and least electronic piece on here, built around chanting and drums. It sounds more like Invasion of the Thunderbolt Pagoda or the Cro-Magnon record, and feels a bit odd between Laurie Spiegel and Ruth Anderson's minimalist synth. Annea Lockwood contributes probably my favourite work on the record, a static, ghost-like piece that is sadly too short. And finally, Laurie Anderson doing what she does - a spoken word narrative piece over sharp, buzzing electronics, also clashing with the rest of the album, but pretty fun anyway. [23 November 2012]


Date: 2 August 2002

Orchestra M. Skrandrani - Musique Classique Algerienne

Label: Pathé

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.87

I've never really heard music like Mustapha Skandrani's piano-driven Algerian magic. There's an unceasing forward motion, but it stalls, lurches, and lunges through various uplifting crescendos/decrescendos. Throughout it all, the piano playing noodles along, incredibly free, pure liquid ivory. It's so incredibly human - and when the horns come in to accentuate these melodic experiments it feels accidental, almost like something the band is trying out, without committing. I've loved this for years, but never thought to look for anything else by Skandrani, but perhaps I should - or maybe Algerian music in general is something to check out - the Rai I've heard has been cool, though nothing at all like this. [22 August 2012]


Date: 16 August 2002

Dead C - New Electric Music

Label: Language Recordings

Format: CD Album Stereo

Source: Paul's

Cost: $14



Date: 16 August 2002

Mekons - OOOH! (Out Of Our Heads)

Label: Quarterstick Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $13

A new Mekons CD is certainly cause for celebration, especially as their last record is probably my favorite out of their whole career. This one doesn't quite live up to the beauty of the last one, though it's still good. It's a bit more rock, and has a different feel, so I really shouldn't compare them - for it's the Mekons, and constant change is their trademark. My fave track: "Winter," a song with really beautiful lyrics that is one of their best ever. It's nice to know that some artists don't wither away in old age, but keep getting better (or at least stay consistent). [3 January 2004]


Date: 16 August 2002

Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso UFO - Absolutely Freak Out (Zap Your Mind!!)

Label: Resonant

Format: 2xCD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $9

Acid Moms dropped a lot of releases around this time and I usually cite La Novia as the high point, but it's hard to argue with this, which packs so much Acid Mothers Temple into two discs that it touches on almost everything they do. The opening cut is a long, dense blast of repetition and it's amazing on its own; that it's followed with 1 and 3/4 more discs of hot psych jams is just icing on the cake. There's ferocious guitar hellstorms, busted up improvisations, and spacey excursions; disc two starts with what sounds like Steve Reich-influenced trance-minimalism. By the end my brain has fallen out of my head, which is exactly the point. I stopped listening to this band for about 8 years so its actually quite rewarding to go back and let this massive psychedelia wash over me. [30 December 2012]


Date: 16 August 2002

Love - Love Story

Label: 

Format: 2xCD

Source: Record exchange

Cost: $0

(trade-in)


Date: 17 August 2002

The Pentangle

Label: Reprise

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: the Attic

Cost: $7

Pentangle's first album is a loose, fun jam that begins with some dark bowed upright bass before laying down the foundation that was their sound: jazzy acoustic rhythm section, virtuouso folk guitarists, and the flute-like voice of Jacqui McShee floating over all. When Jansch harmonises with her, its beautiful, but the long instrumental passages contain some brilliant work. The longest track, 'Pentangling' is I guess their anthem, and it's a warm sketch with a coy complexion, leaving a nice bit of space between the sounds. I listen to this one the least but it's strong all the way through. [15 November 2012]


Date: 17 August 2002

Pentangle - Cruel Sister

Label: Transatlantic Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: the Attic

Cost: $0

(trade-in)


Date: 17 August 2002

Sigur Ros - Agaetis Byrjrun

Label: Fat Cat

Format: CD Album

Source: Record exchange

Cost: $0

Great sex music; total ear candy, pushing all of the buttons of the post-shoegazer romantic. I should pull this out more often. [1/4/2004]


Date: 20 August 2002

Landing - tour CDEP

Label: none

Format: CD EP

Source: International Dareport

Cost: $6



Date: 21 August 2002

Neu!

Label: Astralwerks

Format: CD

Source: Dave's music mine

Cost: $6.41



Date: 6 September 2002

Ilk - Zenith

Label: No Fans Records

Format: CD

Source: Eclipse Records

Cost: $13

The joke-that's-not-really-a-joke, Richard Youngs and Andrew 'Paz' Paine made this album in the late 90s which was highly influenced by progressive rock's biggest excesses. There's spoken bits about fairies and demons (or something, I stopped listening) and lots of atmospheric misty sunlight-across-the-dew moments, and of course thunderous, monsterous riffs ('LABYRINTH' is ripping) and organ solos. It's not really meant to be funny, but rather to genuinely pay tribute to this influence. Of course it's a long way from Yes or Gentle Giant - the lack of drums being a big one, but instead of rooting this in a folk form, they try anyway for the prog pyrotechnics, and largely succeed. I never really listened to the second Ilk record but this is enough, especially as it clocks in at 70 minutes (of course!). I hope I sound positive because I do love this - the mood is perfect, the arrangements adventurous, and 'Of Departure' ranks among the best and most beautiful song-fragments of Richard's entire career. [6 October 2012]


Date: 6 September 2002

Double Leopards - A Pebble In Thousands Of Unmapped Revolutions

Label: Eclipse Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Eclipse Records

Cost: $11

Well, of the 1,701 music entries I've made here over the past decade, I've written something in the 'comment' box for 852 of them, slightly more than half. But my ultimate goal is to have a review/comment on every entry (which I've been very good about with films and books that I finished reading). So I use the 'suggest unreviewed' feature I put in (check the top of your music page) to randomly suggest I listen to things. This Double Leopards LP came up and it's a nice thing to revisit almost a decade later. When I ordered this, I just heard it was good; in subsequent years I met all the band members and actually became really good friends with Mike Bernstein for awhile, talking to him daily for a year or two though we've fallen out of regular correspondance. I don't know if this was the first Double Leopards LP or one of the first, but it sounds almost innocent and young, despite how confident it is. And furthermore it's a blueprint of what everyone was doing when I was most actively involved with UK experimental music. This is heavily psychedelic despite a limited palette; only the track 'garements in the midst of my vestures' really gets wild with synths and other spacey sounds (but also with lots of space). This is music that breathes through it's ebbs and flows, built I think around (mostly) processed voices. The deep drones begin and end in an intertwining fashion and despite the darkness, it's incredibly warm and inviting. Liner notes list three members, with impossible to deciper names and also guitar/bass/drums credited; I think this was before Maya joined? Or maybe before Chris did; not completely sure either way. [1 July 2012]


Date: 6 September 2002

Kemialliset Ystävät - Kellari Juniversumi

Label: Fonal Records

Format: CD

Source: Eclipse Records

Cost: $15



Date: 9 September 2002

Mindflayer - It's Always 1999

Label: Ooo Mau Mau

Format: CD

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0



Date: 15 September 2002

Steve Lacy - Moon

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl LP Album Reissue

Source: Abraxas/Get Back

Cost: $0

Moon is a pretty furious ball of sound, with an Italian band of nobodies (not meant in a derogatory way, but i never heard of any) and some good trombone to cut against the squealing of his straight horn. The album blows by quickly, and never really stops long enough to be memorable except that one song with the vocals. It's from that Globe Unity school of European explosiveness, though the recording quality makes it sound small despite the aggression. I like Moon but it's so dense that it's hard to really unravel it. Lacy is a quite uncompromising artist and though this doesn't stick in my memory like The Forest and the Zoo, it's still a remarkable document about what was happening in Rome in '69. [26 July 2012]


Date: 15 September 2002

Don Cherry - Orient

Label: Get Back

Format: 2xLP

Source: Abraxas/Get Back

Cost: $0

Orient is a great lost Don Cherry record, and when it was reissued a decade ago, the skies sang with a chorus of angels. 'Orient' and 'Eagle Eye' are the centerpieces, both split over two sides. The title track begins with Cherry on piano, and turns into a drum freakout by Han Bennink, with Cherry vocalising. On the flipside we get more piano, which is played in a slow, circular melodic way, not at all a jazz style. There's a tambura player on this track who inhabits the distance but doesn't dominate; it lets the dark modality breath and Bennink can do his thing. On 'Eagle Eye', the piano shifts to a syncopated, slow melody with Cherry moaning (mostly) wordlessly over top. Okay Tamiz is the drummer now and he's far more groove-orientated than Bennink, turning this into something trance-like (and with frequent calls to the audience to help). Things get more Eastern on the last tracks - 'Si Ta Ra Ma' is an endless chant with light bongo-style percussion that becomes taken over by a piano riff which is almost like a pop music hook. Overall this has very little of Cherry playing what he is known for, yet it somehow feels like one of this most representative works. [25 August 2012]


Date: 15 September 2002

Art Ensemble Of Chicago - Reese And The Smooth Ones

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl LP Album Reissue

Source: Abraxas/Get Back

Cost: $0

I've never completely understood how this one is banded - both sides list two compositions, 'Reese' and 'The Smooth Ones', composed by Mitchell and Bowie respectively, but without a band or a clear distinction between the tracks - suggesting that we are listening to two simultaneous compositions, which is very possible. There are exuberant, brassy trumpet parts on side two suggesting this is Bowie at work - not just because the trumpet is present, but because the melodies are so bold, at times recalling Iberian folk music or at least bullfighter images for me. The percussion is full-on, with this being recorded in that amazing fertile Studio Saravah period where the stars all aligned. Pre-Don Moye Art Ensemble is wonderful in its own way and this ranks as one of the most exploratory and rambunctious (there's a part where Jarman and Mitchell just blow against each other as hard as they can, an unusually aggressive act for them). [6 October 2012]


Date: 18 September 2002

Mnemonists - Horde

Label: ReR Megacorp

Format: CD Album Reissue

Source: ReR MegaCorp

Cost: $9.3

Upgraded to vinyl version years later.


Date: 18 September 2002

Biota - Invisible Map

Label: ReR Megacorp

Format: CD

Source: ReR MegaCorp

Cost: $9.3

Invisible Map finds Biota doing what they do - creating acid-soaked song experiments that are buried in electo-acoustic processing. At 38 tracks in 76 minutes, it's pretty full-on, but good times throughout. The endless sea of reverb around the lead vocalist and the chaos created by the acoustic guitars and accordions makes this start to sound the same after awhile, especially with all the affected percussion tracks. Since I have a few other CDs by them, it's really hard to distinguish between different albums. The songwriting uses weird modal patterns that give it a folky/European tilt (not to mention the instrumentation - anything that uses a squeezebox this prominently makes me think of street musicians from a French arthouse film), and this songwriting grounds it, though also keeps it from being as obvious and contemporary sounding as, say, Animal Collective, who employ similar production techniques but sound like a completely different beast. [30 December 2012]


Date: 18 September 2002

Roy Wood - Boulders

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: ebay

Cost: $11

Roy Wood's solo music is no less eccentric than his work with the Move (or Wizzard, come to think of it); this first record is a wonderful song cycle in which Wood plays every instrument and does all vocals (even the ones that sound like female background singers). There's some weird genre excursions that show his interest in Wizzard, but otherwise it's consistent. The best track is a weird 3/4 number that reminds me a lot of Eno's "Put a Straw Under Baby". Another recommended rock oddity. [1/3/2004]


Date: 18 September 2002

Biota - Object Holder

Label: ReR Megacorp

Format: CD

Source: ReR MegaCorp

Cost: $9.3

The first Biota CD that I'm familiar with, this is 70 minutes of exploding songforms, all based around a collective of musicians in Arizona or somewhere in the American southwest - yet I always feel there's a strong European flavour to this music. That's maybe due to the high presence of accordion and the ethereal female vocals that glide overtop. I tend to enjoy Biota, these days, when they are more straight-ahead. Some of these tunes, like 'Private Wire', sound like classic 80s 4AD stuff except with heavy processing. The impulse to put every instrument through some sort of effect is quite hard for Biota to overcome, and what originally drew me to their music; it reminds me a bit of Animal Collective with very different instrumental and songwriting influences. But like Animal Collective, trusting in the melody and occasionally going for something more 'dry' leads to higher dividends. [18 September 2012]


Date: 21 September 2002

Bügsküll - Snakland

Label: Scratch Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Scratch

Cost: $9.5

Bugskull made some pretty weird records in the mid-90s, but who was listening? This is a turning point between the guitar-driven psychedelic pop of Phantasies and Senseitions-era Bugskull and the downtempo electronica of the later stuff. There's still waves of psychedelic guitars over the mellow, spacious jams; A.R. Kane is actually an interesting comparison, though maybe not an obvious one. The singing is pushed low but there's still some catchy songs. 'Exit Wound' is a Morricone-style meditation that closes out the album nicely; the title track is probably the most memorable cut. This feels a lot less like a soundtrack than other Bugskull albums, and maybe is the sound I like the most from him. [2 November 2012]


Date: 21 September 2002

Bugskull - And Big White Cloud

Label: Scratch

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Scratch

Cost: $9.5

When your records are in storage for 3+ years, you tend to forget that some even exist.  When re-alphabetizing I came across this and had absolutely no memory of it, though according to the infallible database I not only bought this 6 years ago, but I even bothered to mail-order it from Canada (likely the only place to get it at the time).  This late period Bügsküll (could he still be making music today? I have no idea!) is collaborating with the Big White Cloud (I guess), and moves pretty far away from the early song-based stuff but also moves away from the more dancey material of Snakland and the Distracted Snowflakes.  There is some vocalising, though it's more of a spoken word style.  This album is still constructed like those other ones though - mostly instrumental, with cheap synths and strangely melodic, rhythmic pieces that are kinda quirky, fruity, silly even.  There are some weird, dark moments with bending melodies, squaking reverb-drenched saxophones, and a curious unending feeling - it actually reminds me a bit of LAFMS stuff, like Smegma, though with a slightly pastel sheen.  I'm sure this was all home-recorded and it's an approach to psychedelia that's relatively free from obvious precedents (besides the aforementioned LAFMS, which is probably just to my ears) - it's pleasing, enjoyable, maybe even great at times, but not earth-shattering in any way. [12 Jan 2009]


Date: 25 September 2002

Jack Rose - Red Horse, White Mule

Label: Eclipse Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Eclipse

Cost: $9

When this came out it was a diversion from Pelt's material and a chance for Jack Rose to show off his acoustic fingerpicking chops. A few years later and he was more known for this, and Pelt was relegated to the sidelines; a few years later, he died. I knew Jack a bit and last saw him play in Glasgow when touring on this type of material (it was after Opium Musick had come out). The Fahey debt is enormous, to the point of almost leaving me little else to say about it. Listening now, I'm struck by how full and intimate the recording is - the second side's scrapes and other byproducts are up-front, almost like as a listener I'm inside the soundhole of the guitar. The structures are clear but the details are semi-improvised - it's all an expression of beauty, even when rolling into its own tension and release. I don't know if I prefer this or the one after it (and I don't even know how many more he put out) but it's definitely a wonderful thing to have on warm, wooly vinyl. [3 October 2012]


Date: 25 September 2002

Sandy Bull - E Pluribus Unum

Label: Vanguard

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: eBay

Cost: $8.98

What I wouldn't give to have more Sandy Bull LPs ... I wasn't wild about E Pluribus Unum when I first grabbed this, but after a late-night listen with JP in Helsinki, I saw the light. The first half of this is an electric guitar blues, 'No Deposit No Return', and I think I used to just fear the 12-bar. But this is a beautiful, open, and fragile blues, with the entire instrumentation played by Bull himself. The b-side, 'Electric Blend' is an even more loose raga, incorporating more eastern percussion. It's soft, yet biting, and displays the mastery of a true musical wizard who doesn't need to show off any fretboard histrionics - the beauty is between the notes here. [5 November 2012]


Date: 8 October 2002

Hochenkeit - omu4h 4aholab / 400 boys

Label: Road Cone

Format: CD

Source: half.com

Cost: $4.99



Date: 8 October 2002

One Ensemble Of Daniel Padden - The One Ensemble Of Daniel Padden

Label: Catsup Plate

Format: CD Album Limited Edition

Source: Catsup Plate

Cost: $0

Daniel's first solo album feels like something from a different era, only because since this was made I got to know him so well and so much changed musically and creatively for him. For both of us, really. The mastering is actually quite low, so it sounds a bit thin, which is a shame - but since the source recordings are homemade, maybe this is appropriate. It's small music that is intensely personal, melodic and charming. Daniel's the least interested in progressive rock of any member of VtB - and maybe the most musically traditional as well - and this is reflected here. The clarinets and keyboards give it a nice British folkyness, but there's no darkness on display. It's a really nice, somewhat quirky musical vision. [31 December 2012]


Date: 12 October 2002

Suntanama

Label: Drag City

Format: CD Album

Source: paul's

Cost: $0

(trade-in) Awful!


Date: 12 October 2002

Leo Cuypers - Heavy Days Are Here Again

Label: Atavistic

Format: CD Album Reissue

Source: Paul's

Cost: $0

(trade-in). Great!


Date: 18 October 2002

Chris McGregor's Brotherhood of Breath

Label: Akarma

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Forced Exposure

Cost: $22.5

Over the past few years I've had a bit of a reactionary stance towards dissonant free jazz - while I like it, and it was totally my introduction into free jazz, I've sort of lost interest in it, and I've gravitated towards more melodic, compositionally strong material. Of which this LP is the absolute masterpiece. A large ensemble South African big band playing straighahead, catchy music that still has room for freakouts and hooks = right up my alley. This is one of my favorite jazz records ever, and their only real great statement (the live albums and bootlegs of the band are sort of terrible). This is still fairly obscure, which is a shame, because it's brilliant. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 18 October 2002

Debris' - Static Disposal

Label: Anopheles

Format: CD Album

Source: Forced Exposure

Cost: $17.5

Chickasha, Oklahoma's greatest band only left one LP and then a second LP's worth of outtakes and rehearsals, but luckily Anophales was kind enough to add this to the queue of long-lost genius artists. Debris brilliantly straggled the line between Beefheartian avant-rock and Pere Ubu-esque noise breakdowns. There are saxophone solos, discordant guitars, and a nihilistic proto-no wave edge. The booklet goes through the story of the band and all of the songs; clearly they influenced nobody, as this was heard by nobody (and probably not even after the reissue) but it's great if you like this sort of thing, which I obviously do. This doesn't have a song that is truly transcendent (except for maybe 'New Smooth Lunch') making this a bit more historical curiosity than personal inspiration, but the vocal effects, sexual obsessions, and general chaos makes this enjoyable through all 76 minutes. [24 December 2012]


Date: 18 October 2002

Gunther Mueller / Le Quan Ninh - La Voyelle Liquide

Label: Erstwhile

Format: CD

Source: Forced Exposure

Cost: $15

Le Quan Ninh is so fascinating to see live - eleven years after this was released, I saw him play solo in Tallinn without any electronics and it was a staggering, beautiful experience of live percussion. This CD is much more 'wet' but offers riches in listening, though there are points where it's so quiet that my old, noisy CD player is more audible than the delicate electro-acoustic percussion improvisation these two geniuses lay down here. I like small, quiet sounds, but the title is accurate as this is completely fluid music, always moving and evolving. It's not quiet all the way through - it flares up into wild, active interplay (track #6 in particular) where the percussion is often identifiably percussion, etc. [26 December 2012]


Date: 18 October 2002

H.N.A.S. - Melchior (Aufmarsch Der Schlampen)

Label: Dom

Format: CD

Source: Forced Exposure

Cost: $16.5



Date: 18 October 2002

H.N.A.S. - Im Schatten Der Möhre

Label: Dom

Format: CD

Source: Forced Exposure

Cost: $16.5

A reissue of Heeman and Khan's classic LP from 1987, packed with bonus tracks galore. Im Schatten der Möhre is a wild trip that throws everything into the blender, happy to employ collage techniques both surrealist and dada, with a strong focus on unsettling, psychedelic environments. This experimentation, while often humorous (I mean, look at the cover!) is never cynical; when smooth strings and female vocals appear on, say on the epic 'Bobbejaanland', it's a further exploration of genre deconstruction, not a mockery. The debt to Throbbing Gristle is apparent, mostly through the variety. The almost-title track 'Im Lande Der Möhre' is a  small masterpiece of minimal drift, and this is a beautiful thing, yet somehow feels casual. The bonus tracks I've never really made it through but I think the album is satisfying enough, so maybe they should be listened to as a standalone listen, not after. [29 December 2012]


Date: 18 October 2002

Richard Youngs - New Angloid Sound

Label: Forced Exposure

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Forced Exposure

Cost: $14

There is something more innocent about early Richard Youngs - like he didn't have quite as much confidence, though he still seems to know exactly what he wants to do. Does that make any sense? This record, based around acoustic guitar, voice, and kazoo, is among my favorite of his "song" records. The intimacy is genuine, but the music is strange (yet simple). A good starting point, I think. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Pere Ubu - Dub Housing

Label: Chrysalis

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is the Pere Ubu record I've listened to the most - it strikes the best balance between the angrier stuff written in the afterglow of Laughner and the pre-Jehovah's Witness David Thomas weirdness. Their more avant-leanings are kept in check a bit, and the weird hooks come out more. It's still a very radical, often disturbing record, and I sometimes wonder just how they had the influence they did. This record is a classic and everyone should own it. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

X-Ray Spex - Germfree Adolescents

Label: EMI Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is such an artefact of it's era, but 25 years later all the bands in Glasgow still essentially sounded like this. That's part of the reason it still sounds so fresh, and we'll probably have kids forever making sounds like this. Of course, none of the Glasgow bands can write songs as good as 'Warrior in Woolworths'. So many of these British bands at the time had saxophones, which is kinda weird, cause they don't sound anything like Huey Lewis and the News. I forgot that this doesn't actually have 'Oh Bondage, Up Yours!' on it, but that's ok. [17 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Pylon - Beep/Altitude

Label: DB

Format: 7" EP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A great 7" from a great band. "Beep" is a punchy rocker with growled, snarled lyrics; the B-side might be my favorite Pylon tune ever though it's a lot more melodic than their earlier stuff and maybe not that representative. I think this haul of Pylon singles completes my Pylon discography. [3 January 2004]


Date: 24 October 2002

Raincoats - Odyshape

Label: Rough Trade (UK)

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Year after year I continue to listen to this album, and it improves with age. The circular, lackadaisacal feel of the rhythms is what makes this preferable to their first album; an interest in dub and world music is only beneficial to their innovations. The sense of isolation and wonder is remarkable. I love this album more than life itself. [13 Sept 2007]


Date: 24 October 2002

R. Stevie Moore - The Original Phonography

Label: 

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

R. Stevie Moore is an acquired taste. The sketches on this record are weird and drugged out, and integrated with fucked up, fractured pop songs that almost seem like they are trying to destroy their hooks. It reminds me a bit of the first Sebadoh album The Freed Man, but also there's a Homosexuals-like glee in the productions. Some of the songs are just beautiful, perfect pop songs, like a hobo Brian Wilson. But other moments are so inconsistent that you realize why R. Stevie Moore is such a miserable disappointment. His fans will probably argue that inconsistency is his virtue, but inconsistency won't help you get over your alcohol problem and get out of your apartment in New Jersey. And how many "fans" are there, actually? [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Red Crayola - Wives In Orbit

Label: Radarscope Records / Radar Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Among the best Red Crayola releases from this era, both 'Wives in Orbit' and "Yik Yak' are wild, discordant post-punk that is not abrasive or tuneless. It's a perfect timely development in the sound of the Red Crayola, maintaining the weirdness of Thompson's 60s songwriting with a contemporary (for 1978) edge. The band is actually just a two-piece with a backing vocalist, but there's more layers, making this a lovely studio construction. Great artwork too. [1 August 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Residents - Commercial Album

Label: Ralph

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The classic short-attention span masterpiece, I guess, though I'm not a massive fan of The Commercial Album. It's hard to find anything wrong with any individual track as they are all so brief, and some parts are amazing - the vocals and synths never really came together so perfectly for them, as the later releases become increasingly goofy, etc. It's only that after the perfect run of their first few records, this isn't quite as magically weird. Still, the few short films they made from this that I've seen are fantastic, and I think watching the entire Commercial DVD would be a vastly preferable way to experience this. [28 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Cecil Taylor - Fly! Fly! Fly! Fly! Fly!

Label: Pausa

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Whenever I listen to these Cecil Taylor solo piano albums I love the way the piano sounds - so the recording quality has a big effect on how I listen to it. This is a pretty good record as it featured 9 songs, all at palatable lengths and with very distinct moods ('The Stele Stolen and Broken Is Reclaimed' is exuberant and wild; 'Astar's playful and sneaky; 'Corn IN Sun + T (Moon)' is somewhat more reflective). The piano used here, noted as being a Bösendorfer Grand Piano Imperial, is recorded with a lot of low mid-rangey sounds. I love the way the upper register of the fingerboard tends to sound on Taylor solo LPs, but here the higher frequencies seem to roll off, sounding at times almost like a well-synthesised MIDI keyboard (though not quite that digital). Good, and diverse enough to be a good representation of Taylor's work, but somehow just not my favourite release of his. [30 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Cecil Taylor - Indent

Label: Freedom

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

One of the numerous Cecil Taylor solo piano albums I've accumulated, Indent distinguishes itself through it's momentum - the pace begins when the stylus drops and doesn't let up apart from when you have to stop to flip it. A live recording from '73, there's a nice sense of atmosphere - a roomy feel, the crowd almost audible holding their breath at Cecil's runs layer and overlap. By the end it's a total miasma, impossible to distinguish from, even though it's broken into three movements. [8 Aug 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Cecil Taylor Unit - It Is In The Brewing Luminous

Label: Hat Hut Records

Format: 2xLP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This double LP is Cecil Taylor at his most transgressive, in that band he had around the period, with Jimmy Lyons (such a great, great player), Alan Silva, and a violinist by the name of Ramsey Ameen. Ameen brings a high-octane kick to the band, which works perfectly with Taylor's own playing; the percussive nature of the piano works great against the screeching assonance of the violin - side three is particularly manic. This is truly relentless - it never stops across four sides - and it might be my favourite Cecil Taylor record of the many I own. [24 August 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Aphrodite's Child - 666

Label: Vertigo

Format: 2xVinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is one of my favorite progressive rock records out of my entire collection. Aphrodite's Child were Vangelis's Greek prog band, and this double LP is a concept about the Apocalypse or something. It's mixed between wonderfully orchestrated, catchy pop that almost sounds like ELO, and these dark instrumental freakouts. It's a long listen at 2 LP's, but one of those oddities that is actually enjoyable to listen to as opposed to just an eccentric novelty. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Cecil Taylor Unit - Dark To Themselves

Label: Inner City

Format: Vinyl LP Stereo

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Another band lineup, with the great Jimmy Lyons and Raphé Malik, this also features a young David S. Ware in two furious, side-long improvisations. The recording is great here, and as much as I loved the violin playing on Brewing Luminous, there's something fantastic about the classic sax/sax/trumpet/piano lineup here. Without any bass, the low end is occupied mostly by Taylor and I guess Ware; it makes everything feel lighter,and you can distinguish the interplay between the pianos and saxes more clearly. I've saved these Jimmy Lyons records towards the end of my plethora of Cecil Taylor releases because they're so enjoyable - invigorating, really. [24 August 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Chris Cutler & Fred Frith - Live In Prague And Washington

Label: Ré Records

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A 45rpm 12" of these two geniuses improvising in two live settings. Side A is dirgy and dark, side B is spacious and dissonant, with a lot of crowd noise to boot. While probably a relative minor release for these two, it's in a beautiful silk-screened cover that looks like the Evil Moisture/Metallux split that I have. [30 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Mission Of Burma - Academy Fight Song

Label: Ace Of Hearts Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Mission of Burma are one of my favorite rock bands ever, and there's not much more I need to say about this classic single, truly one of the greatest of the era. I'm not your Academy, but Max Ernst shows that they're also literate, as corny as chanting "Dada! Dada! Dada!" is. Timeless. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Mission Of Burma - Signals, Calls, And Marches

Label: Ace Of Hearts Records

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

There's a window in my head, there's a window in my heart. I remember borrowing the old 80 minute Ryko Burma comp from the Carnegie when I was a senior in high school, and sitting up one night with a borrowed bass guitar, teaching myself how to play this entire EP. I never looked back on my pre-Burma days. Seeing them live was killer, and even the weak guest stars on "All World Cowboy Romance" (no offense to Thurston) couldn't weaken the power that instrumental punk rock can have. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Mission Of Burma - Vs.

Label: Ace Of Hearts Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I still dream of starting a one-off cover band to play this record from start to finish. I'm pretty sure they opened with "Secrets" when I saw them live, and there's nothing more powerful than just strumming those two chords to open a set. Sometimes a simple gesture can do more than words ever can. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Neil Young - Time Fades Away

Label: Reprise Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This was one of those Neil Young albums I never really gave much thought to besides a few listens back when I got it - then I filed it and figured "ah, too depressing". Going back now it's growing on me - it's raggedness would render it unremarkable if by anyone else, but coming during such a period of brilliance, it gives it a whole new angle. Some of the tracks like "Don't be Denied" are fucking amazing, and "Journey Through the Past", while a second-rate retread of "After the Gold Rush", is great BECAUSE it's a second rate retread. [13 Sept 2007]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Residents - Mark Of The Mole

Label: Ralph Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The Residents maybe never did finer work than Mark of the Mole, which continues their weird earthy conceptual narrative style, begun in Eskimo, into a fantasy play about underground dwelling mole-people. It's easy to ignore the story though, and listen instead to the strange proto-industrial rhythms, accentuated by the usual Residents synth gurgles, broken bursts of melody, and dying kazoo sounds. Maybe the whole thing can be taken as a giant political allegory -- I've never been completely sure, not have I really invested myself enough. There's way more vocals than Eskimo, but thankfully this is before they get into their mid-80s period, where the quality really drops off (though I appreciate their efforts in charging forward). [4 Aug 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Pere Ubu - Datapanik In The Year Zero

Label: Radarscope Records / Radar Records

Format: Vinyl 12" EP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This EP is amazing. It's really the first two Pere Ubu singles repackaged as a 45rpm 12", but since I don't have the vinyl I'm more than happy to have it on this format. 'Heart of Darkness'/'30 Seconds Over Tokyo' are about as good as music gets. I remember Luke Ferdinand saying back in our Pitt days that he found the latter to be a genuinely terrifying piece of music, and he's right - even though I've listened to it a zillion times, it still sends chills down my spine. There's also a great early version of 'The Modern Dance' called 'Untitled' that has the most infectious of early Pere Ubu rhythms. Amazing and essential; what more can I possibly say? [28 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Pere Ubu - The Modern Dance

Label: Blank Records (2)

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Pere Ubu's debut album is such a classic that little needs to be written. Beginning with the feedback squeal intro of 'Non-Alignment Pact' and ending with the bleak pleading of 'Humour Me', this is a great step in the evolution of rock music. I maybe have always overestimated the importance of Pere Ubu because they're from the same rust belt-region as me, and lots of the Pittsburgh heads were way into them when i was growing up, but I think this is as valuable as any other great art rock. Hard to say which is more of a joy these days - this or Dub Housing  - but there's never a time when I don't love to hear either. [28 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Cecil Taylor Quartet - Air

Label: Barnaby Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album Reissue

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is a lovely recording of a transitional time for Taylor and for Shepp. This is built out of the older lineup with Buell Neidlinger, but with Shepp as guest. He hangs back actually and really only accents a few tracks. This was recorded in 1960 but reissued a bit later; there's a few extremely tender runs for Taylor, particularly at the end of 'This Nearly Was Mine', that shows a genius able to merge tradition with his other abstractions. The second side has two extended pieces which get much more blocky, choppy, and rhytmic. Dennis Charles plays off of Taylor here, really feeling the piano as a percussion instrument, and it's a window to the future. I suspect Shepp's byline was added on this repress as he was probably an obscure sideman in 1960 or whenever this was originally released. [23 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Cecil Taylor / Buell Neidlinger - New York City R&B

Label: Barnaby Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

It's 1961 and Cecil Taylor goes into a studio with a bunch of young musicians, recording a few sessions over two days that make up New York City R&B. There is definitely rhythm and blues; you can hear Cecil pulling against the swing of Neidlinger's bass, and it's occasionally a battle. It doesn't take long into 'O.P.' for this to become apparent; this trio recording (Billy Higgins doesn't get title billing since he's replaced by Dennis Charles on 'Cell Walk for Celeste') is playful, but it gets into moods for minutes at a time and doesn't return. The big band comes in for the last track, 'Things Ain't What They Used To Be', the title perhaps a portent of the changes to happen to American jazz that decade. We have Archie Shepp, a misspelled Steve Lac(e)y, Clark Terry, and Roswell Rudd among others. It's a carefully chosen group of musicians I think; no one overplays, and the piece breathes well, conveying a sense of nostagia (or maybe I'm just reading too much into the title). [23 August 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Sunburned Hand Of The Man - Headdress

Label: Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $11

My first Sunburned LP, and it didn't do much for me. I sold this or gave it to someone a few weeks after I bought it, so looking back 3 years later I don't even remember what it was like. Perhaps it might be more enjoyable now? [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Cecil Taylor - Nerfertiti, the Beautiful One Has Come

Label: Arista/Freedom

Format: Vinyl 2xLP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Jimmy Lyons and Sunny Murray are here, and this lengthy release is recorded quite well, culled from a live show in Copenhagen, 1962. The set revolves around several compositions which often break down into long piano explorations, sometimes solo and sometimes in group form. Sunny Murray really suits Taylor - they play their instruments in a similar manner, sprawling in a million directions while being contained as well. The title track is in two versions, one of the more darkly complected numbers when compared to the more lively jazz trio work on tracks like 'Lena' and the cover of 'What's New'. Music this radical must have really blown some minds in 1962, but I guess that's why they had to go to Denmark to perform it. Among the many Taylor records I picked up at this time, this one really stands out because it's got such diversity on it, and some real swinging bits. [10 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Sun City Girls - Dante's Disneyland Inferno 3xLP

Label: Locust

Format: 3xLP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $22

This is a very Charles Gocher-driven collection that certainly showcases the sillier side of Sun City Girls. Getting through all 3 LP's in one sitting is a chore, if not impossible, but it's quite funny, with some of their most ridiculous and hilarious spoken bits. When placed alongside 300,003 Crossdressers (as their other triple LP) it pales a bit, but the two records together would probably be the most complete view of Sun City Girls that one can get with just two albums (though that would be 6 LP's). [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Pavement - Slanted and Enchanted Deluxe and Reduxe

Label: Matador

Format: CD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $14

At some point in 2003 I realized that I've listened to this album close to 1,000 times - if I can even estimate. I used to always say that Wowee Zowee is my favorite Pavement record - and this may be true - but Slanted and Enchanted is the greatest indie rock record ever, and possibly the greatest rock record ever (to me). I never get tired of any of it except for 'Two States' and I will often drive around listening to this with 'Here' and 'Our Singer' on repeat, listening over and over until I get to my destination and singing along. This deluxe edition is nice as it tacks on Watery, Domestic (as perfect of an EP as there ever was) and most of Stray Slack. Stray Slack was actually my introduction to Pavement - well, three S&E songs thrown on a mix tape were, but when I asked for more, my high school friend Nick lent me Stray Slack. That weekend I went to the lake with my family and listened to that tape over and over and over, and it created a new religion for me. The actual album rules too, but many of these songs I heard for the first time in their weird live versions. I'd like to own this on vinyl but the 2xCD is just so nice. [3 January 2004]


Date: 24 October 2002

Cecil Taylor - Solo: Garden

Label: Hat Hut

Format: 2xLP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

OK, I admit it - I have too many fucking Cecil Taylor records. This one I listen to the least because it's in this complicated cardboard packing that I'm afraid I will rip, and it's also fairly interchangeable with the other solo Taylor records I have. Actually, that's not true - they are all distinct - and this one has some poetry and vocal stuff on it too, though it's not the one that's entire poetry, which I sort of want to find, even though I know I will never listen to it. And actually, the way this is recorded and some of the heavy pounding of the lower reigsters might make this my "pick" of all the Taylor records I have - though I should look back at what I wrote about all of the others. With four sides there's just so much here to listen to and it's compelling, demanding full attention, which gives me little cause to spin it. [20 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

No-Neck Blues Band - Re: "Mr. A Fan..."

Label: Trade Mark Of Quality

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: paul's

Cost: $13

This come from 1999 No Neck, back when I saw them in Pittsburgh, so it's a lineup that I remember fondly. Side one is the classic outsider freak soundball, with guitar notes raining from all directions, an uncertain rhythm, and a bunch of conflicting impulses. Side two gets into more vocal-based stuff, as there's all forms of moaning, singing and mumbling over the plodding. Some hippie flutes at the end, on the short mantra-like outro. It's a fun jam and presented in a nice bootleg format. [20 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Brian Eno - Another Green World

Label: Editions EG

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A masterful album that is placed midway between Eno's pop and ambient interests. The glam elements are entirely removed, leaving a record of delicate, placid bliss. It's about half vocal and half instrumental, with the vocal pieces featuring some of his most noteworthy compositions ("St. Elmo's Fire," "Golden Hours," "Everything Merges With the Night" and "I'll Come Running"); the instrumental parts have a ton of guest musicians, including Robert Fripp. This should be in everyone's record collection. [3 January 2004]


Date: 24 October 2002

Arnold Dreyblatt & Orchestra Of Excited Strings - Nodal Excitation

Label: India Navigation

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I bought the reissue of this CD my freshman year of college and loved it, although it didn't contain the aggression of Animal Magnetism. This is a truly minimal study in overtones, often centered around one plucked string and some percussion. It's a difficult listen to the novice, but Dreyblatt manages to incorporate somethig romantic into his music, even if it is one plucked string. On vinyl, this sounds even better, and I can only dream of what it must sound like on a great turntable. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Brian Eno - Here Come The Warm Jets

Label: Editions EG

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Eno's first record is brimming with ideas; still carrying some of the more theatrical ambitions from his Roxy Music days, Warm Jets shifts between murky, fuzzed out rockers and obtuse, experimental bits. The drama is high, and tracks like "Baby on Fire" are classics. The weirder songs on the second side are pretty unrecognized for how great they are; "Blank Frank" and "Dead Finks Don't Talk" especially. The album cover is cluttered with objects, all probably conveying some hermetic meanings for Mr. Eno; for me it's a good symbol of how cluttered the music is. It's not my favorite Eno record, though I greatly enjoy it; it's just nice to see how he refined his ideas into the overarching concept of Taking Tiger Mountain and focused even further on Another Green World. [3 January 2004]


Date: 24 October 2002

Dzyan - Electric Silence

Label: Bellaphon

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This Dzyan record is one of the gems of the more 'out' stuff I own, and yet is strangely obscure even among Krautrock heads. This band walks the line between prog and space-jams perfectly, utilising a shitload of Indian instruments in their druggie excursions. The strings are plucked and creep out of the corners of drone, created by mellotron and tambura; there's not a lot of conventional rock moments here until the last track, mostly letting the moments expand like their consciousness. I've never heard their other records but if they're as good as this, I probably should. [9 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Egg

Label: Deram Nova

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Egg's debut is classic British prog-rock, with soaring yet soft vocals, keyboards and guitars in contrapuntal synchronisation, and long jammy instrumental bits. 'Fugue in D Minor' directly covers (or maybe just quotes) Bach, with a nice 60s organ vibe by Dave Stewart, and side two is the long 'Symphony no 2'. But there's a humour in balance - with titles like 'The Song Of McGillicudie The Pusillanimous (Or: Don't Worry James, Your Socks Are Hanging In The Coal Cellar With Thomas)' (actually a pretty rocking track, probably the album's best) you know we're in a certain territory. The lyrics are printed on the sleeve and they reveal a strangely sophisticated sense of irony. It's easy to see why this was seminal and led to bands like Hatfield and the North and National Health which for some strange reason I've always dug. [18 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

1/2 Japanese Half Japanese - No Direct Line From My Brain To My Heart

Label: 50,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 Watts Records

Format: Vinyl 7" EP 45 RPM

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

One of my most prized possessions, I think this was the second ever release for Penn Jilette's 50 Skidillion Watts and for Half Japanese (if only I had the immortal 'Calling All Girls' single, but thankfully it's on the Greatest Hits double CD). 'No Direct Line From My Brain to My Heart' is a mad, punchy burst of ineptitude, with the near-hook of 'What can I do, what can I do?'. So much frustration. The b-side begins with 'Rip My Shirt' though it's not credited on the sleeve and then the less-than-15-seconds genius that is '(I Don't Want To Have) Mono (No More)', a title which takes longer to type than to listen to the actual song. The labels have "NO NO" and "MONO" screened on them, and the picture sleeve is actually 8" wide, which means it doesn't fit in my 7" box, which is a perfect metaphor. [18 September 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

A. More - Flying Doesn't Help

Label: Quango

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I'm not sure what to think of this Anthony Moore album, released under the name A. More. It's nothing like his masterful Pieces from the Cloudland Ballroom, instead being a record of new wave-styled songs. It reminds me a bit of Eno's work circa Taking Tiger Mountain which is not a bad thing. The songs are catchy, and orchestrated with electric guitars, pianos, and a vaguely Bowie/futuristic sheen. "Caught Being In Love" is a standout track, maybe, though in some sense it feels overall like More of the same, ha ha. But it's impressive, especially the very dark cover of Art Bears' 'War', saturated with distorted waves of noise at the beginning and end. Moore had already proved himself through his work in Slapp Happy and the aforementioned Pieces, but this record shows even more versatility and it's definitely an underrated sleeper amongst music of it's time period. [25 August 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Cecil Taylor - Air Above Mountains, Buildings Within

Label: Enja Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I thought this was one of those Cecil Taylor records where he reads poetry but it turns out to be another solo piano LP. I have far too many of these for any sane person to own, because how many do you really need? I tend to like different ones for their atmosphere, often for the recording quality, but this sounds like he's on a grand piano on stage, without any distinct crowd presence or particularly airyness. Nonetheless, this is a worthwhile LP and showcases his approach, at least as it was in 1976, where this was performed in Austria. It's thick, physical, and while it sometimes lightens up in terms of tone blocks, it never quite slows down or dissipates. [17 August 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Michael Nyman - The Kiss And Other Movements

Label: Editions EG

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Decent enough Nyman stuff, not unlike the Greenaway soundtracks, which is unsurprising cause they are from the same era. But without the associations to the films themselves I'm pretty nonplussed; there's only so much of this that anyone needs. To the "sell" pile!


Date: 24 October 2002

Curlew - 

Label: Landslide

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The first Curlew album pre-dated Davey Williams' arrival but it's a great guitar record anyway, thanks to the interplay between Nicky Skopelitis's electric guitar and Tom Cora's cello. This has a lot of slap bass but it generally adds to the feeling of controlled cacophony. Curlew is jazz-rock-fusion at it's finest; not a genre I usually get too deep into (especially when it's American) but this has a ruthless, innovative edge that goes for the jugular and doesn't let go. [6 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Mission Of Burma - The Horrible Truth About Burma

Label: Ace Of Hearts Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I don't listen to this live album ever, but it can't be discounted from the Burma catalog. The covers of "Heart of Darkness" and "1970" show exactly where their alleigances lie, and the truth isn't that horrible. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Lemon Kittens - Spoonfed + Writhing

Label: Step-Forward

Format: 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94



Date: 24 October 2002

Lemon Kittens - We Buy A Hammer For Daddy

Label: United Dairies

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The more experimental, forgotten corners of post-punk are often the most rewarding. Artists like this that seem to break down the walls between punk and more serious improvisation seem few and far between these days. I don't listen to this as often as I should - why do they make it seem so easy to blend pop hooks with strange tonalities and without being really convincing about their ability to play their instruments? [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Le Orme - Uomo di Pezza

Label: Philips

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Certainly one of the poppier Italian progressive bands, Le Orme I've always appreciated but never become a fan of. This is the only thing I have by them, and it speaks to the part of me that loves Os Mutantes, Aphrodite's Child, and the like. There's a big focus on the high vocals mixing with the dreamy keyboards - and the thicker band sections are closer to the Beach Boys than Area. There's some super fast drum fills thrown in to mix it up and give it that progressive edge, but this is really easy listening. The vocals, being in Italian, have a gravity that I don't think applies to a lot of other bands, for example if this was a High Llamas record. It's remarkably easy to tune this out, which is probably why I wouldn't recognise it if it was played for me Invisible Jukebox-style (despite ten years of multiple listens). [5 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Massacre - Killing Time

Label: Celluloid

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Killing Time is maybe the ultimate power trio record, where all three musicians (Frith, Laswell and Maher) play lead. There's still a unified feel though, as opposed to three people blasting overtop of each other - the pieces are relatively composed, and while the album title suggests they just tossed this off in their spare time, there's such a unity here that I don't believe that. For 1981, this is a statement - coming out of the prog movement of the 70s, which led to RIO and it's avant-garde Brechtisms -- this is almost a return to simplicity, though songs like 'As-Is' are anything but. Chaos and order are constantly in flux here, but the stern confidence of all three musicians guides it through. [4 Aug 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

CroMagnon

Label: ESP

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is one of the most singular documents of music ever made, a true testament to freaks and outcasts that somehow lacks the critical reputation it deserves. Side 1 is an utter tour de force, beginning with the growing bagpipe thump of 'New Caledonia' and then descending into further and further madness.
