A product of its time, maybe, but this is a continual inspiration to me, and it's amazing how many different things they try out over the course of the LP. There's repetitive minimalist primitivism on side 2, a drony, exploratory soundscape that's akin to what artists like No Neck and Sunburned Hand were aping 40 years later, and even some deranged Beach Boys-esque vocal harmonies. On top of it all, I don't know anything about this record - who these guys were and what, if anything, they went on to do. According to discogs.com, this is the first pressing I have - later ones had a colour cover. Let this singularity stand forever. [15 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Mekons - Work All Week / Unknown Wrecks

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl 7" Single

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I don't think of myself as being trapped in the punk/post-punk years artistically, but it's true that much of my formative influences are from this time. It's a tremendously overstudied movement in music culture, yet there are so many remarkable artefacts from this time that it's hard not to still feel some excitement for it. 'Work All Week' manages to succinctly summarise so many ideas in such a short, perfect song: labour, desire, conflict, the decayed North working class.... Thatcher is on the horizon here, and these art-school punks have made something timeless. 'Unknown Wrecks' is a good song too. [10 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Mission of Burma - Trem Two b/w OK/No Way 

Label: Ace of Hearts

Format: 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

"Trem Two" - a vital beginning to post-punk, "introspective" indie, cough, emo even? They focus on texture and the tension is emphasized because the song never explodes like you expect. One of my favorite Burma songs, and they rock out with their hardcore roots on the B-side. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Mekons - Where Were You?/I'll Have to Dance Then

Label: Fast Product

Format: 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I was waiting in a bar, where were you? I was buying you a drink, where were you? I was crying home in bed, where were you? I watched you from a distance, did you see me? I was standing in a queue, did you see me? You had yellow hair, did you see me? I want to talk to you all night, do you like me? I want to find out about your life, do you like me? Could you ever be my wife, do you like me? [3 January 2004]


Date: 24 October 2002

Michael Nyman - Decay Music

Label: Obscure

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Decay Music hails from a time in Nyman's career before he began the melodic, neo-classical repetition that so defines his work in the 1980s. This is instead a product from the Michael Nyman who wrote Experimental Music: Cage and Beyond - a by-the-books clinical composer, even if those books are maths textbooks or the I Ching. '1-100', supposedly composed for a Greenaway film but I'm I'm not sure which ones, is a degenerative sound piece built around the 'Blue Danube Waltz', where the decay of the notes is timed precisely. The recording is four different recordings, superimposed and unsynchronised, yet it's still very sparse, creating a lovely bed of space to becomes lost in. 'Bell Set No. 1' on the b-side is also built around decay but emphasises timbre more, with the different Turkish bells recorded to really explore the potential of their distinctiveness. There is a repetitious figure at the centre of it, but it's so slow and spacious that it avoids the brain-jarring staccato of his later work, instead reminding me of Joe Jones Solar Music without the slurryness. [22 August 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Young Marble Giants - Testcard EP

Label: Rough Trade

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Complexity through simplicity, or something like that. This is the YMG release I always forget about, a six-song instrumental led by the Moxham brothers' unique compositions. Stuart's guitar playing gets hots on side two and the short, sketch-like nature is charming. The liner notes emphasise the domestic nature of the songs and you can hear that, but all YMG music is so clean, gentle and focused that it seems better for the bedroom than the concert hall. [18 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Young Marble Giants - Colossal Youth

Label: Rough Trade

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I've listened to this classic a zillion times and it still surprises me with its sophistication, both lyrically and musically. This is such a piece of modernism, dealing with the pace of urban life, emotional expectations, and other topics that I suspect few bands from Wales were writing about. Stuart Moxham is the svengali behind it all, but it feels like a true team effort - Philip Moxham's bass playing is probably the most central element of it all. When they just straight-up write a love song, like 'N.I.T.A.', it's chilling. That they never made another album makes this the central treasure of a perfect musical career. [26 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Y Pants - Beat It Down

Label: Neutral

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Such an oddity of early 80's NYC bands - Y Pants at times are raging, detuned no wave primitivism, but mostly remind me of the second Raincoats album or later work by the Slits. The bass/keyboard/drums lineup keep things from becoming too dense, and the vocal harmonies have a unique in and out. The album is surprisingly varied and side 1 ends with what sounds almost like gamelan music put through a midwest American lens -- quite bizarre and sort of wonderful. Little details - scrapes, plucks, tentative wind instrument melodies - are really at odds with the more rocking songs, but it somehow gels. I didn't think much of this when I picked it up ten years ago but now I've come to really appreciate it and I think I will listen to it more often. [15 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Tuxedomoon - Desire

Label: Ralph Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Tuxedomoon, by the early 1980s, have made their sound a bit more smooth, but no less weird. There are softer keyboards, saxophones, and vaguely new age moments on tracks like 'Again', but there's still a dark, evil pulse ('Incubus (Blue Suit)', 'Jinx'). The music tends to blend together from track to track, grouping into several suites of songs. This is still very much a "Ralph Records" sound throughout, but I never delved any later into their catalogue. [25 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

J.D. - Warsaw

Label: RZM

Format: 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This 7" actually appears to be a bonus along with the bootleg LP of Warsaw so really I shouldn't file it separately, but inside the LP. It's more of the same - early, lo-fi demos of classic Joy Division songs. It's labeled here as J.D. surely to avoid legal action. 'Insight' benefits from the muddyness, especially when the alien raygun keyboards kick in. [20 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Jah Wobble/The Edge/Holger Czukay - Snake Charmer

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl Mini-Album 12" 33 ? RPM

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

An odd collaboration between these three is based largely around digital synth textures and infectious beats; it's post-disco music, a connection made more evident by the Arthur Russell cover. Jaki Liebezeit plays on a few tracks and his talent is evidenced by the subtleties of the motor-pulse; Edge's guitar is sharp, treated by all manner of digital effects, but not in a psychedelic way. Wobble is the real star, composing most of it and also vocalising; Czukay is more a presence, felt but not always heard. The extended workouts are part Dif Juz, part mid-period Eno; it's not a sound I get that crazy about because it's hard to really enjoy any of the moments due to the overwhelming stench of "production". Maybe I do like this; it's the second time I listened to it in the past few weeks, and I can't quite figure out if I should unload it. [27 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Young Marble Giants - Final Day

Label: Rough Trade

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is maybe the most perfect Young Marble Giants release.  It's only 3 songs but they're all great, and 'Final Day' is probably my favorite song of their.  It's about the apocalypse, but it's sunny and cheerful; the edgy palm-muting and knocking bass works to make the perfect pop sound. [1 Jan 2009]


Date: 24 October 2002

Jac Berrocal Jacques Berrocal - Paralleles

Label: d'Avantage

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I find a so much of this French progressive stuff from the time to be really inspiring, because it seems so removed from any sort of rock/punk/Kraut scenes, and manages to do something unique with sound while maintaining a good humour about itself. In a way, these records become a genre unto themselves, though I wonder how much of a scene there was during all of this. This is perhaps my favorite record of the whole style (the Futura/French non-rock Prog style, that is). Some parts are surreal improvisation, and there are also some strange experimental compositions. The most famous track is "Rock and Roll Station", which many people (including myself) would consider to be brilliant, but maybe without being able to explain why. As possibly the rarest record in my collection, this would definitely be the first thing to grab if there's a fire. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Pylon- Crazy / M-Train

Label: DB Recs

Format: Vinyl 7" Single

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Pylon is getting reissued by DFA, which seems appropriate - no matter how much acclaim, it will never be enough for such a brilliant band. This song is perhaps their most well-know due to R.E.M.'s cover version, but the original has the weird yelp of Vanessa Briscoe-Hays which is just something amazing indeed. [13 Sept 2007]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Residents - Santa Dog '78

Label: Ralph Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Like most Residents singles of the time, this sounds great at 33rpm and even better at 45. Two sides with the usual multitracked weird voices, strange synth bumps, and that great feel. There was apparently a Santa Dog '72 released six years prior, which I guess was a different version entirely. [3 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Residents - Fingerprince

Label: Ralph Records

Format: Vinyl Album LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I always forget this album exists, which is a shame - it's an exemplary release in the early Residents story. Side one consists of several short songs, all stemming from the Third Reich and Roll sessions. They are mellow, with soft toned keyboards, unidentified ethnic instruments, and gentle vocals. The b-side is one long suite, originally written for a ballet, that is the most overtly Harry Partch-influenced thing I ever heard them. The tuned percussive blocks and scrapings are straight from Delusion of the Fury and though synths and keyboards are added, it's almost a tribute piece, and not really Residents "proper". But it's good. [17 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Residents - Duck Stab / Buster & Glen

Label: Ralph Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is the most fun Residents LP, probably - as catchy and weird as the Commercial Album but the songs are a bit longer and easier to sink your teeth into. The disturbed voices on the Buster & Glen half are lots of fun; 'Semolina', 'Hello Skinny' and 'Constantinople' are total classics. i guess this is the best starting point to introduce people to the Residents, but then all of these early albums are so, so strong. I should really spend more time listening to them. [19 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

R. Stevie Moore - Stance

Label: HP Music

Format: 12" EP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Depending on which side you listen to first, the 'Day' or 'Night' sides, this is either classic R. Stevie pop genius or a beautiful, Kranky label-style ambient jam. Whichever way you go, you are in luck. 'Manufacturers' in particular is completely, completely great. [17 October 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

R. Stevie Moore - Delicate Tension

Label: HP Music

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

These early R. Stevie Moore records are the ones I know the best, so this is almost classic status now. So many great songs - 'Don't Blame the Niggers', 'Zebra Standards 29', and the brilliant 'Don't Let Me Go to the Dogs'. The man knows how to write a song - he'll throw in a 7th chord or something at just the right moment. The weirdo, home-recorded affect is of course why he's found a renaissance in recent years but these stand up as great great songs in any context. Moore's anguish is really evident in 'Norway' which makes the more upbeat songs sound ironic, but ironic in a good way. [18 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Stooges - Fun House

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The original Elektra pressing of Fun House is well-made. The bass is thick and heavy, and listening to it with the volume up, I find it hard to suppress the urge to jump around and smash things. Not much to say here that hasn't been said already; all the songs are beyond classic status. I could point out how the guitar solo on 'Dirt' totally rips, and 'LA Blues' is a wonderful cacophony, but it's just reiterating what we all know anyway. I remember when that crazy box set of all the sessions from this came out - I actually downloaded it and listened and it was pretty good in a historic sense, but ultimately the album is the album and that's what the reputation rests upon. [31 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Pylon- !!

Label: Armageddon Records

Format: Vinyl 10"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I love Pylon and I have everything they released in their original run, which involves a lot of overlap. This 10" has 'Cool' and 'Dub' on side 1, which is unnecessary since I own the 'Cool'/'Dub' 7", and also Gyrate which has both tracks. The flipside is 'Driving School' and 'Danger!!', both of which are on Gyrate as well. At least I got rid of the Hits CD some years ago. So why own this? Well, I came across it, which is a good reason, and why not be a completist? Plus I like the 10" format, the artwork, and the flexibility of playing this while DJing ('Danger!!' could be a fun sleeper to jam in the right environment). [23 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Residents - Not Available

Label: Ralph Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

One of the best Residents records, for sure! Not Available was supposedly recorded years before it's release and it might be the one Residents record to cite for the definitive early Residents sound. There's warbling, melting voices, strange keyboards, a dim vision that seems to celebrate circular logic ... in short, it's everything I want from a Residents LP. [9 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Kevin Coyne And Dagmar Krause - Babble

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Oft-forgotten concept album about a relationship falling apart due to a failure in communication; these two actually work pretty well together, and some of Coyne's songs rank among his best (that I have heard). Krause's voice is an acquired taste of course, but I love it and there are some really pretty, fairly conventional sounding duets that even my Mom might like. [1/3/2004] Is this ever going to be reissued? Especially in light of Coyne's death? [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Tuxedomoon - No Tears

Label: No label

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Fuck, do I love early Tuxedomoon. This self-released debut contains 'No Tears', probably their best song, which sort of sounds like they're taking the piss out of the Cure (or at least Robert Smith), except I think this pre-dates the Cure. It's an epic, driving song, and an amazing debut release. 'Nite & Day' seems to tackle the political arena, or at least address the repetition of work - and 'Litebulb Overkill' is a beautiful instrumental, led by Blaine Reininger's violin, which looks to some of the unique modal work which made Tuxedomoon fit better on Ralph than on any sort of post-punk label. This is angry, edgy, and sounds like the product of forward thinking art students in 1978, which is exactly what it is. [15 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Rhys Chatham - Factor X

Label: Moers Music

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Don't let that new wave haircut fool you - this is serious music for serious people. Except it's still "rock". Chatham is someone I've never completely understood. This is absolutely a "composition", especially side A which is called 'For Brass' and has George Lewis, Olu Dara and others. But the brass is all mixed together into a fairly underwhelming drone, which makes me wonder why he bothered getting such legends of their instruments. Anton Fier's drumming dominates and while it's nice enough, somewhat reminding me of Central African tribal drumming, it's, I dunno, just "okay". The B-sides gets more into the rock guitar/Branca thing, with James Lo taking over drumming duties. The three compositions here are fairly indistinct but have some nice moments. If you love the clangy sound of strummed electric guitar chords - and I do - then there's a lot to like here, especially when the momentum slows. [30 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Terry Riley - Happy Ending

Label: Warner Bros. Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This Terry Riley obscurity is two side-long pieces, the first being a darkly modal keyboard workout and the second one having a bit more of a triumphant lift, not unlike his work on the Cale collaboration.  This brightness is probably the justification for the title, 'Happy Ending', as opposed to a Thai massage parlor activity, though I like to imagine TR in his flowing white robes getting jacked by a 'therapist'.  Better than I remember this being - when I first got this record almost ten years ago I thought it was forgettable, but today it's hitting the spot, particualrly the flutes poking out of the corners.  [18 Jan 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Slits - Cut

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I was reading an Internet messageboard last night and there was a debate about Raincoats vs. Slits, in that typical music nerd way that makes you feel you have to choose one or the other (ie: Beatles vs. Stones, Dylan vs. Neil etc.). As stupid as it was, it got me thinking about how unfortunate that these two artists always get lumped together just because they were both females from the same scene. The Raincoats have a sophistication that is almost unparalleled, but then again, they probably influenced each other more than I realised. Cut is considered a classic of the era, but I've never liked it half as much as their second album (which has almost no critical acclaim whatsoever, so I guess I'm just weird). It's certainly good - the more pronounced reggae/dub influences really stand them apart from other danceable punks of the time, like Gang of Four - it's a more mellow and fluid sound, but no less pointed. 'Typical Girls' is probably the most memorable track, or 'Shoplifting' (or at least they were the singles) but I really like 'Newtown' and 'Adventures Close To Home', which use the tension of the dub and the breathy background chants to really propel along something that bears only a slight resemblance to punk. I love the guitar tone throughout, which is always clean and crisp; the few keyboards that sneak in add even more colour, which I think benefits the Slits. [16 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Residents - The Third Reich 'N' Roll

Label: Ralph Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Some time since I listened to this; there's a lot of wonderful fun I forgot all about. Somehow this mashup of 60s songs sounds fresh and genuinely subversive after all these years, or maybe this is just my bias. So many good details here - the way the voices and percussion and piano work so well on the 'hanky panky' part, the way the synths stretch fart and melt, and how genius the ending part of 'Swastikas on Parade' is. I wonder if any royalties were ever paid to the 1910 Fruitgum Company of the Human Beinz or anyone else covered here (or semi-covered) - especially the Beatles, whose 'Hey Jude' is totally disgraced and warped at the end. Maybe this is the Residents' best record overall - it's conceptual but not overly conceptual, and any track stands alone as an example of what drew me to the Residents in the first place. [13 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Soft Boys - Give It To The Soft Boys

Label: Raw Records (2)

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

'Wading Through a Ventilator' shows a side of the Soft Boys not heard on Underwater Moonlight or the other releases - a furious, physical rampage through Robyn Hitchcock's mind. The lyrics suggest sensuality through a very surrealist lens; the delivery does not pause for breath, and I'm left without any. On the b-side we get slightly more psychedelic Soft Boys tunes - 'The Face of Death, written by the whole group, has thick, multitracked guitars in a nervous style; 'Hear My Brane' has a angular, contrapuntal lead that is somewhat Beefheartian, around a song structure that's closer to Steppenwolf. Overall the whole 7" challenges the notion that the Soft Boys were a misplaced beast, out of step with their time; if anything, they were a bit ahead of it. [19 August 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Terry Riley - Shri Camel

Label: CBS Masterworks

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I dig this Terry Riley record, a noodly keyboard-driven jam that reminds me of his Persian Surgery Dervishes - a melodic bed that seems to keep expanding and folding back in on itself. Trying to follow any piece of this would surely be an exercise in meditative listening, though I just let it wash over me. The four tracks are slightly distinguishable from one another, but not astoundingly so -- it could all be one movement. Not essential, but fun. [1 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Stooges

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I'm a far bigger fan of the Stooges first album than I am of Raw Power, because mostly of 'We Will Fall', the epic Cale-driven jam that makes you realise how fuckin' avant-garde the Stooges were in 1969. Cale's presence and production suggests and affinity with the Velvet Underground, but there's so much more ragged glory here than on any VU record. Maybe it's the midwest vs. NYC - different attitudes, different styles, right? This record actually has a large presence of handclaps and that Nuggets-era production style, though with more fiery guitars. It's not as nihilistic as Fun House but it's still one of the most unique debuts in rock history. 'Not Right' and 'Real Cool Time' are utterly great Stooges songs that tend to be overshadowed by 'No Fun' and '1969', but I love them just as much. [28 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Slits - Typical Girls

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Two of the best known songs from early Slits, this is nice to have as a single for DJ purposes as 'Typical Girls' sounds great at 45rpm. The b-side isn't on Cut and is a fun, reggae-ish revamping of an old standard. The serious, European delivery of the vocals and the minor key mood makes this a much darker reading than whomever did the original (I can only think of the California Raisins' version off the top of my head) and of course infused with the gender politics that are so easy to read into these bands. [8 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

The Stickmen - This Is The Master Brew

Label: Phantom Plaything/Red Records 

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I remember old Pittsburgh guys talking about this legendary Stickmen record back when I used to be more excited about herky-jerky spazzed out punk/funk. This was quite collectible in its day so it was nice to find it, cause it is a great product. Stickmen were from Philly, I think, and bear a resemblance to the Pop Group and artists like that, but are not completely alike - in fact, there's a much more ragged and violent edge here, as there's no interest in appealing to a sense of fun. The musicianship is top notch, the production perfectly solid-state, and while I rarely (if ever) listen to stuff like this, it's a worthwhile endeavor. [28 September 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Michael Nyman 

Label: Piano Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is an incredibly rare record on Piano (This Heat's original label) that has most of the soundtrack to The Falls (Peter Greenaway, 1980), except it isn't credited as such. Listening to this music on it's own is super fucking intense, cause it makes me think of The Falls, which is pretty intense, and the repetitve baroqueness isn't exactly something I put on to relax to. Awesome. [3 January 2004]

---------------

FILM: The Falls

BOOK: The Falls


Date: 24 October 2002

Michael Nyman - The Draughtsman's Contract

Label: DRG

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I have this more as a fan of Greenaway than the soundtrack itself, which I don't remember that well (having only seen this film once or twice) but still enjoying it when I'm in the mood for this type of neo-baroque whatever. I don't own the soundtrack to A Zed and Two Noughts which is the one I know in and out from so many film viewings, but I suppose I don't even need to have it on vinyl. The opening piece on side two is the one really distinguished theme from the film that I remember, and I think this is one I'll keep, even though I'm much more likely to listen to the awesome self-titled release on Piano records when I want to listen to this stuff outside of a film. [23 November 2012]

-------------- FILM: Draughtsman's Contract


Date: 24 October 2002

Hugh Hopper - 1984

Label: CBS

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is the great Hugh Hopper record to have, an exploratory session that holds nothing back and fits in well against a lot of the Euro 70s out-weirdness that I've been so into (Mahongany Brain, Horde Catacylsm, etc).  Side one is built around the electric bass, played in an open, dissolving manner that shows a mastery of timbre and experimentation. There's prog-rock parts, but they aren't the main focus. Side two is centered around 'Miniplenty', another long track that is mostly spacey improvisation. The group is small here - mostly Hopper, some horns (Lol Coxhill!) and a rhythm section. Compared to the more standard jazz-rock of the other one I have, this is an entirely different beast. [2 October 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Musica Elettronica Viva - Leave The City

Label: BYG Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The first time I heard this record was right about the time I was discovering the No Neck Blues Band, and it seemed like the blueprint for their sound. Of course this is not representative of MEV, as it's not even really members of MEV, but as a communal European freakout it's a classic. We should all leave the city, at least occasionally. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 24 October 2002

Musica Elettronica Viva - The Sound Pool

Label: BYG Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This jammy free-for-all is the 'real' MEV (as opposed to Leave the City which I think is just some French guys using the name). Despite the presence of Curran, Teitelbaum and Rzewski, this is an incredibly amateurish sound collective, a real inspiration for Vibracathedral Orchestra and full of thick screaming horns and voices. The horns are really over the top which makes this so exuberant. The recording is split into two tracks on each side, which are separated by sudden tape splices - it's a weird effect because this could really be one long piece, at least on side 1. The wigged out amateurism of Amon Duul 1 is one comparison, or maybe a less intellectual Scratch Orchestra. Great stuff; it's electroacoustic collective improv with bite! [14 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Neil Young - American Tour

Label: none

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Bootleg LP. Purchased but lent to Jason Kirker, I think, and I never got it back.


Date: 24 October 2002

Kevin Ayers - Odd Ditties

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Outtakes collection, containing a lot of overlap with things I already had and things I didn't want. Sold.


Date: 24 October 2002

Lindsay Cooper - Rags

Label: Ré Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Rags is a real gem; a song cycle dealing with issues of labour and gender, built around her reeds and with a Frith/Cutler core. The male vocals are handled by Phil Minton and the female by Sally Potter; Minton gives it a very dramatic edge, which puts the Brecht/Weill influence even more full-on. This sounds like something created for a one-off performance but it stands up as an album; despite the pointed vision of the project, it's pushes for a new relationship between songcraft and musical exploration, like most of the best Cow-related projects. The ending cut of Potter singing operatically over recordings of water and a piano is magnificent. [1 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

Tuxedomoon - Scream With A View

Label: PRE Records

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Early Tuxedomoon is dripping with young art-school tendencies, found so commonly in British post-punk circa 1979; that these guys are American doesn't really change much, as the metallic sheen and futurist foreboding carries across. It's the synth treatments, particularly on songs like 'Special Treatment for the Family Man' that make this seem underwater, and the saxophone solos add a surreal level that is almost ironic if it wasn't so creepy. [29 November 2012]


Date: 24 October 2002

V/A - The Wild Sounds Of New Music

Label: Columbia

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Owing this is a novelty - it's a freebie 7" with Harry Partch, Terry Riley, and LaMonte Young on it - like a 20th century composer grab bag. I wonder if it's worth anything? [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 28 October 2002

Gerbils - Battle of Electricity

Label: Orange Twin

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Scott Spillane

Cost: $8

This was the Gerbils' swan song, I guess, and also probably my own last purchase from the Elephant 6-related fountain. Compared to the fun, bouncy pop of their first album and singles, this is a somewhat restrained effort. The ten titled songs are interspersed with unnamed interludes, often built around horns and mostly instrumental. The comparison to Neutral Milk Hotel's instrumental bits is unavoidable since half of the band is shared, but Jeremy Barnes's drumming isn't that spazzy and the songwriting, as much as I like it, lacks the surrealist depth of Mangum's. But these are different bands and it's nice that the Gerbils can step away from the trappings of the indie-pop genre they once inhabited. Even when they step on the fuzz pedals and start riffing, it's a bit downbeat:  'Meteroid from the Sun Strikes a Dead Weirdo' has the most classic rock overtures, and 'a Song of Love' retains some sun with great harmonies and ringing vocal hooks. I bet I listened to this once in 2001, if even, but it's actually got a lot to love about it - the 'mature' followup, clichéd even, but worthwhile, is always one for slow burns and this certainly is. [23 July 2012]


Date: 28 October 2002

A Hawk And A Hacksaw - A Hawk And A Hacksaw

Label: Cloud Recordings

Format: CD

Source: Jeremy Barnes

Cost: $0



Date: 30 October 2002

Don Cherry - Blue Lake

Label: Get Back

Format: 2xLP Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $20

Blue Lake is a glowing ball of beautiful sound, with Cherry's exuberant personality draped all over it. After the title track, really an introduction, Cherry, introduces his band of Okay Tamiz and Dollar Brand and then spends the next side and a half performing their compositions, which are sweet and melodic. There's a lot of piano, chanting, and percussion and a bit of trumpet, yes, but this is really a platform for Cherry's vocalising. The second LP is a track called 'East' which is long and loose, with dark modal piano segents and then some catchy, simple melodies. Johnny Dyani is on bass and works well with Tamiz to propel what would otherwise be rudimentary piano licks into something soulful. This is a wonderful Don Cherry record, like most of them, and far more accessible in the organic earthjazz swing style than others. [25 November 2012]


Date: 30 October 2002

Six Organs Of Admittance - Dark Noontide

Label: Holy Mountain

Format: CD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $8

Looking back at this disc after Six Organs has achieved much more success, I can't help but feel drawn to this earlier work more (along with Dust and Chimes). Not that I fault Chasny for attempting to do something different, and trying to expand upon his talents, but these darker earlier records are more evocative of the type of sound that I enjoy. The work of Alastair Galbraith and a lot of those moody Kiwis is references, and the 4-track hiss and distortion complements the songwriting well. This is not unlike the kind of thing Luke and I were trying to do in Land, and thus I'll always have some sort of soft-spot for it. Too bad Tamburo lost my copy of this. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 30 October 2002

Alan Silva & Celestrial Communication Orchestra - Luna Surface

Label: BYG Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

In reading about this for a long time on one of those early 90's Thurston Moore-compiled lists of obscure noisy record that I didn't know anything about, I sort of built this up to be the ultimate in legendary free jazz. Finally buying this reissue in 2002 I was pretty disappointed by the product. The mix was terrible and it basically is a big ball of freaked-out noise, but not even a remarkable one. I think I'd take any of the European improvisers from the Dutch axis before this one, like the Globe Unity Orchestra. Of course, I am writing this without having heard it in 3 years, for when I bought it, I basically filed it after listening once and moved on. When I return to America, it might be time to give it another gander. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 30 October 2002

Grachan Moncur III - Aco Dei De Madrugada (One Morning I Waked Up Very Early)

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl LP Reissue

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

This is a really short release, under a half-hour, featuring Moncur with some Portuguese musicians and Beb Guerin on bass. Fernando Martins' piano is actually the lead instrument here, as Moncur seems content to be band leader with some mellow trombone licks here and there. The trombone does sound great - like a really bummed out trumpet at times, and it adds the right amount of colour to these numbers. Side 1's two pieces are both Brasilian traditionals, the title track being built around a beautiful sung vocal line which repeats itself in a Mixolydian mode. The originals on side two are slow and feel-good, getting into some moods here and there but generally having the feel of musicians feeling each other out. [4 Aug 2012]


Date: 2 November 2002

Red Transistor - Not Bite / We're Not Crazy

Label: Ecstatic Peace!

Format: Vinyl 7" EP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $0

gift for Adam


Date: 2 November 2002

Camper Van Beethoven - Key Lime Pie

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $0

I used to have a cassette of Fugazi's In On the Killtaker. In 9th grade a kid named Bryan Roberts smashed it by accident, joking around, and had to give me $9 to replace it. Instead I bought this album (on cassette), and spent the summer before 10th grade listening to it on my shitty headphones over and over and over. I have very distinct memories of being in the back of my parents' Dodge Caravan listening to "Borderline" on the way to Cambridge, OH to buy fireworks. That old cassette still gets frequent play in my car. I love Camper Van Beethoven, and this record is really different for them, and had I heard it now for the first time I might not care for it, but wow, what a wonderful record. When I was 15, "alternative rock" was the whole world to me, and there's a certain mysticism I still attach to this album because of what an important role it played during my adolescent development/formation of artistic interests/etc. David Lowery's songwriting peaked here - he was able to shrug off the humour and really be serious in his ambitions, and "Sweethearts" and "June" can still bring tears to my eyes (the former was my favorite song throughout pretty much all of 1994-1996). I don't even know what I need to say about this record now. "The Humid Press of Days" strikes me as a total Beefheart tribute (which I never realized in high school) and "Jack Ruby" is a really edgy, gritty song that is unlike anything else CVB ever did. This album is essential to the existence of John W Fail. [2 Jan 2004]


Date: 2 November 2002

Refrigerator - Rocking Horse Loser 7"

Label: Jupa

Format: 7" EP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $0

This is Refrigerator's first 7", from around the same time as the Lonesome Surprise and Rael cassettes, which was 1991. As to be expected, it's pretty raw and cacophonous; Allen's voice is stretched like a teenager in heat, and the drumming is awesomely crap, especially on punk bursts like 'Nickel'. 'Winter Cooler Stories' is one of the best Refrigerator songs and it's hard not to love 'Junk' ("We don't sit here anymore..."). I love how bands will cram six songs onto their first 7" since they didn't have many chances to release records, so this gets a big thumbs up even if it's not the more polished, adult Refrigerator. To be honest, I love this band to the point where I love all eras of their work equally; this is great to have, especially as something I found at Jerry's! [23 July 2012]


Date: 2 November 2002

Sightings - Untitled

Label: Freedom From

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $0

on trade


Date: 6 November 2002

Mountain Goats - Tallahassee

Label: 4AD

Format: CD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $13

A few years after this came out, I find that I have little desire to ever listen to it. My love of the Mountain Goats grew out of his early, ragged boombox work. Now, the 4AD studio incarnation is more of a singles band - each CD has a few great songs, but a lot of polished yet forgettable material. I don't know that I'm even going to keep listening, which is a sad thing to say when I think to how passionate I was about Darnielle a decade ago. [13 Sept 2007]


Date: 8 November 2002

Grand Buffet - Cigarette Beach

Label: Not On Label

Format: CD

Source: Grand Buffet

Cost: $5

not as good as angels


Date: 9 November 2002

Burning Star Core - California CD-R #2

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CD-R Album

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0



Date: 9 November 2002

Burning Star Core - Live in Oxford OH, 4.06.02

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CDr

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0



Date: 12 November 2002

Landing - Fade In/Fade Out

Label: Strange Attractors Audio House

Format: CD Maxi-Single

Source: Daron Gardner

Cost: $0

Whatever happened to these guys? Ten years ago this came out, classified as a maxi-single, but really a full album at 37 minutes. This does that Landing thing well; gorgeous oceans of guitar drones and plucked, reverberating notes, all slowly swelling into undulating waves that drift across the air like water beading on glass. There's not a whole lot of singing here, but when Adrienne steps it up (as on 'Whirlwind') it's beautiful and integrates perfectly with the band. Daron's light touch on the traps is perfect, and it all slowly crystallizes. 'Pulse' opens up structurally and has some striking e-bow waves. [1 Aug 2012]


Date: 12 November 2002

Yellow 6/Rothko/Landing - newfoundland

Label: Music Fellowship

Format: CD Album

Source: Daron Gardner

Cost: $0



Date: 13 November 2002

Charles Mingus - The Black Saint And The Sinner Lady

Label: Impulse!

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Record Village

Cost: $8

I've had this on CD for ages but my cousin sold me a vinyl copy, so now I can experience this masterpiece in the superior format. There's not much else I can say about this record that hasn't been said before - it's a brilliant evocation of folk sounds and jazz, and it has a badass attitude, and it's beautiful, and you can dance to it, and Mingus probably never made a better record. The New Wave of Folk Is on Impulse! and except for Liberation Music Orchestra nothing quite compares. [2 January 2004]


Date: 13 November 2002

V/A - Music of Indonesia vol. 19

Label: 

Format: CD

Source: Record Village

Cost: $6



Date: 20 November 2002

Simon Wickham-Smith And Richard Youngs - Knish

Label: Ignivomous

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: ebay

Cost: $10

probably my favorite R!!!/S!!! Record, and now I actually own it. [20 November 2002] Knish holds up pretty well - it's probably one of the most 'accessible' R!!!/S!!! Records, containing little dissonance, and as minimalist composition goes it's very well defined. However, it's the atmosphere that really kills me here - the drift of the piano chords and the searing attack of the guitar - and I would recommend this as a starting point probably for those interested in diving into this bizarre, wonderful discography. [2 January 2004]  Is it still my favourite?  It's too hard to pick one, but on this cold Tuesday morning, Knish hits the spot, and I wonder if I've listened to it since last reviewed in 2004? The opening side-long piece is just majestic and sweeping, and despite being only two people it's a huge sound.  And it's actually kind of annoying at times, which I never realised before, which is not necessarily a bad thing.  Side two's 'The Librarian and the Monk' (describing these two's occupations, of course) is the really pounding (or rather plinking), sharp pointy jam.  'Isabel Wears Pink' returns to the melodic, searing guitar of 'Quagmire' with a more active piano part, and it's simplicity manages to channel up dark chasms of psych goodness while still being melodic.  I actually wish this had been recorded beter - the radio station production is a bit thin at times and I love the sound of the piano.  [8 November 2011]


Date: 20 November 2002

Richard Youngs and Simon Wickham-Smith - Enedkeg

Label: Majora

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: ebay

Cost: $10

I always classify Enedkeg with Knish, as they both came out around the same time, have similar handmade covers and are really minimal pieces. 'Normal' is a great SONG - a proper song that somehow sounds like no other artist, and also like nothing else that R!!!S!!! ever made. 'More Urban Music for the Middle of Nowhere' is the masterpiece though - a slow electronic drawl that perfectly suits the title. It's the landscape of British New Towns and failed concrete dreams, and on vinyl it sounds fantastic - both cuts on side 1 would probably make it onto a R!!!S!!! greatest hits, if such a thing were possible. Side two is the lengthy 'Duet', the most drony thing these guys ever did apart from 'Goat' - and it's a lovely piece of minimalism, but a bit plain. I love what these two did in the 90s because it was so colourful and eclectic, so while this is a perfectly serviceable effort, give me Red and Blue Bear anyday. While 'More Urban Music' is every bit as minimal, there's so much more variation within it's running time than 'Duet' and by sequencing it like this, I can't help but get slightly bored, even when 'Duet' attenuates its tone towards pure madness. [26 July 2012]


Date: 25 November 2002

From Quagmire - Caught in Unknowing

Label: VHF

Format: CD

Source: vhf

Cost: $0

There aren't a lot of From Quagmire fans out there, and probably none at all in Estonia, but I always loved this weird, distant, sparse band (and Dorothy's earlier band, Laconic Chamber). I haven't listened to them in ages, ever since putting on a show for her current singer-songwriter stuff, but it's a nice thing to revisit. The percussion and violin are what makes this - it's eerier than anyone could do just solo. The twelve-minute 'Victims and Second Viennese' in the middle of this disc is a meandering horror show of scratchy strings and start-stop melodies, and it's incredible compelling. [17 October 2012]


Date: 25 November 2002

Youngsbower - Relayer

Label: VHF Records

Format: CD Album

Source: vhf

Cost: $0

It's been over a year since I bought this CD, but it's probably one of the most inspiring CD's that I have ever bought since I started listing this stuff. As much as I've been becoming a Youngs obsessive over the years, this CD might be my favorite work that he has ever done (or at least tied with Sapphie). It's a bit hard to describe, but it's a total sea of sound, stationary yet full of movement at the same time, and getting lost in it is a great pleasure. I sort of forgot about this until recently, then pulled it out and though "shit, this is like the best fucking thing ever." I try to avoid superlatives on here, but I definitely have to say that this is a masterpiece. [2 January 2004]


Date: 25 November 2002

Richard Youngs and Stephen Todd - Georgians

Label: VHF

Format: CD

Source: vhf

Cost: $10

This was one of the first Richard Youngs releases I ever heard and it really grabbed me; a shame that Stephen Todd basically disappeared from the radar after this. The working methods don't sound tremendously different from what Richard and Simon Wickham-Smith were doing around the same time. This is largely keyboard driven, with lots of echo/reverb and some lovely instrumental constructions, some homemade synth noises, and some wordless vocals. The album is built around two long tracks - 'Sixteen 00', an eternally ascending keyboard pattern with chimes, and 'Perranuthruoe', which is built around amplified and process breaths. It's a standalone work by these two and one that is really easy to enjoy. [23 November 2012]


Date: 25 November 2002

Richard Youngs and Simon Wickham-Smith - Metallic Sonatas

Label: VHF

Format: CD

Source: vhf

Cost: $10

These fifteen untitled mostly-instrumentals are probably called 'metallic' because actual metallic surfaces dominate the sound-images througohut. This is electroacoustic improv, sometimes active, exploring duo jams (as in track 6, or the shrill workout on track 10) and sometimes washed-out soundscapes, which, even when minimal, maintain prickly textures throughout. Voice appears as an instrument, but with the spectre of feedback always looming behind. Digital effects are all over this release, but it still feels somewhat organic, probably because these guys have such an earthy approach to sound. There's a close attention to construction and a calm patience; even though this is one of the lesser R!!!/S!!! releases it's still solid, maintaining a balance between ear candy and difficult, challenging improv. [16 July 2012]


Date: 25 November 2002

Matthew Bower / Richard Youngs - Site / Realm

Label: Insample

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: vhf

Cost: $10

This early collaboration between Youngs and Bower disappoints a bit after the phenomenal Relayer (which is possibly my favorite work in the entire Youngs body of work). Centered around electric guitar, this LP is a bit of an atonal guitar workout, with some dissonant clangy parts that still show the two musicians working off of each other, though without the complexity of the Youngsbower disc. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 13 December 2002

Outhud - S.T.R.E.E.T. D.A.D.

Label: Kranky

Format: LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $10

I wasn't wild about this ten years ago, though I had previously scooped up Outhud's singles, really being interested in this band who looked to merge smart contemporary punk with dub and other such rhytmic forms. My initial attraction was probably due to the marriage of musical complexity with punk ethos, though actually that was really !!! I was thinking of, and they weren't that complex. But after a long period without listening and now-fresh ears, S.T.R.E.E.T. D.A.D. reveals itself as far more interesting than I remember. A closer comparison than dub would be 80s post-punk like Rip Rig and Panic, later Slits, and various offshoots, plus some 4AD artists from the 80s like Dif Juz. The instrumental LP has a lot of dubby effects, sure, but I think it's more descended from these British artists, so it's influence through influence. The clean channel electric guitar is lovely, clanging against the sudden whooses of white noise and other textures, generated (it sounds like) from mostly cheap equipment. This sounds pretty good when loud, and also reminds me of the summer though maybe that's just cause it's summertime now. [27 July 2012]


Date: 13 December 2002

Art Ensemble of Chicago - Live in Paris 1969

Label: Get Back

Format: 2xLP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

Two lengthy jams, 'Oh Strange' and 'Bon Voyage', recorded at the peak of their pre-Don Moye powers, Paris,1969. Malachi Favors handles the percussion duties, playing full drum kit on 'Bon Voyage', which explodes in a thunder of free exploration. Fontella Bass is present now and then but really this is the place for the core group to shine. And while the usual instrumentation is present - reeds, trumpet, flutes, logs, wood blocks and other little sounds - there's a lot of marimba and vibes present, thanks to Joseph Jarman. 'Oh Strange' is certainly more spacious, and if these are being presented in the order they were performed then you can feel the energy ramp up as it goes along. This is a group that has two amazing live double LPs - the Live at Mandel Hall is equally sprawling - and I only wish we had even more from this incredibly fertile period. [3 November 2012]


Date: 13 December 2002

This Heat - Tago Mago CD

Label: bootleg

Format: CD Album

Source: McDowell

Cost: $15

bought as charity from the destitute mcdowell. This is a bootleg This Heat CD, really only necessary for the first track, originally released as a cassette with a French zine. This is a percussive, improvisatory This Heat, and while it's in no way my favorite material of theirs, it's This Heat so it's essential. The second track is actually Albert Marcour solo, though it's billed as This Heat, and the rest of the CD is filled out by a bad-sounding CD transfer of the Health and Effieciency 12" (which "Graphic/Varispeed" included at both speeds). [2 January 2004]


Date: 13 December 2002

Smog - Accumulation: None

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl LP Compilation

Source: Paul's

Cost: $10

An uneven singles/rarities compilations that tries to go for a thematic feel instead of comprehensiveness. I would have preferred the latter, maybe as a double CD, but I guess as a standalone record this is all right. I'm really biased in that I only like mid-period Smog, so of course those songs are my favorites here. The alternate versions of more well-known songs are the most memorable of course, but "Astronaut" and "A Hit" are also keepers. I will rarely pull this out to listen to it. [8 Feb 2005]


Date: 21 December 2002

Sun City Girls - Three Fake Female Orgasms

Label: Majora

Format: 2x7" EP

Source: ebay

Cost: $9.59

A double 7" at 33rpm is almost an album, right? By my calculations this is 28 inches total, vs. the LP's 24 inches, and the 7 songs here are long and jammy. So considering this as an album, it's gotta rank as one of the Girls' best, though we don't think about it much cause it's in the box of rarely listened-to 7"s records and the format is a bit annoying with all the flipping. But 'Plaster Cupids Falling from the Ceiling', which opens this, is about as perfect as a signature song as any of their others. This is circa-enough the Torch of the Mystics period that even if they tried, they couldn't get the stench of absolute, total musical genius out of these grooves. But they are trying, if anything, to be great, and great it is. This is all epic guitar jams, built around songs which are open for exploration yet remarkably focused; the full power of psychedelic rock music in full force. Some of these have become classics for me - 'Souvenirs from Jangare','Sun Damaged My Ass!' - and it actually flows really well as an album. This was a great score for the price and my fascination with this band hasn't waned in the intervening years.  [19 December 2012]


Date: 29 December 2002

Spike Jones and His City Slickers - Strictly For Music Lovers

Label: Proper

Format: 4xCD box

Source: Copacetic Comics

Cost: $0

(from gift certificate)


Date: 29 December 2002

The Band - Music From Big Pink

Label: Capitol Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

The Band's first album was an impulse buy back when I got it, but I've grown to really enjoy it. There's a distinct "earthyness" to their sound that I've really warmed up to, and I love the idea of a bunch of guys really focusing on recording a great record, without any rockstar egos to go with it. Dylan's presence is felt not just in the artwork but in the "down home" feel of the songwriting, which at times reminds me of gospel music in it's vocal inflections. [1/2/2004]


Date: 29 December 2002

Miles Davis - Live-Evil

Label: Columbia

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $8

Live Evil isn't that evil but it has an edge pulse that more or less stays through all four sides, whether its swampy jazz-rock ('Sivad'),  jammy piano/flute licks ('What I Say'), or even the most soundtracky interludes. Jarrett and Hancock really dominate this, despite the other talents at play. I'm not really a huge Miles Davis fan (and I don't call him just "Miles" like many annoying University students) so this more or less satisfies the rare desire I have to indulge. [18 December 2012]


Date: 29 December 2002

Roy Wood - Mustard

Label: United Artists

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $5

This record can never live up to the genius of Boulders, but it's not to be overlooked. The Wizzard approach is a little more integrated, with some genre pieces losing my interest. The highlight of the album is certainly "The Rain Came Down on Everything" or whatever it's called - a dirgy song that reminds me of Todd Rundgren, and steps back from the Tin Pan Alley/Nilsson influences a bit. [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 30 December 2002

Christopher Tree / Spontaneous Sound - At The Cathedral Of St. John The Divine

Label: Locust Music

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $13

Here's a record I remembered fondly from when I last listened to it six years ago; Christopher Tree, another forgotten late 60's/early 70's sound explorer who made this record inside a cathedral in 1970.  It's a one-man affair, with some percussion and more tonal drones very slowly flirted with through the duration of the album. It's extremely sparse, with Tree happy to let the room take the lead.  It doesn't completely work as deep listening/meditative music though, as there's nothing mantra-like or repetitive - it's more like a workshop, with one man testing out a variety of sounds and letting each sound count, sinking into the air for as long as he can let it.  It's not everyday listening but the thick vinyl pressing carries the sound of the room very well. [9 Jan 2009]


Date: 30 December 2002

His Name Is Alive - Last Night

Label: 4AD

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $3

got $5 off total, was $8. Most recent HNIA full-length (and ultimately the last on 4AD) steps back from the modern R&B approach and takes a more power-pop approach, though the soul element is still prevalent. What results is a stronger album, and oddly my favorite song seems to be the Ida cover (though I've never liked Ida). What will Warn do next? [10 Nov 2005]


Date: 30 December 2002

Destroyer - City Of Daughters

Label: Cave Canem Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $9

This is Destroyer's second album, though probably the earliest that will ever be re-released (Bejar told me he's a bit embarassed by his first offering); it's a mixture of short song sketches performed solo and more fleshed out band pieces. The solo tracks have their moments, and their intimacy is enhanced by the sound of falling rain in the background. The more band pieces are also good, though lacking the impact of Thief and Streethawk material. And like Thief, the album suffers slightly from some aimless instrumental interludes. But it's nice to hear the genesis of Bejar, who really hit his stride right after this album. [2 January 2004]


Date: 30 December 2002

Destroyer - This Night

Label: Scratch Records

Format: 2xLP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

Dan Bejar's major "maturation" is a doozy of a pop record, and definitely a great step forward for him. The expanded production benefits him greatly; additional instrumentation is nice, though I do miss the band of the last two or three; I just couldn't imagine a song as majestic as "The Chosen Ones" coming from those guys. However, at sixty-some minutes he stretches out a little bit beyond his boundaries, causing this record to suffer from the typical "double album" syndrome. Still, this is a continuation of the infection madness by one of my favorite contemporary songwriters, and when I got new speakers the title track was the first thing I played through them. [2 January 2004]


Date: 30 December 2002

Charlambides - INCREASE

Label: Eclipse Records

Format: 2xLP Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

I'm not sure how I feel about this record. It's a very long, very dense set of drones for guitar and keyboard. There are no vocals that I can remember, and at times the music makes me feel uncomfortable. It's a very physical unpleasantness, and I don't think I'd ever pull it out. Of course, not all music has to be pleasant. The images created by this music are very hazy, but distinct in tone; I think it's farily well done though I prefer their more accessible material. [2 January 2004]


Date: 30 December 2002

Holy Modal Rounders - The Mooray Eels Eat...

Label: 

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $13

A classic record of fucked-up psych weirdness. All of the songs run together, united by Weber and Stampel's off-kilter warblings. Caleb once remarked while listening to "If You Wanna Be A Bird?" that he figured my solo work would sound like this. Why doesn't it? [2 January 2004]


Date: 26 January 2003

13th Floor Elevators - Easter Everywhere

Label: International Artists

Format: Vinyl LP Album Reissue

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: €3.94

I don't think I like the 13th Floor Elevators as much as I did a few years ago, though this record is still awesome. In a perfect world you would hear "Slip Inside thie House" and "She Lives in a Time Of Her Own" on the radio on classic rock stations. Roky Erickson apparently lives in Pittsburgh now, whoulda thunk it? [2003] And now it's a few years later, and you know what - I love this record.  Much more than I used to.  Particularly because of how fragile and hopeless it sounds, in songs like "It's All Over Now Baby Blue" and especially "Dust", which is being elevated to my top fave psych songs of all-time.  Music is awesome when you grow and change and you find new things to love about it at different points in your life.  I now feel really privileged to own this. [18 March 2009]



Date: 26 January 2003

Adverts - Crossing The Red Sea With The Adverts

Label: Bright Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Totally great powerpoppunk. This is exactly what I thought punk was supposed to sound like when I was in 7th grade and first started reading about it; and as dated as it may sound, who can deny the wide-eyed genius that is "One Chord Wonders"? Glad to finally have this in my collection, and at a great price.


Date: 26 January 2003

Alternative TV - The Image Has Cracked

Label: Deptford Fun City

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Very interesting - I always thought Alternative TV were just another forgotten post-punk band, but they were a bit earlier and significantly more experimental. There are definitely some three-chord punk chuggers like "Action Time Vision", but there's a lot of arty ideas that, while not always succesful, are charming in their attempts. The first track is such a fucked up way to start a punk rock LP in 1977 - I'm sure it alienated any potential fans they might have had. Mark Perry is such a snotty overintellectual punk; it feels like he's been spending too much time reading Guy Debord and not enough listening to Fun House - but the pretentious dilettante in me appreciates the results. 


Date: 26 January 2003

Amon Düül - This Is Amon Düül

Label: Metronome 2001

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I can't decide if these guys are geniuses or charlatans. I always thought the first Amon Duul just sounded like a bad Ash Ra Tempel - I never had any idea how technically inept they were. This literally sounds like if Half Japanese enlisted a few friends and tried to make a Krautrock album. It's utterly tuneless plodding, devoid of any form, melody or development. Some parts remind me of the shitty improv bits [my project] has to skip over when listening to our old minidisc recordings. But by the end of this record I think I'm charmed into liking it, albeit it in a Jandek way - not ironic, but rather appreciative of the primitivism and failure instead of their intent.


Date: 26 January 2003

Amon Düül II - Wolf City

Label: United Artists Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A more fleshed-out, almost "orch-pop" side of Amon Duul 2. This is never listed in the "canon" but I think it's better than Phallus Dei - or at least more realized.


Date: 26 January 2003

The Work - Slow Crimes

Label: Woof Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $4.08

Tim Hodgkinson from Henry Cow led this band which are surprising contemporaries of This Heat - overpowered by drums and vocals, but there's all sorts of stuff going on, all held together by a driving punk energy. The Work are totally forgotten now, which is a crying shame, because it's yet another great art-rock spinoff of the Henry Cow axis. And Lepke Buchwater from the Homosexuals guests on it! Not as immediately gripping as This Heat, but definitely similar and second only to the Art Bears in post-Henry Cow greatness. Some parts remind me of Spunk, or at least the female vocals. Highly recommended.


Date: 26 January 2003

Germs - (GI)

Label: Slash Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

My punk knowledge has always had a big gap in it - west coast American punk has never been a major interest of mine. I've never owned any records by Black Flag or Circle Jerks, even though I have always liked those bands, and I have to confess I've never really listened to the Germs before. I expected them to be good, but not as good as this - fast, furious, snarling, and iconic, it's easy to hear why they were so inspirational. This record is actually produced really well (by Joan Jett!) which is nice to hear. [5 December 2003]


Date: 26 January 2003

Robert Ashley - Automatic Writing

Label: Lovely Music, Ltd.

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I LOVE this record. I don't even know what to say about it. It's maddening and horrendous to listen to yet so completely fucked that it works as a statement. Great at very low and very loud volumes, but not so great in between. Based on his experiences with Tourette's syndrome, it's focused around involuntary speech, which sounds almost like oval in a weird, glitchy way; but the best/worst part of this record is the weird bass thumping that sounds like your neighbor is playing the soundtrack to Miami Vice in the next apartment. Amazing, and this is one I will gladly keep on both vinyl and CD.


Date: 26 January 2003

Buzzcocks - Time's Up

Label: Not On Label

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Bootleg of Howard Devoto-era Buzzcocks. The sound is pretty weird but it works well, and the music rips. I can't tell if the Spiral Scratch songs are live or just replicated really poorly (because I don't own the original Spiral Scratch). 


Date: 26 January 2003

Buzzcocks - A Different Kind Of Tension

Label: I.R.S. Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I thought this was the one with "Moving Towards the Pulse Beat" on it, but it wasn't.


Date: 26 January 2003

Buzzcocks - Singles Going Steady

Label: I.R.S. Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The funny thing about getting these Buzzcocks LP is that they actually just came out with a new record, and I heard it at the record store, and it was actually pretty great! Not as great as this, of course. [2003]   Pulling this out for the first time in ages, I never stopped tapping my foot and singing along to all of the classics. Of course, if you only have one Buzzcocks record this is the one to have, as it's full of hits and party faves.  "What do I Get?", "Orgasm Addict", "Something's Gone Wrong Again", "Noise Annoys", etc. - all of these songs are brilliant and catchy and remind me of dancing at stupid club nights in Glasgow.  "Harmony in My Head" is a weird one, I think sung by Steve Diggle and maybe covered once by Camper Van Beethoven?  [2 Jan 2009]



Date: 26 January 2003

Cabaret Voltaire - Mix-Up

Label: Rough Trade (UK)

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I dunno why I never got into Cabaret Voltaire - I guess I was always scared away by the "industrial" association I had in my mind. And while there's definitely some strong rhythms and abrasive parts, this is really a group that has a big interest in surrealism. Not every song is a winner, but there are some moments that remind me of Chrome's aesthetic, perhaps through their very textural approach. I'll have to look for more of their stuff.


Date: 26 January 2003

Don Cherry - Where is Brooklyn?

Label: Blue Note

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The third (lost) Blue Note session, this is somewhat less memorable than Symphony for Improvisers and Complete Communion, but still a solid session. Pharoah Sanders appears on it. 


Date: 26 January 2003

Chrome - Alien Soundtracks

Label: Siren Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Raw, damaged and sounding not really like anything else of it's time. Parts of course sound "dated", but what the hell does that matter? I mean I don't complain that old Charley Patton recordings from 90 years ago sound dated! In fact, what I enjoy most is hearing a window into a period past. Chrome definitely make me think about what it was like to be a punk before punk, operating in your own fucked up world in the late 1970's and feeling extremely alienated. And the records hold up well, or at least this one does, but it's supposedly the best.


Date: 26 January 2003

Chrome - Red Exposure

Label: Beggars Banquet

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Probably my least favorite of the three Chrome albums I have, but still good. This is a bit too polished for me (the later "Third from the Sun" I actually like more). I think I still need Half Machine Lip Moves to complete my Chrome collection.


Date: 26 January 2003

London Jazz Composers Orchestra - Ode

Label: Incus

Format: 2xLP box

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This double LP in a nice box is the first release of the London Jazz Composers Orchestra, performing the music of Barry Guy though conducted by someone else. It's a fantastic landmark of British avant-garde jazz. Guy has a sweet style that mixed the melodic with the exploratory, and the list of players is a real who's-who of British jazz. Tony Oxley is astounding (i think).


Date: 26 January 2003

Negativland

Label: Seeland

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Negativland's debut LP sets the scene for their eventual career. They play a surprising amount of instruments on here, and even sing (at least I assume this is original music) but utilize tons of found sounds for comedic value. The social commentary seems lighter here than on their other stuff, or at least what I am familiar with. It reminds me a lot more of Nurse With Wound's Sylvia and Babs record than Negativland, actually.


Date: 26 January 2003

The Music Improvisation Company

Label: ECM Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Maybe I'm forgetting something obvious, but at 1970 this might be the earliest free jazz with electronics that I can think of (not counting AMM/MEV). Evan Parker on soprano and Derek Bailey are the big names here - with Hugh Davies on the electronics. This really isn't a far cry from what Parker's stuff is like 30 years later, though perhaps it's a bit more agitated. Percussionist Jamie Muir is pretty ramshackle, which I like a lot. This is another strong early ECM release that seems to be forgotten.


Date: 26 January 2003

Magma - Üdü Wüdü

Label: Charly Records Ltd.

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I haven't heard this since I was a freshman in college when I checked it out of the library. The centerpiece of the album is of course "De Futura", the side-long closer, which is really Janik Top's studio masterpiece. Side one has some more varied stuff - the opening track has this crazy percussion and horns on it that makes it sound Brazilian. The whole album is laden with over-the-top Magma singing which is ironically enjoyable - parts of "De Futura" remind me of German beer-hall singing. The chops are tight, though, with Vander's drums really being the lead instrument.


Date: 26 January 2003

ESG - ESG Says Dance To The Beat Of Moody

Label: 99 Records (US)

Format: Vinyl 12" EP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This ESG 12" sounds so fucking good on vinyl and at 45rpm. Booty-shaking dance-funk from Brooklyn that revels in it's repetition. There's an innocence to this music that makes it succeed.


Date: 26 January 2003

Eyeless In Gaza - Drumming The Beating Heart

Label: Cherry Red

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Second Eyeless in Gaza record sounds more romantic - with lots of synthy strings and passionate vocals. I think I might have enjoyed this more when I was younger - it lacks the danger of the earlier stuff.


Date: 26 January 2003

Dead Kennedys - Fresh Fruit For Rotting Vegetables

Label: Alternative Tentacles

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I remember buying this on cassette at Camelot Music in South Hills Village mall and listening to it on my walkman in 8th grade and just feeling totally inspired. 10 years later, it holds up amazingly well. It's hard to believe that people really flipped out over "I Kill Children" - it's clearly tongue-in-cheek, and so ridicoulous anyway.... "Forward to Death" might be my favorite punk anthem ever. If i actually gave these things numbers I'd probably give this a perfect score, and not just for nostalgia. They never got any better than this.


Date: 26 January 2003

The Fall - Live At The Witch Trials

Label: Step-Forward Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I love this first Fall record. Even among the millions of other punk rock records released in 1977, this must have really sounded like nothng else - even compared to the Alternative TV record I just reviewed above, this had to just sound like nothing else. And while attitude is a major component of this record too, the songwriting is actually amazing. The opening moments totally capture the fear, paranoia, and ambition of the punk times,and I can imagine myself transported back to a rainy alley in Manchester when I listen to it. Essential.


Date: 26 January 2003

The Feelies - Crazy Rhythms

Label: Stiff Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I love the Feelies - or at least their first two records. This is most people's favorite though I actually prefer The Good Earth cause I'm a folky jangle-loving dork. But this incarnation of the Feelies - quite different from what was to come later - synthesizes punk energy with college-rock nerdyness, and knows just when to build up/release the tension. There's a throwback to sixties pop that punks were afraid to embrace ("Fa Ce La" and the Beatles cover) that really gives it a unique charm. Plus the last few tracks are just awesome ("Crazy Rhythms" and "Moscow Nights").


Date: 26 January 2003

Nico  - The Marble Index

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP Album Mono

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Such a dark, dismal record. Not quite as out there as Desert Shore or The End but perhaps the best mix of accessible and fucked up. I own so many records like this it's a wonder I'm as upbeat as I am.


Date: 26 January 2003

Nico - Chelsea Girl

Label: MGM Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Nico's first solo album is definitely her most accessible, though its still mired in a dark, Germanic gloom. Jackson Browne's songwriting is really great and works well with her deep chanting; the arrangements are simple enough to carry the melodies and gives her room to make the songs her own. John Cale's songs sound like "All Tomorrow's Parties," but the Browne compositions are more major key, sentimental, et al. The stuff from The Royal Tenenbaums is especially great.


Date: 26 January 2003

The Contortions - Buy

Label: Ariola

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The first few tracks are great, but overall this is one of the most overrated records ever. There's a certain "attitude" that is the saving grace - but in terms of confrontation and aesthetic, they were far surpassed by, oh, just about everything. Like Chrome, for example (to look just a few lines above). But still, there is that attitude - a certain style of vocals, guitar shrieks and saxophone that gives it the impact. Their bits for No New York crush it, though.


Date: 26 January 2003

The Cosmic Jokers - The Cosmic Jokers

Label: Barclay

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The Cosmic Jokers never intended this to be relaesed -it was just a jam session that someone put out, a private party, an example of Krautrock luminaries getting together for tea (and probably weed) and goofing around a bit. But it's great. 


Date: 26 January 2003

Dead Kennedys - In God We Trust, Inc.

Label: Alternative Tentacles

Format: Vinyl Mini-Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is so fast and furious compared to it's predecessor, except for the goofy lounge stylings of "We've Got A Bigger Problem Now". It's great because it's so angry but the weird surf influences of Fresh Fruit are surely missed.


Date: 26 January 2003

Steve Miller  / Lol Coxhill - "The Story So Far..." "...Oh Really?"

Label: Cuneiform Records

Format: 2xCD

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

One part Lol Coxhill and the other Steve Miller - I don't know if it's "Fly Like an Eagle" Steve Miller. Probably the weakest entry of the Coxhill records I have; though there's still some bright moments. Miller's guitar is technically adept but lacks personality; the best parts are def. Coxhill.


Date: 26 January 2003

The Cosmic Jokers - Kinder Des Alls / Galactic Supermarket

Label: Kosmische Kuriere

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This second Cosmic Jokers record actually is a bit more cohesive - there are some very alien sounding parts that remind me of a sci-fi take on Popul Vuh. As much as you would tend to think that these are "typical Krautrock", there really is no such thing as "typical" when desribing this movement. Even the weak bits are still interesting. 


Date: 26 January 2003

The Cure - Pornography

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A really dark, inaccessible record that I've always considered the Cure's finest. It doesn't really give Robert Smith a chance to show off his pop hooks, but when you really feel like listening to a dark, melodramatic goth album, this is tops. [2003] I mean, it's not that inaccessible - compared to The Head on the Door maybe a bit - but it's good.  It's actually a really primitive record, with fairly rudimentary drumming, synth drones, and guitar shards.  If it was made by a lesser known band it would certainly be showing up on some Mutantsounds type of blog with rave reviews. The last song ('Pornography') is probably my favorite, with all of these weird disembodied voices mixed in as another texture.  I was reading over some of the lyrics, and while they are very much Cure lyrics, they aren't a million miles away from something I would write.  I think they really found their voice here.  The earliest records are too much in the early Wire/post-punk mold, and the middle period of Kiss Me Kiss Me Kiss Me/Disintegration doesn't do much for me with it's overly thick romanticism.  This album and Faith are probably my favorite releases because it's what my idea of the Cure is.  [16 Feb 2009]



Date: 26 January 2003

Dead Kennedys - Plastic Surgery Disasters

Label: Alternative Tentacles

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

While musically this has a bit more melody than the In God We Trust EP, this record suffers from unmemorable songwriting. It's still great - I think all of of the DK's records are great - it's probably the most forgettable. "Moon Over Marin" though is fantastic and "Trust Your Mechanic" is also a winner


Date: 26 January 2003

Guru Guru - Guru Guru

Label: Brain

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A nice looking record, an original on Brain, but not that amazing musically. Very guitar-driven with some surf parts (really!) and bluesy stuff, but lacking a thematic vision. It's well recorded and I guess it doesn?t sound like any other Krautrock band, but it really doesn't add up. There's some weird electronically affected percussion hidden between the cracks, which is I guess my favorite part. Chris Strunk says "UFO" is awesome so maybe I'll give that one a try.


Date: 26 January 2003

Globe Unity Orchestra Globe Unity - Improvisations

Label: Japo Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Europe's finest free jazz stars assemble around brilliant pianist Alexander Schlippenbach; while some parts are very frantic, and threaten to get lost under the pure barrage of musicians, other sections sketch out space well. Manfred Schoop is a really great, understated trumpet player and the usual stars are here too (Derek Bailey, Evan Parker, Peter Brotzmann) to do their thing. Okay, I'll admit, I wrote the above sentences before actually listening to this thing, though I hit the nail right on the head. No surprises, but it's solid. I think I like this better than the CD that Atavistic reissued.


Date: 26 January 2003

Gang Of Four - Solid Gold

Label: Warner Bros. Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The second Gang of Four album is also great. Maybe not as groundbreaking but they have refined their sound with songs like "paralyzed" and "Cheeseburger". Gang of Four found the right mix of politics without sounding preachy and dumb, and punk rock. They pushed it a little too far on their next album, which is when i gave up on them. But these two albums, the Yellow EP and the Another Day, Another Dollar 12" still manage to inspire me even when I'm at my most jaded. Their performance in Urgh! A Music War is completely incredible.


Date: 26 January 2003

Fred Frith - Guitar Solos

Label: Virgin
