Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Exactly what it says it is, these solos were recorded in 1974 and are pretty fucking sweet. Using no overdubs and few electronic effects, Frith dazzles with prepared guitars, getting some of the most seriously fucked tones out of a guitar. His quickness is evident on some pieces, though others are very sparse and atmospheric. On the last track he actually plays two guitars at the same time. 


Date: 26 January 2003

Richard Hell & The Voidoids - Blank Generation

Label: Sire Records Company

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I've actually never listened to Richard Hell and the Voidoids before, or at least that's what I thought. Then halfway thorugh side 1, "Betrayal Takes Two" came on and I was struck with the most bizarre déjá vu. This song was immediately familiar to me, yet I couldn't place it. The only thing I could think of is that it was something Luke used to play on the radio a lot back in the WPTS days, and then an AMG search reveals that King Missile covered it on The Way to Salvation. Geez. Anyway, this record doesn't need a lot of describing. Allegedly a "punk" record, it actually has strong melodic and technical appeal; parts sound a lot like Television, not surprising since Hell was a founding member. There's some great guitar riffs (thanks to Robert Quine) and a real New York attitude that sounds almost comforting to me because I've listened to Marquee Moon so many times. The lyrics aren't meatheaded like I always thought they'd be. I love discovering things like this late.


Date: 26 January 2003

The Cure - Three Imaginary Boys

Label: Polydor (UK)

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

This is basically the same record as Boys Don't Cry which I didn?t know when I bought it cause there aren't any song titles. The track listing is slightly weaker on this but the cover art is WAY better.


Date: 26 January 2003

Soft Machine - Volume Two

Label: Probe

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Probably my favorite Soft Machine record, even without Kevin Ayers. The band is at it's most surrealistic, with silly flourishes and really edgy organ solos. I'll always have memories of being in college and discovering Soft Machine; hanging out at Caleb's apartment and listening to them - at the peak of when I lost interest in indie rock and discover older music. All music should embrace pataphysics as openly as the Soft Machine did.


Date: 26 January 2003

Material - Temporary Music LP

Label: Red Records

Format: Vinyl Album Compilation

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

An early Material record that sketches out some interesting enough guitar-based instrumental weirdness, but it sorta leaves me cold. It doesn't compare to the one McDowell has which features Whiteny Houston and Archie Shepp covering Soft Machine's "Memories". Yeah.


Date: 26 January 2003

Soft Machine - Triple Echo

Label: Harvest

Format: 3xVinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A three LP box set that I don't really NEED as it's a Soft Machine career retrospective - however, much of the record consists of unreleased or rare material. The first single, "Love Makes Sweet Music" is here, as well as Ayers' killer b-side; lots of BBC/Peel sessions are here too, including the great version of "Moon In June" with the alternate lyrics about being at the BBC. The last record is all post-Fourth stuff, which is actually nice to have, cause in case I ever feel like listening to the Soft Machine lineup with Alan Holdsworth, I now have something.


Date: 26 January 2003

The Soft Machine

Label: Probe

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The first Soft Machine, in the boring non die-cut cover. An absolute classic of the progressive/psychedelic genre, with Kevin Ayers contributing a few classics. One thing I always forget is how cheesy the stereo panning is on this record - as if it was the first record ever made in stereo or something. Rock on Cantebury!


Date: 26 January 2003

Soft Machine - At The Beginning

Label: Oxford

Format: Vinyl LP Compilation Reissue

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Another repackaging of Jet-Propelled Photographs (but on vinyl, so I can get rid of my pesky CD). The early demos show the most pop-oriented Soft Machine, before they really clicked and found their fusion niche. I am a fan of the songwriting and this has my second favorite version of "Memories" (second only to the Whitney Houston/Archie Shepp collaboration on the second Material album).


Date: 26 January 2003

Edgar Froese - Aqua

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Solo album from a Tangerine Dream member that is exactly what you'd expect from a water-themed solo album from a Tangerine Dream member. Froese's synthscapes anticipate, at time, cheesy New Age stuff but also Another Green World and some of the stuff from the first Arco Flute Foundation LP. Nice.


Date: 26 January 2003

Killing Joke - Killing Joke

Label: Editions EG

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Killing Joke's first album is a super heavy, brutal slice of punk with metal overtones - however, the songwriting is fairly catchy, or at least driving. I stupidly have never listened to Killing Joke before, but maybe I should look for their other early albums because this one is great. Parts of it remind me of an angrier Savage Republic, esp. "Complications". 


Date: 26 January 2003

Joy Division - Warsaw

Label: bootleg

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A bootleg of Joy Division's earliest recordings, with dodgy sound quality (but maybe that's just how it was - raw, with phased out cymbals). It's of course obvious how much PUNKER this incarnation of Joy Division was, with some real screaming guitar parts that would never have appeared on Closer. People have the tendency to deify Joy Division and revere recordings like these much more than they should - I'll say that it's a fun, gloom-laden blast of young fury, and it's great to hear an early version of "Love Will Tear Us Apart" called "Novelty", but it's good that their reputation is not based on these recordings.


Date: 26 January 2003

John Greaves - Accident

Label: Europa Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Surpisingly dismal solo record from Henry Cow's John Greaves. He works here in a largely electronic pop format, which doesn't really showcase his strengths, but rather sadly sounds like an attempt to cash in on the trends of the time (1982). There is some relatively interesting stuff going on with the synths and the songwriting, but the whole thing feels flat and lifeless. I guess it's aptly named.


Date: 26 January 2003

Gang Of Four - Entertainment!

Label: Warner Bros. Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Gang of Four were crucial to my musical identity around my sophmore year of college. Entertainment! was so striking, with it's combination of disco and Marxist punk. These songs are anthemic without beind dumb; aggressive without being neatherthal, and dancy without being flimsy. Lyrically Gang of Four were wrapped up in their political pretensions, but if Greil Marcus is to be believed they were hitting the mark right on (and I don't think their lyrics are ever embarassing or awkward). "Anthrax" is as postmodern as punk can get and it rocks too. "Damaged Goods" deals with the issue of romance as a commodity in a thoughtful manner. I'm glad to finally own this on vinyl.


Date: 26 January 2003

Charles Mingus - Mingus Ah-Um

Label: CBS

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The classic Mingus record, more or less a greatest hits. All of the signature tunes that you can hum are present here. This is an old Columbia record and the bass doesn't come across as well as I'd like it to, but it's such a beautiful old LP that I'm willing to put up with it.


Date: 26 January 2003

Magma - Mekanïk Destruktïw Kommandöh

Label: A&M Records (UK)

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A huge, bombastic opera with liner notes that explain the mythology (which I may someday bother to read), this Magma album uses more driving, straight-ahead rhythms to hammer in the themes. Voices fill this record - of many different types - and it really feels like a chaotic opera from hell. There's a few parts where Vander really lets loose and jazzes around. This is probably best experienced as a whole, and therefore not something I see myself listening to frequently. [12/5/2003]   Funny to read my review from 2003 as I randomly pulled this out to listen to again.  This actually reminds me a lot of Canterbury-style prog at times.  There aren't as many insane time signatures and the chordal movement is pretty obviously Western.  On Magma stuff I enjoy the most, there's an almost tropical quality that comes, i guess, from the invented language.  Mekanik Destrutik Kommandöh feels more operatice I guess because of the female vocals.  There's some chilling ghost singing and the occasional bell/chime to really poke out of all the rack-effects guitar; I like this more than I thought I would.  I wish the repeitive parts wouldn't change keys constantly, cause this would sound more like Circle or something.  [6 Aug 2011]


Date: 26 January 2003

V/A - Guitar Solos 3

Label: Rift

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Assembled by Fred Frith, this compilation presents radical approaches to the guitar from several different artists. It's great to hear how little guitar experimentation has changed - there's nothing that makes this material seem dated in any way. It's hard to tell when one artist's work ends and another begins, so I'm not certain who is who - but Frith chose material that worked well together. There are electronics effects used in most pieces, and some get pretty frantic (Davey Williams). Akira Iihjima's piece is very tranquil, and works well to close. It's hard not to compare this to Wooden Guitar. [2 December 2003]


Date: 26 January 2003

V/A - No New York

Label: Lilith

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Assessing this, one of the most overrated compilations of all time, is somewhat difficult. It's as much of a document of it's time as any of the other great comps listed below, but one I always felt was overrated, mostly due to the way in which kids today obsess over this stuff. There are some undeniably great things on here - like the Contortions tracks, which are their best - but other bands who don't fare as well 20 years later. It's hard to really listen to something without associating all of the cultural baggage that goes with it; in this case, tons of dumbass imitation no-wave bands who just want to sound like DNA and make the originals sound sour. But when I try, it's hard to not be moved by the Contortions bounce, or the first Mars track which is so fucking great (too bad the rest are so mediocre). I haven't heard this record in a few years, and Teenage Jesus and the Jerks doesn't sound any better to my ears. It's weird how I like some inept, primitive music (early Half Japanese comes to mind) but some i don't. I guess it's all in the attitude - TJ&tJ just don't do it for me cause I think they are trying too hard. [3 December 2003]


Date: 26 January 2003

V/A - Fast Product - The First Year Plan

Label: Fast Product

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Another classic comp - it's great to have the early Mekons and Gang of Four singles compiled here.


Date: 26 January 2003

V/A - Tooth and Nail

Label: Upsetter

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

An early punk/hardcore comp, featuring fast and poorly-recorded tracks from the Germs, the Flesheaters, the Controllers, UXA, Negative Trend, and Middle Class. It's sort of like listening to one of those old Bloodstains comps, but without as much variety. This is probably the earliest recorded Flesheaters stuff and it's a lot more raw than the stuff I'm familiar with - it actually reminds me of Dead Kennedys with less of a surf influence. The Germs stuff has some damaged piano playing that sounds very sampled, but it's about the only break from the formula. I think I was a bit disappointed by the Negative Trend stuff. [3 December 2003]


Date: 26 January 2003

V/A - Wanna Buy a Bridge?

Label: Rough Trade

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

One of the best compilations ever. I've been looking for this for years - it has the potential to change someone's life. While this may be the definitive document of this musical period, by no means do any of these artists sound generic. This should be reissued on CD - a lot of this material was never reissued because it all comes from singles. "Part Time Punks" by Television Personalities is a great song, by the way. [2 December 2003]


Date: 26 January 2003

V/A - The Wonderful World of Glass vol. 1

Label: Glass

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Compilation from the now-forgotten Glass Records, an early 80's UK label. This comp has stuff from a lot of forgotten UK bands, like Schliemer K and the Marine Girls, mostly of a new-wave variety, though there is a darkness to this music that's absent from most US counterparts. Both guys from Eyeless in Gaza have shitty solo tracks, and the Legenary Pink Dots are also present.


Date: 26 January 2003

V/A - The Roxy London WC2 (Jan - Apr 77)

Label: EMI Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A compilation of early punk live at the Roxy, it's marked by sloppy perforamances and lots of entertaining crowd noise. Slaughter and the Dogs are fairly mediocre punk; Wire is the highlight for me, with the definitive 12XU version and a dirgy "Lowdown"; the Buzzcocks also appear just post-Devoto.


Date: 26 January 2003

V/A - Pillows and Prayers (Cherry Red 1982-83)

Label: Cherry Red

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A comp showcasing some of the finest UK bands of the early 1980's. Perhaps the entire record's existence is justifed for Felt's "My Face is On Fire", though there are other great tunes on here, like the Nightingales song "Don't Blink". Kevin Coyne makes an appearance sounding quite a bit like JJ Cale; the Misunderstood have a real Nuggets-style thing going on; Eyeless in Gaza sound good too. Are the Marine Girls the antecedent of Scrawl? Atilla the Stockbroker's spoken word track is a fun period piece; Quetin Crisp's is a bit more intellectual. The Passage's song is something i should put on a mix for McDowell because I'm sure he'd hate it.


Date: 26 January 2003

Charles Mingus - Lionel Hampton Presents the Music of

Label: Who's Who

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

A late period Mingus recording, though he's performing earlier works. Lionel Hampton's vibes dominate this album, and it pulled it into a WDUQ direction; however some pieces like "Fables of Faubus" are just so badass to begin with, that Hampton just provides nice color. Recorded in 1977, the production is very good and everything sounds full; I just know that this will be the Mingus record I listen to the least.


Date: 26 January 2003

Charles Mingus - Cumbia and Jazz Fusion

Label: Atlantic

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

I think many people feel that this is a lesser entry in the Mingus discography, but the title track blew my mind when I first heard it back in college. Perhaps Mingus will lead me to a discovery of latin jazz? It's only appropriate since he led me to discover bop, avant-garde and free jazz too.


Date: 26 January 2003

Charles Mingus - Statements

Label: Lotus/Passport

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Mingus from 1969, in a slight smaller group that includes Jaki Byard on piano. Byard, actually, steals the show, since Mingus and Richmond are pretty much inaudible due to the pisspoor mastering job on this record. These three compositions show the quieter, more reflective Mingus, and are highlighted by the trumpet. Not my favorite record of his by any means, though "Orange Was the Color of Her Dress" is very very beautiful, conjuring a sense of nostalgia that only jazz can do.


Date: 26 January 2003

ESG

Label: 99

Format: Vinyl 12" EP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Six song ESG EP shows the band branching out a bit. These gals were totally lo-fi but it's mastered at 45 so the bass grooves can resonate well and it's a great sound. "Earn It' is so damn amateurish it rules - sounds like something I would have made in high school if i was latino, female, and talented. I'm so glad I have these records now so I can play them at parties.


Date: 26 January 2003

Felt - Crumbling the Antiseptic Beuty

Label: Cherry Red

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Felt's first album doesn?t pack the punch of "My Face is On Fire," but that doesn't mean it's a bad record. Structured around ringing, jangly guitars, this is a moody slice of angst. The Verlainisms of Lawrence's delivery give it the swagger it needs to distinguish itself from wimpy jangle pop. There's a simplicity to this music that doesn't overwhelm it, and the reverb is well used. Listening to all of this 80's UK stuff lately is starting to take it's toll on me, but I finally understand those who use this as their canon. The hypnotic plundering of "Birdmen" is probably the winner here.


Date: 26 January 2003

Cure - Boys Don't Cry

Label: CBS

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Early Cure singles; some of them are fun for their detachment ("10:15 on a Saturday night") and it's interesting to hear the Cure before they embraced atmopsherics - or lush atmospherics, cause there's definitely a sense of atmosphere here. But it's not the most enjoyable thing to listen to in my recent mood, as a lot of it just sounds like a second-rate Wire.


Date: 26 January 2003

Echo & The Bunnymen - Ocean Rain

Label: Sire Records Company

Format: CD

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Echo and the Bunnymen's most familiar tune is on this record ("The Killing Moon") but the rest of the record is a solid pop record. I've never been a huge Echo and the Bunnymen fan but maybe I should check out their other records. Ian McCulloch's voice contains just the right about of drama to it, a few steps below Robert Smith but still sounding earnest. The last song on side 1 is a bit of a misstep, though he actually sounds like David Ackles at one point! Overall it's a very polished record that lacks the "punk" edge of the earlier stuff, but it's a respectable record.


Date: 26 January 2003

Goblin - Suspiria

Label: EMI

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Goblin's soundtrack is pretty scary; the more brittle sounds are my favorite parts, and not the parts that sound like Zombi. I guess this is the definitive Italian horror score, and It's hard for me to separate it from the context of the movie.


Date: 26 January 2003

Liliput

Label: Rough Trade

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

Lilliput are so inspiring to me because they took punk as a starting point for expressing their own weirdness, rather than using punk as a template for identity, like so many groups today. The "gimmicky" elements - that they are all-female, and sang in a made-up language - seem almost irrelevant, because their music is so excellent. I first read about Kleenex/Lilliput in that Greil Marcus piece in "Ranters and Crowd Pleasers" and searched forever for their records. Now that Kill Rock Stars has issued that double CD, Lilliput are able to be heard by everyone And like the Raincoats and Essential Logic, this is music that is definied by it's femininity - not just the members' genders, but in terms of a left-hand, feminine approach to songwriting. In a million years I would probably never write music like this. It's inside and outside at the same time, a testament to their genius.


Date: 26 January 2003

Gunter Hampel - Broadway

Label: Birth

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.94

The only other Gunter Hampel I have ever heard is his first record, The 18th of July 1969, which is a wonderful ball of free improvisation held together by blistering piano lines and Jeanne Lee's transcendent vocals. This later recording is much more restrained, with a similar melodic emphasis that is heard in other great European bands like ICP Orchestra. Without a percussionist, the group dances around Hampel's melodic structures, some whimsical and some earthy, with Lee present again to provide harmonic vocals. The first piece, "Folksong", is open yet alive; the title track (split over two sides) goes on a bit longer and stretches out into some more chaotic parts, yet never gets bogged down in "too much too fast" like many other pieces from this period. [5 December 2003]


Date: 1 March 2003

The Working Poor - Live, Halloween 1997 CD-R

Label: Rickety

Format: CD-R

Source: Working Poor

Cost: $0

Alan told me that this recording of their first show ever was also the best show they ever played. Here is the earliest possible incarnation of the Working Poor, with Terry Carroll on drums. This takes the "ramshackle" aesthetic to a new level - these songs are hardly there at all, held together by sloppy rhythms and bungled notes. But there's something charming about it anyway. The crowd noise is often overpowering, and at times Alan's lyrics/poetry sound like Rik from the Young Ones, but it's nice to hear the roots of a band that has turned into a very beautiful thing. [5 December 2003]


Date: 1 March 2003

The Working Poor

Label: none

Format: CD EP

Source: Working Poor

Cost: $10

Disappointing. Packaging is the nicest I have ever seen, though. I'm excited to hear the recordings the current lineup has made - this stuff is old, and even the songs on here they do now, like "Upstart Organ" are done so much better and more quielty. The forthcoming working poor album will hopefully be an amazing perfrect record to listen to while drinking wine alone on a fire escape, looking over the city. Oh, love is frightful.


Date: 5 March 2003

Animal Collective - Campfire Songs

Label: Catsup Plate

Format: CD-R

Source: Catsup Plate

Cost: $0

I'm somewhat disappointed by this record. Maybe my expectations are too high after the last one, though. While this record has some defienite good moments (and that Avey Tare feel that really separates them from anyone else), it just drones on a bit too long. Sometimes I get the feeling that they tried to make an all-acoustic record just to show that they could, especially after the last one.


Date: 14 March 2003

Fairport Convention - Heyday - The BBC Sessions 1968-1969

Label: Island Records

Format: CD Album Compilation

Source: Paul's

Cost: $8

Version w/bonus tracks to upgrade my old one Fairport rip up a bunch of dylan and other 60's rock tunes and they do a prety great job - "Reno, Nevada" is a highlight - though the bonus tracks on this edition are great cause they're familiar Fairport songs. "Fotheringay", "Si Tu Dois Partir" and "Tam Lin" all sound a bit rawer and more fun than the album versions.


Date: 14 March 2003

Vashti Bunyan - Just Another Diamond Day

Label: Dicristina Stair Builders

Format: CD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $0

If Anne Briggs is a ghost, Vashty Bunyan is actually a fairy. Delicate, fragile, yet lush at the same time. This is one for deeper listening; it's too quiet to really appreciate at work and I've been so busy doing the alphabetical thing at home?.


Date: 16 March 2003

Jazz Hands

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CD-R

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0

The genesis of this name came from one of our many old chatroom days, and while I was slightly disappointed that Spencer used it for a one-off, the results are pretty good. A live performance in Columbus, Jazz Hands is Spencer on electronics and vocals (though the vocals are rendered unrecognizable) and a drummer, who actually manages to infuse the three short tracks with a "jazz" feel. This swings at times, mostly due to the ride cymbal work, and overall presents a good sensation under Spencer's dark caterwauls. [7 December 2003]


Date: 16 March 2003

Ron Orovitz/Spencer Yeh/Jeremy Lesniak - cdr

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CD-R

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0

Two tracks of this interesting trio, where Spencer plays drums, Ron does electonics and Lesniak plays guitar. Spencer's drumming is very straightforward, primitive, and monotonous. It drives along the other two's explorations; track 1 finds deep sweeping electronics that create huge washed of sound - it's a very full feeling for this audience recording. Lesniak's more epileptic guitar fluctuations are explored more fully on track two, where Spencer's plodding beat becomes maddening at times. [7 December 2003]


Date: 16 March 2003

Prince - Black Album

Label: Warner Bros. Records

Format: CD Album Reissue

Source: half price books

Cost: $1

I bought this because it was a good deal, and I don't own any Prince. I always thought the black album was banned because it was too dirty or something like that, but actually Prince recalled it because he was dissatisfied with it. And now it's been legitimately issued, and who cares? It's not really that great. Of course I am not a Prince fan. The grooves just don't feel as good as they should, and some tracks (#3 in particular) are just stupid. I still like it better than Sign O' The Times, and I'll hold onto it for the next time I have a party. When listening to this, I keep thinking about developing a musical alter ego named Prints who sounds just like this. Or maybe Military Prints. I really like that name. I'm stupid.


Date: 16 March 2003

Burning Star Core - White Swords in a Black Castle/Tabletop Bass Guitar CDR

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CD-R

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0

If I actually release a collection of BxC's greatest hits, both of these tracks will probably go on it. "White Swords in a Black Castle" is a huge, swirling statement that apparently uses all sorts of other artists as source material. It's distorted without being too harsh, and complex enough in it's layering that it doesn't become monotonous. "Oversleep, Gloria, and you will miss the wave" is more beat-oriented, with a driving pulse that recalls club/dance music, and Spencer's chilling vocals intoned overtop. The bonus disc is of tabletop bass guitar, much as the title reveals, from 1998. [7 December 2003]


Date: 16 March 2003

Death Beam

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CD-R

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0

Spencer's a good buddy/madman so I was anxious to finally hear Death Beam, but this hardly represents them. It's Spencer and Ron as a Rosing-less duo performing electronic weirdness outside. It gets aggressive in it's own way but it's not "rock" so I don't really think this is death beam proper. However it still had that unique C. Spencer Yeh aesthetic that he has carved out over the years that I'm only starting to understand.


Date: 16 March 2003

Open City - L.A. We Revise Your Neglect

Label: Thin Wrist Recordings

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $7

LA Group with one member who runs the Thin Wrist label. Very nice free improvisation - though I always hesitate to use that term when I'm not really sure what is improvised and what isn't. Nice percussion and electric guitars show their extended use of dynamics. As always there's beautiful Thin Wrist packaging. I'd like to hear their other record but I think it's out of print now.


Date: 16 March 2003

Tindersticks - Curtains

Label: This Way Up

Format: CD

Source: half price books

Cost: $1

The third Tindersticks album, which I've always considered to be the beginning of their decline, but hey - the price was right! Actually this really follows in the footsteps of the first two records, but it just doesn't seem as magical as those. The drums sound a lot more booming and it's maybe a bit more forceful - almost a driving record instead of a smoky mood-drenched guilt trip. The song "Fast One" is totally fucking awesome and doesn't sound like any of their other stuff; most of the rest of this record does sound like the other stuff though. Listening to this while rolling coins to take to the bank, I'm struck by how much better it is than the newest one (and even that is better than the two retreads that followed this).


Date: 16 March 2003

Alabama Sacred Heart Singers - Southern Journey vol 10: And Glory Shone Around

Label: Rounder

Format: CD

Source: half price books

Cost: $5.98

"Field recordings" for a choral group in Alabama in 1959. The recordings are crisp, and the clarity of the voices is pretty astounding. There are a lot of songs on here, mostly American traditionals, hymns, spirituals, etc. It's a bit much to listen to all at once, but it definitely captures some feeling besides just a bunch of people singing. This is like a Faulkner novel in musical form.


Date: 20 March 2003

Sun City Girls - 330,003 Crossdressers From Beyond The Rig Veda

Label: Locust Music

Format: 3xVinyl LP

Source: Eclipse

Cost: $29.99

Holy shit! Why did I wait so long to get this? As part of my recent obsession over all things SCG I tracked this down - it's a pretty amazing, overly long collection of the more ethnic-veering SCG's stuff. And I might go as far as to say that this is the definitive SCG record, even though I haven't fully digested it yet - cause a definitive SCG record would have to be a bit excessiev to mirror the excess of their career/personalities. The first track is perhaps my favorite SCG song to date - it's a brilliant apeing of Southeast Asian pop, or at least what i would imagine Southeast Asian pop to sound like. the only parts i really don't like are the gamelan pieces beacuse it just sounds like they're dicking around on gamelan instruments (which they are). it's not as ha-ha goofy as the other triple LP, either. Stunning, essential, blah blah blah.


Date: 20 March 2003

Pelt/Keenan Lawler/Eric Clark - Keyhole II

Label: Eclipse Records

Format: 2xLP

Source: Eclipse

Cost: $14.99

I love Pelt, and I feel like I've stopped paying as much attention to them as I used to; after Ayahuasca I think I became overwhelmed and cut back on how much I listened to them. But this record ranks among one of their best, though it's a collaborative work. Recorded in a large room, this is a fantastic record of acoustic ambient/drone. Keenan's parts (at least what I think are his) sound wonderful and it makes me forgive him for owing me money. Eric Clark builds metal instruments that sound like scraped bowls, and it's like a more devloped revisit to the beginning of Empty Bell. The room is really the star of the record though - everything seems to expand under it. This record has the potential to be truly magical. (Note: listened to at 33rpm)


Date: 21 March 2003

Orange Juice  - You Can't Hide Your Love Forever

Label: Polydor

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $6

Slighty sugary, upbeat Scottish pop. Chris Strunk loves this band and I've never checked them out; apparently this is one of their better albums and it's pretty solid. It reminds me of the Close Lobsters only a bit more happy; maybe a similarity to the Chills too. It definitely sounds like early 80's pop - a very C86 sound, of being young and innocent. Some more produced parts even feature female backing vocals - the song "LOVE Love" is an Al Green cover. Come on down to the arcade, where we laugh at our afflictions in the window. I should tape this for the car.


Date: 21 March 2003

Rick Wakeman - The Six Wives Of Henry VIII

Label: A&M Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $3

I hate to say this is awful but I didn't even make it through one side. I am fussy about prog and I've never liked Yes - they seem to be prog that is devoid of any interesting ideas. I bought this mistakenly thinking that Gil had recommended it; I actually thought I might like it since I have become such a proghead since I last heard Yes. It's not without any merit, but it doesn't grab me at all. Despite all of the lightning fast guitar riffs and keyboard runs, I find myself bored. Wichmann says that his main measure of whether a film is "good" or not is whether it's boring or he keeps interested. And while there is some boring music I really like (Stars of the Lid?) this is active, boring music which might be the worst kind.


Date: 21 March 2003

Brian Eno - Floating In Sequence

Label: The Impossible Recordworks

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $8

A bootleg that I had to buy cause I've been on a huge Eno kick lately. There's only a few songs on here, mostly from Warm Jets, and the fidelity is bizarre if nothing else. Probably not worth the $10 sticker tag (Jerry knocked a few bucks off of course) though the dirty, overdriven version of "Third Uncle" is a highlight.


Date: 21 March 2003

Paul and Linda McCartney - Ram

Label: EMI-Bovema Holland

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $3

I first heard this in Tamburo's car and thought it was an OTC outtake or something. For some reason I just always assumed that all post-beatles mccartney was like Wings so I never gave it a chance. This is a fun, lighthearted record with great mccartney hooks and really dirty, lo-fi production. Linda's voice is really compressed and strange sounding (probably to hide the fact that she can't sing) and even though there's some filler, it's still FUN filler. Yet another reminder that I shouldn't be so dismissive about records just because they aren't in the hipster-approved canon.


Date: 21 March 2003

Roy Harper - When an Old Cricketeer Leaves the Crease

Label: Chrysalis

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

Considered by many to be the "best" Roy Harper album ( the UK release of this is called "HQ"), this is most done in a full rock band. There's some nice guitar arrangements here but I like the prettier folkier stuff on side two the best, especially "Forget Me Not". The folkie in me tends to enjoy the less rock Roy Harper stuff, but this is definitely a great release.


Date: 21 March 2003

The Band

Label: Capitol

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $3

I don't think I like this as much as the first one (and I'm not even that crazy about the first one) though it does have that song that you recognize. Again it will probably grow on my slowly, like the first one did, except I'll never have the time to listen to it that much now.


Date: 5 April 2003

Yo La Tengo - Summer Sun

Label: Matador

Format: 2xLP Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

It's easy to say "this isn't as good as the last one" after a few listens, because I really loved the last one - it seemed to conjure up many of the romantic associations I had with my late adolescence, filtered through a small-town/thirtysomething/art-hipster vibe. and here is a definite step towards summer sounds, obviously, though the songs just don't feel quite as powerful. However, Yo La Tengo revels in their subtleties and i'm sure that a year from now i'll love it like a pet dog or something.


Date: 5 April 2003

Van Dyke Parks - Song Cycle

Label: Sundazed

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $10

Nice 180gram reissue! I hope they do Discover America. I don't really know what else I can say about this album; it's one of the masterpieces of it's time and a stunning statement from a pop genius. The instrumentation is a commentary and tribute to traditional and popular music of America, going over the top with strings, etc., all swirling around the solitary voice of V. D. Parks. And the lyrics? They continue to be an inspiration to me, both in the way they reflect a love of American culture as well as for their arty and mysterious tendencies. The final few songs all deal with communism Coming to america in the 1960's, as far as I can tell, and every time i listen (and i've probably listened to this record sixty or seventy times) I find myself thinking.


Date: 11 April 2003

V/A - London is the Place For Me

Label: Honest Jon's

Format: CD Album

Source: Shake It

Cost: $16.99

Great collection of Trinidadian music from the 50's, recorded in London. Besides the musical aspects - the bouncy saxophones and steel drums - the lyrics are quite fascinating, showing the role of the black calypso musician in London society. There are political and social overtones to the lyrics - sometimes just observational, like in "At the Coronation" but somtimes a bit more like in the song about Ghana. It's slowly growing on me and it's fun to drive around listening to this.


Date: 11 April 2003

Wolf Eyes - Dead Hills

Label: Troubleman Unlimited

Format: Vinyl LP Picture Disc

Source: Shake It

Cost: $10.99

Wolf Eyes have surpassed Dread with this release, a more concise distillation of their work. "Dead Hills" traces the path of your fear through the night, beginning with a trepidatious step into the darkness before fully succumbing to it's mysteries. Listening to this loud in my turret with the lights out, I feel trapped in a chamber of horrors. Why is Wolf Eyes signed to Sub Pop now, and why are they so popular with rocker kids? They are entirely deserving of their notoriety, but it's a shame how the culture of independent music allows some artists to find success while other like minded people toil in obscurity.


Date: 11 April 2003

Richard Youngs - Airs Of The Ear

Label: Jagjaguwar

Format: CD Album

Source: Shake It

Cost: $12.99

My initial impression was that of disappointment, but after a few more listens it really grew on me. Production-wise Youngs has gone totally over the top with this one, layering effects and instrumentation that feels unncessary, because it doesn't really help the songs. (in the past i've always felt that his best song-based stuff was the most stripped down, like Advent or Sapphie). But after the third listen I realized that Youngs is really celebrating all psychedelic folk music (which also explains the goofy cover) and he's produced another great record, perhaps not as timeless as Festival or Sapphie, but another very solid statement.


Date: 12 April 2003

Curtains - Fast Talks

Label: Thin Wrist

Format: LP

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0

Curtains are a very interesting musical project, and I strangely heard their forthcoming album before this existing one. I grew to be very fond of Flybys, so Fast Talks comes as a bit of a disappointment. In a weird way I am reminded of Bablicon minus Dave, with the falling apart clattery drums and skewed guitar lines, but it doesn't quite feel like their aesthetic is complete on this. I still like it a lot, but it's nowhere near as good as the next one.


Date: 5 May 2003

New Pornographers - Electric Version

Label: Matador

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $10

Listening to Candian power-pop takes me back to 10th grade where I clutched the first Zumpano CD close to my breast as I sang along with Carl Newman's amazing hooks. The new pornos are certainly more garagey and less burt bacharach, but no less appetizing - if anything the hooks are even more gratuitous and the lyrics have progressed leaps and bounds since Zumpano (or the first new pornos record even). Plus there's three great Bejar songs. I was afraid i'd be disappointed, but with power-pop this perfect, I shouldn't have worried.


Date: 5 May 2003

Ensemble Wabaruagun - Honduras: Chants des Carib noirs CD

Label: Ocora

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $12

These recordings from the Black Caribs of Honduras are all performed by one ensemble, though I still file it by title under the V/A section of ethnic music. It's an impressive 53 minutes of drumming accentuated by sea conches, which at times gets insanely, insanely fast (particularly on the track 'Fedu Hunguhungu', where the drums, cascading vocals and I guess conches sounds completely insane, almost like fast techno music). As a layman, I'd say that it sounds like what you'd expect a cross between Caribbean music and African music to sound like. The voices are really strained at points, moaning in different cadences and really quite disorientating. The conch shells give everything a really awesome flavour, but the drum is still at the core of this. [18 September 2012]


Date: 5 May 2003

Supersilent - 6

Label: Rune Grammofon

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $14

My first Supersilent CD, though now I have heard 4 and 5 and realize how much more mellow and relaxed this is. Very futuristic sounding, with unexplainable instrument processing and a really odd atmosphere. This isn't exciting music unless you turn it up loud and listen bewteen the lines.


Date: 5 May 2003

V/A - Paraguay: Guarani-Nandeva et Ayoreo CD

Label: Ocora

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $11



Date: 5 May 2003

V/A - New Electric Muse II 

Label: Castle

Format: 3xCD box

Source: Paul's

Cost: $30

My interest in British folk music probably has culminated in the purchase of this box set, which brings together a bunch of tracks by well and lesser-known britfolkrock artists. The first disc is very King Arthury and has some medieval style themes. The watersons are especially interesting. disc 2 gets into some instrumental work which is probably the low point, because i love the beautiful voices of these chanteuses - especially Anne Briggs, whom I think was possibly not human and a ghost or something. Disc 3 actually has some selections from later Fairport/Steeleye span records that I would have written off because I'm overly judgemental - I'm glad for their inclusion. Now if I can only find volume 1.....


Date: 5 May 2003

V/A - Centrafrique: Musical Anthology of the Aka Pygmies

Label: Ocora

Format: 2xCD with book

Source: Paul's

Cost: $10

Knocked $13 off to reflect discount I got. These two discs are primarily vocal-based - there is some percussion, mostly just rhytmic stick-banging - but the voices are really the key to it. The music is all group pieces, mostly ceremonial I think, with different phases of vocals going in and out like a round. Its a lot to listen to, and I question if I really need two full CD's of it, but it's a very nicely put together package full of liner notes that I might someday read. Some of the younger voices are great - they sound like children, and the way the voices waver gives it a really nice, imperfect shine. [4 December 2003]


Date: 5 May 2003

V/A - Tanzania: Masumbi: Wagogo Entertainment Music CD

Label: Ocora

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $11

The entertainment music of just one ethnic group in Tanzania, this is life-affirming, joyous and has that magical feeling that I can only get from non-western music. Of the cursory listen I've given to all of these Ocora discs, this one has jumped out at me the most and is the only one I feel comfortable writing about yet.


Date: 5 May 2003

V/A - Seychelles: Musiques oubliees des Iles CD

Label: Ocora

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $11

The music of the Seychelles islands is interesting - it's a very small country that is characterized by islands that are very small and very far apart. The music on this disc all hails from the "mainland" island and was recorded in the late 70's. It's dominated by one particular perfomer, who has a really gentle, expressive voice. The Creole language is like a sexier French and many of the songs are pretty melodies sung over a very sparse accompaniment. Some tracks are just quietly plucked single strings, though others have busy percussion. This is ocean music of bright, clear skies and it's great to hear such a remote part of the world documented.


Date: 5 May 2003

V/A - Venezuela: Chants et tambours Diablos CD

Label: Ocora

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $11

This selection of recordings comes from the central coastal region of Venezuela, and was recorded recently on very good equipment. The fidelity is nice, as the vocals sound pretty incredible. This music is entirely based around drumming and singing, with some tracks of just drumming and some a capella. The group pieces employ a call and response vocal technique that reminds me of Latin pop music - the kind you hear in Mexican restauraunts - and also of the Calypso music on the London is the Place for Me comp. While that vocal style is characteristic of that part of the world, it's still somewhat surprising how alike it all is. [19 December 2003]


Date: 22 May 2003

Dif Juz - Out Of The Trees

Label: 4AD

Format: Vinyl LP Mini-Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Side one is incredible - this must be what Directions in Music listen to when they masturbate. The last track on their first EP is totally stunning, blossoming, colorful - a very focused aesthetic. Side 2 is a remixed EP and suffers a bit from the remixing, i think. But DIf Juz were such an interesting band, combining Krautrock, dub, and textural ambience into what became the "4AD Aesthetic". 


Date: 22 May 2003

Souled American - Fe

Label: Rough Trade

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Rootsy Americana on Rough Trade. The more countrified parts I enjoy the most, and the more rock parts get grating (especially the slap bass - what were they thinking?). While no song is as amazing as "Six Feet of Snow," the drawl of "She Broke My Heart" is a heartbreaker. Souled American were pretty great overall, and I think there's a 4 CD box set out there for me to find. [2003] ;;;  Funny now, looking back at my initial thoughts on Fe when I swapped it with Gil back in the day... now I've come to adore this record, particularly the crunchy "bass" parts which I think might actually be a baritone guitar.  I'm never sure how I feel about self-consciously affected American country music - I think these guys are amazing, and very pure in their constructions, but then what's the line between this and hillbilly revival stuff?  Of course 'Make Me Laugh Make Me Cry' sounds like music to my ears because it actually could be a Camper Van Beethoven song, so this is a sound that I grew up very accustomed to.  I've been trying to score their other LPs on eBay for reasonable prices, though sadly their last two releases are CD-only. [24 June 2011]


Date: 22 May 2003

Eyeless In Gaza - Photographs As Memories

Label: Cherry Red

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

EiG's first album, a far different beast than their lackluster second. This is a great slice of early 80's UK post-punk - rhythmic, edgy and somewhat distraught. The last song, "No Noise," is a near-perfect pop song with a total hook - far different than the drearyness I've always associated with this band.


Date: 22 May 2003

Dukes Of Stratosphear - 25 O'Clock

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

XTC's fake 60's psych band is actually better than XTC - with a total Nuggets-style sound (only far better production). It's a total joke, I guess, but it's so well done that it sorta pisses me off. I guess I should just enjoy it.


Date: 22 May 2003

Sun City Girls - God Is My Solar System / Superpower

Label: Eclipse Records 

Format: 2xVinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Eclipse

Cost: $15.88

Long awaited early Sun City Girls reissue of two cassettes with a gorgeous gatefold. These are the earliest released Sun City Girls recordings as far as I know, and I expected them to have a much rougher, punk edge. "God is my Solar System" shows their more goofy side, I guess, with a some parts reminding me of Starship Beer. The vocals get to be a bit much by the end (and it's long - all four sides are quite long). "Superpower" sounds like it could have been recorded yesterday, and shows the group in a more "out" mode, featuring a paranoid spoken part that is the predecessor to "Napoleon and Josephine". It's great to finally hear this stuff, but like most SCG stuff it's inconsistent. Of course, I'm such a fan that it doesn't matter.


Date: 22 May 2003

PG Six - Old Man On The Mountain

Label: Amish Records

Format: Vinyl 7" Single

Source: Eclipse

Cost: $4.88

I'm looking forward to Six's forthcoming album. The A-side is much in the vein of the first album, or at least the more lyrical parts. The b-side is a Townes Van Zandt covers that reminds me - I need to check out some Townes Van Zandt.


Date: 22 May 2003

Wire - Turns and Strokes

Label: WMO

Format: 2xLP Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

I traded Gil my CD for a vinyl copy. What is there to say about Wire except that they were perhaps the greatest art-punk band ever, and that no amount of records could contain all of the ideas they spit out in their brief, pre-breakup existence. This collection scrapes the barrel for some more material, most of dodgy sound quality, but it's completely worth it just to hear some of their more experimental live appearances. 


Date: 22 May 2003

Nurse With Wound - Alas The Madonna Does Not Function

Label: United Dairies

Format: Vinyl 12" Mini-Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Obscure NWW EP that juxtaposes sharp percussive beats with eerie manipulated strings for side A. It's as unsettling as the finest NWW yet also intriguing. Side B is Stapleton at his best - a lengthy, dark track with lots of room to get lost -- seriously ranking up there with Solliquy for Lilith.


Date: 22 May 2003

Workshop - Welcome Back The Workshop

Label: Finlayson

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Strange, German (I think) pop band with electronic overtones; someone Stereolabby but really just sorta goofy and disjointed. For some reason I could imagine Luke getting really into it. This will certainly grow on me.


Date: 22 May 2003

Surface Of Eceon Surface Of Eceyon - Tussyan Ruins

Label: Three Lobed Recordings

Format: CD EP Limited Edition

Source: Dick 

Cost: $0

An EP from Surface that I only listened to at work. It sounded very very smooth, with some really delicate parts that I couldn't really focus on because of the boom box/low volume issue. To be returned to?.


Date: 22 May 2003

Surface of Eceyon - Dragyyn

Label: Strange Attractors Audio House

Format: CD Album

Source: Dick 

Cost: $0

I fell asleep to this CD last night, and of course it worked well for that. I'm not sure if Surface has "developed" a ton from the first session, but there was a repetitive, electronic sounding glitch to set the rhythm at the beginning of this disc that was totally sweet. Of course, I may be very confused because I did fall asleep minutes after realizing what I was listening to. Sorry guys, you'll have to wait for a better review later.


Date: 22 May 2003

Twink - Odds and Beginnings

Label: Twink Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Twink from the Pink Fairies presents a vinyl-only collectin of odds and ends. I'm not really a fan, having never listened to the Pink Fairies, so this holds little interest for me. After one listen, none of the songs are really memorable, even for as "quirky" as they're supposed to be. I'll return to this when I'm really, really desperate for something to get into.


Date: 22 May 2003

Velma - Parole

Label: Stetic Records

Format: Vinyl 12" EP

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Electronic-heavy post-rock that seems to be built mostly around loops. Some acoustic guitar strum and chanted female vocals add a nice touch. I'm not sure where this group is from but I like what they do - the songs are lengthy and they seem to only get comfortable after awhile. For all I know this is one guy with a computer but it's strangely catchy.


Date: 22 May 2003

Pentangle - Sweet Child

Label: Reprise Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Half live and half studio, and the studio half totally shreds. The live half has some nice parts - two Mingus compositions and a really great solo Jansch piece. I'll probably make a mix tape with the studio part of this and 'Basket of Light'. This is recorded very, very well (thanks to Shel Tamy) and the guitars just sound so awesome it makes me want to practice.


Date: 22 May 2003

Pentangle Pentangle - Basket Of Light

Label: Transatlantic Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Many people consider this to be Pentangle's finest work, which doesn't surprise me. It's a bit more focused than their debut yet still sounds fresh. There's a lot of life in this, and they seem to be radically integrating jazz with British folk (though not as much as Sweet Child", this one also benefits from the shorter length). I'll have to listen to this more.


Date: 22 May 2003

Buffy Saint-Marie - Illuminations

Label: Vanguard

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Gil - thank you so much for this one! This record is the classic example of "WEIRD FOLK". Her haunting voice cycles through what would be a good sixties folk record, but the electronic treatments are really the amazing thing. Using nothing but her voice and guitar as source material, there's crazy creeping electronics throughout the whole record that take an amazing step forward (Animal Collective, anyone?). The opening track is a Leonard Cohen poem that's chanted in a most chilling manner - it makes the record right there. Some tracks have a rock backing band that take it in a Jefferson Airplane direction, though her voice sounds a bit like Sandy Denny's at times.


Date: 22 May 2003

Thinking Fellers Union Local 282 - Where's Officer Tuba

Label: Hemiola Records

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

A 12" EP by Thinking Fellers, which has some pretty strong songs and great production. There's an awesome cover of Caroliner's 'Outhouse of the Pyreeeee' which has a thick, heavy guitar feel and ends with some free fuckery; there's a lot of instrumental stuff on side two, and only one vocal song, 'Hive', which is an epic. Lyrics included as well, which illustrate the not-quite-tangible direction of the songwriting - it's admirable, to a fan of obtuse lyricism like myself. If I had been just a little older, Thinking Fellers would have probably been my idols - and in an EP form, it's the perfect amount to digest. [26 July 2012]


Date: 22 May 2003

Popol Vuh - In Den Gärten Pharaos

Label: Think Progressive

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Ross Rhodes wouldn't sell me either of his copies of this record (cause one was a slightly different mix or something) so I'm glad Gil traded it to me. 


Date: 22 May 2003

Landing - Passages Through

Label: K

Format: CD

Source: Dick 

Cost: $0

Perhaps my Landing OPO? This has a really even mix of the more spacious, stretched out Landing stuff and the "pop" songs, all while staying within the confines of the album. It also sounds really good, though still recorded at Aaron's place - he's doing a really good job with things. I've already fallen asleep to this twice - which I think they consider to be a compliment - but it's been hard to learn the songs. Also, this is the sweetest cover art Landing have ever used.


Date: 22 May 2003

Metabolismus - Sprießwärtsdrall ‎

Label: Amish

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Great mishmash of goofball ideas - this is Krautrock of the late 1990's, from actual Germans who have paid their dues and been around since the early 80's. Electronics are fairly present, but not in a way that really sounds like anything else. There's an almost pastoral quality to some parts, while other sound like a weirdo pop version of Amon Duul II. I'd like to hear more by these guys.


Date: 22 May 2003

Dukes of Stratosphear - Psonic Psunspot

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

The full-length Dukes of Stratosphere record is a bit more polished - the psychedelic for psychedelia's sake touches are less evident, and the songwriting is stronger. I said above that this is a total joke but it's really not - it's just a lighthearted tribute, perhaps. However, few side projects are this successful. Beautiful purple marbled vinyl.


Date: 22 May 2003

Dukes of Stratosphear - You're a Good Man Albert Brown 12"

Label: Virgin

Format: 12" Vinyl EP

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

An EP; two songs from "Psionic Psunspot" and two from the other one. With no original material I'm not sure what the purpose of owning this is; perhaps they are different recordings. Side one is better (especially the title track).


Date: 22 May 2003

Baldwin, Dick - s/t CD-R

Label: none

Format: CD-R

Source: Dick 

Cost: $0

a very well-done solo record that pleasantly surprised me. Some parts were like Landing/Surface/Dickstyle, which Is of course to be expected, though the vocals were a nice touch. But the parts that really got me were the acoustic sections, some of which even had a middle-eastern influence. it's nice to see dick's versatility, and i hope he continues to make music and maybe even release this (he should call it "Dickfish").


Date: 22 May 2003

Akita/Azuma/Haswell/Sakaibara - Ich Schnitt Mich Den Finger

Label: Mego

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

A live collaboration of four electronic improv artists, though at no point does it sound like it needs to be more than one person. Side one is annoying because there's a lock groove between each track; there are shining moments, but overall nothing groundbreaking. The longer piece of side two is a bit more interesting though my attention wanes by the end; there are your typical harsh moments, parts that sound like no-input mixer and some gurgling sounds throughout. Has this type of music progressed at all in the past ten years?


Date: 27 May 2003

Mandible Chatter - Hair Hair Lock and Lore CD

Label: Russell

Format: CD Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

A solid release, containing some really dark, almost ambient but a bit more NWWy to use the word "ambient" sketched. One piece is a dainty guitar instrumental that feels oddly out of place but is fun; the final track is a long, droney epic. Excellent focus on texture and I have to thank Gil for giving me this disc for no apparent reason. I've never listened to MC before; they're very worthwhile deep listening music.


Date: 27 May 2003

Supreme Dicks - Working Man's Dick

Label: Freek Records

Format: CD

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

When I was in high school I heard the Supreme Dicks and dismissed them as being "too weird" or something lame like that. Now that Gil tossed me this extra CD he had, I've revisited them and realized how totally great they were. The easiest way to describe this is to say it's like if early Pavement was crossed with weirder psychedelic music. There's definite "indie rock" moments but also excursions into darker psych/folk. At this point in my tastes it's impossible to not appreciate this on some level. I should seek out their other records.


Date: 31 May 2003

Tindersticks - Waiting For The Moon

Label: Beggars Banquet

Format: CD (promo)

Source: Copacetic

Cost: $0

Bill had this promo that he gave me to round out some store credit; this is probably the finest Tindersticks album since their second one, or definitely since Curtains. Stuart Staples sings in a higher register than usual, but it works. The arrangements are still sickly and sweet and there's a vocal duet on one number that's just like "Traveling Light". Maybe they're just revisiting old territory, but they do it well. This will be definitely one to play late at night with the lights off while i muse on my loneliness.... Update: It's not Staples singing higher, but another member. Oh, well....


Date: 8 June 2003

Frosted Ambassador

Label: Kindercore

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $5

Eric Harris of Olivia Tremor Control's anonymous solo record is a delightful mix of OTC-styled instrumentation with some more Moondog-influenced melodies. I mysteriously received this in the mail a few years ago shortly after Eric had stayed at my house; he still actively denies his involvement with it, I think. It was nice to find this at Jerry's to replace my CD copy.


Date: 8 June 2003

Johnsons Big Band - (love taps &) slow punches

Label: Rickety

Format: CD

Source: Justin Hopper

Cost: $0

I'm completely thrilled that my favorite Pittsburgh band finally has a CD out. It's been about ten years in the making, too! This maximallist masterpiece contains 9 of the songs they've been playing live in the past two years, done up in a heavily psychedelic style. The horns are quieter in the mix than they are live, which focuses more on the "core" band, I guess, but also takes away a lot of the impact. I listened to this five times in a row when I got it, and while I love it, there's a few songs I was sad to see aren't on here. I really oughta put out CD of the slower, sadder Johnsons material.


Date: 13 June 2003

Rowe, Keith/Toshimaru Nakamura - Weather Sky

Label: Erstwhile

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $8

Keith Rowe doing his thing along with Nakamura's no-input mixer. This is a lot different from the no-input mixer stuff I did with the boys; it's a lot more horizontal, very ringy, with less movement than I expected. Of course the Erstwhile aesthetic isn't the most accessible thing around; I haven't finished listening to the whole thing yet.


Date: 13 June 2003

Rothko - A Continual Search for Origins

Label: Too Pure

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $8

I wwas pretty disappoinetd by this Rothko disc. I guess it's Rothko in name only, as only one member is left. It's definitely put together well, but it doesn't sketch out the same sort of hazy vision that their earlier work does. The female vocalist I actually liked though. I passed up the second Bows album for this; I wonder if that was the right decision.


Date: 13 June 2003

Barry Dransfield

Label: Spinney

Format: CD Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

I filed this next to Nick Drake - alphabetically. Musically it's a bit closer to Bert Jansch. This is another lost Brit-folk treasure unearthed by the Spinney label, recommended to me by Mike Seamans at the record store. And I thought "what the hey". It's a very clean, crisp-sounding record, with Dransfield's voice having a bit more of a traditional lilt to it than, say, Richard Thompson. He plays all of the instruments, including some fiddle, though it's mostly acoustic guitar. Split about 50/50 between covers and originals, Dransfield has a bright sense of melody. Sometimes I question why an obscure, forgotten record like this is so much more exciting than a known classic - but obscurity breeds interest, at least among people like me.


Date: 13 June 2003

Stark Reality - Now

Label: Stones Throw Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

Kickass group of fusion musicians doing Hoagy Carmichael songs. There's something very delightful about their approach, with an extremely fuzzed out guitar and dancey vibes over some hotshot drumming; and the compositions are very bouncy and alive. A feelgood party record. [2003]  This record is such an oddity; it's a pretty adventurous fusion jazz record but it has this childlike wonder to it due to the songs and lyrics.  I remembered this fondly but I forgot how sick the guitar leads are.  I don't usually like vibe-oriented jazz but it works here because it mellows out the attack of everything else.  The record sounds great too. The tonal instruments are fuzzy and thick, and the drums sound tinny, clattery, and thin which serves to make the whole thing feel lighter than it really is.  This is a cool album for sure; the one original composition, 'All You Need to Make Music', is as cute as the Carmichael tunes and I never realised it was written by Stark.  The first seven letters of the alphabet are all you need to make music, in case you were wondering.  [4 Jan 2009]



Date: 13 June 2003

Sparks - Profile: The Ultimate Sparks Collection

Label: Rhino

Format: 2xCD

Source: Paul's

Cost: $7

$27 minus $20 for cd's I sold. Where have Sparks been my entire life? I've been meaning to pick some of their records up for a long time but I've never known which ones are good. And now I do so I'll probably wind up getting their first four or five albums anyway. This is brilliant, eccentric pop music with gorgeously overdone production, great hooks, and very intelligent lyrics. I have been listening to "Talent is an Asset" and "Girl from Germany" over and over.


Date: 14 June 2003

Animal Collective - Here Comes The Indian

Label: Paw Tracks

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Pawtracks

Cost: $9.31

I am so glad these guys are making music. Most of this record was performed last April when they played in Pittsburgh, so I was somewhat familiar with the songs - it's great to hear them recorded. Of course they are pushing themselves in the right direction, especially after Campfire Songs. The longer piece at the start of Side two sounds almost like Nurse with Wound if NWW had Attention Defecit/Hyperactivity Disorder. Perhaps this step towards "head" music is due to Josh (Deaken)'s presence. This is sure to be one of the year's best.


Date: 14 June 2003

Slits - Return Of The Giant Slits

Label: CBS

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: ebay

Cost: $19

I've been looking for this for a few years (though I've only been looking halfheartedly). This is probably #1 in my "Records I Want to Reissue" list, but with CBS owning the rights I bet that will be impossible. The Slits fully embraced a dub/"world music" sound here, taking Cut one step further and creating the finest record of that movement (rivaled only by the Raincoats Odyshape). It's amazing to believe these gals were once a fierce punk band. And at $19 including shipping I think I actually got a "deal" on it.


Date: 17 June 2003

American Analog Set - Promise Of Love

Label: Labels

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Paul's

Cost: $9

I love this band, but their music affects me in the most subtle ways. So after one listen or even ten I'm not going to be able to say how great it is - maybe in 500 listens. On the initial impression it sounded okay but without anything as amazing as "Aaron and Maria".


Date: 20 June 2003

Sparks - Propaganda

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: The Attic

Cost: $6

Sparks rule my life right now. This record I might even like better than Kimono. The cover art is certainly incredible. It's actually inspiring me to write pop music, which hasn't happened in a long time. I've been driving around listening to "At Home At Work At Play" over and over and over and over....


Date: 20 June 2003

Sparks - Indiscreet

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: The Attic

Cost: $7

This is called the "experiemental" Sparks record by fans, and while it has some weird-ass production tricks are more "difficult" ideas, it's not hard to listen to. There's still amazing lyrics and songs in here, but there may be a slightly more conscious decision to subvert the what-was-becoming-familiar Sparks hooks and catchyness. I'm getting to be such a fan now that I loved this at the first listen, but i wouldn't recommend it as a starting point. The opening lyrics to "Hospitality on Parade" are brilliant and set the tone for the weirdness to come; I really love "Under the Table with Her" cause I can't figure out exactly how perverse it is. "Pineapple" and "Tits" are also fantastic - a great one-two punch to open side two with.


Date: 20 June 2003

Sparks - Kimono My House

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: The Attic

Cost: $10

The best Sparks album, by general consensus. Every song is awesome - the ones on the greatest hits CD sound even better on vinyl, as well as some of the others - especially "Thank God It's Christmas". Vinyl in great shape, with shrinkwrap still on it (though broken), and an awesome cover. "Equator" is another classic that belongs on the greatest hits collection - actually the whole album does!


Date: 20 June 2003

Roxy Music - Stranded

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: The Attic

Cost: $8

Absolutely killer. Why did I avoid this record for so long? I might even like it better than the two with Eno. Perhaps it's time to branch out into the even later ones. I realized after listening to Roxy Music and Sparks for two hours that I am feeling very "over the top" lately. "Mother of Pearl" is of course the songs that made me buy this, but "Psalm" is just as amazing. Time to try the fourth one....


Date: 20 June 2003

Halfnelson

Label: Bearsville

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: The Attic

Cost: $15

Sparks' first album (before they were Sparks) and it might be one of the best. The songwriting is at it's weirdest but the arrangements (thanks to Todd Rundgren) are really quirky and tripped out - less bombastic than the later stuff. This really makes me want to find A Woofer in Tweeter's Clothing. Side two has some less exciting moments, where you can tell the band hasn't really found their identity, but it ends with "No More Mr. Nice Guy" which is a foreshadowing of the greatness to come. "Fletcher Honorama" is one of those brilliant, underrated pop songs that has only grown on me after a few weeks.


Date: 21 June 2003

Richard Youngs/Leather Mole - vs. 7"

Label: Crank Automotive

Format: 7" EP

Source: ebay

Cost: $4

A collaborative 7" between Youngs and this group I have never heard of that is not the most exciting thing I have ever heard. Side one is very high-pitched, shrill whistling sounds with some drift to them; side two is a bit fuller with bowing and scraping. Nothing gels compositionally, but I bought it anyway cause I'm such a Richard Youngs fanatic. [12/22/2003]


Date: 25 June 2003

.O.Rang - Fields And Waves

Label: Echo

Format: CD

Source: Dave's music mine

Cost: $5.99

The second O.Rang CD is similar to the first - lush, detailed music that defies categorization. There's a lot of field recordings (or field recording-esque) ethnicy stuff mixed in with a solid rhythm section, to create some sort of hybrid dance/world music/psychedelia. There's more singing on this one which is a bit underwhelming. It's easy to see how Talk Talk split into Mark Hollis and O. Rang - the soupiness of Laughing Stock moved on here while Hollis took the restraint.


Date: 25 June 2003

Piano Magic - Writers Without Homes

Label: 4AD

Format: CD Album Mispress

Source: Dave's music mine

Cost: $5.99

Very disappointing - I had forgotten that this received mostly crappy reviews (even from fakejazz) so I picked it up cause it was cheap. As ear candy goes I guess it's fine, though much of it is just boring. This is a good example of how experimentation isn't everything - while I admire their interest in texture and mood, the weak songwriting can't be compensated for. I already listed this on half.com.


Date: 25 June 2003

Skullflower - Last Shot At Heaven

Label: Noiseville

Format: CD Album

Source: Dave's music mine

Cost: $5.99

Why isn't Skullflower popular with stoner rockers? They are sort of the ultimate stoner rock band to me, sounding like a cross between Black Sabbath and Cro-Magnon. You can hear a lot of weird electronic bubbling in between the riffs, which foreshadows Sunroof. This one isn't as good as Carved Into Roses, but it's still pretty fucking heavy, tripped out, and monolithic.


Date: 25 June 2003

Pure Joy - Carnivore

Label: Popllama

Format: CD

Source: Dave's music mine

Cost: $5.99

I've always been a huge fan of Flop because of Rusty Willoughby's songwriting, so I decided to check out his older, allegedly "more psychedelic" band Pure Joy. It's not really any more psychedelic - just a bit less "crunchy" and hard rock-influenced. The familiar cadences are here, with Rusty's great voice carrying it. I'm sure that I could grow to love this as much as I love Flop, over time, but time is something I don't really have. He has a solo album that's only available through amazon.com; reviews say it's mostly acoustic and very depressing - I should order it!


Date: 2 July 2003

Ssion - Opportunity Bless My Soul

Label: Version City Records

Format: CD

Source: Doug

Cost: $0

Gift from Doug; didn't get the irony or whatever it was.



Date: 7 July 2003

Hair Police - Mortuary Servants

Label: Gods Of Tundra

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Trevor Tremaine

Cost: $0

The title track is a rambunctious, abrasive piece that might be the definitive recording HP song I've heard. The B-side flies by in a heatbeat, sounding like Robert falling down a flight of steps with his stuff. While they're always a lot of fun live, they somehow seem more abrasive on record, as if the grooves are crooked or something.


Date: 7 July 2003

Blithe Sons - Waves Of Grass

Label: Jewelled Antler

Format: CDr Album Limited Edition

Source: Dick Baldwin

Cost: $0

Placid, tranquil drone, and the first thing I have ever heard from any members of the Jeweled Antler collective. I don't know how this compares to their other work, but it's a really beautiful, contemplative record. It's strong organic nature is a big appeal to me, for it's the type of meditative drone I feel most connected to. Ringing tones drift off, and my mind follows til it becomes difficult to even notice the more strident gestures of the musicians. i think they have a full-length "real" CD on Family Vineyard that I'd like to hear - perhaps i will order it from secretly canadian. Now that I have finally heard Jeweled Antler, I have a leg up on Gil, who merely owns all of their CD's but has never listened to any.


Date: 13 July 2003

They Might Be Giants - Flood

Label: Elektra

Format: CD Album

Source: Miriam

Cost: $0

Miriam was going to give this to Goodwill but I snatched it first. Definitely the beginning of the end for TMBG, but enough amazingly great songs. Yes, I am a UNIX system administrator. Maybe all of the Sparks I've been listening to lately has got me in the mood for quirky songwriting. "Dead" could be Sparks lyrics, if you threw a few puns in.


Date: 15 July 2003

Isaac Hayes Movement - The Isaac Hayes Movement

Label: Enterprise Records 

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

Sold.


Date: 15 July 2003

Beatles - Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band

Label: Apple Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album Reissue

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

I have never owned a copy of this before, but every now and then I get an urge to hear "A Day in the Life," so now it's on-hand.


Date: 15 July 2003

Van Morrison - Tupelo Honey

Label: Warner Bros. Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

Here's a weird confession - I don't know anything about the discography of Van Morrison beyond Astral Weeks. That may not seem like much of a confession, but I think it's odd that I can love a record as much as Astral Weeks yet never venture into anything else he ever recorded. I guess I always assumed it was all like "Brown Eyed Girl". So here's a random later Van Morrison album, and it's free so I can't say no. And it's quite a different animal than AW - it's a slicked out singer-songwriter record, with strong R&B leanings - which I guess is what I expected. The first track is packed with horns, but the rest of the record has a more acoustic base. But while AW is lilting, loose and drifting, this record (and most of the rest of his career, I imagine) is very slick - performed well, of course, but lacking the, I dunno… mystery? … of AW. His voice still sounds great, and while he never experiments with much, it's familiar to me and I find these songs more likeable than if they were performed by someone else. Still, I don't think I'll be running out to get the rest of his catalog anytime soon. [8 December 2003]


Date: 15 July 2003

Creedence Clearwater Revival

Label: Liberty

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

I've been thinking for along time about how my record collection is lacking some Creedence, so I was happy to grab this first album for free. I don't know why I wanted it, since I never really feel like listening to boogie-rock. I wouldn't proclaim this record a classic of rock, though it's pretty solid, with honest, soulful vocals and the rootsy feeling that characterizes Southern Rock. 


Date: 15 July 2003

John Cale - Fear

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

This fall I fell in love with Paris, 1919 - it has the same lush intellectual feel that Taking Tiger Mountain has, yet it's more emotional. This is the record that came after it, and it's also very good - a lot more rocking, perhaps replacing sentimentality with aggression. There are less memorable songs than Paris, but I think I can safely say I prefer Cale's pop songwriting to his avant/classical/instrumental work. John Cale's solo career is an incredibly difficult thing for me to get a handle on; I guess I'll have to investigate more of his stuff!


Date: 15 July 2003

The Beatles

Label: Apple Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP Stereo

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

What do I need to say about this? A pinnacle in psychedelic 60's pop. I just sold Lori my CD copy and only a few days later I stumble across the LP for free. Yippie.


Date: 15 July 2003

Rolling Stones - Exile On Main Street

Label: Rolling Stones Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP Album

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

I never had listened to this record all the way through before, but one night I was just in the mood to hear some Stones, so I threw it on, and now I understand the appeal. They sound, well - "badass" - on this record, yet it's a bit much - too excessive, too unfocused, and too ambitious. Which is exactly why it's the perfect Rolling Stones album!!! [2003] It's funny to look back now at my thoughts on Exile. Over the years since my interest in 'classic rock' has really amplified and I tow the party lines on many things. I'm uneven on the Stones; listened to this a million times, with particular memories during the Tuned City festival of driving around Tallinn listening to 'Sweet Virginia' over and over to release me from the relentless week of sound art (not that I didn't enjoy it all); plus many couch-diving living room moshpits during the Glasgow years to 'Rip This Joint'. But still I barely ever listen to Let it Bleed and I don't know Sticky Fingers at all. I have my whole life to listen to the Stones cause they'll always be around, but this is generally (with Beggars Banquet satisfying enough that I don't feel the need to go beyond it). [27 December 2012]


Date: 15 July 2003

Barbieri, Gato/Dollar Brand - Confluence

Label: 

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

Barbieri recorded this in 1968 - and I noticed that there is a CD reissue on Actuel of these two, so perhaps this is from the same sessions? Dollar Brand strong melodic sense is present in his compositions, which have a murkyness to them - like an aural equivalent of Edward Gorey, perhaps. When Barbieri starts cooking, his tone is unmistakable. He sticks to the sax throughout this record, while Brand plays the inside and outside of a piano, cello (I think) and the ever-popular "little instruments" like bells and light percussion. Barbieri's compositions on the other side are more in line with an experimental jazz duo recording. It's remarkable to hear this stuff being recorded in 1968 - even in the height of free jazz culture, I didn't realize these types of duo records were made back then (at least Interstellar Space has drums!). [22 December 2003]


Date: 15 July 2003

Rolling Stones - December's Children (And Everybody's)

Label: London Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album Mono

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

This LP is so fucked up looking that I'm not going to even risk playing it on my already-dying turntable. It looks like someone drove a truck over it.


Date: 15 July 2003

Young, Neil - Young Man's Fancy bootleg

Label: none

Format: LP

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

Pretty tight bootleg - all acoustic, including versions of "Cowgirl in the Sand", a lengthy silly "Sugar Mountain", "See the Sky About to Rain" (!!!), and "Tell Me Why" that are killer.
