Sound quality is a bit murky - midrangey, actually - but not terrible. Kirker will shit his pants when he hears this.


Date: 15 July 2003

The Velvet Underground & Nico

Label: Verve Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

Banana is ripped, but there. An original! It's beat to hell (side two is so scratched it's almost unlistenable), but I can still say I found an original copy of this in someone's attic. Records like this are hard to review because they're so influential that there's really nothing left to say about them. So here is a personal anecdote: I first bought this album used on cassette for $3 at Eide's when I was in eight grade - maybe seventh, actually. I remember coming home and playing side 2 first, cause that's what it was rewound to, on this weird old combo thrift store stereo that I used to listen to music on. What a stereo it was - I remember the radio had a digital tuner and you could tune in even numbers, like 92.2, and there was a horrible built-in turntable that I used to use to dub records from the library, like INXS and Led Zeppelin. I played this album in the dark, and everything I read about "Heroin" was true - it WAS scary! Cale's viola part sounded like piercing feedback but I loved it; my mom almost immediately told me to turn it down but I was a fan. I don't think I was ready for "The Black Angel's Death Song" or "European Son" quite yet. Now when I listen to this album, those tracks jump out (probably because I've grown up to be an obtuse art-rocker). "Sunday Morning" is a pretty fantastic pop song, and I only now appreciate the Teutonic gloom of "All Tomorrow's Parties". Before I knew more about music, I thought of most of the indie rock I listened to as either derived from the VU or the Beatles - as if those were the only two paths that could be taken. Yet in a similar way, I still feel that there is something "missing" from people who do not "get" the Velvet Underground. [8 December 2003]


Date: 15 July 2003

Rolling Stones - Aftermath

Label: Decca

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

This, Beggars Banquet and Between the Buttons are probably my Stones "3". Beat up, but free. Too beat up to risk playing on this turntable (like December's Children) so I should probably find a way to get rid of these. Maybe I'll have to throw them away.


Date: 15 July 2003

Rolling Stones - Between The Buttons

Label: Decca

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

This, Beggars Banquet and Aftermath are probably my Stones "3". This has a LOT of great songs on it, and it's placed at the right point between their earlier, poppier stuff and their more "dangerous" rock phase. It's hard to believe that people once found "Let's Spend the Night Together" controversial, but then again, you couldn't even say "pregnant" on TV back in the day. But side one is seriously awesome, even though they're trying to sound like the Kinks here. This record is really scuffed up and I probably won't keep it for fear of damaging my needle. [12/13/2003]


Date: 15 July 2003

Roxy Music - Country Life

Label: ATCO Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

After my late acceptance and love of Stranded, it's only time to try the fourth. Here's a Roxy Music that has almost no regard for experimentation, though the songwriting is strong. Ferry sounds passionate, tortured even, on "Bitter/Sweet". The first track explodes out of the speakers, and displays the new, slicker Roxy Music. There's still the crazy juxtaposition of soulful, R&B and frantic art-rock, but it's just not as deranged as before. I guess "Siren" is the next logical step.


Date: 15 July 2003

Frisbee, Emmett - Sound Paintings

Label: none

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

Emmett is a local filmmaker/artist/weirdo type whom Adam and Lori are friends with, so I grabbed this album when I had a chance. Here is a very interesting set of musical expressions, with everything from Martin Denny-esque soundscapes to speedy prog freakouts that remind me of a cheap-ass Confusional Quartet. This is a classic example of the weird privately pressed psych records that people reissue now and go for tons of money. [22 December 2003]


Date: 15 July 2003

Neil Young - Neil Young

Label: Reprise Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Peter Mark's Attic

Cost: $0

No cover. I realized that this load of freebies from Pete's attic more than negates all of the space I cleared out from the yard sale, but who's to say I will keep all of these?


Date: 19 July 2003

Larry Coryell - Barefoot Boy

Label: Flying Dutchman

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $5

Shawn Brackbill made me buy this cause it was at Jerry's, and I'm glad he recommened it. Coryell is a great guitarist, capable of stunning freakouts but also holding down a solid rhythm, and he displays both sides here. The opening track is a Gabor Szabo number that has a spunky Latin feel to it. At $5, this was a steal.


Date: 22 July 2003

Guignol - Angela, David and the Great Neopolitan Road Issue

Label: Cenotaph

Format: CD Album

Source: Cenotaph

Cost: $0

1,100 of them, actually. Jeremy, Aaron and Laurence bring their musical personalities together in an interesting way; there's more of a Continental European feel to this than you'll find with their other stuff, yet it's still strange and goofy. I love it and I'm glad I'm putting it out.


Date: 4 August 2003

Steely Dan - Pretzel Logic

Label: MCA Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Dave's Music Mine

Cost: $1.99

I'm finally getting around to checking out Steely Dan - I suspected that I would really love them based on what I've read about their cynical lyrics and crystal clear production. I thought they might seem a little bit too sterile for me, and of course I was right, though I suspect if I can get my head around I will really like them. "Any Major Dude Will Tell You" is a pretty good song. The music is just a little bit too sprighty for songs that are supposed to be about disappointment, but perhaps this irony is the appeal.


Date: 4 August 2003

Steely Dan - Katy Lied

Label: ABC Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Dave's Music Mine

Cost: $1.99

I'm down with Steely Dan, but not obsessively like some people I know. But I probably could be if I devoted more time. I've been saying that for ages and I never spin Katy Lied, but whenever I do, I'm like, shit, this is great! I've always appreciated the sheer perversion of the songwriting - I mean, look at 'Everyone's Gone to the Movies' -- but the precision and obsession of the musical vision has always left me a little bit shut out. I'm not horrified by it - I like it actually, as a continuation of the perversity, or rather a complement - but I can't feel inspired by it at all. Some of the songs here are really beautifully written, like 'Your Gold Teeth II' and 'Bad Sneakers'. Bonus points as well for the techie nonsense about the right way to listen to this album ('observe the RIAA curve'). [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 4 August 2003

New Age Steppers - Massive Hits Vol. 1

Label: Restless Records

Format: CD Compilation

Source: Dave's Music Mine

Cost: $4.99

Adrian Sherwood-led dub-punk featuring Ari Upp and Mark Stewart. I don't know much about dub and these British punkers probably aren't presenting the most accurate rendition of it, but it's fun to listen to. There's more singing than I expected, but it sorta fades into the background, so the parts where it's mixed very very high are off-putting. This is one step past the second Slits album and probably will grow on me.


Date: 4 August 2003

V/A - Traditional Music of Peru vol. 8: Piura CD

Label: Ocora

Format: CD Album

Source: Dave's Music Mine

Cost: $7.99

Another Folkways disc of Peruvian field recordings. I wonder why they've put out so many Peruvian discs - I had no idea there was a big demand for it. One track in particular is a great secular folk song that's very edgy, and I think I?m going to try to figure out how to play it (though I certainly can't sing it) - and it's about a burro!


Date: 9 August 2003

Sparks - A Woofer In Tweeter's Clothing

Label: Bearsville

Format: Vinyl Album LP

Source: eBay

Cost: $18

Maybe I paid too much for Sparks' second album, but it was sealed; after breaking the 31-year old shrinkwrap, I heard "Girl from Germany" in all of it's vinyl brilliance, followed by an album that is very strange and wonderful. This is probably the strangest Sparks album I've heard, even more than Indiscreet, and full of incredible songs that hint at the brilliance to come on their next two. "Whippings and Apologies" may be the best Sparks song I've never heard before, and Earl Mankey wrote a song that's good enough to pass for a Maelstrom. I should throw this on a tape with Indiscreet for the car.


Date: 23 August 2003

Pure Joy - Carnivore

Label: Popllama

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's (trade)

Cost: $0

see review below. Now owned on vinyl. [2003] ;;;  My love for Flop is unsurpassed, and I go back to that brilliant trilogy every few months.  But after all these years I just crave more Rusty Willoughby songwriting, so I've been finally getting into Pure Joy.  I bought this album in 2003 first on CD and then a month later on vinyl when I came across it.  It never reached out and grabbed me as much as Flop at the time, but I don't know why since it's exactly the same sound.  I am going to make a concerted effort to listen to this more and get into the songs, because on this listen, it sounds like it could pass as a counterpoint to Whenever You're Ready and that's certainly good news.  [26 June 2011]


Date: 23 August 2003

10cc - How Dare You!

Label: Mercury

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's (trade)

Cost: $0

Taking Matt Wellins' advice is always a good idea - instead of a tepid collection of soft rock, I find 10cc to be full of quirky arrangement and silly ideas - definitely like Sparks though more subdued and slicked out. It feels like they aren't really taking themselves seriously, however - it strikes me as something that Grand Buffet would make, a la "Murderfuck".


Date: 23 August 2003

Bardo Pond - Slab

Label: Three Lobed Recordings

Format: Vinyl 10" EP

Source: Cory Rayborn

Cost: $0

Test-pressing, I think, without a cover. Bardo Pond does their thing here, and it sounds good. Side 1 is a long, stumbling song that is so slow it almost sounds retarded. The songs fades in and out almost by accident, and has the feeling of a disturbing dream, for the rhythm never quite takes hold. Side two starts with a more grounded rocker (though it's still slow), held more steady and with more clearly-recorded guitars. The last track is a fractured electronic haze, distorted in a way that sounds like an old tape being eaten. I would like to hear more Bardo Pond that sounds like this song. [14 December 2003]


Date: 23 August 2003

Viki / Hair Police - Split

Label: Load Records

Format: CD

Source: Trevor Tremaine

Cost: $0

Viki is retarded dancey Loadstuff from Detroit, and I found myself enjoying it more than I expected. There's a basement lo-fi quality to it, with lots of distortion - in a way reminded me of The Lowdown, but without the songcraft. Vocals are a bit annoying but in a good way. The Hair Police stuff is really aggresively out there - moreso than I ever imagined. The "production" is weird, but strangely appropriate for the music - though it makes it hard for me to really follow how the songs are structured - cause I do believe there is structure to this.


Date: 23 August 2003

Stars of the Lid - Maneuvering The Nocturnal Hum

Label: Earworm

Format: 12" Vinyl EP

Source: Jerry's (trade)

Cost: $0

I ripped this from Luke's vinyl about four years ago, but there was a skip in the beginning. Now I have my own copy - yay! This EP could be an LP depending on what speed you choose to play it at; I'll go with 45rpm here. I quit keeping up with new Stars of the Lid records because they seemed to be redundant, but that in no way lessens my appreciation of them. Their music is so simple on the surface, yet so detailed, and it is enjoyed in differnet ways dependng on how loud you play it. Side one is a bit bleaker, appropriately enough as it's music for La Jetée; side two has a bright, yet rusty sheen to the ambience and it subtly mixes in field recordings. Actually, it's a live performance, so it's actual crowd noise, but it works in a similar way. On this side, the surface noise is more readily absorbed into the music. One of their best releases, I guess. [8 December 2003]


Date: 23 August 2003

Red Krayola - Blues, Hollers And Hellos

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Jerry's (trade)

Cost: $0

This 2000 release from the Red Krayola is still very much in indie rock mode, and significantly more song-based than that crazy Fingerpainting record.  Blues, Hollers and Hellos is a pretty nervous record, with lots of jittery guitars, scratching all over the rhythm section (which is fairly constant).  This lacks the diversity of the masterpiece Hazel or even the more psyched-out stuff.  Some long skittery parts remind me of the Supreme Dicks, or Warmer Milks.  Mayo is distinctly Mayo when singing but the guitars reign supreme.  I think this was priced as an EP but it's really a whole album.  There's a sense of blues for sure, even though there isn't much to be heard in the way of a 12-bar progression.  I could see this growing on me if I listened to it more, but it's not likely to get many spins as I probably played this once in 2003 and once again today.  [9 Nov 2011]


Date: 23 August 2003

Mick Turner - Seven Angels

Label: Three Lobed

Format: CD EP

Source: Cory Rayborn

Cost: $0

Seven short sketches in sixteen minutes of Mick Turner doing his thing. These tracks are all solo guitar except one which seems to have piano in it, and they are all very nice. Most stop right as they start to get going, reminding me more of his debut album than his later, more fleshed out stuff. Still, Turner is a remarkable musician who has the ability to draw incredible images from very simple instrumentation. Avoiding the effects found in most of his other work, he succeeds in playing in a very simple, expressive manner.


Date: 23 August 2003

V/A - Music of Bali

Label: Westminster

Format: 2xLP Album

Source: Jerry's (trade)

Cost: $0

This is a monster double record set of Balinese gamelan music, recorded in the 1950's and packaged on thick old mono slabs of vinyl. There's a great black and white booklet inside, tucked into a little pasted-on pocket. The recording has a much more ragged feel than that Rykodisc triple CD I have; everything is tinnier, and more clangy - it's harder to trance out into a smooth soundgasm. The monkey chant is at the end of side 1, and there's a side-long piece with lots of singing. I think I prefer this to the CDs, possibly because I like listening to things in mono and there's something more romantic about this older ethnomusicological approach. Was originally priced at $9, though I traded stuff for this, but that would have been a steal. [1 August 2012]


Date: 23 August 2003

Emitt Rhodes - Mirror

Label: Dunhill

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's (trade)

Cost: $0

Very Beatlesesque pop, with Rhodes playing all of the instruments. It reminds me more of solo McCartney than any actual Beatles record, or even a bit like the Roy Wood solo records (though not quite as weird). The aspect ratio is totally fucked up on the cover, though. Sealed.


Date: 23 August 2003

Idyll Swords - Purposeful Availment

Label: Three Lobed

Format: CD EP

Source: Cory Rayborn

Cost: $0

I expected to hate this Idyll Swords disc after their awful performance at Transmissions a few years ago, but I guess my embracing of all things folk has made me warm up to these guys. As short as it is, there is some very nice guitar interplay, and the lackluster vocals are kept to a minimum. 


Date: 24 August 2003

Roy Harper - Valentine

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

A very well-rounded Roy Harper record, of shorter songs and very "folky" arrangements. Some tracks rock out in full band mode but the majority are centered around the beautiful acoustic strum and his voice. This is an album of love songs, and the most delicate ones would woo any lovely lady, I think. "Commune" amazes me - not only is it utterly beautiful, but the lyrics hint at an engrossing mysticism. "Twelve Hours of Sunset" also featured David Bedford's string arrangements, and they are perfect - timbrally accentuating Harper's voice without being tacky or overdone. And this record is made up only of outtakes!


Date: 24 August 2003

Heldon - Heldon IV / Agneta Nilsson

Label: Urus Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

A few years ago I was really into the Kranky records roster, and I would get really excited about bands that did low, droney electronics. I should have checked out Heldon then, but I didn't know who they were. While there's a similarity to Tangerine Dream, Heldon sounds less dated. The first track on here could be on the first Labradford album. I thought there would be really crazy guitar antics from Richard Pinhaus, but I guess his style is more ambient. Futuristic and dark, deep listening.


Date: 24 August 2003

Steeleye Span - Hark! The Village Wait

Label: Mooncrest

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

The first Steeleye Span record, and they were a quite different band then. There's another singer who sounds great along with Maddy Prior, and that's all I can really say about it so far. It's weird how Fairport were a rock band that encompassed folk elements, while Steeleye Span were a folk band that encompassed rock elements. 


Date: 24 August 2003

Plastic People Of The Universe - Passion Play

Label: Boží Mlýn Productions

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

A rock Opera with Biblical themes, Passion Play is pretty difficult for me to interface with, as I don't speak Czech. There's a full lyrical translation included in the liner notes, but it doesn't increase my interest in the narrative. Musically, the Plastic People's debt to Zappa is really apparent, as this reminds me of of European avant-rock cabaret, like Floh de Cologne. There aren't epic Zappa-like guitar solos, thank God, but rather a ramshackle string section, fusion-style electric piano, and guitars that (at the best moments) remind me of late Ex: ragged, aggressive, and punchy. The improvised moments are few and far between, but there's a huge RIO feel to those parts. Overall, I'm lukewarm. [29 July 2012]


Date: 24 August 2003

Plastic People Of The Universe - Egon Bondy's Happy Hearts Club Banned

Label: Scopa Invisible

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

This album comes packaged with a huge booklet about the Plastic People - almost the size of a full book, it fattens the LP jacket enough that it's hard to squeeze the plastic bag back on.  The booklet is material to study at a later date - it contains interviews, news clippings, and the entire history of this band.  It's a beautiful package, but unfortunately, the music doesn't really excite me that much.  There are some great moments, certainly - especially the weird space jazz with reverby horns and dropout vocals - but it's a bit bogged down by the theatrical elements.  I'm sure this could grow on me if I listened to it more, but I'd rather listen to Trouble Every Day, the album of VU covers that they released.  [3 Jan 2009]


Date: 24 August 2003

Love

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

I like Love's first record quite a bit - maybe it's the covers that get me, like "Hey Joe" and Burt Bacharach - but there are some songs here that hint at what is to come. "Signed DC" is a very tender, touching song that gets me everytime; the rockin' numbers push forward with an agressive swagger. A document of an era that has been overdocumented, but an important one still.


Date: 24 August 2003

Milton Nascimento - Geraes

Label: EMI

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

I'm no expert on Lusophone pop, yet I've always dug this Milton Nascimento record, enough that I've held onto it for all these years. I can't understand a word but that doesn't stop his conviction from coming through - there's an earnestness in every wave of vibrato when he sings, and I like the tropical/island arrangements as well. Sometimes Portuguese sounds a bit like Russian to me, and no one believes me when I say that, but there are a few parts of these songs where you can definitely hear it. I wonder if he is like the Perry Como of Brasil and this is a really silly record to enjoy - and I also wonder how this compares to other works the vast Nascimento discography. It snowed today - the first major snow of the year, so this is a funny thing to listen to when looking out the window at this very different hemisphere. It doesn't warm me up, but strikes me as absurd to juxtapose the two. But today is not a day for Nils Økland or Arvo Pärt or other more regionally-appropriate music; it's a day for bouncy Brasilian swing. [27 November 2012]


Date: 24 August 2003

Incredible String Band - The 5,000 Spirits or the Layers of the Onion

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

I haven't listened to this since I got the LP, but I've had it on tape for years. This is probably my favorite Incredible String Band record.


Date: 24 August 2003

Incredible String Band - The Incredible String Band

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

I've always wondered what this first ISB record was like, as it's the only one feature Clive Palmer as a member of the band. Perhaps a bit more serious, it's otherwise as consistently tuneful as the second and third records. There are parts that sounded very influenced by traditional American folk, though this may be my ears playing tricks on me because of the banjo. Palmer's lone song is somewhat dark, and his arrangement of the instrumental "Niggertown" is nice though the title seems so horribly dated.


Date: 24 August 2003

Fela Ransom Kuti and the Africa 70 - Live with Ginger Baker

Label: Signpost

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

A Fela Kuti record - what is there to say? It's good. I don't know what Ginger Baker does - maybe second percussion? He isn't actually listed in the credits but neither is Fela so I guess he's on drums (though Tony Allen is more than competent).


Date: 24 August 2003

Watersons - For Pence and Spicy Ale

Label: Antilles

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

A later Watersons record featuring Martin Carthy as the fourth member, there are 14 songs here mostly about farming, hunting and fishing.  Mike Waterson's voice has the most amazing vibrato on it, and when the four of them are all harmonising it often sounds really incredible. I  think I can feel a more Northern vibe from this than a lot of other folk songs.  I've avoided a lot of traditional British music for awhile (because I got so sick of it in the UK with my friends constantly performing it) but it's nice to hear this, especially as these aren't songs about kings or princes. [16 Feb 2009]



Date: 24 August 2003

Tim Buckley - Starsailor

Label: Warner Bros. Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

Tim Buckley embraced the avant garde, thank god, and this record is a testament to the power of his music. His voice roams across these songs like an untamed force, and the arrangements struggle to complement it. The first song on side two sounds like US Maple crossed with Soft Machine, and I've listened to "Song to the Siren" about 100 times in the past few weeks. That song is a masterpiece - utterly emotionally devastating, yet a step beyond anything traditional. The guitar just sounds like a high school kid fucking around with a chorus pedal, yet it's so perfect that it puts chills across my body. The rest of the album is great too. I gotta get Lorca.


Date: 24 August 2003

Tim Buckley - Happy Sad

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

Jazz-oriented Tim Buckley is a wonderful thing. I've never enjoyed vibes as much in my life as I do on this record. The whole thing rolls along in a very natural motion, with his voice staying mostly melodic (unlike Starsailor). The longer songs never get tiresome, and the ocean sounds at the beginning and end of the third song don't sound hackneyed at all but very well integrated into the music. 


Date: 24 August 2003

Shirley Collins - A Favorite Garland

Label: Import

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

A greatest hits of Shirley Collins, that varies between the weird stuff with Dolly on the pump organ, and more minstrely full band stuff. I emphasize the term "great" here. 


Date: 24 August 2003

John Cale - Paris 1919

Label: Reprise Records

Format: Vinyl LP White Label Promo

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

I first listened to this record in eighth grade and really liked it and I've been meaning to pick it up at Jerry's for years, but I've actually never seen it. I've seen just about every other John Cale record in the interim, but I've been holding out for this one, cause it's fucking wonderful. Cale writes really fantastic pop songs, with heavy string arrangements that sound like a pop Peter Greenaway soundtrack; as you can imagine the songs are literate, perhaps a bit aloof and very European feeling. The title track slays and so does "Graham Greene", where he actually sounds like Jon Langford with his Welsh accent. Too bad this record is in such bad shape - it skips a lot.


Date: 24 August 2003

Bonzo Dog Doo-Dah Band- Let's Make Up And Be Friendly

Label: United Artists Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

McDowell recoiled in horror when he saw this in the box, and told me how horrible it was, so I went in with a bad attitude, perhaps. This opens with "Do The Strain", a song about constipation that would be a great flipside to Roxy Music's "Do the Strand". The other tracks are full of jokes, and while Neil Innes' penchant for melody and hooks is solid, I felt sort of stupid listening to this. I couldn't make it through the spoken word stuff either. I guess they have better albums than this.


Date: 24 August 2003

10cc - The Original Soundtrack

Label: Mercury

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

This features 10cc's most well-known song "I'm Not In Love" (which I am not familiar with) and is therefore their most well-known album. It opens with this totally sick suite of songs, "Une Nuit a Paris". It's completely ridiculous, but fun; the kind of thing I could see myself really getting into. It's hard to not think of them as a novelty group but there is such a sense of silliness to their music that it really walks the line sometimes. I should put this and How Dare You on a tape for the car. [7 December 2003]


Date: 24 August 2003

Roy Harper - Flat Baroque and Berserk

Label: Harvest

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

This is the Roy Harper album most memorable for "I Hate the White Man," which actually isn't nearly as great as many of his other songs - especially "Don't You Grieve" which is sung from Judas Iscariot's point of view. In these earlier records, Harper seems to be midway between a "folk singer" and a "pop singer"; it's right before he found his own complete identity with Stormcock.


Date: 24 August 2003

Roy Harper - Bullinamingvase

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

Side one alternates between slow and midtempo rockers - backed by a band, but still centered around an acoustic strum. There are slow, almost dirgy tracks like "These Last Days" where Harper's voice is beautiful yet sad. In the past I would have called a record like this overproduced, but I think I really like it this way, esp. with the reverb on his voice. Side two is the lengthy "One of Those Days in England" that is truly epic - with orchestra at times, but veering back to Roy and his guitar. The lyrics are a very negative look at the social problems affecting the country then, with some strange lines ("rolling spliffs for Captain Kirk"). 


Date: 24 August 2003

Harper, Roy - Folkjokeopus

Label: Liberty

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

This is the one with "McGoohan's Blues", which I think is Harper's first very long composition. It's about The Prisoner, and it never gets repetitive or dull thorughout it's eighteen minutes. The rock accompaniments sound great here - it's like my favorite type of folk-rock. I think this is his third album.


Date: 24 August 2003

Roy Harper - Lifemask

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

Lifemask is based around a near-death experience that Harper had, and as you can imagine, it's very charged and affirming. Even the more stripped down songs use a clean electric guitar instead of the acoustic sound I love, and they burn with a remarkable intensity. But I think I prefer the more gentle side of Harper, so this wouldn't be one of my favorites. The side-long piece on side 2, "The Lord's Prayer", gets to be a bit repetitve and isnt as successful as "McGoohan's Blues" or any of the songs on Stormcock (but the long spoken word part at the beginning is pretty cool). Still, this has "All Ireland" which is pretty great. [3 December 2003]


Date: 24 August 2003

Fotheringay - Fotheringay

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

Fierce Sandy Denny-led band, but the record skips a lot. Ross had four copies of this so I guess I grabbed a bad one. A mix of Fairport-styled traditionals, Denny-penned originals and a Dylan cover, this is like a more intense Fairport, maybe a bit less rock-oriented. There's a Gordon Lightfoot cover that is really crazy and good, with all of the guys singing.


Date: 24 August 2003

Guru Guru - Dance Of The Flames

Label: Atlantic

Format: Vinyl Album LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

I think I've got the two least interesting Guru Guru records.  This one is unremarkabe (though quite amped-up) blues rock, with some vocal pyrotechnics that wouldn't be out of place at a German biker bar (which is probably where these guys played).  This would probably speak to me more if I was a bigger "rock" guy, but I'm not.  It's interesting though--  why do I like Prisonshake but don't think I'll ever listen to this again?  [18 March 2009]



Date: 24 August 2003

Roy Harper - Stormcock

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

A masterful record constructed around four long almost-all acoustic songs, this is my favorite Roy Harper album, I think. The lyrics address relationships and religion with equal bitterness, and Jimmy Page actually plays a kickass solo that makes the song better (and isn't excessive!). It sounds like he's singing "Dan Onorato, Dan Onorato" on side two, so maybe I should send it to Onorato's campaign manager. The long songs here work extremely well, a lot better than the one on Lifemask; the very slight arrangements by David Bedford sound a little out of place, for I would have preferred an all-acoustic album, but he more than makes up for it on other Harper records. I would probably recommend this as the starting point for an interested Roy Harper fan.


Date: 24 August 2003

Sallyangie - Children of the Sun

Label: Transatlantic

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

Extremely twee record of Mike Oldfield and his sister. This is a great British folk record, written by a 21 year old with a beautiful voice. There's the usual acoustic bliss behind these songs - and lots of flute - and it just sounds wonderful to me. I'm a total fucking wimp.


Date: 24 August 2003

Steeleye Span - Ten Man Mop Or Mr. Reservoir Butler Rides Again

Label: Pegasus

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

The second Steeleye record has beautiful packaging - there's this weird stony/paisley pattern on the inner gatefold and LP sleeve, and a needless booklet that has full-page photos of each member and a little info about the songs. All are traditional, but the arrangements sure aren't; 'Gower Wassail' sets the tone at the beginning as Carthy intones over a stark, repeated electric guitar chord. They resist the urge to get too rocking OR too folk, instead staying balanced on this middle ground and playing to their strengths, which are vocal harmonies, interpretations , and musicianship. While I love Maddy Prior, Carthy's vocals are a bit more enjoyable, especially on 'Four Nights Drunk' where it twists around with the fiddle magnificently.Throughout there is a lot of range, from the fun (the 'Reels' medley, in particular) to the intense ('When I Was on Horseback'). It's an exemplary effort all around. [2 December 2012]


Date: 24 August 2003

Shirley & Dolly Collins - For As Many As Will

Label: Topic

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

This is a late period Shirley and Dolly record with a bunch of medieval instrumentation and Barry Dransfield on fiddle and voice. The two tracks I love both feature Dolly on piano instead of the ubiquitous organ. One is by Richard Thompson, 'Never Again', a bit at odds with the traditional vibe of the record but Thompson is of course saturated in that aesthetic anyway. But 'Gilderoy' is the real tragic piano ballad, despite it's rolling, uplifting notes. Philip Pickett plays a lot of instruments I've never heard of like the gittern and shawm - seriously, check out the Wikipedia entry for the shawm, it's fascinating - and there's a long medley at the end of side 1 that's almost like a definitive neo-trad take on this all. Dolly actually plays synthesiser a few places, but it's really subdued and nothing like, say, Sun Ra's Atlantis. The psychedelic nature of Shirley and Dolly Collins is all in the aesthetic, not in individual freakouts. [9 November 2012]


Date: 24 August 2003

Roy Harper - Flashes from the Archives of Oblivion

Label: Harvest

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

Roy Harper may be the British Neil Young; if so, this is his Journey Through the Past. A live album showcasing all of his different styles (though with an abundance of songs from Lifemask/Valentine), this has some really weird parts, like the side-long "Highway Blues"/"One Man Rock and Roll Band" which is buried in electronic alterations, delayed vocals, and flange effects. The sound quality and performances are so solid that it's easy to forget this is a live record - his voice is flawless on these tracks, especially the bittersweet "Another Day". "Commune" is another standout - the kind of song that just entrances you with it's beauty and depth. 


Date: 24 August 2003

Hampton Grease Band - Music to Eat

Label: Columbia

Format: 2xLP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

I used to own this on CD, and I sold it cause it was pretty unlistenable. But Ross happily sold me the original double LP for $2, so I had to own it. Wouldn't you like to come to Halifax? The Hampton Grease Band are one of those things that is great only conceptually, but the record does grow on you after awhile. In some ways it's almost better that they are a mediocre blues rock band that was insane instead of another tripped out psychedelic band that was insane.


Date: 24 August 2003

Dando Shaft

Label: Neon

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

The first Dando Shaft album is made up of shorter, perhaps happier pieces. The fiddle work on "Railway" reminds me of Camper Van Beethoven. Overall Dando Shaft has really excellent musicianship, moreso than most of their contemporaries. However, they don't really gel and feel like a real band. There isn't as much flutey shit on this one, just lots of plucking and strumming, with eclectic enough instrumentation but nothing excessive. And it's on RCA's ultra-shitty Dynaflex vinyl, the worst idea ever. I'd like to find the third album.


Date: 24 August 2003

V/A - Guitar Solos Vol. 2

Label: Caroline/Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $3.42

How crazy that this was released on Virgin? This compilation features contributions by Fred Frith, G.F. Fitzgerald, Hans Reichel and Derek Bailey, so with heavyweights like that, it's sure to be good. This was curated really well, because side 1 puts Frith and Fitzgerald together and their pieces sound like they could have come from the same mind. Both take on the guitar as if trying to conjure dead ghost voices from it. There's a wonderful static around everything, and Frith's piece reminds me of the casual but amazingly beautiful opening section he played when I saw him in concert last year (though this was over 25 years earlier). Fitzgerald, who made that brilliant Mouseproof album that I heard at Laurence Coleman's place back in 2001, has a similarly processed electroacoustic approach, which is all glowing stars and burning embers. On the flip, Reichel's crazy homemade two-neck guitar has an alien aesthetic, full of impossible counterpoint and recorded in a very close, very in-your-face way - almost the opposite of side 1. And then Bailey closes it out with a sparse, minimal Derek Bailey thing, which is also very up-front though there's a lot of room in between the notes here. [12 July 2012]


Date: 5 September 2003

irr.app.(ext.) - foreign matter, nor frequency carrier

Label: none

Format: CD-R

Source: Matt Waldron

Cost: $0



Date: 5 September 2003

irr. app. (ext.) - Dust Pincher Appliances

Label: Not On Label

Format: CDr

Source: Matt Waldron

Cost: $0

Back in 2003 I approached Matt Waldron about doing a release on Cenotaph and he was very enthusiastic and sent me a stack of CDs.  I then totally flaked out and never did a release, and listening to this again I'm really regretting it.  I think Crouton ended up issuing this as a proper CD and maybe even LP (in which case I'd like to track it down).  This is a masterful work of surrealist sound, with strange field recordings, bizarre improvisations, and a creeping feeling that is most confusion than dread.  The zither work in particular sounds a million miles removed from any free folk string jamming, yet the style and means of recording could be some New England (or Finnish, hah) people.  Yet instead of a Jeweled Antler amateurish vibe, every second is meticulously focused.  I get the feeling that Waldron puts oodles of effort into every nanosecond of sound here, careful assembling with the precision of a master painter.  The fidelity is wonderful too - these are CDs to really lose yourself listening to and a broad dynamic range really benefits the material.  [16 Feb 2009]



Date: 5 September 2003

irr. app. (ext.) - An Uncertain Animal, Ruptured; Tissue Expanding In Conversation

Label: Errata In Excelsus

Format: CD

Source: Matt Waldron

Cost: $0



Date: 5 September 2003

irr.app.(ext.) - ozenische Gefuhle

Label: Errata In Excelsis

Format: CD-R

Source: Matt Waldron

Cost: $0

This irr.app.(ext.) release is built around a long, 40 minute track with a shorter track at the end. Waldron's approach to sound construction is extremely careful and delicate, though there is an improvised feel for much of this, particularly at the end where there is an irregular rumbling underneath the beautiful, placid drones. Much of this disc is constructed on deep, fluid sounds, with higher sonorities on top - bells and pings, which now actually sound a bit like someone is receiving a text message. It's beautiful and contemplative, and actually a bit loose compared to some of his more intricate work. [25 July 2012]


Date: 5 September 2003

irr.app.(ext.) - radiant black futures

Label: Errata In Excelsis

Format: CD-R

Source: Matt Waldron

Cost: $0

This is maybe the best irr.app.(ext.) recording. The eight tracks are all over the place, from dark, brooding Throbbing Gristle-style industrialism to disappearing sound clouds recorded live (the last track), and including this insane second track that sounds like a live vaudeville performance, with very artificial crowd laughter placed in a very disturbing way - like the rabbit scenes in Inland Empire. The artwork, all inkjet printed in my edition, completely occupies that subgenre of HNAS, Beta-Lactam Ring, etc in aesthetic and intent, but I think Waldron's style is a bit different - more playful, even in a genre that embraces playfulness. [22 August 2012]


Date: 12 September 2003

Arbete och Fritid - Arbete och Fritid

Label: MNW

Format: CD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $14.99

A great collection of weird Swedish progish stuff from the late 60s'/early 70's. Some parts have a real Seventh Seal feel, with medieval melodies and a naturalistic feel. Other moments are more rock-oriented, almost Soft Machine-like. There's a different feel to this than anything I have ever heard, and I can't really explain why. I guess it's Scandinavianess is somewhat responsible, though Arbete och Fritid are definitely unique.


Date: 12 September 2003

Ron 'Pate and his Debonairs - Raudelunas Pataphysical Revue

Label: Alcohol

Format: CD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $15.99

After wanting this for a long time I am slightly disappointed; the Debonairs/Lane stuff is very annoying - I'm sorry, but I'll take Dave Mansueto over Fred Lane any day. Anne Lebaron's piece for frogs is incredible and basically the reason to own this disc; the other groups featured are interesting; the blue denim jeans or whatever is a nice bit of MEV-style improv; the Roman improvisers are also worthwhile. But the Lane bits in between become pretty annoying after you've heard them more than once, overall making me wonder if I'll keep this CD for very long.


Date: 12 September 2003

Alain Savouret - Chrysopee Electronique-Bourges: Sonata Baroque

Label: Le Chant Du Monde 

Format: CD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $15.99

In a way, finding this is like a Holy Grail. Back in my college days, Caleb had a copy of this from his brother, and we used to listen to it so much and wonder who the hell Alain Savouret was. A few months ago, Caleb found it at Twisted Village and I had to get it when I saw another copy. I think this record is best described by McDowell, who after hearing a few minutes said "It makes me happy to know that there are people out there making music like this." This is my favorite musique concrete album ever, I'd say, and to finally own it after all of this time is a good feeling.


Date: 12 September 2003

These Trails - These Trails

Label: Pele Records

Format: CD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $13.99

When Gil described this to me as hippie Hawaiian folk, I expected something very dark, trance-like, and inaccessible, like the No Neck Blues Band channeling Can. I was quite surprised to find an extremely beautiful vocal-oriented record. This is almost twee in how bright and alive the vocals sound; the guitar playing is crisp and there are some keyboards at times. It's a wonderful record and I understand why Gil loves it so much - I love it too.


Date: 12 September 2003

Horde Catalytique Pour La Fin - Gestation Sonore

Label: Mellow Records

Format: CD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $14.99

I'm fascinated by the Futura label right now; I want to hear everything on it and try to figure out what sort of cultural basis this music has. Here is a brief, yet solid record of some indescribable music - that Futura "sound" if there is one. There's a clattery feeling that suggests the Art Ensemble of Chicago's more abstract work if they weren't skilled musicians. There's just an otherworldliness to the music that I can't explain; it's easy to drift away while listening to it even though it's not drifty music. Was there a "scene" in France that produced all of these artists? Or are they all mavericks working independently that somehow were collected together?


Date: 12 September 2003

Robert Wyatt - Solar Flares Burn For You

Label: Cuneiform Records

Format: CD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $15.99

A new Robert Wyatt CD is about as exciting as it gets; this isn't new material, though apparently there's one coming out next month! This collects various BBC sessions and miscellaneous stuff with a few new tracks. The new tracks, sadly, don't kill me; the old stuff is great though, positioned between pre and post-accident nicely. The Rock Bottom/Ruth songs are totally amazing here, more intense and driving than the album versions with just solo piano. The "We've Got an Arts Council Grant"/"Righteous Rhumba" stuff isn't incredible but amusing and important I guess to signify his transitional period. "Little Child" is a wonderful old song that is actually hurt a bit by Wyatt's vocals being less than perfect (for the first time in his career, really). It's still a worthwhile addition to his collection, at least if you're as big of a fan as me.


Date: 12 September 2003

The Young Tradition

Label: Transatlantic

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $4.99

A greatest hits - features "Chicken on a Raft"! In a weird way, I think I like the Young Tradition more than the Watersons; it's hard to not compare them, as they are both a-capella, though the Young Tradition are apparently from Southern England while the Watersons hail from the North. There's something more intense about their music, and the occasional instrumental accompaniment really helps.


Date: 12 September 2003

Rev. Dwight Frizzell - Natural Selection

Label: Paradigm Discs

Format: CD Album

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $6.99

This "other" Dwight Frizzell record shows his solo work from the last twenty years, and it's a surprising about-face from Anal Magic. Aptly named, field recordings of buzzing crickets, water, and other nature sounds cover almost the entire disc, under which he experiments with sine tones, electronically altered strings, and voice. It's not compelling like his other stuff, and it lacks the Dadaist sense that I really liked about it, but this still very well-constructed outsider music, and I've found myself using it to fall asleep more than once.


Date: 14 September 2003

Mouse On Mars - Glam

Label: Sonig

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Mid-period Mouse on Mars, I think originally intended as a soundtrack. My tastes in abstract IDM/electronica are definitely in this direction and other Sonig label stuff from around the same period, though listening with 2012 ears I don't know how much this moves me. The textural qualities are stunning and the dry, digital airyness is something that they've captured very well. When the heavier beats come in, like on side 2, I just find it distracting, which probably explains why I've never been able to appreciate this genre as anything more than a now-and-then treat. But the more sedate and I guess soundtrack moments are lovely - it's always the organic feeling I am drawn to. [15 October 2012]


Date: 14 September 2003

Mercury Rev - Yerself Is Steam

Label: Mint Films

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

Sadly there's a pretty bad scratch right at the beginning of this album, during "Chasing a Bee". I saw Mercury Rev open up for Porno for Pyros on the Boces tour (I think I was in 8th grade) but never really got into them until Luke dubbed me this record a few years back. This is a classic of post-shoegazer psych and it's great to finally have it on the superior format - thanks, Gil!


Date: 14 September 2003

Salamander - Birds of Appetite

Label: Camera Obscura

Format: 2xLP Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

A beautiful gatefold double LP on 180gram vinyl (or possibly thicker) that moves between folky psyche and dark, extended space-rock jams. Side three is one song, twenty minutes long, that lies underneah an avalanche of fuzz. Guitars are king here, but there's enough of a mellow vibe here that even the more intense rockers avoid launching into hard rock repetition. The vocals are buried, which is the way they should be; and listening to the whole album straight through probably takes forever, which can be a good or bad thing. [12/17/2003]


Date: 14 September 2003

V/A - We'll Sail Our far ... Maybe a little too far

Label: Apartment

Format: 2xLP Album

Source: Gil

Cost: $0

This is an epic compilation, released by Per Gisle's label in the late 90's and featuring a bunch of popular and obscure artists, maybe of whom I really love. The Bingo Trappers, Sandoz Lab Technicians and Motorpsycho all share space here, with a bonus 7" featuring a Nordic-themed Mountain Goats song as well. As expected, this ranges from very constructed sound collages (Origami Republika's work is genuinely scary at points), simple bedroom songs, and half-baked experiments.Thurston's track is short but beautiful; Brother JT presents one of his more far-out spoken tracks, which is truly paranoid and whacked-out. The Bingo Trappers are fairly straightforward and it's a great song; Plover's the next cut and it's just as feel-good. All in all, this is a great portrait of music happening in 1997 that was removed from any specific radar; as that's a year right in my own 'golden period' of music at its aesthetic peak, this is a lovely artefact to own. [3 December 2012]


Date: 15 September 2003

Curtains - Flybys CD

Label: Thin Wrist

Format: CD Album

Source: Adam Strohm

Cost: $0

extra copy sent to him thru fakejazz; I kept it. I initially wanted to put this out, and I still think it's solid; I liked it better than their first record when I heard it, although now, revisiting it, I find it a bit weaker. There is some great skronked-out deconstructed scree but not as much of a twisted vision as I initially thought. Maybe I will enjoy this more if I hear it on vinyl (or maybe part of me is disappointed that I didn't put it out, so I am regarding it differently. I hope not).


Date: 27 September 2003

Marshmallow Coast - Antistar

Label: Misra

Format: CD

Source: Phildorf

Cost: $0

This new Marshmallow Coast CD is leaps and bounds ahead of the last one, with more confident singing, better songwriting, and fuller production. The last one had nice moments, but this is a more mature record all around. The mood is still breezy, and it's hard not to smile at even the less memorable tracks. 


Date: 27 September 2003

Centro-Matic - Love You Just The Same

Label: Munich Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Phil Waldorf

Cost: $0

thanks, phil!


Date: 4 October 2003

Cerberus Shoal - Bastion Of Itchy Preeves

Label: North East Indie

Format: CD Album

Source: Cerberus Shoal

Cost: $0



Date: 4 October 2003

Cerberus Shoal - Chaiming the Knoblessong

Label: Northeast Indie

Format: CD

Source: Cerberus Shoal

Cost: $0

Thumbs up. Really. It takes a long time to listen to this whole disc, and there are moments of total greatness and total excess. But why do I get so down on Ceberus Shoal for their long, silly rambling spoken parts? If it were called "Sun City Girls" I would proclaim it genius. So to be fair and appraise them the same way as I would an SCG record, this is pretty enjoyable, even at some of the parts that make me wince, because they're a great group of people making incredibly unique music - and that is the bottom line.


Date: 4 October 2003

Cerberus Shoal/Alan Bishop - The Vim and Vigor of Cerberus Shoal and Alvarius B

Label: Northeast Indie

Format: CD Album

Source: Cerberus Shoal

Cost: $0



Date: 4 October 2003

Cerberus Shoal/Magic Carpathians - The Life and Times of Cerberus Shoal and the Magic Carpathians CD

Label: Northeast Indie

Format: CD Album

Source: Cerberus Shoal

Cost: $0

Two tracks by each group. The liner notes are hard to read - I don't know if this means that each group put a track down independently, or if they are somewhat collaborative. Either way, these are good outings by both groups, but the Carpathians track kills. Their palette is varied and the different sounds keep shifting, creating a really active trance. I might like this better than anything on their albums.


Date: 7 October 2003

Robert Wyatt - Cuckooland

Label: Hannibal Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Rennie

Cost: $0

Assessing a new Robert Wyatt CD is a pretty difficult task. When dealing with an artist whom I love as much as Wyatt, it tends to take me awhile to digest the material. So even though I've been listening for two months, bear with me. This is the longest album he has ever done - seventy-five minutes, split into two parts so it can be properly called a "double album". Of course you would expect some filler here, but none of the tracks are really "filler" in the traditional sense. Instead, the whole album falls into the same category of his last two releases -still good, yet somehow not as relevant as his earlier masterpieces. Which is fine - you can't expect a sixty year old ex-prog rocker to turn out charged, passionate music like a youngster can. Instead, Wyatt seems to be happy sketching out his musical ideas, collaborating with his friends, and sharing the results with us. And I'm delighted that he still continues to do this. Michael Mantler's daughter Karen has a strong presence here, writing two tracks and singing on others; and her style of abstraction works well with Wyatt's. The arrangements are similar to Shleep and Dondestan, with a heavy reliance on his synthesizers - to the point that it takes on a New Age feel. His lyrics, often written with or by Alfie Benge, continue in the poetic style of these recent releases, though they get pointed at times. Like on "Theme for Hamaza", the end of the first half, which is a somber reflection on the Iraq war (and the album also ends with an instrumental piece that originally had lyrics, printed in the booklet, of a similar theme). This political content is relevant, but not sloganistic like his earlier stuff; the hammer-and-sickle-waving Robert Wyatt seems to be gone, and instead we have a more mature artist who is still passionate, still hopeful. There's some quirky bits, recalling his experiments with Ruth/Richard, and his jazz leanings tend to come out more. While this record feels more 'easy' and 'pleasant' than his most classic albums, it's still wonderful in that Robert Wyatt way. But nothing here even attains the edge of "Free Will and Testament"; it's a very comfortable record. And in his heyday, he made records that were very much uncomfortable. [9 December 2003]


Date: 7 October 2003

V/A - Wooden Guitar

Label: Locust

Format: CD

Source: fakejazz

Cost: $0

As great as I had hoped, there is not a bad track on here. My only complaint is the Tetuzi Akiyama track, which is excellent but feels out of place; it's lengthy, and stuck right in the middle of this disc, it causes the whole thing to drag. But the Jack Rose and Rick Bishop tracks do not disappoint. I can't wait until Tamburo hears this!


Date: 25 October 2003

Roesingape - the enemy of all good times CD-R

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CD-R

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0

An album-length cd-r from Chris Rosing that seems torn between wanting to be an experimental electronics record and idm. Not as completely discombobulated as the other stuff I've heard him do, this has some midrangey buzzing drones that are quite nice. Some tracks have vocals, which are interesting; when they are surreal it works, and serves to separate his music from a lot of other electronic artists. But the last track is just a total joke "insane" monologue that devolves into bathroom humour, and while I have no problem with this in theory, I don't know why he chose to end the disc this way. Of course, I still don't understand his aesthetic.


Date: 25 October 2003

Consonant - Love and Affliction

Label: Fenway

Format: CD promo

Source: Shake It

Cost: $3.2

A bit of a letxdown after the self-titled CD, which I totally loved. Here, Conley seems to be writing strong but without as much of an obvious Kinks/pop influence. There's more attention to dynamics, and it's probably more accomplished as a band,. Steed put it well in his fakejazz review. Of course I'm more interested in killer Conley songwriting than a balanced indie-rock effort.


Date: 25 October 2003

3LR/Burning Star Core

Label: Dronedisco

Format: cassette

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: $0

Sometimes I don't understand why Spencer releases what he does. This is a split between Robert Beatty's old drum and bass project with he disavows and BxC, though Spencer's track is a dance track. Neither track is bad, but I don't know why he put it out. He seemed to be unsure as well when he gave it to me.


Date: 28 October 2003

Songs Of Norway - Despite The Cloak

Label: Beta-lactam Ring Records

Format: Vinyl LP/7"

Source: Nick Mott

Cost: $0

The 7" with Earth Trumpet hints at what a Paddenless Bear would be like - darker, and less folky. The LP is a beautiful item, pressed onto 180g vinyl or heavier, and the thing sounds great. There are moments where Nick and Aaron are just playing violin and drums, but they are creeping along slowly, testing each other out, the violin laden with electronic processing. These moments are probably my favorite parts, especially because of the way in which they are recorded. There's tons of space between things, and because of this the music has room to breathe and develop. It's pleasant to get lost in the reverberation of these instruments.


Date: 28 October 2003

El Monte & Aranos - Allied Cooking But Not As You Know It!

Label: Pieros

Format: CD

Source: Nick Mott

Cost: $0

Nick and Aranos work together on this totally great CD that seems to have gotten little attention/distribution. Unsurprisingly, it's dominated by strings, and I'm really impressed with Nick's violin ability - I'm not sure which is him and which is Aranos. One long improvisation has the two of them stretching all over the place with bending tones. Other parts have an incredible amount of space in them, with a similar echo to the Norway LP.


Date: 7 November 2003

Grand Buffet - Pittsburgh Hearts

Label: No label

Format: CD EP

Source: Grand Buffet

Cost: $5

I can't deny that I found GB's last EP to be disappointing; here they kick it up a notch with some more quality (though still not displaying the same level of imagination and zest as Undercover Angels). Gregg Girl Talk's backing track is definitely one of the highlights, though it doesn't really fit with the GB sound - Gregg has become a remarkable wizard behind the computer. The sixteen minutes of this disc go by quickly, but they are smart in keeping it short. I like Grand Buffet when they are at their most strange, and this definitely has some moments but overall isn't as fucked up as what they are capable of. There isn't as much of a Pittsburgh theme to this record as one might think, despite their antics at the release show. This might have their most overtly political material yet, but is anyone listening? [7 December 2003]


Date: 22 November 2003

Xanopticon - Liminal Space

Label: Hymen

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ryan Xanopticon

Cost: $7

I had a few film classes in college with this guy Ryan who was really cool.  I saw him at experimental shows a few times and we chatted a lot - he was into extreme metal and electronic music.  He did this solo beat-oriented project called Xanopticon, and this is his LP. I guess this is breakcore - incredibly fast, skittery beats constantly varying in rhythm, while flourishes of synth string pads swell up in the background.  Though the rhythms are complex, everything else is fairly minimal; lots of space is there behind the beats.  I try to be appreciative of this type of music but by the second half of side 2 I was totally annoyed and wanted ot turn it off.  How people can be mostly interested in this kind of music is a mystery to me.  The sounds and images are so limited, it's too herky-jerky to dance to, and I can't listen deeply because the beats irritate my consciousness.  I don't mean to be a hater though, as there's something technically impressive about what Ryan has done - it's just not my scene, man.  [16 Feb 2009]



Date: 22 November 2003

Burning Star Core - Crystal Castles

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CD-R

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

Spencer's tour-only cd-r is actually one of my favorite BxC releases - the first track is an abstract, percussive nightmare that propels along with rhythmic shifts to create an uneasy environment. The third track is an extended live violin-centric piece that has some subtle speech mixed in - it's manic and explosive and the speech makes it really unsettling, like Ashley's Automatic Writing. [3 December 2003]


Date: 28 November 2003

Utopia - Ra

Label: Warner Bros. Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: ebay

Cost: $5.67

Got this in an ebay package with some good Rundgren albums; this shitty prog attempt was really forgettable so I quickly unloaded it.


Date: 28 November 2003

Michael Snow - The Last LP CD: Unique Last Recordings Of The Music Of Ancient Cultures

Label: Art Metropole

Format: CD

Source: Verges

Cost: $21.95

Gil played me this last time I was in New Haven, and I just had to track it down. Michael Snow creates a disc of fake ethnic music, presenting it with hilariously tongue in cheek liner notes that claim their authenticity. Gil is right- you really need the booklet to make this enjoyable, so it mostly succeeds as a conceptual art piece - though on it's own, some of the music is quite good (in that Renaldo and the Loaf kind of way). It's easy to accuse this joke as being disrespectful to the music of other cultures, but if anything I think it points out the unity of music throughout the world, and lampoons the seriousness in which ethonomusicologists often take themselves. [22 December 2003]


Date: 28 November 2003

Todd Rundgren - A Wizard, A True Star

Label: Castle Communications

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: ebay

Cost: $5.67

After one listen, I'm stunned at how this record has slipped under my radar for so long. Why this isn't mentioned when people talk about tripped-out, over the top psych records is beyond me. There's 28 songs, I think, and they jump between styles and production methods so haphazardly that it's nearly impossible to keep track of what you're listening to; but there are some moments of incredible genius. This might be the precursor to Guided by Voices, except produced very well (employing just about every studio trick imaginable). This particular ebayed copy is pretty worn out though - it has the nice die-cut cover, and there are only a few surface scratches, but the record just sounds beat, like it's been played too many times. And with so many short tracks running together, this might actually be a good candidate for CD purchase (though I hate to say it). Doug Mosurak says this is his all-time favorite album, and I can see why. It's truly the vision of a madman. [7 December 2003]


Date: 28 November 2003

Todd Rundgren - Something / Anything?

Label: Bearsville

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: ebay

Cost: $5.67

Todd Rundgren's third solo album is probably his masterpiece - ranging from perfect psychedelic pop to that Philly white-boy soul of which he is the master; to heavier, prog-influenced balladry and some tripped out jammy stuff. Each side of the album has it's own personality, and it takes a long time to get through the whole thing, yet the filler quotient is surprisingly low. This isn't as indulgent as Wizard so it might be more palatable for newbies - yet as I become more of a fan, I'm finding more and more to love about this weirdo. [7 December 2003]


Date: 5 December 2003

His Name is Alive - Brown Rice

Label: time STEREO

Format: CD-R

Source: Warn Defever

Cost: $10

I would never usually pay $10 for a cd-r, but Warn seemed so sarcastically earnest at the show, and I was sort of feeling sentimental, so I bought this. Wow. Instead of a tossed-off recorded practice (like many of their other cd-r/cassette releases are), this is a full 53 minutes of instrumental beauty. Warn said "There's a lot of harp on it" when I pressed him for a description, but there's also organs and drums and strings and saxophones. It's mellow, but not boring; it manages to capture the late night smoky feeling of their more recent stuff, though without the R+B influence. In a weird way, it reminds me of the last Coctails album, specifically some of the more pretty instrumental parts. And like the organ piece that ends that record, "Brown Rice" ends with a few minutes of low, pulsing drones. This should be given widespread release, because it's beautiful. [7 December 2003]


Date: 29 December 2003

Electric Light Orchestra - No Answer

Label: United Artists Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: The Attic

Cost: $0

ELO's first record is a big sprawling masterpiece of art-pop weirdness. It's hard not to love the sheer ambition of this - whether it's the heavy psychedelic cellos of the '10538 Overture' or the brutal 'Queen of the Hours'. Roy Wood's songwriting is also at a peak, and I believe he left after this one to make Boulders and do Wizzard, which is a shame, because this is like the Move's best ideas taken to a further level. The subsequent ELO records that I've heard are all pretty enjoyable but this is the one that most balances the differing predilections of these two songwriters. I used to have a second copy of this for some reason, but I think I gave it away. [17 September 2012]


Date: 29 December 2003

Sparks - No. 1 In Heaven

Label: Fame

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: The Attic

Cost: $3

Sparks go disco, and their parnership with Giorgie Moroeder is a fruitful one. The catchyness is still evident in "Number One in Heaven" and "Beat the Clock," and their quirkyness is evident in the production, which is actually quite, er, 'psychedelic' for disco. I don't know why I held off from buying this for so long - every track is great and the beat never stops; it's not a Sparks album to sing along to theatrically, but one to just party my ass off to. I'm such a fan now that I'm probably going to start buying their 80's records soon. [2 January 2004]


Date: 29 December 2003

Van Dyke Parks - Discover America

Label: Warner Bros. Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album Repress

Source: The Attic

Cost: $0

I think Discover America is one of those gems that comes from an artist drastically overreaching. Actually, Song Cycle is more ambitious, being of much larger instrumentation, insanely ambitious lyrics, and the whole all-in mentality to make a great psychedelic orchestral record, which, while it's certainly artistically successful beyond belief, it wasn't really commercially. Discover America changes course, overreaching in the way that Parks incorporates Caribbean and other non-white musical forms into his eclectic vision of American music - and I think every track is a cover, or a reinvention of an existing calpyso tune. There's steel drums galore on this record which is maybe why I like it so much - I love steel drums -  and they make for a different form of psychedelia, one that is as lyrically innovative as anything he ever did. Parks seems to be evaluating the conflicted sense of Americana in the early 70's, with the Vietnam war hanging over everything. Tracks like 'FDR in Trinidad' look at imperialism in a strange, celebratory way and theres a really unique, celebratory manner that makes it very bizarre despite the relative accessibility. Maybe I'm just a Van Dyke fan, I dunno. [28 July 2012]


Date: 29 December 2003

Trees - On The Shore

Label: Columbia

Format: CD Album

Source: The Attic

Cost: $12

This is a well-regarded relic from the era of British folk-rock, and in many ways Trees are a Fairport Convention knockoff with less fiddles and a bit more hard/country influence (listen to 'Little Sadie', which is practically American in tone, or the crunching 'Streets of Derry'). Despite the lack of originality in style, The Trees are pretty solid, particualrly the middle section of this CD. There's a tendency for noodly, meandering guitar leads that are also somewhat solos, while the band jams along - again, reminiscent of 'A Sailor's Life' by Fairport but with a languid feel and nice haunting reverb on Celia Humphris's voice.  'Murdoch' showcases her pipes most excellently, and the version of 'Sally Free and Easy' is epic, only to be followed by the album's best cuts, 'Fool' and 'Geordie'. I never got their other album but it's also been reissued, and both can be found easily on vinyl now, so I should make the upgrade. [30 July 2012]


Date: 30 December 2003

Double Leopards - Halve Maen

Label: Eclipse Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: Eclipse

Cost: $18.18

Dense, expanding drones. Murky, searing darkness. A mixture of Wolf Eyes and minimalism perhaps? It's not too far removed from their other record, but it's a lot more expansive and the double LP format gives them room to stretch out. And they've really established themselves with this one. It's hard to make it all the way through this in one sitting, as it's extremely dense (as I said before). I should have bought this months ago. [2 January 2004]


Date: 30 December 2003

Sun City Girls - Bleach Has Feelings, Too! / To Cover Up Your Right To Live

Label: Eclipse Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: Eclipse

Cost: $19.17

Two early cassettes reissued as part of Eclipse's SCG cassette reissue series.  Bleach Has Feelings, Too! begins with an amazing WTF concrÃ¨te collage, but gets dragged down a bit by the long porno piece at the end of side 1.  The flipside has some skittery middle-eastern rock, live radio goofyness, and some recordings of a Christian dialogue.  Overall it's pretty great apart from the porno.  The second record consists entirely of cover versions from early 80's live shows.  There's some brilliantly drunken moments, particularly 'Summertime Blues'; a lot of songs I don't recognize and side 2 in particular has some real freaked out Rick Bishop guitar work.  One of the better titles from this series I think... [16 Feb 2009]



Date: 30 December 2003

Jack Rose - Opium Musick

Label: Eclipse Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Eclipse

Cost: $15.17

Rose's second LP continues to show his exemplary technique, but features some guest musicians, shorter pieces, and additional instrumentation. The more esoteric influences are thus magnified, and it sounds more like what I thought a solo album from a member of Pelt would sound like. There isn't the same level of sadness that's found on the first one, but it's every bit as mesmerizing. Hopefully Bill's CD release of both albums will bring his music to a much larger audience. [2 January 2004]


Date: 31 December 2003

Sarah Gorby - Les Chants Du Ghetto

Label: Philips

Format: Vinyl

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $5

This should be a real downer trip - songs of the Jewish ghetto, subtitled 'Years of Despair', sung in Yiddish by Sarah Gorby. And while I wouldn't call it upbeat, there's an over-orchestration that takes away from the true misery. Heavily produced music can often amplify misery - Leonard Cohen's Death of a Lady's Man is a good example of that - but here, some of it actually sounds like Shirley Bassey. Even with songs like 'Your Mother Will Not Come Back' and 'Marching Toward Death', I can't get past the big, booming brass. This is packaged quite beautifully with a silkscreened cover and large booklet with lyrical translations in English, and it's a powerful, amazing document if you don't actually listen to the music. [20 December 2012]


Date: 13 January 2004

Volcano The Bear - The Idea Of Wood

Label: Textile Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Aaron Moore

Cost: $0

A new Volcano the Bear album is always a cause for celebration, but especially so with this one. Following the improvisation direction of 500 Boy Piano, the boys have created a record that relies less on vocals and more on instrumental interplay. There's a very pastoral, folky feel, and "Golden Hotbite" might be the most beautiful sounds they have ever put onto record. When the vocals do come in, as they do on the closer "The Mountains Among Us," their impact is grand. I know it's the first record I got this year, but so far it's album of the year. [16 January 2004]


Date: 2 February 2004

Mekons - Punk Rock

Label: Quarterstick Records

Format: CD

Source: Daron

Cost: $0

When I heard that the Mekons were re-recording their earliest songs, I thought it was a cop-out; a chance to recycle some early work and toss off a record without writing new material. But I'm pleasantly surprised; they've taken these old, anthemic stompers and infused the effects of 25 years of being Mekons into them. Some retain their youthful aggression, and others are arranged in the more recent style, like "What" which has accordion and xylophone. Some sound just like the originals, only recorded clearly and performed with more competence. What's the point? Perhaps it's a moment of self-reflection, like a writer looking back at his past for an autobiography. The blunt title suggests the many contortions of the word "punk" and what has happened in the past 25 years; the music shows that these old geezers from Leeds have retained some bit of their ethos. And while there's only two original members (Jon and Tom of course), the results of the Mekons experiments: failure, warped glory and a glimmer of sunlight through a veneer of cynicism - are evident in all eras of the band, so this ties them together nicely. [5 February 2004]


Date: 2 February 2004

Wind-Up Bird - Whips

Label: Translucence

Format: CD

Source: Daron

Cost: $0



Date: 3 February 2004

Tim Buckley - Sefronia

Label: Discreet

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

I probably shouldn't have bought this; this is Tim Buckley in his funk/soul style, sounding not unlike Al Green or someone of that ilk; the songwriting and arrangements are very unimaginative, and his voice (while still good) sounds empty. The musicians plod along with funky licks, jazzy riffs, and absolutely no imagination. The only bright moments are the two title tracks, but even these suffer when put up against any of the other records by him. I'm glad he tried different directions, but this work is not for me. [9 February 2004]


Date: 3 February 2004

Tim Buckley - Tim Buckley

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Buckley's first record is quite good, though he seems to be struggling to find his voice. On much of the record he ambles along like an American Van Morrision; his big, brassy voice is beautiful enough to carry some of the less memorable compositions. The jazzy influences of his mid-period work are absent, with some very baroque, dark pop songs (that remind me of David Ackles) nestled in with some more Burt Bacharachy numbers. "Understand Your Man" hints at the fire to come later, though it's nothing like Lorca. Jack Nitzche did the string arrangements, and Van Dyke Parks plays piano, which I would have never known if I hadn't read the liner notes. While this isn't a masterpiece, it's a very promising debut and hints at the genius to come later. [5 February 2004]


Date: 3 February 2004

Cabaret Voltaire - Red Mecca

Label: Rough Trade

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

This is early and good Cabaret Voltaire, a concept album about relgiion with a Christian side and an Islamic side. Lots of this feels at odds with its own tendencies; despite the bang and clatter of the percussion, the soft synth pads seem out of place. The chanted/shouted vocals are of the time, and lend an urgency to songs like 'A Thousand Ways'. This predates Savage Republic, or at least is of the same time, but I feel a real simliarity in this 1980's techno-primitivism. Chris Watson is the interesting figure with Cabaret Voltaire, the Martin Swope of the band, and he delivers some interesting textures on tracks like 'Spread the Virus' and 'Touch of Evil' - and this is the last album with him in the group. The songwriting, while ambitious in scope, is never anything I've clicked with - the production is really the key here. [9 November 2012]


Date: 3 February 2004

Crass - The Feeding of the 5000

Label: Crass

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Crass! I finally own a Crass record - the one I am most familiar with - yet sadly, "Asylum" is blank on this pressing, due to record pressing plant censorship. The rest of the record sounds great at 45 RPM; this is Crass at their fastest and angriest. Chris Strunk has talked about the philosophy of Crass, and I'm not familiar enough with their later work to really understand it, but as an intelligent yet uncompromising punk record, it really doesn't get any better than this. [6 February 2004]


Date: 3 February 2004

Tod Dockstader - Quatermass

Label: Owl Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

What a wonderful find! Dockstader's "organized sound" is remakably ahead of it's time, working in electronics and tape manipulations (as far as I can tell). His sounds are unusual, as he uses a balloon on one track with an oscillator to make a dark, warped soundscape. Other tracks are more active, with punchy beeps and bops that slice through the air. This sounds like Wolf Eyes, only more interesting, and in 1966. For further listening, certainly. [18 May 2004]


Date: 3 February 2004

Fire Engines, The Fire Engines - Lubricate Your Living Room

Label: Pop Aural

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Pretty warped Fire Engines EP that contains only one song that isn't on the German release I also have - should I sell this? It's weird I had the chance to see the Fire Engines and the Magic Band in Glasgow and I skipped it (but it was expensive). The warp makes this near-unlistenable (though oddly it doesn't appear to be that visually warped - perhaps it's some sort of mastering problem?). [8 Feb 2005]


Date: 3 February 2004

Ici La Bas

Label: Black Noise

Format: 12"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Not credited to the Homosexuals proper, this record has lurked in Ross's collection for twenty years, and I never noticed it before because it was filed under I. If it's credited to anyone, it's Les Croyables, though it is apparently the usual gang who made "Hearts in Exile" and all of that wonderful stuff. The six short songs on this EP could all be different artists; there's weird dubby excursions, brief yet slightly brilliant pop moments, and some more aggressive punk moments. For all of the hype these guys receive now, they definitely deserve it, because this is music that is unquestionably original and inspiring. [5 February 2004]


Date: 3 February 2004

Material - Memory Serves

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Skronky, Laswell-led prog made exciting by Billy Bang, Fred Frith and Henry Threadgill. It's a lengthy record, and with different musicians playing on different tracks, it doesn't really gel. But does any Material record really sound like a whole album? Laswell does a good job holding things together, as his bass provides the energy these tracks need to be compelling; but unlike, say, the Massacre album, this leaves more room for detours. There's a lot of synth on it too, but it works pretty well and never overpowers the musicianship. The violing playing is the highlight for me, though I don't know whether it's Bang or Frith. [22 February 2004]


Date: 3 February 2004

Moondog - 2

Label: Columbia

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Moondog's followup to the self-titled record is quite different. Instead of the vast orchestral scores, he showcases the stripped down rounds and madrigals that are found on his older albums.
