The voices are angelic, accompanied by flute, piano and something that sounds like a harpsichord. The booklet that comes with the record notates the melodies and has the lyrics, too, which is a really nice touch. I love Moondog's music so much because it is so open and beautiful - a true reflection of the most wonderful aspects of the natural world. The album ends with a beautiful instrumental, "Pastoral," a perfect coda to this work. [22 Jan 2005]


Date: 3 February 2004

Moondog - Moondog

Label: Columbia Masterworks

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

I had a really striking moment once while listening to this - it was driving home from the lake on Thanksgiving, maybe 2003, and I had this record on while driving up Route 7 in Ohio towards Steubenville. As we passed the steel factories and power plants along the river, there was a part of this record that was really dark and edgy, and the power plant was all lit up, glowing red like the flames of Mordor. My friend even said something about how it was the perfect soundtrack to the landscape, just for that moment. I don't know why this record gets a bad reputation among Moondog fans, because I think it's a successful experiment. [31 Dec 2005]


Date: 3 February 2004

Pere Ubu - New Picnic Time

Label: Chrysalis

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

It's always funny to hear something for the first time in years and realize how brilliant is it. This is a Pere Ubu record I often overlook, but it's quite rewarding with a a dedicated listen. David Thomas doesn't start to creep in his Jehovah's Witnecism til the end, and it's not even that bad. The album has some really scattered rocking songs, reminding me of the Red Krayola "Wives in Orbit/Yik-Yak" single, only with more wild vocal yelping. There's also some more quiet pieces, with some good attention to detail yet not overdoing it, so the confusion/stupid vibe of the record remains throughout. Vocals are also layered at times, with sung/spoken/yelped passages throughout. People talk about New Weird America but does anyone remember Old Weird America? [22 Jan 2005]


Date: 3 February 2004

Poison Girls - Hex

Label: Crass Records

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

The Poison Girls' first record lacks some of the stranger characteristics of their later work, but none of the fury. The primarily gender/sexuality-themed songs explode from the voice of Vi Subversa, which sounds like a nasty pack of snarling dogs. Her gruff delivery adds to the gender confusion. Musically, her backing band (led by guitarist Richard Famous) relies on jagged, but somewhat dancy rhythms. It's oddly closer to Gang of Four than Crass, though I've never really associated the two bands before. Though it's only EP-length, the record is pretty satisfying. [8 Feb 2005]


Date: 3 February 2004

Public Image Limited - Nubes

Label: The Impossible Recordworks

Format: Vinyl Unofficial Release LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

A bootleg LP on the same label that did the Eno Floating in Sequence bootleg, this bears considerably worse sound quality, coming from an audience recording of PIL on their first tour. The material sounds good, with "Annalise" and "Religion" being especially venmous - there's also a version of "Belsen is a Gas" which makes me wonder if they did other Sex Pistols songs then. PIL is a group who sounds best recorded, so this bootleg is hardly a necessary document of them, but it's a neat curiousity piece for fans (and since I stupidly sold the first album a few years ago, I have some of these songs now). [9 February 2004]


Date: 3 February 2004

Tim Buckley - Lorca

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Lorca is the beginning of Tim Buckley's plunge into the avant-garde, and side one announces this with glory. The two lengthy tracks were hinted at on Happy Sad, but they were nowhere near this fucked up. A rumbling demon haunts this side of the record, more akin to Scott Walker's later work than anything else I could easily compare it to; it perfectly suits Buckley's voice. Side two is a little bit more conventional, but still pretty great - it swings like his last few records but doesn't fall into the soul-rock mire of what came later. This is a great bridge between Happy Sad and Starsailor and totally essential. [9 February 2004]


Date: 3 February 2004

Tim Buckley - Blue Afternoon

Label: Straight

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

This is probably the Tim Buckley album I know the least (not counting post-Starsailor)... oh wait, I've actually never listened to Goodbye and Hello ... anyway, this is a really awesome record that has a similar sound to Happy Sad.  The songs are a melancholy, and they slowly unfold with a rambling guitar strum and the nicest accents by the vibes.  'The River' and 'Chase the Blues Away' are great, soulful tunes; the bass playing at times reminds me a ton of Astral Weeks except with a darker, American approach.  Unfortunately this is a cheaply-pressed promo copy that has a ton of surface noise that must be dirt deep in the grooves (as the record itself looks prety clean); it's a bit distracting because there's actually so much noise you can't hear all the instruments ringing out like they should.  Side two has the most conventional song, 'Blue Melody', followed by the long 'The Train', which is definitely the predecessor to Lorca and Starsailor.  The crazy free-jazz guitar solo that Lee Underwood drops is a pretty strong statement of direction - it hints at what is to come while anchoring the soulful moan of Buckley's song.  [17 Feb 2009]



Date: 3 February 2004

Arti e Mestieri - Tilt

Label: Cramps

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Somewhat more interesting than their second album, but this is still far from being a worthwhile record to keep on an already-crowded record shelf. You'll hear synths, jazzy drums, tricky guitar lines, and little else. There's not even a deranged element to qualify it for the curiosity pile. [31 Dec 2005]


Date: 3 February 2004

Arti e Mestieri - Qunto Stato

Label: Cramps

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Very bland jazz-rock that doesn't adventure even as far as their first album (which isn't all that adventurous itself). Some parts of this honestly reminded me of Wham or David Sanborn. While Arti e Mestieri are a second-rate Italian progressive group, this is a third rate record by a second-rate artist, and 2x3=6 so that makes it sixth-rate. Why did Cramps even put this out? [9 February 2004]


Date: 3 February 2004

Red Krayola - God Bless The Red Krayola And All Who Sail With It

Label: Charly Records Ltd.

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Over the years I've listened to this many times, and it's "deconstruction" now seems commonplace. Songs like "Victory Garden" are actually quite pretty in that strained, Mayo Thompson sort of way. I really love something about his approach, which comes off as really fucked up but genuine at the same time. This can probably be described as "anti-music" or something, but I just think it's really fun and it's become a classic for me. [31 Dec 2005]


Date: 3 February 2004

V/A - Jubilee OST

Label: Polydor

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

This was a fun pickup but I almost never play it, which is a shame cause 'Paranoia Paradise' by Wayne Country and the Electric Chairs is such a killer song. The Adam and the Ants songs are pretty great too, and side two changes things up with Suzi Pinns's brilliantly annoying (yet strangely iconic, as it's all I really remember from the film except for Jenny Runacre being insanely hot) cover of 'Rule Britannia' and some mellow Eno jams. This is still one of the only Derek Jarman films I've ever seen, and it's weird that people don't talk about it much these days. [18 December 2012]


Date: 3 February 2004

Arbete Och Fritid - Se Upp För Livet

Label: MNW

Format: Vinyl Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

This is probably one of my most treasured LPs because it's a truly great collection of music that is near-impossible to find on vinyl.  Side one sets the pace, opening with an incredible 16 minute jam, building up from silence into a spacey emergency.  The record, while long, contains such a variety of music - there is weird Swedish music hall folk tunes (perhaps traditionals), strange synth-driven sci-fi soundtracks, guitar-heavy thrashers and introspective folk-rock dirges.  The record is also packaged with a big booklet full of lyrics and drawings.  It's a bit all over the place (and a bit long), but this is Arbete and Fritid's major statement.  I worry that if I could understand the lyrics they'd be stupid and I'd never want to hear this again (as the vocals are on just about every track).. I know enough Swedish just from living here that I know the title means "Look out for life!" (as if life was dangerous).  [17 Feb 2009]



Date: 3 February 2004

Au Pairs - Playing With A Different Sex

Label: Human Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

The Au Pairs are one of those bands who I've always enjoyed, and this is certainly a good record, but it's not groundbreaking. Listening to it right after Pere Ubu, it just sort of feels limp. The guitars are scratchy in a good way, and it fits right in with a lot of other things of the period. There's enough of a dancy feel to carry off a slight Gang of Four vibe, though the songwriting seems to be a bit less overtly political. Maybe this isn't quite a 'classic' but it's good. [22 Jan 2005]


Date: 3 February 2004

Achim Reichel - AR 3

Label: Zebra

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

This first Achim Reichel album smokes - it's a wonderland for weird guitar fans, as his style is so jittery and active that it's really hard to compare him to anyone else. There's a decent band behind him too - backing up his echoey electric guitar with acoustic strum, exploratory bass playing, and great drumming/percussion. The vocals are sung in English and have a raw 70's feel; it's not a terrible sound at all and one that probably grows with time, though I tend to tune them out and just feel the rhythms building up. It's a very contained style of jamming, often leaving the deep drones to organs or other background instrumentations and letting the guitar drive it; it's not unlike soul music, as these Germans are pretty funky. As a one-time scholar of the delay/looping pedal, I have to find a lot to love here. [27 November 2012]


Date: 3 February 2004

V/A - Urgh! A Music War OST

Label: A&M

Format: 2xLP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

As it says, this is the soundtrack to Urgh! A Music War which is a concert video of a bunch of post-punk and new wave bands. The big name was the Police but there are a few gems here - Magazine, Gang of Four, Klaus Nomi, Devo, Gary Numan. I thought this would be a great thing to have but actually I find it a bit dull to listen to, though maybe I remember the film more fondly than I should. There's a great J-Church lyric in 'Tide of Fate': "Fast-forward the VCR to the better parts of Urgh! A Music War", which is basically what I do when I listen to this. The visuals make it; I haven't seen the film in years but I remember Gang of Four's 'He'd Send In the Army' being pretty amazing at the time. Now it's just a relic I can probably live without. [18 November 2012]


Date: 3 February 2004

Achim Reichel - A.R. IV

Label: Zebra

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Achim Reichel has a bunch of people jamming with him here; 'The two side-long compositions are light, flowing progressive rock with jazz inflections. The vocals are by Reichel, I guess, though he is only credited with 'echo guitar' and that's certainly what you hear - a sliding and elusive playing that is mind-expanding at times. Reichel's music has something highly futuristic, yet organic - it reminds me a little bit of Magma, but I'm not sure why. I've always thought of this as heavily 'out' music, but its direct and accessible. The second side has a cleaner guitar tone, but it's stopp loopy and layered, with the recorder and bass-recorder floating all over the place. The intersections of the hard and soft melodic lines makes a latticework of sound here, which actually is a similar feeling that a lot of late 90s/early 00s "post-rock" does. And this is cleary pre-post rock anyway. [12 November 2012]


Date: 14 February 2004

Volcano The Bear - All The Paint I Can Breathe

Label: Beta-lactam Ring Records

Format: Vinyl 10"

Source: Beta-Lactam

Cost: $0

This oft-forgotten VtB release is material from their earliest recordings, and it displays a much more ramshackle band trying to find their voice.  The low-fi recording quality is really extreme on this record - sibilance just rolls off the surface of the vinyl and it caused me to actually adjust my treble EQ to make it more listenable.  Behind all the tape hiss is a mess of collages, weird voices, and acoustic instruments lunged at primitively.  The second side has some repetetive rock band moments, though much closer to a weird lounge/jazz band than the This Heat-isms of their later work.  Overall this is a million miles away from the concentrated, focused efforts heard on records like The Idea of Wood, yet I enjoyed this far more than I remembered.  [17 Feb 2009]



Date: 21 February 2004

Mountain Goats - We Shall All Be Healed

Label: 4AD

Format: CD Album

Source: Daron

Cost: $0

A new Mountain Goats album, and one produced by John Vanderslice. And what production it is - lush, but not overly done, with arrangements that perfectly suit Darnielle's tunes. The single, "Palmcorder Yajna", is a glorious tune that's driven by a straight, driving beat. I listened to it a million times this summer. The rest of the album continues the same themes he's written about in 3,000 other songs, only with a bit more energy. I think it's a definite improvement over "Talahassee," showing that he is finding his groove in the big studio/4AD scene and continuing to do what he does best, with little variation. The final track, "Pigs That Ran..." is sure to be an anthemic live number for years to come. Keep pumping it out Darnielle, cause I'll keep sucking it up. [22 Jan 2005]


Date: 21 February 2004

One Ensemble Of Daniel Padden - The Owl Of Fives

Label: Textile Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Daniel

Cost: $0

Daniel's second album continues the "sound world" that he inhabits, as first presented on his self-titled disc. A more medieval, Third Ear Band feel is present in this music and a bit less of the quirks that make the first album so charming. There's a tendency towards space that I really appreciate, and some of the melodies are familiar from the live lineup I saw last summer. Agent Preest picked this as his album of the year, and while I probably wouldn't go that far I think it's a good step for Daniel and I'm excited to hear what comes next. [22 Jan 2005]


Date: 28 February 2004

Harry Partch - Enclosure Five

Label: Innova Recordings

Format: 3xCD

Source: Shake It

Cost: $0

This is a mammoth collection to have - three very long Partch pieces, including my favorite, The Bewitched (though this is a different recording than the other one which was on, I think, Tzadik, and this one has more percussion and I maybe don't like it as much). There's a lot of vocals on the King Oedipus material which is split over two discs, and sometimes I long for the more resonant clanging of Delusion of the Fury - but this is still groundbreaking, original American music. I feel very inspired by Partch, even though there's not a ton here that I connect to on an emotional level, more because I feel this is such uniquely uncompromising work that manages to push forth the definition of music while simultaneously being expressive, personal, and wonderful to bathe the ears in. [28 December 2012]


Date: 5 March 2004

Nagoski, Ian - Effortless Battle

Label: Recorded

Format: CD

Source: Ian

Cost: $0

Two Nagoski compositions, released in 2003. 'Effortless Battle' is a half-hour work of very bassy drones, the kind that actually rattle windows when being listened to. I can only imagine how great this low end would sound on vinyl. This is a piece that would actually probably irritate my neighbours, if I had any. As it builds, higher tones come in that swirl and swirl, becoming quite beuatiful, if disorientating. 'Ripped Steam Hinterland' fills out the disc, 15 minutes of subtly changing drone played on one of Dan Conrad's homemade instruments, though if you told me it was just general oscillators, I wouldn't really know the difference. It's been 9 years probably since I last listened to this, since I rarely listen to minimal and droney stuff, but I should more because this is impressive. [14 July 2012]


Date: 18 March 2004

Badholes - s/t

Label: Rampart

Format: cassette

Source: Trevor

Cost: $0

Trevor's solo cassette - I *THINK* this is Trevor - is very dark and rumbly - showing none of his quirky pop ideas. It's also fairly lengthy, and rather monotonous in it's mess. It's recorded in a graveyard, so perhaps this adds to it's evil nature. I don't know what the source material is, but the lo-fi aspect of the recording fits the genre well. [21 March 2004]


Date: 18 March 2004

3 Legged Race - Glowing Order

Label: Mountaain

Format: cassette

Source: Robert

Cost: $0

Robert's solo cassette is really a cassingle - a five minute burst of 3LR that is far different from the live set I saw a few week ago. This has ringing overtones, suggesting Eastern religious music, along with bells and some electronics. It's placid, exploratory, and unfortunately too brief. It's weird to hear music like this recorded and presented in such a lo-fi manner, but that is somewhat it's charm. [21 March 2004]


Date: 18 March 2004

Burning Star Core - The Static That You Hear Is The Rain (1999-2004)

Label: Dronedisco

Format: 2xcassette

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

This is buried among the zillion releases Spencer emitted around this time, but it's actually a pretty important one, as it presents a series of live BxC performances over a 5 year period in Cincinnati. The liner notes are quite clear in spelling out background information about the performers and venues, and it makes me a bit sad cause I'm nostalgic for this more simple time (even though I was a few hours away only following Spencer's work through occasional visits). The 1999 recordings are the most interesting to hear now, as they show a rambunctious electronic/computer side that seems miles away from what was to follow. The band with Lesniak and Rich in 2002 (opening up for Arco Flute Foundation, Keenan Lawler and Charalambides, oh my!) is about the time that I checked in to the CSY/BxC story. And then, things gel on the second tape with Robert, Trevor and Mike Shiflet being part of BxC, though to be honest, which is continued (and all together as a quartet) on some further releases. The electronic-drenched crescendos are often blistering, with howling vocal outbursts and percussion struggling to hold it all together. The crowd noise, often indicating just how small these crowds are, adds to everything -- and there's a real curiosity at play for both artists and listener. [31 December 2012]


Date: 18 March 2004

Walter Carson - s/t

Label: Rampart

Format: cassette

Source: Darryl

Cost: $0

Four people show up at my house at 3 AM, and each one gives me a cassette of their material. Darryl's is a lot different than what I saw live - instead of punchy percussive electronics, it's more stretched out and thick. A weird, malevolent spell is cast by the music, and it retains it's composure throughout. Brief, the way it should be. [21 March 2004]


Date: 29 March 2004

Alexander Neilson & Richard Youngs - Ourselves

Label: VHF

Format: CD

Source: VHF

Cost: $0

So glad to see this finally available!!! [2004] This was Richard and Alex's first record together, which I first heard when Alex mailed it to me in Pittsburgh before I had ever met either of these guys. In some ways, this is an exploration of what the two could do upon a first meeting. Alex sticks primarily to percussion and Richard layers on electronics, keyboards, and everything else. Alex rides the toms which are recorded with some reverb yet still sound tinny at points, and the smooth waves of synth that ride over top, especially on the lengthy 'Mexico', are supported by thick, psychedelic layers and with their voices that work together well. 'God Bless the Master' is a traditional song that comes out of 'Mexico's ambience and brings their interest in folk to a beautiful summation. [28 December 2012]


Date: 2 July 2004

Hughes + Todd - Sing the Hits from their TV Series

Label: Memoirs of an Aesthete

Format: CDR

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0



Date: 2 July 2004

Ashtray Navigations - Heavy Flow Traffice of Blind Faith

Label: Memoirs of an Aesthete

Format: CDR

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0



Date: 2 July 2004

Mystery Water Saloon Boys - Shall We Be Ruled By One Peeled Scurvy Priest?- We Will Ring!

Label: Memoirs of an Aesthete

Format: CDR

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0

Phil gave me this when I met him, and thanks to this log I can see that I met Phil Todd on 2 July 2004. Which really reminds me, I should send him an email and see how he's doing. I think this is Phil and Chris Hladowski. The opening track sounds like it - it's a harmonium or organ drone over which a solo instrument, possibly Chris's bouzouki, amplified, noodles around. Dark psych, indeed, from some dark psyches. 'Pitch! Beat Box Two' is built over a rhythm loop, a bit of a groovy jam but slightly nervous the whole time. The two show a real balance of playing off each other, which gets bluesy at points but stays focused.This melodic noodling continues into the fourth track, but it's a nice change from the usual onslaught of static, dirt and noise that is Ashtray Navigations. [30 December 2012]


Date: 2 July 2004

Ashtray Navigations - sssnares

Label: Memoirs of an Aesthete

Format: CDR

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0



Date: 4 August 2004

V/A - The Invisible Insurrection Of A Million Minds

Label: Shadazz

Format: CD

Source: Luke Fowler

Cost: £0



Date: 4 August 2004

Fowler/Neilson/Phizmiz - Shorn off his Nipples He Dances

Label: none

Format: CDR

Source: Luke Fowler

Cost: £0



Date: 15 August 2004

Kinks - The Kinks Are The Village Green Preservation Society (Special Deluxe Edition)

Label: Sanctuary Records

Format: 3xCD

Source: Monorail

It's been six months since I last bought a record. What is out there that could make me break from this self-imposed celibacy? Anyone who knows me knows how important this album is to me, and the promise of an extra CD of bonus tracks was too much too pass up. Sure, I already own the Castle reissue which has most of discs 1 and 2, but the lure of disc 3 (and low price) made me buy it. But in looking through the sleeve notes, the first two discs have a few gems I didn't previously own, even if it's as minor as the mono mix of "Berkeley Mews". Speaking of which, "Berkeley Mews" is now linked to this album so I can sing that too on road trips. But disc 3 - the reason for buying this - does not disappoint. As early as track 2, the brilliant (and unheard) "Misty Water" - I am a happy man. "Lavender Hill" and "Where Did my Spring Go?" are also completely incredible - and now I will always wonder how I ever truly loved this album before this reissue. [14 August 2004]


Date: 22 August 2004

Arctic Circle 

Label: none

Format: CDR

Source: Matt?

Cost: £0

Received as demo while drunk at a campfire.


Date: 2 September 2004

Homosexuals - Astral Glamour

Label: Hyped2Death

Format: 3xCD

Source: Aquarius Records

Cost: $0

I never thought this would see the light of day, but thank God it did. This has just about everything you'd ever want from the Homosexuals, and a spattering of other stuff. If the entire collection were released it would be too much because some of the minor projects are irrelevant. Thankfully the Milk from Cheltenham LP has been re-released since this came out, and eventually everything on It's War, Boys is supposed to see the light of day. This is definitely the most exciting, adventurous side of punk rock to capture my imagination in years. [31 Dec 2005]


Date: 10 September 2004

Ghost - Hypnotic Underworld

Label: Drag City

Format: CD Album

Source: Justin Hopper

Cost: $0



Date: 10 September 2004

Six Organs Of Admittance - Compathia

Label: Holy Mountain

Format: CD

Source: Justin Hopper

Cost: $0

This Six Organs of Admittance record is definitely more "pop" oriented than his other releases, but it still maintains a smoky atmosphere throughout. The bigger emphasis on vocals isn't necessarily bad, for the songs that work work well. A few songs drag on, however, and the mystery of the earlier albums is overall diminished. I can't fault someone for attempting new things, but I don't know if this is a record I'll go back to frequently. [16 Sep 2004]


Date: 26 September 2004

Phizmiz, Ergo and Irene Moon - Pangolin Variations

Label: none

Format: CD

Source: Irene

Cost: $0

Sadly this seems to be heavier on the Ergo Phizmiz side than Irene's - Irene basically does some remixing and processing to Ergo's work. Actually, Ergo's stuff is brilliant - reminding me of Aksak Maboul and even that weird Algerian record I love so much. There's a lot of movement to this music, and that's perhaps why it's so enjoyable.... [20 Oct 2004]


Date: 26 September 2004

Ortho / Irene Moon - Split

Label: Ignivomous

Format: Vinyl 7" Picture Disc

Source: Irene

Cost: $0

The Ortho side of this sounds like static, hiss, and dust on my stylus, massaged into waves of cascading sound. It's very minimal and I like how even when you turn it up loud it sounds distant. No idea what speed to play it at. Irene's side is actually Auk Theatre, the dentist piece I saw so many times back when we lived together. It's a great work of visual theatre but it also translates to the audio-only realm well, mostly because of the time and care Irene put into the soundtrack. The dentist drill dominates and there's also nice Americana/television samples, some spoken bits, and the creeping dread at the end. And on a lovely picture disc too. [6 December 2012]


Date: 26 September 2004

Irene Moon - Excerpts from Field Station A

Label: none

Format: 10"

Source: Irene

Cost: $0



Date: 1 October 2004

Hair Police - Obedience Cuts

Label: Gods Of Tundra

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Robert

Cost: $0

This felt like a landmark at the time, and maybe a turning point for Hair Police. Listening now, it's like a compendium of techniques and ideas for broken, anti-everything music. There's a lot of pulsing electronics, fizzing static hiss, guitar noise, and formless screaming and what you'd expect. But there's also some extremely sparse, quiet, minimal bits, particularly on side two. It's an unpleasant listen, which is the idea, but it's not as stark and distant as the later releases like Drawn Dead or Constantly Terrified - meaning I actually think of this as 'accessible'. [20 November 2012]


Date: 13 October 2004

Inecto School - Wrangthorn

Label: 

Format: CD-R

Source: Stewart Morgan

Cost: £0

Thanks Stewart!!!! This album seems to be culled from live appearances. Any disc of improv is going to have it's ups and downs, but the highs are exciting at times. Stewart's guitar proficiency really shines and when the fidelity is there, the upright bass sounds great. Nice packaging, and wisely kept to "classic album length". I'd like to see more by these guys but I guess it's somewhat part-time now that Stewart's moved to Glasgow... [20 Oct 2004]


Date: 26 October 2004

Pavement - Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain: LA's Desert Origins

Label: Matador

Format: 2xCD

Source: CD Central

Cost: $0

It's weird buying a 10 year anniversary edition of an album I listened to in high school. It makes me feel old. This is not as necessary as last year's Slanted and Enchanted reissue but still great. And there's actually a ton of stuff I've never heard before on here, while the S&E reissue had only one new song. Most of the new songs are obscure for a reason, with Malkmus seemingly improvising lyrics as he goes along, but there are a few gems. The demo "Heaven is a Truck" i actually prefer to the one on the album. I've never owned this album before as it's not one of my favorite Pavement releases, but it's good to replace the ol' TDK tape that Nick made me in 1995. [27 Oct 2004]


Date: 22 November 2004

Microwaves - Attack Decay Sustain Release

Label: New Addition

Format: CD Album

Source: Dave Kuzy

Cost: $0



Date: 22 December 2004

Guided By Voices - Bee Thousand (The Director's Cut)

Label: Scat Records

Format: 3xVinyl LP

Source: Scat Records

Cost: $0

Bee Thousand is one of the greatest records in my life, and certainly my late-adolecence; at the period they made it, Pollard and GbV were at an absolutely brilliant pinnacle, where they just continually manufactured genius tune after genius tune. This collection puts it all together, and while at first listen I was a bit bummed, I just realized that the sequence is completely part of the brilliance of this album. Here in a new form, it's something else - a longer glimpse into Pollard's mind at the time. There's a good mix of old EP/B-side tracks and unreleased songs (or songs at least new to me). Most are worthwhile, and it's great to have gems like "Indian Was an Angel" on vinyl finally, as well as "Postal Blowfish," "Break Even," and "Do the Earth". I feel that the two finest records of my indie rock upbringing, Slanted and Enchanted and Bee Thousand, now have been given the expanded reissues they deserve. I'm not getting rid of my original Bee Thousand vinyl any time soon but thanks to Scat for making this release happen!


Date: 25 December 2004

Albert Ayler - Holy Ghost

Label: Revenant

Format: 10xCDBox Set

Source: Mom and Dad / Santa

Cost: $0

I just realised that this isn't listed, probably because it got lost in the end-of-year shuffle in late 2004.  I received this for Christmas from my parents.


Date: 5 January 2005

Es - Kaikkeuden Kauneus Ja Käsittämättömyys

Label: Fonal Records

Format: CD Album

Source: K-RAA-K

Cost: $0

Another interesting bit of new music from Finland, Es is somehow related to Killa but I'm not exactly sure how as I can't read Finnish. Some parts of this album are dense and droney, with spoken and chanted vocals buried in layers of darkness. Organ is quite prevalent, and some processed female vocals are also nice in parts. It becomes quite heavy at some points, and in a very Scandinavian way the music remains somber at all times. I can't really think of anything to compare this to, though it might appeal to fans of Labradford and early Kranky roster material. [27 Mar 2005]


Date: 5 January 2005

Kiila - Silmät Sulkaset

Label: (K-RAA-K)³

Format: CD

Source: K-RAA-K

Cost: $0

K--RAA-K was nice enough to trade releases and I am very happy with what they chose. Killa is more Finnish psychedelia, though this has a more formal, accessible style to it. There's a tapestry of extravagant timbres and the tendency more towards beauty than dissonance. [23 Jan 2005]


Date: 6 January 2005

Irene Moon - For the Neonate

Label: Begonia Society

Format: 10"

Source: Irene

Cost: $0

Irene presents four tracks, one solo and 3 of assorted projects. "For the Neonate" is a work of musique concrete featuring Irene's creepy voice and some beluga whale calls. "De Mo" is an Ergo Phizmiz piece using Irene's source material, and it works in a beat-oriented motif while sounding really fucked up and weird. The Sick Hour track is the most fucked up sounding piece on here, and one of the most unusual recordings I've heard from any of the participants. The Auk track works well with the whole, though I do miss the visuals. Overall this is probably the best work Irene has ever done, and I hope it gets heard by the audience it deserves. [13 May 2005]


Date: 14 January 2005

Jason Zeh/Leslie Keffer - Ghosts and Glaciers

Label: Eyewish Arts

Format: cassette

Source: Jason Zeh

Cost: $0

Leslie's side is a live performance from my very own house, only before I lived here. Jason's is put together from various unfinished fragmented pieces. Both sides are very lo-fi, focused around staticy drone. It sounds like Leslie was using a cord with no instrument as input, while Jason is a bit more manipulative with some sudden movement in his side. The two sides compliment each other well and I wouldn't doubt that they were actually the work of one person if told that. [16 Mar 2005]


Date: 29 January 2005

Franciscan Hobbies - Walls Are Stuck

Label: Music Fellowship

Format: CD Album

Source: Daron

Cost: $0

There's a gentleness to the music but it doesn't descend into new age stiffness; perhaps this is because the rough edges are so essential to the Jeweled Antler identity. When there's vocals, they're subdued, more part of the atmosphere than part of a traditional song structure. The disc passes quickly, assimilating into the back of my mind like a great ambient record, though there are layers for deeper study Maybe not my favorite Jeweled Antler band, but what does it matter since they're all the same anyway? [5 Feb 2005]


Date: 29 January 2005

1 Mile North/Wind-up Bird/Colophon - Conduction. Convection. Radiation.

Label: Music Fellowship

Format: CD

Source: Daron

Cost: $0

One of the Tryptych series of 3-way split CDs Music Fellowship was putting out a half-decade ago. The three artists here fit together well as all three make pleasant, calm instrumental music. I wouldn't call it ambient, as Wind-up Bird's tracks have a propelling pulse that demands attention. I'm not wildly excited by anything on here apart from maybe Colophon's more static-drenched cuts; it's all a bit too easy-listening post-rock for me. But this is far too "nice" to really complain about. I was supposed to have an Oakwhistle track on one of these CDs but I guess the series has ended. Maybe I should get that track out somewhere cause it was a good one. [21 December 2012]


Date: 4 February 2005

Iovae - Quatervois

Label: Zarek

Format: CD

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

Spencer's released a lot of things on DroneDisco over the years, but this Iovae release stands out among the non-CSY titles. Ron made this in 2001 and I got a copy just around the time I was first getting to know Spencer; apparently, the German label Zarek was as impressed as I was and they decided to reissue it just a few years later. Quatervois is an incredible work of solo electronics, and it's been a long time since I've listened to it, and it was nothing like I remembered. I remembered slow, expanding deep drones in a Soliloquy for Lilith way, but instead it's a much more varied bit of rumbling, static, and carefully compiled layers of his and oscillators. The third track has a subterranean rhythm that is built around a Linn Drum Machine, but completely subverts the machine's capabilities. Track 4 explicitly uses morse code transmissions, and the final track works with machine guns from Fort Knox. It's much closer to the deep listening sound art of Lee Patterson of what Luke's mostly into, than Spencer's brand of chaos and juxtaposition. I wonder what Ron has been doing - it's been ages since I've seen him and I hope he is still making great work. [29 July 2012]


Date: 5 February 2005

Red Krayola - Malefactor, Ade

Label: Drag City

Format: CD Album

Source: Shake it

Cost: $7.99

An oddball, 80s Red Krayola - even oddball by RK terms, with some digital sound effects dressing the songs, and maybe the first presene of Albert Oehlen in the band? Malefacor, Ade has a few fucked lyrical forays ('Steve McQueen's Garden' is genius, as Mayo just has a knack for songs with 'Garden' in the title), a bizarro tape-manipulation work that stands up among any masterpiece of musique concrete ('t.b.-- trissues') and the dub/indie art-rock of 'Colour Theory no. 3', simultaneously bridging the Rough Trade sound of Kangaroo? with the great Drag City revitalisation just around the corner. I never think to pull this out when I listen to RK stuff but it's a gem for sure. [9 October 2012]


Date: 5 February 2005

Leonard Cohen - Recent Songs

Label: Columbia

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Shake It

Cost: $5.99

This Leonard Cohen record took some time to grow on me - after the artistic infallibility of his first four albums, it's impossible not to perceive this as a step backwards. His slow slide towards mediocrity certainly begins here, as there are some throwaway songs, questionable arrangements and halfhearted lyrics. Still, the spooky acoustic pallor of Songs of Love and Hate is present (not dissolving completely into genre exercises like his later records) and "The Guests" is an awesome way to start the album. [24 Aug 2005]


Date: 5 February 2005

John Vanderslice - Cellar Door

Label: Post-Parlo

Format: LP

Source: Shake It

Cost: $12.99

One of my favorite records of last year - this album surprised me because I didn't think this type of thing would appeal to me anymore. Vanderslice's characters are somewhat desperate, and maybe a bit overdone, but there's still something I'm able to connect to on almost every track. The production is brilliant and the melodies remain hung in my brain, becoming irresistable after awhile. And on vinyl, it sounds incredible. [9 Feb 2005]


Date: 14 February 2005

James "Twig" Harper - Intuitive American Esoteric vol 1

Label: Ignivomous, others

Format: LP

Source: Kyle Lapidus

Cost: $0

Among the various records I might own in the 'noise' genre, there's few that I would play to someone with conventional musical taste to make an argument for less ear-friendly sounds. But Intuitive American Estoteric vol 1 is a goddam masterpiece, a landmark accomplishment of music that will hopefully one day be celebrated for the work that it is. I never got much from Nautical Almanac and even met the guy once and barely remember him, but this release blew my mind when I picked it up. But this release has so much personality - it actually achieves a level of human expression through the most abrasive sounds possible, and it does this through a mastery of construction and form. The second side is full of weird locked grooves and bizarre mastering techniques and my copy is even a bit warped, but it doesn't make a lick of difference because there's so much energy and emotion here that it transcends mere pitch differences. I also have volume 2 which I don't know as intimately, and I see there's a volume 3 which I might have to track down. I'd file this alongside John Wiese's Soft Punk for something that I'd have to label as 'noise' but is so accomplished and transcendant that there's really not much else I can even say here. [30 July 2012]


Date: 14 February 2005

MC Trachiotomy/Occasional Detroit - split

Label: Ignivomous

Format: LP

Source: Kyle Lapidus

Cost: $0

You can trust Kyle Lapidus to release the weirdest of the weird. The brilliantly named MC Trachiotomy actually does resemble hip-hop in a small way, though not in a way that's likely to make them fans in that scene. The side-long exploration of voice and rhythm (that's the best term I can come up with) begins sounding like Dr. John growling cajun syllables through a bit of waxed paper, over which a rhythmic beat threatens to rip itself apart continually. It gets weirder as it goes along, and it's chaotic without being abrasive or noisy, thus making it a genuinely fascinating listen. I tune out the words, which are more a percussive element, though there is definite hip-hop intonations at play. Ending on a locked groove, it rewards those with short attention spans. Occasional Detroit, on the flip, is a different beast entirely. It's as much of a deconstruction of techno and dance music as MC Trachiotomy was to rap; it's skittery, breakcore-style beats come in light flurries, and the futurist textures assemble into a barrage of (somewhat irritating) acts of aggression. [17 December 2012]


Date: 14 February 2005

Sukora - Oeo

Label: Ignivomous

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Kyle Lapidus

Cost: $0

This is one of the most minimal things I have ever heard. Parts of side A sound like nothing besides surface noise - the sound of a cheap stylus sliding in a groove. The more "active" parts are dark drones that are slightly distorted, but sounding more like a shortwave radio that needs to have the tuner cleaned. This rivals Bernhard Gunter for minimalist. It's Japanese too. [13 May 2005]


Date: 14 February 2005

Unconditional Loathing - Cornholecopia

Label: Ignivumous, others

Format: CD

Source: Kyle Lapidus

Cost: $0



Date: 17 February 2005

Wiese, John - Arrhytmia Wave Burst and Panner Crash

Label: Helicopter

Format: 3" CD

Source: John Wiese

Cost: $0

John Wiese works in a very harsh, somewhat dissonant form that bears a resemblence to more "traditional" Japanese-style harsh noise. The music on this disc changes quickly, with very distorted electronic sources filtered into a wall of dense sound, though it's quite active. It feels like it's mostly computer-generated, though that may be because I saw him using a laptop live. [2 Mar 2005]


Date: 17 February 2005

Wiese, John - Magical Crystal Blah vol. 2

Label: Helicopter

Format: CD

Source: John Wiese

Cost: $0



Date: 12 March 2005

Faust - The Faust Tapes

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

The Faust Tapes is something I've listened to a zillion times and it's hard to actually write anything about it that wouldn't be repeating something said before, or more likely, repeating something else I said about the tons of records influenced by it. I used to own this on CD which had the whole thing sequenced as 1 or 2 tracks, so you can't skip around to the bits you like, which is precisely the way it should be done. On vinyl you have a bit more freedom to pick and choose but this is famous for it's collage-like nature, so it's most enjoyable as one big trip. The real reason this should be so acclaimed is not because it's a big collage, but because it's so awesome - the entirety of it is really, really strong, whether it's a free jazz freakout, dark psych-folk song, or experimental reverb-laden moanfest. There are actually far more splices than crossfades here, and the fragments are all brilliant as compositions alone. I wonder how much editing was at work here - if this is really the best 40 minutes out of hundreds of hours, or if all the jams being made at this time were so strong. [10 December 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Faust - So Far

Label: Recommended Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

After being apart from the majority of my record collection for over 3 years, it's great to be reunited.  Of course I didn't have a turntable the first two weeks, so it was especially painful to just look at all of these records.  Now I've got a cheap one so I can start listening again.  I'm pulling these records out pretty much at random and listening through the plastic crappyness of this turntable (which is just to tide me over til I can afford a decent audiophile one) but even then this record just sounds amazing.  Since I first heard this (after trying to track it down for months in the pre-Internet days, where I was trying to get a CD for less than $30 on eBay ... oh how times have changed) I've of course heard a million things influenced by it.  I've heard a zillion pastichy psychedelic jam bands and weird surrealist audio-collage specialists, and of course a zillion Velvets/punk-influenced primitives, but nothing seems to do it all as well as this.  And sitting with my head right between the speakers, I get the full impact of the crazy bending guitars and bubbling electronics.  It's not that this is the most far out and NWWlisty record ever - rather, it's accessible and direct, somewhat 'straight-forward' compared to something like, I dunno, Brainticket -- but it's satisfying and eye-opening because of this. And though this is a Recommended reissue from '79 (I think) it keeps the beautful packaging of the original - tight black wrap with lovely screenprints for each track.  Why am I sitting here importing old spreadsheet data when I should be calling people and getting my own Faust together?  [12 Dec 2008]


Date: 12 March 2005

Art Ensemble Of Chicago - Live At Mandel Hall

Label: Delmark Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

I believe this was one of the first recordings of the Art Ensemble that I ever heard, and it is definitely one of the best. While not quite as colorful and idiosyncratic as their studio work, it's a stunning document of live improvised music. This might be the first release with Don Moye on it, and while it definitely it somewhat more "traditional" than their other records, it's still incredible. Over four long pieces (one of them traversing three sides), they use their new drummer to his fullest potential. With the rhythm duties thus freed up, the other members are able to really tear it up on their instruments. Some moments are absolutely beautiful, even conventionally so; others are quite challenging. [19 May 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Captain Beefheart And The Magic Band - Easy Teeth

Label: The Impossible Recordworks

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

The Impossible Recordworks is such an awesome bootleg label, although their sound quality is pretty inconsistent across releases. This is one of the worst sounding of their records that I have heard, but it's still pretty worthwhile - even ten years after Trout Mask, Van Vliet is capable of thrashing through "Pachuco Cadaver" with a lot of energy. The setlist is good, mixing material from all of the good years of the Magic Band, but with the abundance of other live recordings that have surfaced, this one doesn't seem that necessary. [19 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Coronarias Dans - Visitor

Label: SteepleChase

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Like Flasket Brinner, this is a Scandinavian disappointment. Actually, it's a lot better - very competent progressive rock with a jazzy tinge, but dark enough that it doesn't sound like Medeski Martin and Wood. You can hear the influence of artists like Soft Machine on these guys, but they are quite good at it, though maybe not the most original sounding. I don't know if I can justify keeping this for I will probably listen to it rarely, as it's just another forgotten band lost in the prog morass. [18 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Captain Beefheart And His Magic Band - Lick My Decals Off, Baby

Label: Reprise Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Someone declared "I Love You Big Dummy" to be the greatest rock song ever. This is often thought of as the best Beefheart record, and it's a tough call for me - it's certainly got a different feel than Trout Mask, with the marimba and the goofyness seeming a little bit more charming, less "threatening" than Trout Mask but also by virtue of being a single album it's a bit less overwhelming. The instrumental work is recorded much more clearly than Trout Mask and it's easier to tell what's going on (but it doesn't make any more sense). I think the two records after this are of much lower quality - almost like he gave it all he could here. [23 July 2005] 


Date: 12 March 2005

Art Ensemble Of Chicago - Les Stances A Sophie

Label: Nessa

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

The Art Ensemble recorded this with Lester Bowie's wife, Fontella Bass, in 1970 while they were in Paris. It's one of their first sessions with Don Moye as a full member, and it stands alone among their entire catalog for its diversity and accessibility. The opening cut, 'Theme de Yo Yo', is an all-time soul great driven by Bass's great voice and the catchy melody. Yet it's the middle section of the album that is so remarkable - a series of slow, almost neo-classical explorations where Bass is silent (or on piano) and the abstractions of their Paris work find a resonance in the canon of Western music. Monteverdi is tackled here, split over two sides, and done fairly straight and then with a jazz swing on the other side. Bass reappears for the ending cut, by which point there's a new hybrid genre of great black music being made. Absolutely singular. [25 July 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Faust - Faust

Label: Polydor

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

The first Faust album rules. I can't imagine hearing this in 1971 - I'm sure it was as mindblowing as it was when I heard it in 1997. You get a little bit of everything they do here - the long, extended psychedelic jams that never get tiresome, weird folky vocal pieces and musique concrete pastiches that made Faust the greatest of the Kraut bands. It's the mystery, the intrigue, the presentation and the music that makes this music completely timeless. [22 April 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Art Ensemble Of Chicago - Bap-tizum

Label: Atlantic

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This live recording from the Ann Arbour Blues Festival in 1972 (which my father may have attended, though he can't remember which year and certainly doesn't remember seeing this) begins with a crazy tribal percussion jam before blending into a Malachi Favors-penned vocal melée. Roscoe Mitchell's compositions in the middle of this record pull things back towards the direction of brassy jazz, though they're in his usual style, which is open, non-visceral, and subversive. 'Oouffnoon' gets into some madcap free squealing over Moye's spazzy percussion work, so there is some sense that they gave the crowd what they wanted. Much of side two is taken up by a long Joseph Jarman composition that actually feels cathartic after the experiments of the record so far - the band actually plays together in a swinging, jazz fashion, though it's aggressive and quite driven by Favors and Moye. Bowie lets it rip here, almost like he's been holding back his vibrating exaltations until now. This turn towards the inside continues on their rendering of 'Odwalla', a beautiful transition to sweetness, still with a rolling swing, that ends this set. [2 Aug 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Art Ensemble Of Chicago - Chi - Congo

Label: Paula Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This record finds the Art Ensemble at their creative peak in the mid-70's. The first piece is a huge bass-oriented Malachi Favors number that grows out of a percussion jam. His lengthy solo is very aggressive, with Favors quickly plucking and slapping around his instrument. The rest of the record is written by Roscoe Mitchell, though the majority of it sounds collectively improvised. Some of the most free playing that is heard on any of their albums is here, with a lot of squawks and bursts of energy that wouldn't be out of place on an ESP release. [18 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Art Ensemble Of Chicago - People In Sorrow

Label: Nessa Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This totally should be reissued! Side one is the quietest Art Ensemble work I've ever heard - I had to crank up the volume to hear all of the little bells and scrapes. It gets going eventually but it maintains it's restraint. Side two is a departure even for them - there are long, droning horn parts and a falling apart sort of rhythm section, and it actually locks into a groove. This is surely one of my favorite Art Ensemble records, but I love almost all of them! [31 July 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Albert Ayler - Lörrach / Paris 1966

Label: Hat

Format: 2xLP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Listening to Albert Ayler makes me feel completely amazing. The way that this set opens, with 'Bells', just instantly fills me with a sense of goodness, wonder and magic. It's easy to be hyperbolic about music but this type of musical expression is still incredible to me after years of listening. This is that band with Don Ayler and Michael Sampson, similar to what's on the Impulse 2xCD, and probably my pick of Ayler's lineups. I'm a sucker for the violin and for Don Ayler's somewhat crude (yet perfect) trumpet lines. Maybe I'm influenced by all the religious imagery in the song titles and whatnot, but I do find this to be a form of religion as a listener; the great church of Ayler. Side 3 has an extended take on 'Ghosts', titled in the singular here, where things get really distant and deconstructed, almost as if he's tired of his signature tune, but I welcome the workout.. The more discordant bits, like 'Jesus' and the variations on 'Ghosts' are perfect when juxtaposed with the warm, wide trumpet/sax interplay which I completely want to bathe myself in. I think the Lörrach sessions (the first LP) are slightly more exuberant (and better recorded) than the Paris ones but it's all good. [28 November 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Albert Ayler - My Name Is Albert Ayler

Label: Fontana

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Ayler's first record I think? This is far from the visceral blasts of his ESP records, but still showing a bold, innovative young saxophonist. Recorded in Europe, the music moves similarly to the first few Ornette Coleman records. Ayler's tone is a bit glassier here than we're used to, though it still shakes all over the place. The longer piece on side two breaks away the most and certainly classifies this record as "free jazz," though it was probably mostly ignored upon it's release. The title is appropriate though, because this is certainly an announcement that Ayler has arrived. [22 May 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Albert Ayler - Nuits De La Fondation Maeght Volume 1

Label: Shandar

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

I think this is the only LP I have on the great Shandar label, a French imprint that released a bunch of epic free jazz and some LaMonte Young stuff. This is volume 1 in a two-LP live set, wonderfully recorded in 1970, and super energetic. This set focuses on the more melodic side of Ayler, with a beautiful version of 'Spirits' driven by Cal Cobbs' piano and Allen Blairman taking charge with an extended drum solo. This French rhythm section - also with Steve Tintweiss on bass - roots Ayler in a more fluid sound than he would have with Sunny Murray and/or Henry Grimes in place. Cobbs's piano licks are occasionally vaudevillian, and it's a bright star in the Ayler catalog, despite not really being indicative of Ayler's sound. The lack of Don's trumpet leaves Albert as the only real bass, apart from Mary Maria's soprano which isn't even that active. The vibrato is at times almost conventional, but when he digs in, as on 'Holy Family', it really rips. A great record, sure, but it's not 100% the Ayler we want - even his early 60's stuff, while far less adventurous, has more of an edge - but this is the direction Ayler went towards in his last years, and maybe this is a great point before it descended into fusion-rock. [25 July 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Albert Ayler - Witches And Devils

Label: Freedom

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

A "studio" Ayler record, and it's nice because we can actually hear Sunny Murray get the drum mics he deserves. Though I still can't help the feeling he's underrepresented on this record, as on all of his Ayler appearances - perhaps that's the way that Ayler wanted it? The mix is a bit weird, panning the brass into one channel and the rhythm section into another, but the performance is crisp (though I think I prefer the energy that is enhanced by having an audience in front of them). The trumpet player is nice and underrated, though he's no Don Ayler. [31 July 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Anthony Braxton/Joseph Jarman - Together Alone

Label: Delmark

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Two titans of the AACM meet in this mid-70's outing, which has a fantastic African-influenced cover but sadly no credits as to who is playing what.  I think the piano is probably Braxton and the reeds/flute is Jarman.  The labels are wrong so side 2 which says side 1 on the label begins the album with 'Together Alone', which is two saxophones playing simultaneously the same slow melodic line.  The second track is a longer, sparse improvisation with Jellyroll-style piano twinkles and Jarman squeezing the life out of a flute.  It keeps expanding and contracting, occasionally with one player dropping out to let the other start some sort of melodic theme, but it never gels (which is intentional).  At the end it explodes in a cacophony of bells, whistles, toys, and dual-tracked spoken vocals.  It's pretty great, actually.  The other side is two Braxton compositions (you can tell cause the titles are cryptic gibberish) and it opens with a dirty sax honk and what actually sounds like a gurgling Moog or something.  Througout the piece they keep jumping around on different instruments, sounding like they're in a big room and having fun.  They step into sync a bit though, true to the title of the record, with some slow, stepping harmonies - someone is playing two things at once at points, unless there is overdubbing.  Somewhere along the line the second track started.  The side ends in a dirgy sax line with rustling bells, and it's lovely.  Overall the album has a very playful feel, yet mature rather than balls-out.  It's an obscure one but one to cherish.  [2 Jan 2009]


Date: 12 March 2005

Captain Beefheart And His Magic Band - Safe As Milk

Label: Buddah Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

The first Beefheart album of course doesn't have the far-out freakouts of Trout Mask and the later stuff, but it's still great in a weird, warped way. At his youngest, Beefheart sounds completely raw, his voice tearing holes in the speakers. Some of the tracks are Magic Band classics, like "Electricity" and "Zig Zag Wanderer". Ry Cooder was in the band at this point, which is almost hard to believe. [15 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Captain Beefheart And His Magic Band - Strictly Personal

Label: Blue Thumb Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: €2.83

I had fonder memories of this record than when I listened to it now; the production is all washed out and flanged, which was apparently Van Vliet's big problem; some of the songs I like, like "Beatle Bones and Smokin' Stones" and "Kandy Korn" are much better on the Mirror Man outtakes CD; this particular vinyl copy might be beat to shit but everything just sounded unnecessarily dirty. [24 July 2005]  Actually a lot of the "psychedelic" production techniques sound really contemporary - some of these songs sound like Ariel Pink or Lamborghini Crystal etc. [9 Feb 2009]



Date: 12 March 2005

Captain Beefheart And His Magic Band - Clear Spot

Label: Reprise Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This is definitely one of the worst Beefheart records; the production is very crisp and it has a "hard rock" edge, which isn't necessarily a bad thing - the bad thing is that the songwriting is pretty lackluster. The guitars still do some interesting things but the rhythm section plugs along like ZZ Top or something. Some good songs like "Big Eyed Beans from Venus" are here, but a lot of the record is full of weird, soft-rock leaning material, which isn't terrible per se, but just not what I want in a Beefheart record. You can hear his push towards commercial music here, which hit rock bottom with the next two, I guess. [31 July 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Captain Beefheart And His Magic Band - Doc At The Radar Station

Label: Virgin Records America, Inc.

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

The best of the last three Beefheart records, this record is a lot more aggressive than 'Shiny Beast' and has some of his most disconbobulated constructions since Lick My Decals Off. His voice is definitely older than it was ten years prior, but when he kicks it on, it's ON. This is probably my overall third favorite Beefheart album. [20 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Richard Thompson Band - Two Letter Words: Live 1994

Label: Flypaper

Format: CD

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

Gift from Ross Rhodes; not sure what ever happened to this disc, though I remember it being "OK".


Date: 12 March 2005

Free Music Quintet - Free Music One and Two

Label: ESP

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This is a rarely-talked about group of European musicians, mostly Dutch I think, that made a great record here of collectively improvised music. It's from the jazz idiom for sure - there's sax and trumpet and spazzy jazzdrumming and Erwin Somer's xylophone (or vibes, can't really tell) which is a great balance to the skronkyness. The whole thing begins so slowly, with Ferdy Rikkers' bowing some bass very slowly, and it frequently settles down to let musicians paint more delicately. Some of the percussion/xylophone interplay is almost silly, such a contrast to the more growling furious moments. Sometimes I wonder why I need to own so many distinct free jazz records, especially as they are focused on such a short period of time, but they really do all have their distinct personalities. This one has a far more Euro flavour than any of the NYC or Chicago scene people of the time, and also a more exuberant continental feel compared to Derek Bailey or Spontaneous Music Ensemble or Evan Parker, which while brilliant, has a more dry edge. [22 August 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

V/A - Music of Sikkim

Label: Columbia

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This record actually turned out to be Buddhist liturgical music, which is okay because I've been wanting to hear more since I heard that really great record that Alex has in Scotland. This is a bit different - it doesn?t sound like it's made by ghosts like Alex's record does - but the upfront recording brings out the tonality of the vocalists, and it's still very chilling. I thought this was going to be a bit different, more in the vein of folk music. [24 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

V/A - Romane Gil'a: Anthology of Gypsy Songs

Label: Supraphon

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

I don't think I ever actually listened to this record of gypsy songs from Czechoslovakia, which I got in a Ross haul ages ago. My mistake - this is an incredible recording, collecting a ton of different songs from various nomadic people across the country, all recorded around 1970. Actually, it's only the first side that has nomadic gypsy songs, and side two is music of settled gypsies, but I didn't detect too much of a difference. Most of the songs are all vocal, with some tapping or handclaps, and a few of them had insane, crazy vocals that I've never really heard before. When there are strings or drums it's also pretty good, as the recording quality is pretty bad (or maybe the instruments are just really shitty) so everything has that classic field recording sense. Some of the vocals sound so casual - just muttering at times - which I loved because it seems so natural. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Richard Thompson - Live at Crawley 1993

Label: Flypaper

Format: CD

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0



Date: 12 March 2005

Bert Jansch - Lucky Thirteen

Label: Vanguard

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This must be some sort of greatest hits collection, or maybe just a compilation for American audiences. It's very successful, serving as a "Rough Guide to early Bert Jansch". "Needle of Death" appears here (I think it's on his very difficult to find first LP) and it's such a powerful song that I've played it over a few times. This is definitely the Bert Jansch starting point, even if there's a lot of overlap with other records. [24 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Fläsket Brinner

Label: Universal Music

Format: CD Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Obscure is not a synonym for "good" as this Flasket Brinner album proves. I was hoping to find another lost Scandinavian psyche band, something on the order of Arbete and Fritid, but instead got a mediocre jam band. Side one is entirely one melodic hippie jam, with lots of organ in an Iron Butterfly way. Side two has several shorter pieces, mostly in the National Health school. Some parts pick up a bit, approaching the style of someone like Area, only rather second rate. There's one part with vocals that is sorta funny. Maybe side two will grow on me, but this is likely to go on the 'sell' pile. [18 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Bert Jansch - It Don't Bother Me

Label: Transatlantic Records

Format: Vinyl Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

An early Bert Jansch LP (I think maybe his second) and he sounds very fresh and pure. He's definitely in "folksinger" mode, with hardly any influence of British traditionalism. Renbourn appears on two tracks. "Anti-Apartheid" is a rousing tune with a social conscience, but most of the songs center around more personal matters. When stripped down to just guitar and voice, Jansch is pretty irresistable. [24 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Ornette Coleman - Town Hall December 1962

Label: ESP Disk

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

I think the Ornette Coleman trio with David Izenzon and Charles Moffett is one of the most underrated trios in jazz history. I know they didn't record or release much, but it's always overlooked in favor of the much more "controversial" earlier work. This set is fantastic - the standout being side 1, with the droney, low-key second track and "Dedicated to Poets and Writers" which is a fucking string quartet composed by Coleman that sounds so intense. This is also 1962 we're talking about - the longer free piece on side two isn't the most interesting thing I've ever heard, but for it's time it's very forward things and Izenzon (one of my favorite jazz bassists ever) is worth hearing no matter what he's doing. [23 July 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

June Tabor - Airs and Graces

Label: Antilles

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

As much as I listen to British traditional folk, I have to admit that I still know little about it. This is one of my favorite records of the genre, but I can't really say why. I guess it's simplicity appeals to me - most tracks are a capella, though the few with accompaniment are fantastic. Her voice is absolutely perfect - I think I may prefer it above anyone else's - and she brings a weight to the material that seems natural, in no way overdramatic. I've been enjoying it since I copied it from Alex last summer, but to have a copy now on vinyl is really a treat because it sounds even better. [12 May 2005]  Gave this a random spin on this October morning and it was lovely, as always.  Tabor has a deep, European huskyness to her voice and it really drives the a capella songs - 'The Band Played Waltzing Matilda' is pretty epic, and the slight hesitations and tempo changes she can do on those pure vocal songs is great.  When there's accompanyment I like it too - Nic Jones does some lovely fingerpicking and I like the piano on side two.  They aren't all old traditionals - there's a few more recently composed songs here which are also lovely.  [1 October 2011]


Date: 12 March 2005

Throbbing Gristle - D.o.A. The Third And Final Report

Label: Industrial Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This third report is actually the second Throbbing Gristle record, and it's a pretty astounding collection of sound experiments. This one features a solo track by each member, and Peter Christopherson's solo piece, 'Valley of the Shadow of Death', is a masterful tape piece that mixes low-level speech and other sounds into something truly fascinating. The band isn't particularly song-orientated here, though Genesis P-Orridge's pop fetish comes out slightly in 'Weeping'. Other highlights include 'Hometime' which has a recording of a child's voice of an eerie, creeping guitar figure, the chaotic madness of 'Hit By a Rock', and the discord of 'Blood on the Floor'. But generally, D.o.A is a relatively restrained record, with an attention to construction/detail that is masterful. I never listened to Throbbing Gristle when I was young, which was a huge stupid mistake. [20 August 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Charles Mingus - At Carnegie Hall

Label: Atlantic

Format: CD

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $0

You can't really go wrong putting Mingus with Roland Kirk. This later lineup has Hamiett Bluiett in the group as well as George Adams, and it stands up well against any of his more "essential" work. [28 March 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Roscoe Mitchell - Nonaah

Label: Nessa Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This double LP attempts to show everything that Roscoe Mitchell does, and it's exhausting to listen to it all. Side one's solo saxophone performances are for fans of technique, and not easy casual listening. The interactions with Braxton don't make for anything more approachable, but close listening reveals a fluid interplay and balance that's lacking in a lot of collaborations. The fuller group pieces are always abstract, even as Richard Abrams piano tries to inflect some tradition into the works. Side four ends with a flutterly loop of screaming horns that is thick but headache-inducing. I hope these comments aren't taken negatively, as Mitchell is a very talented composer and performer, and this record shows his strengths. It's just an intense listen, that's all. [31 July 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Red Crayola and Art and Language - Kangaroo?

Label: Rough Trade

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Kangaroo? is kinda midway between Corrected Slogans and Black Snakes. The songs are as dogmatic as the previous album, but with a full-band format that they later explore in proper post-punk mode on Black Snakes. I like this middle ground, though I love the ridiculousness of Corrected Slogans a bit more. There's some awesome stuff - the profanity-laced tirade at the end of 'Marches', the vaguely Art Bears-esque 'The Milkmaid', and the pure ideological history of 'Plekhanov'. The band is actually fairly competent, though clearly still second fiddle to the message, and sometimes you think Mayo is just goofing on it all. 'If She Loves You' closes the record with a rumination on the fleeting nature of romance, a theme also present in the oddly-titled (or is it?) 'The Principles of Party Organisation' ; and odd to share vinyl space wit a song called 'The Mistakes of Trotsky', but odd is the name of the game. The biggest Art and Language/Red Crayola "hit" on Corrected Slogans, 'Keep All Your Friends', appears here in a revamped version that's really anthemic but I still prefer the original falling-apart one. [27 July 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Red Krayola - Soldier-Talk

Label: Radarscope Records / Radar Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Late 70's Red Krayola is a wonderful thing. Somehow, while these records fit into the post/punk style that was popular at the time, they also manage to sound not unlike every other records Mayo Thompson made before. This one has clattery guitar chords crashing all over the place, scattershot percussion, and multiple track of yelped vocals. "Countries in Eastern Europe/banding together like pancakes in syrup" is a line that only David Berman or Mayo Thompson can deliver, and there's also a song that sounds kinda like The Ex only years earlier. Has this one been reissued yet? [22 May 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Roscoe Mitchell Art Ensemble - Congliptious

Label: Nessa Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Side 1 has some very loose, open horn solos and quirky lively moments offset by silence. Side 2 opens with a crazy short group jam and this big siren, and it sounds totally intense and scary. This opens up into some sparser call and response type stuff, with babbled vocals, smacking sticks on things, and everyone playing percussion. The roots of the Art Ensemble are clearly on display here. [1 July 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Fred Lane - Swedish Songs

Label: Troll Flute

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

I was expecting some traditional Swedish folk songs, but instead I get a very average sixties folky guy playing Swedish-inspired folk. Jackson Frank he ain't, though he's certainly not bad, and this would be ripe for a rediscovery as Mr. Lane seems to be completely obscure (or obscured by the Rev. Fred Lane of From the One that Cut You fame). [23 July 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Roscoe Mitchell - Old / Quartet

Label: Nessa Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

"Old" is probably named so because it works with traditional themes, or traditional-sounding - a New Orleans Dixieland feel that is taken apart and deconstructed by this group. "Quartet" stretched across both sides and appears to be a longer, more loosely played group session though some themes do emerge. This pre-Art Ensemble AACM stuff is so exciting because you can just hear the musicians being pulled into a million different directions, not focusing as much as the later material but yet still completely innovative and brilliant. Some groups are the sum of their parts - and this record combined with solo Joseph Jarman may equal the Art Ensemble in personnel, but the sum is greater than the parts (though this one is fantastic). [15 May 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Sunny Murray - Sunny Murray

Label: ESP Disk

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Sunny Murray might be the most odd drummer in the whole free jazz canon. He seems at times to be denying the essential rhythm of an improvisation, or at least spreading the pulse out in a wide net. His style, particularly on this record, is so far removed from the jazz traditions, but then the rest of the band is so jazzy that it's really a mishmash. Jacques Coursil dominates here; his trumpet playing is freakish at times, smooth at others. His own composition, 'Angels and Devils', resembles Ayler only in title but instead of being an expressive, direct lyrical statement, it veers all over the course. His playing on 'Giblet' is the perfect complement to Murray's ebb and flow, which is actually remarkable. At times Murray just fixated on the snare drum, hitting it so monotonously it loses any sense of syncopation, while the cymbal crashes continue. The recording quality isn't great here, which adds to the mystique of this. This copy is an original ESP with paste-on back cover and text in Esperanto; it musta seemed like a transmission from another planet in 1966. [31 July 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Roscoe Mitchell - Roscoe Mitchell Quartet

Label: Sackville Recordings

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Roscoe Mitchell delivers another left-field deconstruction of jazz here, though this lacks the warm fluidity of Sound, instead creating a cold and distant feeling. The opener, 'Tnoona', I'm pretty sure is also on Fanfare for the Warriors, but here is built around Muhal Richard Abrams circular piano figure. It's a brilliant direction for jazz-like music that feels underexplored, and the remainder the album is such a different tone that it can't help but disappoint me. George Lewis is a great trombonist and I don't have enough of his recordings; his composition is similar to the two of Mitchell's on the flipside, suggesting this quartet was much  more than an Art Ensemble diversion. The sense of space that I always love about Mitchell's work (and AACM in general) is never threatened - for much of the record, the musicians never play together, instead negotiating a dialogue. Spencer Barefield's guitar is the a highlight, as he's not well known and there's rarely guitar involved in AACM recordings. This is for a specific mood, which is that of tense, yet gentle explorations; I'm glad to have it for when I feel that way. [23 July 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Pere Ubu - The Art Of Walking

Label: Rough Trade

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This may be the strangest Pere Ubu record, no doubt due to the presence of Mayo Thompson in the lineup. The more aggressive residue from the Peter Laughner days is mostly missing here, and the new direction has almost a cabaret feel, although falling apart. Lyrically, Thomas is cryptic and side two is a total bad trip, though a cover of "Horses" from the solo Mayo record picks up the pace before "Crush that Horn," which is the most fucked up and experimental Pere Ubu piece that I have ever heard. [22 May 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Bert Jansch - Birthday Blues

Label: Reprise Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Shel Talmy made this Jansch record, perhaps a partial stab at crossover success as it features a full band on some tracks, with flute/sax, and rolling drumbeat (somewhat more rigid than Pentangle's jazzercise, though it is Danny Thompson on bass). It's also a bit of a stab at garnering sympathy for his loneliness, as the lyrical theme throughout is downbeat blues and mourning. The placid instrumentals are nice against the swinging vocal pieces, 'I've Got a Woman' being a nice example of such, with Jansch really letting loose vocally, almost like Tim Buckley or something. When he steps on the gas and digs in, it's quite driving, thanks again to a solid band -- but it always stays acoustic, god forbid. [27 July 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Areski / Brigitte Fontaine avec Art Ensemble of Chicago - Comme a la Radio

Label: Saravah

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This record is a great collaboration - the Eastern-influenced downer folk of Areski and Fontaine, but with the Art Ensemble of Chicago as a backing band on some tracks. It's not a total synthesis of minds and spirits - the Art Ensemble are just session musicians at points, and there are only a few really jammy places where we see an early glimpse into the free/folk sound that became so commonplace a few years ago. No one is interested in dazzling the others; there's a pretty cohesive group feel to these musical segments, indicating that this collaboration could have lasted and become something great. I guess the Art Ensemble were really open during their Paris residency - every bit of tape they touched during 1969 is remarkble. [24 August 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Friendship Next of Kin - Facets of the Universe

Label: Goody

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This is the only album (as far as I can tell) led by the ultra-obscure South African drummer Selwyn Lissack. I am totally fascinated by the South African jazz musicians that emigrated to England in the late 60's but I've never heard any of the groups beyond the Brotherhood of Breath. Mongezi Feza and some others are present here, though it's not nearly as melodically focused. Far from being a free for-all, these avant-jazz sessions definitely have the same bright energy that I associate with Fezi, though a bit more meandering and free. The b-side has a lot of spoken stuff which works pretty well in the context. Now, what else is there to find? [17 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Gleaming Spires - Songs Of The Spires

Label: Posh Boy

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

I bought this simple because it looked bizarre and had quotes from Ron and Russel Mael on the back cover - funny quotes too, for while they are attempting to push the record, they admit to not having heard it. According to the Internet, Gleaming Spires were Sparks' rhythm section in the early 80's. Their debt to Sparks is pretty vast - they both employ catch melodies, lots of synth, and clever/quirky lyrics.
