Nothing here approaches the brilliance of Sparks' best work, but there are some definite gems. Their one hit was "Are You Ready for the Sex Girls?" which is a really ridiculous song, but good. The closer, "Big Hotels" is akin to Ron Mael's best moments. Some songs like "How To Get Girls Through Hypnotism" are good, but too long. [24 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Faust - Faust IV

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Some people might see this as a more accessible Faust, but it certainly stands up as a masterpiece. It actually blows my mind just how comprehensively GOOD this record is, especially when compared to the inconsistent output of other Krautrock bands. "Giggy Smile" is so amazing, just as a rock song, that listening to the interplay of the guitars takes me to a transcendent place even though I've heard it a million times. A cornerstone of music, certainly. [22 April 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Michel Dintrich / Philippe Drogoz - La Guitare Au-Déla ...

Label: Classic (2)

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

I bought this pretty much randomly because I liked the cover, and Ross didn't remember anything about it. Michel Dintrich is an experimental guitar player who works without any alteration. Side 1 is an entirely acoustic suite that is very sparse and slow-moving, opening up like gagaku in the beginning. The approach is completely without reference to tradition or genre, and it reminds me of Steffen Basho-Junghans in that aspect. Side two is a piece composed with tape using Dintrich's guitar playing (I think) that reminded me of George Crumb in it's imagery. There is still a largely acoustic basis to this though it's much more layered. Overall, a very nice find. [17 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Don Cherry and the New Eternal Rhythm Orchestra conducted by Krzysztof Penderecki - Actions/Humus

Label: Everest

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Intentionally confusing, this collaboration between two titans pretty much lives up to the promise. We get Cherry doing a bit of the 'Si Te Ra Ma' song that's on Orient, and then the big 'Humus' and 'Actions' pieces, which actually properly explore the possibility of free jazz + orchestra. Cherry's 'Humus' is built around a strong melodic riff, a bit like his Blue Note albums. The orchestra goes wild but it's all kept under control; Cherry's spoken introduction is charming too. I rarely pull this one out when in the Don Cherry mood, but I should more often cause it's epic. [2 November 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Ornette Coleman - Town Hall December 1962

Label: ESP Disk

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

It's weird listening to this now - supposedly this was it, the radical "first" FREE JAZZ record (though Cecil Taylor's Jazz Advance may really hold the title, unless you want to count Tristano's "Digressions"). Today it sounds so tame, especially after seeing the Brotzmann Tentet last night. What sounded so extreme and dissonant back then sounds very accessible here, just like a slight deconstruction of bebop. Coleman's sax is really the weird thing here, because the rest of the band sounds music more traditional, even though I realize they are breaking away from chordal/modal foundations. Some things still sound groundbreaking many years later, and some attain a subtlety over the years. This falls into the latter, for sure. [12 May 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Ornette Coleman - Change Of The Century

Label: Atlantic

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This has the original lineup with Charlie Haden, Don Cherry, and Billy HIggins but it's not quite as radical The Shape of Jazz to Come, yet still a fantastic document of post-bop, showing Coleman's lyrical, playful side.The chordal centre is frequently, if not usually, absent, so this was very much 'free jazz' for its time, though it doesn't sound abrasive or crazy to today's ears. Don Cherry is great in any context, and he sounds great on 'Birds'. The rhythm section rolls along, Haden not getting into his more lyrical/folky tendencies yet, but this is 1959 after all. [22 August 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Tippett, Keith/Julie Tippett/Trevor Watts/Colin McKenzie - Warm Spirits/Cool Spirits

Label: Vinyl

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

I love Sunset Glow, but this improv record doesn't do as much for me. The piano style is melodic and circular, but the reeds on this record are forgettable. It's very cold music (despite the title) but I wonder if I just have different expectations from Julie Tippetts. It's certainly closer to Spontaneous Music Ensemble. Her vocals are wordless, moaning in a manner akin to those early Gunter Hampel records, but perhaps brighter. [23 May 2005]  Gave this a random go tonight, and yeah, it's a difficult one, but the real problem is Colin McKenzie's electric bass, which feels more like the slap happy style that often plagues fusion improv. But there's some great moments here, particularly when Keith Tippett is present - his piano is really full and flowing, and it works well with Julie Tippett's sliding vocal energy. Watts's sax style is really precise and tight, and while it's not a tone I love, it's a good balance to the Tippetts. I'm gonna keep this record at least til the next listen, which might be another 7 years from now. [3 April 2012]



Date: 12 March 2005

Julie Tippetts - Sunset Glow

Label: RCA

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

In the past few years that has been elevated to an all-time favorite status for me, so it's great to finally own a copy on vinyl. It sounds great, even on the crappy turntable I'm currently using. I think I read someone describe this as the female version of Robert Wyatt's Rock Bottom - I don't think it's quite that personal, but the voices and instruments are beautifully arranged in a similar manner (although it may not be as quirky). A theme of innocence runs throughout the record, and Tippetts (who wrote most of the songs) carries it with her powerful voice and delicate guitar playing. Amazing. [20 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Bert Jansch - Rosemary Lane

Label: Reprise Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

A lengthy Jansch record that is all voice and acoustic guitar, and what more do I need to say? It rules. There are a few instrumentals but mostly vocal pieces. I think this is one of his later releases but the production is superb and he does everything solo here as opposed to having guests. This could potentially become a favorite. [12 May 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Bert Jansch - L.A. Turnaround

Label: Charisma

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

A bit further into the 70s here, and Jansch has filled out his sound even more. The arrangements have no trace of the ragged honesty found in his 60s work, but they are certainly nice in their own. The instrumental guitar pieces on each side are absolutely beautiful and recorded with a warm intimate charm. Said charm extends to songs like 'Stone Monkey', a straight-up country rock vibe that isn't evident in his earlier work. Jansch works well here - the Los Angeles of the album title must have infused his songwriting with that West Coast Byrdsyness, and I welcome it. There's a redux of 'Needle of Death' here, with some strings in the background that are surprisingly unobtrusive - the slower version has more gravitas, though I still prefer the original. [20 November 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Sun Ra - Nothing Is...

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

Is this the only Sun Ra record on ESP besides the Heliocentric Worlds? I think the free jazz reputation of Sun Ra is largely founded upon this record, which has some extremely exploratory freakouts; however the many other sides of Sun Ra are also present. You get bluesy piano, soulful balladry, and some repetitive pre-funk jamming that reminds me of the Ethiopiques stuff more than Fletcher Henderson. With so many Sun Ra records out there it's hard to pick a favorite but this is certainly one of the best, and a good place to start. [23 July 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Joseph Jarman - Song For

Label: Delmark Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

I've always slightly preferred Joseph Jarman's compositions to Roscoe Mitchell's (though of course they create something magical together) because his work feels more natural and expressive than Mitchell's, which is often overly cerebral. This solo outing (which features Fred Anderson and Steve McCall) is definitely a precursor to Art Ensemble. The first side explodes with flurries of notes and all of the musicians playing their hearts out. "Adam's Rib" features some interesting contrapuntal playing between Jarman and Charles Clark, sounding like a Max/MSP patch to me at times. The title track closes the record, and it develops very slowly, with lots of space - a definite antecedent of what made the Art Ensemble so unique. The inevitable eruptions are as much menacing as celebratory, with some controlled harmonies that make this seem more like a modern classical composition than a "jazz" one. [20 Mar 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Steve Lacy - Solo - Théatre Du Chêne Noir

Label: Emanem

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This is the first release on Emanem and a beauty, and I say this as someone who generally finds solo saxophone records difficult to get through. Actually, I was thinking about what records would be the worst possible choices to set a seductive mood and this would have to be up there. Lacy actually plays kinda sexy at points - there's a real straight-ahead melodicism to his soprano thrusts - but then he's capable of bending the notes into the bizarro zone. There are warbles, hesitations, and outright screeches at times, all presented as a logical step in the modification of a sound. He uses a radio on a few tracks for either background content or static, a nice effect of randomness on solo improvisation. This is not 100% improvisation - there are distinct songs throughout - but the balance is just. [8 November 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Annette Peacock - I'm The One

Label: RCA Victor

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

A very bizarre vocal jazz album. Peacock's voice is strong and brassy, and the music lurches around some riffs. The synthesizers are what makes this really weird - I think they are vocoding her voice, or maybe just playing synth lines alongside it. There are a couple of parts where the electronic vocal affectation lurch out in a really jarring way. Other tracks are more standard jazz-rock, and not that memorable but I haven't listened enough for the lyrics to sink or anything. Maybe this suffers a bit from "product of its time" status but the weirder tracks are definitely memorable. [25 May 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Annette Peacock - X-Dreams

Label: Aura Records (2)

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This record is on a smaller label and features Bill Bruford on drums, so I thought it might be more wild than the debut. It's not - but it's still good. The tracks swing well enough, with a bit of a funk/gospel feel. Her voice isn't as weird as on the first album, but the songwriting feels slighty more cohesive. While I rarely listen to this genre, I think this one might be worth investigating further, especially as her lyrics hint at something quite dark. [25 May 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Psychic TV - Force The Hand Of Chance

Label: WEA International Inc.

Format: Vinyl LP AlbumVinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

As I've never been a big Throbbing Gristle fan, I've had even less of an idea what to expect from Psychic TV. This first album begins with an extremely fey folk song with a cheap synth beat and delicately intoned lyrics - certainly a change of pace from TG work. The first LP is all over the place, with some very dark instrumental jams and other song-oriented stuff. The second LP is instrumental, almost ambient, with a lot of piano and more soundtracky material. As a debut, this hints at the inconsistency and stylistic shifts that are to follow in the rest of their career. [22 May 2005]


Date: 12 March 2005

Sun Ra Arkestra - Jazz in Silhouette

Label: ABC/Impulse

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

This is a mid-70s Impulse! reissue of the Sun Ra classic from the late 50's. Sun Ra's band is smaller here, and much more obviously descended from Fletcher Henderson's band. The songs come out of a midcentury Chicago swing background, with Sun Ra's piano holding the centre and letting the saxes and trumpets swing around. John Gilmore gets special billing in the subtitle and indeed his tenor has a brassy swagger that clearly dictates he is to be top dog (though Pat Patrick's baritone challenges at times). There's little space exploration to be done here, though 'Ancient Ethiopia' does have an unusual chordal progression with an African theme. Fun, jaunty numbers like 'Images' follow a standard bop pattern, with places for solos, and nice interplays between various band members. A great, landmark recording of American jazz, even though it only hints at the crazyness to follow. [24 July 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Throbbing Gristle - Bring You 20 Jazz Funk Greats

Label: Industrial

Format: LP

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

It's a shame I don't know more about Throbbing Gristle, cause they are definitely worthy of being placed on music pedestal along with the other greats of the late 20th century. This is the one that I've always liked the most (not that I know their entire discography) because it has so much variety. It's like every song here is a complete challenge to the idea of music; whether 'Beachy Head's proto-darkwave landscapes, 'Exotica's dreamy psychedelic, or 'Persuasion's burning intensity, everything sounds confidently aware of the past yet completely pushing forward without boundaries. Bonus points for the ironic cover art and stunning poster, which parodies rock imagery so good. [17 December 2012]


Date: 12 March 2005

Red Crayola - Microchips and Fish

Label: Rough Trade

Format: 12"

Source: Ross Rhodes

Cost: $2.83

I don't know why this is a 12" single, as I think it could fit on a 7". Two songs from the late 70's post-punk Red Crayola lineup are featured here, with skronky saxophones and herky-jerky rhythms. Side two starts and stops a bit, sounding as broken as their earlier (and later work), but overall this is just too short and not as essential as Hazel, God Bless the Red Krayola or Corrected Slogans. [24 July 2005]


Date: 16 March 2005

Dragon - Dragon

Label: Mystical Beast

Format: 3" CDR

Source: Dick Baldwin

Cost: $0

Thanks Dick!


Date: 24 March 2005

Eyes And Arms Of Smoke - Birthing Timbers

Label: Chondritic Sound

Format: CDr Mini Limited Edition

Source: Robert

Cost: $0

I remember when this was recorded, except I wasn't there -  I had dinner with John Ferguson instead because we had prior plans, and the EAS people were really bummed that I didn't come, but it was a last minute show and I was sort of sick of shows. This 3" commemorates it, and it's a beautiful exploration of the cavernous interior of the Icehouse, the venue where this was recorded where most underground activity took place during my Lexington stay. The 3" is a nice format for this, certainly a live improvisation but a really beautiful one built around a murky rising and falling, with Sara's clarinet really being front and centre. I miss all the good stuff. I also miss this band, a lot. [22 August 2012]


Date: 1 April 2005

Burning Star Core/Comets on Fire - split

Label: Yik Yak

Format: LP

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

This collaboration has Robert and Spencer representing BxC and three Comets on Fire people (or maybe there only are 3 people in CoF, though when I saw them I remember five). It's a very lo-fi recording of a big thumping jam, where the guitars and bass riff throughout in a monotonous manner akin to that Oneida 'Sheets of Easter' track. The Burning Star Core approach is to add layers to it all, which I guess is violin and electronics throughout. It's integrated quite into the mix, sounding like a cohesive band or maybe they just put everything through the same amps. It's hard to really get the clarity against the chaos; this distinction I tend to enjoy from the Robert/Spencer jams and with Comets on Fire thrashing about behind them, the only thing is to let go and ride along. [24 November 2012]


Date: 1 April 2005

Burning Star Core - The Very Heart Of The World

Label: Thin Wrist Recordings

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

Has it been so long already? 'How I spent the middle part of the 00s' is summed up by a few recordings, especially this one, though I don't play on it or anything like that -- it's made by close friends at a time when I was quite involved with things, and came out when I lived in Lexington, and this was the very heart of my world. I've always thought of this as the single best Burning Star Core release -- it's the one I recommended to Evan Parker -- but maybe I disagree now. It hasn't lost any of its magic - this is a perfect document of all the things that Burning Star Core was and could be from 2002-2004, and even has a nice balance between Spencer solo ('Benjamin'), Spencer with Cinci dudes (Lesniak's electronics on 'Nyarlathotep' make the piece, and it's also a nice early vocal recording) and the Lex crew -- plus, this features the great Jim McIntyre of Von Hemmling infamy. The recording quality is stellar and the mastering is also great - these Thin Wrist LPs are such lovely packages. Trevor's trumpet playing on 'Catapults' is really brilliant and Robert sort of steals the show on side two. A sense of balance and willingness to share the spotlight is why this feels so balanced, I guess. [14 August 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

Dead C - The Operation Of The Sonne

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

This is one of the LPs from the Dead C's middle period, where they made the transition from totally fucked up rock to totally fucked up free improv. It's one I liked when I first heard it years ago, and i's great to finally track a copy down. The first track has some really goofy spoken stuff and a fucked up moog part; side two is one long jam that has no builds, no momentum, and nothing but the weird drugged out vibe that these south islanders do the best. Siltbreeze was really something else in the mid-90's. [26 April 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

Skullflower - White Fang #2 / Glassy Essence

Label: Freek Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $2

This 7" finds Skullflower in full rock mode on 'White Fang #2', I guess a tribute to Jack London. Thundering drums, screaming voices, and a constant pounding that veers into reckless abandon. 'Glassy Essence' is much noisier and unstructured, perhaps due to Bower's influence (Stefan Jaworzyn is not in the lineup for this one). [22 August 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

Ex - 6.6

Label: Ex Records

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

A two-song 12" by the Ex from the early 90s, around their peak period when they were hanging out with Tom Cora and making Joggers and Smoggers. This comes with three pages of angry rants about how evil the Schengen agreement is, which is kind of funny to read now, and I wonder if they still feel such vitriol against the unified Europe (probably). 'Euroconfusion' is punchy, and a bit funky; 'Bird in the Hand' has more shard-like guitar clatter and some explosive sounds. When it slows down, the fury subsides, but only for a second. This probably could have been a 7" but then there would be less packaging on which they could put angry rants about Schengen, and the half-engraved side B wouldn't be there which is fucking lovely. [3 November 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

The Dead C - Clyma Est Mort

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

This is such an awesome record that I continue to own two copies of it, even though the BaDaBing reissue is thicker vinyl and has bonus material (and I'm never really one to care about original pressing collector crap). This has probably the single best take on 'Power' that the Dead C ever did, and they certainly released enough versions; 'Sky' likewise slays. But the opening cut ('Sunshine') and the weird German-titled song at the end are what really bridges this from being just a typical document of the band at the peak of their powers. It makes this a more complete picture, showing the pure free improvisatory direction they were going in while still being rooted to these amazing, amazing songs. And it's not even a real live album! [1 December 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

Commuters - Commuters

Label: Amphibious Records (2)

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

This is an insanely rare one-off collaboration with Dagmar Krause and some Swiss musicians I think. It reminds me most of News from Babel as it's really centered around her vocal delivery. The accompaniment is all piano, and it's rather short - maybe 15 minutes total - but quite satisfying. It's a weird thing to find in Bill Widener's record collection - perhaps that is why he's selling it. [20 April 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

Skullflower - Total

Label: Vinyl Communications

Format: Vinyl 7" 33 ? RPM

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $2

Aptly named, because this 7" manages to convey what Skullflower does in just two short sides, both textural pieces without any real progression (I mean, it IS Skullflower after all). Side one actually ends with just a tape splice. Side two has a rhythm loop in it, and some howling feedback that carries it to the next level. I played this at 33 but I suppose you could listen to it at 45 if you were on meth or something. [15 May 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

Suckdog - Drugs Are Nice

Label: Suckdog

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

It's great to finally have this monstrosity in my collection. A bunch of drugged up art-school girls giggling, screaming and rambling on while making as much noise as possible and trying to be irritating certainly has it's charm; this is definitely an anti-music classic. Suckdog live even in 1999 were still one of the most fucked up things I've ever seen - here in their prime it's just a totally ugly, beautiful mess. [20 April 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

Cabaret Voltaire - Eight Crespuscle Tracks

Label: Giant

Format: LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

A collection of later stuff, often geared towards dance/club forms which just feels inappropriate despite their use of rhythm. 'Shaft' theme as well, which does nothing - this is barely recognizeable as the same band who made Red Mecca.


Date: 20 April 2005

Ex - 1936

Label: Ex Records

Format: 2xCD Mini

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $5

These two 3" CDs each contain two songs and are about the Spanish Civil War. This is really a photo essay published by AK Press, by which the Ex's songs are just accompaniment. The first and last song are classic Ex songs from this period (the late 90s, so just before they jumped to Touch and Go), and the middle two are traditional Spanish folk songs given a rough electric guitar edge and sung as a genuine tribute. The photographs are stunning; it's a remarkable bit of history and there's no more appropriate band to contemporize history than the Ex, who for all of their anti-power hysterics, are stridently intelligent. [29 December 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

Inca Eyeball/Raymond Scott/Arthur Doyle/Shadow Ring - split

Label: Giardia

Format: 7"

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $2



Date: 20 April 2005

Alastair Galbraith - Intro Version

Label: Roof Bolt

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $1

Mid-90's Alastair Galbraith is among the most magical soundworlds ever created. This 7" is five glimpses into it, with tracks being brief (of course) and haunting. There's a lot of guitar and it reminds me most of the Seely Girn-era stuff. Even the smallest fragment that may seem like a mistake or a sketch conveys a wealth of imagery. A treasure. [1 May 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

The Ex - Tumult

Label: Ex Records

Format: CD

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $3

The Ex's third album has a lot of scraping guitars and pounding drumbeats, over which G. W. Sok does his 'Ex' thing. I'm a definite Ex fan though this doesn't have as many memorable tracks on it. It's right before they made Blueprints for a Blackout, which I always thought was their first foray towards experimental music, though you can really hear it starting here, where they start to open up songs and pick them apart. Most of the lyrics are along the intent of 'Squat!', though often an observational tendency that is actually quite memorable. 'F.U.N.E.I.D.Y' gets into almost romantic territory, or maybe it's just addressing desire through an anarchist perspective, who knows. The recording is solid, and Terrie's guitar cuts through everything. 'O.S.L.' actually has some synth drums or triggers or something, which brings an industrial flavour that actually suits the Ex. Solid, but since I listen to them so rarely today, I'm much more likely to pull out Joggers and Smoggers or the two with Tom Cora when I'n in the mood. [1 July 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

The Ex - Joggers and Smoggers

Label: Ex

Format: 2xLP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

The Ex and many guests conspire to make this massive, sprawling double LP, which has always been my pick of the Ex's discography even though I find it too dense and intimidating to get though in one listen. There's a lot of stuff happening here - a lot of 80's style fast start-stop shuffling Ex songs with G.W. Sok ranting, but also a lot of loose improvised bits, including some stuff that is practically ambient in nature. The Ex have such an apocalyptic feel to them and the improvisations carry that on. It's a very long record - so long that I have trouble concentrating on it, though I find it completely impressive as an achievement. 'Brickbat' has to be a tribute to Beefheart as it's among the most abstract lyrics the Ex has ever laid down; Lee Ranaldo and Thurston Moore appear here too, as well as a bunch of great Dutch improv guys like Ab Baars. I always admire artists who stay true to some ideals and yet push themselves artistically; I think Wire, the Ex and maybe even Godspeed You Black Emperor are probably all great examples of this. Joggers and Smoggers is really the first place to start if you want to sum up the Ex in one (double) record; it's not completely obvious but throws you just enough rope to hook you in. [1 December 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

The Ex - Pokeherrie

Label: Ex

Format: CD

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $3

An early 80's Ex record that I never listened to before now. This falls into the period around "Blueprints for a Blackout" where they started to become more experimental. Their trademark jagged rhythms begin here, though they haven't yet embraced the folk aspect. This stands up well as an example of that time period (and sound remarkably influential on stuff like Fugazi that came later) but I don't know if I need to own that many of these records. I'd say that Aural Gorilla probably caps off this period the best, and opens the door for what was to come on Joggers and Smoggers. Still, they are a brilliant band and this is a good CD. [12 May 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

Men's Recovery Project - Immense Ovary Reject

Label: Walkabout Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $1

This is the only Men's Recovery Project record anyone needs - a quick 45rpm 7" packed with their absurdist hardcore/punk experiments. Which actually resemble punk rock only at times. The greatest of their songs, 'Get Your Dick Out of My Food', is definitely a thrash-fest but then has weird keyboards and line-in guitar noise over it all. It's true, it does spoil the flavor. Other tracks are skit-like experimentations with bizarre synths (showing, no doubt, their Devo influence) and some ('My Body is a Jerk') sounding quite like Tuxedomoon. Great from start to finish. [31 July 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

Silver Jews - The Arizona Record

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl 12" EP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

Early Silver Jews has that ragged quality that made early, pre-CRCR Pavement so great - the recording quality is total shit, the performances are halfassed and the songwriting even feels a bit unfinished - but that's the charm, because Berman and co. were just such artists that their most casual offerings stand among the finest of the genre. Having not heard this in years, it sounds every bit as great as it did when I taped it from Manny in 1997. [22 April 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

Savage Republic - Ceremonial

Label: Fundamental

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

I used to think that this was the best Savage Republic album but I'm not so sure anymore. It does what they do well, and the first song has beautiful female vocals (is this the girl that sung for 17 Pygmies?) but it doesn't have the Neubateness of the first album or the weird textures of the underrated Jamalihyra (or whatever it's called). Still, Savage Republic were a great band and this is a fine record. It's production and approach feel a bit dated now, but I suspect if I still have this record in 15 or 20 years it will sound very good. [12 May 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

Last Exit - Last Exit

Label: Enemy Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

This first Last Exit album is pretty cohesive.  Ronald Shannon Jackson plays the drums like a fucking typewriter - it's closer to rock than jazz - and that works with Laswell's clangy six-string wank bass.  Brotzmann and Sharrock fight it out and neither one really wins.  They paint images of dirty, dark cities with dangerous alleys, relentless black rain, and never-ending radio interference.  It's all pumped up by Jackson though it never turns into a messy ball of noise.   However, this is very much electrified jazz, or fusion, or whatever, and they never let you forget it.  Jackson also vocalises a bit, either panting about the Emperor of Ice Cream or just growling, which is somewhat forgettable (as are the "jazz" moments, where solos are taken etc.).  But these few missteps aren't enough to drag down the overall album, which is pretty solid and probably better than Iron Path. [3 Jan 2009]


Date: 20 April 2005

The Fall - Wonderful And Frightening World Of... The Fall

Label: PVC Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

This is about the latest Fall album I'm familiar with, but it's a yummy plate of goodness. The band is confident and it sounds pretty much like a Fall record should. A few standout songs like 'Copped It' (with Gavin Friday on guest vocals) and 'Bug Day' are slight departures from the usual Fall style but they work well. The latter in particularly is a menacing, lumbering piece that sounds trapped under its own weight, an underwater. 'Craigness' I guess is about Scanlon himself, and his guitar playing is exemplary throughout. [19 September 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

The Ex - 6.1

Label: Ex Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $1

'Slimy Toad' has frantically strummed electric guitar, a military drumbeat, and G.W. Sok's inimitable vocals overtop. 'Jake's Cake' has noisy slide guitars across the whole song, but a steady circular riff to give it structure. It's vintage Ex, from '91 which is around the time I know them best. This is not essential - the 12" from the same series is better - but it's fun. [18 December 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

Coil - Hellraiser OST

Label: Solar Lodge

Format: 10"

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

This sounds a lot like Goblin or the Pittsburgh band Zombi, which is to say not really my cup of tea - synthy rhythmic numbers that work well as a building horror movie soundtrack, but are quite uncompelling on it's own (especially given what Coil is capable of). This pales in comparison to anything else I've ever heard by Coil, even the disco stuff. One for the "sell" pile, fer sure. [26 April 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

Jandek - Lost Cause

Label: Corwood Industries

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

Jandek in 1992 really found a voice, or at least he made his Rust Never Sleeps here - the acoustic/electric split. On at least on the first half of the first side - there's some genuinely melodic crooning and a sharp sense of irony ('Babe I Love You' mentions his attraction to another's genitals). It gets progressively more deranged, by the time it gets to 'God Came Between Us' -- which is beyond Kenneth Higney in its monotonous warble. The instrumentation is entirely acoustic until the flip, 'The Electric End', which is a freakout like nothing else. It's got some crunchy electric guitars and plodding drums and yelping and I imagine it's actually a band and not just Jandek overdubbing everything himself, though that would be a feat. The actual listenability of 'The Electric End' is questionable - I think it's more interesting than Love's side-long jam but not enough to really lose myself in. [15 July 2012]


Date: 20 April 2005

Jandek - Six and Six

Label: Corwood Industries

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

The second Jandek record. I've only started to get into Jandek recently, and I've only really listened to the first album, which has the same chord strummed through the entire record. Here, the chord is varied a bit, but the music is no less desperate. Jandek should be appreciated because he works in an aesthetic that is extremely personal and influenced by no one. This is the essence of great music, and I'm not saying that to justify listening to this, because I genuinely do like it. It's extremely evocative music - full of despair - but not in a way that can be approached by general audiences. I need to listen to the next 38 of them now. [12 May 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

Savage Republic - Tragic Figures

Label: Independent Project Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

I used to have a tape with this record dubbed on side 1 and the last Savage Republic album dubbed on side 2, and that was a pretty fun tape to drive around to. This record is really aggressive, with lots of shouting and harsh drums. Their later stuff is definitely more "pop" but this stuff is wilder. After awhile some of the instrumentals start to sound like a slightly more accessible version of the 150 Murderous Passions disc with Stapleton and William Bennett. The one song on side 1 is really fun and corny. California needs to have a Neubaten too! I passed up the letterpressed edition of this because Widener wanted $15 for it. [12 May 2005]


Date: 20 April 2005

V/A - New York Eye and Ear Control

Label: Matador

Format: LP

Source: Bill Widener

Cost: $4.56

What a glimpse into a moment! This compilation shows a bunch of great, noisy rock music happening in NYC in 1990 (plus a Royal Trux track, included here I guess to show an affinity or just because they liked Royal Trux). Tracks range from Dustdevils (who sound exactly like Sonic Youth here) to Thurston himself (with Don Fleming, in the Rudolph Grey band) to Cop Shoot Cop to Unsane. The Biggest Square Thing is a forgotten Sue Garner instrumental guitar duo that is lovely; Rick Brown's other band Timber is probably the best song on here, sounding like some early Merge records-style band.  Zeena Parkins in Owt and Borbetomagus are probably the noisiest tracks here, and Steve Fitch has two goofy songs to balance things out. Circle X have one of the most memorable tracks here, which is loaded with screaming hell-guitars. Matador Records #6 -- such a long time ago.... [8 Aug 2012]


Date: 22 April 2005

Webb, Jimmy - The Moon's A Harsh Mistress

Label: Rhino Handmade

Format: 5xCD

Source: The Attic

Cost: $84.56

Of course this is a lot of material to assimilate, but so far I really am satisfied with this purchase. My favorite records so far are Words and Music, the first one, and El Mirage, the last one. The first album would probably stand up against many 90's singer-songwriter efforts in terms of production, but with a far higher pedigree of songwriting. Webb's voice is great - very soulful - and it's a shame no one remembers him for his self-sung material. A lot of these songs should have been hits because they are brilliant, with a more complex approach to lyric writing than pop music really allows. The middle albums have a more rock approach and certainly have their moments ("Galveston" - oh my God!) but I haven't digested them fully yet. El Mirage is produced by George Martin and it's totally overdone, but it works on some songs (like "The Highwayman" and "The Moon is a Harsh Mistress") really well - the baroqueness that made "Macarthur Park" is in full force with Martin helming. I haven't listened to the live disc yet because my copy didn't come with it and I just got it from Rhino a few days ago. [12 May 2005]


Date: 29 April 2005

Hair Police - Drawn Dead

Label: Hanson Records

Format: CD

Source: Robert

Cost: $0

This is Robert's record, really. These four untitled tracks are pieced together from various jams, experiments and other materials, and it's carefully assembled (in a way that doesn't sound that careful) to create a true statement of unease, disorder and alienation. The fidelity is striking; even though this was all self-recorded, there's an impressive dynamic range and some really moments that I would even call 'beautiful' in terms of motion. It's monotonous but diverse at the same time - when distinct sounds cut through the cloud, perhaps a bowed cymbal or scraped guitar strings - it's a fleeting glimpse of an anchor, which serves to only amplify the confusion. This may be my favourite Hair Police record. A vinyl edition came out, which would be really lovely to have, as this would split really nicely into two sides. [31 December 2012]


Date: 29 April 2005

Hair Police - Constantly Terrified

Label: Troubleman Unlimited

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Robert

Cost: $0

I think of Hair Police as a past-tense band though I guess they are still active. This came out during the time I was living with Robert so it's the period I was most familiar with, though I only saw a few shows that year since Mike lived in Michigan and still does. Irene once said that Hair Police were the perfect combination of an artist, a performer, and a musician, and that's now how I will forever think of them. Constantly Terrified is recorded as a 'band' feel with very little (if any) studio fuckery afterwards. It's a disturbing, stark record that still manages to shake off any sort of 'noise-rock' genre tags and stands as its own voice. There's not a lot of particularly harsh outliers here - it's actually quite a soupy mix, with the broken anti-musical approaches compiled into giant soundchunks. 'Rattlers Echo' is built around an unending drone and Trevor's distraught drumming, a scorched-earth take on jazz hands. 'The Haunting' is dominated by whatever Robert is doing,ending with a great locked-groove rumbling that finished whatever madness was started. 'My Skull Is My Face' returns to the monotony and pounding, but with a ghost vocal over top, chanting over the industrial rhythm, until the squealing electronics battle to the forefront. Title track 'Constantly Terrified' closes it out with meandering saxophone by John Olson over hissing, farting nastyness -- sounding a bit like a Derek Bailey-style improv staged around the gateway to Hell. [29 July 2012]


Date: 8 May 2005

Greg Kelley - I Don't Want To Live Forever

Label: Little Enjoyer

Format: CD Album Limited Edition

Source: Shiflet

Cost: $0

Of the many experimental-orientated records and CDs I accumulated from the years 2003-2007, I Don't Want To Live Forever stands out: this is a masterpiece. It is one 35 minute track of Greg Kelley fucking around with his trumpet and a steel drum, but a masterpiece to these ears. The composition uses loops and repetition to create something truly from left field, which takes its time to unfold. The first section is toneless trumpet breath, punctuated with many pauses, and the occasional angry drum interlude. It refuses to situate itself a deep-listening music or noise music either - it's more akin to sound paintings than any type of improvised music tradition. A lot of this is just air, breath through a trumpet, with the removal of pitch, which lends this something personal and visceral. The CD is actually the perfect format for this as well; the many silences at the beginning leave only the struggling motor of the CD player echoing in the room, an ongoing reminder of the futility of silence. The second movement is a long, minimal drone, built from breath I think, that calls to question the nature of recording itself through the artifice of noise, hiss and the like. When the more rambunctious start/stop activity begins again, it's an integration of the first two parts, thicker with a steady trumpet drone until the closing moments. [21 December 2012]


Date: 8 May 2005

Joe Colley/Shiflet, Mike - Meaning

Label: Gameboy

Format: 7"

Source: Shiflet

Cost: $0

The Colley side is so minimal it's almost nonexistent - file along with the Sakora record for "least actual listening material" award of 2005. The Shiflet side has the shrill focus that I think defines his work. A nice, fun single. Thanks, Mike! [23 July 2005]


Date: 13 May 2005

Warmer Milks - Rwanda

Label: Paper Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Mikey T

Cost: $0

Robert said that this record feels like the intro to something - a 7" that perhaps introduces an LP. Warmer Milks split their debut single between a fragments, fucked up "song" and a droney, electronic collage. "Rwanda" dances around a theme, and when you feel like it's about to kick it, instead you hear the band scraping chairs off the floor and shuffling things around. It's a real moment of tension that doesn't deliver, which is probably for the better. Despite his incredible talent for songwriting, it seems that Mikey T is determined to destroy any conventional approach to singer-songwriter music - in a method similar to the Homosexuals, a bit. Let's hope it capitalizes on the promise shown by this auspicious debut. [15 May 2005]


Date: 16 May 2005

Walter Carson & Three Legged Race - Primitive Ash

Label: Mountaain

Format: CDr

Source: Robert

Cost: $0

Robert and Daryl work well together though I think I can tell who is who. Walter Carson's minimalist approach is here, with a thick organ drone through the first two tracks under which Robert (I think) mucks about with various smaller sounds. Track 3 takes the intensity down a notch but follows the same formula - acoustic scrapings, knocking things about, and other improvised elements are there under a wavering band of midrange softness, before ascending into some more chaotic tinkering.  A lovely release; this really takes me back. [26 December 2012]


Date: 19 May 2005

Danny Saunders - Gold

Label: Shadazz

Format: Vinyl 7" Single

Source: Luke

Cost: $0

Luke discovered this Glasgwegian singer-songwriter and released this to expand his already eclectic label in another direction. Danny's songs have that gentle, unassuming feel of early 80's post-punk, like Television Personalities or the Desperate Bicycles, only a bit more relaxed and feeling completely out of step with the times. Chris Strunk would probably love this, I should get him a copy! [23 July 2005]


Date: 19 May 2005

Rude Pravo - The Dust Is Flying / Mediaeval

Label: Thievery Records

Format: Vinyl 7" Single Limited Edition

Source: Luke

Cost: $0



Date: 27 May 2005

Willie Nelson - Red Headed Stranger

Label: Columbia

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Pops (trade)

Cost: $0

Willie Nelson's classic album is a great concept record and beautifully instrumented with minimal guitars, harmonica, piano and steel guitar - it's the ultimate low-key country sound. The first side is built around the 'Time of the Preacher' melody which tells the story of the red-headed stranger, which is actually some of the few songs actually written by Nelson here. The second side has some instrumentals and a few sad sweet, slow songs like 'Remember Me' and 'Hands on the Wheel'. I really would love to get more early records by him, especially the stuff on that Nashville Was the Roughest box, which is pretty goddam amazing. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 27 May 2005

Emitt Rhodes - Emitt Rhodes

Label: Dunhill

Format: Vinyl

Source: Pops (trade)

Cost: $0

Emitt Rhodes appeals to the powerpop fan inside me; in high school I loved the "indie" side of music like this, though I never became that wild about the Beatles themselves. This is certainly Beatles-influenced beyond belief, actually sounding more like solo McCartney which hadn't actually happened yet in '70. Some good songs though, built around Rhodes's piano (did he play a Fender Rhodes ever?) and decent arrangements. He plays all the instruments and despite being built around overdubs, songs like 'Long Time No See' (called 'You Must Have' on the jacket but not on the label?) have a surprisingly hard rock edge, with jarring basslines and a good sense of tension. [27 November 2012]


Date: 27 May 2005

Sun City Girls - Folk Songs of the Rich and Evil / Exotica on $5 A Day

Label: Eclipse

Format: 2xLP

Source: Eclipse

Cost: $15.99

Another collection of old SCG insanity, Folk Songs of the Rich and Evil is a collection of, yes, songs, ranging from actual folk pieces to madcap ranting over jazz improv -- like a beatnik from hell. The screaming is outrageous and it's the most wild side of SCG's humour-influenced stuff, but I adore that side of them. Exotica On $5 A Day isn't wildly different in goofyness, but it does have much more percussion, as well as other bizarre instrumentation - there's some shit gamelan, as always, some tribal drumming - and the usual SCG ethnic mashup. Packaged together, these two records perhaps give a sense of very different sides of the band. It's like a blueprint for what they do, except that both collections are just above average, not amazing -- making it hard to endorse this as a must-have, given all of the other riches in the works. [23 August 2012]


Date: 27 May 2005

Sun City Girls - Fresh Kill Of A Cape Hunting Dog / Def In Italy

Label: Eclipse Records

Format: 2xLP

Source: Eclipse

Cost: $15.99

Another lovely 2xLP reissue by Eclipse; Fresh Kill of a Cape Hunting Dog is a cassette from the mid-80s that shows SCG at their most un-band like; there's tape collages, surreal radio interludes, and some actual jamming that is somewaht boogie-based and throwaway. 'Diet-Blue Morbid Attraction Soda' is a Faust Tapes-like bizarre sandwich, with spoken word creepyness that's familiar to fans of Charles Gocher's style (I'm one!). Def In Italy is a live cassette again, mostly made up of covers, not all of which I recognise, but they range from punk rock pisstakes to spaghetti western soundtracks. Goher and Rick Bishop switch instruments for a limp run-through of Ayler's 'Ghosts', which is actually pretty awesome. Throughout there's crowd tension galore, manufactured by their taunts; and JFA appears on a few tracks! Overall this might be the most fun of the Eclipse reissues. [30 July 2012]


Date: 28 May 2005

Aaron Rosenbloom - Among the Jackdaws

Label: Hank

Format: CD-R

Source: Aaron

Cost: $0

A short tour CD he made. Very droney, minimal pieces that remind me of the SB, and some nice zither work in interesting tunings. Beautiful packaging. [1 June 2005]


Date: 1 June 2005

Winter - Over, Around, Through

Label: Several Projects

Format: CD

Source: Caleb

Cost: $0



Date: 15 June 2005

Burning Star Core - USA Live Reports Spring 2005

Label: DroneDisco

Format: 4xCassette

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0



Date: 15 June 2005

Jessica Rylan / C. Spencer Yeh - Rylan / Yeh 2xC30

Label: DroneDisco

Format: 2xCassette

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0



Date: 10 July 2005

Richard Youngs & Alexander Neilson - Beating Stars

Label: HP Cycle

Format: LP

Source: Troy and Tyler

Cost: $10

This was Richard and Alex's second collaboration, and it's an outlet for Richard to explore his free, electronic side. Side one has three songs, built around percussion, voice and electronics. 'Rolling in the Dew' is delivered with that distinctive Richard Youngs cadence over a steady thump, a staticy middleground and some irregular tiny instrument sounds. 'A Boat Among Whales' is built around a repetitive bump, all soft bassy warmth, which slowly builds in momentum as the duo explores various free techniques - whistles, drones, and cheap sounds made good. The flip is taken entirely by 'Sent onto the Stream', a free exploratory piece in the vein of Richard classics like Knish or 'Goat'. Alex sticks to percussion against Richard's visceral, piercing tones which sound a bit like guitars and a bit like synths. It has the feel of being recorded live, though there's so much going on that I suspect Richard has overdubbed a bit. I haven't listened to this in ages but it's a great one to revisit. [23 August 2012]


Date: 10 July 2005

Maniacs Dream - Die, Learn, No Way

Label: HP Cycle

Format: LP

Source: Tyler and Troy

Cost: $10

The first LP by Maniacs Dream is something I picked up back when I met the HP Cycle twins, years before I would meet and befriend and brew beer with members of Maniacs Dream. This is a blast of primitive Kraut-style rock, with toy noise-makers, noodling solos that go nowhere, and an overall inbred mentality. There are more restrained moments of Finnish hillbilly string-bowing, repetitive clopping, and psychedelic soups. This definitely sounds like the more focused side of Avarus in conjunction with Kevin/Friccara Pacchu at points, which is maybe what it is - compared to some of the later releases it's a lot less noisy and occasionally quite hypnotic. [15 November 2012]


Date: 11 July 2005

Burning Star Core - Let's Play Wild Like Wildcats Do

Label: RRRecords

Format: CD

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

In two tracks Spencer stakes out in some pretty different directions - a very lush, layered approach is present on both tracks, one rhythmic and one hazy. With the glut of releases this summer, he doesn't seem to be repeating himself at all - there is little indication that he primarily works with violin and voice, as the themes here are much more electronic oriented, and very, very warm. This is going to probably stand out in his entire discography, as varied as it already is, as something distinct and rewarding (albeit brief). [23 July 2005]


Date: 5 August 2005

Uncle Jim - Superstars of Grenwich Meantime

Label: Black Velvet Fuckere

Format: LP

Source: Kris Abplanalp

Cost: $0

I'm definitely a fan of the Sun City Girls more goofy stuff and this is a fucking masterpiece, ranking up there with Horse Cock Phepner as one of the funniest works. There are so many amazing, quotable lines on here that I will probably be spinning it for a long time to come. Way to go Kris for releasing this!! [23 Aug 2005]


Date: 5 August 2005

Sapat - Ox

Label: CD-R

Format: 

Source: Aaron Rosenblum

Cost: $0



Date: 6 August 2005

Armand Schaubroeck Steals - A Lot of People Would Like to See Armand Schaubroeck ... DEAD.

Label: Mirror

Format: 3xLP

Source: Jason Finkbeiner

Cost: $0

R. Kelly could learn a lot about radio drama by listening to this. Over the course of 3 LP's (and most of my day), Armand tells us the story of his juvenile deliquency and the time he spent in Elmira State Prison. Over half of this is dialogue, with a few songs on each side that veer between blues pub-rock to demented, R. Stevie Moore-esque folk. The lunatic style of singing makes this easier to listen to, because the subject matter is not fun; there's a lot of humour that makes people hanging themselves and getting raped in prison much more entertaining than it would be otherwise. It's exhausting to get all the way through this but it's as compelling as a great Hollywood melodrama, with a lot of personality and some great psychedelic moments. This may be the least messy triple LP I've ever heard. Thank you so much to Jason Finkbeiner for ending my long search for this record. [28 Aug 2005]


Date: 6 August 2005

V/A - 10Yr.Series

Label: Carbon

Format: 9xCDR + DVD-R

Source: Joe Tunis

Cost: $0

acquired via trade


Date: 6 August 2005

Konono No. 1 / Dead C - Split Series #18

Label: FatCat Records

Format: Vinyl 12"

Source: Joe Tunis

Cost: $10

This is a brilliant pairing for a split 12" and the Dead C are a brilliant band to lead off with 4 locked-grooves, each containing a brutal blast of guitar noise - the Dead C's essence condensed to a few seconds, perhaps. The three songs here are great, classic sounding Morley/Russell/Yeats, with some two-chord monotony, moan-singing, ring modulator, and endless circular jamming. Konono No. 1 are on the flip, equally brilliant, no less compelling, and completely different. Their two tracks start and don't let go of the throttle, providing an infectious rhythm that stays after the record finishes. [5 November 2012]


Date: 6 August 2005

Konono No. 1 - Congotronics

Label: Ache

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Joe Tunis

Cost: $12

Exuberance is found through homemade amplifiers and gritty contact mic'd kalimbas, as this Congolese music is given a "rock" edge and presented on this very long LP. A closer listen reveals intricate arrangements for the different voicings of thumb pianos, but it's not necessary to focus on that because the rhythm is propulsive and the vocals joyous and the music infects all parts of the body. While the amplification removes the soft edges of traditionally recorded mbira music, the happiness is still present, just with more energy. [24 Aug 2005]


Date: 7 August 2005

Birch Book - Vol 1

Label: Lune Music

Format: CD

Source: Bee Gowan Ring

Cost: $0

B'eirth AKA Bee from In Gowan Ring traded me this a few years ago. The sticker warns 'May contain country of pop material that is linear, narrative and ego-oriented.'  He's so hard on himself.  This is a CD of singer-songwriter folk tunes, at their best moments recalling the lazy depressive vibe of On the Beach-era Neil, at their worst it's plodding coffehouse music.  There's none of that medieval vibe that the Gowan Ring has, though there's some Renaiassnace Fairy-esque instrumentation.  His voice is sweet and honest, and while this is very pleasant, none of the songs really jump out as anything I can connect to.  Tracks like 'Train to Rome', while obviously story-based, bore me.  I'd be curious to hear him rock out on some of these songs with a full band, but something tells me he's not interested.  This could grow on me, if I were to listen to it more, but being that it took me over 3 years to give it the first listen, I'm guessing that won't happen.  [12 Jan 2009]


Date: 8 August 2005

Flaherty/Corsano Duo - Last Eyes

Label: Records

Format: LP

Source: Ron Schneiderman

Cost: $0

A radio session of Flaherty and Corsano from 1994, which my old college buddy Kyle Bittinger recorded! This contains zero surprises, but that's a-ok. I have quite a few records with Chris on them now but this one is a really good example of how he can work in a free/jazz idiom perfectly. Flaherty is a thundering presence, and at times it feels like the alto is about to blow apart; melodic passages are more like teases, which flare up again before you realise it. Throughout it all, Chris is banging away. The push and pull between the two of them is flexible, organically shifting between aggro tone plundering and supportive enhancements. The spirit of the late 60's lives on, and it's a great document of two masters. [27 July 2012]


Date: 8 August 2005

V/A - Over the Edge OST

Label: Warner Bros.

Format: LP

Source: Strange Maine

Cost: $4

Cheap Trick, Van Halen, the Cars, the Ramones - what more could you want? [23 Aug 2005]


Date: 9 August 2005

Jacques Berrocal - Catalogue

Label: Alga Marghen

Format: CD Album

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $12.17

Much more scatterbrained and silly than either Paralleles or Musiq Musik, this is still a really fun document. Most of the tracks are very short, with lots of little diversions showing Berrocal using all sorts of materials to generate sound. There's a French dadaist approach here, and it reminds me of the Anal Magic album in the way it uses cut ups and different collaborators. There are bonus tracks from the 80's and 90's tacked on, some better than others, but the album itself is the real treat. [28 Aug 2005]


Date: 9 August 2005

Asian Mae - Collsing

Label: none

Format: CD-R

Source: Colleen Kinsella

Cost: $0



Date: 9 August 2005

Arsenije Jovanovic - Untitled

Label: La Légende Des Voix

Format: CD Album

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $12.17



Date: 9 August 2005

Musica Elettronica Viva - Pieces

Label: IRML

Format: CD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $12.17

Twisted Village had these weird MEV CDs that were totally impossible to determine what the fuck they actually were - the liner notes are a mess of broken text, like what a teenager would send text messages as, and while these are proper mastered CDs, the liner notes are all Xeroxed. I think I bought this one on someone in the shop's recommendation, and I'm glad I did! This release is really dry and skittery, with a ton of prepared strings (maybe a violin or guitar), with no echo or decay on anything, and a super erratic, jumpy playing style. It sounds like a solo record, and there's only one MEV member on the cover, so maybe Teitelbaum or whomever just pressed these up cause he needed money. But it's a great time, and pretty much the same pattern for the whole discs. Occasionally some lower sounds sneak in, but they maintain every bit the manic intensity of the rest of it. This is absolutely miles away from their two Actuel LPs, but no less invigorating. [1 August 2012]


Date: 9 August 2005

Roel Meelkop - 5 (Ambiences)

Label: Intransitive Recordings

Format: CD

Source: Howie Stelzer

Cost: $0



Date: 9 August 2005

Tazartes, Ghedalia - Une éclipse totale de soleil

Label: Alga Marghen

Format: CD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $12.17



Date: 9 August 2005

Jean-Jacques Birgé / Francis Gorgé / Shiroc - Défense De / La Nuit Du Phoque / June Sessions

Label: Mio

Format: CD + DVD

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $12.17

Défense De is all over the map; a studio experimentation made in the high, high 70s by some French avant-garde dudes I never heard of before, and it's a brilliant, invigorating slice of outsider music. This comes a bonus DVD containing the very goofy film and 6 additional hours of jams that I've never dug through - it's the album proper that I mostly listen to. On Défense De, there's a lot of jazzless swinging - crisp drumming, reeds shrieking in the wrong direction, and electric, crackling electronics. It's an open, airy sound that isn't that far off Berrocal but with a bit more prog-rock sand underneath. A few brilliant parts stand out - like where everything stops and it's just pure sound experiments, or some anti-musical clatter in the background. At times it feels like a curious sidestep of the recording process, though this is very much a 'studio' creation. Like the first Nurse With Wound record which put non-musicians in a recording studio to make surrealist art, this has that similar sort of play to it, though some of the playing reveals an undeniable virtuosity. The 6 hours of extra sessions are for a very long and strange rainy day which has yet to come. [30 December 2012]


Date: 9 August 2005

Ghédalia Tazartes - Diasporas / Tazartes

Label: Alga Marghen

Format: CD Album

Source: Twisted Village

Cost: $12.17



Date: 10 August 2005

Colleen - The Golden Morning Breaks

Label: Leaf

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Cecile

Cost: $0

Cecile's second record is a much more subdued affair than her first one, working primarily around sketches of just one or two instruments. She did a lot of the pieces live, but on record it's easier to take in their subtleties and beauty, especially the music box pieces. Her melodic sense is strong and I love the way this record sounds - it works as great late night music, but also as a way to begin the day (which the title suggests). One of my favorites of the year so far. [24 Aug 2005]


Date: 10 August 2005

Black Forest / Black Sea - Radiant Symmetry

Label: Last Visible Dog

Format: CD

Source: Jeffrey Alexander

Cost: $0

Jeffrey tossed me this as a trade or something, back when we met, and it's funny how I've never really gotten to know the guy but our lives have intertwined in weird ways. This CD is mostly the Black Forest/Black Sea duo but with guests on half the tracks, and those guests are people I subsequently got to know well - Chris, Alex and Daniel from Glasgow; Jan Anderzen and Merja Islaja in Tampere. These improvisations - recorded at Tchai-Ovna in Glasgow! - are nice, but the standout tracks for me are tracks 4, just the duo in Newcastle unaccompanied, and track 5, recorded in Bristol with Nick Talbot playing guitar. When Black Forest/Black Sea leave their comfort zones and get into space madness, I think I like the best. There are some bits here, perhaps the omnichord instrument, that while simplistic in nature, take on a pretty bizarre tonal quality. [18 August 2012]


Date: 11 August 2005

Double Leopards - Savage Summer Sun

Label: Hospital Productions

Format: CD

Source: Mike Bernstein

Cost: $0



Date: 11 August 2005

Rainbow and the Red Eye - When it's Time to Play at Being Human

Label: Heavy Tapes

Format: CS

Source: Mike Bernstein

Cost: $0

Ten minutes of drone/noise, sounding like two layers ("Rainbow" and "the Red Eye" perhaps?) that oscillates between ringing, reverb-laden lo-fi drones and lumbering clunkyness (sometimes at the same time).  Not bad at all but it doesn't last long enough to wear out its welcome. [9 Feb 2009]



Date: 11 August 2005

White Rock - Tarpit

Label: Troubleman Unlimited

Format: LP

Source: Mike Simonetti

Cost: $0

This is a collaboration between Mike and Maya with Brian and Nate from Mouthus, and it's really great, showcasing elements brought from both sides of the collab.  There's the deep, vocal-based drones Mike and Maya were doing in Double Leopards, but also the noisy, textural rock that Mouthus does so well, though this doesn't "rock" per se.  It actually reminds me a bit of the Brast Burn/Karuna Khyal albums though a bit more horizontal.  There's a great amount of separation between all of the layers so you can really hear what each musician is doing (though it's not clear who is doing what).  I guess this is a proto-Religious Knives lineup though it doesn't sound much like the current RK sound.  [13 Jan 2009]


Date: 11 August 2005

Pope Joanna - Separate Wounds

Label: Ignivomous

Format: CD-R

Source: Kyle Lapidus

Cost: $0



Date: 11 August 2005

Dilloway, Aaron - 

Label: Heavy Tapes

Format: CS

Source: Mike Bernstein

Cost: $0



Date: 12 August 2005

Hargreaves, Blake - The Waxathon

Label: Flourescent Friends

Format: LP

Source: Blake Hargreaves

Cost: $0

I saw this great band, Dreamcatcher, over 3 years ago in Baltimore.  They played in the basement of this fucked up punk squat house - I was on tour with Auk Theatre/Eyes and Arms of Smoke.  The show was a weird bummer, but Dreamcatcher were great and I swapped records with the leader, Blake Hargreaves.  I remembered this being really insane when I listened to it in 2005, but now returning to it, it's much different than I remembered.  There's a lot of processed, distorted vocals and contrapuntal electronics, and at the time I remembered there being some hip-hop influence but I have no idea why.  I guess I've seen a lot of vocal experimentation since then but this isn't droney, it's choppy and rather anti-musical.  There's a deliberate disruption of rhythm and mood and it never really sounds like it's focused.  The outsider vibe is genuine though.  There's some great concrète stuff, such as Hargreaves answering machine tapes (simliar to that cassette release I have by him which is more recent).  This record will probably lie in obscurity forever since it came out in 2002, but it definitely strikes a note more successfully than a lot of what has followed.  [2 Jan 2009]


Date: 14 August 2005

Pelt - Untitled

Label: VHF Records

Format: CD

Source: Mike Gangloff

Cost: $0

This is the first proper Pelt full-length to feature the group as a quartet (and I don't think there were many with this lineup).  This is a pretty definitive example of the acoustic Pelt sound.  Mikel D is on shrutibox which really dominates the first track; Jack Rose's acoustic picking comes to the forefront on track 2 (which reminds me of Pelt the last time I saw them, at that weird space in Pittsburgh that Manny briefly ran called The Eye). Mike G is rocking the esraj thoughtout this disc, though it's not always allowed to shine because of the general drone soup.  The last track is Pat Best solo, getting crazy on the cello (and I mean crazy good).  Pelt were really important to me around 1999-2001 and that string of VHF releases (Max Meadows, Techeod, For Michael Hannahs, Empty Bell and I guess Rob's Choice) are "classics" to me, even though I don't listen to them much anymore and the average person might think it's overkill for me to own so many Pelt CDs.  This disc would have stood up against any of those if it had come for me at that time; I still think it's awesome, powerful music but it's just no longer a big influence on me.  So I'll have to remember to spin this one instead of one of the aforementioned 'classics'.  [8 Feb 2009]



Date: 14 August 2005

Nils Økland - Bris

Label: Rune Grammofon

Format: CD Album

Source: Aquarius

Cost: €16.98

I started getting into Rune Grammofon releases around 2003 but when I heard Nils Økland I really fell in love.  His work is actually pretty different than other Rune Grammofon releases - it's very rooted in traditional/classical musics from Norway, and not really electroacoustic or improvisatory or any of the other things I associate with the label.  Well, it could be somewhat improvisational but it's based on traditional themes.  This follows the awesome Straum with a similar approach - light accompaniment but the main focus being the shimmery, amazing sounding violin of Mr. Økland.  This is almost like minimalist shoegazer - I can just get lost in the sound of the violin, radiating overtones and whispers. The images that come out of it are great though - it reminds me of the woods at night, Bergman films (of course), and fireflies buzzing around on a dry summer night.  [9 Feb 2009]



Date: 14 August 2005

United Supreme Council - Oastem! Vibe Orchestra

Label: Eclipse Records

Format: Vinyl 12" LP

Source: Mike Gangloff

Cost: $0

Here's a long and satisfying jam that is essentially Pelt with some others. It's never seen as a Pelt release or even known by many people, which is a shame as it contains some thick, heavy passages. There's some major bongo drumming on side 1, over which the thick, searing drones are laid, and the mood takes it's time to develop. The piece extends onto side two, where it takes on the screaming hellbeast quality. By the end we've been taken to a dark place, a musical communion of a band I truly miss in this lineup (even with the extra people who are just extended guests here). [30 November 2012]


Date: 14 August 2005

Mountain Goats - Come, Come To The Sunset Tree

Label: Not On Label

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Aquarius

Cost: $15.98

The acoustic, non-Vandersliced form of The Sunset Tree is actually a very different album; there are different songs, and others missing (Hast thou forgotten the tetrapods?) and the intimacy of the boombox is something that I think Darnielle sounds most comfortable with, since he's recorded 500-some songs that way. I would have to say I prefer this take, as the confessional, emotional energy is even more focused without the bass and drums and other arrangements. The scene ends badly as you might imagine - and with all that has been said about this album's subject matter, I tihnk it's definitely a step forward from Darnielle, who I think has struggled to convey what he used to convey to me before The Coroner's Gambit (but maybe it's just my problem). [24 Aug 2005]


Date: 21 August 2005

Robin Kenyatta - Girl From Martinique

Label: ECM Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

Slightly dull ECM offering. Sold.


Date: 21 August 2005

Buckingham Nicks

Label: Polydor

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $9

When I bought this, $9 felt a bit steep for what was essentially the proto-release of the most commercially successful band ever (or maybe they were second to the Eagles, whatever) but I guess it's actually quite rare as these things go. The Buckingham Nicks LP is great - as solid as any of the three great Fleetwood Mac records, but with a brash innocence. There's a few familiar songs - 'Crystal', written by Stevie but with Lindsay singing lead being a nice alternate version to the more well-known one. 'Stephanie' is a wonderful instrumental with British folk influence, though still retaining that distinctive 70's pop-rock flavour. 'Frozen Love' is the only tune written collaboratively and it's built around a driving bass/drums crunch, with breaks into guitar arpeggios. This is probably the happiest these two ever were as a couple, and it's remarkable how fully-formed the sound is - considering they joined an existing British blues-rock band, it sounds like they really called the shots when that happened. [15 September 2012]


Date: 21 August 2005

David Sylvian + Holger Czukay - Premonition

Label: Venture Records (2)

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $3

I bought this record over seven years ago but never once played it and didn't even remember I had it. A weird, invisible warp makes the outer minutes of each side unplayable but dropping the stylus in a bit, I find pretty much what I expected - a lush, flowing soundworld controlled by two masters of texture and atmosphere. Side 1 is very 'ambient' but aggressively so - with full on plush sounds that envelop you, moving in a way that it's easy to lie back and let it go somewhere with you. Side two is a bit more otherworldly, with some distant voices brought in as a suggestion, a relatively exploratory piano part, and no real direction.  It's all just so lovely it almost becomes hard to stomach, but it's a great escape, and I'm sad that the warp means I can't completely give myself to this LP. [2 December 2012]


Date: 21 August 2005

The David Boykin Outet - Evidence of Life on Other Planets vol. 1

Label: Thrill Jockey

Format: LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $5

I'm not really sure why Thrill Jockey released this record. Boykin is a more than competent tenor saxophonist who I saw live once solo, and he had a pretty good band in Chicago. But this is nothing particularly mindblowing, and it doesn't really seem very 'Thrill Jockey' to release a record that sounds a bit like early Sun Ra - that American influence of composers like Fletcher Henderson or Duke Ellington. The titles also suggest a space theme that doesn't really jump out of the music, though this is a pretty solid record. 'Hypnotic', the last track, is the most appealing, taking it's time and being content to just roll out a sassy, coy melody that manages to actually burrow into my head a bit. [23 August 2012]


Date: 9 September 2005

Dredd Foole And The Din - The Whys Of Fire

Label: Father Yod

Format: CD Album

Source: Mike Gangloff

Cost: $0

I've never been a big fan of Dredd Foole, a New England-based artist who does experimental, often high-pitched vocal work over improvised electric drones. This has a pretty great lineup as 'The Din' - Thurston Moore, the classic Pelt trio lineup of Best/Rose/Gangloff, and Corsano; yet, I still find myself mostly annoying when Foole himself begins to domainte the proceedings. There are some excellent, lovely bits of interplay especially by what I think is Pelt, which is mostly why I keep this disc - and anything with israj on it, I can't toss. But getting through the whole disc is somewhat of a chore. [28 December 2012]


Date: 9 September 2005

MikelDimmickSpiralJoyBand - Searing Float

Label: Klang

Format: CD-R

Source: Spiral Joy Band

Cost: $0



Date: 20 September 2005

Directing Hand - An Old Soul At The Helm

Label: Chocolate Monk

Format: CDr

Source: Alex

Cost: £0

Alex's Directing Hand project pulls together his interest in percussion with his focus on drone-based work, getting rather noisy at times. He approaches the drums as only he does, and the other layers of sounds are built up to create a scattered, aggravated drone that never becomes placid. Chris, Hanna and his grandfather add to the mix on one track, and the track with Christina Carter has some nice piano playing among the fuckedupness. [20 Oct 2005]


Date: 15 October 2005

United Bible Studies - The Solar Observatory

Label: 23 Productions

Format: CDr Album

Source: Gavin

Cost: £0



Date: 15 October 2005

The Skaters - Gambling In Ohpa's Shadow

Label: PseudoArcana

Format: CDr

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £7

Hear ye, hear ye - there was a time, just a mere seven years ago, where the so-called 'noise underground' was conquered by two strange Californians called the Skaters. They were named after John Ashebery's amazing poem and they came seemingly out of nowhere with a recording called Dark Rye Bread, and minds were blown. For a brief period I became intertwined with these fellows, first meeting them on Marcia Bassett's roof in Brooklyn, then again in Glasgow several times, then also various other random encounters in places like Paris and Berlin. At times, they made music in the 'ecstatic drone' genre better than anyone ever had; at other times they were just 'ok'. Their legendary live set at Subcurrent 2006 failed to really move me, but everyone else thought it was the bees knees. Gambling in Ohpas Shadow came from their original run of CDrs, the material which they based their legacy on, if there is such a legacy now - I suspect James's solo work has probably eclipsed Skaters in terms of popularity, but I still have a soft spot for it. I forgot how actually dirty and distorted Skaters recordings are - and how impulsive, wild and improvised they are despite being, as a friend put it, "one really great sound that just goes on for 20 minutes". It's monolithic, but there's still a ton of movement; it's music of the truest psychedelic form, though it's rough around the edges and carefully calibrated as such. Skaters are no idiot savants; they knew exactly what they wanted to do aesthetically, and the two of them had a pretty incredible relationship even if it they were two of the most ridiculous people I've ever met. I'm still a bit pissy at Spencer Clark cause he owes me money but James I will always love, even if I never see him again. This is the only one of their physical releases that landed in my music accumulation from this time but my fondest (and least fond, come to think of it) memories are strictly non-musical anyway. [23 August 2012]


Date: 15 October 2005

Ben Patterson - Early Works

Label: Alga Marghen

Format: CD Album

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

Ben Patterson's early Fluxus compositions begin with something recorded in the late 90's, a bit of an irrelevant start since this is supposed to be 'early' work, but the Fluxus spirit is evident - Patterson narrates while repetitive foley artist sounds blast through. The rest of the disc actually is recorded from 1960-62 and contains compositions performed on double bass, paper, wind-up toys and other things. The recordings are live, so we hear the audience laughing and applauding, and for something as ephemeral (and visual) as a Fluxus performance, the format of a sound recording seems really inadequate. But if you're interested in the historic document of an amazing movement in music, like me, this is lovely. The last cut, 'Pond', features a small army of goofy noisemakers, using their voices as well as toys and other junk, and it's a brilliant bit of fractured madness. [20 August 2012]


Date: 15 October 2005

Ray Off - Ghost Wolf of Thunder Mountain

Label: United Fairy Moon

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

Another randomly purchased gem; I think these guys are from New Zealand but that's about all I know of it. This disc is quite diverse, beginning with some beautiful collages of acoustic guitar and whistling, ghosty drones to create a very grand outdoor feeling. Then some weird electronics come in and it sounds like Otto Luening crashed the party. Then it gets pretty again, and the whistling comes back in. It's about 50 minutes long and it shows a real mixture of ideas and styles. Very nice. [2 Nov 2005]


Date: 15 October 2005

Duck - Pass the Spoon

Label: Spirit of Orr

Format: DVD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £10



Date: 15 October 2005

V/A - Invisible Pyramid: Elegy Box

Label: Last Visible Dog

Format: 6CD

Source: Ben Reynolds

Cost: £20



Date: 15 October 2005

Aethr Myth'd - Deux Acren

Label: Manhand

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

Strings rumble around and fall apart, in a thick, hazy mess that reminds me a bit of Enos Slaughter live, only with more space. And a lot nicer. After one listen I'm not quite sure what he's trying to do here but I am curious to listen again. The world of modern folk-derived experimentalism continues to deepen. [6 Nov 2005]


Date: 15 October 2005

Ashtray Navigations - The Love That Whirrs

Label: Last Visible Dog

Format: CD

Source: Ben Reynolds

Cost: £0

Lengthy drone workouts from the Ashtray lineup of Phil, Alex and Ben. This is very droney, though twoards the end of the disc there is some pretty guitar playing which I assume is Ben. While there is a lot of noodling and meandering, Alex adding color with percussion, etc. it stays within it's own boundaries. There are points where I think they want to really let it rip, but they contain themselves. There's some nice ampbuzz and AC hum throughout the disc. Well done, boys! [19 Oct 2005]


Date: 15 October 2005

Roots Of Madness - The Girl In The Chair

Label: De Stijl

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

De Stijl reissued this lost private-press record which is really a ramshackle exploration of different genres. It starts with a 12 minute freakout that touches on free jazz, shortwave radio recordings, and electronic composition, but then later on that side of the record we get beat poetry, slide guitar, and a straight-up folk song at the end. The flip is no more clear - there's some vague blues-band jamming, and very amateurish singing. The whole release is totally off-the-cuff, recorded live for the majority of it, and yet somehow still maintaining a collagey, Faust Tapes-esque feeling. I never think to pull this out and listen but it's a lot more fun than I remembered. [18 September 2012]


Date: 15 October 2005

New Blockaders - First Live Performance

Label: Vinyl-on-demand

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

Live at Morden Tower in Newcastle, 1983! Thirty years ago almost, and this has Richard and a second Rupenus ripping up sound in a frantic, multiphasic manner. It's impossible to focus on any one element because it's so busy, but that's not a bad thing - it actually doesn't get tiresome or irritating.
