I've always loved New Blockaders for having an incredible depth to their sound construction, avoiding the monotony of typical harsh noise/power electronics artists. This is pretty goddam experimental, but also has qualities that I would call "musical", which is why I've been drawn to artists like John Wiese and New Blockaders - there's the same drama, motion, beauty, texture and magic that so-called "regular" music has. I was only 3 when this was made, but I did see their last live performance (as far as I know) which attained the physicality the best noise sets I've ever seen have achieved - I also think of some Wiese sets, Spencer of course, Emil Bealieu, and Testical Hazard - and while the LP doesn't have the sheer blistering energy of that, I can still feel some of that heat. [16 July 2012]


Date: 16 October 2005

Brothers Of The Occult Sisterhood - Animal Speak

Label: Music Your Mind Will Love You

Format: CDr

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £9

I bought this randomly having not heard the group, part of a strategy I had at the VT merch table during Instal. It turned out to be quite a pleasant surprise - instrumental folky noodling, sure, but not at all "free" - quite composed, together and structured. I think they are from Australia and at a full 80 minutes you get a lot of it, but it sounds quite nice and I'd like to see them live (some tracks at the end fall into a more jamgrass/Kraut feel, not unlike Urdog maybe, which sounds fun live). [20 Oct 2005]


Date: 16 October 2005

Ashtray Navigations - Dooder Pedal Jugend Reflecting North

Label: Memoirs of an Aesthete

Format: Cassette

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0

Phil told me that he just made this tape because he was playing with a new 4-track he got, but it sounds great - maybe a little bit more exciting than The Love That Whirrs, even. The rumbling, noisy drones lurch around, screaming out at points. It's a bit more abrasive and lofi, but complements the full band well. My new tape deck automatically keeps flipping, so this played 3 or 4 times before I wanted to turn it off. [6 Nov 2005]


Date: 16 October 2005

Ashtray Navigations - Blues Power Cake

Label: Memoirs Of An Aesthete

Format: CDr

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0

Ashtray from circa the time I met Phil, a full album-length blast of his fuzzy dronewaves, and pretty fucking solid. Alex Neilson guests on the 22 minute jam 'Haight-Ashbury Legal' as well as a cellist; this is an extemporized jazz jam, sounding a bit like an Alice Coltrane-flavoured concoction, but this is a 'blues power cake' after all. It's a really mellow and relaxing jam and has a lot of jazzy noodling - a different side of Phil Todd. Closer 'Skylark in a Cake' is more along the buzzing, burning Ashtray sound and order is restored. [29 December 2012]


Date: 16 October 2005

V/A - Patchouli Echoes

Label: Chocolate Monk

Format: 2xCD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £8



Date: 16 October 2005

Birds Of Delay - Spitmule

Label: Alcoholic Narcolepsy

Format: CDr Album

Source: Birds of Delay

Cost: £0



Date: 16 October 2005

Sun City Girls - Montreal Pop

Label: Not On Label

Format: Vinyl LP Unofficial Release

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £12

Every time I move my record collection from place to place, I should think about the many kilograms of absurd nonsense I am dragging around. Now, I'd never part with this - all SCG vinyl is like gold to me, even if it's fool's gold. This is supposed to be a bootleg release of a 2004 gig in Montreal, though I suspect it's more 'legitimate' than it looks. The Girls are in full-on goofball mood here. The whole concert is a big jam, but this isn't improv completely, though the guitar playing is skittery and wild - these are clearly rehearsed songs that just never appeared anywhere else as well as free jazz excursions. There's a series of songs, mostly built around Alan and I guess Charles Gocher's nonsense singing - 'Six Kids of Mine' being a tribute to crib death; 'Man Destroys the Things He Love' in two parts. Some covers as well - 'Natural High' by the Commodores, a jokey yet soulful mess, until Rick Bishop busts out a note-for-note perfect solo in the middle. Lots of insults to French-Canadians too, not that there's anything wrong with that -- even the LP labels are adorned with "Guy LaFleur's Ladies" and "I Love Poutine", so we're clearly at a high level of discourse. But I laugh throughout - I love all sides of SCG and if they weren't being comedians half the time I would truly love them less. By the end, it's descended into screaming and taunting the crowd, mostly for being Canadian. Overall, this is probably the most unrestrained and ridiculous SCG release and that's saying a lot. [9 November 2012]


Date: 16 October 2005

Visitations

Label: Time-Lag

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £9

I'm not sure where I sit with Visitations - I enjoyed their live show a lot but didn't care for the part of their first CD I heard, which someone assured me was brilliant. This one definitely doesn't live up to their potential. It takes awhile to get going, opening with acoustic strumdrone and some moaning. The songwriting seems to be less of a focus here, with the group instead creating sketches using their limited palette. [6 Nov 2005]


Date: 22 October 2005

Modey Lemon - The Curious City

Label: Mute Records Ltd.

Format: CD

Source: Barry Chad

Cost: £0

I was around when Modey Lemon was getting going - quite a lot, seeing them go from a sideproject of Phil and Paul's band Dean Swagger into a full-fledged local sensation, then adding Jason to the band and starting to explore a new sound. This picks up a few years later after I had been away and not really witnessing their glory days. Its a long disc, at 54 minutes, and produced quite well - as a driving, catchy indie rock band should sound, with some psychedelic flourishes. The booklet is great, with Phil's lyrics written out and a nice handmade/zine feel to the notes. Phil has such a fairytale sense of songwriting and it suits this - the soft, fun side of the band that the driving riffs and Bonham-esque drumming might not indicate. The ragged two-piece sound is so far behind here that I wouldn't even necessarily recognise this if I had it played for me Invisible Jukebox style - though i guess this is really what Modey Lemon were. 'Countries' is a song that Phil and i used to play together during our brief jam sessions on Penn Ave, some of which i have unmixed somewhere (especially missing that song 'Architects and Warriors' -- what did I actually contribute to those sessions? I can't even remember). Ultimately, as close as I was with these guys (Jason remains a very close friend) I can't say that I am ultimately very familiar with their discography. I think they put out another full-length after this but I never even heard it. [1 October 2012]


Date: 1 November 2005

Ben Reynolds - Music Is The Music Language

Label: Ikuisuus

Format: CD

Source: Ben

Cost: £0



Date: 27 November 2005

Reynolds, Ben - 

Label: Time-Lag

Format: CD-R

Source: Ben

Cost: £0



Date: 3 December 2005

Air Guitar Magazine - Bass is the Place

Label: Enamel

Format: CD

Source: Pete Spynda

Cost: $0



Date: 4 December 2005

Box Codax - Boys And Girls

Label: The Thin Man

Format: CD Single

Source: Nick McCarthy

Cost: £0

CD singles are a dumb format but it's appropriate for this Box Codax release, which is incredibly silly. Stupid, even, as 'Boys and Girls' is some sort of weird jokey novelty cut, with funny voices and everything. The inherent Germanness of the artists keeps it from sounding like the Bloodhound Gang or something like that - there's actually something commendable about the tune. "B-side", 'Red Wine in Tunis', is goofy spoke narrative over a somewhat pretty electric guitar figure. Not much else to say here as it's such a blip in my consciousness. [24 July 2012]


Date: 4 December 2005

Franz Ferdinand - You Could Have It So Much Better

Label: Domino Recording Company Ltd.

Format: CD Album

Source: Nick McCarthy

Cost: £0

It's funny to listen to this, cause I never had before - there was shrinkwrap on it still today. Nick passed me both of their CDs when I lived with him, which was just after this came out - the second CD by the biggest sensation in the UK at the time. And now just a few years later, they almost feel forgotten, though I'm sure they can still pack a venue on their tours. If they're even still active, which I don't know. This starts off strong, with 'The Fallen' and then the ELO-influenced 'Do You Want To' which I think was the single (at least, I remember seeing posters for it wheat-pasted all over Glasgow in Autumn 2005). This was the second album which was supposed to establish them as more than a one-hit wonder; I'm not sure if it was successful. It's certainly as good as a British guitar-indie record can be, with the appropriate "obscure" influences (in this case, Orange Juice) and a modern, crunchy production. The songwriting is just OK; nothing has the beer-commercial appeal of 'Take Me Out', which is probably why this was less successful. 'Walk Away', which was a soft-rock leaning ballad, and I think the second single, is probably the Franz Ferdinand song I like the most, and the only thing I really remember from hearing these songs a lot at that time. [30 December 2012]


Date: 4 December 2005

Franz Ferdinand

Label: Domino Recording Company Ltd.

Format: CD

Source: Nick McCarthy

Cost: £0



Date: 4 December 2005

Sade - Lovers Rock

Label: Epic

Format: CD

Source: Manuela Gernedel

Cost: £0

How did I end up with this? I think my flatmate Manuela had it and told me that she didn't like it, so she gave it to me. I like this album. I actually don't know much about Sade except she's been around for awhile and it's pronounced Shaw-Dei, kinda like 'Shadynasty's' from the TV series It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia. This is a great album of dark soul - great singing, great songwriting, great production. It belongs to the "slow jams" genre perhaps, which is quite unrepresented in my record collection. The opening cut 'By Your Side' I used to jam a lot around 2002. Never checked out her other records and probably never will. [9 October 2012]


Date: 8 December 2005

Stalk-Forrest Group - St.Cecilia

Label: Radioactive

Format: LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £14.99

This is a reissue of the pre-Blue Öyster Cult band, led by Buck Dharma. It's a sunnier affair than BÖC, with long, winding guitar jams and a bouncy, late-60's psychedelia feel. The dark obsessions of those brilliant first few BOC albums are there, but not quite as obvious. This sorta reminds me of the 80's paisley underground scene of bands like Rain Parade. I don't know if this was ever issued in the first place - it may be the first time it's ever seen the light of day - but I'm glad it has. It's a worthy addition to the BÖC canon and it stands up against those first 3 albums. [21 May 2006]


Date: 15 December 2005

One Ensemble of Daniel Padden - Live on VPRO Radio

Label: Brainwashed

Format: CD

Source: Daniel

Cost: £0

This era of Daniel's band might be the one I know best, though Alex is still on drums here and I guess it's the era after he left that I saw and heard the most. It's before Daniel dropped his name from the project and treated it more as a band, though that name change isn't tremendously meaningful. This is a well-recorded radio session and has some great interplay, particularly between Chris and Alex who had such a good relationship at the time; but ultimately it's still driven by the vocals, which are on most tracks. 'Sleep Norway Sleep', 'Weevils' and 'The Tumble Waltz' in the middle are where I start to drift; I used to know this material well but I feel their later work, particularly what was on Wayward the Fourth, eclipses it so much. There's far more neoclassical musical figures here than later, which is also something I'm glad has been moved past. I hope I don't sound too critical; it's a lovely CD (and packaged in a lovely handmade case by Brainwashed) but it's certainly minor compared to the studio work. I guess as a document of the band with Alex this is probably the one to have. [29 December 2012]


Date: 8 January 2006

David Bowie - Lodger

Label: RCA International

Format: Vinyl LP Album Reissue

Source: car boot sale

Cost: £1

I bought this almost a year ago, and now at years-end review of this spreadsheet I oughta get around to listening to it (though I have heard it - and enjoyed it - before). This finds Bowie in the dark art-rock mode, with creative production by Tony Visconti and several songs written and arranged with Eno. This unsurprisingly recalls Eno's work with Talking Heads at the same time, though perhaps a bit weirder. The opening track sounds like something off Cale's Paris 1919, but the rest of the album is more akin to Eno's own art-rock experiments. There weren't any hits on this, but 'Boys Keep Swinigng' could have been one. [26 Dec 2006]


Date: 28 January 2006

Burning Star Core - Voice and Electronics Live 8/25/05

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CD-R

Source: Spencer

Cost: £0



Date: 28 January 2006

Burning Star Core - Inside The Shadow

Label: DroneDisco

Format: CDr

Source: Spencer

Cost: £0

This has become a favorite of Spencer's limited releases (and is due for reissue on Hospital as a 'proper' CD soon). The two title tracks are deep, pulsing drone, with the first one decorated by 'metals', recalling side 1 of the Brighter Summer Day LP in a parallel dimension. The middle track is a very lo-fi, grungy dirge that fits well between the other pieces. [26 Dec 2006]


Date: 28 January 2006

C. S. Yeh - Solo Violin 1-4

Label: DroneDisco

Format: 2xCassette Limited Edition

Source: Spencer

Cost: £0

It's nice to hear Spencer under his own name. This set is in blown out, blistering mono, with some cleaner parts but a pretty thick vibe throughout. Some of the scratchier parts have a very disorienting feel. Other sections are surprisingly minimal, going for density rather than technique. [1 Feb 2005]


Date: 28 January 2006

C. S. Yeh - Solo Violin 5-8

Label: DroneDisco

Format: 2xCassette Limited Edition

Source: Spencer

Cost: £0

Second set of 4 5-minute violin improvisations, also including 'objects' has some incredible moments - side 5 in particular is a grinding, jerky bridge recording that is a brilliant approach to the violin. Some repeating loops are used and are a bit distracting; the best bits are the rawest ones for me. [26 Dec 2006]


Date: 5 February 2006

Vibracathedral Orchestra - Ragged + Right

Label: Not On Label

Format: CDr Limited Edition

Source: Bridget Hayden

Cost: £0



Date: 5 February 2006

Vibracathedral Orchestra - Tuning to the Rooster

Label: Important

Format: CD

Source: Bridget Hayden

Cost: £0

It's great to pull this out, one of the Vibracathedral releases that I've listened to the least, and on a day when Neil Campbell tweeted me, too. This is the classic lineup and it features expanded versions of some previously released material. The opening cut, 'Baptism > Bar > Blues', absolutely explodes with fantastic cymbal-bashing, a driving riff, and ecstatic horns. It's about the most joyous moments I've ever heard from VCO and this is a band whose reputation is based on ecstatic drone jams. In fifteen minutes it doesn't really change, of course, but that's not why we tune in to Radio Vibracathedral. Everything segues together into a harmonic blur. We get all manner of instruments, tuned to maximum overtones, making the title appropriate. This is an actual studio recording, and I must say it amplifies the beauty of this music, greatly. I also pull out Versatile Arab Chord Chart as my go-to VCO release but this one is maybe better. [31 December 2012]


Date: 5 February 2006

Vibracathedral Orchestra - VCO @ ATP 2004

Label: Spirit Of Orr

Format: CDr

Source: Bridget Hayden

Cost: £0

A live Vibracathedral CD-R that sounds like, well, Vibracathedral. Maybe it's a bit more free than my favorite recordings of theirs; as one long track it goes through a few different movements but it's basically a big VCO jam. There's a lot of whistling and static layered over everything, making the already inadequate recording sound even worse. [26 Dec 2006]


Date: 17 February 2006

Helvetica Is The Perfume Of The City

Label: Foxglove

Format: CDr Mini Limited Edition

Source: Ben Reynolds

Cost: £0

The Stoke-on-Trent supergroup of Phil Todd, Andy Jarvis and Ben Reynolds collaborate here on what is probably the best project title Ben Ren will ever participate in. It begins with a Ben-led acoustic number while Andy and Phil scrape around in the background creating various textures underneath. Track two introduces some jazzy percussion with electric guitar meanderings, creating a free, spacious piece. [29 Dec 2006]


Date: 19 February 2006

Chris Corsano - The Young Cricketer

Label: Hot Cars Warp Records

Format: CDr Album

Source: Chris Corsano

Cost: €0

A solo Chris Corsano disc which was later reissued I believe, this finds Chris bashing about on his drumset (as to be expected) but also saxophone mouthpieces, plastic tubes, violins,and other weird stuff.  The ringing, tonal sounds go well with the drum freakouts, and the overall album feels extremely cohesive.  Sadly,my CDr skips a lot so I can't listen to this on my main discman/CD player right now - but it's a great example of what he can do on his own, carving out something more unique than the average free jazz solo drum record.  [22 Mar 2009]



Date: 19 February 2006

Nalle - By Chance Upon Waking

Label: Pickled Egg Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Chris Hladowski

Cost: £0



Date: 19 February 2006

Dredd Foole and the Din - Ghost Rider/Frankie Teardrop

Label: Open Mouth

Format: cassette

Source: Chris Corsano

Cost: £0



Date: 22 February 2006

Tusk Lord - Familiar Trails

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CDr Album

Source: Mike Kasunic

Cost: £0

Very interesting direction from Mike K, who I last saw layering air organs in delicate, beautiful live show. This CD is largely acoustic guitar focused, though his guitar playing twists and rolls with weird lurching rhythms, denying any sort of familiar sounds. It has a vaguely Eastern feel, perhaps by nature, but it seems to exist in its own sphere. The disc uses drones but doesn't rely too heavily on them. Concise, skillful, and an impressive first effort. [27 Feb 2005]


Date: 3 March 2006

Nonhorse - Tale of Escape

Label: Desert

Format: CD-R

Source: Lucas Crane

Cost: £0

A CD-R of Lucas solo, centered around the cassette-tape manipulations he does so well in Wooden Wand. The sound is appropriately lo-fi, pulled from all sorts of unlisted sources. There's some effects involves, generally delay, but it's not overwhelming. I can just imagine him rocking the crossfader on his mixer like he does when they play live... cutting the tapes in and out, he creates a staccato "cloud of fire", showcasing his fascination with sound recording. [21 May 2006]


Date: 4 March 2006

Croene, Frederik and Esther Venroy - Hout

Label: Audiobot

Format: CD

Source: Carlo

Cost: £0



Date: 4 March 2006

Evil Moisture / Metalux - Split

Label: Veglia

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Laurent

Cost: £0

This is a split between these two very odd sound/noise artists, given to me by that lovely guy Laurent whose house I stayed at once in Mechelen, Belgium. The Evil Moisture side is one long piece of harsh electronics, with gurgling, churning momentum underneath and various layers of buzzing. It's constantly changing, active in the higher registers, and engaging for the most part though it does become tiresome. The Metalux side is a real pleasure though, with weird songforms organised around thick guitars, angelic vocals, and pinging keyboards. It's much more genre-bending than I ever expected from Metalux, who I am only familiar with through their work on that Freenoise tour but now wish I had checked out more of in their heyday. [12 Aug 2012]


Date: 8 March 2006

Spunk - En Aldeles Forferdelig Sykdom

Label: Rune Grammofon

Format: CD

Source: Monorail

Cost: £12.99

Thought this is the only Spunk album I actually own on an official format, this is probably the one I've listened to the least just because it's on CD and I never think to listen to CDs (despite having hundreds of them).  A shame too, because it's a really amazing, adventurous exploration of sound and spirit.  The recording is great too - quite dry, and allowing the weird electronics and processed instruments to have their full dynamic range as opposed to a reverb-soaked copout.  There's a lot of motion and percussive elements, I think largely processed voice, but held together as a group work.  It's hard to get a sense of the composed to improvised ratio, but it doesn't really matter because its such a fascinating listen.  I don't know if Spunk are still an active band - they haven't released anything since this - but if not, this would be a great way to go out. [22 Mar 2009]



Date: 8 March 2006

Arve Henriksen - Chiaroscuro

Label: Rune Grammofon

Format: CD Album

Source: Monorail

Cost: £12.99

Henriksen is a trumpet player and I bought this on my Rune Grammafon-love and also the recommendation of Russell from Monorail. This isn't my favorite Rune release as it strayes into new agey territory quite a bit; some of the trumpet parts sound like weird female vocals, and the overall aesthetic is a bit off the mark from what I usually like about these Norwegians. Still, I might give it another listen and see if it grows on me somewhat. [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 11 March 2006

Wounded Knee  - Wee Reveries

Label: Benbecula

Format: CDr

Source: Drew

Cost: £3



Date: 11 March 2006

Wounded Knee - New Flesh

Label: no label

Format: CD-R

Source: Drew

Cost: £3



Date: 11 March 2006

Usurper - Go For It

Label: Giant Tank

Format: CD-R

Source: Ali from Usurper

Cost: £3



Date: 11 March 2006

Birds Of Delay - Floating Knives

Label: Kovorox Sound

Format: CDr

Source: Kovorox?

Cost: £4



Date: 18 March 2006

Culver - Zero

Label: none

Format: CD-R

Source: Culver guy?

Cost: £0

A really refreshing blast of drone on this blank CD-R with no information besides the title. The first track is a metallic wash that wouldn't be out of place coming from a R!!!/S!!! record; the other bits get harsher and a bit more active, making me think that Culver might be one of the acts to see in the UK right now. Phil Todd has called Culver Britain's best-kept secret, and this CD, while hard to describe, shows a lot of promise - I should hear more! [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 19 March 2006

Ashtray Navigations - Strawberries And Ice

Label: Memoirs Of An Aesthete

Format: CDr Mini

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0



Date: 19 March 2006

Mel Delaney/Bridget Hayden - Ground Zero Celebration Pessary

Label: Memoirs of an Aesthete

Format: cassette

Source: Mel

Cost: £0

Noisy jam between two of Leeds' finest;; Bridget is on guitar (I think), with some soloing over the electronic Delaney bubble. At one part the guitar totally kicks into "The Venerable Song" or whatever it's called by Sun City Girls, though it's not credited as a cover on the (lovely) J-card - call ASCAP/BMI (or Ass-Cap Bummy as Joe Carse used to call it) and turn them in for copyright violation! By side two I lost interest in the murk but that's not necessarily a negative comment. [17 Apr 2006]


Date: 19 March 2006

Ashtray Navigations - Aurora Grease Sweetrocket

Label: Memoirs of an Aesthete

Format: 3" CD-R

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0

I remember that Phil was going through a 3" CD-r period for awhile when I first met him, though I got this from him on the Lied Music tour so it musta been a leftover, as the Internet tells me this came out in 2004. 'Can Dialectics Break Bricks?' has the presence of some cheap keyboards playing a busy, ecstatic melody under the rubble. 'Two chimes for a Tuesday' has chimes indeed, another lighter, higher approach. The heavy drone comes in for 'A Four Foot Banana', which features drumming and a searching acid-saturated guitar lead. Of course, it burns out rather than fading away. [25 July 2012]


Date: 20 March 2006

Crank Sturgeon - Crank Sturgeon Has A Combover Landscape Tapir

Label: Crank Sturgeon (White)

Format: CDr

Source: Johnny Scarr

Cost: £0



Date: 20 March 2006

V/A - Freenoise: Fusion

Label: Freenoise

Format: CD-R

Source: Johnny Scarr

Cost: £0



Date: 24 March 2006

Vitamin B12 - Badges

Label: Tip Top

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: Alasdair Willis

Cost: £7

This was never my favorite B12 record but listening again, the fourth side is an excellent side-long collage of musique concrete, moving between reverb-treated spoken word sections (of dry British howto-diy instructions) and jittery, nervous scraping.  It anticipates the Candy triple LP but has a significantly wider palette, and it may mark a major change in direction for Alasdair.  The first record is the one I'm not that crazy about.  It has its moments, but generally is more related to the earlier 4LP boxset stuff, which is strangely dancey.  Parts of side two actually remind me of something like The Orb - kinda blissful, chillout music with samples that doesn't even hint at the warped sounds that are capable of coming out of the B12 project.  [26 Jan 2009]



Date: 24 March 2006

Vitamin B12 - Cutey's Carpet

Label: Tip Top

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Alasdair Willis

Cost: £4

This is one of the crisper and more structured Vitamin B12 records, though it's full of jerky stop-start rhythms.  Both sides are made up of numerous short tracks but it really is just two side-long pieces.  The first side is an instrumental, largely sax led piece that is either constructed entirely from cut up single notes, or a very composed New York jazz kinda sound.  I think it's probably assembled by Alasdair from individual samples as it sounds computer-precise, but it's awesome either way.  Side B brings in some singing from Karen Mori and has a lumbering, awkward Residents type of feel.  It's rare to compare the B12 to any other artist and this comparison is only approximate - really, it sounds like a clean "pop" version of the Vitamin B12, and it's hard to believe that my experience with these guys has been in largely improvised settings.  By the end we're being told that we are eating at Denny's, a strange sentiment to close a really strange (yet accessible) album. When I first got this record 3 years ago I wasn't so into it but right now I'm on the verge of a B12 obsessive period so it sounds like wonderful manna from heaven.  [25 Jan 2009]



Date: 24 March 2006

Vitamin B12 - Candy

Label: Tip Top

Format: 3xVinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Alasdair Willis

Cost: £9

It's rare to come across a triple LP where I don't feel that it could have been a lot shorter. This is probably the best B-12 I've heard yet, consisting of unidentifiable, crazy cut up sounds probably generating from acoustic instruments at some point but manipulated to death. Lots of this sounds like a tape unraveling off a spool, very much in the Lied aesthetic. There's so much movement and I strangely find this accessible - it sounds like it was very carefully put together with a lot of attention to rhythm and motion. Are Vitamin B-12 the best-kept secret in Britain? Are they even a secret? [14 May 2006]


Date: 24 March 2006

Vitamin B12 - Heads (Volume 6) - Pickpocket

Label: Not On Label

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Alasdair Willis

Cost: £6

Another Vitamin B-12 stunner, Pickpocket is built entirely around vocal samples, presented in a cut-up manner with a lot of repetition and rhythm. It's a complete concept executed well, with humorous and random elements and a good sense of space. On the second side there's a part where it starts to layer too much and almost becomes the wall-of-sound potential hinted at, but then before it's overwhelming it pulls back. Male and female interplay is used well, and while actual meaning is fairly abstracted, there's enough words and proper names (a call from Karen is really repetitive) to suggest a broken narrative. The Bohman Brothers did some things like this when I saw them live, though this is much less concerned with non-vocal sounds (excepting  tape hiss, some knocking sounds, and other incidentals of the source material). [1 Aug 2012]


Date: 24 March 2006

Vitamin B12 - Heads (Volume 7) - Tiki Tomi

Label: Not On Label

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Alasdair Willis

Cost: £6

Another great B-12 release, this one is clearly culled from improv sessions, not unlike the ones I played in with them. This is jittery, schizophrenic music made from guitars, percussion, and sparse electronics. Whenever Alasdair edits this stuff into accelerating momentum, as on here, I find it truly exciting - improvisation, sure, but with an effect on the listener not shared by much of the genre. My few sessions jamming in Brighton definitely rank among the most enjoyable musical interactions I've ever had. [3 November 2012]


Date: 24 March 2006

Vitamin B12 - Heads (Volume 2) - Punahou

Label: Not On Label

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Alasdair Willis

Cost: £6

Volume two of Heads (I wish I had collected them all!) is made in the same cut-up style as most of the others in the series. 'Punahou Carnival 2005', the title of which suggests it was actually recorded on one of Alasdair's numerous trips to Hawaii, is buried in flanger, phasing and reverb - the source material definitely has voices, flutes and other unidentifiably processed sounds, so it could be from that. The A-side is one long pece, 'Are You Ready for Your Tea Sidney?' constructed from old tape loops, with that rolling, bumpy momentum that I used to strive so hard to achieve myself with Lied Music. It's spacious - it really breathes, in a beautiful way - and near the end, some backwards, elliptical drones take over, creating an elegy of the unsettling. There's no other artist on earth capable of creating a vibe like this. [9 November 2012]


Date: 25 March 2006

Peril Hill - Scream at the Jackdaw, Make Him Stop

Label: Singing Knives

Format: CD-R

Source: Jon Marshall

Cost: £0



Date: 25 March 2006

Feather Gatherers - Leaves / Tower At Bollingen

Label: Singing Knives

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Jon Marshall

Cost: £0

Jon and Fiona are the Feather Gatherers, I think. This 7" doesn't do much for me as much as I like these people - both songs are indistinguishable arpeggiated folk tunes, without anything to stick in my head. I'm quite sour on the British folk revival anyway and these songs are really throwaway to me. A lovely colour of vinyl though. [10 December 2012]


Date: 25 March 2006

Stock, Hausen and Walkman - Organ Transplants vol 2

Label: Hot Air

Format: LP

Source: Matt Wand

Cost: £0

It was awesome to swap a Lied LP for this, which is the only Stock, Hausen & Walkman record I own but one that I've really come to enjoy. These guys definitely occupy the same corner of the UK sound/pastiche world that Mark and Barry come from - in fact, I'd suspect they were a pretty big influence on Vernon & Burns. This is very sample-based, but with a lot of their own instrumentation in here. A lot of sequenced rhythms, but in a goofy, retro novelty electronic way instead of anything danceable -- and then lots of organs and guitars. SH&W avoid obvious humour, going for "just funny" instead of "funny ha-ha". As a musical construction, this is fantastic - there's a great bit of detail and the pieces are structured brilliantly. While the whole project is laced with irony, there's something really inviting about the finished product. [1 August 2012]


Date: 25 March 2006

Disco Operating System - Ultrasonic Bath

Label: Lotta Continua

Format: CD

Source: Gareth Bibby

Cost: £0

Gareth opened up for us in Salford and was a really nice guy who did electronic/abstract soundscapes and we swapped discs. This is all over the place - a few parts are actually pretty fantastic and remind me of BxC, the way they crackle and come apart and come back together. But there are a few awkward moments - deconstructed, cheesy casio beats that are probably intended to be ironic, and clichéd Orb-sounding pieces with samples. Gareth is pretty removed from any sort of hipster "scene", yet his music is equal or better than a lot of more famous artists and not really that stylistically different. I'd like to hear more and I'd go see him again. [27 May 2006]


Date: 25 March 2006

Lee Patterson/Benjamin Gwilliam - Heatworks

Label: New Acoustical Pleasures

Format: 3" CD

Source: Ben Gwilliam

Cost: £0

A lovely little 3" with nice, professionally printed artwork. Lee's track is 10 minutes of sparklers, recorded with 'minimal processing' - it's a trebly, scraping sound, even if I know this is actually something burning. This is what Lee does well, and even though this is really old (2002) it's a good M.O. for his work (or at least what I know of it - I have little engagement with his recent activities). By the end it sounds nothing like sparklers and more like something clanging around in a bowl. Ben's track, more composed than improvised, is from heat lamps burning some fax paper. It reminds me of that one Aube release that is all grow lamps. His sense of dynamics is impeccable though this is largely hum and hiss, far more dense than Lee's cut [16 July 2012]


Date: 25 March 2006

Lee Patterson/Benjamin Gwilliam - Collaborative Impositions

Label: New Acoustical Pleasures

Format: CD-R

Source: Ben Gwilliam

Cost: £0

These two soundniks were bigtime collaborators back when I met them, the night they gave me this CDr. Lee's gone on to some acclaim - Luke put out a CD of his, and made a film about him, and we stayed in touch for awhile; but Welshman Ben Gwilliam has disappeared from my radar completely. This CDr contains 3 tracks in about 25 minutes from live recordings of extremely minimal deep-listening stuff. Because I have my window open, it's essentially unhearable right now; more like a 'presence', a minor chill that passes through every one in awhile. There's a sharp piercing presence every once in awhile too, like feedback or something bowed, mostly notably on track 3. This isn't the best way to review this, but it's how I'm gonna do it now. [1 July 2012]


Date: 26 March 2006

Ben Reynolds - Third Tongue Meditations

Label: Memoirs Of An Aesthete

Format: CDr Mini

Source: Ben Reynolds

Cost: £0

Ben's third in the series begins with a track called "Infinite arousal", which explores some dark electronics and guitar noise, and hopefully not Ben's libido. The casio keyboard sticks out more in the second track. There's quite a lot going on in these pieces, with some bubbly motion that's too schizophrenic for any actual meditation. Track 3 whips out the acoustic guitar for some lovely fingerpicked melodies, but juxtaposed with the dark swirls which seem to follow naturally from the first two pieces. [11 May 2006]


Date: 27 March 2006

Volcano The Bear - Classic Erasmus Fusion

Label: Beta-lactam Ring Records

Format: 2xCD

Source: Daniel

Cost: £0

The long-awaited followup to The Idea of Wood is a dense, double-disc affair that is a lot to work through, especially since I only really listen to it when Daniel isn't home. At first listen there's some incredible drone pieces that outdo the Vibracathedrals at their own game, some Aaron-led songs that proceed with delicate violence, and some Clarence-centered madcap collages. But at two discs, I can't help but feel that they are repeating themselves a bit. The minor key intervals and percussion continues the progress into Third Ear territory begun on the last recorrd, which is definitely not a bad thing - but I can't help but wonder why they didn't trim it down to one fantastic single album. Still, I will be listening to this much more. [27 May 2006]


Date: 31 March 2006

Warmer Milks - Permanent Drool/Lucifer's Twins

Label: Ladron Tape

Format: CD-R

Source: Mikey T via Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0



Date: 7 April 2006

Shadow Ring - Lighthouse

Label: Swill Radio

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £11.08

Over time, Lighthouse has risen to prominence for me as an 'all-time great' album, certainly one of the most accomplished double LPs I've ever encountered in my time of listening to music.This was the one that blew things open for me, and it's easy to see why - Lighthouse is a master plan of musical strategies that satisfy all of my idiosyncratic tastes. But beyond that, there's a perfect balance between verbal language and musical language here. Darren Harris's words are so carefully chosen, yet absurd; they occupy a dry, strange and obtuse British territory, as quotable and ridiculous as Monty Python but done without obvious humorous intention. This leads to four sides of obsession, a dark masterpiece weaving together life in sterile, postmodern Britain (just at the Blair years were beginning); and all of the nonsense about King Arthur, the RAF, the  R.N.L.I and the sea/lighthouse themes are part of the Folkstone mythos to me. But what's behind the music is the most radical - this is a redefinition of song structures, using everything that shouldn't be part of a song. This anti-musicality is of course extremely musical - it's constructed in a way that is careful and alien. I've never tired of it, and the last two sides still contain a lot of unexplored territory. I read someone compare this to Trout Mask Replica and it's as much a treasure map as that, if not moreso - though perhaps devolved someone after 30 more years of musical history has passed. What a fucking masterpiece; I have spent the last few years in awe of Lighthouse and wishing I could one day realise something as visionary myself. [27 November 2012]


Date: 7 April 2006

Satwa - Satwa

Label: Time-Lag Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £9.99

It felt like there was a few things that happened to my view of music around late 2005, when I moved to the UK and had to kick my habit of buying tons of records.  First, there was the explosion of people releasing music online, via their Myspace pages or whatnot - I mean, it certainly existed before then, but it really became apparent to me that it was emerging as a normal, even "necessary" way for people to get their music heard.  This of course meant that suddenly every guy with a microphone (or not even) could put their ideas out there, which was liberating and democratising.  Second, the tide of lost forgotten psych/weird masterpieces increased to become more like a tsunami.  Instead of the few choice reissues each month (which were carefully selected by labels I loved and trusted), it was suddenly near-impossible to keep track of how much old music was coming out.  The term "privately pressed" entered the lexicon of hip and zillions of "lost classics" were given a second breath, though usually in limited pressings equal to (if not smaller) the size the originals were released in.  These two trends met in the middle through blogs and Soulseek - rare lost records that were not being reissued were at least digitised and put out there by legions of curiosity seekers, for free.   Now, all of this is totally excellent - liberating and democratising, as I said above - but it also conflicted with my perverse desire to be on top of everything.  Suddenly I felt overwhelmed and I was too poor to keep up with te vinyl, and I didn't have the time to download evertything.  

This is probably actually good for me, as I began to focus on the things that I did love much more, and I saved a lot of money, and I generally loosened up and learned that I could be happy not knowing about something.  Now, the recommendations of trusted friends are much more valuable to me than that of JohnnyBlogger34 or even some of the labels I used to really like.  I know this sounds negative, but a great deal of these records are lost for a reason.  And many are really and truly great, so the important thing is always to listen and try to hear something for what it is - which is just hard when there's 400 billion old albums out there (and 400 billion new ones as well).


So my music intake has fallen into a sort of structured anarchy (structured here by this list, and my guiding lines, but without any previously-soughtafter dream of completeness).  What does this have to do with the Satwa record?  Well, I think this is a really excellent lost psych-folk record, easily on par with something like the Black Sun Ensemble or Virgin Insanity (though much more musically accomplished than the latter).  The thing is, I feel like it was kinda lost in the clutter for me.  I bought this cheap from Volcanic Tongue cause it had a damaged cover, then maybe listened to it twice over the past 3 years.  It's quite competent, with a heavy Middle Eastern influence despite its Brazilian origins - and recorded in a way that the overtones from all the strumming can really resonate.  And of courtse, Nemo did a beautiful reissue job.  But the sad thing is, I can't say that I actually connect with this music in any way.  In the past I may have felt connections to weird reissued records perhaps falsely, due to their obscurity.  Or maybe that's not true at all and I'm just trying to intellectually justify why I can recognise a record like this as competent but have no passion for it myself.  But I think if I had heard this maybe six years ago instead of 3, I would have grown with it - learned its chord progressions and beautiful moments and truly considered a favorite.  Now it's just one more on the shelf that is nice to listen to now and then, and assessments like that kind of challenge my whole conception of musical greats and landmark albums.  I don't know where I am going with this so maybe I will try to write more later.  [18 March 2009]



Date: 7 April 2006

Økland, Nils - Blå Harding

Label: Morild

Format: CD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £3.99

I have a real thing for the somber elegies of Nils Økland, who I first heard via his Rune Grammafon CD Straum some years ago. This is an earlier release, which has additional Norwegian folkies playing behind him on guitar, percussion and other things, but the violin is still first and foremost. His tone is so melodramatic it's almost sickening, and I wonder if I was more familiar with Norwegian folk tunes if I would find this to be too much. But instead it's a beautiful, haunting record of thick lush strings, reverberating through my imagination - stars in the Northern sky, sung to with abstract vocalisations and the most beautiful of the violin's possibilities. There's some churchy organ stuff too which works well in balance, but it's really the violin I'm after. [30 July 2012]


Date: 7 April 2006

Stanley Brothers - Earliest Recordings: The Complete Rich-R-Tone 78s (1947-1952) 

Label: Revenant

Format: CD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £7.99

Five years of the Stanley Brothers, restored from 78 to CD fidelity as good as can be done. As usual, Revenant does a good job on liner notes and other such material, giving clear indication as to who is in the lineup for each track. It's not sequenced completely chronologically though. The version of 'Death is Only a Dream' is incredible. [21 October 2012]


Date: 7 April 2006

Ray Off - I Am Not in the Racing Sky

Label: United Fairy Moons

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6.99

Ray Off, here a quartet, deliver three tracks of beautiful strangeness. It's so easy to idealise music from New Zealand, especially when it has this inviting night-time quality. There's a spaciness to things with the guitars and keyboards being made to ring out, with just enough delay/reverb to suggest another world. But then there's moments of subtle beauty - the plucking zither over dense organ drone + cello in track 2 is a moment of abstract genius. There's a romanticism to this sound, even when it flares towards something slightly more malevolent. I don't really know what happened to this band (or label) but when I remember to listen to this (which is not often, as it ends up in the spineless box of CDr releases, easily forgotten) I love where it takes me. [29 December 2012]


Date: 7 April 2006

Milk From Cheltenham - Triptych Of Poisoners

Label: Alga Marghen

Format: CD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £13.99

I award this my 'best of genre' award, with the genre being "music". I have such a connection to this album, even though it's inherently dissociative and left-brained. Of all the Homosexuals-related projects this one is the most mysterious and I'd say successful, though I never really kept up with the legends so I'm not even sure which members are responsible for it. What I do know is that Triptych of Poisoners is a compendium of possibilities for playing music as a group, a skeleton key for ideas, none of which are particularly well-developed. The rock stuff is clearly culled from jams and overdubbed with various layers of vocals and strange sounds; the less formed interstitial tracks are even more loose, sometimes complete sci-fi jokes ('Mr. Fridge') and sometimes soundtracky bits of improv ('The Plan Must Rule'). It stops every time it starts to get going; it leaves me wanting more from track to track. It doesn't sound like anything that ever came before or after it, including the Homosexuals themselves, except for maybe The Faust Tapes, but really only in structure (and this is not a collage - these are distinct tracks). It makes a lot of sense that this was released on Alga Marghen, who I think plans to reissue the entirety of the It's War Boys label, though I think they've only done this and the Modern Shit release. Absolutely, totally inspirational to the nth exponent. [19 August 2012]


Date: 7 April 2006

Rory Storm - We Are Superior Beings

Label: United Fairy Moons

Format: CD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6.99

The now-forgotten Rory Storm made this fantastic, stunning CD for the fantastic, stunning (and now-forgotten) United Fairy Moons label. It wasn't even that long ago, but I was way into this stuff in 2005 and now I haven't heard a peep from him or the label in a long time. This is a solo project that uses a wide array of instrumentation (electric guitars, organs, static, field recordings, etc.) to make epic, spacey instrumental jams. It's loose, but colourful; evocative of starry nights on the other side of the world, and a real audio fantasy. There's a tendency towards weird, rumbling mystery here - I'm reminded at times of F/i, though without that ramshackle quality - and the home-recording approach is perfect, neither hi-fi nor lo-fi. It actually gets rocking at points - there's quite a lot of musical competence on display - and I wish I heard his other recordings as well. [30 October 2012]


Date: 7 April 2006

Magik Markers - A Panegyric To The Things I Do Not Understand

Label: Gulcher Records

Format: CD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

Live, I wasn't impressed by Magik Markers - I thought they just sounded like Nirvana. But this disc is recorded very well, and portrays a collapsing, crazy free-rock group. The vocals are deranged and sorta funny, and the drumming serves as a strange focal point among the guitar clatter. I don't know if this is something I'll pull out frequently but I'm certainly glad to have gotten a free copy of it. [11 May 2006]


Date: 7 April 2006

Jacques Berrocal / Dominique Coster / Roger Ferlet - Musiq Musik

Label: Futura Records (2)

Format: CD Album

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £5.99

My love for Berrocal really rests on this disc and Paralleles.  This is a bit more "normal" at least in the sense that one can listen to this and at least picture the scenario - a few musicians exploring the sound possibilities of a few instruments and objects, but keeping things sparse.  I still wouldn't compare this to most improvised music, as it had a cut-up surrealist feel that suggests studio processing afterwards.  It's short, really an EP, but a true unclassic. [18 March 2009]



Date: 7 April 2006

James "Twig" Harper - Intuitive American Esoteric Vol. 2

Label: Slowtoe

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition Etched

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £11.99

A continuation of the madness on volume 1, side 1 runs through a variety of electronic bursts, looped found sound, and sheer noise. It's lively, playful, and never tiresome. Side 2 is more of the same, mastered I think by Twig himself because the stylus moves all over the fucking place and I think there's some lock grooves as well. Either way, my cheap turntable doesn't like it. I played this at 33rpm though the option is given. [11 May 2006]


Date: 14 April 2006

Hildegard - Family Hymnal

Label: Feed and Seed

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £12

Debut from a group in Massachusetts who work in a low-key instrumental vein. It's hazy, very loose and probably mostly improvised, with a very distinct recording aesthetic that reminds me a bit of Alastair Galbraith's best work. The last track has a long, rambling piano part that feels more like an impression than a melody. I'm not sure why I like this so much; there aren't any moments that are stunning, but the disc as a whole has a very focused vision. [18 July 2006]


Date: 14 April 2006

Spit - Trash Music Spitacular

Label: United Fairy Moons

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £10

Spit is the project of Ryan Cockburn, who I can tell from the liner notes has received an MFA from Dunedin Art College. His music is really lively, mostly instrumental textures and sketches but infused with the spirit of Red Noise, Mahogany Brain, and that type of thing. It's sequenced well, and none of the tracks wear out their welcome - most are excerpts of longer pieces, which shows his good sense of editing. I'm very impressed and I look forward to hearing more. And like everything on this (incredible) United Fairy Moons label, it's really nicely packaged. [18 Apr 2006]


Date: 14 April 2006

Fushitsusha - Double Live (15/16)

Label: PSF

Format: 2xCD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £20

Without any exaggeration, this is a groundbreaking landmark of music. I've had a copy of it for years, but I finally broke down and bought the CD in the lovely all-black packaging. This will be great to have for much late-night listening. There's one particular track, I think it's track 3 on disc 1, where Haino starts out singing like a banshee for a really long time, and then when it finally comes in, it's like the heaviest thing ever. At 2 CD's it doesn't feel long at all. Utterly fucking amazing. [19 Apr 2006]


Date: 14 April 2006

Virgin Insanity - Fish Friends / The Odometer Suite

Label: P-Vine Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £13



Date: 14 April 2006

Inca Ore - Brute Nature vs. Wild Magic

Label: Weird Forest

Format: LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £10

Inca Ore has an interesting solo vocal approach - she has no problem with burying the voice in layers of effects and delay, rendering her larynx into a lo-fi soup base. The first side is a series of shorter pieces which are most effective when subtle hooks emerge. Side two is a long, expanded piece that is extremely repetitive, maybe the aural equivalent of a new age amusement park ride on ludes. It's hard for me to not compare her to Meredith Monk, though this is a dirty, druggy doppleganger. [18 Apr 2006]


Date: 14 April 2006

Valley of Ashes - Cavehill Hunter's Attrition

Label: Black Velvet Fuckere

Format: 3xLP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

It's finally out - the sprawling, excessive 3LP debut (and finale) from Valley of Ashes. At first listen it just sounded like Kris Abplanalp and his friends dicking around for about two LP's too long, but then it grew on me. That totally smokey, late night Rufer St. vibe is captured, and even though this band broke up before I had met any of them, it feels very familiar and nice. The violin - I guess that's Natalie? - is a really nice presence, though the thin recording is a shame;; I guess a lot of this is done on a dictaphone. David's bass is also lost a bit, unfortunately. There's some scorching Amon Duul II-style guitar playing on side 2, and side 5 is a really beautiful organic ball of drone that reminds me of Scatter or Jewel Antlercathedral stuff. Side 6 is a great finale, actually incorporating some scratchy Kentucky hoedown guitar and building up a hillbilly porch jam. Everything is dark, not in terms of being sad or depressing but in a nighttime way. Three records might be a bit much but if this is their one and only statement, then it's not such a bad way to do it. I never lived in Louisville and sometimes feel like I shoulda moved there instead of Lexington, but this gets the imagery: the bumpy dark landscapes of the Highlands, late night hangouts in Tyler park, drinking Falls City, sleeping on Rosenblum's floor after an evening of drinking, playing and hanging out... the music might not directly manufacture these memories for me, but it certainly suggests something. Yeah, they're just jamming without direction and there's a million other bands that do this, but this particular assortment of personalities does bring something special to it and I'm glad this finally saw the light of day. [17 Apr 2006] 


Date: 15 April 2006

Jessica Rylan - Orange Ices

Label: P-Tapes

Format: CDr Mini

Source: Jessica Rylan

Cost: £5

This 3" showcases the electronics side of Jessica, using mostly her home-made synthesizer (I assume). There's little to discern of the vocal approach she does, apart from some whistling at one part. Punchy synthetic bursts of static and noise jump around, occasionally quite rhythmically, with a few waves of volume that are quite disorienting. She keeps the plate clean and leaves a good bit of space to keep things from getting too muddy. And it's a tribute to David Tudor - not a million miles away from Rainforest I guess. [17 Apr 2006]


Date: 20 April 2006

Axolotl - Object Phantom

Label: Spirit Of Orr

Format: CDr

Source: Karl

Cost: £10

A full-length CD-R from Karl on Ron's Spirit of Orr label, with longer pieces that remind me a bit of the Gipsy Sphinx EP more than the live show. The noisy bits are far from harsh; if I would have to call Axolotl "noise" then it's noise in the most beautiful, inviting sense of the term. I think my favorite parts are when it breaks up like static; I'm curious to hear him do more cut-up/manipulated stuff, though I don't know if it's in the cards. [14 May 2006]


Date: 20 April 2006

Mouthus / Axolotl - 12-25-04 Split

Label: Olde English Spelling Bee

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Karl

Cost: £0

Both artists hold back a bit - Mouthus's tendency to rock out is put aside in favor of a more restrained, atmospheric approach. It's not obvious what is Axolotl and what is Mouthus, which I mean in a positive way because it shows the mind-meld of these old friends. Recorded on Christmas, there is a certain warmth to the collaboration, with stretched out drone interaction. I was a bit surprised by what this sounded like, but pleasantly so. [27 May 2006]


Date: 20 April 2006

Birds Of Delay - Gateway To Feather

Label: Alcoholic Narcolepsy

Format: CDr

Source: Steve Warwick

Cost: £0

Noisy, droney mess, poorly recorded and too long. I'm not saying it's bad, just that's what you get here. The two pieces flow into each other pretty seamlessly, sounding like they perhaps came from the same session. It's too thick to really get a sense of who's playing off of whom. The constant presence of feedback (or an intentional high-pitched noise) is actually the axis among which the other swirls of distorted electronics circle. Still need to see these guys live... [14 May 2006]


Date: 21 April 2006

Libérez - Untitled

Label: Not On Label

Format: CDr Mini-Album Limited Edition

Source: John Hannon

Cost: £0

These really nice guys who run a studio in Southend gave me this and when I finally got around to listening to it, I was pleasantly surprised. Two long pieces, the first sounding like early 80's Nurse With Wound in that it's dark but more 'surrealist' than 'industrial'. The second track builds from a drone base into a free rock freakout. It would be cool to see these guys again and catch them live. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 21 April 2006

Family Battle Snake - 

Label: Curor

Format: CD-R

Source: Koulio

Cost: £0



Date: 23 April 2006

Smegma - Pigs For Lepers

Label: Harbinger Sound

Format: CD

Source: Steve Underwood

Cost: £10

This CD collects some early Smegma recordings, from a much different lineup that I saw last week. There are strange, corrupted songforms here, a preponderance of electronic effects and processing, and overall a fucked up Futura-type feel. Why Smegma don't get the respect they deserve is beyond me - the music is completely fucked, experimental as hell but retaining an identity of its own. Now may be the time to begin exploring the rest of their discography. [4 May 2006]


Date: 23 April 2006

Axolotl - Chemical Theatre

Label: Gipsy Sphinx

Format: Vinyl 12" Limited Edition

Source: Karl

Cost: £0

An EP of two short pieces. Side one is a scratchy, hazy static-filled sketch that reminds me of something Burning Star Core-esque. Side two expands into a beautiful, shimmering wave of zithers and strings, recorded in several layers that move and shift. Psychedelic as fuck and wonderfully recorded, my only complaint is that it's too short. [11 May 2006]


Date: 24 April 2006

Ashtray Navigations - Sky Whine

Label: Memoirs Of An Aesthete

Format: CDr

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0

Sorry, Phil, but the CD you gave me doesn?t play. Review pending replacement copy.


Date: 24 April 2006

Astral Social Club - vol. 8 

Label: Astral Social Club

Format: CD-R

Source: Neil Campbell

Cost: £0

This is the first volume I've heard of the Astral Social Club, but it's unsurprising - a mixture of beautiful, rich drone (probably emanating from guitars but I'm not sure) and then some weird, techno-style drone that sounds like Bowery Electric or something. Overall it's very nice and something that I should try to remember to listen to again, but I suspect I won't. [4 May 2006]


Date: 24 April 2006

Ashtray Navigations - Trunk O Tuned Skulls

Label: Memoirs Of An Aesthete

Format: CDr Mini

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0

An eclectic, fun, and overall satisfying Ashtray 3". Track one comes blasting with the wall-of-cheap noise sound that makes Ashtray Navigations who they are, and it also features some funky drumming. Which, I wonder, might be Alex Neilson? -- since this was recorded during Easter 2006, when Alex was definitely playing with Phil a lot. There's no credits to indicate, though. 'Where Fortune Smiles Bewares' is an abrupt turn towards a more electronica side. The closing track is probably the highlight, a rambunctious clean-channel guitar noodle over a quiet underwater loop with some crying voices underneath. It gets stuck in an actual loop in my CD player, making the end of the track impossible to listen to, but it's not a bad eternity to share, if unrepresentative of Ashtray's usual aural assault. [1 Aug 2012]


Date: 4 May 2006

Hassle Hound - Limelight Cordial

Label: Staubgold

Format: CD

Source: Mark Vernon

Cost: £0



Date: 7 May 2006

Dragibus - Tutti Frutti

Label: Autobus

Format: CD

Source: Frank

Cost: £0

Frank and Etienne, two gents I sorta know in Paris, play in this goofy children's music band. Apparently they do pretty well travelling around to schools and whatnot. As someone who was really interested in doing the Grand Buffet children's album a few years ago (whatever happened to that project anyway?) it's great to hear the French take. If I had kids I would definitely play this for them. There's a Moondog cover and a bunch of happy, catchy songs with a fairly rock edge to them. Some of the guitar parts are actually quite weird and definitely more far-out than anything I ever heard as a kid. Plus I can imagine Etienne dressed up like a penguin doing this. I don't know if I'll listen to this very often but it's a fun thing to have, perhaps to play at parties. [11 May 2006]


Date: 11 May 2006

Boyd, Phil and the Hidden Twin - s/t

Label: Faux Totem

Format: CD

Source: Phil Boyd

Cost: £0

Phil sent me his first solo disc, which allows him to free his pop songwriting from the more rock-and-roll aesthetic of the Modey Lemon. I miss Phil and I never got as close to his songs as I would have liked. This is a guy who, when we were at University together, actually majored in songwriting (as a self-designed major that combined music and anthropology, or something like that). Lots of acoustic strums here, and some earnest singing. There's a real simplicity here - the songs are basic, often accompanied with just a second lead guitar, and it sounds a bit like some of the 90s lo-fi indie stuff I liked, Shrimper-label style, etc. Even the more raucous sons, like 'Hanging on the Line', still have the home-recorded sound. I think he's made some more Hidden Twin stuff since but I don't really know what direction he's gone in. [29 December 2012]


Date: 16 May 2006

Bongle Eros - 

Label: Puik

Format: CD-R

Source: Jelle Crama

Cost: £0

There doesn?t seem to be any way to open this without destroying it. It's nicely sewn together by Jelle and it looks really nice, so I'm probably not going to actually ruin it to actually listen to the music. 


Date: 16 May 2006

Burning Star Core - Two In The KY & One In The OH 2005

Label: DroneDisco

Format: 2xCassette

Source: Spencer

Cost: £0

I'm actually listed in the liner notes here -- apparently I recorded some of this, possibly the Louisville show. This is the quartet of BxC that I really miss; three live shows, split somewhat awkwardly over four sides and with proper cassette fidelity. The Louisville show has a really great, jazzy drum solo from Trevor at the beginning before it melts into the thick resonance of the whole quartet. Trevor isn't on the Columbus show so therefore it's far more electronic in nature, with deep rumbles and all sorts of motion. The second half, starting side C, becomes a calvacade of scraping, bursts of electronics, and the musicians teasing each other. It's beautiful. In Lexington, a show I must have been it but can't remember really, which beings with a cloudy, cavernous dark drone (it was in the Icehouse, after all, which sounds that way) before the Shiftlet-less trio really lets lose in a true state of complete freedom. Lovely set, and silly, idiotic band photos and a great title too. [30 December 2012]


Date: 16 May 2006

Mottige Del - Beter Dan Boterhammer

Label: Puik

Format: CD-R

Source: Jelle Crama

Cost: £0



Date: 16 May 2006

Tomotonttu - 

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

Jan's first solo Tomotonttu release came out alongside our Lied Music LP, so you know that was absolutely ages ago! Listening now, it's surprisingly more aggresssive and repetitive than I remembered, especially compared to his later stuff and his live show which (at least the last few times I saw him) was built around broken, melting rhythms and thick layers that overlap. There's certainly the foundation of that here, but it's also got a lot of little excursions into one sound idea that he sticks with for a minute or two before moving on. This is so very much a 'solo' project and definitely in-line with a lot of the noiseniks coming out of Finland at the time, though there's a more manic/soft duality than Kuupuu or JP's stuff or any of the solo Avarus stuff. The recent two KY records have gone more in the direction of the solo genius, though I think Jan really separates the assemblage method of a KY release from Tomotonttu, which is all his source material - something I completely understand. [12 July 2012]


Date: 16 May 2006

Astral Social Club - #9

Label: Astral Social Club

Format: CD-R

Source: Neil Campbell

Cost: £0

Half an hour of poorly recorded live Neil Campbell, from Sheffield in 2006 and released a month later in an edition of 40 for the Subcurrent festival. There's a massive wall of industrial blare here, and it doesn't get any clearer as it goes along, though Neil starts to shout, yell, moan, etc about halfway through. This is far closer to the Vibratcathedral/Total "ecstatic drone" genre and significantly less evolved towards his love of the Kompakt label and minimal electronica; it feels like an Astral Social Club that isn't quite there yet. Actually this wouldn't surprise me if it's not solo, as there's so much going on that John Clyde-Evans may be present too, though there's nothing credited and you know what people can achieve with technology like looping pedals .... [9 October 2012]


Date: 17 May 2006

Noisepussy - Catterina

Label: Imvated

Format: CD-R

Source: Lieven Martens

Cost: £0



Date: 17 May 2006

Tomutonttu - Triplapuisto

Label: Imvated

Format: CS

Source: Lieven Martens

Cost: £0

I miss Lieven's Imvated label, which was a really shining light of that Antwerp cassette underground I floated around back in the day. This is a great Tomutonttu release, one that should be reissued maybe on vinyl. Toy rayguns at war, a battle that feels ultimately silly, like troops fighting over a potato; there's spazzy digital percussion outbursts in the corners. Short attention span theatre for sure. A nice long dirgy bit, though sounding like treble-attenuated miniatures - and then it goes all rambunctious and stops before it wears out its welcome. I think this is 20 minutes of music on one side of a 60 minute tape. When I got this tape, I had no idea what 'tripla puisto' meant in Finnish, or that I'd ever live there. Great spray-painted splatter everywhere; I'll say it again, I miss Imvated. [16 July 2012]


Date: 6 June 2006

Richard Youngs - Summer Wanderer

Label: No Fans Records

Format: CDr

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £7.99

Three a-capella Richard Youngs songs that are as stark and minimal as you can imagine; structurally this is just like Sapphie except with the guitar removed, maybe the next logical step. 'Summer's Edge' is the longest but the most, well, wandering; 'No Longer in this Perdition' is only 5 minutes long but sharp and penetrating. 'Garden of Stones' I remember seeing him perform at ATP; it's a treasure map pointing back to itself, a repetition so naked and bare that if you can stomach the intensity, it's a beauteous thing to behold. [26 December 2012]


Date: 6 June 2006

Ladderwoe - Live

Label: Kitty Play

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £4.99

I heard David reviewing this in the VT office and I was quite taken by it, so I bought a copy. This is completely weird fucking music - strange breaths, bicycle bells, unidentifiable plinkings, and the sounds of expiring life. They apparently come from New Jersey - who'da thunkit? - and the LeafLeaf records page advertises a whole range of further product to sink into. One of the brightest surprises of the year for me - must hear more! [29 Dec 2006] 


Date: 9 June 2006

Bradam Streiple - Aab

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CD-R

Source: Adam Strohm

Cost: £0

This live document shows Adam's tendency towards percussive improv (making me think of that brilliant set with Jim Lingo a few years ago) merged with a dark, Organum-esque drone. I'm not sure who is doing what but Brad and Adam do sound as one here, surging towards an apocalyptic climax that recalls early Nurse With Wound, 150 Murderous Passions, and other dark music... while at the same time having that raw, simple live approach. Very nice. [25 June 2006]


Date: 9 June 2006

Strohm, Adam/Shiflet, Mike - split

Label: Ordnung

Format: CD-R

Source: Adam Strohm

Cost: £0



Date: 12 June 2006

Lanterns - Wax Cavern

Label: Screeching Snowflake

Format: CDr

Source: Andreas

Cost: £0

Andreas' group Lanterns, the majority of whom live in Leeds, didn't impress me live but they seem to feel more comfortable on this recording. Fitting in with the current wave of drone purveyors, you can hear loads of effects applied to build a thick wall of sound, with phasers, flanges, and reverb galore. Over 62 minutes they change gears a few times, ranging from noisy free moments to more melodic, placid (and quite pretty) harmonics. It is a bit long, but I suspect that's the statement they wanted to make. [25 June 2006]


Date: 30 June 2006

Ben Reynolds - Outmospheric Arts Of The Outmosphere

Label: Digitalis Recordings

Format: CD Album

Source: Ben

Cost: £0



Date: 5 July 2006

Burning Star Core - See You in 2004

Label: U-Sound

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £8.99



Date: 5 July 2006

Red Kites - Nawadaha

Label: U-Sound

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £8.99

The Tip of the Tongue review made it sound like this is the second coming of somebody, and while I must admit this is an excellent, surprising release, I suspect that the NEXT Red Kites release may be their 'statement'. If it's the second coming of anybody it's probably Jandek, though there's less of a, well, "outsider" feel to Red Kites. What I like about this music is the smoky ambience, the strange percussive/guitar interplay, and the fact that I have met this Mr. Januirek and find him a somewhat fascinating, mysterious figure. [11 Jul 2006]


Date: 5 July 2006

Son of Earth - Erotic Empire

Label: Apostasy

Format: CD-R

Source: Aaron (via VT)

Cost: £0



Date: 5 July 2006

Edmond De Deyster - Selectie 01

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £7.99

i've never known whether or not to 'believe' in this record's veracity; Alex Neilson and I were convinced that these synth recordings were actually made by Cassis Cornuta or Dennis Tyfus or one of the current Antwerp crew of weirdos.  The question that this raises, regardless of if it's true or not, is "why does it matter?"  Shouldn't the music itself carry eveything?  Why would I be more interested in these recordings if they were made by some obscure dead guy than if they were made by Lieven Maartens?  I don't usually go for minimal synth records but this one does sound lovely. There are some little quick beeping sounds that create a rainlike pattern, which is a really nice layer over the deeper spacey sounds.  It's not purely experimentation for experimentation's sake - there is a focus on constructing a mood, even if everything goes haywire at times.  Of course I go back to the entire package of the record - the cover, some old Flemish family photograph; the insert with one badly Xeroxed face, a moustache almost too-accurately placing this in the mid-70s milieu.  If it's a hoax, it's a well-designed hoax, but again, it shouldn't really matter.  And it doesn't. (Not that much). [12 Jan 2009]


Date: 5 July 2006

Burning Star Core - West Coast Spring 2004

Label: What The...? Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Spencer (via VT)

Cost: £0

This is a vinyl reissue of some of the choice recordings from the original tape boxset of this West Coast tour, which was duo of Spencer and Robert.  Side 1 is a playful fight between an insanely scratchy, cheap-sounding violin and Robert's acoustic appraiser, which is bubbing all of the place.  The recording quality sounds distintly handheld, or maybe it's a cheap PA, or maybe they just wanted it to sound like that - and on vinyl, it sounds great but annoying (if that makes any sense).  By the end, my head hurts and they're right back where they started.  Side B starts as a slower performance, where Spencer's violin is drowned in reverb and Robert's hearing test machine blends into the sounds slightly.  There's some deep hornlike crawls of sound occasionally punctuated by less reverby violin scrapes, and the hearing test machine occasionally shouting out.  It's almost like they're trying to create a deep underwater feeling but their attention span is too short.  After awhile the reverb cuts out and it becomes a piercing scrapefest again.  The hearing test machine tends to squeal more and the violin is more of a crackling effect.   It ends but then they go into a second piece which is vocals and hearing test machine.  The fidelity is so gritty that the vocals sound even less human than they usually do; Robert responds to it pretty well though the nature of the acoustic appraiser is pretty rambunctious so there are some parts where they are definitely heading in different directions.  [12 Jan 2009]


Date: 5 July 2006

Hildegard - Tape for the Tuning of the Ear

Label: Feed and Seed

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £7.99

One long track in a larger ensemble than is found on Family Hymnal; here Hildegard get a bit more electric, with some drums and guitar effects. There's a real Steve Reichy feel to it, but it still has that weird farmyard ambience I like so much about Family Hymal. I'm going to have to break down and get their third CD now... [22 Jul 2006]


Date: 6 July 2006

Anthony Braxton - Five Compositions (Quartet) 1986

Label: Black Saint

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Monorail

Cost: £3.99

More 80's Braxton that proves to be innovative and uncompromising. This quartet, with David Rosenboom, Mark Dresser and Gerry Hemingway, is flowery and playful. Rosenboom is prone to fast, dazzling runs, under with Anthony gets quite soulful, sometimes working a slower counterpoint to the more active keys. The final composition is the most cohesive, even though it's the most sparse. The musicians take their time feeling each other out, with a few moments nothing but a bass bowing and a low-registered clarinet. It gets furtive as it goes along, but resists the tendency to go all-in. Braxton had the luxury of a tenured professorial position during this time and it's great that Black Saint was able to take a chance on releasing such uncommercial music. [2 December 2012]


Date: 6 July 2006

Scott Walker - The Drift

Label: 4AD

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: Monorail

Cost: £11.99

Well, six years have passed and I'm not sure if I understand The Drift any more. It's certainly become the Scott Walker album I listen to the most - the one the felt the most shocking and raw, even after being familiar with Tilt and all that. I remember getting MP3s of this and going over to Chris Hladowski's house in Glasgow and listening to it with him in his kitchen, and both of us were somewhat slackjawed by it - and Chris isn't even someone who really likes this kind of stuff. The Drift is a dense listen and there are a lot of themes here - genocide, family, intimacy, distance - and that's just a guess as the lyrics and arrangements are somewhat inpenetrable. On thick vinyl, the deep rumbles of a song like 'Clara' sound insane - like four speakers at least, even though it's just on my regular stereo system. There's already somewhat of a myth around the construction of this record - using the peas, the simulation of the World Trade Center falling, etc. - and it's interesting to see how this record crosses into different audiences. (A regular customer from the bookstore who's in his 60s and mostly listens to old country and jazz is way into this album). At a point in my life when it seemed everyone was making a new 'most fucked up record ever' announcement every few weeks, The Drift came along and genuinely won the title. [2 November 2012]


Date: 6 July 2006

Moondog (2) - Rare Material

Label: Roof Records

Format: 2xCD Album Compilation

Source: Monorail

Cost: £13.99

This isn't THAT rare - the first disc was previously released as vinyl only, and most of the second disc comes from various albums that aren't that well-known. I'm not complaining though as I don't have the records in question. This is lots of fun - the earliest stuff on disc 1 sounds very formative, as it contains the joy and energy but it just doesn't feel like it's quite there yet - it lacks the openness, and the sense of unfolding. The collection is still nicely packaged and has some great Moondog wisdom in the booklet. There's a long track on disc 1 where everyone is playing one note, and it's like minimalism's fun redneck cousin. Great! [22 Jul 2006]


Date: 6 July 2006

Anthony Braxton - Six Compositions (Quartet) 1984

Label: Black Saint

Format: CD

Source: Monorail

Cost: £3.99

Braxton always has this reputation of being pretentious "head" music and it's easy to see where that comes from, given that it's impossible for me to even refer to any of the track titles in mere UTF encoding. However, this record has a really warm side that plays with melody in a really visceral way. It's got a "cool" feel, definitely, but that's not to say it isn't human. The first track in particular uses a ascending and descending 5-tone scale to keep a center while the musicians explore around it - it's rooted enough in tradition that I don't think it would scare a lot of people away, and is uniquely Braxton. [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 6 July 2006

Anthony Braxton - Four Compositions (Quartet) 1983

Label: Black Saint

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Monorail

Cost: £0

This quartet has George Lewis on trombone and a very stark-sounding Gerry Hemingway on drums. The compositions are very tight - with lots of bumpy sax/trombone interactions. The side-long piece that opens moves through a lot of different territory and is maybe ultimately somewhat inconclusive for me. Melodies come together and then are immediately disassembled; it's diverse, and actually fun, but somewhat overwhelming. The opening piece on side two has a really great bowed bass section and there's some great improvised moments among the structure. I always associate the early 1980s with a time where jazz died, as longtime artists started to take a distinctly more commercial stab. This wasn't the case with Braxton - though I have that weird In The Tradition album, actually from the 70s - in 1983 he is pushing forward and doing exactly what he wants to do, and it's quite commendable. [24 November 2012]


Date: 6 July 2006

V/A - London Is The Place For Me 2: Calypso & Kwela, Highlife & Jazz From Young Black London

Label: Honest Jons Records

Format: CD

Source: Monorail

Cost: £6.99

Honest Jon's second collection of London calpyso from the 50s is a strong successor to the first volume. It begins with 'Calypso Be' by Young Tiger, a slightly silly song about be-bop and the Dizzie Gillespie, ultimately concluding that this music is not for him and Gillespie should go back to 52nd street. I always enjoys songs about another genre of music, but I'm disappointed by Mr. Tiger's appraisal. The more mellow and wordless tunes here are more to my tastes, like Ambrose Campbell. Nothing is quite as catchy as 'At the Coronation' from volume 1, but this is a bit more broad, containing Kwela and some other offshoot forms (which I don't really know the difference of). The more repetitious bits are great because they are casually repetitious, if that makes any sense. Ultimately this is another chapter in a story of a city - the music here, despite it's island flavours, is completely London-based and it portrays a world of Caribbean-descended Londoners trying to make a life. [16 October 2012]


Date: 6 July 2006

Alasdair Roberts - Farewell Sorrow

Label: Rough Trade Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Monorail

Cost: £3.99

I slowly grew to become a big fan of this album, mostly over the year I lived in Kentucky. This is the perfect merging of indie rock and traditional music - beautiful, Scottish traditionals with slightly altered lyrics and that guitar/drum sound that populates many a 90's indie folk/rock record. But what makes this so remarkable is Ali's delivery and knack for finding the beauty in the lyrics and making it sound uniquely his own.
