The notes you are forming, I long to possess them - sends shivers down my body yet I can imagine it sounding clich?d and forced from almost anyone else. And I found a mint vinyl copy for cheap at Monorail! [12 Jul 2006]


Date: 6 July 2006

Van Morrison - Saint Dominic's Preview

Label: Warner Bros. Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Monorail

Cost: £3.99

When I'm feeling argumentative, I claim this as my favorite Van Morrison album. It lacks the total mystic revery of Astral Weeks but actually combines the great Astral vibe ('Listen to the Lion', 'Almost Independence Day') with the bluesy Ulster soul that he's also known for ('Saint Dominic's Preview', 'Jackie WIlson') -- in some ways, it's the perfect balanced Van album. 'Almost Independence Day' is my favourite song of his, better in my opinion than anything on AW. I once bonded with Neil Campbell over that song, and he was going on about how he realised when Van is crooning about 'I can hear the fireworks' that the 12-string guitar playing IS the fireworks, which is no great symbolism but a nice gesture and sharing that with Neil was lovely. I love this song insanely and I try not to wear it out, but the rest of the record is so goddam solid that it's really the one I pull out the most - I mean, after all, you can't rock Astral Weeks every day. [21 August 2012]


Date: 6 July 2006

Red Krayola - Introduction

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Monorail

Cost: €10.99

This Red Krayola is really similar to Hazel or the first s/t Drag City one in that it's a series of fairly straight-forward pop/rock songs.  Of course, nothing is straight when it's Mayo Thompson.  The songs, by any other standards, are extremely weird, extremely wordy, and obtuse.  There are a few songs that deserve to be Krayola classics, like "Psy Ops"; others that are solid and a few that are filler.  But overall, it's a very strong album, the kind that Thompson only makes about every ten years.  It helps that the core musicians are people he's been working with for some time, so it's got a real "band" feel, perhaps moreso than the earlier Drag City releases which feel a bit more hodgepodge.  I've had this for a few years but only listened to it a few times, which is a shame as it's definitely one of their best records overall.  [21 Mar 2009]



Date: 8 July 2006

Aksak Maboul - Un peu l'Ã¢me des bandits

Label: Crammed

Format: CD

Source: Recommended

Cost: £9



Date: 8 July 2006

This Heat - Out Of Cold Storage

Label: This Is

Format: 6xCD AlbumBox Set

Source: Recommended

Cost: £48

What do I need to say? The single most inspirational musical unit, to me, finally has everything available, in print, with the deluxe reissue it deserves. Before I listened to anything I read the book, which made me hate myself for not having an active band right now. Charles Hayward says "We thought people were going to start accepting improvisation instead of parlor games" (or something like that). The music - do I need to say anything new about this? I guess I can talk about the live disc, remastered from cassette recordings. The quality isn't great but you can hear how amazing and powerful they were, especially on the live version of "Health and Efficiency" which sounds like a mountain collapsing onto a song. Even writing this review feels like a waste of time; I should be listening. [22 Jul 2006]


Date: 11 July 2006

Ben Reynolds - Book Of Beyond

Label: Last Visible Dog

Format: CD

Source: Ben

Cost: £0



Date: 11 July 2006

Uton - Mystery Revolution

Label: Digitalis Recordings

Format: CD

Source: Ben

Cost: £0



Date: 20 July 2006

A.M.  - Episteme

Label: Apoplexy

Format: CDr

Source: Anthony Milton

Cost: £0

Anthony Milton is a very, very underrated artist. This CD-R reissue of an out-of-print full-length from a few years ago is really varied, with some noisy electroacoustics and folky touches. It's hard to really describe this here without making it sound like every other record I got this year, but this is really fantastic, and immensely relistenable. [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 20 July 2006

Paintings of Indian Windows - Guhkta

Label: Audiobot

Format: CD-R

Source: Anthony Milton

Cost: £0



Date: 20 July 2006

Dialing In - Cows In Lye

Label: PseudoArcana

Format: CD

Source: Anthony Milton

Cost: £0

I'm ready to drop everything and declare an allegiance to Dialing In as the most exciting new drone purveyors I've heard this year. Taking the mentality of the Skaters but giving it a darker, slightly more modal tendency, this CD (and the one I downloaded on Celebrate Psi-Phenomena) are absolutely fantastic, an inspiration for the deep listening psychic alterations. I will be listening to this throughout the remainder of my dissertation writing to clear the head and let new ideas develop. [22 Jul 2006]


Date: 20 July 2006

Lost Domain - Palace

Label: PseudoArcana

Format: CD Album

Source: Anthony Milton

Cost: £0

The Lost Domain apparently have been kicking around Brisbane forever to little acclaim, but they're hard workers who conjure an impressive disc of psychedelic drone. The long second track has some slide guitars which get all over the place nuts and it's a nice one to relax to but it still goes into interesting places. I think I met some of these people when I was in Brisbane but I'm not sure - I don't know if they are a tight band or a messy collective - I'd guess the latter. I will rarely listen to this disc but when I do, I like it - especially the more lo-fi tracks with the disembodied voices in the distance. This was probably about it for Brisbane music until that recent outburst of artists that Volcanic Tongue was championing. Maybe it's time to reconsider this city. [28 December 2012]


Date: 27 July 2006

Vernon, Mark - Notes on a Re-Run

Label: Meagre Resource

Format: CD-R

Source: Mark Vernon

Cost: £0

Mark spent some time in Belgium and did this CD-R collecting some of the recordings he made there with his own style of processing. I love what Mark does - few artists could work exclusively with 'samples' and be so successful; some of the accents over the children singing are subtle but incredibly complex. Everything sounds very clean and it's easy to tune out Mark's stuff and get stuck in the environment he's documented. [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 9 August 2006

Coptic Nausea - Community Nuisance

Label: No label

Format: CD-R

Source: Trevor

Cost: £0

Trevor's solo electronics CD (which he described as a followup to the first ever Rampart release) uses a lot of loops and piercing tones. It's a fairly apt title, as the sounds do become annoying and antisocial. Once again, Trevor masters whatever he attempts to do musically. He ought to do more in this style, as it has really strong sense of rhythm (without being actually rhythmic). [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 9 August 2006

Dream/Aktion Unit - Blood Shadow Rampage

Label: Volcanic Tongue

Format: CD

Source: Heather

Cost: £0

As a large group recording I expected this to get lost under its own weight but it's completely great. My favorite moments are where some goofier sounds poke out, giving it an almost carnivalesque feel. I'm not sure which musician brings that to the group - maybe Thurston? - but it reminds me of Dutch free jazz,like the Willem Breuker Kollektief or something (though obviously less melodic). [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 9 August 2006

Three Legged Race - Mourning Order

Label: Mountaain

Format: CDr Limited Edition

Source: Robert

Cost: £0

A 27-minute solo work by Robert Beatty, Mourning Order works from a serious, intense sound art perspective; it begins with full-bodied synthesizer tones laid on thick, sounding more like drones/horns than like synthesizers often do. After about 8 minutes this shifts to a slow buildup of church bells over a rustling restlessness which feels a bit like water, but is clearly all electrons. This builds into a persistent, abrasive oscillation, too fast to tune out and too slow to ignore. What's magnificent here is the fidelity - it's not of this world, an echo from some alien creation. This was probably a great live set, though it's not recorded live. [23 August 2012]


Date: 9 August 2006

Hair Police - Untitled

Label: Gods of Tundra

Format: CDr

Source: Mike

Cost: £0

The European tour CD-R was thrown together in a messy manner; I know one track is Robert solo - the first track reminds me of something they played in Glasgow so maybe it's an early version of a piece they were working on. Even as an odds and ends collections there's something special about Hair Police; I might even prefer the loose feel of this to a lot of their "proper", studio albums. [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 23 August 2006

Hermann Nitsch - Musik Der 60. Aktion, Berlin 1978 / Musik Für Rita Nitsch Geburtstag

Label: Alga Marghen

Format: CD Album

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6.99

A collection of later Herman Nitsch stuff that I got secondhand, this uses some weird No Wave band as part of a larger, somewhat conceptual piece. There are some strange juxtapositions that make it sound like early, sloppy plunderphonics. It's very unusual music - in a way significantly darker than the Aktionist stuff I've heard, perhaps because its harder to place it into context. [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 23 August 2006

Richard Youngs - Untitled

Label: No Fans Records

Format: CD-R

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £7.99

These seven songs form Richard, released in 2006 in a super limited untitled CDr, would make a great Jagjaguwar record akin to May or Airs of the Ear. All of these songs are built around looped vocal fragments with enough delay between them to make a round-type style. This isn't just Richard singing 'Row, Row, Row your Boat' but instead creating a disorientating, yet inviting soundscape around these vocals. It's all acoustic, using some ethnic instruments (shakuhachi which sounds like a ghost; a Thai harp, and some zither too) plus a basic acoustic guitar pattern and slide electric bass under everything. [30 December 2012]


Date: 23 August 2006

Dreamcatcher - Nimbus

Label: Fluorescent Friends

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £11

I saw this weird Montreal band play in a  Baltimore basement back in 2005 and dug 'em. it was Blake Hargreaves, who made this wonderfully damaged solo LP, and a very tall blond girl, and they made destroyed, dark electronic noise workouts that played off each other well. Using feedback, distortion and the usual bag of tricks, Dreamcatcher make a ruckus and the LP is pretty much as I remember the live show - strangely inviting, despite being a Wolf Eyes-like wall of sound. This somehow sounds like everything else that was happening in that world at that time, yet above average in execution. I don't listen to this much and may not need to carry it around forever, but it's an obscurity even among a genre of obscurities. [8 November 2012]


Date: 23 August 2006

Bruhin, Anton - InOut

Label: Alga Marghen

Format: CD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6.99

Records like this remind me of the reasons I first found experimental music inspiring - the sense of ingenuity, excitement, and sheer strangeness. Music like this amazes me because it's so primitive but could be made from another planet. Long live the cassette tape, even if working with them annoys me a lot; if I had the pause-button skills of Anton Bruhin I'd be a happy man. [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 23 August 2006

Flaherty/Corsano/Yeh - Snow Blind Avalanche

Label: Important

Format: LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £12.99

Pure free jazz from this fantastic trio, a natural pairing really as all envision 'freedom' slightly differently. Spencer and Corsano are both rather furtive, playing around the pulse instead of directly into the middle, while Flaherty burrows straight through like a rocketship. There are parts of the opening track, 'Human Suffering', that become incredible sparse - like everyone stops for a solo and then it's just Spencer ekeing out an idea on a scratchy, fuzzy violin. His violin takes the higher register, affected at times but not ridicuously so, and often dancing delicately around Flaherty's guttural blasts. On the second side there's some vocal work which is wonderful against Corsano's rolling rhythms. It's a short record but pressed on thick vinyl and the sound is full and encompassing, despite the extreme frequencies at play. [29 September 2012]


Date: 23 August 2006

Astral Blessing - Astral Blessing

Label: Mad Monk

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £11

This is a Paul Labreque project that was recorded at a live show- the audience chatter is as much a part of side 1 as the music - and it ranges from open chord strumming to full on electric guitar jamming. There's a real late 60's feel to this, almost like Creation or something, and while I didn't care for it at first by the end of the record it really really grew on me. [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 26 August 2006

Family Battle Snake - Crawling Madness

Label: no label

Format: CD-R

Source: Koulio

Cost: £0

This is the duo of Koulio and Harry, rocking it live in London in March. It's a lot closer to the solo FBS show he did at the Captain's Rest than the first CD-R on Curor - a more reflective and well-paced drone that shimmers and pulses. The live recording quality isn't too shoddy but I wonder what a nice 'studio' recording could sound like. [29 Dec 2006] 


Date: 6 September 2006

Strountes - 

Label: Slottet

Format: CD

Source: Daniel

Cost: £0

A seemingly improbably meeting of Mats Gustafsson, Alan Courtis from Reynols and the singer from the Concretes actually works very, very well. This is a collection of short songs which seem to focus mostly around Eriksson's voice, but accented with all manner of instruments. At times it gets quite insane, sounding like Hair Police; other parts are creepy and beautiful. I suspect with a few more listens this could contend for favorite of the year. [9 Sep 2006]


Date: 6 September 2006

DräpEnHund - Be Yourself

Label: Slottet

Format: CD

Source: Daniel

Cost: £0

This is Mats Gustaffson's teenage daughter and her friend playing "drum and bass" music, or rather, rock music using just drums and bass. There's nothing particularly derivative about this, but it isn't that great either - I guess that's what you get from having 13 year olds make a CD. The singing gets annoyoing and after about 3 tracks, the novelty wears off entirely. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 15 September 2006

Blazing Bulkheads - 

Label: Rocks and Rolling

Format: CD-R

Source: Weird Paul

Cost: £0



Date: 19 September 2006

Nüx - Analog Dreams

Label: Tagbanger Media

Format: cassette

Source: McDowell

Cost: £0



Date: 19 September 2006

Melted Prism - Improvisations Spring 2006

Label: Biological Radio

Format: cassette

Source: McDowell

Cost: £0



Date: 29 September 2006

Tamburo, Mike/Matt McDowell - Searching for Augie Leonard, Sr.

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CD-R

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0



Date: 29 September 2006

Tamburo, Mike/Matt McDowell - God Will Fail John's Horn

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: 3" CD-R

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0

I don't really appreciate having records named after me that I had nothing to do with, but I suppose this isn't too bad. Here's Mike and McDowell playing a God's horn, which sounds like it's been prepared with a variety of objects and effects. It's a nice recording and on this instrument, its hard to do wrong, so I wonder why it's so processed. The parts that are electronically treated to make an ambient soup somehow work - strangely reminding me of O.Rang - but some of the more exaggerated electronics sound a bit cheesy (to use a word McDowell is fond of). [29 Dec 2006]


Date: 29 September 2006

Nüx - The Signal

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CD-R

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0



Date: 29 September 2006

Spiderwebs/Tamburo + McDowell/Lawler - Strands Formerly Braided

Label: Music Fellowship

Format: CD

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0

Spiderwebs start off with some extremely clean plucking, then into a cover of 'Powderfinger'? Or at least that's the title,though it's unrecognizable. Mike and McDowell's track is the one I booted off the last Arco disc; I don?t dislike it though I feel it moves around too much and never really establishes any ideas (great synth part though). Keenan's contribution unsurprisingly steals the show; the second movement has some incredible overtones. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 29 September 2006

Tamburo, Mike - Screwing Sox Bolts Into Last Week

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CD-R

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0

I've always thought of this as Mike's best work (along with the Meisha 'on a clear day' track) but I haven't heard it in a few years. Now, finally issued on CD I have to say it is pretty great. The electric piano at the beginning is pretty, a straight-up reminder of old Meisha stuff, and then when everything falls into itself in manages to keep breathing life into itself by recycling it's own momentum. The weirdo electronics here feel so at odds with Mike's acoustic guitar stuff (even when he tries to implement electronics) and also way, way, way better. [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 29 September 2006

Krejci, David - The Cleophone

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CD-R

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0

Krejci built an instrument out of an old piano and describes the construction of it in the liner notes using a very flowery, poetic language. The one piece on this disc is recorded on the Cleophone, yet somehow manages to sound like the synthesized score to an 80's B-movie action flick at certain parts. There are nicer moments as well, but the instrument suffers from the recording (contact mics, according to the liner notes) which makes everything sound a bit dirty. I think a better recording of the instrument could probably be made, and that might be more interesting to investigate. [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 29 September 2006

Meisha - The Secret Of Paul Groper

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CDr

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0

A Meisha release recorded back in our heyday, based around another of Mike's characters, in this case Paul Groper which was a joke pseudonym for Ken taken too far. This is less rigid than most of the main Meisha albums, with Mike or Ken fingerpicking a lot and some mellow tones behind it all. The tracks are recorded live and sound spacious, echoing through the room. There's a long bit of track 1 where they move to an AMM-style improvisation with quiet clicks and buzzes - it sounds not unlike the bottom falling out of a folk band and wind-up gears instead. Most of this disc is harmonious and lovely, particularly track 3, but it feels a bit indistinct, though it could just be that I still haven't reacclimated to melodic improvised noodling after all these years. [13 Aug 2012]


Date: 29 September 2006

Keenan Lawler - Ghost Of A Plane Of Air

Label: Music Fellowship

Format: CD

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0

Music Fellowship reissued Keenan's semi-classic 1999 CD with an extra track. Actually, isn't this more or less Keenan's only real output? A shame too, because it's an amazing slab of fiery strings, a real vision of a distinct American minimalist drone. This is electroacoustic music at its finest, and it's easy to see why he clicked so much with Tamburo - Keenan's music is dramatic, passionate, and fluid. The extra track sounds sloppy at first, dobro notes bucking in a breeze, but it rights itself and blazes on with an intensity that is perfect when the final cut, 'A Suspension in Dream Time' takes over. This is a long, immersive piee that is Keenan's masterpiece. I wonder if he'll ever get anything together again. [24 September 2012]


Date: 29 September 2006

Fathmount - 6-string Renderings (one)

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CD-R

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0

I don't know anything about these guys (guy? Girl?) but this is presumably guitar-based, and it has some really interesting strange textures that have no real comparisons, but also some parts where they turn on a distortion unit and it sounds like the end of a Mudhoney song. The fuzz parts make it sound very amateurish - not a bad thing on its own - but the really great unusual plinkings and tones seem completely at odds with the other side of them - and they seem to shift between these modes frequently, even within a same piece. But it's very interesting, perhaps the most interesting thing Mike'es released yet. [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 29 September 2006

Robert Horton (2) - Winter Suite

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CDr

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0



Date: 29 September 2006

Meisha - For Sayas

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CDr Limited Edition

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0



Date: 29 September 2006

Horton, Robert - Expootition

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: CD-R

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0

I think Robert Horton is from Texas; I don't know much about him but this CD ranges from Jeweled Antler-esque folk pluckings to electroacoustic drone - very much Tamburo's kinda thing,and its nice. A few years ago I woulda flipped out hearing this but these days it feels like so many people are doing it... which doesn't mean it isn't of value. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 29 September 2006

Lawler, Keenan - The Strange Tale of Eddy Westport

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: 3" CD-R

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: £0



Date: 7 October 2006

Stelzer, Howie and Tim Feeney - Never Happened

Label: Audiobot

Format: CD-R

Source: Carlo

Cost: £0

Dirty, noisy improvised music? How surprising, as this year's spreadsheet is full of it. I really like Howie Stelzer but there was nothing on here to warrant me remembering this a week after I listened to it. That's not to say there wasn't an incredible amount of effort and technique put into it, but rather that my own music intake overload is starting to get in the way of my enjoyment. [28 Jan 2007]


Date: 7 October 2006

Albert Ortega - Fuzzy Pupa

Label: Audiobot

Format: CDr Limited Edition

Source: Carlo

Cost: £0

Another new artist on Audiobot - this guy works with electronics,I guess. There's a wide range of sounds on this disc, which is broken up into tracks that work more like textures. It reminds me a bit of Asmus Tietchens and also like something I would have seen at the Transmissions festival in '00. For repeated listening, surely. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 7 October 2006

Kitchen Cynics - Compulsive Songwriting Disorder

Label: Audiobot

Format: CDr

Source: Carlo

Cost: £0

The Kitchen Cynics are some Scottish songwriter project that reminds me of a jangly, more psychedelic Robyn Hitchcock with some weird psych-drone parts but mostly a clean melodic purpose. It's a pleasant CD-R, and a real surprise from Audiobot, but by the end I wanted to put something else on. Still, this might be something to go back to in the future. [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 8 October 2006

Dananananaykroyd - Totally Bone / Hey Giles

Label: Moshi Moshi Records

Format: Vinyl 7" Single

Source: Giles

Cost: £0

This is a funny thing to pull out. When I lived in Glasgow, my dear friend Giles and another friend/acquaintance Duncan started playing in this band, a strange juxtaposition between pop-emo and something more aggressive. The first time I saw them I didn't even notice that they had two drummers; I was somewhat surprised by the tone of the band, which I thought would be more art-rock. Giles didn't last long due to tension about the direction of the band (one member's explicit goal was to sign to a major label) and soon departed, leaving only these two songs as a record of his involvement. Giles is more rooted in 90s punk/hardcore than anyone I know and thus these two songs have a hard, screamy edge that recalls (thanks to the catchy guitar lines) bands like Cap'n Jazz. I remember hating this when it came out and now it already feels retro and kinda funny (opening lyric is 'This is how I became emasculated'). His eponymous song is certainly the Dananananaykroyd song I remember the most; it's nice to have this, his Howard Devoto moment. After this they embarked on a series of lineup changes and attempts to raise their profile, getting into shitty battle-of-the-bands circuits, eventually signing to Mogwai's label (I think) and well, who knows where they are now? Duncan is a great guy and I hope he's doing well. [18 November 2012]


Date: 12 October 2006

Hungover Breakfast - Untitled

Label: Alcoholic Narcolepsy

Format: Cassette Single Sided

Source: Steve Warwick

Cost: £0

Steve solo is a spastic affair, with ADHD-fueled electronics bursting around, the occasional long sinewave squeal, and a lot of static around everything. It's a great work of electronic weirdness and not at all mellow like you would expect with a name like Hungover Breakfast. The band-aid holding the tape case shut is a nice touch. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 12 October 2006

Heatsick - Pre-Cum Fog Ballet

Label: Alcoholic Narcolepsy

Format: Cassette

Source: Steve Warwick

Cost: £0

Solo Warwick tape that works around a melodic looping guitar figure, recorded in a dirty manner to sound like a lo-fi Steve Reich with painful moans emerging. Side two finds these moans overriding the guitar loops, becoming center focus. The tape runs from end to end, suggesting that this is an excerpt of a larger work. [20 Jan 2007]


Date: 12 October 2006

Heatsick - Total Afternoon Sundae

Label: Alcoholic Narcolepsy

Format: Cassette

Source: Steve Warwick

Cost: £0

It's funny going through random old tapes and finding this, the Steve Warwick I know and love -- a far cry from the Casio-house that he does in Berlin clubs to great acclaim.Total Afternoon Sundae begins with a side long repetition called 'Previously Unseen Brook', a cycle of ebb and flow, with audible keyboard drone behind the waves of confusion. It's noise music that isn't harsh or distinctly digital - and it's recorded piss-poorly, with complete dropouts and so lo-fi it's almost irritating -- though I like it. On the flip, some shorter tracks: 'Later, Mirror' is a lengthy wave of keyboard drone but they all kinda sound the same. Closer 'Unspent Realisation of Dawning Release' (which has to be about ejaculation, as does the title of the whole cassette) is pretty, and then ends suddenly when the tape runs out. [11 July 2012]


Date: 12 October 2006

Younger, Luke - Full Bloom

Label: Alcoholic Narcolepsy

Format: CD-R

Source: Steve Warwick

Cost: £0

Luke's solo disc is loow-key electronics, I guess I would say harsh but not really, just not mellow either - maybe mid-rangey? "Refined Reason #1" is my pick, a longer and rather plastic sounding buzzing that is psychedelic in a very Luke Younger way. [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 17 October 2006

Nmperign/Jason Lescaleet - Love Me Two Times

Label: Intransitive

Format: 2xCD

Source: Jason Lescalleet

Cost: £0

Two hours of these three gentlemen is a lot, but it's minimalism isn't it? Jason's tape work adds a lot to the Nmperign sound - to the point where I'm not entirely sure what's him and what's them. The obvious speech samples are there of course, but it's not that frequent, and works really well to change the mood of pieces. It's an entierly different approach to tape improvisation than Luke and I have used, and it's really nice especially on the ultra-minimal stuff (long parts of Disc 2 are almost inaudible in the office environment where I listen). This is a very good meeting of minds (as it was live). [29 Dec 2006]


Date: 17 October 2006

Jason Lescalleet - Electronic Music

Label: RRRecords

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jason Lescalleet

Cost: £0

This album comes highly recommended by Aaron Rosenblum, and I see why. Jason's tape manipulations are incredibly warm, like audio liquid that runs thick. There's not too much going on where one loses focus - it's highly constructed, from simple sources. The flutter and flicker that pervades everything gives this record a cinematic quality, like a projector whirring. Brilliant. [18 Jan 2007] 


Date: 17 October 2006

Jason Lescalleet - The Pilgrim

Label: Glistening Examples

Format: Vinyl Picture Disc LPCD

Source: Jason Lescalleet

Cost: £0

I don't even know how to properly assess this work, which is one of the most personal, intense, devastating and extreme releases I've ever encountered. Jason is an intense guy but I never thought he would create something this emotional, yet still in the realm of experimental music. The second side of this picture disc is something I may never listen to again because it is extremely difficult to sit through. Of all the music I've heard that tries to be extreme and uncomfortable, this surpasses it all. This isn't much of an "opinion" because it's really hard for me to come to terms with this yet. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 17 October 2006

Jason Lescalleet's Due Process - Combines XIX, XX

Label: We Break More Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jason Lescalleet

Cost: £0

I think Due Process is a series that Ron Lessard does with different artists; Jason's presumably has Ron playing on it, though I can't identify any particular interplay between two people. This is a very collage-based work, reminding me of Prick Decay with lots of weird loops and samples. At first I didn't really get into it, but now I'm feeling it to be pretty excellent, like all of Jason's work. [25 Jan 2007]


Date: 3 November 2006

Horrible - Untitled

Label: X+Z=0

Format: Cassette Limited Edition Single Sided

Source: Erwin

Cost: £0



Date: 5 November 2006

Ashtray Navigations - The Vulgar Glissando

Label: Beyond Repair Records

Format: Cassette Limited Edition

Source: Jonas

Cost: £0



Date: 7 November 2006

Te Koop - Tienen

Label: NOISE2

Format: CDr

Source: The Ryfylke guy who's name I for

Cost: £0



Date: 7 November 2006

Eriksen, Jon/Sten Ove Toft/Utarm - Penumbra Booming

Label: no label

Format: CD

Source: Ryflke guy

Cost: £0

A split between three artists, all Norwegian I assume. This was extremely difficult to make it through at work, not because it was bad but because it was generally extremely harsh noise with lots of movement. It reminded me a bit of John Weise's work, actually - though the middle piece had a bunch of cheesy classical music samples, processed pretty heavily but still a bit awkward. They burn down churches in this place so I guess I'm not surprised that they make extremely harsh noise. [25 Jan 2006]


Date: 8 November 2006

Crazy River - Sounds Like A Melon To Me

Label: Humbug

Format: CD

Source: Per Gisle

Cost: £0

Per Gisle's solo project is as varied and eclectic as you'd imagine from a man with such diverse taste in music. There are some bits that remind me of Pumice, with thick organ and a rolling rhythm. Other parts are pop-based psychedelia. Much of the disc has weird vocals that sound like talk radio or overheard conversations; they're buried under everything and it works really well though gets perhaps a bit tiring by the end. Not everything works, but a few tracks are really excellent and I'd like to hear him make another one. [25 Jan 2007]


Date: 9 November 2006

Surplus People - 

Label: no label

Format: CD-R

Source: Record store in Malm?

Cost: £0



Date: 9 November 2006

Anla Courtis Klingsor Ved - Lives pa Pa Besök

Label: Mussigganger

Format: CDr Mini

Source: Record store in Malm?

Cost: £0

Live recording from the great little cafe that Ben and I played at, Courtis I assume being Anla Courtis of Reynols. No idea who Klingsor or Ved are, or who is playing what, but this 3" is a recording of a nice group session with a rolling, oceanlike drone with some quietly noisy elements underneath, soon fading into a cloud of screaming seagulls. Some synth squeals are present but it all fits together really well. The second track is a looser, spacious improvisation with some clarinet playing that reminds me a bit of Volcano the Bear, only murkier. [29 Dec 2006] 


Date: 9 November 2006

Klingsor Presenterar - Inspelningar fran ett kallarhal II

Label: Klingsor

Format: CD-R

Source: Record store in Malm?

Cost: £0

Another random Malm? record store purchase; this is the most disappointing of them so far, with a bunch of Tortoise-styled postrock, some guitar textures layered overtop that harken back to shoegazer days, and rudimentary electronics. It sounds incredibly reductive to say this, but it could be a mashup of MBV, Tortoise and Oval and it wouldn't surprise me. [25 Jan 2007]


Date: 9 November 2006

Ved - Demis Roussos Internal

Label: Mussigganger

Format: 3" CD-R

Source: Record store in Malm?

Cost: £0

Another 3" on Henrik's label by Ved, whomever that is - a bit different from the improvised jam with Courtis, this is one longer track that runs from layered drones to weird casio-beat electronica. There's something very bright about it all, and I found myself really enjoying it, though I'm not sure if there's a unified vision at work here. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 11 November 2006

Bomper Patrol Committee - 

Label: none

Format: CD-R

Source: Dale Jiminez

Cost: £0



Date: 13 November 2006

Brasil And The Gallowbrothers Band - Legionowo

Label: Monotype Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Tomek

Cost: £0



Date: 13 November 2006

Mirt - Oh! You Are So Na?ve!

Label: Monotype

Format: CD

Source: Tomek

Cost: £0

Not surprising, Tomek's solo disc is a bunch of ambient synthesizer pieces with some trumpet - just like his live show, and when we played with him. I much prefer having a recording of this because it is very much atmospheric, all gesure and intention, the kind of music that warms up an environment. I feel like this would have blown me away a few years ago, while now I seek out the challenges of the Nmperign/Lescalleet discs with more enthusiasm. But there's a lot to be said for this approach still. [30 Dec 2006]


Date: 13 November 2006

Valerio Cosi - Conference Of The Aquarians

Label: Palustre

Format: CDr

Source: Valerio

Cost: £0

Billed as Valerio and Enzo Francini on "aquarian alto" and "aquarian drums", this sound more like a Valerio solo album - or maybe aquarian alto is Italian for guitar. I dunno but this moves from free squonk with heavy metal drumming to Krankyesque drone layers, all a bit new agey in that Italian way (but it's called Conference of the Aquarians, isn't it?). This Aries is stoked to have gotten to hung out with V&E for 3 wonderful days in my homeland. [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 13 November 2006

Valerio Cosi - The Three Faces Of Moongod

Label: Ruralfaune

Format: CDr Album Limited Edition

Source: Valerio

Cost: £0

Completely different from the jazz approaches I saw him do live, this find Valerio staring into his crystal ball, making a soundtrack to a 'nighttime panistic ritual'. And it fucking rules - the lengthy middle track 'Invocation' is a brilliant circular ritual indeed, with some clattery percussion and a beautiful accordion track, sounding like the Third Ear Band hiding in the bushes beneath an orgy. The last track is a simple, but effective bit of slumbertime. I'll keep saying it - Valerio is a FORCE! [29 Dec 2006] 


Date: 13 November 2006

Valerio Cosi - Immortal Attitudes

Label: Foxglove

Format: CDr Album

Source: Valerio

Cost: £0



Date: 13 November 2006

Cosi, Valerio/Wilson Lee - Cold Solemn Rites in the Sun

Label: Mymwly

Format: CD-R

Source: Valerio

Cost: £0

Valerio's collaboration with Wilson Lee (whomever he is) is as crisply recorded as the others, yet goes into a heavy ECM/New Age at times, which doesn't thrill me as much as the deep occult trance of Three Faces of the Moongod. Still, there is some interesting guitar clatter and a few really nice synth layers. It's hard for me to not just love everything Valerio is doing. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 22 November 2006

Pavement - Wowee Zowee - Sordid Sentinels Edition

Label: Domino Recording Company Ltd.

Format: CD Album Remastered ReissueCD Compilation

Source: Fnac, Lyon

Cost: €20

As proof of my own aging, all of Pavement's albums have gotten reissue treatment and I'm barely in my 30s. The Crooked Rain and Slanted and Enchanted reissued are pretty essential as all of the live and b-side material from those eras is part of the cement that holds together my church of Pavement. But here's where it starts to tail off. Don't get me wrong - Wowee Zowee is unquestionably my favourite Pavement album. (Actually, I'll drag out my oft-repeated Mark Twain analogy - Slanted and Enchanted is the Huck Finn of Pavement albums, the 'greatest'; but Wowee Zowee, like The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, is actually 'better'). I bought this album on cassette, on my 15th birthday, and immediately found it a more difficult listen than the previous ones. Being that I was young and determined, I stuck with it, and now find this to be the band's masterpiece. But as far as a double-CD reissue, it's not exactly overkill, but it's far less necessary to me than CR,CR/S&E.


It certainly deserved a reissue (after only 11 years, though) and I scooped it up while in France, just glad to have so many of the extra tracks in one place. The Pacific Trim EP is here in its entirety, meaning I don't have to wear out my very-travelled 7" -- though I still will, because vinyl always sounds better. The second disc here, I actually left at a friend's house in Glasgow and had to burn a replacement copy, but it doesn't really matter cause I rarely listen to it. There's some good songs for sure, though a lot of live/radio material that feels more like it's there for the sake of completeness than anything else; whereas the bonus material on the two prior reissues is almost entirely essential to the Pavement myth. 'Easily Fooled' is probably the B-side of this era I've loved the most, but it doesn't fit with Wowee Zowee proper, which is still the most valuable thing on here. [29 December 2012]



Date: 1 December 2006

Toyerro - 

Label: Ahaeon

Format: CD-R

Source: Raph

Cost: £0

Raph from Bordeaux's project is a highly processed approach to electric guitars and drones, with a rich dynamic range from the organic meeting the digital. Sequenced as one long track, there are some deep droney parts that are really beautiful, like a French version of Organum, and other parts that could be an Ashtray Navigations guitar solo. But because he uses a laptop, a lot of people I know won't ever give this guy a chance, even though this record kills half the other stuff out there. [29 Dec 2006]


Date: 1 December 2006

Toyerro/Defleur Fantome - df-t

Label: Ahaeon

Format: CD-R

Source: Raph

Cost: £0

Split release between Raph and someone else, with (I assume) collaborative improvisations mixed among the individual tracks. Their styles work well together; the waves of static are thick and suggest a giant electroacoustic scream. Maybe people should start paying attention to what is coming out of Bordeaux - I am now. [25 Jan 2007]


Date: 2 December 2006

Reynolds, Ben - Basic Consciousness

Label: Dreams the Ship

Format: cassette

Source: Ben

Cost: £0



Date: 2 December 2006

Frozen Corpse - Fueld by Asteroids

Label: Puik

Format: cassette

Source: Jelle Crama

Cost: £0

Frozen Corpse must be some Belgian nonsense; much of the tape is murky rumbling that sounds like a really bad hangover. One part goes into a gamelan or steel drum workout, though recorded through a beat-up tape recorder - it's nice though. The tape ends with a recording from an Italian TV show. Those Antwerpians are all so wacky... great packaging by Jelle, as always. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 2 December 2006

Stuckometer - Onyx

Label: no label

Format: DVD-R

Source: Stuckometer

Cost: £0

This DVD freezes when inserted into my computer; perhaps spraypainting discs has a negative effect? Will try again later.


Date: 2 December 2006

Ashtray Navigations - Four More Raga Moods

Label: Ikuisuus

Format: CD

Source: Ben Reynolds

Cost: £0

This captures Ashtray Navigations just before Ben and I became friends, so now it feels like a strangely familiar document due to my familarity with the musicians on it.  The opening track, 'History of Psychedelia', begins with a weird cut-up tape moment before Ben starts to play the acoustic guitar in that flowery style he was big on at the time.  The track features Andy Jarvis so it may be from the Helvetica is the Perfume of the City sessions.  'Hey Sunflower Motherfucker' is Phil solo, and it's a 10 minute "typical" Ashtray track, though that's not to denigrate it - it's a deep, dense buildup of drone and feedback.  'The Pete Nolan Effect' is Pete and Phil and Mel Delaney and Ben, and it opens with ten minutes of melodies buried under a ridiculous amount of tape hiss - before the proper "jam" comes in, with a flange-heavy distant recording technique.  It starts slowly - very slowly - and over the course of the next twenty minutes it moves little. Pete Nolan is on guitar so it doesn't come in with any thunderous rocking; in fact, it's difficult to determine what, if anything, is "the Pete Nolan effect".  The final track is another twenty minutes of deep dense droning, this time featuring Chris, Alex and Matt Cairns - a weirdo Ashtray/Scatter hybrid that is spooky and foreign-sounding due to the presence of dijiridoo and "magic bouzouki".  Everything is still staticy and crackly, and it's actually quite a gem from the discographies of all of these gentlemen, yet one that is probably forgotten by being buried at the end of a 70+ minute Astray Navigations CD that no one will ever listen to the end of.  Despite the deluxe gatefold CD packaging and the crisp CD sound, Phil made sure to keep enough noise and static on here to show his roots, and if you want a document of what he was doing in 2004-2005 it's probably the best one I've heard.  [12 Jan 2009]



Date: 5 December 2006

Blood Stereo - Enfold The Hiss

Label: Chocolate Monk

Format: CDr

Source: Dylan Nyoukis

Cost: £0

Half tape recordings, half live, this seems to be an accurate representation of the Blood Stereo show that I saw at ATP a few weeks ago, though without the weird visual sense of watching Dylan performing. The creeping sense of terror is present, created through the disconnected human voices and unidentifiable electronic processing, all buried in a think blanket of hiss. Blood Stereo are a remarkable thing to experience and this makes me want to track down more recordings. [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 5 December 2006

Courtis, Anla/Dylan Nyoukis - Fight the Pyramids

Label: Chocolate Monk

Format: CD-R

Source: Dylan Nyoukis

Cost: £0

Track 1 is Courtis, which is weird but not unlike the Blood Stereo philosophy. Dylan's solo track is all Casio-based, with some weird bursts and a heavy drone conclusion. It has the strange, displaced cut-up feeling that his music has and it works really well in it's lo-fi glory. The combined live track doesn't sound live but rather like one processing the other, and then switching off. There's some clattery bits that are probably guitarbased, and then some fluid tape sections with quiet, muffled clanging. [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 5 December 2006

Robedoor - Christ's Vipers

Label: Chocolate Monk

Format: CDr

Source: Dylan Nyoukis

Cost: £0

An American drone group discovered by Dylan Nyoukis (well, at least that's how I'll imagine it), Robedoor mine similar territory to Birds of Delay and other UK dronetronics groups. The CD has that type of dark, grimy haze that I'm used to hearing by this point, and I'm not sure if there's anything special about it that would make me chose this over others. Still, it's enjoyable and I will give it a deeper listen when I have more time. [25 Jan 2007]


Date: 7 December 2006

Sudden Infant & Bill Kouligas - Split

Label: absurd

Format: CDr Album

Source: Koulio

Cost: £0

This is a split release, not a collabration, though Koulio played in Sudden Infant when he gave me this and it was fucking great! The Sudden Infant half starts off very promising, with weird guttural vocal spurts before descending into a wall of harsh electronics. Koulio likewise teases with some drones before everything explodes; the live track "Breast/Hole" is wonderfully named. Very noisy, and not something I will listen to frequently, but it shows these two musicians whose styles complement each other well. [20 Jan 2007]


Date: 7 December 2006

Birds of Delay - 

Label: Alcoholic Narcolepsy

Format: CD-R

Source: Steve Warwick

Cost: £0

A very limited Birds of Delay CD-R of their live set in Paris that may be my favorite release by them - it's exuberant, built around swelling keyboards and happy drones. I think I prefer this side of them to the chaotic bits, and Luke says they're going to re-release this in a larger run so I hope they do and people hear it. Very very nice! [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 8 December 2006

Jazzfinger - Slowed By The Grace Of Water

Label: Alcoholic Narcolepsy

Format: CDr

Source: Ben Jones

Cost: £0

Some more recent Jazzfinger recordings that are very much made of amp hiss, scraggly free playing, and drones. This is much more lo-fi than their first CD and surprisingly I don't like it as much, though it is closer to their incredible live show at the Arches. [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 9 December 2006

Teignmouth Electron - 

Label: none

Format: 3" CD-R

Source: Moreen from Leopard Leg

Cost: £0

Moreen (Koulio's ex) passed me this at ATP, a 3" cd-r of her solo voice and electronics (I think). It's really good, too - fluid, active washes of distortion but all in a pleasing manner, with rotating vocal drones panning across. At the end it goes into a crazy babbling wacky section before fading out. I never heard Leopard Leg but I assume they were a lot different than this (which is more akin to Polly Shang Kuan). Let's hear some more! [29 Dec 2006] 


Date: 10 December 2006

Family Underground - Familiar Places

Label: Into The Lunar Night

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: ATP Merch table

Cost: £10

I probably don't need to become a Family Underground completist but having one on vinyl is a good way to be. This is unsurpringly a set of slow, fluid drones with some free improvisation. There are some gritty sounds buried in the waves, but generally it keeps to a minmal, Organumesque vibe. The rhythmic elements serve to emphasize the drone, and theres a really strong sense of control from these (lovely) Danes. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 10 December 2006

Ju Suk Reet Meate et al - Dr. Octopus pts 1 and 2

Label: no label

Format: LP

Source: ATP Merch table

Cost: £10

A Smegma side project that sounds straight out of the Futura 1970's. It's mellow, weird, with unidentifiable instruments collaging against processed voices in the most surreal of ways. The whole record flows as one piece and I suspect it was edited out of one long jam. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 10 December 2006

Birth Refusal and Cassis Cornuta - 

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: 1-sided LP

Source: ATP Merch table

Cost: £12

Cassis Cornuta's contributions are clear- the weird Ubu-esque doppler effects and white noise that surround Olson and Connelly's dark rumblings. It gets scarier as it progresses, and while it doesn't offer any surprises, it's a very good document of these three. It ends with great repetitive whispery sounds over electronic tones - very clinical! [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 10 December 2006

Burning Star Core - Everyday World Of Bodies

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: ATP Merch table

Cost: £12

This may be my favorite Burning Star Core release ever- it opens some new directions in voice/casio collaboration, and has some moments of total beauty in doing so - but it also refines previous approaches more. The violin work is less obvious but perfect where it is. The whole album just sounds really GOOD on vinyl, and its named after a Rodan song too. Stunning. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 10 December 2006

Hair Police - Prescribed Burning

Label: Hospital Productions

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Trevor

Cost: £0

The newest Hair Police full-length (and their only "proper" release of 2006) sounds lovely on Hospital's thick vinyl issue. The first side is a very minimal, atmospheric side that I have seen Hair Police do live but never as focused as this. The attention to detail is great. The second side is more varied, with some really fucked up parts that dont wear out their welcome. I suspect this might not be remembered as much as some of their other records, but it's a good look at the complexity possible from these three wonderful dudes. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 10 December 2006

Jazzfinger - The Little Girl on the Plane Who Turned Her Doll's Head Around To Look at Me

Label: Muza

Format: CD

Source: Ben Jones

Cost: £0

A reissue of the first ever Jazzfinger album, which was way back in the late 90's. And it's fantastic! I know they've gone in a somewhat different direction now, but this isn?t miles away - you can hear their approach, and there is still a similar philosophy behind the newer stuff. But this is actually recorded really well, so there's a lot of texture to feel. [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 10 December 2006

Lambsbread - Black Star Liner

Label: Maim and Disfigure

Format: CD-R

Source: Merch table @ ATP

Cost: £5

This is a screaming mess of free rock that is pretty great. Like their live show, Zac's guitar dominates and the late-Flag stylings are totally heavy and wild. Lamsbread are actually pretty phenomenal to experience ; they take the free rock approaches that many people are going for now and infuse it with punk roots. This is also 3 times as long as they play live so maybe it's more satisfying (though there's less of a pit). [28 Dec 2006]


Date: 10 December 2006

Micht - Termitine

Label: Audiobot

Format: CD-R

Source: Carlo

Cost: £0

Carlo enthusiastically gave me this new Audiobot release of some weirdo Belgian who proudly uses "No gear". And I wonder what that means, for although this is a harsh burst of static, unrelenting, for 20 minutes it sounds like it's definitely recorded to a tape loop or some sort of looping device, so I wonder what 'gear' is defined as. Maybe this is just an endless loop cassette and he's rubbing the internal microphone of a boombox with a piece of cloth... but even still, that's 'gear', isn't it? [29 Dec 2006] 


Date: 10 December 2006

Caves (2) - Flood Room

Label: Rampart Tapes

Format: Cassette

Source: Trevor

Cost: £0

My former housemate Ben Allen has been working solo as Caves since just about the time I left Lexington, but this is the first recorded work I've heard. Side 1 is a distorted grunge jam, probably based on guitar. Side 2 begins with some pulsing, stacatto sounds before turning into a very visceral pounding that eventually evaporates. Well made and it will be cool to hear Ben do more. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 10 December 2006

Failing Lights - False Dawn

Label: Rampart Tapes

Format: Cassette

Source: Trevor

Cost: £0

A solo cassette by Mike Connelly is made up mostly of low (synth?) drones, with some friction generated by their different interactions. It's gritty, and very much a 'Rampart' type of aesthetic. The end of side 2 has some clanging guitars (I think), all integrated into the mix. Great artwork and overall another great Rampart release. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 11 December 2006

Working Poor - Come Down For Your Silver

Label: Rickety

Format: CD

Source: Leah

Cost: £0

Nothing can make me rejoice as much as a new CD by the Working Poor. And it doesn't disappoint, although it's not as completely solid as the classic New Wealth, this has a few songs that are completely brilliant, such as 'Another Restless Night' and 'Grey Cat'. I prefer the purely acoustic work, but Greg's electric guitar does add the ragtag edge that Alan's songs are built around. The recording is pretty good and I've already listened to this a few times but I plan to a million more. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 11 December 2006

MikelDimmickSpiralJoyBand - Floating Seer

Label: Klang

Format: CD-R

Source: Spiral Joy Band

Cost: £0

Revised edition of a Spiral Joy CD-R that moves from static-based old radio drone to the blissful, shruti-centered style they are known for. There's a track of dirty percussion that doesn't feel out of place though it's obviously a different style, and a track from the duo sessions I did with Mike that is one of the best sounding esraj pieces I've ever done. Interesting that it's titled as mikeldimmickspiraljoy even though Mikel doesn't play on every track. [18 Jan 2007]


Date: 15 February 2007

Lily Greenham - Lingual Music

Label: Paradigm Discs

Format: 2xCD Album

Source: Volcanic Tongue (credit)

Cost: £0

Greenham is an unrecognized sound poet who's been dragged out of obscurity by Paradigm in this deluxe reissue (along with Daphne Oram, which I want to get too). Greenham's work is reminiscent of Henri Chopin in that it utilizes tapes and manipulations to create weird atmospherics. Some live performances are included here too. It's a lot to take in, and after two months I still don't feel like I really know the work well. One long piece of disc 1 is beautiful, similar to that Dwight Frizell 'Natural Selection' night sky type of feeling. I don't know if she was going for pastoralism, but that's what I extract for it at least. [7 Apr 2007]


Date: 15 February 2007

Toshi Ichiyanagi - Obscure Tape Music Of Japan Vol.5: Music For Tinguely

Label: Edition Omega Point

Format: CD Album

Source: Volcanic Tongue (credit)

Cost: £0

"Obscure tape music of Japan vol. 5"- How can I not be drawn to a title like that? The music on here doesn't sound particularly tape-based beyond the first track, a stuttering cold mechnical outburst. The lengthy middle piece, assembled however which way, sounds like a screaming guitar, sounding like something from Keiji Haino (completely with amp buzz and room atmosphere). The final track begins with a vocal choir, but before anything gets too devotional, it is overtaken by a synthesized computer voice, sounding like an early 80's Commodore 64 babbling in Japanese. It's odd.


Date: 14 April 2007

Love Crimes/Oakwhistle and Ludo Mich - 

Label: Puik

Format: cassette

Source: Jelle

Cost: £0

Jelle has this tendency to go to shows, tape them, and then release them without crediting or asking anyone. I didn't mind though, and I was really surprised to get two copies of this in the mail, kinda like "Whoa, I have a new tape out, cool." The Love Crimes side is much more repetitive and dreamy than I remember it being that night but strangely hypnotic, broken only by applause and my shouts of "LIEVEN! LIEVEN!". My collaboration with Ludo was pretty insane and I'm glad it's been documented, even though our names aren't listed on this and Jelle wasn't even sure it was me. [14 April 2007]


Date: 23 April 2007

Minn Minn Lights Duo - 

Label: Shh/Bzz

Format: CD-R

Source: Daniel Meyer Gr?nvold

Cost: £0

This duo recording of just Daniel and ?ivind is a really mellow, blurry drone. It sounds very much like a casual aside - almost like a recording of the in-between moments. [28 Oct 2007]


Date: 23 April 2007

Ghost Hairdo - Injure the Horizon

Label: Shh/Bzz

Format: CD-R

Source: Daniel Meyer Gr?nvold

Cost: £0

Another project of Daniel's, this is a very low-key single track of feedback, whispers, and looped rumblings. It builds into a very harmonic drone by the end via some thumping and scraping. The sounds of the room and recording are very much present here - footsteps, clicks, and other artifacts. [27 Oct 2007]


Date: 23 April 2007

Mi-Kydno - 

Label: Shh/Bzz

Format: CD-R

Source: Daniel Meyer Gr?nvold

Cost: £0

This is the duo that I saw live when I met Daniel, and the recording is a bit more spacious, not as soupy as my memory of their live set. The percussion is really notable here, recorded very bluntly, but that's the awesome thing about it. The sounds are delicate and the closeness of the recording is evident as the non-musical sounds (footsteps, buttons being pressed) are not covered up. Good work. [7 May 2007]


Date: 24 April 2007

Friends and Family - Recycled and Restored Reels of Tape 2003-2006

Label: Leaf Leaf

Format: cassette

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: £0

This is another Dave Sutton III solo project, and it may be the most interesting thing he has ever done. There's 20 "songs" spread across 46 minutes, comprising a primitive, lo-fi New Jersey version of the Faust tapes. Among all of the detritus there are some really beautiful moments, even if they're only the barest gestures. The sound palette varies from hissing electronics to plucked strings and piano; the vocals range from falsetto whispers to almost silly groans. Brilliant. [28 Oct 2007]


Date: 24 April 2007

Celesteville/Friends and Family - split

Label: Leaf Leaf

Format: 3" CD-R

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: £0

Three songs from Celesteville that surprised me by being totally straight, accessibile bedroom folk - and really excellent too. Acoustic guitars and casio sound like a recipe for disaster, but Celesteville holds it together and has something weird and manic about his delivery. Dave's Friends and Family project is a bit more obtuse but still fairly song-oriented here - the crackle and hiss makes everything feel fragile, and one has to work a bit harder to experience the songwriting. This is an excellent release. [7 May 2007]


Date: 24 April 2007

Ladderwoe - Unreleased and out of print

Label: Leaf Leaf

Format: double cassette

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: £0

This double cassette I think was put together for my trade cause I said I was a Ladderwoe fan; there's four different pieces on here, some live, and all great. Although this is incredibly damaged, fucked up music, there are parts that veer into accessibility and structure. When the world sits up and pays attention, they'll be a lot happier. [7 May 2007]


Date: 24 April 2007

2673 - 

Label: Leaf Leaf

Format: cassette

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: £0

This short 2673 tape seems to be compiled from found sounds - weird child speech and low gurgling ambience - and it's over 11 minutes after it begins, far too strange and too short. [25 April 2007]


Date: 24 April 2007

Car Commercials - Jar

Label: Leaf Leaf

Format: 7"

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: £0

There's four songs on this and they are definitely songs, though of the most fucked up variety. It's not just lo-fi, but it's so deliberately obscure yet human, hinting at some actual emotional content but buried under it's own stylistic obsessions. I keep listening to it, as it draws me in mysteriously like the Shadow Ring does. This might be my favorite record of the year so far. [25 Apri 2007]


Date: 24 April 2007

Current Amnesia - 

Label: Leaf Leaf

Format: CD-R

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: £0

Current Amnesia is Dave Sutton solo, I think, and it appears to be a more "refined" sort of ambient/drone project. The first track hangs in the air forever, suspended by one keyboard drone that dominates the soundsphere, with various activities in the background calling for ones devoted attention. The third track is another immense blast of sound, with electronic pulses pulling each other apart, opening up a middle for exploration. There is an incredible attention to detail here, which makes you wonder why he only bothered releasing this in an edition of 10. [4 Nov 2007]


Date: 24 April 2007

Axon Family - 

Label: USAGoldExchange

Format: CD-R

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: £0

Another mysterious outburst that came in the package Dave Sutton sent me; it's probably him or his friends, who knows. This is 55 minutes of total anti-music, packaged in a true anti-packaging style. There's traces of Siltbreeeze-label material (Dead C and Shadow Ring specifically), and the deliberate obfuscation of It's War, Boys and those types of things. Other moments attain a communal beauty not unlike the more damaged end of the Jeweled Antler spectrum. There's enough here to probably warrant a vinyl reissue. I'm so excited about all of these guys. [28 Oct 2007]


Date: 24 April 2007

USAGoldExchange - 

Label: USAGoldExchange

Format: CD-R

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: £0

I'm not sure if this is the artist or label or what - their website just makes things more confusing. Here is a collage of manipulated radio recordings, repetetive guitar meanderings, and outright noise. It has similar gestures as the Leaf Leaf stuff, and what I like so much about this music is its sense of intimacy. [7 May 2007]


Date: 26 April 2007

Burning Star Core - Amelia

Label: No-Fi

Format: Vinyl 10" Limited Edition

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: £0

My double CD set is sorta being reissued as a series of 10"s - it's kinda like a reissue of the original CD-Rs, except not exactly. Well, Amelia is maybe the best Burning Star Core limited release ever, so it's great to have it on vinyl. 'I Want to make Supersonic Woman Out of You' and 'The Point of Departure is Not to Return' sound incredible when mastered to vinyl, even on my crap turntable. It's nice to have 'Homing Pigeon' on wax as well. [28 Oct 2007]


Date: 26 April 2007

Burning Star Core - Blood Lightning 2007

Label: No Fun Productions

Format: CD

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: £0

Another new Burning Star Core full-length, this one beginning with a thick synth drone that is completely enveloping. Later tracks find some vocals that are almost conventional compared to his trademarked approach, and some violin that sounds almost classical for once. Is Spencer going soft? Hardly, as the lengthy jam that closes the disc (and gives it a fairly lopsided feel, though I could see this working on vinyl) shows. [7 May 2007]


Date: 26 April 2007

Times New Viking / Psychedelic Horseshit - Split

Label: 300%

Format: Vinyl 7" Limited Edition

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: £0

If I had heard Times New Viking when I was 18 I probably would have loved them. I do think they are good, and this low-fi collection of riffage suggests that I might benefit from listening to them a bit deeper. Somehow, I just don't think it will happen. Pyschedelic Horseshit are similarly poorly recorded, but have a slightly less aggro approach. It's a fun single though; there's something that feels just a bit retro about it, though I can't really explain why. [3 Nov 2007]


Date: 29 April 2007

KMVSNI / Usurper - Split

Label: Giant Tank

Format: CDr

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: £0

The first two tracks are Lea and Rory, both sounding like they are recorded live. The first track is a banging mess that sounds like a bunch of people falling over their equipment. Track two moves toward a common dronething, really just an extended feedback squal with a bit of low end. Usurper's tracks are a bit on the rambunctious side, as usual recorded on a walkman with the occasional freakout. [6 Nov 2007]


Date: 29 April 2007

Burning Star Core - WSBC/SSS

Label: No-Fi

Format: Vinyl 10" Limited Edition 33 ? RPM

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: £0

This not-quite reissue of White Swords (where's 'Oversleep, Gloria'?) sounds thick and meaty on vinyl. Lee is doing a great job mastering these things; I'm jealous I didn't do MSS as a 4xLP or something. This is one of the busier, thicker mixes of BxC material, and the crackles and pops of my shitty turntable actually help the material. [28 Oct 2007]


Date: 2 May 2007

Yellow Swans Dove Yellow Swans - Live During War Crimes #2

Label: Release The Bats Records

Format: CD

Source: Pete Swanson

Cost: £0

This is taken from their European tour about the time I met these guys, yet features a dronier, less rhythmic sound than the show I saw at that time. The fidelity is reasonably good, though the density of the guitar mess here doesn't necessarily require it; the sense of live performance is captured here, not so much because it has a rough feel but because there's a certain energy present. [7 May 2007]


Date: 2 May 2007

Yellow Swans Descension Yellow Swans - Descension Yellow Swans

Label: Three Lobed Recordings

Format: Vinyl Album LP Limited Edition

Source: Pete Swanson

Cost: £0

This LP is a more reflective, deep drone side of Gabe and Pete. Subsequently, it's my favorite release in the Yellow Swans canon (at least from what I've heard). Both sides are really one long piece, with a dark, distorted drone going throughout. It's not anything groundbreaking, but it's performed with the right amount of restraint and tension - enough to keep it moving but let every tone slowly burn out. [2 Nov 2007]


Date: 2 May 2007

John Wiese - Soft Punk

Label: Troubleman Unlimited

Format: CD

Source: John Wiese

Cost: £0

Previous Wiese stuff I've always enjoyed but found a bit too harsh for day-to-day listening. And while this is definitely harsh, it's totally awesome as well, and I could see myself jamming this disc a lot. The movement in this music is incredibly complex; Wiese also rocks the stereo field like nobody's business. Totally fantastic! [7 May 2007]


Date: 2 May 2007

Ashtray Navigations - Monocycle Americain

Label: Not On Label

Format: CDr Limited Edition

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £0

Seeing Phil of course leads to another Ashtray release in my collection (or LEEDS to one, ha ha) which is totally great, because can you ever have too many? This one is one track, not sure of the lineup because there's minimal packaging but I'd guess Phil, Phil Legard and Mel, and it's a horizontal charge through thick guitar sludge, recorded in a way that it actually feels light, not dense. This might even be the track to play someone who's never heard Ashtray before as it seems to exemplify their approach in just 20 minutes. [2 Nov 2007]


Date: 2 May 2007

Wiese, John/Andy Ortmann - Recorder Out of Tune

Label: Nihilist

Format: CD

Source: John Wiese

Cost: £0

An EP by this collaboration that quite surprises me. There are some extremely punctuated, harsh bits that are what I think of as the John Wiese sound - but other moments that are like a beautiful Nurse With Wound track. Some really great broken violin playing appears on track 2, and there's a really mellow ambience to the whole thing. Very well done, and sure to become a favorite in the Wiese catalog. [26 Oct 2007]


Date: 2 May 2007

Wiese, John and Pain Jerk - Terrazzo

Label: Harbinger Sound

Format: CD

Source: John Wiese

Cost: £0

This cache of discs Wiese handed me were actually pretty varied - this one is probably the most "harsh noise" of them (as "Soft Pink" has enough rhythm and variety, the 'party' album as he described it). Pain Jerk blends with him so well that it's impossible to pinpoint this as a collaboration - maybe because unlike his other collabs, the two artists come from a very similar background. It's 43 minutes that doesn't really let up, and I think I prefer John's stuff with some breathing space. [6 Nov 2007]


Date: 2 May 2007

Wiese, John - Magical Crystal Blah vol. 3

Label: Helicopter/Kitty Play

Format: CD

Source: John Wiese

Cost: £0

I think Wiese actually gave me a copy of this the first time I met him but I never listened to it, or don't remember. This is a 17 minute collection showing Wiese's manipulations of other people's source material. It moves around a lot, with some incredibly active, crunchy fast parts and some more desolate, empty expanses. As always, the fidelity is top-rate and the attention to detail is very precise. [4 Nov 2007]


Date: 15 May 2007

Skeleton Crew - Learn To Talk

Label: RecRec Music

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Rocking Horse

Cost: AU$19.95

I didn't listen to this for months after buying it, which is a shame - cause it's brilliant! The duo of Fred Frith and Tom Cora, playing a ton of instruments and assembling everything in the studio (I guess) present a strong album of songs. Frith's singing recalls Cheap at Half Price only without the goofyness; there's some beautiful stringwork, touching on traditional musical forms while still retaining a progressive edge. This is one I need to listen to many more times for inspiration. [3 Nov 2007]


Date: 15 May 2007

Fucked Up - Hidden World

Label: Deranged Records

Format: 2xVinyl Album LP

Source: Rocking Horse

Cost: AU$49.95

Hardcore is such a stupid genre of music, with its self-imposed limitations and close-minded behavior - but every once in awhile something grabs me. This Canadian band has gotten a lot of hype for their blend of melodic classic hardcore with some of the songwriting devices of more recent, commercial fare - thus it makes some sense that emo label Jade Tree released it. And it's a great album, indeed - lengthy songs, cryptic lyrics, and a rejection of typical HC imagery in favor of a more mystical artwork style - a good way to push the buttons, offering something new by not offering anything new. A few of these songs are ridiculously great. I'd have been first in the pit to see them if I hadn't decided to go see Wrestling Team instead. [3 Nov 2007]


Date: 15 May 2007

Mnemonists - Gyromancy

Label: Dys

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Rocking Horse

Cost: AU$79.95

This EP, though played at 45 RPM, is pretty long; side one went on for ages, and just when it feels like it's coming to an end there will be a surprising burst of activity. This is slightly less accessible than Horde - I'm not sure if it came before or after. [6 Nov 2007]


Date: 15 May 2007

Mnemonists - Horde

Label: Recommended Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Rocking Horse

Cost: AU$79.95

This was expensive - though not really, given the currency strengths of the Australian dollar and the UK pound - but well worth it. This is a classic of weird damaged art-noise, the kind of music I find most inspiring. It feels very much like a group, and it explores ambience and improvisation while still having a very lively edge to it. At parts, kazoos and other "fun" sound burst from the seams, while other parts are like subterranean explorations. I've owned this on CD for years but it's great to finally upgrade to the original vinyl (which is extremely limited to 79 copies!). [4 Nov 2007]


Date: 15 May 2007

Unrest Work and Play - In-Forms

Label: Recommended

Format: LP

Source: Rocking Horse

Cost: AU$59.95

Unrest, Work and Play are an offshoot of The Work (and also referencing Henry Cow's second album in their name) who released a few obscure records in the early 1980's. This one claims to be an investigation of different genres, as the tracks are named "Rockabilly'', "Pop", "Swing", etc. However, most of the tracks sound like they come from common ground, and a brilliant ground that is. There's the usual RIO elements here - quick changing time signatures, complex song structures, and technically dazzling playing. The lyrics overtop are sung in a very post-punk monotone, perhaps the one weak link. But there's a universe of ideas on these 8 songs, which I'm sure will only become more rewarding upon further study. [27 Oct 2007]


Date: 15 May 2007

Art Zoyd - Symphonie Pour Le Jour Or Bruleront Les Cites

Label: Cryonic

Format: LP

Source: Rocking Horse

Cost: AU$24.95

I always think of Art Zoyd as being more atmosphere-based than technical, but this has a bit of both. A tightly constructed symphony, it moves between screeching strings, neo-classical embellishments, and dark psychedelic prog. The vocals remind me Renaldo and the Loaf, delivered in a surreal manner. There's some jazzy trumpet/guitar runs, and a very Western European inflection to everything. [4 Nov 2007]


Date: 4 June 2007

Failing Lights - The Spine Of The World

Label: Gods Of Tundra

Format: Cassette Limited Edition

Source: Mike Connelly

Cost: $0

Mike's solo Failing Lights tape could be a predecessor to Birth Refusal, sounding like a more stripped down, bare version of the harsh crackle and electronics on the Birth Refusal (or recent Wolf Eyes) recordings I've heard. Perhaps it's because it has this breathing space I enjoy it significantly more - though it does stand up on its own, rather than sounding like a missing puzzle piece. My only concern is that Mike's most interesting experiments get buried in the sheer volume of material he releases. [17 Nov 2007]


Date: 4 June 2007

Wolf Eyes - Time Of Clearing

Label: Gods Of Tundra

Format: CDr Limited Edition

Source: Mike Connelly

Cost: $0

Mike chucked this Wolf Eyes release in the package along with Daryl's LP, and I can't say that it's a particularly memorable one. There's a bit of bass guitar riffage buried in a cloud of desolate fuzz, and the usual screaming electronics. It's actually on the more mellow side of WE releases, but lacking the patience that makes records like River Slaughter so successful. [1 Nov 2007]


Date: 4 June 2007

Walter Carson - Recalcitrants

Label: Gods Of Tundra

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Mike Connelly

Cost: $20

Daryl finally has an LP out! Although one-sided, it's on beautiful clear vinyl and probably is the tinniest record I've ever heard. It begins with a high-frequence drone, full of movement within, before migratinting to sounds that remind me of static, only focused static. The electronics creak along and I feel that Daryl put a lot of effort into the assemblage of these sounds, as they always stay restrained and never lurch into easy freakout territory. Great work! [3 Nov 2007]


Date: 4 June 2007

Birth Refusal - The Lanes Call

Label: Gods Of Tundra

Format: Cassette Limited Edition

Source: Mike Connelly

Cost: $0

This is a long tape, and a bit of an endurance test - it feels like about an hour of harsh, lo-fi electronics. It punches along in seemingly random aggressive stabs, spaced out by mellow yet sinister gurgling. It's probably too harsh for me to truly enjoy - or rather, not as dynamic as I like harsh electronics to be. [17 Nov 2007]


Date: 12 June 2007

Russian Tsarcasm - My Life Is As Natural As My Grip On The Machete

Label: Bone Tooth Horn

Format: Cassette Limited Edition

Source: Bone Tooth Horn

Cost: $4

I'mnot sure who Russian Tsarcasm is, but it's a great name. This is a collection of fucked up songs, built around sloppy bass guitar and nerdy, nasal vocals. The structures are repetitive and the recording is appropriate bathed in lo-fi damage. It feels very original and personal, though I must admit exhaustion by the end of a half-hour. [4 Nov 2007]


Date: 12 June 2007

Mandarin Clit - Sugar Britches

Label: Bone Tooth Horn

Format: Cassette Limited Edition

Source: Bone Tooth Horn

Cost: $4

A short collection of weird fragments that reminds of something Jelle would put out; there are the vaguest gestures of musicality to some moments, like a few strummed chords, but it moved on to another murky collage before picking up a rhythm. I listened to it twice without realising the tape was auto-flipping. [14 June 2007]


Date: 12 June 2007

2673 / King Darves / Ladderwoe - Secret Show 3

Label: Bone Tooth Horn

Format: Cassette

Source: Bone Tooth Horn

Cost: $4

A recording from the 'Secret Show' series, which may be shows played to just a few friends or maybe real shows with all of the crowd noise edited out, I don't know. 2673 starts with a quiet collage that isnt that far off from the 'studio' recordings I've heard, but presented via a 'live' recording. King Darves dominates this tape, straddling both sides of it, and his songwriting is solid and his voice is rich and deep; I can only imagine this guy will explode and become super duper famous. It somehow manages to work between the other two artists despite the complete difference in musical approaches. The Ladderwoe set here is based around acoustic guitar and violin; I'm not sure if there's multiple people playing or if Dave is using loops or something. Either way, it's a strange bit of sound. [25 Nov 2007]


Date: 12 June 2007

Erna Fluhr - 

Label: Bone Tooth Horn

Format: C40

Source: Bone Tooth Horn

Cost: $4

This is a rather monolithic collection of songs, with vocals buried in reverb until it passes Inca Ore/Grouper territory and becomes a full on wall of sound, with melodies rendered indistinguishable. The guitar playing in the background is stretched to breaking point, at times sounding like a waterlogged 'Song to the Siren'. [14 June 2007] Listened again, and there's some great moments and some awkward ones (like the Leonard Cohen cover) - I think this shows a lot of promise though, and I'd really love to hear a followup. [26 Oct 2007]


Date: 12 June 2007

GT Performers - Slam Cic Remacore

Label: Bone Tooth Horn

Format: C24

Source: Bone Tooth Horn

Cost: $4

GT Performers remind me a bit of that band the Lowdown whose first album I liked so much - though without as much production. This tape explodes with noisemakers, a lot sounding like toys or other manic electronics; it has a very basement, somewhat silly feel. [14 June 2007]


Date: 12 June 2007

USAGoldExchange / Werkstatte - NinetySeven NinetyNine / Das Anthology

Label: Bone Tooth Horn

Format: C40

Source: Bone Tooth Horn

Cost: $4



Date: 12 June 2007

Car Commericals, / Rvmspringa / King Darves / Lifers / Plane Seahorse Sanguinevessel / 2673 / Gorgot - Secret Show 5/6

Label: Bone Tooth Horn

Format: 2xCS

Source: Bone Tooth Horn

Cost: $4



Date: 23 June 2007

Gaillard, Slim - Laughing in Rhythm

Label: Proper

Format: 4xCD box

Source: Bill Boichel

Cost: $0



Date: 25 June 2007

Graham Lambkin - Salmon Run

Label: Kye

Format: CD Album

Source: Graham Lambkin

Cost: $14.5

This is my album of the year so far, though I wonder if I am saying this perhaps because I am so perplexed by it. It is utterly strange, but in the most fascinating way; the ambience is unlike anything I have ever heard, yet I don't feel like it's weird for weirdness sake. I'm not entirely sure what is expressed by this, but it feels familiar to a very underevaluated piece of my own subconscious. [14 Aug 2007]


Date: 1 July 2007

Speculum Fight - Live In Tokyo '95

Label: What The...? Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

After seeing Damien Romero live in London, I think I have trouble with his music. "It's not so much that he's playing a show as much as 'creating a situation'," said the What The ? proprietor to me during said set. This recording from 11 years earlier is similarly dense and horizontal, almost as if Romero is trying to remove the dimension of time from the recording. I wonder what his contributions specifically were to that killer New Blockaders set that I saw; I can't imagine how this approach could gel in a group form so he must be fairly adaptable. [25 Nov 2007]


Date: 1 July 2007

Burning Star Core - Operator Dead... Post Abandoned

Label: No Quarter

Format: CD Album

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

This is the first "proper" debut of the four-piece lineup, and it takes on a rather fusiony feel, in the first two long pieces. It is very much a group-based recording; Spencer does not dominate the mix so in a sense it's a better group portrait than even The Very Heart of the World. The two shorter pieces at the end forsake the jazz influence for a tense, forced anxiety that is quite compelling. Weird 4AD-style artwork but a great title; in a way this feels almost like the closing of a chapter and the beginning of something new. [29 Nov 2007]


Date: 1 July 2007

Burning Star Core - Three Sisters Who Share An Eye

Label: No Fun Productions

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

Three Sisters Who Share an Eye may be Spencer's least distinct LP. One side is a thick rush of distortion and static, with any finer details lost in the mess. The second side is a slightly cleaner drone, at times recalling the side-long violin outing of his first LP, only with a few more years of alcohol damage and sleep deprivation. I'll be curious to pull this out in six months or a year and hear how it sounds to me then, but in the pile of Spencer's releases it feels like the least remarkable. [7 Nov 2007]


Date: 1 July 2007

Dilloway, Aaron/C. Spencer Yeh - Squid, The

Label: Hanson

Format: LP
