Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

Here's a meeting of the minds - and one that seems well-suited, given the two participants respective strengths. 'Ahab' fills side 1 with a deep foghorn drone, over which more active, excited sounds are explored. There are moments of beauty and moments of dissonance, but it's all anchored by a ceaseless, heavy churning. 'Ink Sac' has some reverb-drenched rumbles over which a frantic shenhai loop is layered. 'Hydra' is pure flange jazz - interlocking figures drenched in reverb and effects, building up a menacing aquatic pulse. [27 Oct 2007]


Date: 1 July 2007

C. Spencer Yeh - Solo Violin 1-10

Label: Tone Filth

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Spencer

Cost: $0

I have 4/5 of this on cassette already, but on vinyl it sounds a good bit cleaner, and more up-close. The surface noise doesn't seem as pervasive as the hiss of the cassette. And while I liked the tapes, I'm probably more likely to listen to this on vinyl since I prefer the format. Nice cover art- great duotone printing, good design. [7 Nov 2007]


Date: 4 July 2007

Usurper - Don't Even Fucken Bother

Label: Rampart

Format: C30

Source: Trevor

Cost: $0

Usurper on tape is a lot dirtier and noisier than they are live. The sound explorations work better for me when I have a visual reference point, though the clatter made on this tape is pretty fun. It's a murky, rambunctious half hour, and it lacks the distinct vision of their live work (which is not to say that it's not good, just not what I expect from them). [13 Sep 2007]


Date: 5 July 2007

Hair Police - Blind Kingdom

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: Vinyl LP Single Sided Limited Edition

Source: Robert

Cost: $0

A one-sided LP by Hair Police that shows them at their most experimental. It's als a fairly hi-fi recording, at least compared to the recordings with drums. This is a sneaky, unfolding electronic piece that may be Robert solo for all I know (I don't ask). If played for me blind I would guess it was a Sick Hour track, actually. The crisp recording is really nice, as it adds some dynamics missing from a lot of the other recordings. Deep listening, dude! [3 Nov 2007]


Date: 5 July 2007

Hair Police - Strict

Label: Troubleman Unlimited

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Robert

Cost: $0

Nice to have HP on a 7" again, thinking back to how my first HP release was the 'Mortuary Servants' 7" ? here we have one track split over two sides, or maybe two untilted tracks both called 'Strict'. One side is a fierce, banging rocker with washes of flanged noise overtop, and the other side is a more sparse, shrill sqeal of broken machines. Great fucked up art by Robert on the cover. [4 Nov 2007]


Date: 5 July 2007

Hair Police - The Empty Quarter

Label: Harbinger Sound

Format: CD Album

Source: Robert

Cost: $0

Hair Police's debut for the great Steve Underwood's label is a loose afair, with gurgling electronics dominating the mix. It's hard to tell who is contributing what to this, which is either a testament to HP's group mentality or a lost chance to focus on individual talent. On headphones, this sounds very sharp; out of the recent Hair Police releases this may be the most distinguished, almost like they're moving back from the long-form pieces (though this is only 5 tracks). [29 Nov 2007]


Date: 7 July 2007

Tamburo, Mike - Language of the Birds

Label: New American Folk Hero

Format: 7 CDr box

Source: Mike Tamburo

Cost: $0



Date: 6 August 2007

Haniver, Jenny - Sea Wall/Abyssal Plain

Label: Leaf Leaf

Format: C18

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: $0

This brief tape consists of two side-long pieces, both in the dark, gurgling electronics/noise genre. The first side is a buzzing, see-sawing monotony. Side two gets into a bubbly, cartoonish vibe. Both tracks feature the "line in" low-fi sound. [24 Oct 2007]


Date: 6 August 2007

Current Amnesia - Worst Cases

Label: Leaf Leaf

Format: CDR

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: $0

One of Dave's solo projects that is focused on atmosphere. Some lovely ringing drones, and some deep bassy moments, verging into Solilquy for Lilith territory (only lo-fi). This feels like a very refined, focused work and almost jars with the other New Jersey output that I've heard. [26 Oct 2007]


Date: 6 August 2007

Orator - 

Label: Leaf Leaf

Format: C12

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: $0

I assume the Orator is another Dave Sutton project. This one is really beautiful - as if beauty is the sole objective. Delicate piano, pastoral drones and gentle tones create these sketches. It's another fine example of the versatility of Mr. Sutton, recording and releasing these experiments for the sheer pleasure of the artform. [27 Oct 2007]


Date: 22 August 2007

Ã‰l-G - L'Echelle?

Label: Memoirs of an Aesthete

Format: CD-R

Source: Laurent Gerard

Cost: £0

Two ten minute songs that show Laurent's songwriting talents (with lyrics about an anguished overweight child that certainly comes from personal experience). The guitar playing on said track erupts into a Fripp-like orgy, burning with electric rage. The other track has some lovely singing, more like chanting, and overall shows Laurent's versatility. Very well done! [29 Nov 2007]


Date: 22 August 2007

Ã‰l-G & Charlene Darling - Liz

Label: none

Format: CD-R

Source: Laurent Gerard

Cost: £0

One long 17-minute song, in several parts, may by Laurent and Charlene's prog masterpieces, recorded with a very close mic and moving from hushed singsong vocals to dark, elliptical drone melodies. There's probably a lot of antecedents for this sound, but the male/female Francophone vibe makes me think of Brigitte Fontaine and Areski. That's not a fair comparison because Laurent and Charlene's sound is thicker, dirtier and darker - there is none of the acoustic lift that I find in Areski's best work. Despite the language barrier I really enjoy this, and I definitely prefer it to the more experimental side of El-G (though there is certainly an experimentalism here). [17 Nov 2007]


Date: 22 August 2007

Ã‰l-G & Duncan - 

Label: none

Format: CD-R

Source: Laurent Gerard

Cost: £0

This duo of Laurent and Duncan begins in a quiet, whispery way - a far cry from the Yellow Swansesque battery of their live show in Glasgow. The vocals are wordless, buried in waves of delay and reverb, and shift around in an ambient, slightly disturbing way. Eventually this builds up to a thick buzzing square wave, and then Duncan's guitar solo comes in - I think it's Duncan at least - which is exploratory, rambling, and nervous. It's a great bit of axe-shredding that accelerates as the background drones rise. It's a really explosive sound, with some muffled vocals (maybe sampled) that just kick it into a seriously deranged territory. By the end there's not much place left for my brain. [17 Nov 2007]


Date: 24 August 2007

Ã‰l-G & Charlene Darling - Au Grand Dam du Jour

Label: none

Format: CD-R

Source: Laurent Gerard

Cost: £0

From the way Laurent described his music, I thought it would be a lot more singsong and poppy. Yes, there are songs, but they are very dark, resonating as if performed in a cavernous space and feeling very much like a live thing (though I think this was done with overdubs). The chord progressions remind me of something like Nico, and Laurent's lyrics will be fun to decipher as I'm trying to practice my French. Gotta check out the other one now! [17 Sep 2007]


Date: 5 September 2007

Tod Dockstader - Quatermass

Label: Starkland Recordings

Format: CD

Source: Daniel

Cost: £0



Date: 5 September 2007

Bob James Trio - Explosions

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Daniel

Cost: £0

I'm very fond of this album, which features one of the most criminally underrated jazz bassists of all time, Barre Phillips. This finds Bob James in a brainy, exploratory mood, with circular piano figures seemingly without centre. Side two moves further away from jazz, with some prepared piano (I think) and concluding with a joint composition by Bob James and Robert Ashley that features some voices and radio static, presumably tuned in by chance. [18 Nov 2007]


Date: 5 September 2007

Bongwater - Too Much Sleep

Label: Shimmy Disc Europe

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Daniel

Cost: £0

I got into this album when living with Daniel, as he had it on CD and played it a lot. Because he strangely prefers CDs to LPs he got rid of this when he moved. It's a great album, with some really catchy songs and a brilliant cover of Slapp Happy's "The Drum". Subsequently it's the Bongwater album I know the most, so I guess it's my favorite. I wonder when Shockabilly and Bongwater will make a resurgence. [4 Nov 2007]


Date: 5 September 2007

V/A - Made to Measure vol. 1

Label: Crammed Discs

Format: LP

Source: Daniel

Cost: £0

This compilations assembles material that was created for theater/film works by several different artists. It was of interest to me because about half of it is Aksak Maboul, with music from a play that is not available on anything else (as far as I know). One track is a turntable collage probably by Marc Hollander solo; the others are group pieces that are restrained, yet interesting. Definitely "soundtrack" work. Minimal Compact has that style of electronic post-punk that has made a trendy comeback, though their tracks do nothing for me. Tuxedomoon sound exactly like Tuxedomoon, here with the soundtrack to a short film. [4 Nov 2007]


Date: 5 September 2007

Reynols - Pacalirte Sorban Cumanos

Label: Beta-Lactam

Format: CD

Source: Daniel

Cost: £0

A full Reynols album that verges between dire, go-nowhere tuneless strumming and downer, Dead C-esque rock. It's all plodding and hopeless, and there's a thick haze over everything. Not an easy listen, but what Reynols releases are? Tomasin's vocals are the dominant centre which sometimes masks quite interesting, insane guitar playing, but that's what you get here. [26 December 2012]


Date: 5 September 2007

Dixon, Bill - Collection

Label: Cadence

Format: 2xCD

Source: Daniel

Cost: £0

Well, both of these CDs are the same, so it's really two copies of a single CD. Dunno what went wrong there. The thing is, one CD of solo trumpet is enough (I think this is actually a sampler from a 7 CD set too!). Dixon does some great things with his trumpet. There's parts that are totally Greg Kelley territory, sounding like some weird electronics - and other parts that are straightforward and melodic. It never gets super fiery, at least not for any prolonged period of time. [26 Oct 2007]


Date: 8 September 2007

Abyss Whispers / Nackt Insecten - Untitled

Label: Sound Holes

Format: CDr Limited Edition

Source: Dan from Aberdeen

Cost: £0

Rory's CD gets going with some screaming, harsh electronics, a good deal harsher than the live sets I've seen from him recently. It isn't til a few tracks in that I start to feel the details emerging from the wall of sound. This was probably recorded a good deal before I saw Nackt Insecten live so maybe this is what he used to sound like more. [25 Nov 2007]


Date: 8 September 2007

Crow Feathers / Ville Moskiitto - Split

Label: Sound Holes

Format: Cassette Limited Edition

Source: Dan from Aberdeen

Cost: £0

I cynically expected the entire tape to be like the power electronics that open side 1, but after a few minutes of that the tape yields to far gentler territory. There's some strummed acoustic guitar, and some lovely shimmering electric guitar notes and electronics. This actually is similar to the music I recorded today, in one of those strange coincidences. Quite good, well done Dan from Aberdeen! [24 Oct 2007]


Date: 8 September 2007

E.E. E.E - Ceramics

Label: Sound Holes

Format: Cassette Limited Edition

Source: Dan from Aberdeen

Cost: £0

I had a pop song stuck in my head when I started listening to this, and I realised halfway through the first side that I was still humming the song and paying no attention to the "noise" presented here. Which, if you think about it, is a true failure of "noise" as a genre right? I've succeeded in making E.E's distorted blasts of who-knows-what into another ambient musak. There are occasional tonal overlays, sounding like extremely filtered electronic toy or other controller, but for the most part this is built around an unrelenting assault of rumble. Impressive is that Dan from Aberdeen maintains his website, and his label, to this day. I don't think this E.E. is Erika Elder from the Child of Microtones scene, but who knows. [29 December 2012]


Date: 9 September 2007

Guest Beers - Guest Beers

Label: Giant Tank

Format: CDr Album

Source: Ali

Cost: £0

Guest Beers is a project of Ali from Usuper with Dave from Major Stars and Greg Kelley. From the fidelity of the record, it sounds like Ali really dominates, as it's scratchy and plucky, and doesn't feature any of the atmospheric approach that I love in Greg's playing. Or maybe it's just because it's recorded on a Walkman, in typical Giant Tank style. Like all Usuper recordings, this is okay, but I really wish it could get the treatment it deserves in regards to fidelity. [24 Oct 2007]


Date: 11 September 2007

Wiese, John and C. Spencer Yeh - Tiny Red Tables/Big American Hole

Label: Helicopter

Format: 7"

Source: John

Cost: £5



Date: 11 September 2007

Wiese, John and Bruce Russell - Californian Front

Label: Helicopter

Format: 7"

Source: John

Cost: £5

I don't know if I would have realised this if John hadn't told me, but side 1 is all John's work, but edited by Russell. Side 2 is the same material run through some effects, and it's on this track that the hand of Bruce Russell is felt. Even though it's John's typical frantic, crisp electronic/collage, it's injected with the atmosphere of the South Island. [17 Sep 2007]


Date: 19 September 2007

Wooden Shjips - Wooden Shjips

Label: Holy Mountain

Format: CD AlbumCD EP

Source: 

Cost: £12.99

After that 10" came out I thought these guys were the band of the century - and the strong Dance, California single that followed seemed to encourage that belief. But this full-length, while hardly a bad album, takes everything down a notch. It sounds a LOT like the Doors, which works if you like the Doors I guess (I'm not a fan). There's some great moments of reverb-drenched guitar psych, but none of the songs rip it up as much as the singles, which will one day be legendary. Luckily, this release comes with a bonus disc collecting them. Maybe I'm not judging the album fairly because I'm comparing it to the singles, but whenever I listen to it, I just want to put the other disc on. [1 Nov 2007]


Date: 19 September 2007

Lee Rockey - Music

Label: De Stijl

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: 

Cost: £11.99

Gurgling synths, creeping drones, and weird free outbursts - sounds like the recipe of about a million young performers today, sure;; but Lee Rockey's approach avoids any commonplace imagery and instead invents something completely unique. Rockey was a schooled jazz musician, and you can sort of hear it - no sense of technical profieciency is evident, yet the way the sounds interact with each other suggest a deep understanding of improvisational experience. The only real comparison is of course the incomparable sounds of 70's art-damaged experimentalism, NWW-list rumblings, and Futura label scraps. Which is my favorite type of music! [23 Sep 2007]


Date: 19 September 2007

Sun City Girls - Beginnings Dark

Label: Enterruption

Format: Vinyl LP Single Sided Limited Edition

Source: 

Cost: £26.99

Yes - this is just a song from "Dark Beginnings, Bright Surroundings" played backwards with expensive, deluxe packaging - but if the physical material of a record album has some sort of talismanic function, then this can summon Charles Gocher, Jr. from beyond the grave. The song takes on a brilliance when backwards, the packaging is indeed amazing, this is one of the definitive SCG songs anyway (and was played the first time I saw them, still one of the most incredible live experiences I've ever had) - so it was worth every penny. And I practically have to choke back tears when I look at the picture of CG,Jr. [15 oct 2007]


Date: 19 September 2007

Kark - The Hermit

Label: HP Cycle Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: 

Cost: £10.99

Kark is a subset of Sapat, or if it were expressed pseduomathematically: Sapat{Kark, Valley of Ashes} - although there's overlap between them so maybe you need some crazy Venn diagram. I dunno. Anyway, this shows the more jazz-oriented side of the Louisvillians (at least in terms of instrument choice) - it screams with horns both atonal and melodic, upright bass propelling everything with an ethnic smirk, and clattering percussion that still holds it together. They sound at times like a cross between Scatter and Bablicon (even quoting one of the most well-known Bablicon riffs, albeit unintentionally I'm sure) - and it makes me think about how I just don't listen to enough music like this anymore. [15 Oct 2007]


Date: 19 September 2007

Lambkin, Graham - Draining the Vats

Label: Pineapple Tapes

Format: C90

Source: 

Cost: £6.99

Salmon Run will be among my list of faves for the year, if not the favorite. This earlier cassette is an odds and ends collection that just predates it, though it has some of the "coughing over classical music" magic that appears on Salmon Run. There's also an appearance of Elkin, the electronic/improv group of Lambkin and Hoyos. Because of the more scattered nature, it loses some of the vision that Salmon Run has - but the cassette format is charming, and there's a lot of great sounds on here - I think almost 90 minutes. [15 Oct 2007]


Date: 19 September 2007

Youngs, Richard and Tirath Singh Nirmala - 

Label: HP Cycle

Format: LP

Source: 

Cost: £10.99

This album is LONG! Or at least it feels that way, yet it's a single LP and the sound quality doesn't seem compromised. Maybe it's that Richard and Tirath's compositions are so HEAVY - not in a Sunn O/Sabbath way but in the way that there is a lot of weight between the notes, where every track feels like a definitive statement (but then the next one starts....). There are some incredibly beautiful pieces here that stand up against Richard's greatest one-off collaborations (the Youngsbower, the CD with Stephen Todd, Knish, etc.) and once again I find myself feeling that there is yet another brilliant addition to the Youngs canon. [17 Nov 2007]


Date: 19 September 2007

Sweet Kelly - Tape Fed Into Garbage Disposal by Spaceman and Jake

Label: Zedikiah

Format: LP

Source: 

Cost: £19.99

I feel like I paid too much for this, as it doesn't even really have packaging (just a hand-numbered black die-cut sleeve). Also I don't know anything about the backstory of this record, except for David's usual exuberant missives on the VT site. This record is pretty rad though - a dirty, hissy raw rock record with some repetitive, almost cult-like chanting. I could see it growing on me with more listens, which I will have to give it. [24 Oct 2007]


Date: 19 September 2007

Yeh, C.S. - 

Label: Gods of Tundra

Format: LP

Source: 

Cost: £10.99

One side of voice and one side of violin, both recorded very "raw", probably in mono and unnervingly close to the listener. The violin side finds Spencer sawing away, with some objects clanging around as well. Interesting fidelity, but I like it. The vocal side, which I suspect is untreated, though the machinations of his lips create a type of flange at some points. [9 Oct 2007]


Date: 20 September 2007

Cherry Blossoms - Cherry Blossoms, The

Label: Yeay!

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £10

The Cherry Blossoms are so wonderful that the record of course doesn't do them justice; there's no way these shoddily-recorded songs can compare to the circus that was their live show, which included tap-dancing and live poetry. But when viewed as the chance to listen to their songs over and over, it's an opportunity to be seized. Peggy Snow's songs are so incredibly beautiful, especially "The Wind Did Blow", but John Allingham's weird repetitive nursery rhymes are not without their charm (I've had "Rocks and Stones" stuck in my head for weeks now). [23 Sep 2007]


Date: 20 September 2007

Various Artists: - Avant Marghen vol. 1

Label: Alga Marghen

Format: 7xLP box

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £85



Date: 20 September 2007

Various Artists: - Avant Marghen vol. 3

Label: Alga Marghen

Format: 7xLP box

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £85



Date: 20 September 2007

Various Artists: - Avant Marghen vol. 2

Label: Alga Marghen

Format: 7xLP box

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £85



Date: 21 September 2007

Weird Weeds - Weird Feelings

Label: Sounds Are Active

Format: CD Mini-Album

Source: Nick Hennies

Cost: £8

The Weird Weeds are wonderful; they have grown on me in the manner of all vastly rewarding musics. This album continues from the greatness of their acoustic EP, even featuring a few songs from it (such as the brilliant, concise "Broken Arm") but has a bunch of new songs to fall in love with. The production is spectacular, recording them just as precisely as they need to be recorded - for this is music where every gesture is very calculated - every breath, every note. This is definitely going to be something I listen to very often, for the songs aren't overtly catchy but offer an intrigue that makes me want to frequently revisit. [15 Oct 2007]


Date: 27 September 2007

Box Codax - Naked Smile

Label: The Thin Man

Format: Vinyl 10"

Source: Nick McCarthy

Cost: £0

More goofy Box Codax recordings - Nick and his friend Alex experimenting with drum programming, German accents, and silly songwriting. This is one song 3 times; Manuela sings backup vocals and it's sort of likeable and fun.The first remix less so; the B-side is a long, minimal remix where everything is broken and it's super self-indulgent but has a charm too. Maybe I just miss these people. [21 December 2012]


Date: 27 September 2007

Box Codax - Only an Orchard Away

Label: Thin Man

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Nick McCarthy

Cost: £0

The Box Codax full-length reveals them to be a much more goofy project than I thought they were. There's something quite charming and anarchic about the guitar-driven tracks, but the synth starts to wear on me by the end of the album. Still, it's fun in a very Barley style; Manuela's singing is awesome too. [9 Oct 2007]


Date: 27 September 2007

Royal We/1990s - 

Label: Hitherto

Format: 7"

Source: Roxanne

Cost: £3

Going into a studio gives the Royal We a confidence I never saw in them live. This is an Orange Juice cover, and it comes off as a really nice, upbeat vibe. The background vocals are pretty irritating but the lead vocals, which I always hated live, sound great. It's all a bit cutesy but I guess that's what they're going for. There's still something ramshackle about it, which makes it dwarf the 1990's lame Josef K cover on the other side. Still, I wonder when the rest of Glasgow will tire of the cute/retro/post-punk thing. [9 Oct 2007]


Date: 3 October 2007

Motor Ghost - A Gold Chain Round Her Breast

Label: Dancing Wayang

Format: LP

Source: Ben Reynolds

Cost: £0

Alex and Ben's free-form (largely) electric guitar-based rock album is a very strong debut. The fidelity is perhaps the surprising thing - it's so well-recorded that the notes are really allowed to ring out to their full grandeur. While I haven't been enjoying this type of free rock much lately (nor the trad-folk gestures that the last song makes), this is an exception to my mood. Maybe it's because of the recording quality but this feels like Alex moving back towards his work in Scatter, still my favorite output of it. And maybe it's cause I know these guys that I like this so much, but I think it'll hold up for many future listens. [17 Nov 2007]


Date: 28 October 2007

Defektro - Destructive Reconstruction

Label: Lastgasp Art Laboratories

Format: CD

Source: Hirofumi

Cost: £0

I much prefer Defektro recorded to their live show; while their industrial-mechanical noise sounded run of the mill and indistinct live, the recording maintains a crisp fidelity that accentuates the metallic clanging. It's a long disc - probably longer than it needs to be - but it actually stays interesting by shifting to different pieces, recorded (I think) over a long period. Hirofumi is a rad guy and I'm glad he gave me this, because it is a better way for me to remember Defektro than the live experience. [17 Nov 2007]


Date: 1 November 2007

Pink Reason - Cleaning The Mirror

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Alt.vinyl

Cost: £10

On the strength of this record alone, this guy will probably find himself enshrined in the psych hall of fame; it's a blast of dark energy that has the wigged-out vibe of 60's ESP psych while being grounded in post-punk and 1990's indie. The opening cut, "Goodbye", could be a Peter Jefferies/TKOP outtake, with dark acoustic cadences driving the dour lyrical moans. The record doesn't get any brighter, but rather implements canned percussion and scratchy, reverb-laden background haze to further the gloom. The lyrics may at times feel juvenile, but they work really well in the whole scheme of things - the sentiments expressed are extremely real, allowing emotion to sometimes override an artistic aesthetic. "Dead End" shows that a song can be fast-paced yet still soaked in misery - and the final track, "Up the Sleeve," is like a funeral dirge for oneself - the masterpiece at the end of the ladder, or maybe the noose. This has grown to be one of my favorite records of the year, perhaps because I've had some dark times of my own. And given the press and attention this record has received, he'll probably never equal it, cause nothing spoils depressing music like success. [3 Nov 2007]


Date: 1 November 2007

Sapat - Mortise And Tenon

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Alt.vinyl

Cost: £11

At long last, a Sapat vinyl LP emerges - and it's better than I could have possibly imagined. This shows the 'rock' side of Sapat (with the 'jazz' side presumably reserved for the Kark LP) in a very coherent album, showcasing the jam vibe and some killer songwriting as well It's interesting how Sapat works best when the group bands together and focuses, despite being defined by their loose collective nature. There's a zillion more hours of Sapat in Kris's archives, and I wonder if we'll ever hear them all. This is like a synthesis of the few times I saw Sapat, or at least their rock side - and I'm going to treasure it. [3 Nov 2007]


Date: 1 November 2007

Visitations - 

Label: Time-Lag

Format: CD

Source: Alt.vinyl

Cost: £10

Visitations have left the science-fiction themes of their earlier work, or at least downplayed it a bit. Now they're a straight-up folk band, which isn't nearly as interesting. There's the tendency for these songs to just go on and on and on, a few minutes longer than they need to be - it's only 8 songs, yet feels like an eternity. There's a much higher standard of recording than their first self-titled CD, though that's a detriment here. It lets the voices shine through, but also becomes very dull about mid-way through each song. Small gestures towards rock (track 4) don't help much; it's only on track 7 that the harmonies and textures converge to create something truly psychedelic and beautiful. Maybe this will grow on me, but I prefer the outsider vibe of their first release (even if it's a bit contrived). [5 Nov 2007]


Date: 1 November 2007

Jazzfinger - Lain-led Cloud Fucker

Label: Chondritic Sound

Format: 3" CD-R

Source: Ben Jones

Cost: £0

A twenty-minute blast of Jazzfinger recorded fairly well, with no surprises here but it's still a lovely bit of sonic tapestry. It starts to go haywire at the end, but then suddenly it's over. I'm not sure if I prefer the "many short tracks" Jazzfinger or the lengthy pieces - I guess this is more like that amazing live show I saw. [17 Nov 2007]


Date: 1 November 2007

Jazzfinger - The Well of Used Dreams

Label: Classic English Womb

Format: CDR

Source: Ben Jones

Cost: £0



Date: 1 November 2007

Jazzfinger - The Glass Key

Label: Classic English Womb

Format: CDr

Source: Ben Jones

Cost: £0

A lengthy exploration of Jazzfinger's less overtly droney side, this features some piano playing, some clanking, and generally clearner fidelity than I'm used to. You can really hear what the two members are doing separately, and sometimes this is beneficial. The track titles suggest some sort of weird legal concept but maybe they were just watching Law and Order. [27 Nov 2007]


Date: 1 November 2007

Jazzfinger - Orange Sauce

Label: Altvinyl

Format: Lathe Cut 8" 33 ? RPM Limited Edition Shape

Source: Ben Jones

Cost: £0

Not sure which side is which, but it's a lovely lathe from these lovely lads. One side is a crisp, in-the-room sound with some rattling and clanging that it absolutely wonderful; the flipside is a slightly sludgier murk that relies on its own density to carry it to completion. Being a lathe it will probably melt if I play it too often, so I should probably make a digital copy of this ASAP! [3 Nov 2007]


Date: 1 November 2007

Laziers/Noisebastard - 

Label: 

Format: cassette

Source: Alt.vinyl

Cost: £2

Laziers is Cameron Sked solo and his side begins with some harmonica playing through tremelo and reverb, reminding me a bit of some of Tamburo's harmonica work. The side is short but very nice, and it reminds me very much of Cameron. Noisebastard's side is not that noisy, but rather low level rumbles and grinding sounds, almost like the sound of the boombox I was listening to it on was amplified. [25 Nov 2007]


Date: 10 November 2007

Poltergroom - 

Label: 

Format: CD-R

Source: Lawrence

Cost: £0

A trio of Lawrence, Keeby and Will gives me high hopes, and while I don't dislike this music, it's not anything that gets me excited. These six songs are predominantly intsrumental, two guitars and drums in a jittery, riff-based rock mode. They're put together well, only sounding awkward when the vocals come in, but it reminds me a lot of Pittsburgh-style post-rock from the 90's which I don't really miss. Still, it's a good effort in the genre and I love these guys so much that I'm charmed by the music eventually. [15 Dec 2007]


Date: 23 November 2007

Axolotl - Trade Ye No Mere Moneyed Art

Label: Loci

Format: CDr Album Limited Edition

Source: Karl

Cost: £0

Karl dumped out this outtakes CD for tour which is pretty good, sounding like excerpts from other recording sessions (which is what it is, I guess). There's a more lo-fi approach than I prefer (Axolotl excels when recorded well, I think) overall, but some really celestial moments that I need to re-visit. [15 Dec 2007]


Date: 29 November 2007

Microwaves - Contagion Heuristic

Label: Crucial Blast

Format: CD Album

Source: John Roman

Cost: £0

Microwaves have probably released their best record here, though I'm still biased towards the one that I put out; though they are maybe a bit more like the rest of the pack now, they're excelling in songwriting and interesting musicianship, and therefore this probably stands as a better record. I rarely listen to heavy rock, but I'm glad John sent me this because it makes me miss those guys. [15 Dec 2007]


Date: 4 December 2007

Working Poor - Songs and Sounds

Label: Rickety

Format: CD

Source: Leah

Cost: £0

This Working Poor lineup is the Alan/Lee/Greg/Thad/Brian quintet, and it's much more lively and raucous than New Wealth or Come Down For Your Silver. They're so much further away from sounding like a country band here, despite 'Black and Blue Damselfly', an awesome song really. I don't like this sound as much as the earlier stuff, but it would grow on me if I gave it time, for sure - 'Rusty Arrows' and 'Drowning on Dry Land' are classic Alan songs, mixing surreal allegories with a sense of devotion. It's also amazing how little of a presence this band has on the Internet - sometimes I feel like they only exist in Pittsburgh, and these few CDs (all in beautiful embossed cardboard sleeves of course) are the only proof to the outside world. I guess it's just our little secret. [22 August 2012]


Date: 8 December 2007

Mekons - Natural

Label: Quarterstick Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Monorail

Cost: £0

My Mekons love is uncritical but I've really liked their direction over the past few albums, which is definitely wimpy adult-contemporary stuff, but with a songcraft that few can equal. The concept behind the title translates into acoustic instrumentation, making this a sequel to Journey to the End of the Night if anything. It gets a little amped up with 'Zeroes and Ones', but for the most part it's all relaxed and certainly organic. There's some subdued and beautiful songs here - 'Hope and Anchor', 'Old Fox' and 'Diamonds' are all gems. This won't make any new fans but it's a delight all the way through. The ska-riff structures on Journey appear again, particularly in 'Cockermouth', and I wonder if Mekons actually do this gracefully or if I'm just a fan. For a group that is basically an art collective, their musical output has become quite safe, but they have aged so well that this mellowing is really appreciated. [10 July 2012]


Date: 8 December 2007

Cardinal - 

Label: Wonderland

Format: CD

Source: Monorail

Cost: £0

I just remembered that Cardinal put out a new album this year, their first in 18 years, and I forgot to check it out. This is the way my life is now - because I am not constantly talking about music with people, I have to really make efforts to keep up with this stuff. Not that anyone would ever have talked about Cardinal with me, at any point in my life. This CD reissue came out some years ago, packaged in that thick, nice cardboard cover that looks like a mini-gatefold LP, and it contains a slew of bonus tracks including the entire Toy Bell EP and the other b-sides. This album is a masterpiece, though it's one of the slowest of slow burners - which is maybe why I've never tired of it, and every time I pull it out it's a joyful reunion. I was always under the impression that this was a really balanced collaboration between Davies and Matthews, but actually Richard wrote almost all of the songs apart from the instrumental jams and 'Dream Figure'. This is a relic in ways, from that magical 1994 underground that I was so influenced by, when there was a slew of artists I found that were heavily influenced by 1960s pop (Zumpano for example) while still being "indie" beyond belief. Of course the sophistication of Davies' songwriting gets better with age, and as much as 'Christmas Trees' and 'Big Mink' are the obvious classics, 'You've Lost Me There', 'Silver Machines' and 'Last Poems' are pretty incredible too, and some of his most straight-forward lyrics. The bonus tracks are a nice addition, especially 'Say the Words Impossible'. [22 August 2012]


Date: 8 December 2007

VA - SedmikrÃ¡sky OST

Label: Finders Keepers

Format: LP

Source: Monorail

Cost: £12

How fucking awesome is it that this soundtrack has been released! It reminds me of watching the film, which I haven't seen in ages, which is to be expected. Separated from Chytlova's incredible visuals, the sound stands on its own as a wonderful carnival of sensation. The song structures are lively and idiosyncratic masterpieces of surrealism; the interludes are great works of juxtaposition, interpersing everyday life sounds with more tonal bits. On top of it all, it's a fantastic pressing, great packaging, and nice liner notes. May this last forever and ever. [15 Dec 2007]


Date: 2 January 2008

The Family Elan - Stare of Dawn

Label: Locust

Format: LP

Source: Chris Hladowski

Cost: £0

Thanks Chris!  Chris's solo album was released at a pretty difficult time, and for that reason I put off listeneing to it.  But it's not that painful, besides the cover art.  On vinyl, it sounds amazing - the mastering/pressing is of the highest quality, as the bouzouki really sings with brightest tone imagineable.  His voice has never sounded better; John Cavenagh did a great job of keeping things simple here.  The songs are great, sounding similar enough to keep a coherent theme.  It's more remarkable knowing how things all went so horribly wrong, but I suspect that will really be evident in the new Nalle album.


Date: 15 February 2008

Usurper - Booby Price

Label: Puik

Format: CD-R

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: £4

"Yet another Usurper CD" but maybe because I was sitting really close to the speakers, I heard this one resonate with a newfound fidelity.  There's the usual gaps of silence and awkwardness, crippled noise breakdowns, and static/cord mess, but here it seems to come together well.  It feels like each Usurper disc I listen to is better than the last, but maybe I'm just "understanding" them more.  Although I fell in love with them at first sight.  [6 May 2008]


Date: 15 February 2008

Usurper - You're A Winner!

Label: Giant Tank 

Format: CDr Album

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: £4

Usurper dudes proclaimed this "the best Usurper release ever" or some other such malarkey on the merch table; cause I like the looks of those two cute Lothians I splurged the £4 to hear what the hype was about.  Of course it's another half hour of plinking, dripping, tapping and clanging sounds, maybe slightly higher than average fidelity.  It's probably the wrong thing to have listened to while doing the dishes but hey, that's when these CDrs get the most play.  And while I love the guys live that's cause I can give them the attention they deserve, which they didn't get in the kitchen.  Next time though, I promise.  [4 April 2008]


Date: 16 February 2008

Family Battle Snake - Searching for Venus

NULL

Format: CDr Album

Source: Koulio

Cost: £0

Two tracks from original 'classic' FBS lineup of Koulio and Harry, recorded last September.  It sounds like a 'studio' recording or at least a soundboard tape if live.  In a half hour these guys start out with some really small, quiet drones that build to a wall of noise, but without ever actually being noisy or loud.  It reminds me a bit of Heldon in its spacyness.  The second track, 'Melting Your Insides', has a screaming guitar? line looped over everything, slicing through the ringing tones and providing a centre.  This is a really nice and representative recording of Family Battle Snake.  [16 March 2008]


Date: 16 February 2008

Family Battle Snake - Frozen Womb

NULL

Format: CDr

Source: Koulio

Cost: £0

This might be the 'ultimate' Family Battle Snake release, at least of what I've heard.  The sound is totally huge here, with booming engulfing drones that completely smothered me while listening.  There's a couple of pieces so it feels like a full substantial 'album', and while it's still not the highest fidelity recording there's a lot of dynamics to it.  I think this will definitely be the "go-to" release when I feel like listening to Koulio.  [28 July 2008]


Date: 16 February 2008

Family Battle Snake - Sweet Mine of Child

NULL

Format: CDr Album

Source: Koulio

Cost: £0

This collaboration between Koulio and Slash (ha) is based around the sample riff from its namesake, except instead of looping it into an early Steve Reich-styled piece, it lifts into a high, harmonic drone.  It loses sight of GnR for a bit and drifts along for about 20 minutes before coming back down to the melodic riff that set it off.  It's funny seeing FBS veer into 'novelty' territory, but maybe its best to think of it as a plunderphonics cover version kinda things.  [6 April 2008]


Date: 16 February 2008

Family Battle Snake - Persisting Finger Void

NULL

Format: CDr Album

Source: Koulio

Cost: £0

Twenty-three more minutes of Family Battle Snake, again a largely homogenous drone, again recorded in middle fidelity and probably life, and again with a lovely screened cover.  The more of Bill's releases I listen to the more I feel I "get" his approach to drone, which may not sound like the most unique but is extremely well done, with a strong reliance on a pulse that gives it a very physical feel.  THis one fades away and leaves my ears ringing, which is always a good move.  [6 April 2008]


Date: 17 February 2008

Ghost of an Octopus - XVIII XVII

NULL

Format: 3" CDr

Source: Gareth Howells

Cost: £0

When Gaz handed me all these 3"s he told me what each was but I forget which was which ; I think most of them are him, and this sounds like the work of one to three people.  Dirty, aggressive noise with scrambling electronics and fuzzed out dementia moments, but it never quite lifts off for me.  The 18 minutes go by slowly, buried in the sound of static cheap amps and today's young noise.  Maybe it would feel more distinct another time but it's 'noise listening night' and I think my brain is starting to get angry at me.  [12 March 2008]


Date: 17 February 2008

NULL

NULL

Format: 3" CDr

Source: Gareth Howells

Cost: £0

Another weird quickie that I assume is Gaz; this one is my favorite, I think, with a lot of hissing and blowing that reminds me a bit of old MEV stuff (The fake MEV that is).  There's some less distinct parts later on but in general this carries a warped, LAFMS kinda vibe to it.  Well done!  [6 April 2008]


Date: 17 February 2008

Roses - Spared the Lash

NULL

Format: 3" CDr

Source: Gareth Howells

Cost: £0

Another release from Gaz, this one I think with Sinead as track 1 boasts some vocals that might be hers (but what do I know) around a really demented, echoey song structure.  This is incredibly promising - a real winning track - and the rest of the disc shifts into more horizontal territory, not a bad thing per se but I want to hear more vocals!  Space is an asset, even when buried in reverb.  [12 March 2008]


Date: 17 February 2008

Ashtray Navigations - Hands Under Water Reaching For Nothing: 1995-1997

Label: Revival

Format: CDr Album

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £2.5

Phil's now starting to become his own archivist, and with the zillions of tiny releases he's done he can spend the rest of his life chasing his own tail - which is exactly what this disc sounds like.  A murky, mid-fi heavy fuzz guitar dronetone that builds to a crashing crescendo of feedback and bliss, with percussive clanking barely audible behind it - and it continues for a nice long period of time, hypnotic as all of the best Ashtray work but still a bit wild and exploratory.  There's nothing that would make me think this wasn't recorded last week except the date on the cover; this isn't to suggest that Phil hasn't developed in the last 10-12 years but rather that he's been refining his approach and concentrating on what he knows he does best.  [12 March 2008]


Date: 17 February 2008

Ashtray Navigations - Srpls Provncl Hrbs

NULL

Format: CDr Album

Source: Phil Todd

Cost: £2.5

Wow Christ HOLY CRAP, this oddly decorated underwater-themed CDr that I bought from Phil turns out to be maybe the best solo Ashtray work I've ever heard!  Track 1 is an absolutely devastating Fushistusha-like dirge with industrial percussion and the Ashtray fuzzdrone, only sounding robotic and evil.  The middle of the disc flits around in various modes but it all seems like a buildup to the final track, a thick soupy wonderfully shoegazery drone that sounds like he's been listening to Seefeel or something.  It's also unusually hi-fi for an Ashtray track but hey - I ain't complaining!  Very very well done and I will pull this one out a lot if I can distinguish it from all the others. [9 April 2008]


Date: 21 February 2008

Biota - Half a True Day

Label: Recommended Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Worm shop

Cost: £12.07

When Biota comes out with a new album there are probably very few people that rejoice, but I did and I still can't bring myself to properly articulate any thoughts on it.  In some ways this isn't a huge step forward from Object Lesson; it is still very driven by accordion and processed improvisation, vaguely structured into songs but taken apart before they get anywhere.  The vocalisations are significantly less song-oriented than before; there's a lot of jams that start to come together and then instantly start melting thorugh studio trickery or whatever.  It's about an hour long and somewhat of an insane listen, as there's so many musical directions packed into every song that it's really hard to concentrate on anything.  Still, it's another worthy addition to a already strange discography. [12 April 2008]


Date: 25 February 2008

Caboladies - Optopio

Label: Rampart

Format: C32 Cassette

Source: Trevor Tremaine

Cost: £0

Sadly side one of this tape is only in the left channel - I kept waiting for it to burst into the other channel, or maybe thinking that was the intention, but it's more likely a Trevor fuckup.   Side one is beautiful too - well, the whole tape is beautiful.  These Kentucky kids, who hit the scene after I left, channel the great spirits of the harmonic drone masters while also experimenting with tape manipulations and concrete techniques.  It sounds like a big happy jam but avoids the throwawy aspects of the zillion other groups doing this kinda thing.  And I've only heard 75% of this tape - I need to get TT to dub over my side 1 with the full version so I can enjoy this in full bloom.  [1 April 2008]


Date: 25 February 2008

Kraken Fury - Burn in Earjh

Label: Rampart

Format: 2xCDr Album

Source: Trevor Tremaine

Cost: £0

Thad, one of the Lexington oddballs who I remember with a lot of affection, has made this double CD of him playing every instrument.  It's primarily guitars/drums/bass, bouncing between crunchy rock instrumentals and more discordant Beefheartian skronk.  It's due to the length that I love it.  The first disc is relentless and hard to take in its repetitveness and duration; by the end of the second disc I realised that it is a work of genius, albeit an unconventional one.  It's not an easy thing to listen deeply to, sounding on the surface like some 90s Skin Graft band's outtakes - but the reward is there, coming about an hour into the madness. A slow burner, perhaps.  [1 April 2008]


Date: 25 February 2008

Three Legged Race - Ringing Order

Label: Rampart

Format: C32 Cassette

Source: Trevor Tremaine

Cost: £0

"This should have probably been an LP," said Robert, "but whatever, tapes are cool."  He's right on both counts - the second side in particular balances the slow, unfolding world of Three Legged Race with a psychoactive overlay of evaporating motion.  It's a great sound that probably isn't actually helped by the limitations of the format, but there's always room for a reissue.  This is definitely my favorite Three Legged Race release, it but it's made me realise how rarely I listen to solo Robert and made me vow to pull the other tapes and cd-r's out more. [3 March 2008]


Date: 25 February 2008

Ara - Toxic Motions

Label: Rampart

Format: C32 Cassette

Source: Trevor Tremaine

Cost: £0

O'Keefe solo!   O'Keefe solo!  Well, the drums on side two hint that O'Keefe's better half is a bit involved, but this is totally her show.  Melting clarinet and saxophone, with bursts of melody and strange loops, lumbering percussion, and complementary dream-clogged vocals make this a real winner.  There's some cuts I like more than others, namely the first track on side two which feels "jammy" and "band-like" and just great-great.  Can't wait to hear more; maybe I should start bugging her about doing a Cenotaph LP again.  [6 May 2008]


Date: 28 February 2008

Van Morrison - Brown Eyed Girl

Label: Black Box

Format: 2xCD Compilation

Source: Tara

Cost: £0

Somehow Tara found this at the post office - it's a bootleg of the New York sessions as disc 1, and the legendary 'Payin Your Dues' contractual obligation sessions on disc 1.  Not bad for a pound - and how weird is it to find bootlegs at the post office?  The contractual obligation material is pretty amazing, as most of the songs are exactly the same, ie: "Twist and Shake," "Jump and Turn", "Swing and Shout" etc.  "Ringworm" is of course an all-time classic, and luckily the set is only about a half hour so it doesn't become too tiresome.  Disc 1 is pretty good too though it doesn't work in my CD player - it's got some demo versions of a few Astral Weeks songs and jams like "TB Sheets".  [3 March 2008]



Date: 7 March 2008

Mayo Thompson - Corky's Debt To His Father

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl LP Album Reissue

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £14

It's great to finally own this on vinyl after ten years of loving it.  I bought it my Freshman year of college on CD and over the years I have played it countless times.  It's a continuous source of inspiration and I still don't think anything quite equals the combination of sincerity and strangeness.  The bonus 7" has a lost instrumental track from the era that fits nicely as a coda to the album.  I don't think I'll sell my CD but to finally hear this on the superior format is like hearing a new record, only one that I am incredibly familliar with. [8 March 2008]


Date: 7 March 2008

Thames - IX

Label: Flourescent Friends

Format: cassette

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6

I consider myself a mild Blake Hargeaves fan - at least I find all of his projects that I've heard to be pretty varied and interesting.  This one starts off with some weird samples of children reciting some sort of schoolbook text about history or Latin or something (I already forget) before melting into a strange slow dance album!  I mean dance album in the worst possible way, as you'd have to be a bit psychotic to shake your booty to this, but a lurching rhythm runs throughout while buried with lo-fi electronics and distortion and samples and all sorts of fucked up shit.  From what I remember of his solo LP (which I think I only listened to once before filing it and moving) he's not adverse to playing with genres, though this really is closer to Throbbing Gristle than the Pet Shop Boys.  Still, interesting, dark, and dense - and worthy of another spin next time I have 'cassette night'.  [9 April 2008]


Date: 7 March 2008

Ilk - Language of the Court

Label: Sonic Oyster

Format: CDr Album

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6

Ilk is the "prog" group of Richard Youngs and Andrew "Paz" Paine, and I've always followed their work with a bit of amusement.  There's something wonderfully "outsider" about it, even though I know they are doing it very tongue-in-cheek and with far too great of a wealth of musical knowledge to be truly naive.  This disc is driven by the electric bass guitar, but with electric guitar solos, dreamy keyboards, Richard's beautiful tenor and Paz's fantastical spoken passages.  At its most compelling it builds up a strong tension missing from all but the best progressive rock groups; however, it still just sounds like two people and Pro Tools (due to the lack of percussion).  I don't know how serious they are, but even if it's just a 'goof' it's a damned impressive one.  I haven't really given a listen to the lyrics, but I think they are a bit more abstract than being about gnomes and wizards, thankfully. [16 March 2008]


Date: 8 March 2008

Inseminoid - Dolls for Amerie

Label: Matching Head

Format: cassette

Source: Lee (Culver)

Cost: £1.5

A lenghty workout from Lee Stokoe that I picked up when I asked him "which of these are poppy"?  I don't really hear it but maybe there's some melody and structure at the beginning, at least compared to the usual Culver drones.  Actually it has a distorted Carnival of Souls feels, sort of appropriate given his love of horror film and the fact that said film was on TV at the TravelLodge the night I met Lee.  Later on it mophs into a thicker noisier thing, without any pauses in between.  It's a lot to listen to and not the kind of thing that lends itself to even this much verbosity.  [9 April 2008]


Date: 8 March 2008

Culver - Black Acid Confession

Label: Matching Head

Format: Cassette Single Sided

Source: Lee (Culver)

Cost: £1.5

Even by Lee Culver standards this is some miminmal stuff.  Is this amplified blank tape? The sound of my cheap stereo playing back nothing?  Or a subtle and humble roar, growiling ahead?  [6 May 2008]


Date: 28 April 2008

T.U.O.B. - Don't Fight At Gigs!

Label: Very Good Records

Format: Vinyl 7" Limited Edition

Source: eBay

Cost: £7.56

I have been seeking this for some time and it's amazing to finally have a copy.


Date: 28 April 2008

Car Commercials - Black 93

Label: Fuck It Tapes

Format: cassette

Source: Jeremy Earl

Cost: £0

This Car Commercials release is a far diferent beast than my LP; it's really direct, slightly one-dimensional, and has a tossed-off feel (except all Car Commercials sorta feels that way).  It's got a messy cover of Springsteen's "Johnny 99", I guess the most public embracing of their Jersey roots yet ... and some other songs with guitar and drums.  A hint of piano ... it's brief, and though it's 8 songs, it feels more like a single.  [21 May 2008]


Date: 28 April 2008

Nonhorse - Mushhead

Label: Fuck It Tapes

Format: C40 cassette

Source: Jeremy Earl

Cost: £0

I released a CDr for Nonhorse once, but I think the casette is Lucas's best format. Since his source material is all on cassettes, or at least I think so, the muddy fidelity and hiss of indeterminate origin become the materials he shapes sound with. This is collaged from who-knows-what, but has a fairly static vibe across all 40 minutes. It's not quite as cut-up and scattered as my favourite Nonhorse stuff but it makes me want to check out what GLC has been up to lately, as we've fallen out of touch. [27 December 2012]


Date: 28 April 2008

Graham Lambkin & Jason Lescalleet - The Breadwinner

Label: Erstwhile

Format: CD

Source: Swill Radio

Cost: £8.19

Here's a true meeting of minds, a match made in heaven that I've cherished for the past four years. The Breadwinner is explicitly constructed around the concept of domesticity; the sounds here are selected and treated carefully as expected by these two. Lambkin's uniquely singular sound world fits right in with Jason's subtle sense of time and presence. When Lambkin-leaning tracks like 'Listen, the Snow is Falling' are built from creaking, everyday mundanity, pieces like 'E5150/Body Transport' are thick, resonating blankets that offer an ever-escaping centre. 'Lucy Song' has a tender piano core + mumbled confusion that's so incredibly fragile, yet soft, that this contradiction is a good symbol of their overall genius. This album is completely abstract yet so warm, inviting and comforting at the same time, that I feel it's about as close as possible to a perfect merger of 'music' and 'sound art'. There's actually not a lot happening on The Breadwinner - it's more like the spaces between activity that are explored here. These spaces are fuzzy, distant recordings, like aural memories of something we can almost grasp, and it's absolutely captivating if you are so inclined towards sounds like this. Oddly, I've never picked up Air Supply, their second record, but I think I need to immediately. [24 December 2012]


Date: 28 April 2008

Idea Fire Company - Stranded

Label: Swill Radio

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Swill Radio

Cost: £8.19

Exotic electronic synthesisers open this LP, but it's a wet, organic feel despite the inherent alienation of the Idea Fire Company's music. This is a band who creates environments that are somehow alien, yet familiar. The static baths that surround everything make some of the cuts, particularly the title tracks, into a rainforest of obsolete welcoming. You can fixate on any element - the barely audible vocals, the placid ringing tones that float in and out of the sonic horizon, or the trembling uncertainty of the whole. Even the off-kilter interludes - the bumpy juxtapositions between the smoother soundscapes - contain a feeling of the vestigal, the domestic. [25 November 2012]


Date: 28 April 2008

Tart - Bring In The Admiral

Label: Swill Radio

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Swill Radio

Cost: £8.19

Tart's second outing is a much more minor key affair, though of course it is really not in any key.  Here the bouncy rhythms of Radio Orange are slower, more dirgy, and thickened by held down keyboard and Lambkin's own weird Lambkinisms.  The shorter pieces are where they truly excel - it's truly some of the most effective examples of concrète I've heard in ages.  There's much more of an uneasy feeling about this one; maybe this is that "difficult second album" bands are supposed to make.  Everything on this label is pretty incredible and this is no exception. [4 Aug 2008]


Date: 28 April 2008

Tart - Radio Orange

Label: Swill Radio

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Swill Radio

Cost: £8.19

This Tart album is a pretty fun slab of buzzing and ringing electronics.  There's some rhytmic stuff that reminds me of Astral Social Club, and some other Lambkin moments of scraping and breathing sounds.  This is an awesome record actually. The pieces are all exactly the right length too, so it's a good party record for people who like primitive obtuse electroacoustic music at their parties. [28 July 2008]


Date: 28 April 2008

Idea Fire Company - Anti-Natural

Label: Swill Radio

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Swill Radio

Cost: £8.19

You know, the 'anti-natural' manifesto included with this is actually a pretty well-written and intelligent art manifesto. It's a shame that art people don't know anything about experimental music and therefore never noticed this, because it makes a pretty good point about the way we can all have aesthetic experiences and maintain a critical interaction with capitalist life. I guess this is probably the first IFCo record and it's a groundwork for Foust and his weird electronic world -  an anti-musical lake built around sweeping synths and something unsettling yet placid. Maybe not as textured as the later stuff but raw and elegant in its own way. [9 October 2012]


Date: 28 April 2008

Idea Fire Company - The Island of Taste

Label: Swill Radio

Format: LP

Source: Swill Radio

Cost: £8.19

This is the newest Idea Fire Company album and probably my favorite of any work I have heard by them.  It is magnificent and beautiful, deploying static against plaintive piano to weave a minimalist dream.  Though there are still some searing electronics and garbled tape manipulations, it is significantly less jarring than their earlier records.  It's also on super thick vinyl and features a beautiful essay/card set and lovely painted cover.  So far this is one of my favorites of the year; I'll be going back to it plenty. [4 May 2008]


Date: 28 April 2008

Son of Earth - Pet

Label: Apostasy

Format: LP

Source: Swill Radio

Cost: £8.19

I only saw Son of Earth live but they were about the best ramshackle minimalism I've ever seen live; my once-close friendship with Aaron Rosenblum (which would be close again if either of us were better at staying in touch) has always made them favorites for me, so when they finally get around to releasing an LP it's a pretty big moment and I expect to be floored by it.  Except, the very nature of Son of Earth somewhat defies flooring; I found myself struggling to even concentrate on this, despite the fact that it's by all measurable standards "excellent".  Everything goes by the wayside here; it's a challenge to connect to it, and hell maybe the LP format isn't ideal for them - I don't know.  A few repeated listens doesn't open any more windows.  If I'm slightly dumfounded then chalk that up as a success. [4 Aug 2008]


Date: 28 April 2008

Shadow Ring - I'm Some Songs

Label: Swill Radio

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Swill Radio

Cost: £8.19

The last Shadow Ring release has never clicked with me as much as the earlier ones, but listening to it now I feel a real spirit of desolation that speaks heaps to me right now.  Not that I am depressed or anything, but I feel like they really hit on a collective vision for this one, and that's something I appreciate.  This is probably their most minimal record - many tracks are just ambient hums and gurgles, especially "SC DN" which is almost nothing.  Most of the tracks have extremely slowed down vocals - that is, if you play it at 33rpm.  I've never really been sure what speed to play this one at - it works at both, and the voice is slowed down either way so it doesn't really matter.  At 45rpm, the other stuff sounds too fast, especially the beautiful synth loop that is behind "Start Repeating" (a track that sounds closer to Idea Fire Company the Shadow Ring and is probably a more Scott Foust-heavy one). I don't even mourn the end of the Shadow Ring since all of the projects I've heard from them since have been totally amazing- I wonder what Darren Goss has been up to? [3 Jan 2009]


Date: 10 May 2008

Raymond MacDonald and Neil Davison - Carnival

Label: Iorram

Format: CDr Album

Source: Una MacGlone

Cost: £5

As the debut release of Neil's new label, it certainly makes a statement.  This is a long, confident statement that is a lot bolder than the live performance I saw to accompany the release.  It still sounds like Neil and Raymond, of course, but Neil's guitar sounds absolutely amazing - like a reign of static with electronic bursts, except I don't think it's treated in any way.  I really like having a recording of this because I can focus on what Neil is doing - live, the details are often lost.  Raymond is such a virtuosos and he shows all sides here - I don't think there is a soprano player I enjoy more.  Unike a lot of improvised CDs that I have, I will probably listen to this one frequently.  [21 May 2008]


Date: 10 May 2008

Una MacGlone / Aileen Campbell / Neil Davidson - Cave

Label: Iorram

Format: CDr Album

Source: Una MacGlone

Cost: £5

Can't seem to find this; must have gotten lost or misfiled. [29 December 2012]


Date: 16 May 2008

Matmos - Supreme Balloon

Label: Matador

Format: CD Album

Source: Dave Martin

Cost: £0

I like Matmos, but this CD is somewhat lackluster.  I admit I like "gimmicky" Matmos, whether it's the Civil War stuff or A Chance to Cut is a Chance to Cure; here, they're relinquihsed their usual approach to objects in favor of an all-synth album.  It proudly boasts that no microphones were used and proceeds to construct a lot of interesting, yet thorwaway IDM tracks from a huge collection of analogue synths.  There are some cools parts, like the weird baroque classical qutoes around track 5, but ultimately it just feels too machinelike and generic for me to really click with.  This may be a result of my own rockist/acoustic-favoring predjudices.  [29 May 2008]


Date: 16 May 2008

Earles & Jensen - Just Farr a Laugh

Label: Matador

Format: 2CD

Source: Dave Martin

Cost: £0

I've listened to the first volume of Just Farr a Laugh probably a hundred times over the years, but the second disc is entirely new to me.  And it's like finding out that there's actually a great album by an artist you love that you've never heard.  It's absurd that Matador sunk money into this project and even more absurd that they wrote a giant booklet of stupid liner notes (which actually kinda detract from the charm of the calls).  But I'm glad they did because it brings this humour to a large audience, if there actually is a large audience that finds something like "Loder's Run: The Quickening" or references to Murphy's Romance funny.  The new disc does not disappoint; it has a few duds as does the first, but there are some great great great calls, like the guy who calls T-Mobile to get a new celphone that will stop women from hanging up on him.  My favorite is still probably the yogurt machine ("Well, tell me about 'em ....") but there's no shortage of yuks.  [16 June 2008]


Date: 20 May 2008

Trumans Water - Spasm Smash XXX0X0X Ox And Ass

Label: Elemental Records

Format: CD Album

Source: eBay

Cost: £8.44

Technically I saw Trumans Water on this tour, when I was 13, though I barely remember anything besides it being very loud.  I listened to this over at Chas's a few weeks ago and it sounded amazing, so I tracked down a copy.  I remembered Trumans Water as being spazzy and similar to bands such as Drive Like Jehu, yet this album has a very art-rock approach.  It's long and pretty poorly recorded (or maybe the record is just mastered badly) but I can hear a whole universe of angular guitar dreams bubbling under the solid state buzz.  It's actually quite a lot to digest but I'm really feeling this record.  The psychedelic approach is actually not unlike the whole San Diego hardcore scene from around the same time - and I think TW were from SD, so maybe there's some connection.  I shoulda heard this in high school cause it woulda been the bridge between Pittsburgh rock and psych/avant stuff for me. [29 May 2008]


Date: 4 June 2008

His Electro Blue Voice - Fog

Label: S-S Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: S-S Records

Cost: £0

His Electro Blue Voice (the name probably makes more sense to an Italian) are another in the S-S mold - awesome punk energy, avant-garde gestures that wouldn't be out of touch on the Mutant Sounds blog, a motorik rhythm and the 7" delivery format.  'Fog' is just too short; it's at 33rpm for some reason, maybe for symmettry's sake?  The b-side is a jam if I've ever heard one; these guys are definitely from the same family as Cheveu and another promising sign of the resurgence of punk (in my life at least).  [7 July 2008]


Date: 4 June 2008

Le Club des Chats - Ring-a-Ding

Label: S-S Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: S-S Records

Cost: £0

In a collection of records that contains much that is stupid, this 7" by Les Club des Chats makes a serious bid for the title of 'most stupid'. A bunch of French kids pretending to be cats, this sounds like a modern day reboot of Renaldo and the Loaf with appropriate energy to tie it to contemporary punk and hardcore. The voices are strained and silly, the songs come at machine-gun speeds, and it's exactly the kind of thing I love. But I love Renaldo, and Family Fodder, and all of the other post-punk operatives in their wake. This is right alongside them and I'd buy a full-length without hesitating. [19 December 2012]


Date: 4 June 2008

The Geeks - Too Fat Pig

Label: S-S Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: S-S Records

Cost: £0

Soriano reissued this oddity from Marin County, circa 1980. The Geeks are like a darkwave Fugs, influenced by Ralph records material, psychedelic music, free jazz, and lounge. This reminds me of that one Peter Ivers Band record I like so much in the way it has a loose, vocal-based feel with moody reeds and dark percussion. 'Visiting Day at San Quentin' is a dark trip indeed. It's just a sketch here, with two songs, and how I want more! [10 December 2012]


Date: 4 June 2008

Los Llamarada - The Very Next Moment 

Label: S-S Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: S-S Records

Cost: £0

I haven't kept up much with S-S records, Los Llaramada or anything from that genre over the past few years. This single is pretty much what to expect -mid-tempo, noisy sludge with heavy psychedelic guitars burying everything. 'The Very Next Moment' feels loose and exploratory, though clearly built around a song - it's a pleasant mix, especially when the tempo picks up for the coda, though it's not a groundbreaking statement. 'I'm Sorry' on the b-side has a female vocalist and feels a bit more pulled towards an old Rough Trade type of sound. [10 December 2012]


Date: 4 June 2008

Baby 63 - Quiver

Label: S-S Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: S-S Records

Cost: £0

Scott reissued this old weird tape project from someone in the early 80's.  It's really amazing, actually - sounding like Renaldo and the Loaf on 'ludes, bashing around the Ralph sound with a very dark vibe.  The two songs are long and uncompromising, and I wonder if this is the pick of the litter or if there's a whole brilliant album's worth in the vaults.  [10 June 2008]


Date: 4 June 2008

Antennas Erupt! - Magical Energy

Label: S-S Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: S-S Records

Cost: £0

This is a scorching and fun release from Antennas Erupt, a band who I saw play in Lexington in '04 or '05 and who I think stayed at our place. Scott Soriano released this and I think it was one of the last copies - and it's a beauty, on white vinyl with a lovely fold-out cover. Antennas Erupt were built around a free-ish jazz group - two saxes, cello and percussion - but with a very direct, fun compositional framework that feels like rock music more often than not. There are some incredibly abrasive, guttural sax solos and a bit of an electronic presence as well, and it's excellently recorded to leave a nice amount of balance and space between everything. The last track is a very angular, tightly composed piece for saxes in counterpoint and it cuts against the party vibe felt elsewhere. I wish there were bands like this around me now. [20 November 2012]


Date: 4 June 2008

Los Llamarada - The Exploding Now!

Label: S-S Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: S-S Records

Cost: £0

Los Llamarada are probably Mexico's best band, not that I know the first thing about what is going on in that country.  The opening cut suggests it's going to be a marvelously stoned, blisteringly lo-fi punk rock record, and it is - but there's hints of very deep range throughout, most obviously with side two's opener.  This is an album that's rocking and blown out, but not overly aggressive; it disorts so much (either due to bad recording, bad mastering, bad pressing or my shit plastic turntable) that it's actually a bit annoying to listen to.  But it's awesome at the same time - a truly fresh punk roar for today's thinking man. [4 Aug 2008]


Date: 11 June 2008

Ben Reynolds - Two Wings

Label: Strange Attractors Audio House

Format: CD Album

Source: Ben

Cost: £0

Ben busts out a solo guitar record that is at times intense and ragalike, and at other times restrained and contemplative.  Knowing what his life was like while he was making this, it feels a bit unrepresentative.  I have so little interest in solo guitar recordings these days (as he joked when he handed me the CD) that I don't know if I'll go back and listen to this again any time soon. But it's definitely a major departure from his last few proper CDs, and probably one that will win him a new audience.  [16 June 2008]


Date: 15 July 2008

Tusk Lord - Summer 2008

Label: no label

Format: CDr Album

Source: Mike Kasunic

Cost: £0

Holy Christ is Tusk Lord awesome!  The old CD was good, but this builds upon that without even being a focused, finished product.  Just a collection of demos, this could be the Basement Tapes for one man's twisted vision.  Matt Wellins got a real medievalist/Gregorian chant vibe from sections of this, which I can sorta see, but then other parts are surfy guitar pop and others are shimmering psych-folk.  Although it's lengthy and scattered (by definition) it all feels like a man with a very cohesive vision.  I am very excited to hear a "proper" Tusk Lord album and I'd love to play with Mike at some point.  [4 Aug 2008]


Date: 15 July 2008

Cheveu - Cheveu

Label: Born Bad Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: X-Mist

Cost: £0

I love this record and so far it's probably my favorite album of 2008 (though I should read through this spreadsheet and see how many other times I've said that).  Cheveu are simple yet amazing; weird Chrome-esque guitar riffs, arty babbled vocals, goofy synth drums and strange dance-pop experiments.  Why can't I explain how great this is?  I had to get it on vinyl though it actually sounds terrible on my cheap turntable, but terrible is great in this case and the red vinyl is beautiful.  'Lola Langusta' for some reason has totally been my jam lately.  How do these guys get away with shouting a Rimbaud poem over a frantic guitar freakout and make it sounds so good?  [15 July 2008]


Date: 15 July 2008

Thomas Function - The Insignificants

Label: Tic Tac Totally! Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: X-Mist

Cost: £0

'The Insignificants' is built around an electric piano line and this song takes some time to get going, but soon the familiar Thomas Function yelping is there and it's a solid, fun song. The b-side sounds clearly from the same session; 'Blue & Green' has a shifting-time chorus that builds up tension quickly before releasing into a familiar rock-out pattern; 'Conspiracy of Praise' is a great jam from the album, but a bit slower here. It's a satisfying three songs for a 7" release and I forgot how much I enjoyed Celebration; never checked out their followup, probably never will. [8 November 2012]


Date: 15 July 2008

Cheveu / Tyvek - Split

Label: S-S Records

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: X-Mist

Cost: £0

Since moving to Finland/Estonia, whenever I see the work "Tyvek" (either in the context of the band or that thing they wrap houses with) I pronounce the 'y' the Finnish way, so I accidentally said too-vek around someone in America once and they thought I was super weird. 'Future Junk' by Tyvek is a good, short, discordant song that has guitar leads pulling in strange directions and the best short-attention-span theatrics. It ends with the most annoying locked groove I've ever heard. But I bought this for the Cheveu side, 'El Tortuga', which is, I dunno, "good". Not great, but clearly from the first album era and with that frantic downstroke infernal madness that made them my favourite band that year. [18 December 2012]


Date: 15 July 2008

Cheveu / Crash Normal - La Cerise

Label: Rococo Records

Format: 7"

Source: X-Mist

Cost: £0

The Crash Normal side is actually a bit more memorable, with two scuzzy, slow punk songs with big simple beats and sci-fi overtones. The latter sounds more like Cheveu so I can see why this was an idea for a split. The Cheveu song is short and slightly rockabilly-influenced; at least, it sounds like the Reverend Horton Heat to me. In the glut of material they released around 2008 this is definitely the most minor. [21 December 2012]


Date: 15 July 2008

Boom Edan - All Suffering Soon to End

Label: Monmouth Music

Format: CDr Album

Source: Tuukka

Cost: £0

Tuukka floated me a copy of his first solo disc under the Boom Edan name and I am very impressed by it!  There's a lot of changes between each track, indiciating an interest in composition that I didn't pick up from his live set.  The recording is great - dirty and homemade, but with enough range to provide a rich sound experience.  The last track is a harebrained vocal piece that sounds truly deranged, and though it's completely different than the other tracks it still feels like part of the whole album.  I look forward to hearing what he does next.  [9 Aug 2008]


Date: 15 July 2008

Eye Shaking Kingdom - With Metal And Swordlight

Label: Sick Head

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Ruaraidh Sanachan

Cost: £0

Traded Car Commercials LP for this.


Date: 19 July 2008

Sebadoh - The Freed Man

Label: Domino

Format: CD Album

Source: Monorail

Cost: £4.99

At £5 I couldn't pass up this reissue of The Freed Man, an album that stands up against the classics of deranged outsider psych/folk.  Most people only know an abridged version of this album that ended up on CD, but I had a dub of the LP in high school so I grew to really love the weirdness within, even if I didn't like the more tuneless diversions.  This record is so fragile and fractured and it wears its soul on its sleeve, yet it's wild and druggy and unstable.  It completely blows away all other Sebadoh that followed except for maybe III which is awesome too except for the Jason Lowenstein songs on it.  But there's no Lowenstein here; it's just Gaffney and Barlow, and they are presented as equals as opposed to the usual Lou dominance (see Weed Foresting).  This actually adds on the tracks from the Magic Ribbons 7" box set, which I dubbed from Weird Paul at the peak of my Sebadoh-mania (there was a time when Nick Sarno and I had a printout of Lou Barlow's complete discography and we were obsessed with hearing every single song. Getting a copy of those songs from Paul was a major coup in this quest, which ended at the time Harmacy came out and Sebadoh sunk into being just another boring rock band, one that I didn't even like anymore.  I was too young to realise that Eric Gaffney was the best thing about Sebadoh).  Anyway, those songs are amazing, and the stuff that didn't end up on the original LP is amazing too.  I should have bought the vinyl version of this but it was £10 more and I know I'm going to go back and buy it at some point anyway.  [28 July 2008]


Date: 19 July 2008

Broadcast - The Future Crayon

Label: Warp Records

Format: CD Album Compilation

Source: Monorail

Cost: £6.99

This is a compilation of Broadcast's b-sides and singles and miscellaneous tracks, dating mostly from around 1999-2001.  Despite the older nature of it and the patchwork sequencing, I love this album.  I'm not sure if it's just because I've listened to it more than other recent Broadcast or if I genuinely like it better than their last two albums.  I also bought Tender Buttons when I got this, but something is wrong with the CD and it won't play in either of my CD players.  Anyway, this has some awesome jazzy bits and some great space-pop songs that I just want to play over and over ("Poem for Dead Song"!!) and overall it makes me realise just how fucking incredible Broadcast are and how I should listen to them more. [5 Aug 2008]


Date: 19 July 2008

Broadcast - Tender Buttons

Label: Warp Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Monorail

Cost: £6.99

Defective copy; replaced.


Date: 19 July 2008

Chris McGregor - Up To Earth

Label: Fledg'ling Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Monorail

Cost: £7.99

The world has unearthed another Chris McGregor gem, this one featuring Evan Parker and unheard for years.  Which is a shame, because it's a fine document of some incredible musicians in their prime.  The straight-forward anthemic quality of Brotherhood of Breath isn't as evident here apart from the coda to the second piece, but Dudu Pukwana's lyricism still roars, cut away by Parker's playing to create a pretty stunning effect.  Harry Miller isn't on this recording but Barre Philips and Danny Thompson are more than suitable replacements, as they click well with Moholo.  I dont think there can ever be enough of this music, so I hope the reissues keep coming.  [9 Aug 2008]


Date: 19 July 2008

Mission Of Burma - Signals, Calls, And Marches

Label: Matador

Format: 2xVinyl LP Reissue RemasteredDVD DVD-Video

Source: Monorail

Cost: £19.99

I've bought this and Vs. four times now!  Originally on the Rykodisc Mission of Burma CD, the 80-minute compilation; then I bought the indivdual reissues of the three albums on Ryko.  Then I had the chance to pick up original Ace of Hearts LPs of the three records, so I got those too.  So when i saw that Matador had done a deluxe reissue of these records I hesitated ... but then the allure of 180gram vinyl pressings, bonus tracks on vinyl, beautiful gatefold covers and a bonus live DVD was too great.  Well, I held back on Horrible Truth but I may even give in.  I don't know what I need to say here about Signals, Calls and Marches that I haven't said before.  So I'll just use this space as a justification of having bought this.  The vinyl sounds great.  The records look great.  I haven't watched the DVD yet but I'm sure it's great too.  [28 July 2008]


Date: 19 July 2008

Mission Of Burma - Vs.

Label: Matador

Format: 2xVinyl LP Album Reissue RemasteredDVD DVD-Video

Source: Monorail

Cost: £19.99
