Any doubts I had about spending £20 to buy this record yet again were washed away as soon as I dropped the needle on 'Secrets'.  Cause I've heard the song a million times, listened to this album a million times, etc. - but its never sounded so incredibly awesome as it does on 180g deluxe vinyl.  Martin Swope's tape work during the bridge sounds thicker and clearer than ever before, even on my totally crap plastic turntable.  I can only dream about how wonderful this will sound when I get a real deck.  The record, well, what else do I need to say?  It's moody, mature and drives me to jump up and down still.  Yet I still marvel at new things each time through - this time, it's the wiggly guitar solo on 'Einstein's Day' that teeters on the verge of frustration.  Thank you, Matador. [9 Aug 2008]


Date: 23 July 2008

Tomutonttu - Tomutonttu

Label: Beta-lactam Ring Records

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £19.99

I think Jan Andersen is a genius and Tomottontu is probably my favorite Finnish project, period... being that I am relocating to Helsinki soon I felt like I should catch up with his latest release.  I didn't realise it was a super expensive Beta Lactam Ring title until I got home and realised how much I had spent.  Fiscal woes aside, this is a solid record, thickly psychedelic with all manners of sound sources and crazyness.  I love the Ultra Eczema release but this one sounds more like the work of an insane man, which I guess it is.  I hope Jan and I can play together at some point because he can certainly give me zillions of ideas.  [9 Aug 2008]


Date: 23 July 2008

Burning Star Core - Challenger

Label: Plastic Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £10

Spencer's long awaited "masterpiece"?  The high water mark of a genre?  I've heard all of these things used to describe Challenger, plus I know that Spencer and Robert both felt very strongly about this release.  It is a very focused, controlled record and the pieces are all relatively short, which left me wanting more of just about every track.  After one listen I am impressed, though I don't see this as a massive departure - if anything it's just a refining of what he has been doing for a long time.  The second side seems to rev up a bit more than the first, but maybe my view will change after repeated listen.  I'm glad I was able to snag a vinyl copy because they went pretty quickly.  [26 July 2008]


Date: 23 July 2008

Blues Control - Puff

Label: Woodsist

Format: Vinyl LP Limited Edition

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £10

I have a real 'thing' for this album.  I saw Russ and Lea play in Lexington the summer I lived there as Watersports, which was one of the best shows I've ever seen.  It really used the natural surroundings to create a beautiful sound, and it felt like a true justification for live music - there's no way a recording could have conveyed the experience.  Blues Control is just a more rockin' version of Watersports, and this album is a fucking masterpiece. Though it probably draws comparisons to a lot of noise/drone music due to personal associations, the closest thing sonically to something like the Skaters is the fidelity.  Yet the electric guitar cuts through and plays these wonderfully slow, bending pyschedelic riffs.  The compositions are strong but my favorite parts are when it becomes kind of dubby, with weird keyboard patterns and oscillating rhythms.  I wrote how a lot of people are saying Burning Star Core's Challenger is a "high water mark" from this scene; well this is a record I could see going down as an all-time cult great, maybe still being talked about in 10-15 years.  Of course time will tell; I'll try not to wear it out in the meantime.  [4 Aug 2008]


Date: 24 July 2008

Thomas Function - Celebration

Label: Alive Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £12

Even though it's fiscally irresponsible I've been on a kick to buy records that I've been listening to a lot over the past few months.  I do think that downloading music leads me to ultimately buy more music, though I of course don't buy nearly as much music as I used to, I also have a lot less disposable income and thousands of dollars in debt.  Anyway, enough justification - I downloaded this album a few months ago and fell in love with it for reasons beyond my own understanding.  It's a straightforward punk record with catchy hooks and some nice keyboards.  The singer yelps through it all, relentlessly.  There's total anthemic punk rock tunes like 'Can't Say No' and melodic slower songs like '2012 Blues.'  This could have been released in 1992 and I wouldn't be able to tell - I'm not sure if it's a throwback sound or if it's just timeless, brilliant rock music.  Note to label: "clear" is not a colour (re: COLOURED VINYL sticker on the shrinkwrap) but this pressing sounds fucking great - I usually expect clear or coloured vinyl to sound shitty, but this sound far better than the MP3s, even on my cheap turntable.  I feel young and inspired about rock music again and this record has helped to chip away years of cynicism.  [24 July 2008]


Date: 24 July 2008

Dodos - Visiter

Label: Frenchkiss Records

Format: 2xVinyl LP

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £12

Dodos are an indie-pop band with sweet, sunny melodies and frantically strummed acoustic guitar over frantic, lively drumming.  For some reason I was quite taken by this when I heard it.  It's musically a simple formula, yet there's quite a lot to listen to.  The percussionist is so incredibly good that it makes it sound like there's 10 people making a big swirling ball of sound, but they're just a two piece (though surely aided with some overdubs).  The lyrics are straightforward and the songwriting teeters on the edge of being cloying and singsong, like some crummy twee band - except it all clicks.  This record is serioulsy great.  There's some very short interlude-style pieces in between more fleshed out songs, and I love that sketchy quality.  Though it's a double LP it doesn't drag on, and there's an incredible song "Ashley" near the end that sustains my interest.  I don't pay attention to music like this much anymore but it's a style that I grew up with and something I really do have a soft spot for.  [28 July 2008]


Date: 19 August 2008

Blood Stereo and Ludo Mich - From Tapes and Throats

Label: Giant Tank

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: £0

Giant Tank vinyl! This is a meeting of some true weirdos. Side A is live from Instal 2006, a performance which I was certainly there for though I don't remember that clearly. It's built around vocals, obviously, with Dylan and Karen's more alien sounds juxtaposed with Ludo's babbling hysterics. Ludo is such a product of another time; his vocalising here reminds me of old Aktonist-style performance artists and the grand theatre of European insanity in the 1970s (more like a stereotype I have instead of any concrete examples). The electronic processing is there but minor; the end sounds like a giant swarm of bees. The B-side contains three tracks where Blood Stereo processed source material Ludo sent to the, and it's much more electic, full of tiny gestures and awkward spaces. There's points where Blood Stereo really take over and it sounds like their stuff, with Ludo thudding along. I played a set with Ludo once that Jelle released as a tape and I always thought he was a wonderful, sweet, insane man. I never picked up his film music LP but I bet it's also wonderful, sweet and insane. [18 December 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Paul McCartney - McCartney II

Label: MPL Communications

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

McCartney II is an example of the always-interesting phenomenon where an incredibly successful recording artist makes an extremely whacked out record which develops a cult following. This isn't Metal Machine Music but it's an extremely goofy half-hour of McCartney fucking around with his four track and writing not-serious-at-all tunes that are somehow transcendent of the situation. There's a great bootleg double album out there containing outtakes which I'd much rather have, because listening to this now and then is fun but it's the full ordeal that is more enjoyable. [29 November 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Shoes - Present Tense

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $3

The second Shoes album isn't as classic as Black Vinyl Shoes but it's still great, with a few classics ("Tomorrow Night") and a few underrated gems ("Your Very Eyes"). The production is far more clean and big than the home-recorded sound that made their name, but that's just what happens when artists sign to major labels. I don't have their first album unfortunately but this is a great power-pop record and will have to do when I want some Shoes. [15 November 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Mickey Newbury - I Came to Hear the Music

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $3

Newbury by the mid-70s had definitely eked out a career but there's not really anything more upbeat on this record than his first one. It's produced with a somewhat more hands-on production, containing the full studio treatment. But his confessional, sparse singing style is still evident and this is a great downer trip. 'You Only Live Once in Awhile' might stand out as my pick, being fit for Tom Waits to deliver, but 'Love Look (At Us Now)' is also commendable for it's sophistication. Sometimes everything slows down and he just picks a few arpeggiated notes, and it's a stunning effect, while still fitting comfortably into the genre of country and western ballads. [1 December 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Mickey Newbury - 'Frisco Mabel Joy

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

Mickey Newbury opens this with 'An American Trilogy', a medley of 'I wish I was in Dixie' and 'Glory Glory Hallelujah' and something else, which works well. It recalls the spare arpeggiated medleys on Looks Like Rain, sung with the same dour drawl. Newbury's a master of slow, depressed regret; whether it's acoustically plucked guitar or piano, it's helped along with some string arrangements which are never overbearing. 'Remember the Good' is an updating of 'I Don't Think About Her No More' and while the lyrics occasionally veer into such sad-sack territory that I want to slap him and say "knock it off!", it's also exactly what I'm in the mood for some times. Looks Like Rain was definitely the one that got me into his work but this one is almost as strong. [30 December 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Neil Young - Hawks & Doves

Label: Reprise

Format: LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

I've never gotten that into Hawks & Doves but I've also been hard on it for it's weird right-wing, pro-Reagan leanings. In actuality, 'Captain Kennedy' is one of my favourite Neil sleepers, and 'The Old Homestead' is a pretty impressive epic. But then there's the problematic title track and 'Union Man' which feels pandering and lazy. And the album overall is short and has a throwaway feeling. As I've never gotten into Trans and in general, have never heard anything post-Rust Never Sleeps that even holds a candle to the 70s work, this feels a bit like the last great gasp, and it's not even that great. [28 November 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Rake - Cow Song / My Fish Died

Label: L Records

Format: 7"

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $3

The first Rake single is a blast of noisy post-hardcore, and it's funny to imagine Bill Kellum rocking out like this. According to Discogs.com this was on L records (my copy says so, at least) but later ones had the VHF logo taped over the back, so maybe this is the first VHF release, catalogue number zero? 'Cow Song' sounds like Bastro or Bitch magnet, with screamy thrashing riffs and angular, Am-Rep influenced guitar interplay. 'My Fish Died' continues this - to throw out another comparison, maybe Land Speed Record-era Hüsker Dü as an influence here. [21 December 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Electric Light Orchestra - No Answer

Label: United Artists Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

Second copy bought by accident, given away.


Date: 12 September 2008

Kate Bush - Hounds Of Love

Label: EMI America

Format: LP

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $5

Hounds of Love is so widely known in the UK that it was shocking to friends when I moved to the UK with no familiarity of it or any of Bush's work. After living a few years in Scotland I became intensely familiar with this, not just from my flatmate's constant playing (he cites it as his favourite album of all time, which is a good choice) but from the general pop culture presence of it - a rare feat for a record 25 years old. Side one of this is packed with hits, which hold up well - I would say "despite the 80s production" but actually said production is exactly part of the charm. 'Hounds of Love' is as infectious and brilliant as anything; 'Cloudbursting' is an epic, driving hit. But it's the B-side of this album, subtitled The Ninth Wave, where the real magic lies. Apart from 'Jig of Life', this is mostly slower and less catchy songs, but it's where Bush really tries out some ideas. I've written before about the subtle key change in 'Watching You Without Me' but it hits me everytime as pure beauty, yet pure simplicity. The lyrics are definitely in a realm of foggy English mysticism, but Bush is confident and delivers everything with a brash brilliance, whether she's 'Waking the Witch' or 'The Big Sky'. Sometimes records are deserving of commercial success; this is one of them, and it's also amazing that something so adventurous can also find such a large audience. [8 November 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Thunderclap Newman - Hollywood Dream

Label: MCA Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $5

Thunderclap Newman's lone album is a bit of an anomaly in rock music, led by a former Who roadie; they were a one-hit wonder but this album is an impressive piece of British pop-rock, a bit early for glam but certainly leaning in that direction. This is far from a giant buildup to 'Something in the Air', though that track, appearing last, is certainly majestic; there's other great jams throughout, performed well with a punch. 'When I Think' is a rolling ballad and the cover of 'Open The Door, Homer' from The Basement Tapes is nice too. Pete Townsend plays bass and he's the svengali of the group, but I think they're better than the Who, personally. The theme of Hollywood is cast as a wistful, nostalgic view-from-abroad fantasy which really works to drive the record. This reissue has a weird cover but I kinda like it; it came shrinkwrapped as well. [22 November 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Radiopuhelimet - Pian, Pian

Label: Sonet

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $4

Bought excitedly, but the LP inside was something else entirely. Discarded.


Date: 12 September 2008

Iran - 

Label: Vulgar Tango

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $8

I for some reason received the tUMULT CD of this album to review, I think, probably for fakejazz. I was impressed and therefore happy to upgrade to the vinyl years later when I randomly came across it at Jerry's. Iran were from California, I think, and took a slightly more slow, stoned approached to Faust Tapes-style art-rock collage. There are aborted, discordant folk fragments, instrumental drone jams, space-rock pastiches and an emphasis on the record as a whole instead of the individual parts. The experimentalism never takes over and threatens to derail it, though I of course love this type of balance. They remind me of a less folk-centered Tower Recordings, except far, far stronger and consistent than Tower Recordings ever were. I know they put out a few more albums but I think Iran's destined to remain in obscurity, a real shame for such a brilliant band. [18 December 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Kate Bush - The Dreaming

Label: EMI America

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $5

Kate Bush's predecessor to Hounds of Love is actually the better record to me, with a bit more adventure and less commercial overtures. Not that a favourite must be picked, because both are masterpieces. This has a few songs that I go back to repeatedly, most notably 'Suspended in Gaffa' and the title track, a uniquely bizarre vision that only could have come from Bush. Her love of big synth textures, boldly artificial percussion, and thick-tracked vocals was perfect for 1982 and because it's supported by such visceral, invigorating songwriting, it really really works. These are songs about confusion, perception, sensations, other people, and despite trying to write about the topic, love; it's a confident step from a singular vision, and a sort of penultimate truth before her smash commercial breakthrough. [18 December 2012]


Date: 12 September 2008

Mickey Newbury - Live at Montezuma Hall / Looks LIke Rain

Label: Elektra

Format: Vinyl 2xLP Album

Source: Jerry's

Cost: $8

I grabbed this Mickey Newbury promo gatefold record because I wanted Looks Like Rain on vinyl -- said album has become a classic in my personal pantheon of downer country records. And while the pressing is thin it's great to hear this slow misery unfold on wax. "I Don't Think About Her No More" is a brilliant bit of dishonesty and even the more upbeat genre filler like 'T. Total Tommy' has a charm. Luckily, the live album is stripped down and slow too - just Mickey and his guitar. The material isn't quite as strong, though 'She Even Woke Me Up To Say Goodbye' closes it to great fanfare. The recording is intimate and when he's being straightforward, it's great, a bit like John Prine crossed with Townes Van Zandt. The only lesser spots are the songs like 'Heaven Help the Child', attempts to be an everyman Guthrie/Ochs character, which is not his strength. But this was a definitely nice pickup to have, and Looks LIke Rain is enough to justify the "expensive" cost (for Jerry's, at least when I shopped there regularly). [18 November 2012]


Date: 22 September 2008

Prisonshake - Dirty Moons

Label: Scat

Format: 2LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $16

Twelve years in the making, this double LP by Prisonshake is a stunning masterpiece of American rock music.  With a lovely, occult-influenced gatefold cover this looks like its going to be a Current 93 album.  Instead, it's an explosive, somewhat angry guitar-rock album that's recorded to the utmost level of perfection.  There's different song titles on the labels than on the sleeve, so it's a bit confusing - plus the booklet has some hilarious pictures of fake former releases, suggesting that this band likes their sarcasm.  Lyrically there's a fairly serious approach, with relationship-centered lyrics and none of the surrealism of my other Ohio/Scat fave, Robert Pollard ... but it gels so well it's hard to believe this was assembled from a zillion different sources.  There's some angular, crushing guitar riffs and the 80's indierock infuence that I imagine was big when this band formed - but then a few songs have that slower, slightly calmer feel.  "The Understudy" reminds me of Hurl; actually, this whole album reminds me of that style of indie rock that was popular in Pittsburgh when I started going to shows - Karl Hendricks, Hovland, that WRCT sound - the difference being that years later when I'm removed from that scene, this record sounds like an instant classic in a way that those bands never did.  I'm really surprised by how much I like this album - the all-analog recording is just so impressive that it's honestly a pleasure to listen to it, especially on my new turntable.  I should investigate their back catalog, though there's a lot to digest here first (and very little filler). [3 Jan 2009]



Date: 22 September 2008

Scritti Politti - Early

Label: Rough Trade

Format: 2xLP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $15

I used to dream of having all the early Scritti Politti material collected into one release, and alas, Rough Trade responded to this fantasy. These first singles are so naive, energetic, and ragged; they continue to be a source of inspiration 30 years later. Some of these songs - 'Hegemony', 'Messthetics', 'Scritlocks Door' - should be ranked among the greatest ever British punk/post/whatever songs - certainly as much a cornerstone of this movement as the Homosexuals or Desperate Bicycles. That SP went into a very pop direction later probably hurts their legacy, but if you only had this record to base it on, they'd be proper legends. [24 November 2012]


Date: 22 September 2008

The Music Tapes - Music Tapes for Clouds and Tornadoes

Label: Merge Records

Format: LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $14

Julian takes a lot of time between Music Tapes releases -- by the time this came out, I didn't know he was still actively recording at all, and my own connection to these people has long withered away. But I still bought it on faith and never really listened to it, which is a shame, cause there's some really beautiful melodies here. Mr. Koster may be an acquired taste but I've always loved everything he's done, because it masquerades extreme sadness as cute and fey. This is recorded on very old sound equipment, with the usual gang of suspects helping out, but it's still very much about Julian's vision. The giant song-cycle feel of his first album isn't so obvious; instead, we get some simple, strummy songs. His voice is earnest and cracks at times, just like back in the Chocolate USA days, and I now (listening for the first time since I bought it) think I should dive into it deeper. And, surprise, he has a new record out this year! [24 November 2012]


Date: 22 September 2008

Sic Alps - US EZ

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: LP

Source: Paul's

Cost: $13

Wow, this has been four years already. I loved Sic Alps when I first heard them and I think this one was the pinnacle. It's really bluesy, with the whole album wrapped in the same production techniques and generating a strange displaced retro-yet-modern sound. The songwriting is quite strong and I'm not sure why I lost interest - as I suspect their recent material is just as good. I guess this was a time for me - what I was listening to in 2008, and it holds up really well. [9 November 2012]


Date: 27 September 2008

Wasteland Jazz Unit - Shadow Flood Shrine

NULL

Format: C30 Cassette

Source: John Rich

Cost: $0

NULL


Date: 27 September 2008

Wasteland Jazz Unit - Shroud of Furnace Souls

Label: Skeleton Dust

Format: C20 Cassette

Source: John Rich

Cost: $0

NULL


Date: 28 September 2008

Warmer Milks - 

Label: Paranoid Overtime

Format: CDr

Source: Mikey T

Cost: $0



Date: 28 September 2008

NULL

Label: Paranoid Overtime

Format: CDr

Source: Mikey T

Cost: $0



Date: 28 September 2008

Warmer Milks - Let Your Friends In

Label: Release The Bats Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Mikey T

Cost: €0

This is two tracks that are really three.  The first is made of two parts, of which the first, 'The Ripple Children', is a full-on assault of tape manipulations of (I assume) Warmer Milks improvisations, probably assembled by Mikey solo to explain the 'Kentuckee Pong Tapes" credit.  It's actually pretty great at these things go, and it merges nicely into 'The Jaunting' which is a dirt-rock riff fest sounding like the darkest SST hangover.  The longest section of this disc is 'The Wanderer', which is a freaked out guitar and bass argument, heavily affected and sounding like a really really bad time.  The title is probably apt because while it steps all over the place (there's moments that remind me of Dr. John while others that sound like something from Ralph Records) it never sets forth in a definite direction.  There are vocals buried there too but they're processed beyond any recognition.  If you like the acoustic, soft side of the Milks this is definitely an album to stay away from, but as their more strident rock experiements go, this is a keeper.



Date: 28 September 2008

Warmer Milks - Soft Walks

Label: Animal Disguise

Format: CD

Source: Mikey T

Cost: €0

It's hard for me to write about Warmer Milks because even though I know them, have seen them a bunch of times, heard tons of recordings and even played a little bit with them, I still don't understand what Mikey is doing.  If WM can be distilled to one philosophy, maybe it's that they are perpetually changing direction.  Soft Walks is masterfully recorded, beautifully produced, and on the surface appears to be their most accessible record.  It's guitar-driven, with lots of acoustic instruments, huge ambience (feeling like the band is jamming inside of a barn), more conventional verse/chorus structures, and few experimental diversions (though there are some strangely psychedelic, electronic parts that feel as natural as the rest of the record).  Yet, like Mayo Thompson's Corky's Debt to His Father, it feels like Mikey's weirdest record yet (despite being the most accessible).  The songs are languid, and they unfold to portray a vision that is almost-human, but distant enough to prevent me from connecting to it.  Like everything else by WM, I don't really feel like this is something I would listen to repeatedly (or ever again).  But it also has a million years of rewards buried in the cracks - gestures, silences, and hidden meanings that will emerge after one finally has some familiarity with it.  Maybe.  This could end up becoming my favorite record ever, but something tells me it will remain obtuse and distant.  This is the Warmer Milks M.O. I think, and I like when clues are buried and the reader must dig them up. Whether anyone will make the time to go on this treasure hunt remains to be seen. [19 Feb 2009]



Date: 28 September 2008

The Teenagers Responsible - Are Bart Simpson, Who the Hell Are You?

Label: Rampart

Format: CDr EP

Source: Trevor

Cost: $0

Trevor made this 8 minute blast of stupidity by himself, and it's fucking amazing wonderful nonsense. It's so great to hear punk rock being made by people who never really listened to it. These five songs ask questions like 'Why Do You Think They Call it High School?' and 'What If You Got Tomorrow's Newspaper Today?' (which is totally the highlight). The fake band member names are also awesome (Scott Stovetop, Mel Hormel, Brian Boyardee and Scott Employment-History) and while this is probably mostly forgotten even by the guy who made it, I love it dearly. [29 December 2012]


Date: 28 September 2008

John Wiese & C. Spencer Yeh - New York / Atlanta

Label: Helicopter

Format: CD Album

Source: John Wiese

Cost: $5

NULL


Date: 28 September 2008

John Wiese - Teenage Hallucination: 1992-1999

Label: Troniks

Format: CD

Source: John Wiese

Cost: $5

With 52 tracks and almost 80 minutes, it's really incredibly difficult to make it through Teenage Hallucination: 1992-1999 in one go. But as a personal document, it's unsurpassed - and as quality 'noise' music, it's also remarkable. The sounds that come of this disc for the most part hurt my ears, at least at high volumes, yet they're crafted with a sense of purpose lacking in the majority of noise artists I've encountered. The liner notes are funny - the guy from Hijokaidan wrote something quite heartfelt about John's work, and then Seymour Glass contributes something surreal - but both remark on how solid and consistent Wiese has been his entire career. For a teenager to make noise this coherent is actually more incredible than it looks and his subsequent development of a kinetic, highly edit-based aesthetic follows from this. I can't confess to having made it all the way to track 52, but I deeply appreciate what's here. [31 December 2012]


Date: 29 September 2008

Ara - Pick Up and Run 2007

Label: What The ...

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Sara O'Keefe

Cost: $0

Sara's solo release - which I think has Trevor on it too - is an awesome pair of live recordings, showing her skills on saxophone and clarinet, with some electronic processing. It's spacious and recorded somewhat poorly, except that recording quality is so much part of it all. And also, that's MY saxophone here! Trevor, I guess, plays drums a bit on side two and it's always nice hearing two people who are so happy together making music. I don't know how prolific Sara's been since she has a child now but I hope there's more Ara in the pipeline. [5 Aug 2012]


Date: 29 September 2008

Palace Brothers - Days In the Wake

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Drag City mailorder

Cost: $10

I've never been completely fair to Will Oldham, often dismissing his more adventurous experiments even though had a different artist attempted such things, I would be more supportive. The man has certainly been virtuous, though maybe not consistent. Alex Neilson used to argue with me that this was the worst Oldham album and he couldn't understand why it was the only one I ever wanted to listen to - this was when he was playing drums for Oldham and inevitably having to learn how to play some of these tunes. Anyway, I go back to this one constantly because it's simplicity and honesty is what elevated it to classic status. Actually, I've been listening to all the records under the Palace monikers recently. This is a guy, sitting on his porch, playing his guitar and singing a perfect set of songs. Maybe 'I Send My Love To You' lacks the pathos or tragedy found in his more developed work, but it still brings me to my knees. The songs I used to skip over, like 'Come a Little Dog', are the ones I enjoy the most now, perhaps because I've worn them out less. When I sing along with 'I Am a Cinematographer', I feel a truth in the delivery that is rarely found in other artists's work. 1994 was the golden era for me, and I have no idea why I'm writing so defensively about this masterpiece. [13 August 2012]


Date: 29 September 2008

Palace Music - Viva Last Blues

Label: Palace Records

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Drag City mailorder

Cost: $14

Oldham's last great gasp as Palace, Viva Last Blues is a pretty complete picture of indie-country longing. It doesn't hold back from being strange or difficult, but at the same time has a full rock sound for most of it. This band, which features Jason Loewenstein from Sebadoh, is languid, yet crisp - this is probably the record that best captures that Palace 'band' feeling the way I idealise it. For all the encounters with death and having intercourse with mountains on here, I think Oldham is at his best when we can relate. 'New Partner' is the masterpiece, the song I've practically worn out of the vinyl; the ending acoustic songs are likewise masterful, a 90's updating of Big Star Third and a beautiful way to end. [6 December 2012]


Date: 29 September 2008

Smog - Julius Caesar

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Drag City mailorder

Cost: $10

This was the first Smog record I got into, and still my favourite. Actually it's just one of my favourite records.  It's the perfect bridge between the noisy, home-taping madness of his first records and the more mature, depressing acoustic work of his mid-period, and really the beginning of a series of masterpieces that runs through Wild Love and Doctor Came at Dawn.  The desperation is extreme and even teenage, but there's moments of a totally unique fractured beauty on songs like 'Your Wedding' and 'Chosen One'.  'A Lou Reed - Mistrial stick in the mud' is an amazing lyric, and while these songs are inherently hard to empathise with, I've really grown up with this record, ever since Mark Monakey dubbed it for me when I worked at the Carnegie Library in 1997.  [17 July 2011]


Date: 29 September 2008

Silver Jews - The Natural Bridge

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Drag City mailorder

Cost: $10

Stitch after stitch, I keep returning to The Natural Bridge. I first dubbed this from someone back in '96, when I was still in high school. I recorded it from my parents Dual turntable that played things slightly too fast, so the tape I committed to heart was always a tad higher-pitched than it should have sounded, which I didn't realise until years later. Over time this has risen to a very high place in my personal pantheon, along with Starlite Walker and American Water; it's silly to keep revising a 'favourite bands of all time' list but Silver Jews are certainly among them, top 5, top 3, whatever.


So writing about The Natural Bridge is more writing about how I grew up with this album; I've now spent half of my life with it. (Whoa.) Berman's indie-country mix is idiosyncratic and the power and meaning I've read into it says more about me than the music. To be honest, this record probably had a huge influence on my own sense of poetry and lyricism, along with other teenage touchstones like Neutral Milk Hotel; a difference is that I continually return to this while I've left most of the others behind, and there's something more direct and connective in the SJ lyrics than I get from, say, GbV (another artist I've listened to obsessively for the recent half of my life).


An advantage of more "honest" lyrics vs. surrealism is that as I get older (and subspace grows colder) there's more to connect with than ever. It's Leonard Cohen syndrome - these lyrics make more sense to me the older I get, as I've had my own experiences with love, loss, failure, misery and self-doubt. And Berman's lyrics aren't even that direct - I'm the one reading my own life story into 'little glowing cumbuckets in her ankles', after all - but this is the beauty of the country-fried indie aesthetic. It suggests a universalism, a familiarity, through it's motifs and tropes, even if it's manufactured. And this works for me. It's never struck me at any point that Berman's style is disingenuous - it seems logical, the necessary progression of righteousness from The Arizona Record onward.


I remember my first ever "girlfriend", Ailecia, putting 'Pet Politics' on a tape at the time - actually I think she titled her annual mixtape 'Pet Politics', which at the time was a song I tended to skip over. Now I crumble every time I listen to it; it's probably (along with 'We Are Real') my favourite Berman song ever, and there may never be a better opening line (or line, full stop) than "Guard my bed / while the rain turns the ditches to mirrors". Despite all of Berman's affectations and the one-liner style of his songwriting, his pleading repetition of 'Please guard my bed' at the end of this song is among the most emotionally powerful and connective things I've ever heard in rock music. And despite a few tracks that are less than perfect (which all three of these albums share), and all the dumb jokes (in 'The Frontier Index', actual straight-up jokes), and the use of session musicians instead of the Malkmus/Nastanovich core, The Natural Bridge as a whole is far, far greater than the sum of its parts.


The lost Malkmus/Bobby N sessions are probably the Holy Grail of indie rock for me, though I sort of hope I never hear them. I don't need The Natural Bridge to be any different than it is. I used to mishear the lyric "the way water drips" and "the way water drifts" which maybe was an improvement, but the imperfections are part of the magic. [9 November 2012]



Date: 29 September 2008

Silver Jews - American Water

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Drag City mailorder

Cost: $12

I loved The Natural Bridge and still do; when this follow-up was released (I remember hearing it at WPTS) I was really disappointed and dismissed it.  When I was living in Kentucky, seven years later, i went back to it and fell in love with it; I now consider it as solid as the other two in the great Triumvirate (with TNB and Starlite Walker).  Of course I was just listening to MP3s I've downloaded (which I've probably listened to a zillion times since 2005) so when I placed this much-overdue catchup order to Drag City, I ordered the whole triumvirate.  Listening now, probably the first time I've ever heard this album on vinyl, it sounds wonderful and full as only vinyl can sound.  If the story of the Silver Jews has been the slow progression from utter ramshackle madness to professional polish, then that would explain why I love these three albums - they're the perfect midpoint between those two extremes.  And actually, though this came after TNB it's actually (slightly) closer to the ramshackle side, probably due to Malkmus.  There's a new confidence that greatly benefits the material, and also this probably has the least filler of any Silver Jews album. 

The funny thing, with Berman, is how he can write these weird, almost jokey images that totally give the finger to all of my established ideas of good taste: puns, cracked metaphors, clichéd Americana .. and then, for some reason these lyrics often make me shiver, magically, rather than cringe in embarassment.  I feel like just quoting all of the brilliant lyrics on this record here, but it's not just the one-liners or the melodies - it's the overall feel, the rhythm and the way it can feel so fucking 'genuine' when someone sings a lyric like "and the NASCAR blurred into porn".  But it's not just those "clever" lyrics that affect me, for there are some classically beautiful songwriting moments here too: "The kids in the court are all covered in dirt / they were caught trespassing under the moon"; "I wrote a letter to a wildflower / on a classic nitrogen afternoon"; I'll stop now but the record is dripping with them.

Berman's America isn't really my America of course; it's the America I think I'm from.  And I don't live in either one at the moment, so it doesn't take much. The fact that I listened to this so much that summer of 2005, when I was finding my way through Kentucky and about to depart for the UK, indelibly binds this record to some "important" personal moment.  The Natural Bridge stuck with me too, of course, from my Senior year of high school to the present - the tape I dubbed from Rob Berthold's LP on my parents stereo, set to run just slightly too fast so I still find the actual album to be a bit slower than I got used to it ... but that's material for the review of that album.  But what I was getting at is that I am still so closely stuck to the music that I equate with nostalgic moments - Pavement, GBV, The Natural Bridge, His Name is Alive - those were the sounds of my life during those turbulent times of adolescence and University.  Those records have lyrical/conventional themes that, whatever they may actually mean, are easier to stick to than the predominantly abstract, experimental, and often non-Western or instrumental sounds that have dominated my life since college.  So of course I love what I love, but going into my late 20s theres certainly been less records I click with on that deep, emotional level for the above reasons (plus the general jadedness of being slightly older, plus the overall influx of every sound imaginable thanks to the Internet).  When I found American Water in 2005, it was easy because it was a band I already loved two other records by, and it stroked those same feelings that I never thought would be stroked again. (Berman's recent records sure ain't doing it). [3 Jan 2009]



Date: 29 September 2008

Silver Jews - Starlite Walker

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Drag City mailorder

Cost: $10

Starlite Walker is beautiful and ragged. It's balanced perfectly between the country-fried polish of The Natural Bridge and the anarchic sounds of The Arizona Record. Some of Berman's most free moments are here - 'Tide to the Oceans', and the mostly spoken 'Country Diary of a Subway Conductor'. But the genius is evident, even if it's sparse. Despite the millions of times I've listened to 'New Orleans' and 'Trains Across the Sea', it still stirs me; 'The Silver Pageant' is still simple instrumental magic to my ears. This is a cornerstone for me. [16 December 2012]


Date: 16 October 2008

Uton - We're Only In It For the Spirit

Label: Digitalis Industries

Format: CD

Source: Jani Hrvn

Cost: €0



Date: 17 October 2008

Quetzolcoatl - Where Are We Going Sister

Label: Ikuisuus

Format: CDr Album

Source: Jani

Cost: €0



Date: 17 October 2008

Muuttuvat Kasvot - 

Label: Ikuisuus

Format: CD-R Album

Source: Jani

Cost: €0



Date: 17 October 2008

Elektronavn - Songs of Impermanence

Label: Ikuisuus

Format: CDr Album

Source: Jani

Cost: €0

This is a re-release of some Icelandic solo project that I don't know anything about, and you can question the value of re-releasing something on a very limited CDr label, but the music is quite impressive so I see why Ikuisuus wanted to bring this to a larger audience. 'Loss/Grief/Perishableness' is the opening cut, which is 18 minutes of unfolding electroacoustic drone experimentation, very much in the genre that Ikuisuus releases often are (thinking here about Uton, Kulkija, things like that). It's beautifully rendered, with small bells and all acoustic sources, and some field recordings woven in as well. Track two, 'Impermanence/Emptiness', contains a lot of singing, essentially a 15 minute folk song built around a clean-channel electric guitar strum, with swirling organ drones around the high-pitched, backwards-sounding singing. It's beautiful, somehow tying together influences of  obscure singer-songwriter psychedelia and the contemporary underground dronescape. [24 July 2012]


Date: 18 October 2008

Uton & Valerio Cosi - Käärmeenkääntopiiri

Label: Fire Museum Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Jani

Cost: €0



Date: 21 October 2008

Richard Davies - There's Never Been a Crowd Like This

Label: Flydaddy

Format: CD

Source: eBay

Cost: $25.99

I bought this on eBay because it's the Japanese edition with bonus tracks, and I was so desperate to hear them.  I couldn't find them anywhere on Soulseek or blogs or the usual sources, so I started watching eBay for a CD, which I never do.  But let me tell you - it's completely worth it.  The booklet appears to be the standard Flydaddy booklet and the only mention of the bonus tracks comes from the little Japanese insert.  But I've never owned this album properly, so the lyric sheet alone is almost worth the $25 - it is the codex to unlocking the mysteries of these songs which I have misinterepreted for so long.  And the Japanese insert has lyrics for the bonus tracks, in English!!  But anyway, the bonus tracks!  The demo versions are largely acoustic, sung more clearly, and maybe a bit slower.  "Transcontinental" is every bit as awesome as the rocking version; "Chips Rafferty" has some nice piano tinkling.  "Topple into my Fantasy" suffers a bit without the plodding drums, but you can tell Davies composed it with space left for them. But the main reason I wanted this CD is for the live version of "Cars for Kings Cross".  It's hard to pick a favorite song from Instinct but this would probably be it.  Hearing a rough live version is great, even if it's kinda rough, kinda silly - the full band kicks in for the "riff" and it sounds kinda heavy metal.  It sounds like someone is singing backup in the band but they don't do the offset vocals on the "25 minutes down..." verse.  Still, I can only dream of seeing the Moles perform these songs live so this takes me a bit closer to my dream.  Oh yeah, there's also live version of 'Already in Black' and 'If You Believe in Christmas Trees' which makes me think these could be from live Cardinal gigs, and maybe that is Matthews singing backup.  The 'Already in Black' is thrashy as hell with some screaming, barking lyrics - a rocking side of the Moles that doesn't really come across on record.  Davies sings so deep on 'Christmas Trees' that maybe it actually is Mathews, I dunno.  His trademark accent sounds buried.  I don't know what I've done to frighten everyone.  For the coda, the "Should I really say..." part, the drums drop out and it's just sung over strummed electric guitar, which works really well in the live band context.  Now I just need a copy of Instinct - I've been waiting for vinyl, but that may be impossible to find, so I should probably just get the CD.  I should also write one of those 33 1/3 series books about that album.  Anyway, the album is already amazing and brilliant and these bonus tracks are pretty much better than I could have hoped for, so i can be buried happy.


Date: 26 November 2008

Daniel Padden - Pause For The Jet

Label: Dekorder

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Daniel

Cost: €0

Daniel's last solo record, I think, though I haven't really kept up, was recorded when I lived in Glasgow with him - or at least around the time I lived with him. I listen to this and feel a strong similarity to this and the music I was making at the time, which isn't surprising. With Daniel's there's different instrumentation and a reliance on vocal manoeuvres that I'd never have, but I think we both have really similar approaches. It's funny also listening to the instrumentation here that I remember just lying around the kitchen, etc. There's a less discordant, more folky feel than The Isaac Storm which I think suits the labels appropriately. The empty sketches here - by which I mean the melodic fragments that begin and end without figuring themselves out - are actually some of my favourite parts. It ends with a different version of 'English Again', the little tune at the beginning the first One Ensemble CD from way back when. I think Daniel knocks out these solo albums to let off steam and doesn't consider them as 'important' as the One Ensemble releases, but I actually might prefer them in ways. There's a lot of gestures here - the scrapes between tracks, pure atmospheres, and of course the fragmentary nature - that are right up my alley. [27 July 2012]


Date: 29 November 2008

Cause Co-Motion - Which Way Is Up?

Label: What's Your Rupture?

Format: Vinyl 7"

Source: Monoral

Cost: €0

A blast of neo-punk fun, 'Which Way is Up?' has energetic guitars, earnest vocals, and it's over in an eyeblink. 'Falling Again' is slightly longer but no less lively. These guys remind me a bit of Eat Skull, particularly in the vocal affect, though in a cleaner and more direct manner. [28 July 2012]


Date: 29 November 2008

Cause Co-Motion! - I Lie Awake

Label: Slumberland Records

Format: Vinyl 7" Single

Source: Monorail

Cost: €0

'I Lie Awake' is a perfect little song, with an upbeat, driving rhythm, and brittle guitar hooks around the low-mixed, amateurish vocals. It's over in a heartbeat, but it leaves me wanting more. There's two equally brief songs on the B-side, the latter of which hangs on big guitar chords and open, plodding basslines. Cause Co-Motion so perfectly balance the simple with strong pop song construction - they're probably much more aware of what they are doing then they let one. At times I think of a less 'punk' Eat Skull, but that's probably cause both remind me of early Flying Nun bands so much. [10 December 2012]


Date: 29 November 2008

Pink Reason - Winona

Label: Woodsist

Format: 7"

Source: Monorail

Cost: £4

I always forget about this 7" but it's the best Pink Reason release outside of the first LP (oh, and also 'Down On Me' which is an awesome song). 'Winona' is a miserable, slow, quiet downer folk tune. 'Give Yerself Away' is a strummy, somewhat tuneless song and 'Letting Go' has a bluesy edge. This is probably the most depressed Pink Reason release, even moreso than Cleaning the Mirror, and that's why I like it. [1 August 2012]


Date: 29 November 2008

Jay Reatard - Blood Visions

Label: In The Red Recordings

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Monorail

Cost: £11.99

This may sound silly, and maybe I will regret writing these words in ten years, but I think Blood Visions belongs in any "top 5 punk rock records of all time" list ( that is inevitably made by list-type music fans). I try so hard to not be one of those fans yet I'm constantly saying that such and such is my favourite album or song by an artist. I got into this record during the end of my Glasgow residency and don't you know, it made me feel young again. But that's not all - this is timeless, amazing music that can communicate to a 14 year old and also to a 32 year old who was once 14. While I hear so much contemporary music now and feel completely old and dated, this speaks to every bit of me still. I listened to the shit out of this around the time I moved to Helsinki, which culminated in the last live concert I've attended where I jumped up and down, sang along, and knew all the words. I guess I was 28 then and when he played 'My Shadow' I thought I was going to explode into a ball of fiery excitement. I feel no sympathy for Mr. Reatard and I didn't even really care much for the rest of his output; well, the two singles collections hold up pretty well but the last album was weak and I already stopped thinking about him. But pulling this out now, it's hard not to crank it and jump up and down and get excited. As juvenile as 'Greed, Money, Useless Children' may sound on paper, it still means something to me, even if there are a lot of layers. And there's such an incredibly appreciation of great 60's pop and mod music in his songwriting that you can't get hooks like "Oh/It's such/a shame" out of your head, or "I/keep searching for you". Simplicity wins in the end and this will endure forever, far longer than Mr. Reatard's own time on this earth. [1 December 2012]


Date: 29 November 2008

Blank Dogs - On Two Sides

Label: Troubleman Unlimited

Format: LP

Source: Monorail

Cost: £9.99

I've listened to this Blank Dogs record a lot over the past few years but it's always been a sort of 'easy listening' for me. The dark, edgy bedroom post-punk sound was very much in my radar back in 2008, though Blank Dogs is much more influenced by artists like Magazine, whereas Cheveu (for example) have a much more manic and experimental edge. There are great tunes here - 'The Crystal Ladies' for example, has a sort of earnestness that I don't hear much elsewhere on the record - but I never kept up with his prolific output. It's not a pure retro exercise - the recording, while fairly lo-fi, sounds contemporary - nothing made in 1980 would have had this mood exactly. But I can't quite articulate why this is. Sometimes the casio-beat percussion is really driving and I will get lost in the back-and-forth monotony; credit where it's due to this guy for using cheap instrumentation very very well. [27 November 2012]


Date: 21 January 2009

Broadcast - Tender Buttons

Label: Warp Records

Format: CD Album

Source: Warp

Cost: €0

I bought a copy of this last year at Monorail but the CD was defective; I finally emailed Warp about it and they graciously sent me a replacement.  Thanks! [2009]  Broadcast are one of those bands that's grown, over time, to become a favourite of mine, but sort of accidentally.  I've always liked them - back to high school/early college, with Work and Non-Work and then The Noise Made by People which Caleb and I used to jam a ton back in the college days.  The thing is, I never really remember to think about them and their music always felt slightly disposable to me - just because it never wedged into my brain and I never learned the words and I never made a personal meaninful connection to it.  But somehow, that has to change.  Tender Buttons is probably the one that will do it for me too.  I just totally love this fucking record.  It's solid, and concise - short, pop-based songs that do all the Broadcast things, just really well.  It's nice to actually have the CD booklet because the lyrics are presented in a scattered, slipshod way but it totally works.  There's just the right balance of sketchy abstractness and conveyed meaning in these words, and the music is somehow clean, futuristic and archaic all at once.  There's a few standout tracks - 'Black Cat', 'Tears in the Typing Pool', 'Michael a Grammar' - but I've never overall fixated on particular songs, just the overall feel of the album.  But I think this listen tonight, which has got me in a perfect mood, has me determined to sink deeper into Broadcast's ouvre (a difficult task being that I feel overwhelmed by all the other things I have to listen to).  Ultimately, Tender Buttons makes me want to start writing pop songs again myself; that something created inspiration is probably one of the best endorsements it can get.  [27 April 2010]



Date: 26 January 2009

Vernon and Burns - Sing it Softly to the Pebbles

Label: Meagre Resource

Format: CD

Source: Barry Burns

Cost: €0

This is the soundtrack to an exhibition at the CCA that happened after I left Glasgow but i wish I had seen it.  Here, instead of Mark and Barry doing their usual cut-up/vaudeville/dada weirdness they work with other musicians - Sarah Kenchington, Katy Dove, and Belinda Gilbert Scott.  The whole album is a story, narrated by Wendy Woolfson, and while I didn't follow the text closely, it has a fairy-tale like, dreamy feel.  The music consists of quiet abstractions, using a lot of bells and chimes.  Any unusual sound sources are so well integrated into the overall vibe that they don't feel weird or anything - just like it's part of a coherent whole.  I assume Mark and Barry cut up the recordings quite a bit and reassembled them, but it feels a million miles away from the stuff we did with them.  It's a really unified vision, and quite restrained for them (but really great that they are working with other people, and really letting them shine).  The last track, a bonus track, is a more typical Boy Band Tax Returns-sounding mishmash but it's good too.  [11 Feb 2009]



Date: 25 February 2009

Pengo - Counterfeit Memories

Label: Nashazphone

Format: Vinyl

Source: Hicham Chadly

Cost: €0

Ah, Pengo.  Such a brilliant live band - a feeling I'm sure is echoed by anyone who has ever witnessed them.  Yet I've never heard a recording that captures their energy and inventiveness.  This is a solid Pengo record, but sadly, still falls into the void of disappointing records.  This is a really repetetive stomper, which only lets up the gas at the end with some beautiful fragmented piano sounds, and it's not unlike the set I saw them play in my house when I first moved to Kentucky.  If I had never seen them I may think more highly of this - or perhaps I would think less, thinking they were another free noise-rock band.  It's a beautiful package and I'm glad Hicham is putting out LPs and I will probably listen to this more and learn to love it, but for now, it's just another good but not great Pengo LP.  [4 Mar 2009]



Date: 7 April 2009

Kulkija - Autio Valo

Label: no label

Format: cassette

Source: Jari-Pekka

Cost: €3



Date: 10 April 2009

Eugene Chadbourne - Country Music In The World Of Islam

Label: Fundamental

Format: CD

Source: Flipside Records, Athens

Cost: €18

What a collaboration - Eugene Chadbourne backed by Sun City Girls, plus Elliot Sharp and artwork by Matt Groening!  And it's falsely attributed to Alan Lomax as well.   I like Chadbourne a lot (I think Shockabilly is a great, underrated band) and this is him without any restraints.  The songs are goofy, he sings on them all, and there's some scorching banjo playing, weird Torch of the Mystics-style electric guitar solos by Rick Bishop, and some open, improvised parts that sound mesmerising for a bit (before lurching back into the goofball rock mode).  A lot of Bishop's guitar parts are recorded in a hard/heavy rock style, though distant in the mix, almost feeling like a mockery of grunge.  Some traditional stuff like 'I Cover the Waterfront' sounds occasionally very beautiful despite mashed keyboard chords and radio voice interference; the political stuff like 'Hippies and Cops' or 'Don't Burn the Flag, Let's Burn the Bush' gives me a real idea of what it musta been like to be a politically cognizant goofball artist in the late 80s.  The sillyness of this will probably turn a lot of people off which is a shame cause SCG + Chadbourne is really a match made in heaven and this certainly stands with the best gonzo SCG records like Horse Cock Phepner.  [22 July 2009]



Date: 10 April 2009

Judy Henske and Jerry Yester - Farewell Aldebaran

Label: Radioactive

Format: Vinyl

Source: Flipside Records, Athens

Cost: €20

This record may be in my all-time top ten - certainly among the scores of "lost psych classics" that have surfaced over the past few years, this is the cream of the crop.  This is a nice 180g vinyl reissue of questionable legitimacy, but I'm just happy to have it.  It doesn't sound amazing - I could hear a bit of distortion in 'Lullaby', though my stylus and the vinyl looked perfectly clean.  But, again, I'll take it - the bootleg MP3s I listened to for years were even shittier sounding, and the end of 'St. Nicholas Hall' actually cut off.  So, what to say about this record, apart from the fact that all fans of creative, catchy psychedelic music should hear this?  Judy Henske wrote all of the lyrics and Jerry Yester wrote all of the music (and I think plays every instrument, cause there's no other credits here), and the partnership is magical.  The gatefold has a wonderfully disgusting paisley background but prints the lyrics in a somewhat unreadable font, and it's awesome to be able to read these strange, beautiful songs, which work as poetry without the tunes.  But what tunes they are!  'Lullaby' begins with the premise that "The end of the world is a windy place," and Henske tends towards apocalyptic imagery in the best possible way - shaking off any vestiges of 60's hippiedom for a more strident vision.  'Farewell Alderbaran' is a dark, intense paen to a comet; 'Rapture' and 'Three Ravens' are beautiful yet with a powerful gravitas to them.  The only dud on the whole record is 'Mrs. Connor', aka 'One More Time', sung by Yester, but it's not even that bad.  And it's wedged between the AMAZING 'Raider' and 'Rapture', so it's a pardonable offense; blink and you miss it.  What else can I say?  'Snowblind' is dark psych with a pounding, funky evil edge; 'Horses on a Stick' is infectious bubblegum, and 'St. Nicholas Hall' is such a brilliant, epic fucking song I don't even know what justice I can do it with my words.  It's funny that I'm only getting around to reviewing this now because about 3 years ago I was completely obsessed with it and listened to it every day.  Now, it's like a familiar friend, but it never stops sounding amazing.  This is one of the most essential documents of American rock music in the 1960s, if not the most essential; any of you other agents who might be reading this should go out and buy this now, as I give it the highest possible recommendation.  [9 July 2010]



Date: 10 April 2009

Third Ear Band - Alchemy

Label: Drop Out Records (2)

Format: Vinyl

Source: Flipside Records, Athens

Cost: €17

Whatever these guys were motivated by, it's really something unique - a druid jam, maybe, but also undeniably lush and beautiful. Alchemy has some really amazing fiddle playing, especially on 'Ghetto Raga'. The clarinets or cor anglaises or whatever they are are perfect - I think I am still realy open to this medieval, English kind of sound when it's got these 20th century classical overtones - more moody and felt out, and less based around folk singing. I should really get to know the rest of their catalogue, which I currently only have Macbeth from. [6 May 2012]


Date: 11 April 2009

Reverse Mouth - Pearl Hidden In Pigslot

Label: Phase! Records

Format: CDr

Source: Panagiotis Spoulos

Cost: €0



Date: 11 April 2009

The Countlet - Mesopotamia Blues From the Armless Men

Label: Phase!

Format: CDr

Source: Panagiotis Spoulos

Cost: €0



Date: 11 April 2009

Placenta Popeye / Reverse Mouth - split

Label: Absurd / Phase! / Tanzprocesz

Format: 7"

Source: Panagiotis Spoulos

Cost: €0



Date: 11 April 2009

V/A - Induced Musical Spasticity: Buttecounty Free Music Society Twenty Fifth Anniversary (1984-2009)

Label: Private

Format: 4xLP box set + CD

Source: A Strange Attractor, Athens

Cost: €70



Date: 13 April 2009

Sun Ra - Nothing Is...

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl

Source: Crossroad, Athens

Cost: €8.5

Bought this picture disc a few years ago in Greece even though I already had an ESP original. I gave this a spin and it sounds pretty good, though I'm not sure if it's been remastered. The long piece at the end of side 1, 'Exotic Forest', is a Marshall Allen show-off piece with a nice funky sway to it. I dig it, lots; and the on the flip you have a track titled 'Sun Ra and His Band from Outer Space', which I guess is to them what 'Queen of the Ryche' was to Queensryche. Totally great and essential, and I certainly don't need to have two copies of it, but I suppose I'll keep 'em. [4 March 2012]


Date: 13 April 2009

Sun Ra - The Heliocentric Worlds Of Sun Ra, Vol. II

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl

Source: Crossroad, Athens

Cost: €8.5

The Heliocentric Worlds of Sun Ra, Vol. II spreads across three tracks, all around very open structures. The opening cut starts off with a somber bowed double bass movement, but once the band comes in there's all manner of cascading chaos. This is a great example of Sun Ra's distinct approach to avant-garde jazz - it's not easy to categorise, as it's miles away from NYC loft blow-out stuff but then far more visceral and psychedelic than something Roscoe Mitchell or Anthony Braxton would compose. Great artwork too, which puts Sun Ra alongside astronomer greats like Galileo and Brahe. [2 Aug 2012]


Date: 13 April 2009

Esa Pethman - The Modern Sound Of Finland - The Music Of Esa Pethman

Label: Warner Music (Finland)

Format: Vinyl

Source: Crossroad, Athens

Cost: €6.9

Dull. Sold.


Date: 13 April 2009

Kevin Coyne - Case History

Label: Tapestry

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Crossroad, Athens

Cost: €21.2

I've always wanted to hear Kevin Coyne's debut album, which was thankfully reissued on 180g vinyl. This is entirely stripped down, almost all acoustic (or acoustic + electric/steel guitar leads), which is the side of Kevin Coyne I like, or even love.  After one listen I think this might be a classic - the album felt really consistent, with little filler, and a hint of derangements in the vocals and the strumming (as Coyne wrote these songs directly relating the experiences of the mental patients he worked with).  The guitar playing manages to be bluesy, yet ramshackle, and conveys a desperation that is really genuine and empathetic.  With Marjory Razorblade, I think I might really love Kevin Coyne so maybe I should start delving into the later albums.  [19 Apr 2009]



Date: 13 April 2009

Venom - Black Metal

Label: Earmark

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Crossroad, Athens

Cost: €7.5

I grabbed this cause it felt iconic and worth having, and cheap, but when do I ever want to listen to it? I think if the entire musical genre of 'metal' disappeared from existence then my life wouldn't really be affected. My life at age 13, sure, but nothing that i love and connect to in music now is particularly metal influenced. Even my appreciation for artists such as Celtic Frost, Slayer or Venom is just that - a part-time appreciation that I could really live without. What I even know about metal is just due to the friends I had growing up in Pittsburgh the general meathead culture of the music scene - I learned to appreciate things about it. But now, listening to 'Black Metal', it just sounds so fucking stupid. 'Lay down your soul to the gods of rock and roll', sure - I'll take the stupidity of druggy psych-outsiders instead. This is a nice remaster though on clear vinyl with bonus tracks which I also don't care about. [20 December 2012]


Date: 13 April 2009

John Phillips - John, the Wolf King of LA

Label: Harte

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Crossroad, Athens

Cost: €19.8

I bought this a few years ago in Athens and then soon after the story came out where Phillips allegedly fucked his daughter and drugged her senseless with coke and heroin. Maybe it's because of that reason that I never even took the shrinkwrap off this, or maybe it's just because I forgot. Either way, I decided to ignore that potentially horribly story and give this a spin, the first time I've heard it in a few years, and I really really loved it. I've been really interested in this type of country music lately, where it's coming out of the 60s hangover and into a new expression of American myth. There's some great, great songs on here, like 'Drum' and 'Down the Beach', and it's really the group effort that makes it. The band is tight, there's some great piano playing on it, and the backing vocals are just right so it doesn't feel like the Mamas and Papas but really closer to the Flying Burrito Brothers. On 'Mississippi', Phillips sounds like Loaded-era Lou Reed, and it's an awesome tune. Closer 'Holland Tunnel' is a road trip epic, and also mentions Pittsburgh so I gotta give it up for that. Totally great, and I'm gonna spin this a lot and try to forget about the rapeyness. [4 March 2012]


Date: 13 April 2009

Jon Appleton and Don Cherry - Human Music

Label: Flying Dutchman

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Crossroad, Athens

Cost: €13.3

This pairing of Cherry and Appleton is incredibly exploratory experimental synth with Cherry's ethnomusical touches, as well as some voice. The two have a great sense of play, and even though Appleton's aesthetic is seemingly miles away from Cherry's earthbeat, they interact with each other to the point of total mind-meld. The sounds here are sparse, which really lets them breathe, and in some ways it suits Cherry's work around this time, particularly his Swedish period. It's not always clear what is electronic and what is a little whistle or other noisemaker, such is the recording. The only drag is that the hole is cut too small to fit over the turntable spindle, so I actually have to screw it in place, and then it's really hard to remove without almost breaking the record. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 13 April 2009

Comus - First Utterance

Label: Earmark

Format: Vinyl

Source: Crossroad, Athens

Cost: €17

The ultimate Satanic folk classic on thick 180gram vinyl, mastered well by Earmark and in a beautiful glossy gatefold. Nothing more to say here - I listen to this surprisingly frequetly, as 'The Herald' is among the loveliest use of the female voice in all of music. That the songs are about dragging Christians into the woods and beating them to death is neither here nor there, or maybe it increases the greatness of this. Comes with a bonus 12" that I listened to once but don't really care about. [9 October 2012]


Date: 13 April 2009

Area - Caution Radiation Area

Label: Get Back

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Crossroad, Athens

Cost: €11.9

This was the first Area record I ever heard, in Aaron Moore's bedroom many years ago (in Leicester), and I guess the first Italian prog I'd ever heard too.  When I scooped up all the Area LPs from Ross a few years back, he didn't have this one so it's always been the one hole in my collection, and I remembered it being totally amazing but maybe that's just because I hadn't heard it.  I didn't hesitate to grab this vinyl reissue, lovingly preserved by fellow countrymen Get Back.  it's pressed on thick 180gram vinyl with full artwork reproductions and even the original Cramps label (with a tiny Get Back icon appended).  This album is the second Area record, where they start to get much more 'out' than Arbeit Macht Frei.  There are some astounding proggy riff-fests, but the more experimental moments are the most interesting.  Some tracks sound like Throbbing Gristle, though I think it's best when they merge the rock with the other sounds.  The last track is really beautiful, consisting of layers of sculpted hissing and metallic drones, and it's a nice counterpoint to the amped-up energy that fills most of the rest of the album.  [15 April 2009]



Date: 13 April 2009

Embarker - Needlebank

Label: Phase!

Format: cassette

Source: Panagiotis Spoulos

Cost: €0

Embarker is another harsh noise project that I can't tell you much about except that someone I know released something by them. It's perfectly succinct, blasting a blend of squealing harsh electronics across 15 or 20 minutes max. I don't mind it, but I don't know what will ever possess me to listen to it again - but harsh electronic noise is a genre that I don't like nearly as much as the number of recordings I own in it would suggest. [24 September 2012]


Date: 13 April 2009

Antler Piss - Body Jar

Label: Phase! Records

Format: Cassette

Source: Panagiotis Spoulos

Cost: €0



Date: 13 April 2009

Reverse Mouth - Brussels / Tienen

Label: Phase!

Format: cassette

Source: Panagiotis Spoulos

Cost: €0



Date: 13 April 2009

Slicing Grandpa - Lauxapalooza

Label: Phase!

Format: CDr

Source: Panagiotis Spoulos

Cost: €0



Date: 13 April 2009

Panagiotis Spoulos - Loops Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Label: Editions Zero

Format: CDr

Source: Panagiotis Spoulos

Cost: €0



Date: 13 April 2009

Reverse Mouth - Black Bimbo

Label: Rumor

Format: Cassette

Source: Panagiotis Spoulos

Cost: €0

Hand-numbered, this is 49 out of 50 so how lucky to have it! Actually, while I like Reverse Mouth, this is a fairly rote noise tape that fails to distinguish itself from the pack. Side one's 'Animal Martyr' is low, and grinding; 'Yo Bobby' answers it by being midrange and drony, with occasional high-pitched squeals. The flipside, 'Thin Crisp', is an ode to a cracker, I guess. It's long and gets into navel gazing loops that are uneven and appropriately irritating, but without sharp edges. [7 Aug 2012]


Date: 15 April 2009

The Dead C - DR503 / The Sun Stabbed EP

Label: Ba Da Bing! / Jagjaguwar

Format: 2xLP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £10

A year ago I bought the reissues of these first two Dead C albums, but I haven't really listened to them.  They've gotten enough play off my old CD copies, though there's something pretty magical about hearing it on vinyl - especially with all that cassette hiss poking through.  This earliest Dead C stuff amazes me because of how fully-formed of a rock band they are.  There's a hell of a lot of dour atmosphere but this is an expressive, lyrical band working out of the same place that This Kind of Punishment came from.  When I listen to something like 'The Wheel' it's great how Russell is just fucking around and eveything is detuned, but it's not lazy or casual.  It wouldn't be much of an exaggeration to say that these records changed music forever, at least for a lot of important people.  A nice pressing and nice packaging is enough to make me happy, but I don't think i'll ever get rid of the CD since it's the sequence I'm more used to. [29 April 2010]



Date: 15 April 2009

The Dead C - Eusa Kills / Helen Said This

Label: Ba Da Bing! / Jagjaguwar

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £10

I keep finding myself unable to write anything about records that are such classics, like this one.  Eusa Kills is so perfect and what's really great is that the Dead C never repeated themselves - it's the only one of their albums anything like this, really - even DR503 has a totally different feel. These are the pretzels of exile. This is a vinyl reissue, though I'm not getting rid of my CD anytime soon. Like all these Ba Da Bing! issues, it's really well done, with absolutely beautiful thick slabs of wax. 'Now I Fall' has never sounded more warped. The second platter puts 'Helen Said This' on 12" with 'Bury' -- what more could we ask for? [1 Aug 2012]


Date: 21 April 2009

Religious Knives - In Brooklyn After Dark / The Hand

Label: Troubleman Unlimited

Format: Vinyl

Source: Maya Bernstein

Cost: €0

'In Brooklyn After Dark' is a stomping rocker, a good choice for this to be a single (which I guess this is - a 12" single at 33RPM) with fun thrashing about and then a great thick organ ending. The b-side starts where the a-side left off - from the organ, and builds up some Charlemagne Palestine-like drones over which we hear some tape experimentation or other found sounds. It's very brief though, and I wonder why this wasn't a 7" or 10" or released at all, though it's great so I'm glad it was. [8 November 2012]


Date: 21 April 2009

Religious Knives - Evidence volume 1

Label: no label

Format: CDr

Source: Maya Bernstein

Cost: €0



Date: 21 April 2009

Religious Knives - Evidence volume 2

Label: no label

Format: CDr

Source: Maya Bernstein

Cost: €0



Date: 21 April 2009

Insayngel - 

Label: Heavy Tapes

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Maya Bernstein

Cost: €0

This is a band that the Bernsteins put out an LP for a few years ago and I never heard about again. I see now that Jon Lockie is the drummer, who I didn't know at the time I got this, but have since made his acquaintance. This is total NYC noise-rock, crouching fetally around a ungraspable bucket of scuzz. Howling vocals, distorted guitar shards, and Beefheartian drumming makes me think a bit of the Cro-Magnon LP, and weirdly, a bit of Savage Republic as well. The rhythms are here, sometimes overlapping, and there's a truly soaring, reach-for-the-stars energy despite the illogical construction of it all.The last track is the most diverse, with some really slow and grinding parts and a sparse desolate feel. Pretty good. [7 Aug 2012]


Date: 21 April 2009

Religious Knives - It's After Dark

Label: Troubleman Unlimited

Format: Vinyl

Source: Maya Bernstein

Cost: €0

The full length Religious Knives LP begins with the same fun stomper on the 12", 'In Brooklyn After Dark'. It's after this where things get really interesting - 'The Streets' featured creepy duet vocals over a looped rhythm and a lot of echo, recalling cult-psych touchstones while situating itself in a distinct atmosphere. This is well-recorded but not overproduced, hitting a perfect balance. The long songs are nice because they allow ideas to develop without being overly jammy. 'The Sun' brings in some electric piano and wind chimes, sounding mellow despite the stark vocal delivery. 'Noontimes' ends things on an hypnotic drone-jam, slowly plodding along with swirly organ and searing horn intrusions. This was already six years ago which is another crazy thing about time passing, cause it feels like yesterday. [6 December 2012]


Date: 23 April 2009

Shadow Ring - Life Review (1993-2003)

Label: Kye

Format: CD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15

I try not to buy CDs but this was impossible to pass up. The Shadow Ring were probably the "last" epiphany I've had with music - I suspect that now I'm too old and jaded (and it's too easy to hear everything immediately) for a similar feeling to come around. 1993-2003 is almost a perfect time period to commemorate because this was the last decade that something like the Shadow Ring could be possible, if that makes any sense. I don't know how else to articulate this without sounding stupid, but the Internet era, while bringing us access to vast amounts of riches, has also removed much of the mystery of isolation that drew me to such weird and outside sounds. I am putting my own personal background and feelings here, and I hope that kids today can still feel like they are discovering a secret world, but I have my doubts. Anyway, this band was a lifechanger for sure - and this is a perfect summation of what they did, carefully assembled in a way that combines some of their greatest 'hits' with obscurities, unreleased tracks, and live material. So you get 'Arthuring Tina' but then you also get a live jam on Pink Floyd's 'Interstellar Overdrive'. I'm glad they kept this straight - the sequencing is purely chronological, so disc 1 begins with the primitive clatter, mostly acoustic; disc 2 ends with total abstraction, the Im Some Songs level of dark conceptualism. In some ways you can say they developed as much as a band like Wire did, though i guess ten years is a long time. For a band so pivotal to me, I mostly know their work through mp3s I've downloaded (see?) so I don't actually have any of this stuff on physical media except a few tracks on disc 2. I brought this with me last year to the Estonian National Museum in Tartu when I actually ran a little seminar/talk about Graham Lambkin and the Shadow Ring; I think I played 'Wallet of Wasps' and then 'The Riverside' to a room of interested people, and thought how insane it was that I could be able to do that. The booklet is almost all photos, of the releases and of the band throughout their years - this is presented honestly, really managing to demystify a band whose music is so strange and amazing, yet who seem (from the photos) to just be regular beer-drinking blokes, albeit intensely creative ones from Folkestone. I'm so glad to have this, though it's already getting a bit beaten up, and I will still try to eventually track down all of the original vinyl releases. The lyrics to 'Put the Music in Its Coffin'  are printed inside but nothing else, suggesting this as some sort of thematic identity - it certainly is a poetic masterpiece. The live version of 'Hold Onto I.D' is from the gig at the Oakland Beehive on 16 September 1997, which my band with Weird Paul was asked to open up at - we had to decline because Paul had oral surgery that day. I didn't even go to the show because I was stupid, and I've been kicking myself ever since. Now I can at least hear what I missed. [23 August 2012]


Date: 23 April 2009

Axemen - Big Cheap Motel

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15

Siltbreeze is bringing some of the Axemen's gems to wider consumption and this former cassette release is incredibly fun. Most of Big Cheap Motel is live, a concert where they wrote a bunch of songs to protest the company who sponsored the concert because of sexist advertising. They are tackling gender issues here in an irreverent yet passionate way, and the musicianship is absolutely random. This is a snarling document for those who see the streak of genius in amateurism, and I'm certainly one of those. Despite the chaos, this is a band with a vision, and the pointed lyrics about desire, bodies and attitudes are inspiring in a weird way, even if there's something teenage about it all. Maybe I like this record so much because it's fun, first and foremost, and it's from New Zealand after all. [1 December 2012]


Date: 23 April 2009

Bachs - Out Of The Bachs

Label: Void Records 

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15

Hooray for vinyl reissues again, because I can own this for about $2000 less than it was previously selling for. This issue on Void records feels like a bootleg but the sound is pretty great (despite what any authority such as The Acid Archives might claim) and with a record as classic as this, you want it to sound great. This greatness is actually a distant, far-away sound due to the amateurish recording, amateurish performance, and total 60's sound. A few of these songs are just incredible to behold in all of their power and naievete - 'Tables of Grass Fields', and 'Answer to Yesterday', and of course 'Minister to a Mind Diseased'. But every song is great and this is one of those perfect treasures that thankfully can reach the audience it deserves. [18 August 2012]


Date: 23 April 2009

Gol / Ana-Marie Avram / Iancu Dumitrescu - Musique Directe

Label: Planam

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15

The French group Gol consists for four electro-acoustic improvisers who open up the space between quiet gestures and otherworldly electronic elements.
