They are joined here by Ana-Maria Avram and Iancu Dumitrescu on most tracks, though these guests (even when playing 'straight' instruments like violin or piano frame) don't distinguish themselves from Gol's regular sound; it's a total group feel, a cohesive element that outputs as such a low level it's a quiet listen even on nice thick vinyl. There are very electronic moments - sine waves, rolling frequencies hitting against ringing percussion or other small objects - and the complete effect is somewhat mesmerising. [28 November 2012]


Date: 5 May 2009

John Wiese & C. Spencer Yeh - Cincinnati

Label: Dronedisco

Format: CD

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

My own time spent in Cincinnati with Spencer (and sometimes with Wiese) gives this place an almost mystical significance - certainly the place names these tracks are named after recall many memories of my mid-20s, which I get nostalgic for. But this should be about the music, which is excellent. These two have such a strong relationship that they are able to push each other into new territories; the physical volatility of Spencer's music is great against Wiese's careful precision. "Weekend Pass" might be the best example of this - it teeters on points, has lots of emptyness, and yet is still incredibly boundary-pushing.  A lot of electronics or what I suspect are electronically-processed voice tracks, so overall this feels somewhat clean; the more organic, room sounds ('Skyline', which I dream was recorded in a Skyline Chili but I'm sure it wasn't) contrast here and there to balance the disc as a whole. It all ends with 'Stettinius' which is as elegiac as appropriate given the subject matter. [25 December 2012]


Date: 5 May 2009

C. Spencer Yeh - New York Nuts & Boston Beans

Label: Important Records (2)

Format: CD

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0



Date: 5 May 2009

C. Spencer Yeh & Sick Llama - Split

Label: Arbor

Format: 7"

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

Spencer's side is more solo violin improvisation, where the recording and presentation is half of the magic. This moves (very quickly) between dictaphone muffle to possibly processed electroacoustic squalor. The violin playing is manic, arco and pizzicato at once. Sick Llama's side is more washed over drone/fuzz, with pulsing electric interference disguising what little motion there is. It's difficult abstraction, and when it gets more active it's still within very confined boundaries. [10 December 2012]


Date: 5 May 2009

Justin Lieberman & C. Spencer Yeh - Object Lessons

Label: Dronedisco

Format: VInyl LP Album

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

It's safe to say that this collaboration is a far different beast than anything Spencer has ever done before.  The musical segments are recognisable as his work, but the editing style tends to be dominated by Lieberman's channel-flipping glossolalia.  This is some amazing stuff though: a vibe that isn't really like anything I've experienced in waking life, except for all those moments in which I am awake.  Lieberman's taunting voice starts to develop a familiarity and though this is far more 'out' than most other music (most other music, full stop) it appeals to the part of me that appreciates the spoken work record as art form.  I think this is a record I will probably play hundreds of times, learning it's chasms and nuances.  And I'm really psyched that Spencer's branched out into this area because I think possibly his most interesting images are on thie record.



Date: 5 May 2009

C. Spencer Yeh - Songs 2002

Label: What The...? Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

This 3 song, 1-sided 12" collects three fairly straight, conventional songs (at least for Spencer) from around 2002.  This stuff is pretty heavy and it hits me hard since it was right after I met Spencer that he did this stuff (though I never heard it before).  'The Butter Day' reminds me a lot of Smog, with it's stark, narrative voice and detached guitars.  'Lose Air / Flip Backwards' takes on a more 4AD quality, atmospheric yet lyrical, with some screaming, bent guitars smothered by the structure of the song itself.  'Remember' is doused in bitterness but strangely calm; it's great to hear this really personal material be release, even if it's only going to be 135 copies.  I can hear the birth of Stettinius Tavern in these songs and maybe, simultaneously, the death of it.



Date: 5 May 2009

Matt Wellins / Zach Wallace - split

Label: What The...?

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

Matt's track is something that I've been a fan of for years, so it's awesome that Spencer has pressed in onto vinyl.  It sounds great - the cool sound of sax and laptop floats right off the surface of this (1-sided) LP.  The Zach Wallace track is a good pairing, as it's similarly satiny, yet even more chilled out - it would be totally conceivable that these are both the same artist.  I wish Matt would put out more stuff but I guess he's a victim of the same bottlenecks that I've been victim to, namely, our own neuroses.



Date: 5 May 2009

Cometa Fever - Dead Light

Label: What The ... ?

Format: 1-sided vinyl EP

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

I don't know where Spencer found these guys - it's an Italian duo that makes moody, dense pop of which the Jesus and Mary Chain is the easiest comparison. Ringing fuzzy guitars, canned percussion, and reverb laden drone vocals, all making a fun yet druggy atmosphere. There's been a lot of bands mining this sound recently - this isn't that different than Merchandise except European and maybe a bit less noisy. But it's a great set of songs; unfortunately there's only a couple, as this is a 1-sided 12". According to discogs this is the only thing they ever released; I wouldn't be the slightest bit surprised if the whole thing is actually Spencer and someone else, but he's never told me. [26 November 2012]


Date: 8 May 2009

Ric Royer & G. Lucas Crane - Dark Cabinet of the Strange Weird

Label: Ehse

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Doug

Cost: €0

Lucas Crane, who I am definitely a fan of personally as well as musically, made this goofy horror-themed collage album with Ric Royer. This is modeled like an old radio show, with Royer's flamboyant voice attempting to deliver genuine spine-chills. Lucas's sound collages are great, though - when Royer shuts up and he takes centre stage, the album's most compelling moments happen. Unlike the Nonhorse stuff, this is spare and focused on supporting the narrative, which I unfortunately tune out quickly. Though I like the juxtaposition of narrative form with sound art/collage music, the genre-basis of this isn't enough to win me over. [8 November 2012]


Date: 8 May 2009

Paul Flaherty - Aria Nativa

Label: Family Vineyard

Format: Vinyl

Source: Doug

Cost: €0

Two sides of solo Paul Flaherty saxophone is an intense listense for a Wednesday afternoon but the stark, cold squeals of the upper register are sort of appropriate for my mental state right now -  and also for looking out the window at a snow-covered Tallinn. The cover of this is similar wintry, and while there are moments of blues, they quickly spin themselves into sharper tendencies. These are live recordings with crowd noise throughout and it's a real gutbucket performance - some of the vibrato shakes the stylus out of the groove. Solo sax records are often a 'statement of purpose' for musicians and this is so truly the work of Flaherty, I could never mistake it for anyone else. [19 December 2012]


Date: 8 May 2009

Jazzfinger - Mole & The Morning Dew

Label: Spirit Of Orr

Format: Vinyl

Source: Doug

Cost: €0

A 2009 release by Jazzfinger captures the band doing what I've seen them do numerous times, so I think this is a good one to have, especially when I feel nostalgic. The final track, 'Tower of the Sunset Eye', rides out an acoustic guitar arpeggio and ecstatic, cheap keyboard swirls, all over the usual bowing, scraping and droning. 'Fishing Trip' struggles to stay interested with itself but creates that uniquely dissonant soup of sound which only Ben and Has can do well. The first side has some thick, pulsing drones, perfectly tense between a noise feel and a shoegazer ethos. The radiant pink-purple vinyl is one of the prettiest colours of vinyl I've seen, even though I rarely care about coloured vinyl; it suits Jazzfinger well, especially when combined with the drab beige-brown of the cover. [19 December 2012]


Date: 8 May 2009

Talibam! with Daniel Carter - The New Nixon Tapes

Label: Roaratorio

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Doug

Cost: €0

Talibam are a good fit with Daniel Carter - they both know when to get rough, and respond well to the rhythmic variation. Talibam's drummer is Kevin Shea, who was the shining light of Storm and Stress, a band I used to listen to and wish I could hear only Shea playing. This is pretty thick with the synth and sax but I still tend to focus on his uniquely propulsive free style. Each side is a long jam, clearly cut from an epic session, and while this sounds very much like a one-off meeting, it's certainly successful enough. [24 November 2012]


Date: 8 May 2009

Blindhaed - Whether That Will Make People Want To Become Archaeologists, We'll Have To See

Label: ini.itu

Format: Vinyl

Source: Doug

Cost: €0

Heavily processed contemporary concrète by some Belgians who went to Indonesia and made this record, I assume based on crap they brought back with them.  It's good listening though, if you like the low-level delicate approach to electronics.  I wish the effects were less obvious but I suppose it would just sound like a bunch of rattling otherwise.  It takes me back to Transmissions festival almost a decade ago, watching Lucky Kitchen and all those laptop dude.  What's changed?  Me, not the style.  Definitely from the same school as Lied Music/Usurper/the Bohman Brothers, though maybe not as disticnt sounding as either of those groups.  it's a one-sided LP so it doesn't wear out its welcome; still, I can't help but think that the origin of the source material isn't reflected at all in the record and this could just be some crap they found in a drawer instead.  Should that matter?  Am I just a miserable grumpy old prick now?  [19 June 2009]



Date: 8 May 2009

Twinkle³ - Let's Make A Solar System

Label: ini.itu

Format: Vinyl

Source: Doug

Cost: €0

Sold.


Date: 8 May 2009

Christian Toscano & Adam Menzies - 

Label: no label

Format: Vinyl LP Album (promo copy with no cover)

Source: Doug

Cost: €0

I received this bare LP to review and it was apparently a limited edition of 100 with little info out there online. It's great, too. This is filed alphabetically near the Christopher Tree LP I have but also can be filed there stylistically. This is all about acoustic resonance, with lots of amplified air, tiny instruments such as twinkling bells, and some extremely subtle harmonium playing. It's a great late-night record even though it's actually some pretty clear skies at work.[28 December 2012]


Date: 8 May 2009

Zashiki-Warashi - Mail Wars

Label: Conduit Creations

Format: Vinyl LP Album

Source: Doug

Cost: €0

This was assembled by mail with a bunch of different musicians sending source material, and Zashiki-Warashi put it all into a collage. A simple idea, done many times, and here he asked people like Marcia Bassett, Burning Star Core, Dave Shuford, and others for source material. So as you can imagine it's wildly abstract, with harsh electronics, droning strings, weird vocal samples and everything else you can imagine - a compendium of late 00's experimental techniques. Of course it doesn't sound cohesive as its not, by definition. [20 December 2012]


Date: 8 May 2009

Alle med balloner og terrasser - 

Label: Escho

Format: 10" (blue vinyl)

Source: Doug

Cost: €0

Sold.


Date: 8 May 2009

HamaYÃ´ko - SHASO -train window-

Label: Entr'acte

Format: Vinyl 12" EP

Source: Doug

Cost: €0



Date: 8 May 2009

Sunny and the Sunsets - Love and Death

Label: Soft Abuse

Format: 7"

Source: Doug

Cost: €0



Date: 8 May 2009

Various Artists - I/D/V 01

Label: Unframed

Format: 7"

Source: Doug

Cost: €0



Date: 8 May 2009

Various Artists - I/D/V 02

Label: Unframed

Format: 7"

Source: Doug

Cost: €0



Date: 8 May 2009

$100 - Fourteenth Floor

Label: ?????? Recording Club

Format: Vinyl

Source: Doug

Cost: €0

Contemporary Canadian country. Pretty decent; politically/socially conscious, but not in an annoying way; part of a whole new scene happening up there that I don't know anything about.


Date: 8 May 2009

Refrigerator - Down With

Label: Ajax Records (2)

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: €7.19

I dream of eventually tracking down Refrigerator's entire discography, though sadly some of their awesome recent albums are only available on CD (particularly my favorite, 1999's Glitter Jazz). This 7" from 1993 logically has a similar sound to their earlier stuff, particularly the How You Continue Dreaming album. There's scraggly guitars, no bass, and pounding drums, all recorded pretty lo-fi but with the angelic voice of Allen Callaci soaring over it. There's six songs on this 7" (though only five listed) and not a bad one among 'em. 'Black and White Photograph' has a darker, grungy feel and sounds like the kind of song I fell in love with in high school. 'Down by the Law' is a banjo-driven, gentle song that will go on every Refrigerator best-of mix tape I ever make in the future. At this time these guys had the perfect balance of melody, spirit, and messyness. A small dose like this might not be enough to convince a newcomer of Callaci's visionary abilities, but I'd hope anyone who was came of age in the 90s like myself will find something special here.


Date: 19 May 2009

Cheveu - Dog

Label: S-S Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: $8

'Dog' is a hit from Cheveu's first record, presented here in a slightly slower form (I think). It's such a standard, primitive rock and roll riff, but totally destroyed by all the layers of home-recording space-noise and ritalin-affected vocals. 'Make My Day' is a strong song though definitely a "b-side" -- it's got crunching guitars and a good structure. [19 December 2012]


Date: 19 May 2009

Cheveu - My Answer Is Yes!

Label: Rob?s House Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: $8

'.. but what's the question?' asks Cheveu, in this single, the b-side of which is an alternate version of a great cut from their first album. 'My Answer Is Yes!' is a bit slower than I think benefits it - but the drum machine gets all Big Black halfway through and whatsnisname starts to shout and while it's a formulaic early Cheveu tune, it's a good example of why I loved early Cheveu. And then on the b is 'Lola Langusta', a goofball sex number. It's brighter and also cleaner than I'm used to it, but every bit as infectious. This is a fun one to DJ with as the 7" format is convenient. Plus, nice white vinyl. [25 July 2012]


Date: 25 May 2009

Mireille Mathieu - Mireille... Mireille

Label: Barclay

Format: Vinyl

Source: The Time Machine, Nambour, Queen

Cost: AU$3

Sold.


Date: 28 May 2009

Deerhunter - Microcastle / Weird Era Cont.

Label: Kranky

Format: Vinyl

Source: Rocking Horse, Brisbane

Cost: AU$44.95

Microcastle is the Deerhunter record that turned me into a fan, so having it on vinyl is nice. And there's a lovely bonus LP called Weird Era Cont., clearly outtakes and less-polished songs, but still pretty solid - at least as good as their first LP was. Of course, I only play Weird Era occasionally. MIcrocastle, though, I'm practically wearing out. This is a masterful step forward for a great band, whose next album goes even farther, simultaneously pushing more inside and outside. There's a lot of pain in these songs, hiding behind the catchy hooks etc. I learned to love this album while listening on earphones at night, falling asleep to the first few songs over and over. Maybe because of this, I always associate Microcastle with sonnambulism in general - that hazy, half-conscious reality that is the 'real' hypnagogic pop. [27 July 2012]


Date: 28 May 2009

News From Babel - Sirens & Silences / Work Resumed On The Tower

Label: Ré Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Rocking Horse, Brisbane

Cost: AU$29.95

I've never gotten as familiar with the News from Babel output as I have with Art Bears, which is a shame - it's essentially the same band from a songwriting perspective, but with Fred Frith replaced by Lindsay Cooper and Zeena Parkins. That is actually a big difference, as Frith and Cutler are like a mindmeld, but the different instrumentation is lovely and really makes Krause's voice feel more regal and operatic. This is a 45rpm 12" but fairly long, feeling as satisfying as a full-length album, and the higher speed mastering makes it sound great. The tendency towards grandiose chord changes, seen a bit in the Art Bears, is perhaps stronger here, but it works well even if I miss the more punk-edged aspects. I have the CD with their other album but I don't know it well; it would be nice to track down that one on vinyl but in the days of less disposable income, maybe not. [18 November 2012]


Date: 28 May 2009

Jan Steele / John Cage - Voices And Instruments

Label: Obscure (UK)

Format: Vinyl

Source: Rocking Horse, Brisbane

Cost: AU$59.95

This split LP was released on Eno's Obscure label and it reads like a who's-who of the art-rock scene of the mid-70s.  Despite each side being attributed to one composer, it feels more like a compilation, as each track contains different musicians expressing different ideas.  Steele's pieces use larger groups and are musically conversational.  It's not dissonant, but it is austere and somewhat detached sounding.  A viola might make a sThe overall feel is like something that you would expect to come out of a forward-thinking musical academy in the mid-70's, though I don't mean this to sound derogatory.  Cage's side is much more minimal as most pieces are for just one solo performer.  Richard Bernhas seems to be the primary interpreter of the work, and the album closes with a beautiful solo piano piece never stops moving, yet is barely there.  Robert Wyatt sings on two tracks and Carla Bley on another - they are unaccompanied and the melody suits their voices well.  The Bley track feels a little bit like a medieval, new age-leaning songpoem though I'm sure if I concentrate on the lyrics they will be something hypermodern.  This is an interesting (maybe even great) record with a few really beautiful moments that fits well with Eno's aesthetic.



Date: 28 May 2009

Sun City Girls - Fruit Of The Womb / Polite Deception

Label: Eclipse Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Rocking Horse, Brisbane

Cost: AU$59.95

One thing that is so interesting about these SCG reissues is how fully-developed their sound was, even back in 1984 when they only had their first album out. Fruit of the Womb is a jammy instrumental cassette showing the wild jazz/psyche sound that they employ on many later albums. The cassette recording quality is perfect, as you can hear everything really well and there's a lot of great drumming by Gocher. 'When The Jewels Roll Out of Your Eyes' is a 25 minute long jam that sounds at times like Django Reinhardt mistakenly wandering into a punk club, and at other times like a Moroccan hash bar. The shorter tracks on side 1 are awesome too, containing some quotes that later ended up on Torch of the Mystics and other tunes.  Polite Deception is more of the same, pretty much. It's maybe a bit more rock and a bit less jazz, by which I mean a bit less improvised.  'Sun of Talisman' reminds me of the Black Sun Ensemble, a bit of guitar-god heroics. The set closes with 'Gulf Con '79', a departure from the rock in favour of a 17-minute experimental workout. There are gestural guitar acoustics, lots of static/field recordings, and a collectively improvised atmosphere - it's beautiful and strange, and somehow appropriate. [30 November 2012]


Date: 1 June 2009

The Dutchess and the Duke - Never Had a Chance / Scorpio

Label: Hozac

Format: 7"

Source: Missing Link, Bourke St., Melbou

Cost: AU$9.5

I really loved the Dutchess and the Duke album from last year and would like to find a vinyl copy.  This single continues the raw, stripped down rock sound with dual vocals.  Here the rhythm section is minimal and the guitars are electric (though pretty clean-sounding), transforming what would otherwise be gentle folk tunes into machines of edgy soul.  Both tunes are great and it's hard to pick a favorite.  The vocal affect may sound a bit put-on but I feel the attitude seeping out of traditions.  I had to put off listening to this for the past month because I couldn't find my little-to-big 45 adapter, but now that I've located it I expect this to get a lot of spins.  [10 July 2009]



Date: 1 June 2009

Cheveu - Like a Deer in the Headlights

Label: Born Bad

Format: 7"

Source: Missing Link, Bourke St., Melbou

Cost: AU$15

The new Cheveu record!  Did I ever think that there would come a day where I pay $15 for a 7"?  Well, that's Aussie dollars so it ain't SO bad but still .... 'Like a Deer in the Headlights' explodes with a jangly guitar riff and strong vocal melody, sounding like a different band from the get-go - but then a fast parts kicks in and it captures that nervous energy that's all over their first album.  The recording quality is leaps and bounds ahead of anything they've done before, sounding like they've found the light to lead them out of the lo-fi tunnel.  There's a very 'edited' feeling to the song, but it furthers the nervousness (which I guess is also in the lyrics).  The b-side is a somewhat gothic tune with organ and French lyrics.  It's very French, very baroque but sadly very brief too.  [19 June 2009]



Date: 1 June 2009

Alasehir - The Philosophy of Living Fire

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: LP

Source: Missing Link, Bourke St., Melbou

Cost: AU$14

I grabbed this cause it was (relatively) cheap, marked down from AU$30, and on Siltbreeze.  I usually listen to (via mp3) everything on the Siltbreeze label, but somehow I missed this one so I bought it figuring it couldn't be bad.  This is a pretty good album of instrumental guitar/drone scraping, but it isn't the kind of thing I get super excited about anymore.  I think with repeated listens I could really find it to be a masterful effort, but the backlog of things to listen to pretty much guarantees that won't happen.  The first side is really long and dense, with very slow moving guitar tones and drums to keep things moving.  On the second side, there's some acoustic fingerpicking, though it feels intentionally aimless, more like a doodle than a distinct sketch.  The recording is great though, really pulling you into its blast furnace of sound.  [22 June 2009]



Date: 1 June 2009

Oper' Azione Nafta - Cavuru

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: LP

Source: Missing Link, Bourke St., Melbou

Cost: AU$15

This Italian group reminds me a great deal of Bablicon's first album, particularly the parts that are recorded on a walkman.  This whole album has the fidelity, and the very brief side one blasts through so quickly that you barely realise what' happened.  They stretch out a bit on side two as well, which is an electric rock/jazz freak-fumble. The reeds, when played alone, remind me a bit of the first Lol Coxhill record.  There's a sense of energy and freedom, and the only darkness is in the name of textural exploration, which makes this a somewhere weird fit for Siltbreeze.  Some good electronics too, but I'd like to hear what they'd sound like in a good recording studio.  [16 Jan 2012]


Date: 1 June 2009

Fresh Maggots - Fresh Maggots

Label: Sunbeam Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Missing Link, Bourke St., Melbourne, Australia

Cost: AU$30

This is a long-lost British acid-folk record that I first read about in Badaboom Gramaphone's folk issue; the double LP reissue is lavishly packaged in a gatefold and on nice thick vinyl. But how great is the music? I go back and forth on Fresh Maggots - the voices are somewhat generic, and it's such a product of its time. When the electric guitar cuts in, it can sound quite nasty and biting, and those are point during which I really enjoy it. The anti-war song just sounds silly now, but there are some nice melodies; it's really the album closer 'Frustration' that is the pinnacle, particularly the fuzzy string section on the jam-out. The bonus disc has pretty much everything else they ever recorded - a novelty single ('Car Song') and then some live stuff. This is scraping the bottom of the barrel, but it's ultimately an appropriate packaging for this band (who were from Nuneaton!) [16 July 2012]


Date: 1 June 2009

Major Stars - 4

Label: Twisted Village

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Missing Link, Bourke St., Melbourne, Australia

Cost: AU$15

A discounted Major Stars LP that I forgot I owned - so many private press or low-budget releases get overlooked when they don't have spines, because I honestly skim the shelves sometimes when I'm looking for something to play, and these plain white records or spineless ones are never seen. (Though there's been so many more of those in recent years, and I'm guilty myself of releasing a few). This is a stomping heavy rock album with some really nice singing (there could be more, actually) and awesome, psychedelic guitar solos - a more tradition-based Comets on Fire, but somehow Major Stars don't really remind me of anybody else. The last song begins with a long, slow drone that eventually builds into some stunning rock riffage; the bass and guitar interplay is rock-solid. The guitar lead on 'Song for Turner' is absolutely triumphant; this is music without cynicism, without irony. [15 July 2012]


Date: 1 June 2009

Treepeople - Guilt Regret Embarrassment

Label: Toxic Shock

Format: Vinyl

Source: Missing Link, Bourke St., Melbou

Cost: AU$12

I used to have this on tape back in the ol' Summer of '97, that fateful summer where nostalgia rings most crushing.  Of course i was obsessed with There's Nothing Wrong with Love by Built to Spill, so it was logical that I go back and check out earlier Doug Martsch work.  This is a crunchy pop-punk record but with an indie edge as opposed to the Fat Wreck Chords vibe.  You can hear a few screaming guitar solos though nothing like BtS wankathons, and there's a great cover of 'Andy Warhol' cause Martsch thinks Bowie's cool (though it's Lodger, not Hunky Dory that rules, so what gives?).  Now this is probably not the most essential record in my collection but the price was pretty good and I've been really swinging back to this kind of stuff lately.  I'm sure with repeated listens this could grow on me as much as TNWWL, though since I'm 29 and not 17 it's gonna be a lot harder to usurp it.  I will stand by stuff like this as "my" soul music, extending Soriano's analogy that Black Flag was soul music for white kids from the suburbs in the early 80s.  Maybe this is a sadly watered down essential musical experience but it's mine and it helped make me who I was.  I just realised that I've reviewed this as if it was There's Nothing Wrong with Love, which I stupidly don't even own a copy of (did I lose it?  Lend it to someone? Sell it in some sort of indierock backlash?), something I will rectify now.  Oh yeah, Treepeople, well, they kinda sound like early Lemonheads a bit too.  [29 June 2009]



Date: 2 June 2009

Alex Chilton - Like Flies On Sherbert

Label: Aura

Format: Vinyl

Source: Licorice Pie, High St., Prahan, 

Cost: AU$30

I was recently turned onto this record so I'm glad to stumble across a vinyl copy so quickly as I think it's kinda rare.  The cover here is pretty dinged up but the LP is in great shape and it sounds magnificent.  This record is pretty insane and probably worthy of "classic" status.  On the surface it's a drunken fiasco, loaded with fucked up covers of R&B-influenced rock songs with tons of mistakes left in.  But, this is the type of statement that few artists ever make, and it definitely holds up one end of the continuum carried on by Pussy Galore, Harry Pussy, and other bands that don't have the name "pussy" in them.  There's still hints of the Big Star pop genius here, and also songs like "Alligator Blues" which do the R. Stevie/Ariel Pink thing (only better).  There's demented noise-rock guitar solos and stumbling, lurching rhythms, and it has bizarre production techniques as well - lots of distortion, uneen levels, etc.  This sounds remarkably fresh now given the plethora of bedroom pop "outsiders" like Gary War, Blank Dogs, etc. though this of course comes from a completely different place.  Chilton's genius is inexplicably tied up in his failure and this record might be his attempt to tackle it head-on, failing even though it's impossible to fail.  A masterpiece?  I suspect I will pull this one out more frequently than any Big Star records in the next few years though maybe I just listened to Big Star to death.



Date: 2 June 2009

Richard & Linda Thompson - Hokey Pokey

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Licorice Pie, High St., Prahan, 

Cost: AU$15

This is their second album together if my memory serves me correctly, and one that takes on a stronger American C&W direction than the predecessor, I Want To See the Bright Lights Tonight.  Though the music is a bit jumpier and more fiddle-oriented, the lyrical content isn't any brighter.  These two were another step closer to the dissolution of their marriage and perhaps the songs reflect that.  "Never Again" at the end of side 1 is a really beautiful, haunting piece that risks drifting off into the atmosphere before it's even finished.  Because of the juxtaposition of dark melodies with brighter melodies, this may take a bit longer to connect with.  But there's a few of those driving Richard-sung tunes like 'I'll Regret it all in the Morning' which is like a series of continually raising M.C.Escher-like plateaus in a bleak nighttime landscape.  When Ben started getting into Richard Thompson he told me that he found it hard to believe RT could write songs like this without killing himself, because they were so depressing.  I think I'll agree with that, but what does it say that this darkness is what attracts me to his music?  I'll always maintain that these records, or Big Star Sister Lovers are far more depressing than anything like Joy Division because the pain is so genuine.  [29 June 2009]



Date: 2 June 2009

Leo Cuypers - Theatre Music

Label: BV Haast

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Licorice Pie, High St., Prahan, Melbourne

Cost: AU$30

I really love Dutch jazz and Leo Cuypers in particular, but I almost missed this LP because it was hiding in the 20th century composers section at this awesome Melbourne record store.  The first side is a trio of Cuyper, Arjen Gorter, and Martin van Duynhoven that rums through four rather rocking Cuypers compositions, presumably for the theatre.  All three musicians play as a rhythm section; despite flashes of showmanship from Cuypers and a great Arjen Gorter bass solo, this really feels like a tight power trio acting as one spirit.  There's a very rolling, swinging feel to these pieces that is very familiar from the Heavy Days are Here Again CD.  Side two picks up the same feel though adds Willem Breuker on a variety of reeds.  There's a small bit of synthesizer instead of piano, though it adds colour to the album and works well with Breuker's rich palette.  The slow descending lurch of 'Triste' is a highlight as van Duynhoven pulls back and lets Leo and Willem play around with each other's tonal centres.  Overall this is a record that feels lively and free, yet tightly focused on it's melodic agenda.



Date: 2 June 2009

Third Ear Band - Music From Macbeth

Label: EMI

Format: Vinyl

Source: Licorice Pie, High St., Prahan, 

Cost: AU$40

Third Ear Band were the perfect choice to score Macbeth, or at least I say that presumptuously since I've never seen the film. The rustic, old-world pagan atmosphere saturates every second of this, whether it's violin-driven folk dances or bending, searing improvised moments. The female vocals are a good centrepiece to break up what would otherwise be a gloomy, dark trip. This is definitely a soundtrack that stands on its own, but I really should see the film finally. [2 Aug 2012]


Date: 2 June 2009

Captain Matchbox Whoopee Band - Wangaratta Wahine

Label: Image

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Licorice Pie, High St., Prahan, 

Cost: AU$10

I only know the Captain Matchbox Whoopee Band because they released their first album on ESP, which is surely the most odd fit for the ESP label. This is their second record, and it's such a goofy parody of ragtime/swing that it's strange I like it so much. It's hard to enjoy these rowdy Australians without thinking of that shitty pop-swing revival that occurred in the 90s -- which is apparently happening again as 'electro-swing' now (or at least that's what the local kids are telling me). As much of a genre pastiche as it is, the musicianship is good, the humour is solid (but not overbearing), and a few songs, such as 'Half a Moon' and 'Wait for Me, Juanita' actually tickle something soft inside me. I guess I like the Holy Modal Rounders too and as I get more into traditional Americana the best revivalists will float to the top, like cream. [6 December 2012]


Date: 2 June 2009

Henry Cowell / Lou Harrison - Persian Set / Suite for Violin, Piano and Small Orchestra

Label: CRI

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Licorice Pie, High St., Prahan, 

Cost: AU$20

I like the idea that composers can make split LPs just like hardcore bands. I actually don't know much by Cowell but this is grand, making a wonderful large sound with a small chamber orchestra. It's modal, Eastern-influenced as the title suggests, and has some strange tunings I think that give it a nice shine. I'm a big Lou Harrison fan and this doesn't disappoint, though it eschews his usual brightness in favor of a more shadowy sky, particularly on the third movement. It's got some beautiful gamelan-influenced moments, and that step-step-step progression that is so characteristic of Harrison's work is in full evidence here. [17 December 2012]


Date: 24 June 2009

Eat Skull - Sick To Death

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: Vinyl

Source: Repo Man Records, NÃ¸rrebro, KÃ¸benhavn

Cost: DKK100

I really liked this first album by Eat Skull when it came out, though after the poppier tones of Wild and Inside I barely listened to it anymore. This isn't really any different of a formula, just a bit less catchy. There are still a lot of good songs, and when they get slow and dirge-like it hints at a depth and potential. There's a bit more sentimentality here than the rough, punk-rock artwork indicates - it's a bit tied up in the artifice of these images, the subcultural attitudes of being young, etc. Perhaps it stirs some nostalgia in me, while of course twisting around the same influences I have. At this point Sick to Death sounds underrated to me so maybe I will listen to it a bit more frequently. [16 December 2012]


Date: 24 June 2009

Angst Hase Pfeffer Nase - Glistening Inn

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: Vinyl

Source: Repo Man Records, NÃ¸rrebro, KÃ¸benhavn

Cost: DKK150

It was nice to find this Angst Hase Pfeffer Nase record in Denmark as I missed my chance to order it when it was still live in the distros. This begins with some strange vocals over noodling keyboards and unidentifiable (yet tinny) sounds - side 1 is very organic, with some reeds and cello, sounding like broken songs. It reminds me more of Fat Worm of Error (without the rock instrumentation) and of course Residents/Renaldo; the other record I have, Seashard, is far more shrill and busy. The second side is somewhat closer in terms of electronic resonance, but no less colourful. Sounds are constantly shifting, and Cooper's approach to layers and construction is as genius as Jan's recent Kemialliset material, though completely different, infused with his own personality. It's a great fit for Ultra Eczema and I'm probably moving Angst Hase to the "get everything he releases" category. [28 December 2012]


Date: 24 June 2009

Alternative TV - Vibing Up The Senile Man (Part One)

Label: Deptford Fun City

Format: Vinyl

Source: Repo Man Records, NÃ¸rrebro, KÃ¸benhavn

Cost: DKK140

This is a pretty incredible record that I've never given enough time to in the past. It's the second Alternative TV record and takes the avant-leaning jamming from the first one and pushes it into a whole new arena. I always celebrate Wire for being able to push so far in 3 albums in their music and ideas, starting from the punk movement but being true artistic innovators. But Alternative TV maybe went further, faster. This has long, jammy free parts with intelligent, creative lyrics, but it's not even remotely like anything else happening in punk. It's far closer to Throbbing Gristle, mixed with some good ol' avant-gardisms - Robert Ashley, Kip Hanrahan, minimalist composition - all of these things are touched upon, yet put together as a coherent album. It's not an aggressive spit in the eye of the punk movement, because it doesn't care about that - they've already moved so far beyond by this point. [28 September 2012]


Date: 24 June 2009

Harmonia - Musik Von Harmonia

Label: Lilith

Format: Vinyl

Source: Repo Man Records, NÃ¸rrebro, KÃ¸benhavn

Cost: DKK180

Here's a nice thick repress of the first Harmonia album, on a Russian label. It sounds great - tinny in all the right places and deep and thick where it counts. The genius of this sound is that it's driving and abstract at the same time, able to be a focal point for psychedelic immersion as well as as background listening. Which probably explains why Eno was a good collaborator for these guys, as they had the same ideas about 'attention' and ways of listening. The more mellow bits with the guitar plucking are so beautiful, and not what I think of when I think of Harmonia, but really where the deepest bit of pleasure come from. [19 December 2012]


Date: 24 June 2009

Frank Sumatra and the Mob - Te Deum

Label: Small Wonder Records

Format: 12"

Source: Repo Man Records, NÃ¸rrebro, KÃ¸benhavn

Cost: DKK160

This is a spinoff of Family Fodder, I think; four songs with the same formula, as 'Tedium' could be right off the Savoir Faire CD. It's a catchy song with a feel-good chorus and just a hint of ambition. 'The Story So Far' is a bouncy art-rock number that recalls Art Bears through the baroque piano and clarinet sequences, and a Krause-like vocal part. There's a very dismantled cover of Joe Meek's 'Telstar' which is wonky and propulsive, and the whole thing ends with a bit of studio experimental called 'The Blues'. Great stuff, but I want more! [21 December 2012]


Date: 24 June 2009

Pavement - Westing (By Musket And Sextant)

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl

Source: Repo Man Records, NÃ¸rrebro, KÃ¸benhavn

Cost: DKK100

How do I review something like this, which I have actually listened to a million times over the past decade (though never actually owned before, relying on dubbed tapes and mp3s to become familiar with it)?  I guess I can talk about what it sounds like on vinyl, which is (not surprisingly) "great".  Funny now that I finally own every Pavement album legitimately on vinyl or CD (and that it only took me, I dunno, about fourteen years to do it) since they are my all-time favorite band, probably.  And also funny that I bought this a few days after the big 4LP Brighten the Corners reissue came out, which I kind of want, but I really want the Slanted and Enchanted set to get the vinyl reissue.  Anyway, this record is pretty close to perfect and stands as a great album even though it's a compilation.  This really contains the only material Pavement ever released that can be classified as "lo-fi", and not even that much of it.  I would say that by S&E they were recording at least at a "mid-fi" level, plus parts of this record are really glossy.  Every song is a classic, and the less songy sketches are classics too, at this point.  'Home' is maybe my favorite Pavement song ever; it contains a universe of personal meanings, memories and associations that I can't possibly put into language, but that's why we listen to music after all.



Date: 24 June 2009

Hüsker Dü - Metal Circus

Label: SST

Format: 12" Vinyl EP

Source: Repo Man Records, NÃ¸rrebro, KÃ¸benhavn

Cost: DKK70

This is possibly Hüsker Dü's finest release, so it's nice to find for reasonably cheap, though there's a pretty bad warp that makes the first track on each side rather unplayable. But it's still phenomenal, especially at 45 rpm - the production here is perfect, as that's something that weakens some of the later ones. The tunes are midway between the almost-unlistenable Land Speed Record thrash-fest and the saccharine stuff that comes at the end; we end up with gems like 'First of the Last Calls', the amazing 'Diane', and 'Its Not Funny Anymore' which is one of the best Grant Hart songs for sure. Some Danish kid sold this, probably needing a fix - he wrote his name, MATTHIAZ, on the back of the sleeve, but with an anarchy sign replacing the first 'A'. Yeah. [19 September 2012]


Date: 7 July 2009

Life Partners - AIDS Of Spades B/W Teenager In Trouble

Label: Ride The Snake

Format: Vinyl

Source: Chris Strunk

Cost: €0

This is a goofy punk band with Greg Kelley and I think a guy from Major Stars, led by an organ and some stupid gruff vocals with lyrics that stray into humorous territory.  But not in a ha-ha Weird Al funny way, more like in a great retro punk style.  Though there's probably so many layers of irony on this that I can't be sure how to disect it.  I don't doubt that Life Partners is a serious band and believe in what they do, and there's a very artful approach to this.  Noise leaks out of all the cracks and it has the dynamic that punk made by people with really adverturous taste in music produce - like Swell Maps or Cheveu or something.  'Teenager in Trouble' is probably my pick here and I'm curious if I'd enjoy a whole LP.  I'm psyched that Chris is putting out records though!  [22 July 2009]



Date: 7 July 2009

Reports - Bill Wyman Metal Detector

Label: Ride the Snake

Format: 7"

Source: Chris Strunk

Cost: €0

This reports single is a totally retro 7" that reminds me of the kind of thing I woulda bought in high school and put on a hundred mix tapes.  Fast, high energy rock with guitar solos and ragged chords, yet catchy, melodic hooks.  The voice gets just a bit snotty on 'Bill Wyman Metal Detector' and there's a wonderful guitar solo on 'Attleborough Trailers'.  The recording is slightly lo-fi, or maybe it's just the pressing but it sounds just right.  [11 July 2009]



Date: 7 July 2009

Dead at 24 - Blast Off Motherfucker!

Label: Ride the Snake

Format: LP

Source: Chris Strunk

Cost: €0

Dead at 24 are such an odd band.  I never really knew what to make of them back in '97 and '98 when I used to see them play all the time.  At times I found it annoying because it seemed like they were playing every show I wanted to go to, and their music was too fucked up for me to appreciate at age 17.  But thinking about them over the years, retrospectively, they've greatly increased in stature.  And I've come to love Alan's songwriting in Anita Fix and the Working Poor so much, that I was really excited to hear that Chris was reissuing the 'Blast Off, Motherfucker!' cassette.  Somehow he's made it sound amazing, apart from the live songs included which still sound great, just extremely lo-fi.  This is a good time to bring them back to the greater public, as this type of ramshackle art-punk is really fashionable right now. I remember this band as being really Steve Boyle-dominated - crazy synthesizer noise covering everything, making the songs only barely recognizeable.  But on the recording, the guitars are dominant and there are parts where Steve's contributions are sometimes barely noticeable.  Ernie's songwriting is a pretty different type than Alan's but it complements it well and gives the record a lot more depth -- as much as I love Alan's words, they are so dense and powerful that it's best to appreciate it in smaller doses.  I'm really psyched that Chris did this as I know it's been his dream for the past decade.  And of course it's nostalgia value is immense for me - I remember going to a party on New Years Eve 96/97 at the Rickety House with Brian where Dead at 24 played with the Korel Tunador-era Johnsons.  And meeting Alan that night and he gave me a 1985 sticker because I was really into them and we talked about bands and I felt like my life was about to change, just as soon as pesky high school could finish.  Well, it did.  So this is pretty crucial to it.  [11 July 2009]



Date: 23 July 2009

Moles - Instinct

Label: Fire

Format: CD

Source: eBay

Cost: £9

I've been trying to find a vinyl copy of this for ages, but this CD will have to suffice for now.  In the past 4 years or so, this has escalated to the top of my "favorite albums of all time" list, and I decided to start writing a longish piece about it.  I've been interviewing Richard Davies via email and whatever shape the final piece comes will certainly be more detailed than whatever I can put here.



Date: 31 July 2009

T.A.S.K. - Relaxing Time is Over

Label: Heartworm

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Heartworm

Cost: £14.27

I fell in love with this record via MP3 so I had to order it.  It's shocking that I like this so much cause it's not the kind of thing I usually like.  This is total "hipster" music, conuring images of snotty Berliners in stupid clothes making music that reflects their tastes - synthetic, cold, and detached.  With wonderfuly bored-sounding vocals, added almost as an afterthought.  The whole package attains something special, a real 'vibe' like I've never heard before. And apparently there's some connection to Metabolismus, who I liked.  I hope it ages well.  [31 July 2009]



Date: 5 August 2009

Django Django - Storm / Love's Dart

Label: Shadazz

Format: Vinyl

Source: Luke Fowler

Cost: €0

Luke's label is surprisingly eclectic - alongside Lee Patterson, Lied Music/Vernon and Burns and the Daniel Padden/Sarah Ketchington albums is this single by a Dundee band (I think) called Django Django. It's an extremely pleasant pop slice, built around a solid, bright beat and sharp, staccato accompaniment - but instead of an intense dance-orientated thing it has an extremely laid-back vibe. Maybe the Beta Band is an easy comparison because both are Scottish, but 'Love's Dart' really has a twangy, almost country feel. [10 December 2012]


Date: 5 August 2009

Daniel Padden & Sarah Kenchington - The Bellow Switch

Label: Shadazz

Format: CD

Source: Luke Fowler

Cost: €0

Daniel and Sarah's collaboration is an unevenly recorded mixture of Sarah's homebuilt instruments and Daniel's broken-folk fuckery. The casual feel of these pieces is nice; when Daniel starts to sing, it's almost an afterthought, which is probably better with song titles like 'Unbagging the Wish-Spoon' (which is not to say I don't like his voice) -- it works. Throughout this is a sense of things about to collapse; farting horns, repeating arpeggios of plucked strings, sawing/bowed metal, and a percussive haphazardness. I'm really glad they decided to shape these into songs because it brings out a character in her work, even with Daniel's influence, that is really distinct. Normally, when people build crazy instruments, a lot of the resulting product becomes a show-and-tell, merely a demonstration of what they do rather than an exploration of their expressive tendencies. The way the recordings are sometimes from dictaphone or other lo-fi device accentuate them - I'm really glad this isn't anything close to a novelty record. I hope they do more together. [14 August 2012]


Date: 5 August 2009

Lee Patterson - Seven Vignettes

Label: Shadazz

Format: CD

Source: Luke Fowler

Cost: €0

This CD by Lee presents seven pieces as sound art experiments but also as a coherent album. Though the tracks are built from deep listening experiments such as burning items, kettles, and heating pipes, they're sculpted into a very somber dronescape that keeps the mood from track to track. The final track, 'Plateau #1', uses a bunch of "Lee" objects to create a thick, bulbous sound that rides out the album nicely. This is probably the most complete overall recording by Lee and hopefully there's more to come. [4 Aug 2012]


Date: 11 August 2009

Fricara Pacchu - Midnight Pyre

Label: Lal Lal Lal

Format: CD

Source: Roope Eronen

Cost: €0

Roope gave me this out of enthusiasm for Fricara Pacchu, who I must say is probably my pick of that whole Lal Lal Lal scene (I had heard a tape on Lieven Maartens' label a few years ago that I really liked).  This is relatively structured music with programmed rhythm tracks and strange dissonances bursting in at random times.  It's noisy and distorted at points, but not fuzzy - rather, it has a really fucked up Eastern feel, like a sci-fi take on gamelan music.  Despite the canned beats there are points where it breaks down and melts a bit.  I definitely dig this a lot - maybe this will turn around my attitude towards a lot of this scene, and I'm looking forward to seeing him live in October.



Date: 16 September 2009

Evan Parker / John Wiese - C-Section

Label: Second Layer Records

Format: CD

Source: Tommi Keränen

Cost: €0

Finally, the answer to the question 'What could Evan Parker and John Wiese do together?'. I've heard the processed Parker before, with his own Electro-Acoustic Ensemble from the early 00s, but this isn't really processed at all. It's really live, actually; John's mastery of the digital world, laptop-MSP-etc, makes him an adept improviser, and the recording is top-notch, with Parker's flurries and impulses floating overtop John's more circular mechanics. Tommi Keränen mastered this and he made it sound intimate, which is nice for a record of this type. At 45 minutes it's a solid album and 'Dog Ceasearian', the 24 minute closing track, is a total circus, starting slow and getting into every imaginable interaction. Wiese chooses sounds that are metallic and edgy but fit well with saxophone - percussive in nature, and as usual he works the stereo field quite well so this is a good one for headphones (like all of his records). [21 December 2012]


Date: 1 October 2009

Vermillion Sands - Mary

Label: Rijapov

Format: 7"

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

I'm glad VT had one copy of this left because this has become an 'all-time favorite' for the 7" format, though I have only known it through some MP3s I downloaded.  Vermillion Sands are an Italian pop-psych band that have the bouncy, catchy singing found in bands like Jennifer Gentle but with a slightly more garagey, less proggy sound.  That description may sound average but these three songs are so phenomenal that they transcend everything.  If these guys can keep it up with subsequent output then they will be a truly great band - retro, sure, but also full of youthful energy and a deep understanding of great music that comes through in the songwriting.  And if they don't follow this up with anything, then they've still released a truly classic 7".  [1 Oct 2009]



Date: 1 October 2009

Rosemary Krust - 

Label: Spleencoffin

Format: 7"

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

I wanted to check this band out for awhile cause they sounded right up my alley - hazy, dirty male/female psychedelic folk, but not in a New Weird America vibe so much as a more down to earth, innocent sound (or maybe I was hoping they'd be like Tuob).  It doesn't disappoint, with searing electric guitars, murky yet sugary vocals and a genuine ambience that comes of as unaffected and complex beyond its apparent simplicity.  The moments of gentle folkstrum are perfect for the 7" format and recall some early 90s underground that I've probably imagined.  The noisy bits aren't really noise, just low-energy psychedelia.  Definitely this is a band to look for more by.  [5 Oct 2009]



Date: 1 October 2009

Chris Corsano - Another Dull Dawn

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

Another dull dawn, another Corsano solo album.  Not that he has that many.  This is along the same idea of The Lonesome Cricketer or whatever it was called, but sounding slightly more hi-fi (perhaps because everything sounds better on vinyl).  Over 15 tracks, Chris moves around from solo drums to little instruments, with a few surprising diversions.  "Kittenish Gnawing, part 2" is on a toy gamelan and it's played somewhat crudely, yet there's still a fantastic set of overtones.  There are some noisy scrapers, like part 1 of the aforementioned piece or 'The Frayed Elevator Cable", which sound like the more power electronics side of Burning Star Core.  When he's just playing drums, it's pretty great too - clattery energetic but with that distinctly narrative Chris Corsano style.  This actually is a bit of an odd release for Dennis to put out because it does adhere so much closer to traditional "improv" records, despite the unconventional instrumentation and the focus on short pieces.  Yet maybe he's onto something, for while this is a document of one of the world's most talented percussionists, I would never file this alongside solo Andrew Cyrile or Milford Graves records - this ain't jazz, it's just music.  [7 Feb 2010]



Date: 1 October 2009

PC Worship - NYC Stone Age

Label: Shdwply

Format: LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

This record, made solo by one Justin Frye, is a song-based enterprise, a testament to late 00's bedroom-recorded psychedelia. Frye does a pretty good job of maintaining clarity in the songs - so the detuned electric guitars can go in their different directions and it doesn't interfere with the rhythmic swing. There aren't really any hooks here, and the songs tends to feel like improvisations - as a listener, I'm most impressed by the texture, construction and atmosphere, not any sort of lyrical basis. At some point I wonder if leaving some of the layers behind might benefit the record more - allowing the ideas to breathe, because there is something being expressed with words and melodies underneath, and instead of some artists who fuck up their songs like this, I'm not really pulled towards them. The artifice of a song can be dramatic, or mysterious, or contradictory, and all of those things are good - these deconstructions often lend a mystery, but instead of making NYC Stone Age feel like a treasure map, the mess on top of these songs just makes them feel like aborted experiments. Which is not in itself bad, but it doesn't really inspire me or even leave any effect on me. [22 August 2012]


Date: 1 October 2009

Eat Skull - Wild And Inside

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

I loved this record when it came out cause it found a perfect balance between sloppy, bedroom-recorded neo-punk stuff and really impressive songcraft. I liked their first album lots too, but this one seemed to take a huge leap forward, most obviously incorporating Kiwi/NZ pop influences into the songwriting. A few songs sound exactly like early Clean, and I can't complain about that. Now it's a few years later and I haven't played it in awhile, and the quirks and charms are slightly less inspiring, but I still think this is a pretty solid record. [28 November 2012]


Date: 1 October 2009

Idea Fire Company - Beauty School

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

Two side-long explorations of the Idea Fire Compay's unique sound environments. 'Buzzbomb', despite it's title, is very low-key and has distended voices which eventually disappear into a cryptic, evil piano figure. It's distant, haunting, like the solo Mark Hollis piano track on the Allinson/Brown disc. The title track on side two begins with the most insanely wet, inviting sea of ambient tremolo Idea Fire Co.'s yet laid down. As the title might indicate, this is pure ear candy - an exploration of sonic beauty, a sleepwalk through the 20 minutes that it lasts. This is maybe not the most representational release for these guys, but maybe the most pleasant one to get lost in. [17 December 2012]


Date: 18 October 2009

J.J. Cale - Okie

Label: Shelter Recording Company Inc.

Format: Vinyl

Source: Blochairn car boot sale

Cost: £0.5

J.J. Cale is one of those guys I always thought I should get into because I have a real soft spot for rootsy Americana rock, like the Band and more countryish leaning stuff. Okie is considered one of his best albums and I've listened to it a few times over the past few years, and always enjoyed it, but never been totally blown away by anything. There's no J.J. Cale song I've heard where I've been, like, 'Oh my god holy shit' or anything close to that. But the songs here are all solid, and feel a bit underwritten, or underexpressed maybe - everything is fairly casual, and it's hard to imagine what sort of vision Cale must have had going into the recording session. [21 August 2012]


Date: 18 October 2009

Dead Kennedys - Bedtime For Democracy

Label: Alternative Tentacles

Format: Vinyl

Source: Blochairn car boot sale

Cost: £1.5

Not a bad find for £1.5, though the condition is pretty battered. The last DK's record is packed with songs (21!) and a pretty decent last effort, though it lacks any ultra memorable "classic" status tunes. The production is good and there's a balance here between thrashy hardcore and somewhat more, well, lyrical songs. 'Chickenshit Conformist' is probably the best tune but East Bay Ray's 'Do the Slag' is certainly the most fun. You can hear the DK's striving for a bit more musical variety here, though I would never call them unsophisticated, even going back to Fresh Fruit. Missing the 'Fuck Facts' newspaper, sadly, but it's a car boot sale so what can you do? [25 July 2012]


Date: 20 October 2009

Glasgow Improvisers Orchestras - GIO Poetics

Label: Creative Sources Recordings

Format: CD

Source: Neil Davidson

Cost: £2



Date: 20 October 2009

Aporias Trio - Entre Nous

Label: Iorram

Format: CD

Source: Neil Davidson

Cost: £2

Raymond and Neil are joined by Tatsuya Nakatani, who I had the pleasure of seeing live once with Jack Wright back in Kentucky. His flamboyant, wiry approach to percussion translates well into Neil's thoughtful bumps and Raymond's furtive squawks. It's unceasing in it's explorations - resisting the idea of 'gelling', with each member pushing apart from the others. Because of that, there's actually a lot of space but the patterns shift so fast it's hard to focus. When they're all scraping and grinding it becomes fairly mad, but mad is often wonderful and at the best parts it's exactly that - invigorating, alive. [29 December 2012]


Date: 20 October 2009

Raymond MacDonald, Satoko Fujii, Neil Davidson, Natsuki Tamura, Tom Bancroft - Cities

Label: Nu-jazz

Format: CD

Source: Neil Davidson

Cost: £2

A meeting of several Glasgow musicans and two Japanese ones, recorded just before I moved to Glasgow but not released until I left. Neil tends to get buried here a bit, and when the piano is playing along with Raymond it becomes pretty 'jazz'. The sparse parts, like 'Two Blocks East', feature the Neil Davidson I know and love. I think this was recorded at a live concert, cause when it gets quiet the space of the room actually overwhelms the tiny plucks and reverberations of the percussion and of Neil's guitar. Raymond has some nice licks and I like this best when they play gently but not so idiomatically. 'Euphoria', which closes the disc, is a really slow circular breathing workout that serves to diversify an already-diverse album. This goes into the pile of improvised music CDs, hundreds of which come out every year, that are all pretty good but easily ignored. It's sad to say that because these musicians really dedicate themselves to continual innovation and mastery of their craft, yet even fans of stuff like this, like myself, struggle to stay interested in it all. [16 July 2012]


Date: 20 October 2009

Una MacGlone / Nick Fells / Neil Davidson - PrÃ³ximo

Label: Iorram

Format: CDr 

Source: Neil Davidson

Cost: £2

Neil started this CDr label last time I was in Glasgow and had a few lovely releases to begin, built around the idea of boats or something like that - I forget exactly. This release is really a Nick Fells outing, where Nick is on laptop and joined by Neil on track 1 and Una on track 2. The Neil/Nick cut is zany and bouncy, changing tack pretty frequently and with a big open-room space that allows the various what-the-fuck sounds to really reverberate. I'm not sure if Fells is processing Neil or if he's generating his own sounds - some of Neil's bizarre guitar sounds are clear, but in general I'm kept guessing. By the end it's a battle of chaotic feedback and static, though all still in a fairly "small" sounding way. When Una joins, it takes some time to get going, and the sound is all thick bowed bass, with the laptop echoing it and swirling it about. It's a soft, wet mess of low-end to rest in. It gets bumpier and ultimately builds into a wall of wooden sound. [25 July 2012]


Date: 20 October 2009

Ernesto Rodrigues / Neil Davidson / Guilherme Rodrigues / HernÃ ni Faustino - Fowerw

Label: Creative Sources Recordings

Format: CD

Source: Neil Davidson

Cost: £2

Neil Davidson had a fertile time in Portugal, where he recorded this all-string CD. There's occasions when it's clear what is the cello and what is the double bass but not many; Neil's guitar sounds often like feedback as he's probably playing with the rotating stick I've seen him do so many times; elsewhere there is prepared moments, rumbling grabbing fighting, and general improvised interplay. I love strange strings and this is very much that - it's good all the way through as invigorating improvisations go. Nothing is too fierce but it isn't boring either, if you've come to listen. [25 December 2012]


Date: 20 October 2009

King Crimson - Starless And Bible Black

Label: Polydor

Format: Vinyl

Source: Daniel

Cost: £2.5

I'm a bad Crimson fan - not a fan at all, really, but I like smart prog-rock enough to enjoy a few of these albums. I always get this one mixed up with Larks Tongues in Aspic which I think I like more, because it has the extra percussionist on it and that totally amazing opening track. But this is pretty decent too; anything with Bruford on it, really, is remarkable,and I particularly like when David Cross adds violin/viola, because it helps to fight that constant riffing/Don Cab feel that it takes on. John Wetton's singing I basically tune out and enjoy the music. Side two are longer pieces, instrumental thankfully, that verge between exploratory push-and-pull to lockstep melodic reinforcement. [2 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2009

Volcano The Bear - The Shy Volcanic Society At The Bear And Bird Parade

Label: Beta-lactam Ring Records

Format: CD

Source: Daniel

Cost: £2.5

I never really listened to this split CD between VTB and LaSTPO, which is misleading titled as a collaboration. VTB have the first 5 tracks, and they're mostly instrumental - sparse, spacious scraping in a free-improv vein, really indistinguishable from a lot of the free-folk things happening at the time though culturally not part of that scene at all. 'The Open, The Closed, and the God-Like Shutter' is VTB at their most Third Ear Band-worshipping, but recorded in a way that really lets the mood ring out. The second half of the disc is the Frenchies, a band whom I sort of like in theory but then never actually want to listen to. There's a similarity to VTB in terms of rumbling, anarchic acoustic-based fuckery, but the vocals are exaggerated and French, with heavy breathing and grunting. The tunes are okay though, and I supposed this is a good, cohesive pairing; at least the production and sound approach by LaSTPO is better than the horrible computer-rendered artwork which adorns the CD gatefold here (thankfully they let Laurence's stuff appear on the outer covers). [30 July 2012]


Date: 24 October 2009

One Ensemble Orchestra - Other Thunders

Label: No-Fi

Format: CD

Source: Daniel

Cost: £2.5

Other Thunders was a special project commissioned for a festival where Daniel expanded his band to include two bass clarinetists and two vocalists. I never saw the concerts but this was all underway while I was living with him so it's weird that I don't know this music at all. One of the vocalists is my good friend Giles and the other is Thom War, so this should feel like old friends gathering around. But it doesn't, at all. The compositions are slow, drawn out and open towards long vocal harmonies. This gives it a chamber-music like vibe, helped along by the bass clarinets and Peter's cello. When the vocals really take over in 'The Sun' it provides the most compelling moment of the project, attaining a sacred harp singers quality. The room really resonates here and there's an intensity without being too formal. Closing cut 'The Words' uses a lack thereof to create a dissonant ball of trepidation, leaving the whole thing to end in an unsettling manner. [25 December 2012]


Date: 24 October 2009

David Bowie - Low

Label: RCA

Format: Vinyl

Source: Daniel

Cost: £2.5

Bowie's celebrated for the trilogy of Low, Heroes and Lodger, and rightly so. But Low is split between an album of classic, almost ridiculously good pop songs and an atmospheric, mostly instrumental second half. The mood is thus split, and one only feels properly 'low' at the end, especially after 'Subterraneans' which is wonderful. The songs on side 1 are deservedly winners, with Eno's fingerprints everywhere. It's a true vision of a new, cold, detached modern pop music that reeks of Britain's 70s and the towers of concrete and glass that now define our landscapes. [28 September 2012]


Date: 30 October 2009

Helm - Direct Landscapes/Monuments

Label: Tone Filth

Format: C20

Source: Luke Younger

Cost: £0



Date: 1 November 2009

Kodama - Turning Leaf Migrations

Label: Olde English Spelling Bee

Format: Vinyl

Source: Michael Northam

Cost: £10

I first heard this when I downloaded it after reading a rave review from Dylan Nyoukis and I can see what he likes about it - it's a thick, exploratory soundworld with some beautiful drones (particularly on side 1), but it isn't afraid to get really weird, as the numerous short tracks on side 2 attest. I didn't realise that Koji was in this band until I actually ran into him at Colour Out of Space, where Kodama performed, and then it made a bit more sense. Anyway, there's a natural feel to the drone, but the calm is undercut by some malevolance under the surface; it's beautifully, precisely recorded and as full-fledged psychedelic listening experiences go, it's a cut above the rest. [13 July 2012]


Date: 1 November 2009

Aster - 

Label: R.E.L Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Eli Keszler

Cost: £10

Aster is a duo of Eli Keszler and his girlfriend Ashley, with Eli's usual percussion-based soundworld and her on saxophone, clarinet and other things. This is a very high-pitched record, with lots of shrill explorations, but it reveals itself to be a masterful set of improvisations. When I saw Eli live, he had an incredible sense of momentum, but here it's more about exploring space, and the take their time getting there. In some ways it's like a bizarro version of Trevor and Sara, as couples on similar instrumentation, except where Ara is often fuzzy and smoky, Aster is in-your-face and clean. [25 August 2012]


Date: 1 November 2009

Eli Keszler - Tilt

Label: REL

Format: CD

Source: Eli Keszler

Cost: £2

Eli chucked this CD in when I bought his LP, being the great guy that he is, and for some reason I listened to this first.  This is a relatively short disc of Eli's experimental solo percussion.  A standard drumset (I think) is made into a buzzing, kinetic ball of electricity through the application of metal discs, bows, and who knows what else.  The sound is rich - this is recorded very well, recalling the intimacy of the first time I saw him live - and it moves in about 8 different directions in a relatively short runtime.  The packaging is lovely, with a very handmade feel and a focus on the disc as an art object, whcih is pretty nice if you can't get it on vinyl.  This isn't the most spacious recording but I suspect Eli would be great in a delicate improv setting, and I hope we can one day play together.  [23 Nov 2009]



Date: 1 November 2009

Sunshine Variety - Embla Quickbeam

Label: none

Format: CDr

Source: Rowan Forestier-Walker

Cost: £0



Date: 1 November 2009

Carl Holmes - The Occult Establishment

Label: none

Format: CDr

Source: Carl Holmes (I guess?)

Cost: £0



Date: 1 November 2009

Moniek Darge - Soundies (selected work 1980-2001)

Label: Kye

Format: CD

Source: CooS merch table

Cost: £10



Date: 2 November 2009

Astral Social Club - Model Town In A Field Of Mud

Label: Textile Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Neil Campbell

Cost: €0

Neil left this LP for me when he played at Ptarmigan (sadly, I was out of Finland at the time and didn't get to see him) and it's a pretty great document of Astral Social Club, a project which (in typical Neil Campbell fashion) he's released a shitload of stuff by and which is constantly evolving.  This is billed as a full-fleged collaboration between John Clyde Evans, though I'll always think of this as Neil's thing; indeed, the tracks are so dominated by either one or the other that it feels a bit schizo. Parts of this record mark a huge step away from the Vibracathedral drone and towards a more deconstructed electronica-influenced sound, particularly in track #2, 'Hydroponix' (the Kompakt label is a huge influence on Neil and you can hear it here in the repetitive electronica and glitchyness). As soon as I say that, some wonderful, loose organic plucking beigins 'Crex Fucking Crex', which is obviously Clyde-Evans or Tirath Singh Nirmala or whatever he's called. But a beauteous drone it is, and Neil brings in an electronic edge to create a mesmerising batch of sound. Side two follows the same format - opening glitchyness followed by extended jam, but this time, the longer jam completely succumbs to the digital pressure. It doesn't hold a candle to 'Crex Fucking Crex' but it's still an impressive workout from these Loiners. [15 July 2012]


Date: 2 November 2009

Alog / Astral Social Club - Split #20

Label: Fat Cat

Format: 12"

Source: Neil Campbell

Cost: €0

An interesting pairing here. Side 1 is Alog, the Rune Grammafon artist who do a gently moving bit of electronic renaissance, with anthemic chants and the slow creep of computer-sound static. Under all of this, guitars swing back and forth like construction workers, until the weird vocals take over. Astral Social Club on the other side is definitely much more in the electronic realm as well, compared to some of the more John Clyde-Evans dominated work on the other releases. The three tracks here are very much in the German vibe that Neil digs so much. [2 Aug 2012]


Date: 20 November 2009

Ã„änijännite - EP

Label: none

Format: CDr

Source: Guy from the band

Cost: €0

This band left keyboards in Jyväskylä and they asked Tommi Keränen to pick them up.  He left them here and then they called me to come get them. When they came to get them, they gave me their CDr, which I thought was nice. Will I ever actually listen to it?



Date: 21 November 2009

Hevoset - Hevoset

Label: Dekorder

Format: Vinyl

Source: Jani Hirvonen

Cost: €0

Traded for the Boat Trip LP, when I get them. [2009] A meeting of Finnish underground personalities (Jan + Jani), this record sounds pretty much what you'd expect - like Uton on top of Tomutonttu. Maybe it's a bit more on the folky side, but then strange, broken toy synths will take over and destroy the vibe as soon as it starts to feel comfy. There's possibly some tension between their two approaches as this record never completely gels, but it doesn't attempt to widen the tension either, which leaves it feeling a bit unsatisfying to my ears. [26 December 2012]



Date: 21 November 2009

Uton - Mental Connections

Label: Housecraft Records

Format: CDr

Source: Jani Hirvonen

Cost: €0



Date: 3 December 2009

Satoru Wono - Sauvage

Label: Sonore

Format: 12" EP

Source: Franck Stofer

Cost: €0

Experimental Japanese electronica is not usually my thing but I kinda like this record because it's built mostly from static, sounding at points like my stylus is going nuts. There's a regular rhythm throughout, the whole "clicks and cuts" thing, but it's infused with a nervousness that puts it on my wavelength. When other sounds come in - synth/organ for moments, it starts to take on the more clichéd sound of the genre for me, but luckily this is only for glimpses. A quick listen at 45rpm, and the grooves have beautiful visible patterns in them, just like all those Brinkmann 12"s I have. [25 July 2012]


Date: 15 December 2009

Graham Lambkin - Softly Softly Copy Copy

Label: Kye

Format: CD

Source: Penultimate Press

Cost: £12

Lambkin's followup to Salmon Run is a much more placid, deep-listening collage. It's like a box of objects underwater, or more accurately like the scene in Tarkovsky's Stalker where the flowing water covers the rusty artefacts. Though evenly divided in terms of time, SSCC consists of many small, episodic pieces that form together into  whole. When my solo LP came out, one or two reviews compared it to this, and of course I was honored as Lambkin is a huge influence, though this actually came out after Boat Trip was finished. A sense of mystery covers everything, though the more alien sounds (the "Swill Radio" parts of the disc) pale when compared to the delicate strangeness of the every day, often accentuated by the tiniest details in the listening distance. [6 November 2012]


Date: 7 January 2010

John W. Fail - The 15,000 Day Boat Trip

Label: 8mm

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Luca/8mm

Cost: €0

Starting the year with my own LP!  It's weird writing a review of it.  I got 30 copies in the post from Luca finally and they look and sound GREAT.  Really, really great.  I am extremely happy with this.  The low end just booms off the vinyl.  I am totally excited about making records again and I want to get back to work on the next one.



Date: 7 January 2010

Maniacs Dream - Turku Hold'Em

Label: Lal Lal Lal

Format: CD

Source: Roope Eronen

Cost: €0

This is a super dense, kind of hard-to-listen to Maniacs Dream release.  I thought Zanzibar was a suprisingly gritty, chunky blast of improv but this is even more extreme.  The opening track is really long (like, over 45 minutes til I stopped noticing) and sounds like a bunch of ritalin-needing kids making noise without much pause for space or interaction.  But there's something about it that makes it a cut above the ilk.  The songs are weird, not really identifiable as any particular instruments beyond percussion and synths, but it's more the way they are played.  It's jerky and start-stop but in a fluid way, if that makes any sense.  Which it probably doesn't, which is probably the best way to describe Maniacs Dream.  Turku Hold'Em is an awesome title. [16 Feb 2009]



Date: 7 January 2010

Munuaussymposium 1960 / Maniacs Deam - split

Label: Lal Lal Lal

Format: 7"

Source: Roope Eronen

Cost: €0



Date: 7 January 2010

Maniacs Dream - Zanzibar

Label: Arbor

Format: Vinyl

Source: Roope Eronen

Cost: €0

This is a long re-release of a cassette tape that features Maniacs Dream in their most gritty, herky jerky spazz rock mode.  It's a long way from the Faust Tapes like sound of the HP Cycle one or the conceptual weirdness of their live show, but i dig it.  There's parts that remind me of dense, jammy noise rock stuff like what you'd hear on Load records, but with strange synths and clearly non-instrument sounds that I image are probably Tero smacking pieces of wood against buckets or something random.  There's a great deal of rhythm to it, though not the kind of rhythm that you can actually follow; likewise the recording is blown out but not overly so.  I wonder if this is named after that super weird nightclub in Talinn that Tara and I had a drink at?  I will have to ask. [8 Feb 2010]



Date: 7 January 2010

Topias Tiheäsalo - Eyes Of A Dead Lamb

Label: Tyyfus

Format: CD

Source: Topias Tiheäsalo

Cost: €0



Date: 7 January 2010

Amon Düde and The Hoopo / Nuslux - Split

Label: Not On Label

Format: Vinyl

Source: Roope Eronen

Cost: €0

Arttu's Amon Düde project is always a good time and this collab with the Hoopo follows. It's a brainless, idiotic bit of weird fuckery with flanged, phased percussion and bizarre electronic singing. In one side of a 7" it somehow feels like a whole hour. Roope continues the electricity on the B-side, with some shrill, squirting sounds, carnivalesque chords, and circular metallic resonance. It's dazzling, certain with intent and with a perfectionist tendency that I rarely see in the live sets. [17 December 2012]


Date: 8 January 2010

Second Family / Anla Courtis - Gangun Guru

Label: Chocolate Monk

Format: CDr

Source: Alan Courtis

Cost: €0



Date: 9 January 2010

Fricara Pacchu - Lucy

Label: Vauva

Format: 7"

Source: Jan Anderzen

Cost: €0



Date: 9 January 2010

The Puke Eaters - Y. M. I. Dead? / Flesh Descending

Label: Vauva

Format: Vinyl

Source: Jan Anderzen

Cost: €0

The Puke Eaters succeed with everything they try. 'Y.M.I. Dead?' puts a solid, ominous beat behind some rabid high-register clanging and a distant screaming voice. The sentiment is more goofy than morbid, almost like a mockery of dark, gothic music. 'Flesh Descending' is more akin to the Tomotonttu style of bending, warbly rhythms with overlapping thick layers. This is incredibly unsettling, constantly evading comprehension while still being based around repetition - one of the Puke Eaters' finest tracks yet. [10 December 2012]


Date: 9 January 2010

Tsembla - Tuplafiesta

Label: Vauva

Format: Vinyl

Source: Jan Anderzen

Cost: €0

This Tsembla release is awesome. Marja uses many of the same tools that others in that scene employ - strange loops, warped voices, variable speed melody fragments, alien percussion samples - but assembles it all with a compositional balance that welcomes while still being extremely fucking strange. 'Myrskyn Juhla' has a beautiful decaying carnival feel, and the long piece on side B is paradoxically dense and light, a real piece of magic. [10 December 2012]


Date: 9 January 2010

Tomutonttu - Untitled

Label: Peippo

Format: Vinyl

Source: Jan Anderzen

Cost: €0

Another untitled Tomutonttu record, and this 10" is a pleasure.  Side one begins with some singing, but buried in the usual weird Jan-fidelity.  The tunes are melodic and rhythmic, but just off-kilter enough.  The everything-falling-apart fuckedupness that I've heard from him before (on his Ultra Eczema LP, and the few live sets I've seen) isn't present here, but there's still enough skittery movement to keep this from being too feelgood.  There's some great Indian/eastern timbres ringing through a few tracks (most notably the end of side 1) and a fairly dirgy march bit on side 2 that is strangely beautiful and moving, though not compromising the Tomotonttu sound one bit.  Overall this has a fairly more somber approach than other recordings I've heard, but it's still a ton of fun.  [4 July 2010]



Date: 9 January 2010

Avarus - IV

Label: Secret Eye Records / Ikuisuus

Format: Vinyl

Source: Roope Eronen

Cost: €10
