Roope traded me this and I figured since I hang out with these guys all the time now, I should probably try to start liking their music.  This is two jammy sides that sound pretty much like they did live - like a ramshackle, noodly space-rock band.  The pieces are held together by Jukka's basslines which are repetitive and rhythmic, and occasionally they're actually catchy.  I'm still not really that wild about this, though.  At the beginning of side two, things become a bit more fluid - the electronic whirrs and whooshes take over for a bit, but the music keeps shuffling along.  There is something really "shuffly" about this, actually.  I wonder if Jukka is the presence that actually pulls them into a more accessible direction.  The first time i saw them live, before I knew anyone except Arttu, he wasn't there, and granted it was at Magneetti, but it was a million times more messy and fucked up than anything I've heard since.  I should try to get into this more, if only to prove the rule that it's hard to really dislike music when you are friends with the creators.  [16 Jan 2010]



Date: 9 January 2010

The Puke Eaters - Hello Valhalla

Label: Skulls Of Heaven / Lal Lal Lal

Format: Vinyl

Source: Erkki Sinnemäki

Cost: €0

The Puke Eaters (Erkki and Jan), here augmented by Chris Corsano, have turned in what may be the most rewarding single album from the whole recent Finnish underground (at least from what I've heard).  Viewed as a sum of its parts, you can hear how the Reijo Pami and Tomotonttu sounds combine, and if Corsano is the one on the more percussive bits, then he's successfully unlearned everything he knows. The tracks are fairly short, just two to three minutes of sound exploration, but there's a focused vision to each track rather than a jammy, exploratory mess.  I particularly like the juxtaposition of (very nicely recorded) acoustic textures with nervous, semi-inept clattering.  The sense of movement is great here, and whenever there's delay/reverb effects used, it's natural and you barely notice them (or at least you don't think "That's a delay pedal").  Brilliantly strange stuff, but the personnel is top-notch.  [6 July 2010]



Date: 10 January 2010

The New Monuments - 

Label: Important

Format: LP

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: €0

This is a trio of Spencer, Don Dietrich and Ben Hall and as imagined it sounds like a cross between the Hall/Dietrich Spitfire LP and the duo of Don and Spencer that I caught last year at a small show in Manhattan. Spencer's violin and electronics tends to recede amongst Dietrich's blasting and Hall's nonstop rumble; the constant force of the drumming puts this quite firmly into the free jazz-leaning camp as opposed to the more Borbeto- stylings that can happen with more breathing room. A beautiful thick pressing with a silk-screened cover of Dietrich's art, which is suitable for this odd mishmash. [19 August 2012]


Date: 10 January 2010

White Out / Giffoni / Yeh - Live At No Fun

Label: No Fun Productions

Format: Vinyl

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: €0

Side A of this is short, a creepying excursion into electronic netherregions by Spencer and Carlos, which becomes slowly taken over by White Out's more jazz-based approach. By the end of the side, it's all Tom Surgal, who generally dominates the record. On the flip we get nervous violin work to start, and Surgal seems to struggle at first in feeling this out. It resembles a 'drum solo' too often but Carlos isn't content with that, so you can hear him working in all sorts of subtle electronic effects to gradually alter the mood. But this too, is over in a blink of an eye - this is really an EP if anything. [29 November 2012]


Date: 10 January 2010

C. Spencer Yeh and Taiga Remains - Winter 2009

Label: Callow God

Format: Cassette

Source: Spencer Yeh

Cost: €0



Date: 13 February 2010

Kiila - Tuota Tuota

Label: Fonal Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Niko-Matti

Cost: €0

Traded a boat trip LP. This 'band' version of Kiila is a lot different from the CD that I got years ago. Instead of being all about Niko-Matti, it's a cohesive band unit with fleshed-out arrangements, rocking instrumental jams, and lots of vocal harmonies. Niko-Matti is still the principle songwriter but it's anchored by an organic core, which is lovely when Jari, Jukka and Jaakko take the jams into a more Krautrock style (which is only present a bit here at the end of side 1, compared to the live show which was much jammier). Pekko Käppi's kantele really sets a dark, folky base, and there are a lot of guests from the scene; Topias, Antti Tolvi, and Lau Nau (who lays down some beautiful vocals at the beginning of side 2). [23 December 2012]



Date: 15 February 2010

Feelies - The Good Earth

Label: Bar/None Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Popparienkeli

Cost: €18.5

Agent Strohm tipped me off a few months ago that this vinyl reissue was coming, so I unloaded my CD on eBay and waited for this.  I actually forgot about it so when I saw it for sale at this random record store I jumped at the chance to get it, because my record collection without The Good Earth is just not complete.  The reissue is nicely done - it's not overblown, with the bonus tracks saved for digital download (which is just the covers from the No One Knows EP and a live version of 'Slipping into Something').  The liner notes are lovely; it's some great writing about the slow maturation process that led to this masterpiece, and the suggestion that it's a bit misunderstood as being too Peter Buck-influenced.  I do love this album so much.  It merges a strummy, jangly 80's college-rock sensibility with Americana, impressionism, and still a trace of the post-punk energy (heard mostly in the guitar solos, which the liner notes point out are quite influenced by Tom Verlaine).  The songs feel more suggested than written, and there's just the right level of understatement, akin to Bedhead (who I think took their sound on CDEP 19:10 from this record directly).  I get chills when I listen to 'When Company Comes' every time, and on 180gram vinyl it sounds totally fantastic.  Rich, high frequencies and a deep bed of vocals - thank god this finally is in my collection on the proper format.  [15 Feb 2010]



Date: 16 February 2010

Vitamin B12 - Untitled

Label: Not On Label

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: €105.6

I paid a lot for this but it's really rare, and the only Vitamin B12 record that anyone really finds 'collectible'. This is Alasdair's debut release, from the late 80's, a massive 4LP collection of songs, fragments and experiments. Compared to the B12 that I know and love, it's wildly different and very straight. There's still a very singular vision at play but some tracks fall into genre experiments much more. Certain tracks (all are untitled) remind me of 90s post-rock like Fridge, and others sound like Bügsküll. But it gets weirder as it goes along; at the end of the second record it starts to get into bizarre cutup logic, which is more like the B12 I know. This is so massive to listen to - but surprisingly diverse, so spending two and a half hours doesn't get tiresome. It's probably mostly solo Alasdair, but who really knows? There's some female vocals in a few places and the song structures are pretty solid. In many ways this might be seen as a transition between what he was interested in and what he solidified his focus towards, though 'solidified' is entirely the wrong word to use when talking about something as exploratory as the B12. I'm not sure how I managed to spend so much on something but it's a true jewel and probably will never be reissued, so thank god for eBay. [24 December 2012]


Date: 8 March 2010

Taco Bells - Vadelma/Hawaii

Label: Ikuisuus

Format: Vinyl

Source: Sami Pekkola

Cost: €0

Traded for a Boat Trip LP. 'Vadelma' brings out the 'bell' in Taco Bells, as Sami's horn brutally dominates, and that's despite everyone else trying their best to take control. It only stops to recharge a few times, but the crazy violin bowing (played by Pekko Käppi), too low in the mix, recalls Ayler's band circa '66 and Jaakko Tolvi drums with the furiousness and intensity of two men. 'Hawaii' replaces Pekko with a guitarist and follows more or less the same course, though there's a few parts where it's just drums and a few plucked guitar notes and maybe I feel the Hawaiian theme there. [24 December 2012]



Date: 8 March 2010

Paavi - Untitled

Label: Lal Lal Lal

Format: Vinyl

Source: Erkki Sinnemäki

Cost: €0

This mysterious release is solo Erkki Sinnemäki, aka Reijo Pami, and it's a dense blast of minimalism that sounds like an early Richard Youngs experiment gone mad. Most of the record is Erkki banging on a piano (after the smooth opening movement) and it's a relentless cloud that grabs and never lets go. Different movements come and go throughout the tinkling and it's quite remarkable as a whole - a really great, great record. It's mostly dissonant, but the overtones eventually ascend into a haze that is inviting. The A-side stretches forever and then the B-side changes tone, but only a little bit. It's Erkki's theatre of eternal music, and it's successful at lasting forever. [20 December 2012]


Date: 16 March 2010

Love Cry Want - Love Cry Want

Label: Weird Forest Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15

This is a mammoth, towering beast of psychedelic jazz-rock, somehow spilling into every imaginable corner of fusion without committing any aesthetic transgressions. If you like big guitar solos, big organ solos, and big drum solos, it's all here. The record is aptly named - it's simultaneously passionate and evil, full of raging desire and nihilistic  vitriol at the same moment. The tracks are long and jammy, and they stretch out through various studio effects (even the drums sound processed), reminding me of a logarithmic take on the first Tony Williams' Lifetime album. Which is fair enough, as organist Larry Young played on that record, and also on Bitches Brew, but this takes everything to a further level of 'out'. The opening cut, 'Peace', really does feel like an introduction, as it's fluid and expansive, taking it's time and introducing the musicians in a non-corny way. Other cuts, like side 3, are crunchy and aggressive; repetition is used to keep the musicians playing at each other, pushing along a groove through almost subterranean tactics. There's more ring-modulated guitar here than an early 00's Dead C album, and despite all the chaos, there's a lot here to reward patience. [28 November 2012]


Date: 16 March 2010

Bill Orcutt - A New Way To Pay Old Debts

Label: Palilalia

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15

Exhilarating, aggressive and burning with a fierce edge like almost nothing else I can compare it to -- Orcutt's first solo album revisits the mad freedom of his Harry Pussy buzzsaw but through an amped up acoustic guitar. Before I heard this, I saw him play live with Paul Hessian in Brighton and it was an amazing interplay of free guitar that kept it's freedom within very strict boundaries. On his own, it's even better - the spaces and silences between his handchops give it a structure and momentum that no doubt came from a dedicated vision that took many years to unfold. Orcutt's put out a few more since but nothing has quite had the impact, the out-of-nowhere mindfuck, the gravitas, as this. As gritty as this is, it's a surprisingly everyday guitar masterpiece - it always seems to fit my mood. [15 July 2012]


Date: 16 March 2010

Ducktails - Landscapes

Label: Olde English Spelling Bee

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: €15

Easy psychedelia is still a nice world to inhabit and I've always liked Ducktails and Matt personally. This record is so pleasant it's impossible to say anything bad about it except maybe to criticise it for taking the easy road. But this is the style he works in - light breezes, gentle strums, straight-forward rhythms, yet something still a bit strange about it all. The guy has a vision, and it's a well-constructed one, and I've listened to this quite frequently over the last few years when looking for something relaxing but not completely minimal. Bugskull is a good comparison, though I don't know if he's ever listened to Bugskull. [29 November 2012]


Date: 20 March 2010

Mohel - Babylon Bypass

Label: Tyyfus

Format: Vinyl

Source: Sami Pekkola

Cost: €13

Mohel is one of the finest in Finnish free jazz, and their three-sax attack is as brutal on record as it is live. Taneli is on tenor here, because Janne Martinkauppi is on bariton, and the two drummers (Jaakko and Petri) are ferocious as well. But despite the full-steam-ahead aesthetic, this doesn't sound anything like old ESP releases or whatnot. Side 1, the lovely doubly-negatively titled 'There Will Never Be No Peace', has some bursts of human air through brass that are so aggressive they almost tear the speakers out - the rage and frustration of the title carries through. How I miss these live shows; seeing aggressive free jazz in Estonia is such a rarity that I should probably think about traveling over to Helsinki more for it. [29 November 2012]


Date: 20 March 2010

Boris Morgana - Muuan sali

Label: Boriksen Kirja ja Kassu

Format: cassette

Source: Juuso Paaso

Cost: €3

Boris Morgana were the first friends I made in Helsinki, so it's odd that I don't really have any of their recordings. This tape finds them trying different things, rooted around a rock around. Side B begins with a shrieking, crazy vocal track over some solid riffage. The more Kraut/art-rock tendencies take some time to emerge here, but they are also covered in some vocal madness - harmonies of pure pain, a bunch of Finns emoting together something dark and strange. The 70's vibe is dominant, especially when Hermanni and Taneli add the violin and sax to the mix. If my primitive Finnish isn't too rusty I think this title means "Hall of some others" which is appropriate for the sense of distance and unbelonging conveyed. [30 December 2012]


Date: 23 March 2010

Eat Skull - Jerusalem Mall

Label: Woodsist

Format: 7"

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £0

Eat Skull's followup to the fantastic Wild and Inside is a fairly plodding hard-rock song with heavy bass thumping and ecstatic electric guitar solos.  The lo-fi sound is scorching but it's over in a minute 45 or so, and I've learned nothing.  Side B is where the brilliant buried pop hooks emerge -- 'Dont Leave Me on the Speaker - Thank you!' has a great 60's retro strum vibe and just a perfectly calculated level of fuzz.  It's catchy with some Phil Spector guitar hooks and an example of what I love about Eat Skull.  'Smokebreaks' is a faster, manic jam with some confused bashing about.  [5 April 2010]



Date: 23 March 2010

Jailbreak - The Rocker

Label: Family Vineyard

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15

Jailbreak was Heather and Corsano, and it's a lot more punk/aggro than I expected, cause Heather's blasting her pedal steel through some wicked distortion. She keeps a consistently nasty tone throughout, and when she solos (as on side two) it's a really mesmerising and evil sound. Corsano keeps it turned up to 11 pretty much throughout the whole record, and it's recorded in a properly lo-fi way to actually sound like a raging hellbeast. There's vocals too, from Heather, but she sounds like an angry punk dude instead of herself which is kinda awesome too. Corsano's prowess need not be remarked upon here, except to say this is as good as one should expect. While I guess this was just a one-off project, its pretty great and one of my favourite things Heather has played on. [14 July 2012]


Date: 23 March 2010

Richard Youngs - Like A Neuron

Label: Dekorder

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15

Richard's LP was billed as 'ecstatic house' which is what I thought Heatsick/Steve Warwick did. This is definitely pulsing electronica generated entirely with keyboards, but it lacks the repetition and (in my opinion) annoying nature of house music. Instead you find Richard's same fascination with layers of psychedelic drone - this is not a million miles from the amazing Youngsbower CD, though without any guitars. As usual, the sounds are warm and sweeping, building up ideas in longer bursts (there's six tracks here) and establishing a consistent mood that, while it bears little resemblance to his vocal and guitar work, definitely comes from the same musical consciousness. [18 August 2012]


Date: 23 March 2010

Speed, Glue & Shinki - Eve

Label: Phoenix Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15

I never heard of this til reading the Julian Cope Japrocksampler book, but, christ, is it fun. This is hard, crunchy Japanese rock - derivative of lots of hard/blues/psych of the 70s but distinguished by the wild vocals of the Filipino speedfreak who sang lead. The songs are pretty much about getting wasted, almost dazzlingly unpoetic, and accented by Shinki's powerful guitar chops. Classics include 'Stoned out of my Mind' and 'Ode to the Bad People'. I should look for the second album which is apparently a studio assemblage and not really a power trio at all. [18 October 2012]


Date: 30 March 2010

Refrigerator - Glitter Jazz

Label: Shrimper

Format: CD

Source: eBay

Cost: £8.99

This is my favorite Refrigerator album but one I never owned, getting intimate with it via MP3s only.  I grabbed this off eBay because I was just in one of those moods, even though I hate buying CDs -- this, sadly, was never issued on vinyl.  I really think this is the high water mark for this band, whom I love so much, though it's definitely far more polished than their earlier wonderful stuff.  It opens with 'Tourists', which, while confident, contains the same white-soul negative space that I love about their earlier records.  Franklin Bruno's meandering piano line is perfect and I didn't realise til I looked at the booklet that Ira and Georgia from Yo La Tengo do background vocals.  Anyway, the album is so incredible and there are a few highlights that bring me almost to tears.  'Western Disconnection' is maybe my favorite Refrigerator song ever -- the winding bassline and the soaring vocals just perfectly capture the essence of some magical moment that I never can make myself feel anymore.  And then 'Heart of Bone', a poem sung over a simple looped structure that is an absolute masterpiece - one that gives me a spooky, shuddering feeling everytime I hear it.  'Sweet A.M.' is a brilliant finish too, Refrigerator's 'Our Singer'.  I didn't need to buy this, but as CDs go, it's actually a really beautiful printing job and it's nice to have the lyrics typed out. I'll never deny my love for 90s indie stuff and this one will hold up forever. [11 April 2010]



Date: 12 April 2010

Vermillion Sands - In The Wood

Label: Fat Possum Records

Format: 7"

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £3.29

'In The Wood' retains the rolling, fun shuffle that Vermillion Sands do so well, lyrically rejecting someone else being proud of the vocalist, because she doesn't need it. Nice organ playing too. The flip has 'May', a fair aggressive rocker, and a cover of the American traditional 'Trouble in My Way' - great to hear a slice of Americana delivered by a weird sounding Italian girl. All three songs have a slight edge to them and it's another winning side from this band. [7 Aug 2012]


Date: 12 April 2010

Dirty Projectors - Bitte Orca

Label: Domino USA

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £12.99

The Dirty Projectors really took me by surprise with this record, which connected with me in a way that their previous work never did. What's paradoxical about my enjoyment of this band is that the most distinct characteristics of the Dirty Projectors - the oddball deconstruction of the song structure, the broken-sounding experimental approach to pop  - are not what I like about them. It's when the band is straight-forward and direct that I connect, and feel some real power in their songs. But it's not that clearcut of an explanation, because there are aspects of the experimentalism I love - the guitar-god jamming is uniquely strange, brilliantly exploratory, and passionate. But if it was all just that, I would only enjoy it to a certain level. So it's really the direct songs juxtaposed with strange angles that I find so moving. This is mostly great all the way through, but 'Two Doves' is the one tune from this album that completely cripples me It's a song that really hit me personally at the time I most dived into this album (2010), and it's magical and punishing to my ears.  I've come to love the followup even a bit more, again for the largely straight folk/pop songs surrounded by all the contemporary detachment. This gap - this space between honesty and the slightly show-offy aspect of the obtuse structures - is maybe what I've always wanted to explore myself with song-based music (and have consistently failed to do so). [17 December 2012]


Date: 12 April 2010

Electric Bunnies - Through the Magical Door

Label: Florida's Dying

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £16.99

On the surface, the Electric Bunnies appear to be another upstart bedroom punk band, a product of the Terminal Boredom generation, appropriately situated on Florida's Dying and releasing sloppy, lazily-written songs. But I think Through the Magical Door is a real cut above the rest, as the songs are solid, the playing appropriately psychedelic (without compromising the fun, punk attitude), and some bits being genuinely out-there. There's jams like 'Psychic Lemonade' which are pure 60s pop perfection, but also some more Velvet Underground-styled dirges. It's actually really impressive to me how diverse of a sound they have, plus the packaging, which is all die-cut board game-style fun (I declined to cut up my sleeve though) is brilliant. Let's hear some more from them. [3 November 2012]


Date: 12 April 2010

Deerhunter - Cryptograms / Fluorescent Grey

Label: Kranky

Format: Vinyl

Source: 

Cost: £16.49

I came around really slowly to Deerhunter -- when I first downloaded this back in '07 I thought it was interesting but never really gave it much consideration.  Then I somehow got super into Microcastle, in a way that I didn't really enjoy indierock anymore.  So I went back and grabbed this to have the nice vinyl collection, and plus it has the Flouresecent Grey EP which is a minor masterpiece -- the song in particular, is so haunting and chilling that I think it's definitely one of the gems of the past few years.  And it's made all the more intense by being about death, and then Jay Reatard covered it, and then he died;; anyway, Cryptograms has some pretty fantastic parts.  The more upbeat tunes, particularly when driven by the noodly basslines (such as 'Cryptograms' or 'Octet') are super intense, and the thick vinyl pressing sounds fantastic.  But then the more sketchy tunes like 'Providence' are quite brilliant as well.  I think Bradford Cox might really emerge as an important 'voice', though on Cryptograms he is hiding his songwriting a bit behind all of the textures.  But what I loved about Microcastle was how thick it was with subtleties.  The more I listened to it, the more I heard, and the more utterly miserable and depressing the record proved to be.  Cryptograms has a lot to invest in too, though I don't know if I will find the lyrical content quite as affecting.  That's okay though, cause this is a great album too and hopefully this band will keep providing. [12 April 2010]



Date: 12 April 2010

Art Museums - Rough Frame

Label: Woodsist

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £12.79

This is a pretty early candidate for album-of-the-year, or at least album I've listened to the most.  In fact, this is probably the most I've listened to any record in years.  I downloaded this about a month ago and listened to it maybe 20 times before realising it was a Glenn Donaldson project.  That makes sense now, but it even surpasses the Famous Boating Party in greatness for me.  Sure, it's a bit silly and contrived, trying to ape the Style Council and maybe it's a bit disingenuous -- but if you wanna talk about a band that tweaks all of my art-pop switches, this is it.  Glenn is a sweet dude and I know he's just passionate about this stuff, and the songwriting is great great great and the production is a perfect copy of a style. The bass playing really makes it, but also the way cheap fuzz/delay effects will kick it on the guitars (or even vocals), plus the songwriting is just great.  I like Skygreen Leopards but there's something much more concise at play here, and plus I like this style more than the post-Dylan hippie thing.  I wish this was longer but maybe it wouldn't be so perfect.  I have probably listened to this over 40 times now.  My favourite song keeps changing (currently it's 'Sculpture Gardens') which is a sign of a classic album, or maybe one I will burn out on soon.  But I'm enjoying it while I have it. [12 April 2009]



Date: 12 April 2010

U.S. Girls - Go Grey

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £14.99

Megan's new LP is leaps and bounds ahead of her last one, though I'm not sure if I can finger why.  The vocals are more audible and the recording is a bit cleaner, though murk and haze are still the name of the game.  I think a few parts remind me of that awesome New Grape cassette -- or His Name is Alive in general -- though she had never heard that when I asked her.  There are a few really catchy and dense grooves here and I could even see myself learning the words the few times they are intelligible.  Another fine Siltbreeze release, I guess, though I wonder if I will pull this out in 5 years - and what I will think of it, if I do.  [12 April 2010]



Date: 9 May 2010

Totstellen - KSR

Label: 1000+1 TiLt / Totes Format

Format: CDr

Source: Gerrit Kröger

Cost: €0



Date: 10 May 2010

Harangue - 

Label: Wilder-Pryor

Format: LP

Source: Wilder-Pryor

Cost: $19

I grabbed this via Paypal after reading the review on Still Single, hearing the song on the Harangue website, and then being amazed that they were from Pittsburgh.  I obviously haven't lived in that city for a long time but I still expect every band to try to sound like Don Caballero -- so imagine my pleasant surprise!  I don't know any of these people but it's great to hear a band mining the emotional/art-rock territory of Roxy Music, Eno, etc. The lyrics are quite raw, laid out like a weird British-influenced take on emo, but with music that constantly pulls between glam theatrics and dark psychedelic jams.  About halfway through side two I realised who this band sounds a lot like: Frog Eyes, which is not a bad thing.  This is heavily piano driven and the recording often sounds like the piano keys are spikes digging into my ears, but there's a real crunch to the guitars too.  This will probably grow on me a great deal, and it's so great they're from my hometown.  [12 May 2010]



Date: 10 May 2010

Usurper Trio - Party Tapes

Label: Total Vermin

Format: cassette

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: €0

I sort of love this Usurper Trio tape, which joins a third member (Smith?) with Ali and Malcy. There's some babbling at the beginnin but the same skiffly fuckery as usual, and a lot of pause button edits. It turns into a low-fi mess, like a bunch of old car parts being tossed around in a washing machine. That's definitely a party, if your definition of a party is really fucked up (mine is!). [28 December 2012]


Date: 10 May 2010

Smear Campaign - Do Let's Hang the Aristocracy

Label: Giant Tank

Format: cassette

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: €0

Smear Campaign bashes about in a chaotic celebration of noise fuckery. I hear what I think is Ali's trumpet on some of it, and the first side ends with a tape splice, just as all good noise records should. Dictaphone recording techniques abound, but the longer piece on side two is slow, bass-heavy, and pretty stupid, taking it's time to go nowhere. Good fun. [31 December 2012]


Date: 10 May 2010

Ali Robertson's Moron Quest - Live Pieces For Trumpet 'N' Shit

Label: Giant Tank

Format: cassette

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: €0

"Ali Robertson's Moron Quest" is a great concept - though it's just a solo project. How I would love to hear a progressive rock band led by Ali. This is moronic, sure, but isn't most of what Ali does? And I say that with deep respect for him as one of my favourite musicians in Scotland. Moron Quest side 1 is some discordant breathing into what was once presumably a trumpet. It's close-mic'd, distorted, and with an ominous hum in the background, but that's part of the charm. The rattling bit in the middle is especially beautiful, and there's some good throat clearing at the end. On the b-side it's more clattery and accidental, yet no more coherent. Another find Robertson mess. [25 July 2012]


Date: 10 May 2010

Dead Labour Process - Meatpacker

Label: Giant Tank

Format: CDr

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: €0



Date: 10 May 2010

Peeesseye - Blood Spots In The Porridge

Label: Giant Tank

Format: CDr

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: €0



Date: 10 May 2010

F. Ampism - Venus Drainage

Label: Giant Tank

Format: CDr

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: €0



Date: 10 May 2010

Usurper and Winsor Damonbeast - Holy Fucking Shit

Label: Know

Format: CDr

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: €0



Date: 10 May 2010

Robertson / Doll / Duff - 

Label: Un

Format: CDr

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: €0



Date: 10 May 2010

Usurper and Sticky Foster - Usurper Sticky Foster

Label: Chocolate Monk

Format: CDr

Source: Ali Robertson

Cost: €0



Date: 17 June 2010

Part Wild Horses Mane On Both Sides - Blew In The Face

Label: Chironex

Format: Vinyl

Source: Pascal Nichols

Cost: £0

Pascal and Kelly really kick some ass on their first LP.  It's a new way to approach free music, and it's strikingly it's own sound despite having roots in fluid, organic jazz and spacey jam music.  Instead of going for the balls-out freejazz drum freakout, Pascal is very languid, exploring the space and providing a good sparring partner for her flute.  There are some mellow passages where she uses tapes or electronics or something, and when the flute cuts back in (at the end of side one) it's positively epic, yet also sounding like it was recorded some time in the 1950's.  Side two is a long live recording from Den Haag and it's a really unique exploration.   It's thick in the low-mids and the flute sounds so diverse as it billows out of the speakers.  I'm obviously a bit biased because these are friends of mine, but I think they turned in a really really solid record here. [12 July 2010]



Date: 17 June 2010

Le Drapeau Noir - Le Drapeau Noir

Label: Chironex

Format: Vinyl

Source: Pascal Nichols

Cost: £0

This LP is a live recording of an octet collaboration between Part Wild Horses Mane on Both Sides, the Hunter Gracchus, and Chora.  It's nice to hear a documents of the Sheffield/Manchester young free axis, which I only partially crossed paths with in my UK music days.  Despite the large lineup, all of the players provide a lot of space and because the flute and drums are so predominant, it feels quite led by Part Wild Horses.  The billowing, organic noodles of Chora (at least from the time I saw them live, as I'm still not familiar at all with their recorded work) decorate everything, and Hunter Gracchus (which I guess is John and Fiona from Sheffield) are probably the ones providing the wordless chants and vocals on side B.  This is a live recording from a performance in Lyon and it sounds like a soundboard recording - there are parts where it feels a bit compressed, and the droning bits are a bit unclear as to what they actually are (probably guitars?).  Everything tends to plateau into a cloud that is not droney or minimal, yet somewhat horizontal anyway.  There's tons of movement, don't get me wrong, but it all feels a bit constrained.  You can hear kazoos and other noisemakers jutting out into their own areas but it's all propelled along by a rhythmic casual stroll.  I should have checked these guys out more when I was around because I think they're all interesting players that are negotiating a good balance between free, jazz, and noise.  If there's one main criticism is that they by not fully committing to any of those three camps, they end up filling a rather indistinct netherregion.  [4 July 2010]



Date: 17 June 2010

Vernon & Burns - Mort Aux Vaches

Label: Staaplaat

Format: CD

Source: Mark Vernon

Cost: £0

This is one of the most elaborate and beautiful CD packaging concepts ever, and I'm grateful to Mark for this gift. This is Mark + Barry in 2007, for a radio broadcast which is why this is just about a clean hour. It's not as narrative as the radio experiments they would later do, but instead a collection of 21 short tracks that showcase their bizarre take on sound manipulation. Though these guys are often humorous, this isn't so ha-ha funny, even if the track of Barry arguing with someone about cigarettes veers into this territory. Instead we get a playful investigation of what sound processing can achieve, through effects, repetition, or juxtaposition. Things are very clean, as always, and while there's no doubt they used computers to piece this together, it doesn't feel overworked. As I always feel when I listen to Vernon & Burns, I miss working with these guys.  [29 December 2012]


Date: 17 June 2010

Hassle Hound - Born in a Night

Label: Staubgold

Format: CD

Source: Mark Vernon

Cost: £0



Date: 17 June 2010

Vernon & Burns - The Light at the End of the Dial

Label: Gagarin

Format: LP

Source: Mark Vernon

Cost: £0

How I love Mark and Barry, and especially the pleasure of having them on vinyl. This is classic Vernon and Burns - carefully assembled soundworks that are mostly built around field recordings and an affable accompaniment, occasionally with singing. Their vaudeville influence comes across on the record, where you don't see them perform, as more "old-timey" than straight vaudeville. Songs like 'The Night We Invented Forgetting' are incredibly beautiful and chilling; this record overall has a more reflective atmosphere, leaving some of the humour behind. I think listening to this, Lost Lake makes a lot more sense, actually, or is at least more clearly a 50/50 collaboration. The liner notes are awesome too because there are descriptions of each song on the back cover as well as on the sleeve, so you get two viewpoints. [2 December 2012]


Date: 18 June 2010

Hotlegs - You Didn't Like It Because You Don't Think Of It

Label: Philips

Format: Vinyl

Source: Monorail

Cost: £3.99

I have a soft spot for Hotlegs, the pre-10cc band featuring most of the core band. There's some really sophisticated pop songs here, laced with the same irony found in 10cc's stuff, and some excellen tearly 70's British pop production as well. 'Today' is a sweeping ballad, as good as the Beatles could manage; 'How Many Times' is a superb song that is beautiful and catchy. The breeze blows by on 'All God's Children'; 'Run Baby Run' takes on something countrified, done quite well for these Mancunians. 'Neanderthal Man' is the novelty song which I like better than either of the Kinks tunes ('Apeman'/'King Kong'), precisely because it's so under-formed. I still need to brave the Godley and Creme triple LP concept album but I've just never stumbled across a copy. [27 November 2012]


Date: 18 June 2010

Mekons - Hole In The Ground

Label: Sin Record Company

Format: Vinyl

Source: Monorail

Cost: £2.99

Honky Tonkin' is not one of my favourite Mekons albums but maybe I never gave it a fair chance. This 12" single of 'Hole in the Ground' also featured the same album's 'Prince of Darkness', with Michelle Shocked on vocals, so the only new song is the cover of Flying Burrito Bros' 'Sin City', which is great and worth the record. But 'Hole in the Ground' is a pretty great song, actually - as great of an indictment of Thatcherism and the loss of a manufacturing jobs in the North as anything I've ever heard. It's really beautiful and sad, though still a driving Brit-country tune. [22 August 2012]


Date: 18 June 2010

Rip Rig & Panic - Bob Hope Takes Risks

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl

Source: Monorail

Cost: £2.99

Both songs on this 12" are exactly 6:00 long, which is nice symmetry. 'Bob Hope Takes Risks' blasts through in what feels like quicker time, though in the course of those six minutes we're taken through collapsing Cecil Taylorisms, echo-drenched spacetravel strings, a lumbering, punchy horn section, and Neneh Cherry's brilliant vocal glossolalia, singing about getting stuff in your eyes. 'Hey Mr. E! A Gran Grin With A Shake Of Smile' is a total B-side, more of a sketch, with a dub feeling. A great find for £3! [7 Aug 2012]


Date: 18 June 2010

Paul Bley Quintet - Barrage

Label: Base Record

Format: LP

Source: Monorail

Cost: £6.99

Early Paul Bley, leading a band,is rambunctious and horn driven compared to those miserable downer ECM piano records I listen to so often. Carla actually wrote most of the tracks except for the collectively improvised title track at the end. Marshall Allen is the alto here and he squawks along with trumpeter Dewey Johnson so much that the whole thing is bumpy, but in a good way. The cacophony peaks probably on 'Ictus', but it rips itself apart as soon as it builds, with a great Eddie Gomez bass solo. The more fluid sections are mere diversions from the jerkyness, which is probably due to Milford Graves's style, which is quite heavy on the toms. Or maybe it's just the way this is recorded - a classic NYC mid-60's loft sound. You can practically feel the dust on the wooden floor and the smog from outside traffic. [26 July 2012]


Date: 18 June 2010

Anthony Braxton - In the Tradition Volume 2

Label: SteepleChase

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Monorail

Cost: £9.99

Here's Braxton in a quartet with three competent European dudes, recorded in 1976 in what was probably a lark. "Tradition" is a word that started popping up on jazz records in the late 70s and it signaled a return to that - and a migration from the adventurous explorations of the late 60s and early 70s. This is exactly that  - an LP of Charlie Parker, Johnny Green, Richard Rogers and Miles Davis tunes, delivered in a straight-forward manner. While I'm not usually that wild about hearing these standards, when juxtaposed with the other 9 Braxton LPs I own, this is actually kinda fun, a nice break. He plays contrabass clarinet on the first track, and the tone on that instrument is wild - at first I thought he was processing his alto through an octave pedal, or playing with a weird mute. Overall this is a stab at commercial success, but the man certainly did not abandon his vision, just had some fun with standards here, so I can have fun listening to it. [9 November 2012]


Date: 18 June 2010

Michael Mantler - Something There

Label: Watt / ECM

Format: Vinyl

Source: Monorail

Cost: £2.99

I'm not so into this; I have a soft spot for Mantler because he's done some great work, but this solo album from the early 80s is just too much of the bland electric fusion style to really intrigue me. Carla Bley, Nick Mason, and Steve Swallow play on it but they aren't doing a whole lot to sell me. The washes of rack-effect electric guitar are at least slow and mellow, as opposed to some jazzbo fingertapping wank, but this might be too dull for even my tastes. [3 March 2012]


Date: 18 June 2010

Fred Frith / Bob Ostertag / Phil Minton - Voice Of America

Label: Rift

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Monorail

Cost: £9.99

I got my ears cleaned out today and everything I hear has more detail - the best I've heard in years. I've been taking it slow with music but I put this on, kind of randomly, and found myself amazed at how enjoyable it is to just lose yourself in music. This is mostly Frith and Ostertag, on synth and guitar but mostly (at least it seems) using tape. I wouldn't call this a straight-up tape collage because it's clearly improvised and live, and Minton wails on side 2, and there are actual instruments though in the hands of these guys, you can't really tell. Most of this record sounds like a few radios fighting each other, a description I once heard of Arab on Radar's later lineup, which is a complete compliment in both cases. When there are more obviously guitar sounds - plinks and plonks - they serve to ground the overall mix. The source material contains lots of foreign-language radio broadcasts, lending (along with the album's title) a very political feel. [9 October 2012]


Date: 24 June 2010

Ischio Romantico - From the Hip

Label: Shadazz

Format: CD

Source: Luke

Cost: £0

Luke released this really interesting CD which is a Bohman Brothers side project, a very strange collaboration that touches on a lot of territories of improvised and processed music. Knowing Luke as I do, I totally see why he loves this. There's a lot of the Bohman's tape-manipulated sound constructions and a lot of acoustic samples, really making this the same genre territory as the Lied Music/Vernon & Burns material. But there's also two guys involved in this who used to collaborate with Die Trip Computer Die, and you can hear this tendency towards broken song structures and more rhytmic repetitions, especially on 'Foot Right Down'. It's an impressive record and it shifts gears really after the four act suite which opens it, which features disembodied operatic samples to make something worthy of the name Romantico. [24 December 2012]


Date: 24 June 2010

Moon Unit - New Sky Dragon

Label: Krayon Recordings

Format: Vinyl

Source: Andreas or Rory

Cost: £10

Moon Unit started as a side project of Pyramidion and got a lot more popular locally, as they ride a feelgood wave of thick Krautrock-style jams. This is heavy, deep psychedelic rock, with swirling keyboards and thick, layered guitars, but it's never abrasive or noisy. Side A starts slow, with the drums creeping in, before attaining a back and forth momentum over a razor-wire guitar line. The keys are layered but constantly swirling around each other, like perfect ear candy. The B-side picks up where this left off, rocking out til the end, an easy horizontal structure that blends minimalist construction with smoky, eye-widening awe. The ending guitar part is meaty, cutting through like a knife, until there's only an echo left in the room. I don't know if they are still active or playing under this band - maybe I should send Rory and Andreas an email to catch up. [23 November 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Peter Nicholson - Shutters Drawn

Label: no label

Format: CDr

Source: Peter Nicholson

Cost: £0



Date: 25 June 2010

Peter Nicholson / Raymond MacDonald - Streetlevel

Label: Iorram

Format: CDr

Source: Peter Nicholson

Cost: £0

Raymond and Peter are brilliant here, a session recorded at the Streetlevel space in Glasgow that I went to a few times. Peter gets a wobbly cello improvisation going and Raymond wobbles right over it, which sounds like a continually unstable, organic sound creature. There are some mesmerising bits, so active it's hard to believe it's only two people, where the soprano sax soars over Peter's thick, active movement. The voices are good too, not as song-based as Peter's later solo work, but not abstract either, actually using them to support the improvisations as fragments of language. The atmosphere is great too - Streetlevel is an excellent room for improvised acoustic music. [20 December 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Joanna Newsom - The Milk-Eyed Mender

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Monorail

Cost: £9.89

Before I left Pittsburgh I copied a bunch of mp3s from Andy, onto the off-brand iRiver MP3 player I had, which served me damn well over the years. This was one of them - a new Drag City artist, something that appealed to the more quirky side of my folk tastes, I guess. Connections to Deerhoof through a one-off project called Nervous Cop ... Drag City is my favourite label ever, probably ... can't really go wrong here! I don't remember precisely the first time I listened to it, but by the time I arrived in Japan I was listening to it multiple times per day. This was 8 years ago - April 2004 - and I have a distinct, yet abstract memory (as it must have happened multiple times) of waking up where I was staying, looking out over the green tea fields, and listening to Newsom's odd songs as the morning dew lifted. By the time I got to India, this had become so much more than just an album to me - it was the personal soundtrack that happens so often in summertime life, but in this case it was the most turbulent and (at the time) exciting summer of my life, so -- bonus points! (I remember listening to Animal Collective's Sung Tongs lots too that summer, which can only accurately be described as a breakthrough album for them, but it didn't have the same personal impact as this). That summer culminated in a drunken folk-based music festival in Wales where Newsom performed, a seemingly appropriate denouement to the Summer of Newsom, the Summer of Emotional Upheaval, the Summer of New Friends and New Places, the Summer of a Window to a New Life. I was pretty drunk and didn't really enjoy her set - I don't even think I watched it all - as the live performance failed to impact me in the same way the record had. Or that was my excuse. Because the reality is that I felt like I was compromising my secret relationship to The Milk-Eyed Mender, sharing it with hundreds of British music fans.  In retrospect, that maybe was the last time I felt the sense of elitism/belonging through a common shared experience degrade.


On the inevitable flight back to America in early September, I picked up the Guardian at Prestwick airport and found an article by Dave Eggers about his relationship to The Milk-Eyed Mender and how he hoped she looked like the crazy toothless had that she sounded like. But of course, she is kind of beautiful and odd like her music, and for some stupid male reason that is disappointing. The story plays out as we all know - Newsom makes an overambitious second album (which some people love but I absolutely can't stand) followed by an overblown third album (which I like parts of but find a chore to get through) and generally her star fades, as it always does under the bright lights of fame and attention. She's now well-known enough that I'm just one of a zillion other kids who love this album, and she's probably gone as far as one can in the music industry these days - I wouldn't be surprised if she never releases another note. And I even hung out with her once randomly in Helsinki and she was really nice and I didn't bother to tell her how much her first album meant to me when I was 24. I'm not anymore and this means something different now. Which is fine with me; I'll always be grateful for that summer and those memories. 


Writing about the actual music here seems irrelevant, but spinning it now it hasn't lost any of it's charm after all these years and so many listens. The epic, punishing masterpiece is of course 'Sadie', which I spent great amounts of time in 2004 and 2005 discussing with Spencer or anyone else willing to talk about it - but listening to 'Cassiopeia' or 'Clam, Crab, Cockle, Cowrie' is no less powerful, especially today. When you love something so much you can sink deeply into it to the point that you pass completely through it, and that's probably where I'm at now. I can feel the power, but I'm happy to let it pass by and just spin this for nostalgia's sake. [26 November 2012]



Date: 25 June 2010

The Rebel - Northern Rocks Bear Weird Vegetable

Label: Sacred Bones Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Monorail

Cost: £13.49

Ben from the Country Teasers is so prolific that he releases a bunch of Rebel stuff all the time on the side. There's not a major difference between the two sounds - both bands are led by his off-key, snarky wail, and I suppose the Teasers are nominally a 'country' band while The Rebel is much closer to punk-rock. But nothing is fast or furious - it's midtempo British snarls throughout. Lyrically there's probably a lot less irony - songs with fairly improvised lyrics that get into political issues I know he actually stands behind, such as gay rights. "It's cold outside but your vagina is warm" is the type of lyric that only this man can write, and while of course I think of the Fall a bit while listening, he's infused a personality of his own into the music. [28 October 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Zs - Music Of The Modern White

Label: The Social Registry

Format: Vinyl

Source: Monorail

Cost: £10.79

I don't listen to this often, but every time I do I come away very impressed. This is inventive as hell, a band that mixes incredible technical prowess (off-kilter time signatures, discordant tonal progressions, bizarre arrangements) with something quite communicative and lively. The handclapping bit on the second side is absolutely fantastic, clearly recorded as a live improvisation, but seamlessly integrated to the piece as a whole. I played a party at Pete Spynda's flat with these guys years ago and was left really cold by what I saw, which seemed to be an overly brainy, distant bit of wankery. But on record, I think there's an obvious nod to the traditions of smart progressive rock, without being a victim of the past. I should really investigate the rest of their discography, but I probably never will. [22 August 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Meth Teeth - Everything Went Wrong

Label: Woodsist

Format: Vinyl

Source: Monorail

Cost: £14.39

The Meth Teeth full-length is, I think, just a collection of the cassette and 7" they released before, but it's a nice document which I suspect is all we'll ever get from this band. Out of that whole brief scene that revolved around Woodsist a few years ago, this might be the one record that stands out the most, though really just because it's a good amalgamation of styles. The band switches frequently between clean n' jangly argpeggios and teenage fuzzpedal stomping, with the drumming crashing about wildly with cymbals. The singer moans out of the side of his mouth and the songwriting leaves no impression on me about meaning, intent, etc except that it's quite a good sound they've constructed. Reminds me a bit of Eat Skull, who are also from Portland, but possibly a more fun, poppy version. [2 Aug 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Rodan  - Rusty

Label: Quarterstick Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Monorail

Cost: £8.99

Wow. I randomly pulled this out to listen to since I hadn't written a review yet and it fit my mood, and then I discover while listening to it that Jason Noble died today. This is a weird coincidence surely but one that feels profound right now. But Rusty .... I really listened to this a lot in high school. Listening to 'Bible Silver Corner' now, it's like I know every nook and cranny. My teenage mind was blown by this bit of indie classicism, and it feels like I could pick up a guitar right and play the whole thing verbatim, so accurate is my memory of it. Which doesn't end when "proper" Rodan kicks in, with the incendiary 'Shiner' and 'The Everyday World of Bodies' - could a better side one exist? Boy, I loved the shit out of this record and even followed the less interesting post-Rodan projects for awhile, but ultimately this was a unique stroke of genius that would never be repeated. I upgraded to vinyl a few years ago but then the liner notes were just the CD booklet stuck inside the album -- I think this is a repress so maybe Quarterstick just had an overrun of CD booklets and were trying to save money? 'Jungle Jim' is the only weak track and it's still pretty great. All of my teenage idols are falling (Bill Doss left us last week). When I was 17 and worshipped Rusty, I went to see Shipping News at the Beehive in Pittsburgh and talked with Jason Noble afterwards for ages. He wrote me a list of music to check out, which ended up turning me on to Talk Talk's last two albums, gamelan music, Bela Bartok's Divertimento, and I remember the Barry Black album was on the list too. I wrote him a few times by post and we stayed in touch for a little bit. Yet another reason to be sad tonight. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Royal Trux - Twin Infinitives

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl

Source: Monorail

Cost: £15.29

I came to Royal Trux late; my first exposure to their name was in the original 'What is Indie Rock?' flyer Manny handed me at Lollapalooza '93, where it mentioned "prominent national acts like Fugazi and Royal Trux".   At some point in high school, my friend Joe's girlfriend played us a Royal Trux song - I have no idea which one, but I'm guessing it was probably something off Cats and Dogs given the time frame, or maybe one of the major label albums - and we both hated it, saying it was too close to hip-hop (?!).  So I only started to appreciate them when I heard Twin Infinitives at some point around the Arco Flute years - I think I borrowed or took Tamburo's copy which was on CD, with no booklet or liner notes, and the disc was cut into only 4 tracks for the four sides of the LP.  At the time I was dazzled by anything convoluted or inpenetrable, which this record certainly is.  So I considered myself a mild 'fan' of RT but it wasn't until the UK years when hanging around with Warwick led to frequent playing of Accelerator and other more rock-oriented releases.  Now I'm definitely a fan, though I still haven't absorbed their entire discography and lately, it's the two major label records that I'm grooving on the most ('Ray-O-Vac', anyone?).  I grabbed this repress last summer and pulled it out yesterday for a random listen, and I can't say that i have any more insight into it than before.  I do enjoy it, but it's a tough one to spin when you're trying to focus on something else, like coding or writing or filing papers even.  It demands full attention, and then continually shifts whenever you think you've figured out a structure or hook.  I've listened to this a bunch of times but I still can't really hum a melody or probably even recognise it if you played me a snippet.  But the pressing nice and I guess that's a good thing.  [6 May 2011]


Date: 25 June 2010

Red Crayola With Art And Language - Corrected Slogans

Label: Drag City / Dexter?s Cigar

Format: CD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6.29

Budget price new CD and while I try not to buy CDs, this is a fun one to own.  Who wouldn't want to play "Ergastulum" at parties, and lead everyone in a sing-along?  "C is constant capital, V is varied capital, D is surplus value."  Corrected Slogans occupies a special place among my favourite Red Crayola records.  It's simultaneously a product of its time and an ahead-of-its-time critique of capitalism and art movements.  I'm sure that some members of Art & Language were very serious about these tunes, but Mayo's ramshackle warble and the absolutely primitive musical structures lead these into the category of the ridiculous.  I mean, the ideas in these lyrics, when accessible, are insanely thought-provoking, and it's a hell of an experiment to see how grafting these "slogans" onto melodic structures can possibly take hold.  But obviously these tunes didn't take over the world, and even though I'm often up for a discussion of class warfare, this maybe isn't the best window into that world.  But it's hard to deny some of these songs having their charm - 'It's an Illusion", "Keep All Your Friends," "War Dance I & II".  This feels like a perfect document of the Cornelius Cardew-style dialogues that overconsumed avant-garde music in Britain in the mid-70s, which is a world I never lived through -- but one that I often emulated, whether directly or indirectly.  [9 July 2010]



Date: 25 June 2010

Brast Burn - Debon

Label: Paradigm Discs

Format: CD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6.29

The mystery Japanese psych band from the 70s, Brast Burn resemble the cult-like folk of Yahowa 13, only minus any sunshine: these people sound like they are coming to cut our your kidneys with spoons. The construction of the album is episodic, with wind sounds linking together the songs (recalling the 'burn' feeling) and tortured vocal chants driving it along. None of it makes any sense, despite the relatively traditional instrumentation (up-front percussion keeps this from getting too out of control, and the strings are mostly acoustic). On the middle of side two, a long instrumental jam of overlapping modalities builds into chaos, with distant recordings mixed in the background - animals, domestic sounds, and who knows what else - to create a pretty dazzling quilt. At the time Paradigm issued this, they had no idea who the artists were and the CD traycard contains a plea for contact, but I don't know if that ever happened. I think a vinyl reissue came out more recently but maybe it's just as unofficial - it would be nice to upgrade this, though. [5 Aug 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Cup Cake Club - Fantastic Doug and the Cup Cake Club

Label: Breakdance the Dawn

Format: CDr

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6.29



Date: 25 June 2010

Sun of the Seventh Sister - Live at Club Consolador

Label: Breakdance the Dawn

Format: CDr

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6.29



Date: 25 June 2010

Marianne Nowottny - Illusions of the Sun

Label: Camera Obscura

Format: CD

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £6.29

This half-hour mini-album by Marianne Nowottny is a pretty challenging listen, though not intentionally so. Built around organ and Nowottny's weird (but not abrasive) voice, the song structures are so haphazard that the record feels like it's always lurching.  It would be an exaggeration to say that it's teetering on the edge of chaos, but it's really hard to find a centre. Nico is an obvious comparison because their voices are similar and the arrangements have the same dark complexion, but Nowottny is definitely closer to a crackpot coffeehouse open-mic vibe. Afraid Of Me deserves classic status and some of her other experiments have been worthwhile, but Illusions of the Sun just tends to fall into a middle ground. [29 September 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

The C & B - 

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: 7"

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £7.19

Yes.  Siltbreeze has issued a 7" of four pre-Shadow Ring recordings, made in Folkestone by Darren Harris and Graham Lambkin (the Cat and Bells club, supposedly) in 1991.  This is of course of immense interest to Shadow Ring fanatics, and it does not disappoint.  Side 1 captures the barely melodic riffage of the City Lights days, with Harris' inimitable vocal delivery.  The fidelity is excellent - the acoustic plucking and percussive rattling (sounding distinctly like household items) is crisp and clear, and the distorted, dictaphone speech has the same weird essence that Lighthouse does.  'Kent Custer' names the future band, and both tracks capture that slice of modern Britain that I think they capture so well - the everyday strange, the foreboding urbanity.  The musical motifs don't stray near the dark oddness of their later electroacoustic textures, but follow a primitive path not unlike Inca Eyeball, though I think Phil and Joincey didn't start IE until a few years later.  Side two finds a slightly less vocal outing, 'Cave of Ice Cats', really a guitar duet that I can only compare to the Door and the Window or early Jandek, but with a more curved recording quality.  'Father's Dead' ends things, another burst of oddball language.  These are "real" songs, boasts the cover, and my world is a richer place for them.  It's always amazing to hear where genius began, and this is no exception.  [3 July 2010]



Date: 25 June 2010

The Dead C - The Dead See Perform M. Harris

Label: Ba Da Bing! / Jagjaguwar

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £12.59

Two versions of 'Max Harris' comprise the debut Dead C release, or one of the first. The riff rings out eternally - a signature song in two iterations, neither one exactly 'direct' but close enough the first time around. 'Beyond help from Max Harris' is much more about the air, with more space and some inadvertent tape manipulations for colour. This is Bob Dylan to me. [7 November 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Vertical Slit - Slit And Pre-Slit

Label: Smudge Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £17.99

I wonder if crazy Vinnie and his 'Forever Lowman' blog are singlehandedly responsible for kickstarting a resurgence of interest in Jim Shepard.  Whatever the reason, I'm happy for it, cause this bootleg has been made available (and I can now dream of vinyl issues of Photograph Burns, Negotiate Nothing and other Shepard masterpieces).  Slit and Pre-Slit wasn't a record I was super familiar with before, but hearing it on vinyl makes me see it in a new light.  It's definitely a strange, experimental work that employs lots of tape fuckery, recording experimentation, and bizarre space jams, but it completely avoids any precendent in these things.  if you think this is gonna be some post-Kraut punk band like Swell Maps, you're wrong.  But when the songs come out, they're brilliant, and the overall collage actually puts this closer to R. Stevie Moore's early recordings than anything else I can think of.  'Ascension' is an amazing, totally fucked up rock song and the bluesy rock jams carry something wholesome as well.  'A Day at the Factory' is as far-out as anything you've ever heard, and while it isn't exactly clear what is Slit and what is pre-Slit, it's all pretty amazingly visionary.  This was slightly on the pricey side for a single LP, but I'm just excited that it's on my turntable.   [9 July 2010] 



Date: 25 June 2010

Otto Muehl - Psycho Motorik

Label: Not On Label

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15.29

Thank heavens that someone out there felt the need to press up a bootleg of Pyscho Motorik, Otto Muehl's early 70's burst of insane vocal fuckery. The majority of this record is actually language-based, in German which I don't understand, and that might be for the better. Otto brings hysterics of all sorts, some piano clanging, and some muttering and walking about. The first side ends with a long track of Muehl doing his thing overtop of the Blue Danube waltz, but avant-garde music is just as much under attack. By the end I'm sick of it, but that's what Aktionism is good for - producing feelings of disgust. Kommissar Hjuler's stuff is really just a continuation of these sounds. [25 September 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Burning Star Core - Papercuts Theater

Label: No Quarter

Format: 2xLP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £14.39

Papercuts Theater is in some ways, a conceptual companion piece to the compilation I put out, Mes Soldats Stupides. Maybe I just see the connection because both titles come from fake movies invented for a Friendster profile a decade ago. But where MSS is a compilation of previously released studio pieces, this is a collection of live recordings, all worked into an epic 4-side seamless piece. The recordings date back to the late 90s and feature just about everyone who Spencer regularly played with as well as some others. The first half is a blast of thick BxC sound, with a fusion/jazz feel at points from Trevor's drumming. This is probably the sound that I'd associate with that show I saw in Louisville with Robert and Mike Shiflet in the band. The process of compiling everything into one mixed piece musta been insane to do (66 recordings were used) but the resulting whole is, while overwhelming, pretty much a 'statement' as anything could be. There's definitely variation in dynamic, but even more noticeable are the variations in density. Sometimes it's a thick screaming miasma of electronics and violin - at other points it's a spacious exploration with tapping and other rustling sounds making it nervous. The thick parts are more smooth than the thin, if that makes any sense. This is inherently a difficult listen but it's a fairly necessary document of the BxC thing, I'd say. [15 September 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

The Dead C - Clyma Est Mort / Tentative Power

Label: Ba Da Bing! / Jagjaguwar

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £23.39

My lord, this just sounds amazing right now.  I can't resist these Ba Da Bing reissues because they sound so good -- though it's been years since I've spun my Siltbreeze issue of Clyma Est Mort.  I think, since the Dead C are one of the best bands ever, that I'll hold onto the original and maybe one day spin them side by side to compare audio quality.  It's funny how few actual memorable "songs" the Dead C had in their prime, as these reissues seem to have endless versions of 'Power', etc.  There's three in particular here, of which the Clyma Est Mort version may be the best ever.  I'm not sure where the Tentative Power tracks come from but every second of this second LP is completely incredible.  I need to sit down and figure out if any of these versions are on the Trapdoor Fucking Exit CD or anything else, but why does it even matter?  When put together as this 6 song, 45 rpm LP, it somehow congeals into the best Dead C record EVER.  'Radiation's got some music concrete bits mixed in and the guitars are all amped up beyond belief, yet really piercing and tinny.  This version of 'Hell is Now Love' is a perfect cacophany.  Clyma's 'Ein Kampf, Ein Seig' reminisces about the Dead C vs. Sebadoh 7" (speaking of, is that gonna end up on the Ba Da Bing 2LP reissue of Operation of the Sonne?).  It's all just, I dunno, so fucking perfect and anti.  [7 Dec 2010]



Date: 25 June 2010

Kommissar Hjuler / Mama Baer - Amerikanische Poesie und Alkoholismus

Label: Feeding Tube Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £11.69

A split release, rather than a collaborative one. Side 1 of this is by Kommissar Hjuler und Frau, but it consists of cutting up and manipulating existing records of American concrete poetry, though it mostly seems to be people introducing the poetry through feedback-enhanced echo, and distorted radio sounds. It's an odd approach to putting something together but Hjuler is a pretty insane artist, at least from the live appearance I saw. It suits the Feeding Tube aesthetic well and mostly is just the phrase "concrete poetry" shouted in various formats, but all is good. Mama Baer's side is a lot more interesting - weird tape loops, broken German speech, howling ... it's a twisted vision and right up my outsider alley. She brings in some creepy singing, and then some chopped-up spoken bits which resemble the concrete poetry referred to on side 1 quite a bit. It's truly fucked up and weird, enough to make you run for the hills, which is probably where these weirdos hail from in the first place. [25 July 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Vermillion Sands - Miss My Gun

Label: Sacred Bones Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £11.91

I had this 12" on order from Norman records forever but it was late in being released so I eventually gave up and canceled it.  Luckily, VT had it so I could hear the latest installment in the Vermillion Sands saga.  The super fun 60's ye-ye style pop + modern psych style continues, leading off with 'Where Was He From', a surprisingly droney, dark Wall of Sound-style tune that is closer to the Jesus and Mary Chain than I'd ever thought I'd hear from these Eye-talians.  But then the title track crashes in, resuming the bouncy fun that made me fall so completely in love with their debut single.  'I Need No One' is even jumpier and has Anna's sharp voice giving it the strange edge that is part of their sound.  I love it.  Side B opens with a Betty James cover and ends with a jammy instrumental that still has a primitive beat and thick, thick guitars.  The middle section reminds me of Burma's "All World Cowboy Romance" in a way.  Overall the effect reminds me a bit of all those twee Glasgow bands, if only they had a bit more energy and were influenced equally by Sonic Youth and Phil Spector.  Another fine release, still not quite as brililant as the 'Mary' 7", but making me salivate at the thought of a full-length. [4 July 2010]



Date: 25 June 2010

Joanna Newsom - Have One On Me

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl

Source: Monorail

Cost: £17.09

Jesus, it's hard to get through this record. I'm in a mood to tackle box sets today, but Have One On Me is a formidable wall to break through. I feel like I'd have a better time with the much longer Smegma or Tazartes boxes I have. I bought this on the strength of a few songs from the first half of the album - '81' and 'Good Intentions Paving Company' are as perfect as anything she's ever done, even if they've abandoned the quirky caterwauls of Milk-Eyed Mender for a more sophisticated Ladies of the Canyon vibe. But that's fine - 'Good Intentions' is a stunner, with an ascending momentum that never gives into to the impulse of its own tension. Many others, however, fail to make this distinction - 'In California' goes on forever, like a reminder that the record is only half over even though it feels like you've been listening to it forever. There's something depressingly bland about the whole album - from the Drag City session musicians (an approach which worked magic for Silver Jews with The Natural Bridge, but here they fail to carry across any personality besides competence, and these are totally different guys anyway) to the ugly artwork and dull graphic design - it makes the less compelling songs fade away even before they are over, and the most ambitious ones (like the impenetrable title track) just tedious. The solo voice and harp tracks are actually more distinct, despite the orchestral provocations occasionally being stirring. 'Jackrabbits' is probably the highlight, if you can handle the Biblical references and the word 'darlin' thrown about so much. The last three sides are pretty much a snooze, though there's occasional delicate bits that recall the fractured beauty of her earliest work - 'Ribbon Bows' and 'Kingfisher' have it, though it's hard to stay engaged by this point. The odd word choices, rooted in naturalistic wonder, become too much -- seriously, get a fucking editor! I hate to rag on this so much but if it were a single LP it would be such an accomplishment, but overall Have One On Me ends up being the Sandanista! of its generation. [13 August 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Gummystumps - 

Label: Watts of Goodwill

Format: 7"

Source: Dep

Cost: £0

Rob Churm's post-Park Attack band was Gummystumps, who I saw play once or twice and sort of enjoyed. The 7" takes the Fall as a starting point, containing a choppier, chunkier punk songwriting approach than Park Attack had. Rob sings with such an exaggerated Scottish accent that this could never be mistaken for any other origin. The second side starts to hint at some real paranoia, 'Stark Real' in particular. This is a band that would have been fun to see more often live but I wasn't really on the rock radar at the time. Great photo of Dep in the booklet. [21 December 2012]


Date: 25 June 2010

Pärson Sound - Pärson Sound

Label: ti'llindien / Subliminal Sounds

Format: Vinyl 3XLP box

Source: Monorail

Cost: £38.39

Subliminal Sounds put out this collection of the recordings of the Pärson Sound, the legendary Swedish heavy psych band from the laet 60s. I was way into these recordings back in my post-University days in Pittsburgh, when they were issued as a double CD and became part of the hyped up wave of psychedelic/folk reissues. Having this on vinyl is a joy; it sounds great, and the thick, heavy jams are quite a lot to listen to despite the recording fidelity, which is a feat of mastering. This is heavy crazed Scandinavian farm drone, and despite the appearance of instruments like cellos and saxophones, there's little resemblance to free jazz or anything else happening at the time - even compared to something like Amon Düül 1, Pärson Sound were more focused at their craft. Most of these recordings are very long - 1 or 2 tracks per side - and many taken from various happenings in Sweden in those years, such as museum shows and festivals, making this a pretty important historical document as well as something worthwhile to listen to. I like this material better than anything ever released by Harvester/Träd, Gräs & Stenar, maybe because it's not held back by lyrics or songs, really just being an intense, almost cult-like trip. [12 Aug 2012]


Date: 26 June 2010

Smegma - I Am Not Artist (1973-1988)

Label: Vinyl-on-demand

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £96



Date: 22 August 2010

Boom Edan - Home Hut Tiara

Label: Sick Head

Format: cassette

Source: Tuukka Asplund

Cost: €0



Date: 27 August 2010

Pyramidion - Hail! Pyramidion!

Label: no label

Format: CDr

Source: Tuukka Asplund

Cost: €0



Date: 16 September 2010

Souled American - Around The Horn

Label: Rough Trade (US)

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: $20.99

I keep fluctuating as to which of the first three Souled Americans I like the best. Around the Horn is certainly the sleeper but has some beautiful, driving songs. The cover of 'Six Feet of Snow' is the first thing I ever heard by them and somehow manages to make Little Feat sound like they're from the Civil War time. 'Durango's Hornpipe' is a perfect instrumental and 'Rise Above It' takes so long to end that it's majestic. The slower, more pained singing is something I value here, even if it lacks the experimental edge of Flubber or the exuberance of Fe. [25 September 2012]


Date: 16 September 2010

Peter Blegvad - The Naked Shakespeare

Label: Virgin / Virgin / Virgin

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: $12.99

The Naked Shakespeare finds Blegvad at his most eclectic. Working closely with John Greaves as well as XTC's Colin Moulding/Andy Partridge and Anton Fier, this is a great lineup for interpreting his oddball pop songs. There's thick guitar roasts on 'How Beautiful You Are', synth experiments on the (very dark, disturbing) 'Irma', and even a marching band on 'Vermont'. The lyrics are a bit more cryptic than the Slapp Happy days, though still rich with invention, and 'Blue-Eyed William' is reinvented here. Something more contemplative is afoot, even though he sounds like he's having fun singing these. Love and loss is a present theme, which is the fundamental basis of most rock music, but in Blegvad's hands it becomes something else. 'Lonely Too' interjects a commentary during a verse which somehow is more aorta than cerebellum, despite the intellect that went into the construction. It actually took me years to really appreciate the genius of Acnalbasac Noom; I don't think any Blegvad is quite as immediate as his Leviathan comic strips, but that's OK cause I like the slow reward. [21 December 2012]


Date: 16 September 2010

Peter Blegvad - Knights Like This

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £10.24

Mid-80s Blegvad has that bright, sharp production that characterises music of its period: loud, bold drums that sound nothing like drums, thick backing vocals, and a crunch layered in something shimmery. There's a lyrics sheet so that helps with the songs, which are always central to Blegvad. A few touch on something quite powerful - 'The Incinerator' is a really genuine ode to love and loss, though the spry production seems inappropriate. 'Face Off' is about someone ripping off another's face; 'Last Man' is about the last man on earth - so there's some dark territory here, for sure. The band is unremarkable, steering him away from the cabaret-pop influence that made Slapp Happy so brilliant. The tone is pretty uneven despite the lyrical focus, and even the closing cut, 'Marlene' (a beautiful, brilliantly written song about loss) can't be saved from an average performance. [13 August 2012]


Date: 16 September 2010

Stereolab - Refried Ectoplasm (Switched On Volume 2)

Label: Duophonic

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £25

This is a double LP compilation of early period Stereolab singles, or maybe mid-period was the right term at the time though now it's early-to-mid or something like that. The packaging is a lovely silk-screened cover with luminous orange vinyl, which makes it a perfect package for the futuristic psychedelic sounds inside. There's some classics here - 'Lo Boob Oscillator', 'John Cage Bubblegum', and the Nurse With Wound collaboration 'Animal or Vegetable' which takes up the entirety of side three. Some of the songs are just so incredibly French sounding, thanks to Laetitia Sadier's sweet voice; 'Tone Burst (Country)' actually sounds like something you could hear from a French street musician, except not really cause it's still Stereolab. This is material right before they hit their master stride (Mars Audiac Quintet, Transient Random Noise Bursts -- which have both been reissued lately on vinyl, so I should scoop 'em up) and there's a penultimate truth at play here. [4 Aug 2012]


Date: 18 September 2010

Cassis Cornuta - 25 Jaar De Gebraden Zwaan Zingt

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: LP

Source: Dennis Tyfus

Cost: €5

The cover of this is all-haircut, which makes Cassis Cornuta look like a new Romantic. But this doesn't sound anything like Morissey - instead it's an assault of minimal synthesiser experiments, building on it's own illogical breaks and bursts, and never being satisfied to enjoy its own sines and squares. When I saw him live, he added a manic Pere Ubu edge to the Taurpis Tula set; on its own, it's a more challenging listen but then I don't come to Ultra Eczema releases for being easy. He had a double CDr on this label before which was supposed to be more collage-based tape work, but I never managed to snag a copy before they diappeared (though I had my chances). He's got a lot more to explore in his discography but while I like this LP, I'm more curious about the collage-based material because I don't need any more records that sound like this. (Well, maybe I do, if I need any records at all). [19 December 2012]


Date: 18 September 2010

Preggy Peggy & The Lazy Babymakers - Get An Ace Case Of The Measles

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: Vinyl

Source: Dennis Tyfus

Cost: €5

Records like this make me miss being involved with underground or noise or whatever music; they're so eclectic, antisocial, and goofy and part of me still loves the absurdity of the vinyl LP as a format to express stuff like this. I think this is that woman Angela who used to work at Twisted Village that I met once, and it ranges from sick-sounding harsh noise to weird comedy skits (just like a hip-hop album, except way better) to bizarre genre-bending country workouts, twee pop interludes, and other miscellany. It's an audio treat - actually not a million miles away from Vernon and Burns except far more sloppy. I live for nonsense like this. [27 November 2012]


Date: 18 September 2010

V/A - Popcorn

Label: Ultra Eczema

Format: Vinyl

Source: Dennis Tyfus

Cost: €10

Dennis sold me this cheap because he was having trouble selling them. I wonder why a double LP compilation of 'Popcorn' covers wouldn't fly off the shelves? Also, since there's about 40 different artists on here, I think he gave out royalty copies and hardly had any left. It's a tremendously stupid record, and it's hard to listen to; despite the diversity of the sounds, the recurring melody eventually makes you nuts. So many of my friends appear on this it's ridiculous - and there's lots of different takes, some fairly straight, some only loosely related (and a few that actually use the sound of popcorn being popped).
