But it's also a neat snapshot of my musical world, or at least the people I hung around for a few years. [26 November 2012]


Date: 21 September 2010

Stereolab - Aluminum Tunes

Label: Warp Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £18

I've been trying to get the 'essential' Stereolab records from eBay lately - ever since Caleb was rocking 'Refried Ectoplasm' on his laptop speakers in Mooste, I've been having a huge Stereolab revival.  This is a pretty phenomenal selection of music, presented in a beautiful triple LP/double gatefold with screened covers.  I don't know any of the material from this but that's because it's all singles, b-sides, and outtakes, from their most rewarding period of activity.  There's a lot of amazing songs and I'd maybe say they get a lot more experimental here than on the albums ('One Note Samba' which is playing as I type this is particularly amazing); there's a few tracks that are just sketches and they're pretty nice too, and indiciate a bit of what it must be like in the studio with Tim Gane.  At £18 including shipping, this was really a bargain; I think this might be a nice time to get old Stereolab records cheap, as they are too recent to be trendy again and there's something a bit unhip about it.  I want to get Mars Audiac Quintet, Transient Random Noise Bursts and most of all, Dots & Loops before I quit.  And maybe Cobra and Phases if that's easy to find on vinyl.



Date: 24 September 2010

Rauhan Orkesteri - Dingdongtyyny-Europetour-05

Label: Tyyfus

Format: Vinyl

Source: Sami Pekkola

Cost: €12.5

A reissue of a live CDr, this has mixed fidelity and presumably recording dates too, and that's exactly what makes it so special. The second track is so overdriven that the saxes sound more like a children's toy, or a broken kazoo. Jaakko pounds away with that bursty, rolling rumble he does that no one else, not even Corsano, can approximate. As explosive as this band is live (at least from the one awesome time I've seen 'em), the quiet bits here really scream - weird vocals-thorugh-sax, small Art Ensemble sounds, occasional shrill hiss - I think there's a lot of instrumentation not listed here. Listening to this makes me really miss Finland and how lucky I was to be around musicians like this; crazy that I've only seen Lauhkeat Lampaat once, because I should have taken every opportunity for it (though maybe they've only actually played properly once since I moved there). I need to push myself back up there into this jazzworld because I can't get any taste of it here - what Estonian improvised music I've seen, when good, has been pretty far away from this pulse. [16 July 2012]


Date: 27 September 2010

J. Tolvi Semiband - Oleilua

Label: Ikuisuus

Format: CD

Source: Jaakko Tolvi

Cost: €0



Date: 1 October 2010

Game Theory - Blaze Of Glory

Label: Rational Records 

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay.co.uk

Cost: £19.99

I've been on a huge Game Theory kick lately and I found this rare pressing of their first LP on ebay for "only" 14.99 Buy it Now.  Of course, it comes without a cover, but being that there were only 500 pressed I jumped at this.  I dunno, maybe I actually paid too much.  Game Theory and Scott Miller are in no way popular or trendy right now, but I bet the rest of the world will wise up eventually and the value of this will increase exponentially.  This pressing is absolutely terrible sounding - lots of distortion, to the point where I kept checking to see if my stylus was clean.  But there's some great songs on here, and I'm starting to be won over to early GT more than later stuff.  It's a simple sound, with pretty shitty sounding keyboard layered over new wave gloss, but it doesn't hurt awesome songs like 'Something to Show' and 'Bad Year at UCLA'.  'It Gives me Chills' is one I didn't really know before and it's an awesome song.  I guess I'll have to grab the missing GT records because they're establishing themselves as an all-time fave (and it only took about 10 years of enjoyment!).



Date: 4 October 2010

Bobb Trimble - Iron Curtain Innocence

Label: Secretly Canadian

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £15.29

I listen mp3s of these Bobb Trimble records constantly but I never jumped on Secretly Canadian's vinyl reissues when they were made available, so now I've corrected that.  These are pressed very nicely, and you can hear what marvelous fidelity is there and all of the layers.  The bass playing is particularly thick in a way that makes me glad to have this.  I don't care if The Acid Archives says these SC reissues screw up the sound and sequencing - this sounds awesome.  That book is probably right is calling these the two best self-released albums in the history of rock music.  I used to slightly prefer this one but now Harvest of Dreams (which will probably arrive in the post tomorrow) gets the nod, but that's not to say that this isn't amazing too.  I actually like how divided the two sides are because I'm not always in the mood for both.  [4 October 2010]



Date: 5 October 2010

Bobb Trimble - Harvest Of Dreams

Label: Secretly Canadian

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £19.05

Harvest of Dreams!  What a record, and one where Trimble's voice is attenuated to a shrill, focused banshee wail.  'If Words Were All I Had' is pretty brilliant and balancing the trebly Trimble treble with the same fractured warble that makes Buckley's 'Song to the Siren' so great.  This is a really complex and weird album, which also repeats 'Premonitions' like Iron Curtain Innocence repeats 'One Mile from Heaven' -- except these are really two different versions, and 'Premonitions' is probably my favourite Bobb Trimble song, so I don't mind hearing it twice.  There's a lot of flanger, phaser and effects here but it still sounds like one man's personal vision at all times.  It's definitely more eclectic than the first one and definitely there's more to unravel here.  The silence track sounds great on vinyl cause of course it's not silent (and makes me realise it might be time to get a new stylus).  [5 Oct 2010]



Date: 6 October 2010

Daphne Oram - Oramics

Label: Young Americans

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £25.99

Reviewing a quadruple LP properly is a time-consuming activity, especially one from a single artist. This came out on CD at the same time as the Lily Greenham issue, also on Paradigm, and I was thrilled to discover both artists. It's fascinating how many women were working on the margins of experimental sound, especially sound like this which crosses over between electronic/synth composition to sound poetry to improvisation. Oram's work is a bit less vocally driven than Greenham's, but I'm really only comparing them because they were released around the same time. The four sides of this are continually provocative, with sci-fi dreamscapes, verbal glossolalia, and fairly dissonant noise workouts. It's too much to listen to in one sitting - even on CD, this has so many different pieces, being essentially a review of her entire career, that it's best taken in parts. The liner notes are spares, just directing me to a website, but the photos add to this sense of mid-century Americana that infuses her work. A photo of a woman with a conservative hairstyle and glasses in a 1950's-style housedress bent over a Uher reel-to-reel is almost comical, and I'm sorry it adds so much to the enjoyment of this as pure sounds, but it does. [2 December 2012]


Date: 6 October 2010

Andrew Paine & Richard Youngs - Guide To Music

Label: Sonic Oyster Records

Format: CDr

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £5.99

Richard and Paz release a ton of CDrs that I never have heard, and I figured this was weird considering how I love most of Richard's other collaborations.  So I took a gamble on this one and found something that was surprisingly clean and restrained, yet clearly casual.  There's a lot of hard-edged rhythm here, but very slow, and in the space between you can really feel the digitally-recorded acoustics.  The first and last tracks are the longest and maybe form a bit of a shell around the shorter tracks in the middle, but when it's over I'm left feeling like there was nothing essential whatsoever here.  Paz is a pretty awesome guy (at least from what I remember, the one time we hung out) and maybe I should investigate the other 25 cdr releases they do together, but with all of the other Youngs product out there (not to mention the boatloads of non-Youngs records I have to listen to) it's probably not going to be high on my priorities. [16 Oct 2010]



Date: 6 October 2010

Deerhunter - Halcyon Digest

Label: 4AD

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £12.79

Deerhunter have slowly and gradually become perhaps my favourite existing indierock/mainstream/whatever band, though this happened quite gradually over the past few years, and I still haven't really dived headfirst into their world like I used to.  I chalk that up partially to age and saturation, and partially to the time required to really extract pleasure from their music.  Microcastle eventually became a fave once I really started to feel the layers of misery underneath the surface sounds - unlike their first record or that amazing Flourescent Gray EP, this was a record that revealed its genius between the lines.  Halcyon Digest is even more subtle in its beauty.  In fact, writing these comments after only three listens is kinda funny because I think (providing I give it the time that it warrants) I will love this record immensely in two years.  On the surface this is far more restrained, a low-key third album (maybe a bit like the Velvet Underground's third or the Mekons Journey to the End of the Night).  The songs are very, very strong and a bit more accessible than anything before, and recorded wonderfully (4AD's white vinyl pressing sounds great, with the distorted vocals and warm acoustics amped up to recall the same sentimental memories of teenage years spent listening to R.E.M. and Pavement).  This may almost sound like a step backwards from the ambient/punk textures they explored before, except they've actually managed to integrate them into the songs as a more cohesive unit.  The two songs that are written by the other guy are both amazing - bright and warm, and recalling something familiar without being derivative.  The title suggests a more peaceful place, and though I haven't really dug into any lyrics yet, I'm already feeling themes of religion, loss, and wasted youth, which isn't anything groundbreaking for Deerhunter -- but I suspect as I further lose myself in this well of nostalgia, I'll probably feel the true melanchollia that I know is lurking.  Many artists write dark, sad songs, but Deerhunter expresses pain in such a genuine, under-the-surface way, that I feel like it's better to compare them to Alex Chilton on Big Star's third album than to something overtly down n' out.  Let's let the bad times roll.  [11 October 2010] 

I was right; two years later I love this record immensely and still listen to it constantly. 'Memory Boy' might be my top rock song of the past few years. [30 December 2012]



Date: 6 October 2010

Kemialliset Ystävät - Ullakkopalo

Label: Fonal Records

Format: LP

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £14.99

Holy shit, Jan has made something really truly incredible here.  And in a way, it's sorta slipping under the radar.  It's weird to finally hear this in October, when I actually hosted the record release listening party.  But I actually didn't hear the record at all when this happened - I was stuck in Ptarmigan making sushi while he played it for the audience of about 60 people, so I really just felt the vibrations through the wall.  I decided to wait for the vinyl to appear and then I forgot about it, until I became too embarrassed to ask Jan for a copy or buy it locally. So I imported it to Finland, which is kinda stupid.  And I finally got to sit down and listen to it, and I'm actually totally blown away by this.  This is a true work of genius, a densely layered, meticulously arranged masterpiece of sound.  I've only been sorta-into KY before, preferring Jan's solo vision, but this is really that -- just utilising the contributions of lots of lots of friends (Roope, Jaakko Tolvi, Carole and Koji, and pretty much everyone else I know).  This defies any sort of classification as psychedelic music, freak-folk, electro-acoustic, etc. -- it's really a beast of its own, providing a million twists and turns.  It's an audio maze, with an almost ludicrous attention to detail and a masterful touch of editing.  I think by this point the greater musical world isn't paying much attention to what's going on in Finland, which means this will probably escape the attention it deserves, or it will be unfairly marginalised as being part of that whole scene that people were into 5 years ago.  But that's fine with me, because it will honestly take me years to unravel this and every listen will be a new thrill.  [11 October 2010] 



Date: 6 October 2010

Richard Youngs - Beyond The Valley Of Ultrahits

Label: Jagjaguwar

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £9.29

My god, have I grown to love this record.  I remember when Richard originally did it as a limited CDr through Volcanic Tongue and the team was ranting in their update about how brilliant it was ... I downloaded it and thought it was OK but didn't compare to my favourite song-based Richard stuff.  But now, after spending a good year listening to it frequently (while driving) it's become a singalong favourite.  When Tuukka visited last summer he told me how the last live show he saw, Richard was just doing karaoke to the whole album and trying to get the audience to sing along.  How I would have loved that!  I love belting out 'Collapsing Stars', and 'Summer Void' is probably my overall favourite, but every song is worth singing along to.  There's a lot of complexity and quite a lot of styles influencing this, which really does stand apart from his other work.  The electro influence is not insignificant but it still retains that downhome folky feel of Sapphie or New Angloid Sound.  It's impossible to say what's the best Richard Youngs album but this is unquestionably a milestone in his career, though because I'm already a somewhat obsessive fan, maybe this is just me.  [24 May 2011]


Date: 6 October 2010

Richard Youngs & Simon Wickham-Smith - 20 Years

Label: VHF Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £31.99

The 20 Years package is not just an LP but an LP with three bonus CDs, so it's a ton to digest. 20 Years itself commemorates Richard and Simon's long-running relationship with a series of short sketches, very electronic-tinged, that remind me somewhat of Metallic Sonatas. 'Silence', for example, is anything but - it's a buzz-saw of exploratory assonance. Songphase is the most celebrated CD here - 10 great pop songs from 1996, never released before for some crazy reason. This has the shimmer/shoegaze buzz throughout and an earnest, reverb-laden Richard singing throughout. 'West of the City' is bright and sweet; 'Dream Song' is exactly that. The live CD has dark, cloudy explorations and gothic Casio-beat songforms; it's recorded pretty well so is maybe a good example of these guys experimenting without the benefit of overdubs. But the real gem might be SMIRR, four tracks cut in 1995 that are absolutely beautiful, built around an electroacoustic strum. Liner notes by Marc Masters, Neil Campbell and David Keenan, but my one complaint is that the CDs all got scratched when I slid them out of their cardboard sleeves. [30 October 2012]


Date: 6 October 2010

Richard Youngs & Simon Wickham-Smith - 5 Years

Label: VHF Records

Format: CD

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £11.79

Every year for 5 years, R!!! and S!!! bashed out a track which was released in 2006 on this CD. It's interesting how similar these tracks sound - they could have been recorded all at the same time, for they all tend to be electro-acoustic ecstatic madness in the same vein - a vein they have mined before, for sure, but not as completely distinct as here. The car-alarm synths in '2003'  become pretty abrasive, definitely a callback to Metallic Sonatas; '2004' is a tremelo effect taken to the extreme, which is disorientating and brilliant. Of the many many of Richard's albums I've accumulated over the years this is one I tend to forget about, falling into the lower 10-15 that I rarely listen to. But all of those, for the most part, have their rewards, and this is no exception. [24 December 2012]


Date: 11 October 2010

Bobby Brown - The Enlightening Beam Of Axonda

Label: Destiny Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £19.99

If you look up "privately-pressed outsider psychedelia" in the dictionary, there should probably be a picture of Enlightening Beam of Axonda there. I mean, for Christ's sake, the record is called Enlightening Beam of Axonda after all. This is the Bobby Brown record that made his name (if he actually made any sort of name beyond being the Beach Boys' drug dealer) though Prayers of the One Man Band is the album that I truly love. If I hadn't fallen for that one first, I would probably be crazy about Axonda, but it's somewhat less accessible and much more far-out, without as much calypso influence. The songs are not quite as catchy, but much more serious in their conveyance of the truth of Axonda, or whatever, and I eat this shit up with a spoon. [26 July 2012]


Date: 19 October 2010

Can - Future Days

Label: United Artists Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £18.99

Realised my CD disappeared, so I grabbed this on eBay, happy to have it on vinyl anyway.  This appears to be a bootleg though - the cover printing has noticeably pixellation, and the labels on the LP itself are completely blank.



Date: 1 November 2010

Fossils - The Golden Door

Label: Kye

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £11

Another cryptic release from Kye, following the formula if there is one - low-level murky motion with little discernable sources. Side one is like a rock caught in one's throat; side two squats down for a fully overwhelming sound barrage, like a low-flying plane. The last movement is an unsettling hum, a coda of unrest. It's over in an eye-blink but it packs each moment with 'action'. [18 December 2012]


Date: 1 November 2010

Sun City Girls - Funeral Mariachi

Label: Abduction

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £24

This is the end, I'm afraid, and I find this impossible to play without getting sad. If this is a true tribute to Charles Gocher then it's appropriate in tone, for sadness saturates Funeral Mariachi, their final album, and I think one of their definitive works. I'm not sure how much was assembled in the studio posthumously (as this came out 3 years after his death) but it's magical in a way that nothing else they ever recorded is. There's madcap surrealism, ethnoforgeries, surreal songs, and unexpected soundtracks of pure beauty, sure. But unlike the other million albums they released, there's a sense of true development here - the band is not repeating themselves at all, but instead showing what could have been, which makes it even more devastating to listen to. As the title indicates there is a funereal mood here - lots of piano, at times making this stunningly 'inside' ('Mineral Wells' and 'Vine Street Piano' are chillingly accessible, the later accentuated with Eyvind Kang's viola). But there's also tracks like 'Ben's Radio' that show the musical brilliance that SCG were capable of practically phoning in. 'The Imam' is full of falsetto vocals in a made up language, yet it's striking how much I am moved by it, despite how ridiculous it is. 'Holy Ground' could be a blueprint for a new genre of songwriting, if anyone wanted to pick up the lead.  Maybe this is overall their most mellow release, but it succeeds in being an elegant, graceful swan song without compromising any of the nonsense that made this band so brilliant. The closing track, 'Funeral Mariachi', sends off their legacy through a ghostly echo, smirking as it fades into the distance, while tears rumble in my eyes. [23 August 2012]


Date: 1 November 2010

Jim Shepard - V-3 Next Album

Label: Not On Label

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £19

This is a bootleg of what would have been the last V-3 album had Shepard not tragically committed suicide.  I've become such a fan that I had to get this even though it's kinda pricey and there's not really any packaging to speak of.  The album is of course unfinished, about half-instrumental and half-vocal.  Unless that was what Shepard intended.  There's some hissy, dirgy instrumental tracks that recall early Vertical Slit, as they're saturated in weird cheap effects and have an otherwordly feel, with some extended instrumental creeping in the corners.  Others sound just like they are missing a vocal track.  But when Shepard opens his mouth, it's on -- and pretty satisfying too.  There's a spoken track at the beginning of side two, and a great dark angry song on side one with the line "I gave her $100 and she put it in her arm".  The last song (which I'll call "Illogical") is a long bouncy one that is surely one of Shepard's greatest.  "All that I learned I taught to myself/ self-taught delusions and secondhand mess", and even though this is a cheapo bootleg I'm just happy to be able to hear this.  [6 November 2010]



Date: 1 November 2010

Les Rallizes Denudes - Blind Baby Has It's Mothers Eyes

Label: Phoenix Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £15

This feels like the longest single LP I've ever heard, though I haven't actually measured it since time melts into an unceasing hammering brainthrust when listening to Blind Baby Has It's Mothers Eyes. Incorrect punctuation aside, this is a pretty epic jam, built around thick yet open guitar shards, squeals of voice and feedback, and a repetitive ascent on the closing track where all the musicians seem like they are driving towards something impossible. 'An Awful Eternity' is the track split over both sides and it's awful and splendid simultaneously. Again, props to Phoenix for a ridiculously great job on the mastering and pressing. [18 August 2012]


Date: 1 November 2010

Les Rallizes Denudes - Heavier Than A Death In The Family

Label: Phoenix Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £24

Heavy it is - this double LP set is bookended by two massive side-long slabs of distorted freakout rock; 'rock music' taken to all levels of extreme, but not only volume - thick layers, aggressive blasts of crazed vocals, and a remarkably group-based cohesion. Side three becomes the closest to singer-songwriter rock music, built around slightly more lyrical songs - inching towards convention, but then 'Ice Fire' comes crashing in and we're back in the land of insanity. Phoenix did a great job on these - the sound great, all the static and distortion sounding 'true' in the thick 180g vinyl. [28 July 2012]


Date: 1 November 2010

Call Back The Giants - Call Back The Giants

Label: Kye

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: £16

Tim Goss's first solo album under the name Call Back the Giants isn't incredibly surprising if you're familiar with his work in the Shadow Ring, especially I'm Some Songs. Much of the album is built around minimalist synth and odd ambience, with the occasional vocal (in a downtrodden, processed and generally WTF manner). I don't really think of this as anything like all those other minimal synth artists (Oneohtrixpoint Never, for example) because this has that otherwordlyness that is on another plane entirely, like most of the Kye roster. 'My Brother' ends the record in a really contemplative mood, with twinkling stars. Their second one got a bit more attention but I still haven't listened to it. [2 Aug 2012]


Date: 25 November 2010

Alex Chilton - Feudalist Tarts

Label: New Rose Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Kimmoncado records

Cost: €15

Pretty weak 80's Chilton - the 'don't give a fuck' attitude is present, but the sounds don't do much. The production is glossy and sterile, and the disingenuousness is finally a bit too  much. Great title, though. [12 November 2012]


Date: 25 November 2010

Prisonshake - Singles '87-'89

Label: Scat Records (2)

Format: Box Set

Source: Kimmoncado records

Cost: €25.99

This is a box set of the first four Prisonshake 7"s, an excellent and varied introduction to the early period of this most underreated band. The first EP, "Fairfield Avenue Serenade", has that great Midwest guitar-balladry that 80's indie rock is capable of. Doug Enkler joined as vocalist for the second 7" and instantly the songs take on a more anthemic quality that reminds me greatly of early Silkworm - fun, energetic, and somehow serious at the same time. The B-side contains a bunch of overlapping fragmentary songs, split between the left and right speakers, a good experiment that I decided to listen to all at once, which makes a cool sea of indierock mess (but with some nice overlapping phase serendipities at time) The 'Deanna' 45 is the closest to mature period Prisonshake, though still a bit ragged, and the last 7" is a pure experiment of genres and goofing around, which is fun but a bit like filler. This is somewhat annoying to listen to, with the constant flipping and speed-changing, but would be a good collection to have as a standalone album, which I doubt will ever happen since no one really cares about Prisonshake. [12 Aug 2012]


Date: 16 February 2011

Cheveu - Mille

Label: Born Bad Records / Kill Shaman

Format: Vinyl

Source: Kill Shaman Records

Cost: $19.5

A new Cheveu record is cause for celebration, though oddly I never picked up the Cheveau release, leaving a large hole in my collecting of this band (one of the few contemporaries who I feel compelled to get everything by).  Mille is a huge step forward, as Agent Royalty already commented on.  The basic sound of their first record was probably starting to feel like a dead end, but there's still many elements from it - synth drums, manic vocal glossolalia, and edgy yet strangely familiar guitar licks.  There's actually a string section on some tracks, and 'No Birds' emerges as a real masterpiece, with crossover hit potential.  'Like a Deer in the Headlights' was a single I got almost 2 years ago, and this appears on side two, and is really a blueprint for the new direction.  Better production, more confidence, and they're taking chances - I'm totally delighted by Mille and I think it will ultimately eclipse the first album for me.  'Charlie Sheen' is an awesome song with a great thrashy breakdown which is particularly relevant given Mr. Sheen's recent activities.  [3 March 2011]


Date: 16 February 2011

Dead Luke - American Haircut

Label: Floridas Dying

Format: Vinyl

Source: Kill Shaman Records

Cost: €16.5

I can't decide if this Dead Luke LP is totally great or if it's just going through the motions of the current weird bedroom-psych/punk thing (or maybe not-so-current anymore, but what I was checking out a lot about 1-2 years ago).  There's a lot of reverby vocals, damaged guitar textures, weird casio bits and enough of an organic feel to tick my boxes, but I think it's the actual songwriting that makes this good.  With titles like 'The Best Drug I've Ever Done' and 'Acid Forest', the M.O. is pretty clear. At one listen there's stuff like 'Sunrise' - a totally expansive, psychedelic soundscape that really sets the mood, in the middle of the album; also 'You're Bringing Me Down' which feels like a compendium of druggy effects centered around vocal monotony.  I think this guy is from Portland, or maybe I just assume that cause Pete Swanson mastered it.  I can certainly feel this coming out of the same scene that produced Eat Skull, as there's a similar approach, just minus all the punk.  I think I like this though, and will probably listen to it lots.


Date: 15 March 2011

Volcano The Bear - Planetary Bethlehem

Label: Beta-lactam Ring Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Nick Mott

Cost: £35

It's been ages since I've bought an ultra-limited art edition VtB release but I'm not sure why I went for this - maybe just for nostalgia's sake, and because I like Nick's art. This is very nicely put together - not over the top like The Mountains Among Us was, but just generally a clean, elegant package. The music appears to be Paddenless-VtB, recorded over past years and collaged together into a series of untitled tracks. There's a lot of looping, circular sounds here using keyboards, synths, and clatter, and very little voice. Taken as a whole it feels like a collage, but the individual tracks work as short pieces; as fragments and ideas that assemble into a whole. It's a different direction for them, I guess, though it's also maybe a bit less distinct, lacking their original surreal, alien approach to construction. [24 December 2012]


Date: 18 March 2011

Vernon and Burns meet Lied Music - Lost Lake

Label: Shadazz

Format: LP

Source: Luke Fowler

Cost: €0

Oh, there's nothing quite like the thrill of opening a box of LPs and taking our your own record and putting it on the turntable for the first time and then sliding it onto your shelf when you are finished listening to it.  This is the third time I have experienced such a pleasure.  But actually, the first time I've really heard it since I only had the rejected test pressings of the first go-round.  Wow, they did a great job the second time through!  I'm really happy with this, even if The Wire supposedly gave it a bad review and I'm sure it will sell about 22 copies.  I'm also incredibly happy with the silkscreened covers, which I also didn't get to see before. [18 Mar 2011]


Date: 4 April 2011

D.W. Sutton - American Wildlife

Label: Highland Park Gem and Crystal Society

Format: CDr

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: €0

Dave from Car Commercials/Ladderwoe sent this to check in with me since we had been out of touch for awhile. Have I ever expressed how brilliant and fucked I think this guy's music is? American Wildlife picks up from the Ladderwoe vibe of a complete anti-aesthetic with something direct about it. This is from that genre of electro-acoustic weirdness that I try to work in with my own solo stuff (or at least Boat Trip), though this blows away anything I could do. The obvious comparison is Lambkin's Salmon Run, especially in the way there are small, fuzzy domestic sounds meeting electronics meeting sampled neo-classical beauty. But there's a really distinct vibe here, and as the disc goes on, I'm more and more baffled by it, which means I am more in love with it. Maybe it's time to relaunch the aborted Drake Pun Element project. This probably got little or no attention, which is a shame because it's so insanely great. If I had any money I'd do a full vinyl reissue immediately. [16 July 2012]


Date: 4 April 2011

David Sutton and Kevin Winter - Breakaway

Label: no label

Format: CDr

Source: Dave Sutton

Cost: €0



Date: 8 April 2011

Sagas - Between Worlds

Label: Greenup Industries

Format: LP

Source: McDowell

Cost: €0

I'm so excited that McDowell has a Sagas LP out now; everything I've heard before has been stunning and this is a real summation of it, with a few surprises.  Having known him so well, even if I haven't actually hung out with him much in the past six years, this is a wonderful and rewarding listen that makes me really miss him.  In some ways he's a real musical brother of mine, as our tastes are so striking similar and really developed in tandem, moreso than I would say about other close collaborators like Caleb.  So there's a lot of mysterious, cryptic guitar wizardry here (especially on side two, which takes on a shimmery mysterious ambience) but also a good bit of multi-instrumental jamming - drumming, This Heat-inspired clatter, and a real jazzpulse at times.  Maybe this is the skeleton key to McDowell, a starting point for future maps and explorations.  In any sense, I miss the hell out of him. [6 May 2011]


Date: 8 April 2011

Waterfinder / Nite Lite - split cassette

Label: Stunned

Format: cassette

Source: McDowell

Cost: €0

Nite Lite's first track is a brilliant bit of improv/concrete, built around delicate taps and hoots, like an owl caught in a very slow clock. It's a highlight for sure, and the thick, distant drone that comprises their second track (like a mellower Skaters, maybe) is also lovely, but when it gets back to the more spare plinks and plucks, I'm a bit more interested. Waterfinder is McDowell and Jackie, husband and wife and dear friends of mine. This beings in a sinister tone, with an ominous, unresolved drone hanging over some creepy vocals. This moves into some scraping bowed violins or other such strings, and it has that tense-but-ramshackle feeling that I like so much. Over the half-hour, the McDowells move around a variety of sounds, all rooted in acoustic clouds. There's some vocal experiments, some tentative plucking, some pulsing tape-motor, and an overall feeling of communication. [31 December 2012]


Date: 15 May 2011

Stephen Cornford - Two Works For Turntables

Label: Permanent Gallery

Format: Vinyl

Source: Stephen Cornford

Cost: €0

I enjoyed hanging out with Stephen Cornford and I also enjoy his recordings, which are very much demonstrations of sound-generating projects he did. Sound art, of course. The first side of this 7" is neutral sounding rotating drone, with a few different physical layers - probably ceramics and string - before it clicks into place and a deeper, more resonating drone (like a Tibetan prayer bowl) takes over. Side two is a bit more clangy, with bell sounds reverberating semi randomly, suggesting they are tied up and left to dangle from the turntable's motion. [16 December 2012]


Date: 15 May 2011

Stephen Cornford - Hysteresis

Label: Gifts Nobody Wants

Format: Cassette

Source: Stephen Cornford

Cost: €0

It's funny to me how Steve Cornford has this fancy Oxford Brookes sound education (sorry, Agent Ford) but then makes tapes that sound like this - not different, aesthetically, than what I would put out or anyone else from the neo-minimal underground would release. Side 1 is built around a tape echo on I think blank tape, which produces a whistling, flutey owl sound - over which various nervous jittery sounds come and go. On the flip, Steve gets a bit more miasmic and visceral; the instrument there is credited as 'galvanized extraction duct'. Of course. [14 July 2012]


Date: 15 May 2011

Stephen Cornford - Battery Acid

Label: Banned Production

Format: Cassette

Source: Stephen Cornford

Cost: €0



Date: 17 May 2011

Fall Of Saigon - Fall Of Saigon

Label: Gazul Records

Format: CD

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €19.12

An early Pascal Comelade project, Fall of Saigon is most easily compared to Young Marble Giants, for the formula is the same - simple bass lines, keyboards, and small songs led by a sweet, world-weary female vocalist. But there's a bit more diversity here - some dark, pulsing synths and some songs sung by guitarist Terry Den, who's 'She Leaves Me All Alone' is a highlight for sure. There's a couple cover versions - 'The End' which is closer to Nico than the Doors,and 'Part Time Punks' by Television Personalities, which is nice in this French early 80s context. Despite the spare palette, Fall of Saigon do a lot with a little and this is a very rewarding glimpse of English-language French post-punk. [21 December 2012]


Date: 17 May 2011

Fille Qui Mousse - Trixie Stapelton 291 - Se Taire Pour Une Femme Trop Belle

Label: Bichon Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €22.09

This is such an NWW-list classic that I've always taken it a bit for granted. It's surely a compendium of weird sounds from the 1970s, dipping into genre excursions at times. There's a lot of left-field sound fuckery - more primitive and lumbering than Berrocal, but more experimental than Faust. Mostly conventional rock instruments are at play, though there's some plucked strings that sound more ethnic and there's a sense that they'd do anything to avoid tradition. When it does sound like a rock band, there's actually a few psychedelic guitar solos, snappy drumming, and some vague song structures. Trixie Stapelton 291 is an album of sketches; vocals, scrapes, dog barks, and bells are all just additional colourings. The mix of 'band' moments and more abstract, weird soundforms is what makes the record overall so effective - it's a real pastiche of 'anything goes' exploration, yet still with a vision. [1 Aug 2012]


Date: 17 May 2011

Juju - A Message From Mozambique

Label: Black Fire

Format: CD

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €17.12



Date: 17 May 2011

Group Ongaku - Music Of Group Ongaku

Label: Seer Sound Archive

Format: Vinyl

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €22.11

Ongaku is the Japanese word for 'music' if I recall correctly, but these recordings, made in the early 1960's, are as radical of a redefinition of what music is as anything imaginable. The three compositions have a similarity to Fluxus scores but sound-wise, they are insane, even beyond what you would expect. These lengthy pieces are some of the most genuinely "non-idiomatic" improvisations I've ever heard. I could try to pick out sources - strings, pianos, tapes, radios, electronics - but it's really irrelevant. The key to me is the aesthetic, one which over 50 years later is still untouchable -- and the sense of group interplay. My tastes in outsider/experimental music are easy to pin down - I like feeling some balance between complete anti-establishment innovation and universal structures that are identifiable as 'music'. I think you get that here through the idea of the group, an important part of the ensemble's name. There is a world of interplay between these different musicians, and something expressive beyond "let's destroy music" or "isn't this experimental". By this I mean motion, tension, dynamic, and juxtaposition, all of which are in full-force throughout the diverse sounds of these 3 pieces. [23 November 2012]


Date: 17 May 2011

Elklink - The Rise Of Elklink

Label: Kye

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €19.12

Elklink is early Graham Lambkin, from a cassette release, and it's a wonderful thing. Cassettes are the core of this - a very manipulated and strange approach to sound construction, which is really tape heavy, but also with breathing, vocal murmurs, and lots of broken pause-button edits. I don't think voice is the entire source material - there's some definite electronics, though it's underplayed in favour of the voice material. There's a bonus track not on the original cassette, 'You', which is almost pure static atmosphere, with the barest bumps of activity. [1 November 2012]


Date: 17 May 2011

Ton Vlasman - White Room With Disintegrating Walls

Label: Wah Wah

Format: LP

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €22.12

Dutch psychedelia from 1970, reissued on thick vinyl the way it's done now. Vlasman sounds pretty mental when he sings, but when he shuts up and plays his guitar, like on the epic 'Fight With a Circular Course', it's like nothing else. Despite all the acoustic guitar wizards that have risen from history, Vlasman doesn't really sound like anyone else. He's not technically stunning on that track, but the atmosphere/mood is unbeatable - utterly distraught, with Eastern influences (percussion that takes a backseat), like a stoned, slow Sandy Bull. It gets more impressive on the flip, with a ragged, fast fingerpicking style. His cover of 'Pale Blue Eyes' pushes things into the outsider territory, mostly due to his singing style, which isn't terrible but certainly bizarre. I didn't think much of this when I first got it, but on a fresh listen it sounds fantastic. [25 September 2012]


Date: 17 May 2011

Sperm - Shh!

Label: De Stijl

Format: Vinyl, LP, Album, Reissue, Limited Edition

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €19.57

DeStijl, I guess, reissued this - or maybe it's a bootleg I have, cause the labels say it's the original O records and there's no mention of DeStijl and paste-on covers. This is a legendary record of Finnish outsider music, and I actually met the guy responsible once but I can't remember where - I just remember him coming up to me, probably some Ptarmigan event, and telling me how he was the guy that made the Sperm LP back in 1970. This is actually a fairly restrained and minimal bit of weirdness - most of side A could fit on the late 90's Kranky roster, with lots of soft, low drones to set an unsettling mood. There's definitely a strong influence of free improvisation, but contained into a patchwork of misuse. This really does sound like a prototype for a lot of the Lal Lal Lal artists 40 years later, even though that's an easy comparison to make cause Finland is so small. [15 November 2012]


Date: 17 May 2011

Staff Carpenborg And The Electric Corona - Fantastic Party

Label: Wah Wah

Format: Vinyl

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €22.12

Another long lost psychedelic artefact loving restored to thick vinyl, Staff Carpenborg actually has a nice party-boogie vibe. There's a rolling bassline and some excursions into fuzzy guitars and other noisemakers that makes this much closer to the United States of America (or that one Peter Ivers Band album that I like) than any German kozmikmusiche of that time. The vocals aren't super memorable but the fun jammy bits are great, not too heavy or experimental but also pleasantly weird, especially when some studio trickery is involved. One comparison is actually the Howling Hex work, though it's maybe not quite as goofy - and actually a bit more loose. The vocals are totally easy to ignore and they left no impression on me, and that's actually quite nice here. The last track in particular is a great swampy jam with spazzy too-much-coffee guitar - which really sounds like nothing else. [23 July 2012]


Date: 18 May 2011

High Aura'd / Andre Foisy - Split

Label: Stunned Records

Format: Cassette

Source: Stunned Records

Cost: $6

High Aura'd, with high in the name, sound like a stoner projet and indeed this is very slow, heavy music. It starts out like a beautiful Organum piece, slowly bringing in searing guitars in a delicate way. About halfway through it gets highly thunderous, but that fades away, leaving a buzzing drone with some beautiful electric guitar scenery. Andre Foisy, on the flip, creates a strange, dense sound piece that builds up electronics and organic sounds into a very voice-laden hurricane. The final moments are like something out of THX1138. The sides complement each other well, and like all Stunned releases, the packaging is lovely. [17July 2012]


Date: 18 May 2011

Inez Lightfoot / Je Suis Le Petit Chevalier - "Offering" / "Pannacotta"

Label: Stunned Records

Format: Cassette

Source: Stunned Records

Cost: $6



Date: 18 May 2011

Inhibitionists / Afterlife - Split

Label: Stunned Records

Format: Cassette

Source: Stunned Records

Cost: $6

Inhibitionists and Afterlife fit pretty well together, as both are long-form, expansive psychedelic drone.  Inhibitionists push the high-end well and it works with the tape hiss to homogenise even the free-improv sections.  Afterlife is quite heavy on the synth gurgles, and the long section with a a slowly tugging motor feel is utter stasis, despite the erratic delay-drenched chik-chik sounds.  [24 May 2011]


Date: 18 May 2011

Remote Islands - Days Of Heaven

Label: Stunned Records

Format: Cassette

Source: Stunned Records

Cost: $6

I don't know much about Remote Islands, but it sounds like one man's solo singer-songwriter project, built around tinny, home-recorded banjo and a deep, soulful (yet "indie") voice. The production and predilection for repetitive, instrumental bits puts it closer to the 'psychedelic' side than 'straight', but do the two have to be opposed? The banjo playing is rhytmic, not particularly traditional in style, and leads to a solid pulsebeat and cohesion. The songs are catchy, and there's a really nice atmosphere to it all. I could easily fall in love with this tape, especially the bits that remind me of the Homosexuals and Brian Eno (most of side two, really). [18 September 2012]


Date: 18 May 2011

Mortuus Auris & The Black Hand - The White Paper

Label: Stunned Records

Format: Cassette

Source: Stunned Records

Cost: $6

Here's a double cassette I got on a big order to Stunned last year, which is by this curious artist who I've never heard of before. The tapes are inspired by a book I never heard of, by Philip Ball, and over 80 minutes explore all manners of modern experimental psychedelic music. The source instruments are mostly acoustic, and some parts (particularly side C) reminds me of the experiments of Asmus Tietchens - they aren't afraid to drop a coherent moment in favor of something a bit more fragemented, if it means they can try something else. By the end of this I'm very impressed, especially at the dedication to the cassette format, which is not as high-quality in terms of fidelity but provides a nicely structured package for this. It would be really good to check out some of their other work. [29 December 2012]


Date: 18 May 2011

Super Minerals - Multitudes

Label: Digitalis Recordings

Format: CD

Source: Stunned Records

Cost: $6

Mixed psychedelia from Phil French, proprietor of Stunned Records, and William Giacchi. Multitudes is extremely swirly instrumental music, with soft-toned keyboards, layered vocals, and light percussive elements such as bells and other patter. It flows seamlessly, getting a trippy underwater vibe underway on tracks such as 'The View' and never showing it's hand completely. As mysterious as it gets, it stick to a vaguely pastoral atmosphere, and it's a good voyage, if a bit indistinct. [29 December 2012]


Date: 30 May 2011

C. Spencer Yeh - In The Blink Of An Eye

Label: De Stijl

Format: Vinyl

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

I love this 7", two songs by Spencer that find him exploring his songwriting side. 'In the Blink of an Eye' is an insanely catchy, simple song that hints at a domestic darkness underneath.  It's great, but the b-side, 'Condo Stress', is the real treasure map. I can hear so many of his influences here, particularly Smog and Drag City-label stuff, but there's really a brilliant, unique take on everything. It's a mystery, an emotional enigma, and laid out completely straight-forward over an electric piano line. I need to get his whole song-based album that is now out. [10 December 2012]


Date: 30 May 2011

Sych - Lunar Roulette

Label: Strange Attractors Audio House

Format: LP

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

SYCH is an acronym for Shoup, Yeh, Corsano and Horist, and this is one of the more overtly blues/jazz-based recordings I've ever heard Spencer play on.  This is due to Shoup and Horist, who tend to hit these moody, modal intervals throughout, most notably on the first side. Spencer and Corsano have such a good dialogue at this point but it feels cohesive, and not like two duos.  Horist's guitar is great against the vocal section Spencer drops, and the free-for-all 'Qoph Odyssey' on side two is sadly too short.  [7 June 2011]


Date: 30 May 2011

Don Dietrich & Ben Hall - Spitfire

Label: What The...

Format: LP

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

A nice What The... release with a full colour cover, Spitfire presents the distinct saxophone style of Don Dietrich against Ben Hall's flowing drumming. This is a fairly clean recording, with a lot of space for both musicians to work off each other. Dietrich is a hellbeast of a player, but he's able to effortlessly slide between the 'jazz' feel and a more wall-of-sound noise approach (which I'm more used to hearing him do with Bortbeomagus). Over the two sides of this he does both of these things, but does not dominate - it really is a fair split in screen time across the two. The pulse is relentless, and when Dietrich mellows out for just a bit at the beginning of side two, it's not long before he amps up the dissonance and finishes the set with pure ferocity. This gets filed between the Dictators and Durutti Column, heh. [2 December 2012]


Date: 30 May 2011

Bren't Lewiis Ensemble - At the North Pole, Easter Day, 1982

Label: What The ...?

Format: one-sided 12"

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

This was recorded on the North Pole and that's special indeed. I didn't get enough Bren't Lewiis Ensemble in the BUFMS box set, so thank God for Spencer's label to issue this 1-sided 12". Its full of vocals shenanigans, repetitive nonsense, thwacking about on various objects as percussion and tonally too - a true trip to goofball land. 'A weeba wobba weeba wobba weeba wobba woo' is the name of this, and you can hear on 'Mermaid Freakout' that there was actually a decent crowd at the North Pole. Guess there was nothing else to do, especially on a holiday. Wish it was a full LP. [26 December 2012]


Date: 30 May 2011

Gordy Horn - The Glue That Holds the Kids Together

Label: What The ...?

Format: one-sided 12"

Source: Spencer

Cost: €0

Spencer was playing in this Gordy Horn project for awhile which wasn't super popular but I always dug; the cassettes and material I heard before seemed to be built around messy, rhythmic jams while this guy who used to be tangentially related to Parliament runs amok. This one-sided 12" has a bit of that, but the music is a lot more flowing, with some distorted noisy jams, a dream-like song, and a drifting meditation at the end ('The Concept of Love') over which the madcap vocals are laid. A good time; like all these 1-sided 12"s, I want more. [27 December 2012]


Date: 21 June 2011

Trumans Water - Godspeed The Punchline

Label: Elemental Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £9.99

I've had a real resurgence of interest in Trumans Water this year.  I saw them in 1993 I think, and again around 2000 at the MIT, but I have no memories of them as a live band.  They're one of those bands that I was always aware of, but sorta slipped through my cracks (and also I think I was wary because of the Christian thing with Soul Junk, which doesn't bother me anymore).  So revisiting Trumans Water now is fun, especially as their records are relatively easy to find because there's nothing collectible or hip about them (yet).  Godspeed the Punchline is a really solid record, which has some great instrumental freakouts between the carefully constructed songs.  I still don't really understand where to place their sound.  They were from San Diego and play a punk/hardcore-influenced art-rock style, but they don't remind me of Antioch Arrow or Heroin at all.  But they do sort of remind me of Harriet the Spy.  There's more of a Beefheart edge than any of those bands, and the often double-tracked vocals that give it a frantic, yelpy style.  Though it's mostly hard and fast, there are moments that things get more lyrical.  I think the production is better on this one than on Spasm Smash which might be another reason I like it the most (so far).  But there's a pretty massive discography to investigate.  [20 Dec 2011]


Date: 6 July 2011

Bobby Brown - Prayers Of A One Man Band

Label: Destiny Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay.co.uk

Cost: £41.99

Could this be most I've ever paid for a single LP?  SO fucking jazzed about this even if I paid a ton for it.  It's in great shape and the MP3 copy I fell in love with is missing a track and really sounds completely different.  There are many layers of gurgling synths and much bolder percussion here than whomever ripped the copy floating around online.  Fucking shit I love this record.  I think the hardcore psychheads probably prefer Enlightening Beam of Axonda but I think this is the masterpiece, even though the songs all kinda sound the same.  There's a bright 80's sheen that makes the steel drums and other aspects jump out and the songwriting is just amazing.  The liner notes have typewritten lyrics with Bobby's own handwritten addendums.  Absolutely essential.  [6 July 2011]


Date: 6 July 2011

Paste - Silverwood

Label: Imp Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay.co.uk

Cost: £4.97

As a Refrigerator fan I figured it's my constitutional duty to check out Paste, Dennis Callaci's solo project. His singing voice is actually a lot like his brother's, but I guess they share a lot of DNA. But while Refrigerator constructs measured, emotional indie-rock anthems (at least as their career progresses), Paste is unsurprisingly much more free-form. A lof of Silverwood finds Callaci banging on an acoustic guitar and singing almost Jandek-style, except with lyrics easier to connect to. The straight folk-forms feel like a Refrigerator record and this is probably exactly why these things are called "side projects" - it's like an appetiser besides the main course. Paste hasn't released anything in over 15 years so maybe Refrigerator has been the only outlet Dennis has needed since. [8 November 2012]


Date: 27 July 2011

Psychic Frost - untitled

Label: Deep Water Acres

Format: CDr

Source: McDowell and Jackie

Cost: $0

This is a duo of Mike Tamburo and Matt McDowell, two former close collaborators (we had a short-lived trio that never did much but many jam sessions in my old apartment) and friends. This is I think a live recording, as its recorded in a coffee shop that is now closed, but maybe it was just recorded there without an audience. The fidelity is crisp, though it sounds like a room recording - no distortion, and everything is very loud and up-front. The two long tracks feature these guys doing more of what they did in Arco more than their later work, meaning this is very acoustic/folk-based space/drone. The second track starts off with some lovely dulcimer and banjo interactions, which does actually remind me a bit of the Sagas records McDowell has made. It's really jammy in a faux-middle eastern way, until it eventually falls apart and becomes the harmonious drone style of track 1. There's a more manic edge to this one though, and I take it over the first track because I like that intensity more than the sense of wonder conveyed before. I'm not nearly as interested in music like this anymore but these guys certainly do it well. [8 Aug 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

The Working Poor - Icing the Kicker

Label: none

Format: 2xCD

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $9

Collecting Working Poor releases is like trying to get blood from a stone, but I was overjoyed to see a live double CD in the usual deluxe packaging, sure to disappear from the records of history as soon as I purchase it. This is a live show from 2008, recorded pretty well but with tons of audience noise, banter, and intrusions from children - which is certainly the intention. This is a drummerless Working Poor, a quartet with Greg Pierce on electric guitar, and I like it, though not quite as much as the New Wealth lineup. The songs are a mix of faves and some new ones, and some Anita Fix songs I guess, spread over two discs yet it doesn't feel overly long. I love Alan's songs so much and this is a really valuable recording to have - there's great versions of 'Love is Fey', 'Seratonin', and 'Kiss Me Twice' on here, and some fun new ones I wasn't familiar with like 'Sexy'. Hopefully next time I'm in Pittsburgh I'll get some other magical dropping from this most secret of pleasures. [7 Aug 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Alasdair Roberts & Friends - Too Long In This Condition

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $7.25

These are the songs that I've seen Ali play live the last few times I've seen him, and 'Friends' primarily consist of Stevie Jones and Shane, with Ben Reynolds playing (pretty decent) lap steel on a few tracks. The song about the ptarmigan is here! This has probably become my second favourite Alasdair Roberts record after Farewell Sorrow, though the vibe is completely different. The songs are contemplative and mature, lacking the exuberance of the early material but with the same earnest intensity. The recording is lovely, and as traditionally rooted as the instrumentation is, it doesn't sound derivative at all. Ali's voice is so full of truth that it's hard not to be somewhat chilled at the delivery. [7 Aug 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Tony Caro & John - All On The First Day

Label: Gaarden Records

Format: Vinyl /Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $12.5

Tony, Caro and John made this one totally great electric psych-folk record and it's reissued here on lovely marble green vinyl - the better to stare at when tripping out. Stylistically, this lands somewhere between early Tyrannosaurus Rex and the Giles, Giles and Fripp album. It's all rooted around guitars, sometimes with backwards effects and other processing of the time, and young, nieve English vocalising. The blues licks are throughout but this trio crunches along nicely, and some of the more stripped down, eager songs like 'There Are No Greater Heroes' for some reason transcend the trappings of the time period. 'Snowdon Song' and 'Sargasso Sea' are absolutely great; 'Dont Sing This Song' is even more awesome, and has a goofy Holy Modal Rounders meet the Incredible String Band feel. The liner notes thank decades of fans for keeping this album alive, so here's to a few more. [28 July 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

El Jesus De Magico - Scalping The Guru

Label: Columbus Discount Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $5

Columbus has produced some interesting music in the last few years, and El Jesus de Magico is near the top of the class for me. Scalping the Guru has a fragmented, exploratory feel like the best Krautrock (Faust!) but without a retro effect. This is psychedelic rock music, but with Throbbing Gristle-like diversions into the dark static world; it's not noise-based, but rather a controlled form of chaos. The vocals are lazy, sung through the side of the mouth, and creating mood more than anything ('Summer of Luhv' reminds me of the Dead C, but if they were American). There's more to this than attitude and collage - 'Elohim City' closes out on a jangly jam and attains a true beauty. As a representative of the past few years of underground midwest Rock, this is a fantastic example. [8 November 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Nudge Squidfish - 20,000 Leagues Under Nashville

Label: Columbus Discount Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $5

Columbus Discount has released so much interesting music over the past few years that I really have come to see Ohio as the hotbed of America's great musical underground. This actually comes mostly from Nashville, and it's a reissue of Al Martin's home-recorded material from the mid-1980s. On the surface this is fun, goofy home-recorded psych-pop, reminding me structurally of early Sebadoh (The Freed Man, especially) but without any of the somber parts. There's outright jokes, like singing about banging the girls from Gilligan's Island, but then there's also brilliant, dark psych like 'City of Sorrow' and perect pop like 'Goodbye Princess' and 'Wonder Where You've Been'. This features a lot of the names associated with that scene - Thomas Jay Jones, Jim Shepard - and makes a lot of sense to reissue now, alongside the contemporary psych soundworlds. This also reminds me a bit of the Martin Newell reissue, not becuase the songwriting is similar but the production is identical. [20 December 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Blank Realm - Deja What?

Label: Bedroom Suck Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $7.5

Blank Realm are from Brisbane, I think, and play a lo-fi, noisy style that was somewhat in my radar two years ago. I wish I could have found people like this in my two visits to Brisbane, because it didn't seem like anyone was doing things like this - though I'm sure Joel Stern knew 'em. The best track is a long, repetitive jam on side one that stays crisp with the rhythm guitar, yelping vocals, and more colourful keyboards on top. This isn't half as amateurish as it sounds, but totally fun and delicately constructed to sound casual. There are some great spacey guitar jams, recalling the murky impressionism of great Kiwi music but with a somewhat more 'fun' feel. I should see what they've been up to, if they are still even active. [28 September 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Martin Newell - Songs For A Fallow Land

Label: Fixed Identity

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $12.8

Martin Newell's solo classic has been reissued here on vinyl, and the wax makes the lo-fi cassette hiss sound extra good. These songs really fit into 80's British pop despite their bedroom production standards. A few, like 'Julie Profumo', have become classics. This sounds rougher, but more intimate, when compared to Cleaners from Venus material - songs like 'Golden Lane' and 'Gamma Ray Blue' are drenched in a retro amateurism, that warmth I feel from British 80s artists like Felt and the Durutti Column, even if the sound is a bit different. Chorus pedal galore, or maybe it's just the tape's wow and flutter, but it's a great set of songs to have on vinyl. [2 November 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Fraction - Moon Blood

Label: Phoenix Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $20.4

This is one of the undisputed kings of hard-edged privately pressed psychedelic music, and thankfully Phoenix made it available for less than $1000 - while keeping the awesome diakuva-style cover. I think The Acid Archives calls the second and third tracks something hyperbolic, like the most powerful two tracks in rock music history or something like that -- but it's not that much of a stretch. I mean, 'Come Out Of Her' and 'Eye of the Hurricane' are absolutely devastating, and I say this as someone who isn't even that into heavy, slow rock. The second side begins with the singer sounding a little bit like 90s alternarocker style vocalists, but it doesn't bother me at all. Though like Collective Soul, Fraction were Christians. This should be a cornerstone of our understanding of rock music. [23 August 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Richard Youngs - Advent

Label: Jagjaguwar

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $6

Jagjaguwar reissued Advent which makes this a title I own on both CD and vinyl. I guess I can toss the CD now cause I can't see any reason why I would want to hold onto it after having this. Advent is one of Youngs's masterpieces, and one of the earliest works I heard by him. It's a simple concept - a song on vocals on piano that is transformed through three iterations, adding clarinet and electric guitar. As a minimalist statement it's unlike anything else he's ever done, even the rolling Sapphie, the expansive Knish or the fluid Asthma and Diabetes. This is not mere repetition, but extension through iteration. The simple piano figure, which is probably just a loop, drills into my brain and creates a contrast to the stretching, sinewy clarinets and the psychedelic heavyness of the guitars. Side two is where the guitars come in, and it's a thundering masterpiece. Glad to have this; I should spin it more often! [6 May 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Gunter Hampel / Galaxie Dream Band - Angel

Label: Birth Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $25

These Gunter Hampel records are awesome, but I don't always remember which ones I have since they all have the same cover, listing ten possible releases on the back, with a stamp next to the one this is. Hooray for DIY economics though. Angel starts with a very slow, quiet drone before erupting into a flurry of sax, flute, clarinet, trumpet, and drums. But it's not an aggressive, cacophonous mix, instead sounding like swarms of (happy) birds. The percussion is light and dances, teasing, so the other musicians can respond. It's recorded live on the radio and therefore has a someone amateurish production - the low end is non-existent, though maybe it's just the pressing. Daniel Carter plays here, probably quite young as it's 1972. Then, it gets funky - or maybe I should say 'choppy' - the guitar starts to provide some upstream and there's a bit of grittyness injected. Side two is more composed sounding but has the same fluidity. A bit of wah on the guitar and we're off. Jeanne Lee's voice is there, but not abundant. Good use of vibes, too. [21 October 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Meredith Monk - Our Lady Of Late

Label: Minona Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $25

Despite being a Meredith Monk 'fan' I never heard this record, or really even knew of it.  This is a spare, intense record built around shrill drones and Monk's dominating voice.  There are 16 tracks and it's recorded with a chilling church-like ambience, at times unlistenably intense and minimal to the point of ridiculousness.  Some great, great vocal warblings here; this is a great one for late at night (which is when I listened to it) and for setting that unmistakeable mood. [6 Aug 2011]


Date: 1 August 2011

Crazy Backwards Alphabet - Crazy Backwards Alphabet

Label: SST Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $5

This is a hit and miss jam band, mostly built around the trio of Henry Kaiser, John "Drumbo" French, and Andy West. Kaiser's and West have a pretty good interplay - their rendition of Ayler's 'Ghosts' is spot-on - and the instrumental fuckery is pretty enjoyable. The vocalising by Michael Maksymenko on a few tracks is where I get lost - it takes on a boogie-soul vibe, and makes it hard to enjoy the musicianship which is otherwise excellent. It's a long session too, and I see why this ended up on SST cause it certainly is the kind of record I could see Greg Ginn grooving on. There's no anger whatsoever here; Crazy Backwards Alphabet doesn't have the sharp edge found on Massacre's first LP, for example. And while there's certainly a lot of transcendant passages, it's not enough to add up for the entire duration. [30 November 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Rice- Fuck You This Is Rice

Label: Lookout! Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $8.99

I never really understood if this band was a total joke or not, because it seems really intently serious. This is a concept album about rice, and it's executed very well - this is good hardcore music, touching on lots of subgenres circa 1994 (it's mostly faster, grindy stuff, but they can also slow down on metal-core tunes like 'Under Your Skin'). It's definitely a partial joke - the liner notes are funny, with silly quotes from punk rock luminaries like Kent McClard and Sam McPheeters, lyrics written out in all of their ridiculous glory, and other miscellany. But the music delivers - I don't listen to hardcore often, but this is pretty great, and holds up well since I last heard it (which was a dubbed cassette in the kitchen when I lived in the Peach Pitt, 1998).  [5 November 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

New Bad Things - Freewheel!

Label: Candy-Ass Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $6

I wonder how history will remember the New Bad Things. Most likely, they've already been forgotten. I think of this as total indie/twee party music, as fun is the bottom line. The songs are pretty catchy and occasionally anarchic, and captures that 90s spirit pretty well. There's extended instrumentation - horns, strings, etc but mostly it feels like it was recorded live or in one take, so the rough edges are the charm. 'I Suck' is the hit, and certainly the song I most remember them for, but there's other gems: 'Ephedrine', 'Josh Has  Crush on a Femme from Reed' and 'Product', to name a few. The Dream of the 90s in Portland begins here - actually, this is so iconic of a brief movement in indie music that it's a worthwhile historic document if nothing else. I don't think the New Bad Things other releases held a candle to this but all I can remember is that dub of Society I had kicking around in college. [19 September 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Gastr Del Sol - Mirror Repair

Label: Drag City

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $10

Gastr del Sol's only EP for Drag City is a bite-sized dose of what made the O'Rourke and Grubbs combo great. There's a bit of the "Grubbs sings stupid stuff, plucks guitar + O'Rourke subtly alters it" sound they employed so well on Crookt, Crackt or Fly, and there's also a bit of  Don Cab/Fucking Champs-style guitar hysteria in 'Dictionary of Handwriting, with John McEntire's crisp indierock drumming (I love this track but don't care for other bands that sound like this, but I'm biased). The lengthy 'Eight Corners' is maybe the masterpiece, built around a seemingly endless hall of mirrors (which the title of this record also suggests, even though the track 'Mirror Repair' seems to be about organised labour) created by a solo piano. Various bits of insanity come and go, giving fleeting glimpses of complexity and pluralism. [5 Aug 2012]


Date: 1 August 2011

Yo La Tengo - I Can Hear The Heart Beating As One

Label: Matador

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $20

No amount of money is too much to be able to finally listen to 'Deeper into Movies' on vinyl.


Date: 16 September 2011

Core Of The Coalman - Box Of The Last Help

Label: Zum

Format: CD

Source: Jorge Boehringer

Cost: €0

I really loved seeing Jorge play live and also enjoying playing with him in that surreal show we did together at Soodevahe. His recordings are likewise enjoyable, if you like thick, organic sound chunks built around strings. And I do! By opening with 'Inertia II', Core of the Coalman isn't fucking around - this staccato repetition would be best described as 'annoying' by the majority of listeners and I only like it for it's Steve Reich-esque tonal shifts, which are quite dramatic without being clichéd. The recording is quite dry which works well here, instead of being an easy reverb chamber. This pattern repeats as the much shorter 'Inertia I', which is maybe like a radio edit. It's an intense way to open a disc, which makes the second piece, 'Last Help', almost jarring when begins with a delicate guitar arpeggio. This uses a loop pedal for a similar repetitive sense as 'Inertia' but with a very different language. It recalls a lot of loop pedal guitar activities I've heard in recent years and thus isn't my preferred side of Jorge's music, but it's put together well and takes it's time to build steady overtones, resisting the urge to release. [24 December 2012]


Date: 16 September 2011

Core of the Coalman - Precambrian Figures

Label: Unverified Records

Format: CDr

Source: Jorge Boehringer

Cost: €0



Date: 18 October 2011

Archers Of Loaf - Icky Mettle

Label: Merge Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £15.39

It's so weird when records you loved in high school start getting reissues in 20-year anniversary editions.  Although, this one is only 18 years old.  And holy shit, does it sound awesome to my ears today.  Perhaps that's cause I live in a state of perpetual nostalgia, or maybe it's cause the label (my edition is on Fire) did a great remaster job.  Blue vinyl too .... the memorable hits are still as memorable - 'Web in Front' and 'Wrong' are certainly classics of the genre - but some of my fave Archers tunes are songs like 'Might' and especially 'You and Me'.  The bonus material is "digital only" which is a big 'who cares' for me, but yeah, really really glad to have this.  Price, like everything in this order, has extra costs factored in for shipping to Estonia. [18 Oct 2011]


Date: 18 October 2011

Art Museums - Dancing With A Hole In Your Heart

Label: Slumberland Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £8.69

After Rough Frame I was salivating for more Art Museums - even if it's not the most serious band, that album was probably my favourite record of 2010; it ticked all the right boxes with me. This single is more of the same formula, and 'Dancing With a Hole in Your Heart', in your bedroom, is clearly mined from the same post-adolescent headspace as so many of the great songs on the LP. But just by the nature of being a single, I don't have quite the same love of this, maybe because I rarely listen to it. All three songs are great though, and if we ever hear any more from this band it'll be a great day indeed. [21 December 2012]


Date: 18 October 2011

Vermillion Sands - 20 Hours

Label: Trouble In Mind

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £10.19

'20 Hours' has a nice descending riff over a high-energy chord progression, sung in that great Vermillion Sands sideways accent. 'The Last Day' is a bit noisier and downcast but has frantic drumming at just the right times. This is probably their strongest release since their first 7", though it seems they put out a full-length that I completely missed. [6 Aug 2012]


Date: 18 October 2011

Mountain Man - Made The Harbor

Label: Bella Union

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £21.49

The perhaps inaccurately-named Mountain Man are a trio of three female vocalists who perform original folk songs in the Americana vein, either a-capella or accompanied by the most minimal of acoustic guitar. I fell in love with this record because it stands out against all of the neo-folk things I usually hear, being based around simple cadences, incredibly evocative lyrics, and a stripped-down feel that understands it's space. As compared to the 10", the songs here are bathed in natural reverb, as I imagine this being recorded inside a large barn with just two really good microphones. The harmonies are pure ear candy, but it's more than just beautiful - they shift throughout parts of the same song, often creating the effect you'd get from medieval music ('Babylon', with biblical lyrics, could have been musically created in the 1400s). The overall effect still feels simplistic, but it's actually hiding much more complexity. Some of the lyrics have wedged themselves into my head by now, and there's a couple of incredible, incredible tunes. Plus the lone cover, 'How Am I Doing', is just stunning. I can't wait for their next release. [5 Aug 2012]


Date: 18 October 2011

Mountain Man - Sun Dog

Label: Underwater Peoples Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £20.39

Different versions of 5 songs from the album, but on a 10" of their own and really beautiful with it's turquoise marble vinyl. These songs are great at 45rpm, which seems to enhance the harmonies, thick and chilling as they are floating through the air. Glad to have this, because how many times can I listen to the LP? (Well, lots). [5 Aug 2012]


Date: 18 October 2011

V/A - To Scratch Your Heart: Early Recordings From Istanbul

Label: Honest Jon's Records

Format: Vinyl /Box Set

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £32.79



Date: 18 October 2011

Tindersticks - The First Tindersticks Album

Label: Plain Recordings

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £31.79

Fuck, this first Tindersticks album ended up costing a lot with the shipping and everything. It is a beautiful double vinyl gatefold reissue, and I guess this is the reality of how much records cost now. The Tindersticks reputation rests mostly on these first two albums, which take an emotional, dramatic twist on British indie music, with something maudlin and theatrical added. The second album has more of the dour Gothic moods, while this one has some great jangly guitar-pop, such as 'Blood' or 'Patchwork'. Some really powerful stuff here, like 'Tie-Dye' - Tindersticks are masters of slowing things down just enough to let Staples' voice hang in the air, and an organ or string line to give it some extra gravitas. Other songs are so simple you can imagine them rehearsing in a garage, influenced by the C86 comp and naively picking out some guitar arpeggios - 'Piano Song' is so simplistic that you don't notice there isn't even any piano in it. [25 November 2012]


Date: 18 October 2011

Tindersticks - Tindersticks

Label: Plain Recordings

Format: Vinyl

Source: Norman Records

Cost: £31.79

Tindersticks' second album is the first one I heard, back in college, and I've had the CD for years. But who can pass up a luxurious vinyl reissue? This doesn't have a gatefold cover but nice, thick wax and by having so few songs per side (only 3 or 4) it actually feels like an even more monumental achievement than it actually is. There's so many classics here, all occupying this bizarrely British/Euro romanticism. Heavy handed? Yeah, 'My Sister' may seem that way, and the theatrical nature of these songs is laid on thick, far thicker than the first album, but can one deny the power of 'Cherry Blossoms'? The duets with the female vocalist are really lovely - 'Traveling Light' is not a million miles from boozy Mekons melancholia from the mid-80s - and the strings are played with the perfect mix of vibrato and drama. (Why are strings always 'arranged' and not just played?) [24 August 2012]


Date: 26 October 2011

His Name Is Alive - Detrola

Label: Silver Mountain Media Group

Format: CD

Source: eBay.co.uk

Cost: £3.91

How do I begin to talk about my relationship to His Name is Alive? Certainly they rank in my 5 favourite artists ever, if you held a gun to my head, but luckily the world of art and media is rich enough that no one has to make these choices. I first fell in love with them in 1998 when I moved out of my parents' house into Pittsburgh infamous punk rock house, the Peach Pitt, for just a few weeks (just housesitting for a friend and future roommate). One of my roommates, John C. Huha, was for some reason a huge HNIA fan and would listen to Stars on ESP a lot when he was in the (filthy, disgusting) kitchen cooking his vegan food. I remember coming down one day on my way to work at the public library and hearing the gospel ending of that album and asked him "What the hell is this?". "His Name is Alive, dude!" and he ejected the tape and tossed it at me. I put it in my Walkman, walked to work, and by the time I arrived 15 minutes later I was a changed man. As I subsequently investigated the career of Warn Defever I became more and more fascinated by his approach to music, which skirted over genres, was intensely personal, and actually built a mythology. As he fell from favour with the 4AD crowd, I've stuck with him, within reason. After Stars on ESP came the might Ft. Lake, and together those are my two favourite releases, but then he went R&B which I didn't like at the time (but now do) and then back towards pop and here, with Detrola, somewhat towards a more electo-dance type of pop. I've grown to like this record lots, and it's actually the last one I have (though I've heard and enjoy Xmmer) and think it's just the next logical step if you understand this man's strange musical progress. Which harkens back to Livonia's Cocteau clouds and through the Beach Boys obsession, through the solo I Want To Live for 100 Years Americana-trip, through the R&B and then back to some amalgamation of it all.
