There's always been something extremely sentimental in Warn's work, ever since day 1, but songs like 'Mama, Don't You Think I Know' feel extra packed with his own life story.  'Summer Left Your Heart Behind' is as perfect as anything on Stars on ESP or Last Night; and this may sound crazy but I feel a real Billy Joel influence on this record. And then 'I'll Send My Face To Your Funeral' comes along, with Warn harmonizing, and it's like we're back in the I Want to Live 100 Years smoke and magic. I guess I'm just hooked my Mr. Defever, deeply in my core. How else can I explain why I am still listening constantly to 'I Can't Live at Home In This World Anymore' 14 years later? [24 December 2012]


Date: 15 November 2011

Damon & Naomi - More Sad Hits

Label: 20|20|20

Format: Vinyl

Source: 15.99

Cost: £0

Back in college I had listened to this a few times when I got into Galaxie 500 (this coinciding with the active Land days and lots of hanging out with Agents Ferdinand and Wichmann); but I forgot about it for many years.  I recently listened to the D&N with Ghost CD for my record blog and in the process decided to download this and listen again.  I fell in love with More Sad Hits which I always liked but now have really grown to love, so an ebay vinyl find was required.  This reissue has great liner notes about how they wrote this attempting to deal with their bitterness over the Galaxie 500 breakup, and that Kramer really encouraged them throughout.  He actually plays many of the guitars and organs on it, and even sequenced it in such a brilliant manner, that it's almost as much his album.  The reissue sounds great, the songs are better than almost anything, and I think I like this better than even anything by Galaxie 500 now.  [15 November 2011]


Date: 15 November 2011

John Davis - Leave Home

Label: Communion Label

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £12.57

I went on a mild John Davis kick last year and eBayed this, which I actually bought on CD in my high school days (during the Folk Implosion time, of couse) and then sold in disgust at the time. I didn't know how to handle his fey, minimalist/impressionistic songwriting and I didn't find anything to click with until his masterful Blue Mountains came out in '97. But on a revisit, Leave Home is almost as great. It's almost too easy to call this minimal or sketch-based, and not completely fair because that suggests that his songs are unfinished or sloppy. Davis is certainly not a polished musician or songwriter, but as an artist he nails something - a feeling of awe, a complicated innocence, and something actually primal, to employ and overused rock-cliché. A lot of these songs are based around a guitar riff or drum part that seems to be pulled from the essence of great rock anthems - like distilling the feeling of rock impulse into just one repetitive thrust -- but then without being cerebral about it. It's not for everyone, but it's definitely for me, even if it took me 15 years to figure that out. [20 November 2012]


Date: 15 November 2011

Ken Lauber - Contemplation (View)

Label: Dynamic 

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £14.95

McDowell raved about this and i couldn't find a download anywhere, so I just bought this, a lovely thick vinyl reissue on the Dynamic label.  I expected a lone singer-songwriter freak record, but this is a fleshed out, slightly rocking country band.  The production is awesome - just from the first drop of the stylus, it has that early Burrito Bros feel.  Lauber has a great voice but it's not overdone; the band fleshed things out with piano, and a loose enough rhythm section to let the songs breathe.  This is going to be a slow grower, but I think it will - although a bit short, I think 'Rainy Day Sunday' is going to be a classic for me.  Great moustache too.  [16 November 2011]


Date: 15 November 2011

Von Hemmling - 'J.W. Kellog' E.P.

Label: Shrat Field Recordings

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £13.38

I like to think of myself as one of the world's biggest Jim McIntyre fans, though I haven't talked to him since I left Lexington and I wonder where he has gone. This is a strange one-sided 12" of Von Hemmling's oddball, deconstructed rock songs. Some are low-key, like 'Heads Up, Tin Man'; others are more experimentally structured, like 'Charlie Hustle'. 'For the 5th Time in 4 Years' is a sound collage built from radio signals, and it's a beautiful turning point in the middle of the record. Jim has such a sparse discography but he's one of music's true weirdos, who will never be recognised as such. [29 November 2012]


Date: 15 November 2011

Amon Düül II - Yeti

Label: Liberty

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay

Cost: £29.99

I know this Amon Düül II record less than Phallus Dei or Dance of the Lemmings or even Wolf City just because I never had a copy until recently. It's remarkably consistent, never getting tiresome over two LPs, including the last LP being mostly a big long jam. The first LP is basically a great classic rock album, with awesome guitar riffs and hooks, and even that song with the robot voice, I think 'Eye-Shaking King' is completely epic. The third side extends from the end of the second and bleeds into the fourth, being the aforementioned jam. As jams go, it sounds quite composed actually - it's stays in rock territory, leaving the super free territory for other Kraut explorers. I dig the presence of female vocals - on 'Sandoz in the Rain' and 'Archangel Thunderbird' especially. There's a mood that is completely apocalyptic here - Lemmings comes off as relatively restrained and mature - and this dark magic is what makes this possibly their masterpiece. [23 July 2012]


Date: 24 November 2011

Throwing Muses - House Tornado

Label: 4AD

Format: Vinyl

Source: Black and White records, Hakaniemi, Helsinki

Cost: €15

Last year I briefly dated someone whose favourite band was Throwing Muses and I decided, in that open-minded mentality that happens when you're dating, to finally check them out. For whatever reason, they're a band that I never listened to but never had any feelings for, or against. They were just a neutral entity. After listening to their first and allegedly best album a lot, and then purchasing this, allegedly their second best, I can say that I "like" Throwing Muses, but I feel no real passion for them. I've listened to this album 3 or 4 times but nothing jumps out at me, yet it's all sort of excellent in a mediocre way, if that makes any sense. The songwriting is actually pretty great and not like anything I can easily compare it to, yet I know I'll never have the time or investment to really get super into it. The sound of this band - the acoustic strum with 80s indie rock rhythms, and smart, edgy female vocals - is pretty awesome and I can totally understand the appeal. [26 July 2012]


Date: 24 November 2011

Rip Rig & Panic - I Am Cold

Label: Virgin

Format: Vinyl

Source: Black and White records, Hakaniemi, Helsinki

Cost: €15

I'm a Rip, Rig and Panic fan, always preferring them to the Pop Group or other funky-dance punk experimentalists of the era. I'm not much of a dance type myself but when I do want to feel rhythms take over, I like it when it's built on top of extreme chaos, a dayglo panopticon of musical images, and enough jazz influence (my god, the piano playing!) to create unique flavours. This might be their best record, a double EP at 45rpm so it sounds loud and bassy, just like Metal Box isn't for me (since I only have it as Second Edition, 33 1/3 rpm). There's some singles on here like 'Storm the Reality Asylum', a totally good tune, but the more exuberant explorations are really where it sings. 'Take a Don Key to Mystery'  features Uncle Don Cherry , and his presence is always welcome. His voice and trumpet playing make me think of where I left off with him - the time of Brown Rice, 7 years earlier - and how Rip, Rig and Panic is the next logical choice for him. That track takes the chaos of the 1980s and brings his philosophy to it, and it's a happy merger, with the hands in the cookie jars as they say. The few slower and more somber tracks, such as 'Subversive Wisdom', are also very welcome -- they prevent the record from becoming a massive blur. I've purchased so few records from Helsinki record stores but this was a very very nice find. [19 December 2012]


Date: 28 November 2011

Lori Felker - Light Makes Music

Label: Southbridge 

Format: 7"

Source: Lori Felker

Cost: €0

Lori's a filmmaker but she's crossed into sound recordings successfully here. This is performed on a projector, using film as source material but manipulated I imagine in a very hands-on, active way. I'm not sure how much this was improvised and how much was done with editing later - I guess not at all. There's speech and music from whatever film the source material was, as well as the smashed distortion of wrong-speed (or manual?) film soundtracks. The 7" is a good format for this; I'd like to hear more from Lori. [31 December 2012]


Date: 11 December 2011

Thomas Buckner / Edyta Fil / Ilia Belorukov / Alexey Lapin / Juho Laitinen - Bewitched Concert

Label: Intonema

Format: CD

Source: Ilia Belorukov

Cost: €0



Date: 13 January 2012

Paal Nilssen-Love / Ken Vandermark - Chicago Volume

Label: Smalltown Superjazz

Format: CD

Source: SAIC arts management programme

Cost: €0



Date: 18 January 2012

Souled American - Flubber

Label: Rough Trade

Format: Vinyl

Source: eBay.co.uk

Cost: £14.19

I think Flubber is my fave Souled Am album, and one that took me a surprisingly long time to find on eBay.  This is a nice clean edition on Rough Trade UK and it sounds great.  Side one of this record is such a tour de force; the movement from the slow 'Wind to Dry' into the amazing 'Drop in the Basket' is a powerful effect.  Actually the latter tune is probably my favourite Souled American song, as it's so deconstructed and experimental while still maintain it's evocative, dry pain.  I can't really say I've ever heard a track that is quite in the same genre of "experimental country" except for maybe Henry Flynt, but Souled Am mine a different side of their avant tendencies, sounding a bit like Beefheart crossed with the VU's 'Murder Mystery' crossed with Hank Williams.  And the Beefheartisms are a natural fit for that punchy Bass VI sound.  On the flipside are more awesomes songs, especially 'Over the Hill' which practically melts under its own fragility.  I just need Sonny now to complete the quartet. [19 Jan 2012]


Date: 5 March 2012

Ø + YN - He Resucitado En La Montana

Label: Winebox Press

Format: Cassette

Source: Jon Collin

Cost: €3.33



Date: 5 March 2012

Serfs - Mr. Railroad Man / Good Morning

Label: Poot

Format: CDr

Source: Jon Collin

Cost: €3.34



Date: 5 March 2012

Vampire Blues - Sub-Terra Maching Band

Label: Winebox press

Format: cassette

Source: Jon Collin

Cost: €3.33

Jon Collin's Winebox releases are so insanely beautiful, being made out of hand-carved wood, and this is no exception. The Vampire Blues recordings on here, live in Glasgow and Edinburgh, are really different than the deep blues-psych they did in Tallinn. Side 1 begins quietly, with some hazy drone and quiet plinking sounds that gradually ascends but then sets the weight back down instead of lifting off. Plucked acoustic strings, scrapings, and other halfhearted measures are backed by a thickening harmonium part, and it feels intensely casual. Incredibly fidelity too, for a live recording and a cassette.The B-sides begins with Collin's noodly, evocative electric guitar and the tone is fantastic. It floats slowly around a searing, hovering centre that slowly oscillates towards disorder. But it's an inviting, supportive disorder with rich waves of harmonium and wah-wah. [20 August 2012]


Date: 5 March 2012

Beets - Spit In The Face Of People Who Don't Want To Be Cool

Label: Captured Tracks

Format: Vinyl

Source: Rahva Raamatud, Viru Keskus, Tallinn

Cost: €15.91

A friend of mine became slightly obsessed with this record, saying it grabbed him by surprise and was the most charming and wonderful thing he had heard in a long time.  I bit, and while it's definitely charming and fun, it never sunk it's teeth into me. This is self-consciously amateurish, overly juvenile (done with a wink and a nod yet with real honesty at the same time) and feels really of an era of rock music I was checking out from '07-'09, when I was looking to Terminal Boredom for recommendations of new artists. But the Beets lack the bile of a lot of other bands from that time and create a few musical images that are really wonderful. The slightly too-slow, 4/4, low-mixed vocal approach is monotonous but that's precisely the point; when they occasionally conjure a country twang (such as on  'I Wish I Knew') or a penetrating pop hook, I start to see why he loved this so much. [6 Decemeber 2012]


Date: 6 March 2012

Magnetic Fields - Get Lost

Label: Merge Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Rahva Raamatud, Viru Keskus, Tallinn

Cost: €16.55

My favourite Magnetic Fields record, and an overall favourite record of the 90s. Or wait, do I actually love Charm of the Highway Strip more? They're both amazing, but the weird thing about this one is that I grew to know it from a dub someone made me back when I worked at the Carnegie Library (circa 1997 or so) and they dubbed it with Side 2 starting things off, so to me , 'Famous' is the opening cut. But lo and behold, I finally get a proper copy of the record and discover that the album begins with 'With Whom To Dance', which seems crazy, perverse even! Whichever order it's in, it's great and timeless etc etc but it's kinda funny to recontextualise something that I thought I knew intimately. [13 July 2012]


Date: 6 March 2012

Magnetic Fields - The Charm Of The Highway Strip

Label: Merge Records

Format: Vinyl LP Reissue

Source: Rahva Raamatud, Viru Keskus, Tallinn

Cost: €16.55

I think of all the years I've wasted. The roads don't love you, and they still won't pretend to. But some nights, the neon gas gets free, and turns into walking dead like me. I'd like to come and comfort you, but I'd be blinded by the blue. Just make believe we're still in love. We come, unnoticed, at sundown - at the start of a blackout, we set bonfires all over town, and it's over by morning. But the straw that broke the camel's back was you. Time, measured in yellow dotted lines has passed you by. Now I have been closing all the shutters in the house; well, I know you'll be back when every tree is turning brown. You'll find the house is empty and the swingset's fallen down. So I stay so long in a place and then move on to the next town. Fifteen years of loving this album.... [30 July 2012] 


Date: 27 March 2012

Spooky Tooth / Pierre Henry - Ceremony: An Electronic Mass

Label: Island Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Art Rock/Oskar, PoznÃ¡n, Poland

Cost: zl99

I've always wanted this freaky aberration, a Catholic mass of sorts by Spooky Tooth (who I've never particularly cared for) with Pierre Henry as special guest. There's some slow, organ-led songs with wailing vocals, not overly religious (in general this is less churchy than the Electric Prunes mass LP) and a great vibe. But it's really what Henry adds that makes this so great. There's tape manipulations throughout, sometimes just low gurgling that sounds pre-digital skipping; sometimes more overt fuckery. The coda to the second track is awesome - completely whacked out vocal repetitions, with a juxtaposition of this over a moody, emotional rock song. The folky, heavily dramatic 'Our Father' prayer is actually pretty cool too, cause of Henry's sweeping ghost sounds overtop. By the end it starts to drag up some Catholic dust that I was hoping to repress, so I have to take this off (and maybe throw on my Venom record instead). How appropriate is it, that I bought this in super-Catholic Poland? You are what you are, and I'm flashing back to Sister Roseanne's 5th grade religion class here. [8 October 2012]


Date: 27 March 2012

Van Morrison - Veedon Fleece

Label: Warner Bros. Records / Warner Bros. Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Art Rock/Oskar, PoznÃ¡n, Poland

Cost: zl55

This is the last Van Morrison record I'm familiar with, but I love it. It's much more on the folk-soul tip than the rock-soul, and there's a loose, airy feel to most of it. The really elegant, flowing tracks like 'Linden Arden Stole the Highlights' and 'Country Fair' are amazing; the more romantic ones have their charm as well. When he gets the swing on, like 'Streets of Arklow', there something undeniabe in the groove. With more listening time dedicated it could probably emerge on the same level as Astral or definitely St. Dominic's Preview. Bonus points for the bizarre cover. Where next? [18 November 2012]


Date: 27 March 2012

Vangelis - L'Apocalypse Des Animaux

Label: Polydor

Format: Vinyl

Source: Art Rock/Oskar, PoznÃ¡n, Poland

Cost: zl39

This is a film soundtrack by Vangelis that I bought on a whim cause the cover looked good. And, it's pretty rad! The more newagey Popul Vuh-sounding stuff is mostly on side two; side one has a few short instrumentals, with some nice electric piano. Wow, Vangelis is really good, or at least during this era. There are some tiny, searing resonating tones in the distances of the more ambient tracks which are as graceful as my favourite Stars of the Lid tracks; the only real criticism I have is that there isn't very much apocalypse to hear. [18 December 2012]


Date: 27 March 2012

Brainticket - Cottonwoodhill

Label: Lilith / Lilith

Format: Vinyl /CD

Source: Art Rock/Oskar, PoznÃ¡n, Poland

Cost: zl67

I bought Cottonwoodhill on CD during my Krautrock exploration phase, circa 1998/99, and eventually sold it or lost it or gave it away. I always thought this record was just a novelty, and it was too funny and far out to really enjoy. But time weathers attitudes and when I saw a nice vinyl reissue (with a bonus CD version) I had to grab it. This week in Poland, John and I had a blast listening to "the song" over and over. Because while there's some decent enough prog-jam explorations here, it's really the endless orgasmic loop/chant/freakout that defines Cottonwoodhill. It really became an inside joke between us, and we've even proposed setting up events around this album. "The song", which is actually called 'Brainticket', is split over both sides and I'm glad to hear it in 180gram goodness. And as a fan of crazy psychedelic explorations, this is about as extreme as it gets, so welcome to my shelves again, Brainticket. [19 December 2012]


Date: 27 March 2012

Roy Harper - Born In Captivity

Label: Awareness Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Art Rock/Oskar, PoznÃ¡n, Poland

Cost: zl55

I've never ventured into 1980's Roy Harper but know it to be a hit and miss venture. This is supposedly one of the hits, the album of demo versions of songs that later got overly produced for Work of Heart. The more stripped-down demos are still very produced for my tastes - rich, ringing electric guitar strums, percussion in the background, and multi-tracked vocals with lots of reverb (or some sort of effect). The songwriting is pretty OK though. 'No Woman is Safe' is a masterfully dark tune, and the long suite of songs making up 'Work of Heart' is not unlike 'McGoohan's Blues' and other great Harper songs of the past. I probably won't pull this out much, because as much as I like the minimal Harper guitar/voice combination, the clangy sound of the guitar and the similarity of the arrangements starts to grate on me after awhile, not really showcasing the elegant songwriting tricks I like about him (such as when things slow down and get more spacious). But still, not a bad find and the songs could certainly grow on me with further study. [19 December 2012]


Date: 4 April 2012

Kenneth B. Higney - Attic Demonstration

Label: One Kind Favor

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: €0

Thanks David and Heather! Here's one more to cross of my list of 'repress dreams'. Higney's record is legendary for being fucked-up, off-key, and desolate. Well, yeah. Higney recorded these with him singing as demos, basically, and sent this around to demonstrate his songwriting talents. It was never re-recorded, thank god, and thus we are left with gems like 'Cant Love That Woman' and 'Children of Sound', built around go-nowhere guitar strums and one-measure adrenaline rushes. Like all great painful records, Attic Demonstration is tortured but masquerades the misery behind attempted universalising; more commercial stabs, got entirely wrong, and of course the amateur psychedelic production techniques help. On the more rockin' songs, Kenneth sometimes get this manic edge to his voice; the slower ones all sort of sound the same, but I like to think of it as one long piece with many movements. The reissue sounds as good as possible, and comes with liner notes written by Mr. Higney himself who sounds fairly well-adjusted these days. [26 December 2012]


Date: 4 April 2012

Garbage & The Flowers - Stoned Rehearsal

Label: Quemada Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Volcanic Tongue

Cost: €0

Thanks, David and Heather! Stoned Rehearsal is exactly that - a rough, one-mic recording of the beautiful mess that is the Garbage and the Flowers, stumbling through some smoky vision in the 90s. A rehearsal it really is - there are starts and stops, retakes, the sounds of dogs barking in the distance, tuning up, etc. There's a lyric sheet presented which is laid out nicely, and allows one to follow the wordy 'Henry, Where is Lyon?'. This is a story, unfolding over a long repetitive chord progression, and I wish a studio version of this existed because it's an incredible song. As I may never find a vinyl copy of Eyes Rind I'll have to make do with this as the lone G&F wax to have. [21 December 2012]


Date: 5 April 2012

Dream Syndicate - Medicine Show

Label: A&M Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Shopper, Kopli tn, Tallinn

Cost: €3

I've passed on this LP for years and years, but when I found it here in Tallinn I figured 'what the hell'. This is a big departure from the first EP and album, with Steve Wynn taking command in a much more Americana/Neil Young style. There's some good rock and roll for sure - 'Bullet with My Name On It' has a brilliantly precise Crazy Horse rhythm section, but some of the lyrics are too clich?d and lame, and there's not enough Karl Precoda except on 'John Coltrane Stereo Blues', the album standout, which makes side 2 a much more fun trip. Kendra Smith left before this and I would have never thought she made so much of a difference, particularly as the replacement bassist has such a similar style (as the title track indicated) but, yeah, it's just lacking something though not bad at all. [14 May 2012]


Date: 5 April 2012

Pell Mell - The Bumper Crop

Label: SST Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Shopper, Kopli tn, Tallinn

Cost: €4

I think I used to own this on cassette too.


Date: 5 April 2012

Bela Bartok - Divertimento for String Orchestra

Label: BCA

Format: LP

Source: Shopper, Kopli tn, Tallinn

Cost: €1

discogs.com really fails me when it comes to Bulgarian pressings of classical LPs.


Date: 14 May 2012

Ghédalia TazartÃ¨s - Works 1977-79

Label: Vinyl-on-demand

Format: Vinyl /Vinyl /DVD /Box Set

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €79.99



Date: 14 May 2012

Aspec(t) - Waspnest

Label: Toxo Records / Viande / Fratto9 Under The Sky Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €12.99

Aspec(t) played a show here in April with a filmmaker called 70fps in the band, who accentuated their electroacoustic improv with sound generated from 16mm film loops. This LP doesn't feature him, but it's all there is on vinyl so I'll take it. I was blown away by Aspec(t) live because they illustrated the joy that can come from working with reel-to-reels, old analogue equipment, and acoustic things as well -- I was reminded of the rush I felt from the earliest Lied Music sessions with Luke, except they're a million times better than we ever were. The record, which I assume is drawn from improvised sessions, mixes between extremely intricate, delicate interactions and spazzy noise bursts. The more restrained side wasn't present in the live show, and fair enough - the energy they had was honestly something I've rarely ever seen before in this type of music. So having something on vinyl for more 'deep listening' is nice, although the visual element of the live experience was a big part of what I enjoyed (something else I can't say too often). I realise that this is supposed to be about the record and I keep talking about how great the live show was, without saying anything about the record, but when listening, it's really the only thing that I can think about. [7 Aug 2012]


Date: 14 May 2012

Suzanne Ciani - Lixiviation Ciani/Musica Inc. 1969-1985

Label: Finders Keepers Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €15.99

This is a compilation of music from Suzanne Ciani, which I bought basically on a whim because Finders Keepers usually issues pretty interesting things, and this is no exception. Ciani is an experimental electronic composer who did a lot of commercial work, so this collection really spans a lot of territory. There's some insanely psychedelic, spacy synthesizers (though in the lengthy liner notes, she explains that she doesn't really like the term) and some more outsider scratchings, which are pure experiments. There's also some more structured, composed work with vocals that were made for documentaries and/or TV. It sounds nice, and will provide some real worlds to explore on further listens, so I'm happy to have picked this up. [14 May 2012]


Date: 14 May 2012

Angst Hase Pfeffer Nase - Seashard

Label: Senufo Editions

Format: Vinyl

Source: Soundohm

Cost: €15.99

The latest Angst Hase LP doesn't disappoint; packaged in monochrome artwork and on white vinyl, this seems to influence my perception of it as a black and white type of record. That doesn't mean the sounds aren't diverse and lively, though, as there's a nonstop momentum from the moment the stylus hits the vinyl. Little jittery sound clicks and more layered drones make this sound, from my words, like a lot of other things, but there's something bonkers about his approach. As insanely processed as this is - some of these edits are impossible to do without a computer, and I'm sure the whole thing is digitally assembled - it doesn't feel like your typical electronica/experimental creation. Maybe it's the inherent woodyness of these sounds - even when they are synthesized, they recall some old, distant memory. Great popping sounds on side 2 also; one of my fave pickups this year. [29 November 2012]


Date: 11 June 2012

Nocht The Only Ghouls - Nocht The Only Ghouls

Label: Vwyrd Wurd

Format: Vinyl

Source: Vwyrd Wurd mailorder

Cost: $20.5

Hooray for Vwyrd Wurd, purveyors of very bizarre sounds from, of all places, Kutztown, PA! Nocht the Only Ghouls is bare, a gestural project that I would best describe as 'acoustic haze'. This is actually electroacoustic music as it's most indistinguishable (between the electric and the acoustic); some tracks are content to poke out a loose guitar arpeggio and let the air tell the story. Others have distinctly digital processing, almost comically so, yet somehow it mixes well. It's 45rpm on red vinyl but it doesn't feel short; there's enough ideas sketched out here to be as satisfying as a full album. Some of the playing is ridiculously primitive, but it's presented as full pieces and there's a beauty to the strangeness. One of my favourite records of the year, for sure. [22 August 2012]


Date: 11 June 2012

Daywand - Temporary Sanctuary

Label: Vwyrd Word

Format: LP

Source: Vwyrd Word mailorder

Cost: $20.5

Spelling the name of this label seems impossible but they are changing it too - it's Wvyrd Wird on the label of the Daywand LP. I love the Nocht the Only Ghouls record which is extremely odd and hard to situate. Daywand is a little more together, and much thicker in orchestration. It feels a bit like something from the Not Not Fun or Shdwply labels - mostly instrumental jams, dirty in production, with weird, often conflicting layers. There's programmed drums, keyboards, and electronic noise ('Drip Daze' sounds like it has that cheapo sampler I used to have where you rubbed your finger to 'scratch') but some guitar playing as well, occasionally very delicately placed (though it sounds like they might try carefully to make this sound messy) . The singing is slow and mixed in quite well; I wonder what possible influences there are. The band name makes me want to sing it to the tune of the 'Dayman' song from It's Always Sunny but there's not really much resemblance musically. This music is largely the work of one person and it's an interesting window into what kinds of things happen in Kutztown, PA, and American underground music in general in 2012. [23 August 2012]


Date: 15 June 2012

Erkki Kurenniemi - Rules

Label: Ektro

Format: 2xLP

Source: dOCUMENTA bookshop

Cost: €21

This is a deluxe, beautiful vinyl issuing of Erkki Kurenniemi's classic recording, based around his two guiding principles/rules. The mastering on this is superb - Jari told me that 'On-Off', which is probably his most famous piece, has never actually been heard properly before because the dynamic range was clipped on all of the previously existing recordings of it. This isn't even a different recording, just a better mastering job and I must admit, it sounds great - a lot is going on between the dissonant shimmer and alien clanging that makes up the track. Things often sound better in mono, though. The latest recording on here is ''?Death 3' from 1975, but most recordings are from the 60's. It's overall a lovely collection and it was nice to pick up while in Kassel. [10 July 2012]


Date: 27 June 2012

Great Valley, The / Happy Jawbone Family Band - Permanent Christmas

Label: Feeding Tube Records / Spooky Town Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Feeding Tube Records

Cost: $0

Free 7" thrown in with my order, thanks! This is a Christmas single, with a fun bedroom garage rocker from The Great Valley and two slightly weirder tracks by the Happy Jawbone Family Band. The first is a rather perverse Xmas tune about having too much pent-up aggression and 'Martian Santa' is a good bit of fun. This has a great recording and feel to it, though it's weird listening to this in mid-July. [10 July 2012]


Date: 27 June 2012

Blanche Blanche Blanche - 2wice 2wins

Label: Feeding Tube Records

Format: 12"

Source: Feeding Tube Records

Cost: $25

Blanche Blanche Blanche put out about 4 or 5 albums this year so it's a bit much to take in, even though I find everything I've heard delightful. They've maintained different vibes throughout, with 2wice 2wins leaning more on their sequencer programming/synth heavy material. The songwriting still has that intimate familiarity, and though it's only half an album it's really strong. The songs here take on relationships and dating in a frank manner - 'That's OK' is a particularly brilliant/strange hybrid of close and far. Great etchings on the B-side, but it doesn't edge out Our Place as the BBB record to fall deeply in love with. [21 December 2012]


Date: 27 June 2012

Blanche Blanche Blanche - Our Place

Label: Feeding Tube Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Feeding Tube Records

Cost: $15

I've really been taken by Blanche Blanche Blanche and this record is certainly my favourite, as it's the most straight-forward and song-based. The hazy, murky synth assonance found on the other releases is cut through in favour of a clean, direct voice and keyboard approach. There are some nice guitar bits as well - weird, Residents-like solos that squirm around, but never distract. The songwriting is top-notch - and with 20 songs it's a lot to take in. The low-key, almost conversational singing style of the main vocalist is the charm of this band, and Our Place keeps to its title - a warm, inviting visit. [24 November 2012]


Date: 27 June 2012

Ambergris - Anti-Matter Alma Mater

Label: Feeding Tube Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Feeding Tube Records

Cost: €18

This is a pretty intense listen, definitely emerging from a playful art-school narrative world. 'Anti-Matter Alma Mater' is built around a story where someone goes through a wormhole on a ski lift, and it's done with narration, singing, and some more outro musical jams. I like quirky, goofball shit like this, but it starts to wear out its welcome before the end of the second half, ultimately reminding me of the kinda thing Juliacks would be into - which is not to say bad, but it means that I'll probably play this about as often as I listen to my Monotrona LP (which is about once every 8 years). [12 July 2012]


Date: 27 June 2012

Egg, Eggs - The Cleansing Power Of Fruit

Label: Feeding Tube Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Feeding Tube Records

Cost: $14

Egg, Eggs is a messy noise-rock band made up of some Western Mass luminaries - I recognise John Moloney from Sunburned in the lineup, as well as the guy that runs Feeding Tube. There's a lot of guitars, strained and distorted vocals, long jammy electronic bits, and just plain fucking around. The legacy of bands like Starship Beer is kept alive here, though I doubt it's an intentional influence - the wacked out singing, often several voices at once, lends an absurdity to the whole thing. As much as I want to listen deeply and really find the brilliant ideas in The Cleansing Power of Fruit, I end up getting distracted easily and tuning it out - and it sounds to me like the band was also in this state. [9 November 2012]


Date: 10 August 2012

Sindre Bjerga / Java Delle - split cassette

Label: TimTimTonTräger

Format: cassette

Source: Tim

Cost: €2.5



Date: 10 August 2012

Legion of Swine / Haender og Taender - split casette

Label: TimTimTonTräger

Format: cassette

Source: Tim

Cost: €2.5



Date: 10 August 2012

Don Vito/ Abraxas Apparatus - Untitled

Label: Tremor Panda / lo-fi/sci-fi records / TimTimTonTraeger

Format: Vinyl

Source: Tim

Cost: €5



Date: 10 August 2012

Das Elektrische Ich - N*Pi

Label: TimTimTonTraeger / Beachhead2Records

Format: CDr

Source: Tim

Cost: €0



Date: 10 August 2012

Interstellar Nightmare - Interstellar Nightmare

Label: lo-fi/sci-fi records / TimTimTonTraeger / Coccorola / Difficult 

Format: Vinyl

Source: Tim

Cost: €10



Date: 12 September 2012

Shep And Me - Cloudy Chowder

Label: Trd W/D

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, 3138 Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $8

This Shep and Me release is a bit bouncier than the other one - with a country-friend voice at times, some very nice banjo playing, and a jaunty rhythm throughout most. There's some more mellow moments, and a beautiful instrumental in the middle of side one. This was originally released as a cassette in 2007 so it's earlier than the other LP, and definitely recalls something a bit caricatured about Americana. I l like it anyway. [25 November 2012]


Date: 12 September 2012

V-3 - Evil Love Deeper

Label: Thrill Jockey

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Mind Cure Records, 3138 Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $18

So psyched to find this, which discogs.com credits to V-3 though I've always thought of it as a Jim Shepard solo album. There are all sorts of weird experiments at play here, but somehow it manages to be really direct despite being so indulgent. Maybe Mayo Thompson's Corky's Debt album is a good comparison, as that's simultaneously his most "accessible" and "weird" work at the same time. I don't know Shepard's catalogue as deep as I do Thompsons, but Evil Love Deeper has moments that resemble the bitter garage punk of Photograph Burns while also having moments of aborted tape experiments, electroacoustic dirges, and collages, just like the Vertical Slit LP I have. There's a spoken reminiscing about the Vertical Slit days - 'when we were 17 and we could barely tune our guitars' becomes his 'Me and Mike Watt just playing guitar', except it seems infused with a sadness the Minutemen stuff only took on after Boon's death; Shepard had yet to die at this point but is clearly headed that way. [27 November 2012]


Date: 12 September 2012

Axemen - Scary! Pt. III

Label: Siltbreeze

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, 3138 Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $5

It's nice to hear some more Axemen; Big Cheap Motel is great but not super representative. This double LP has lots more to offer and really spans a lot of different things. It's from '89 and it's not exactly genre-hopping, but it goes into a lot of different territory. 'Shacked Up in Yr Egypt Tomb' is so Royal Trux-like I thought it was a cover. 'The Virgin' I think is a Kim Fowley song or something, cause I've definitely heard it before. There is snarled, Crass-style punk songs, detuned tracks that sound like early Tuxedomoon, and a streak of irreverence throughout everything. It's diversity is its strength. Siltbreeze can keep these coming, cause I'm even more happy with this than the first one. [11 December 2012]


Date: 12 September 2012

Gary War - New Raytheonport

Label: SHDWPLY Records

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, 3138 Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $7

During Shadwply's brief run of being a label that I was interested in, this was pretty much the pinnacle of it. Actually I don't know what this label is doing but it's probably still releasing interesting music. Gary War's record is built around home-recorded rock/pop songs layered with cheap effects and whatever other tools were available to the home-psychedelicist in the mid-00s. This means a lot of lo-fi hiss, flanger, and phase effects as well as simple rhythm/drum tracks and chorus pedal galore. Some songs resemble Ariel Pink ('Healthy Living', in particular) who must be now be perceived as the leader of this sound, but Gary War has a more weird, distant atmosphere on his better tracks. The melting, elliptical 'Cyclops Eye' is a highlight as well as the album closer, 'Edge of Mess'. [19 December 2012]


Date: 12 September 2012

Cheveu - Cheveau

Label: Permanent Records

Format: Vinyl LP

Source: Mind Cure Records, 3138 Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $8

I was really taken by this band back in 2008 and scooped up everything  I could find; somehow I missed this second album, which is really a collection of outtakes. But there's some great stuff here, though nothing as powerful as the hits from Cheveu. The space-rock bits are a new direction, as it's impressive what these guys can do with rudimentary equipment in (presumably) their bedrooms. Overall this is somewhat more exploratory; there is weird underwater gurgling on 'PsyX', bursts of treated synth noise on 'Sacha', and much less focus on fast, punk-styled song structures. It's a different listening mode and a step towards the beautiful 1000, but not one that I will remember to play frequently. [25 November 2012]


Date: 12 September 2012

Moss Icon - Complete Discography

Label: Temporary Residence Limited

Format: Vinyl /Vinyl /All Media

Source: Mind Cure Records, 3138 Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $18

How delightful to see this issued on vinyl! Over 5 sides, the entirety of Moss Icon's brief, unheralded existence is presented, with minimal liner notes (partial lyrics and credits). Moss Icon were pretty interesting - their most obvious influence is probably Saccharine Trust, though without the jazz influence, except for parts of the second record ('Moth' and 'Memorial' in particular, where vocalist Jonathan Vance leaves the gruff post-hardcore voice behind entirely and we even get some acoustic guitar, strumming 7th chords). The first disc is their full-length album, a classic of transitional post-hardcore: punchy riffs, changing tempos, and that shitty late 80's solid-state production. Moss Icon's greatness lies in the conflict between Tonie Joy's guitar playing and Vance's bizarre stream-of-consciousness lyrics, the likes of which had never been seen in the punk rock world before. Drenched in equal parts Castaneda and collegiate philosophising, this acid-burned approach to punk was developed much further by the Gravity Records roster a few years later (a label which possibly took its name from a Moss Icon song?). Musically, it's smart; on 'Lyburnum Wit's End Liberation Fly' there's even a change-up that could be lifted straight from an R.E.M. record. I guess this is seen as early 'emo' now, or mid-period depending on where you draw the lines. [8 November 2012]


Date: 12 September 2012

Shep And Me - Nasturtium Inertia

Label: Mind Skull

Format: Vinyl

Source: Mind Cure Records, 3138 Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $0

Mike put out this record for Shep and Me, some sort of new outcast/weirdo artist who was based in Pittsburgh for a bit. These songs are distraught, desperate and distant; built around an acoustic ambience that is imprecise and wistful. Jandek's an obvious comparison but it's a lot less abrasive; the vocals are high-pitched and there's a sense of drifting that passes through it all. When necessary the oddball recording techniques add to the vibe; I suspect this is best experienced in totality rather than partially. I bought two by him cause I liked what I heard. [18 September 2012]


Date: 12 September 2012

Beaver & Krause - The Nonesuch Guide To Electronic Music

Label: Nonesuch

Format: Vinyl /Box Set

Source: Mind Cure Records, 3138 Dobson Street, Polish Hill, PIttsburgh, PA

Cost: $15



Date: 14 December 2012

Murmer - Framework 1 - 4

Label: Herbal International

Format: CD

Source: Patrick McGinley

Cost: €0

Patrick's new double CD is a mammoth exploration of field recording, editing, and resonance. The opening cut sounds like a tribute to the first cut of the Dead C's Tusk, with this rattling sound repeatedly appearing and disappearing, but I know he's never heard that, so here it's becomes a uniquely unfolding exploration of contrasts. 'Framework 2' has some subtle soft drones in the background but it never allows one to be too comfortable. Patrick is really meticulous in choosing which serendipities to accentuate; there are buzzings, wind, and rustling but they are left in situ, only to be showcased by adjusting what is around them. It descends into some French speaking and then throat-clearing or snoring or something of the sort. Very odd, and I like that. Disc two beings with 'Framework 3 [Swam]', which goes for 33 minute and the swarm is a warm, metallic resonance that moves nicely across the stereo field, with some friends of mine harmonising on minor intervals. Here's a case of duration adding to a work - because it can take its time, the environment takes over and humanity is pushed to the periphery; the sounds of civilisation are present, but equal to the treated layer that is the 'swarm' of the title. And then finally (after another lovely interlude), 'Framework 4 [Spaces]', which is pure acoustic space. There are creakings in the background over what sounds like Maryanne Amacher's non-inner ear work, and then an overwhelmingly up-front outdoor cricket symphony takes over - to compare this to yet another recording, Dwight Frissell's Natural Selection. I think one of the reasons I will compare this so many other things is because I know Patrick is reading this. It's lovely as well and then the epilogue comes, 'Irrigation Drain' which is just that - what I always cite when I want to make fun of sound art, but it is beautiful to listen to. Patrick also explains his motivations and techniques in liner notes which are honest, direct, and informative without destroying any mystery. I'm impressed at how well this is put together as a complete package - maybe this is his theatre/clown past at work, where the sense of a 'show' is evident -- something Ville remarked to me after his Kodu Baar gig last May. [24 December 2012]
